description: Part of our national tradition is the American Gothic buffet for large groups: roast turkey, baked ham with potato salad, pickles, relishes, assorted cakes and pies. Certainly nothing is wrong with such a menu save its utter predictability. But with a fraction more effort (and no more cost, the price of chicken being what it is), it is possible to reach for elegance. Chicken in champagneperhaps white winesauce, for example. With rice and mushrooms, this menu could serve as many as three dozen guests and neatly dispel the American Gothic image at the same time.

title: Venice Faces Power Cutoff
description: VENICE, Italy, Feb. 1 (AP) Venice was told this week to pay its twoyearold $1.7million electricity bill or have its power cut off. The ultimatum came from the state electricity monopoly, which is having trouble paying its own bills. Venice, like many other Italian cities, is in financial trouble. Its debts last year totaled more than $160million.

title: Kenny Rankin Show Draws the Faithful To the Bottom Line
description: Kenny Rankin, who is appearing at the Bottom Line through tonight, is performing with impressive confidence these days, and his fans, who filled the club for both shows on Friday night, are responding with a mixture of solemnal respect (shushing the noisy, actually articulating bravo's at the end of each song) normally reserved for the likes of a FischerDieskau.

title: Maryland Stops N. C. State With Goal in Final Seconds
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 1  Brad Davis, a freshman, sank an 8foot shot with two seconds remaining today to give Maryland a 9897 victory over North Carolina State, the current National Collegiate basketball champion, and snap the Wolfpack's home victory string in Reynolds Coliseum at 36.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: U.S. and Soviet Negotiators Hold TwoHour Arms Talk
description: GENEVA, Feb, 1 (Reuters) Soviet and American negotiators met for two hours here today to start work on a new agreement limiting their offensive nuclear weapons for the next 10 years.

title: Survey Finds Public About Evenly Split On Economic Goals
description: The American public is almost evenly divided as to whether curbing inflation or reducing unemployment is the more inmortant goal at present, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: Editors Choice
description: Fiction

title: The Lure of the Black Sea Resort
description: THERE was a time, not long ago, when American tourists looked at a map of Europe and saw nothing between Germany and Greece. The Communist nations of Eastern Europe were unthinkable destinations, and the Communists themselves did little to alter that view.

title: Stabilized Buildings Seek Hardship Rent Increases
description: The Conciliation and Appeals Board disclosed last week that there has been a sharp upsurge in applications for hardship rent increases in rentstabilized buildings.

title: Byrne Panel Will Weigh Reform of Parole Board
description: TRENTON  The Byrne administration is considering major reforms of the controversial system for releasing inmates from the state's prisons.

title: Detroit Unveiling New Models This Spring
description: DETROITFor automobile manufacturers here, the new year usually begins in the fall, when they bring out their new models.

title: Memorial for Slain Police
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. l (AP)  Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, has in1 trod, uced legislation that would authorize a nationallmemorial in Washington for policemen killed in the line of duty.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: After two years of municipal breathholding, the decision has come down from the Supreme Court of the State of New York against the landmark designation of Grand Central Terminal. Penn Central and UGP Properties, Inc., the developer to which the railroad had leased the air rights over the terminal for a new office building, had sued the city of New York and its Lanamarks commision to have the designation abrogated. The suit was instituted after the Landmarks Commission refused a Certificate of Appropriateness for the office building proposal. And so now this early 20thcentury Beaux Arts monument, considered a master work of planning and design, can have the new building on top of it (market permitting), or be demolished outright.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: Our house is 10 years old and the cedar shingles on the outside have never been treated. I have received conflicting advice as to whether they need any finish to maintain them. I'm afraid to apply anything as it might darken them, but is it necessary for preservation?

title: Beth Holly Doobin Plans June. Bridal
description: The engagement of Beth Holly Doobin to Gary Allen Blazek, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Blazek of Lyons, Ill., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. rand Mrs. Leo Doobin of Cedar Grove. N.J.

title: Queens Gets Role In Mental Project
description: A program of supervised halfway houses to help mental patients released from Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens return to everyday life has won city approval after a compromise that gives Community Boards a voice in the location of facilities.

title: Advance Rents Finance a Renovation
description: The owner of a Greenwich Village brownstone has found an unusual way to finance custom renovations. He collects rents in advance.

title: HighEnergy Studies Indicate The Existence of New Particle
description: Indications of a third particle in the recently discovered series of new atomic fragments have been observed in highenergy collisions at the Stanford Linear Accelerator in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: 3,000 MEASURES FLOOD CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Although the 94th Congress is hardly a month old, its legislative hoppers are being flooded with bills both serious and curious, dealing with, among other things, the interests of the desert pupfish, the Royal Army of Yugoslavia and Polecat Bench, Wyo.

title: Curbs on Soliciting Pressed
description: TRENTON  Many New Jersey communities have long required doortodoor salesmen to register with the police, but the brutal murder of a licensed practical nurse in a private home in Leonia last month, coupled with a recent State Supreme Court decision, have stirred new interest in regulations covering canvassers.

title: FAMILY LOSES SUIT ON POISONED PORK
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 1 (UPI)A Federal judge has said that the plight of a povertystricken family whose children were poisoned by mercury from contaminated pork six years ago was tragic but he ruled he could not grant the family the $3.9million it sought in a suit against the Federal Government.

title: 14YearOld Tanzania Runner Sure U.S. Will Remember Her
description: The odds seemed to be stacked against 14yearold Mwinga Mwanjala, the Tanzanian distance runner who arrived in New York earlier last week to compete in the Millrose Games at Mathson Square Garden. Not only would it be the first indoor competition for the 4foot11inch, 90pound runner, the only female on her team, but prior to the competition she had never heard of Cheryl Touissant or Francie Larrieu, the two American challengers in the Millrose 1,000yard run. In addition, her youth and unfamiliarity with the English language were added disadvantages, it seemed. She finished fifth in the race and seemed uncomfortable on the strange. running surface.

title: New Task Force Ruling Helps Ease HoldingTank Controversy
description: With an AliceinWonderland logic, the holdingtank controversy has been flushed down the drainat least, temporarily. A joint task force from the Environmental Protective Agency and the Coast Guard has agreed to permit the use of flowthrough treatment devices for marine toilets, according to a spokesman for the Coast Guard's Office of Boating Safety. The decision reverses the E.P.A.'s mandatory holding tank requirement that had caused a furor among boatmen.

title: Kissinger Fails to Achieve Delay in Turkey Aid Cutoff
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Secretary of State Kissinger failed to persuade key members of Congress today to continue military aid to Turkey beyond Tuesday night's cutoff date.

title: Less Wheezing and More Visibility in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELESOn a clear day, you still can't see forever in Los Angelesbut you can see Catalina Island more often.

title: 5 Held in Montreal Fire
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 1 (AP) Five persons have been arrested in connection with the deaths of 13 persons whose bodies were found in a storage closet after a Montreal nightclub fire, a police spokesman said.

title: Man Is Questioned in Death Of Woman Under A Train
description: A woman was killed yesterday evening when she fell under a moving train in a Brooklyn subway station, and homicide detectives later questioned a 43yearold man who several witnesses said had pushed her from the platform, the police reported.

title: In Rutherford, Dolls Belong To All the Area's Children
description: RUTHERFORD  Lee Kuenzle has been collecting dolls for 16 years, but it has been only 10 years since she discovered that she was not the only adult to enjoy the playthings. That was when Mrs. Kuenzle was able to stop pretending that the collection belonged to her three daughters.

title: Handwerkers Have Child
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Handwerker of Valley Stream, L. L, on Jan. 1 in the Northshore Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. Mrs. Handwerker is the former Karen Turkel of Seaford, L. I. The child, who is named Heather Michelle, is a granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Handwerker of Lawrence, L. I. The baby's paternal grandfather is president and chairman of the board of Nathan's Famous, Inc., of which her father is assistant vice president of corporate development.

title: Catholic School Leaders Optimistic on the Future
description: NEW ARK  'Catholic Schools Week starts tomorrow, with the state's 584 Roman Catholic institutions holding open house and presenting special programs designed to show that the church's educational system is alive and well. The schools, church officials believe, have passed through a time of crisis and the question of survival is no longer the issue that it was a few years ago.

title: Braniff Is Ordered By Peru to Reduce Flights From Lima
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 1  The Peruvian military Government has ordered Braniff Airways to cut its flights from Lima by more than half, beginning today, in an effort to increase passengers on Aeroperu, the fledgling state airline.

title: DeceptivePackaging Accord
description: The Milton Bradley Company of Springfield, Mass., has agreed to stop packaging certain craft and hobby products in deceptively oversized containers, the Federal Trade Commission said Wednesday. According to the Associated Press, a complaint had charged that products produced by Bradlejes Whiting Division, under the name Crafts by Whiting and Lisbeth Whiting, were in oversized containers that made purchasers think they were getting more than they were.

title: SPLIT ON LANGUAGE WIDENS IN QUEBEC
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 29Every Saturday since Christmas scores of preschool children have been filing into church basements and lodge halls here for makeshift English classes designed to circumvent Quebec's controversial new larumage law.

title: Fashion
description: The loose dress is not a passing fancy. It was launched. last fall and now it's in full sail. This spring there are several variations in the shape of the big look: chemise, smock and shirt, to wear belted or loose. And the big bonus is that the prices won't break the bank account.

title: Beame to Cite Austerity Efforts In Seeking U.S. Aid for Budget
description: City officials, hoping that !concessions wrested from municipal labor unions will impi ess both the White House and Congress. said yesterday that Mayor Beame and Governor Carey would meet with Vice President Rockefeller. in Washington next week to seek help in cutting the city's remaining budget deficit this year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Deirdre Gilbert Will Be a Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. George J. Gilbert Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deirdre Gilbert, to Robert C. Neppel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Neppel. Both families reside in Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

title: Importers Try the American Way: New Models
description: This is the year Volkswagen tries to replace a Beetle with a Rabbit in the hearts of America.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: On Thursday, at the Metropolitan Museum, Music From Marlboro will include on its program the Trio in D minor for Piano, Violin and English Horn by Sir Donald Francis Tovey. It is safe to say that the work will come as a complete novelty to every listener in the auditorium. Indeed, it is safe to say that any Tovey work would come as a complete novelty. The current Schwann listings do not contain a single example of his music. Not that his fame depended upon composition. The man was much better known as a pianist, conductor, lecturer and, above all, analyst. Yet the hundredth anniversary of his birth will be coming up on July 17, and Music From Marlboro on Thursday is paying a quiet tribute to the author of the famous Essays in Musical Analysis.

title: The HighPriced ears in Town...and a Search for Cheap Ones
description: Running around looking for a new car these days isn't an unpleasant experience. Since you're apt to be the only customer in the dealer's showroomespecially on a weekday afternoonyou can be assured of a warm and courteous reception.

title: Pick of Peck Of Sweet or Hot Peppers
description: Many recipes include green peppers  soups, Spanish rice, omelets, to name just a few. Slices of green pepper may be sauted slowly until lightly browned and seasoned with salt or they may be Frenchfried by dipping them in egg and a mixture of bread or cracker crumbs, salt, Parmesan cheese and paprika.

title: BOOK EXCHANGE 9700
A Mother in India: Children Come and Children Go
description: NEW DELHI  The most obvious and pointed question arising from the populationfood crisis is why. do improverished people have six or seven children when they can barely afford to feed themselves and when they know that several of the children will die of disease or starvation?

title: Jets New Defensive Stalwarts Remember Old Times on Colts
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb.  Anthony Davis, the Heisman Trophy runnerup from Southern California and the New York Jets top draft pick, didn't arrive at Hofstra for the physical examination for new players today, but just about everybody else did, including two refugees from New Orleans and Baltimore.

title: 5 Inmates Caught, One Believed Dead In Rikers Escape
description: Six young inmates escaped from a cell on Rikers Island last night, but five were recaptured soon afterward and the sixth was missing and believed drowned in the East River.

title: Joanne Miller, C. T. Olcott 2d Plan Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Miller of Yardley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanne Louise Miller, to Charles Townsend Olcott 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Van Santvoord Olcott :If., of Hopewell, N. J.

title: Richard Litman Fiance Of Adrienne Schorr
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Schorr of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Adrienne Schorr, to Richard Litman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Litman, also of the Bronx.

title: Is RussianAmerican Trade Overrated?; Moscow's Rebuff Of Accord Raises A New Barrier
description: The Soviet rejection of the trade agreement with the United States did not come as a total surprise. The immediate reason ,given was, of course, the JacksonVanik amendment which in the Soviet view was transgression of the principle of noninterference in domestic affairs. But for the deeper reasons of the Soviet decision one ought to look elsewhere.

title: Democratic Noncandidates Still Yearn for Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Four years ago, they were among the leading candidates for the Democratic nomination. But now Hubert H. Humphrey, Edmund S. Muskie and George McGovern are just three Senators among 100, mere onlookers as another national campaign begins.

title: NICOTINE IS FOUND IN THE NONSMOKER
description: Nicotine gets into your blood and urine even if you never 'touch a cigarette, according to a British study of nonsmokers that adds further evidence about the risks of smoking to society.

title: Schools to Lose Millions
description: TRENTON  Confronted by the worst fiscal crisis in New Jersey's history, Governor Byrne is expected to propose on Tuesday a rockbottom budget that will include a series of drastic cutbacks involving a wide range of essential state services.

title: Shop Talk
description: MAPLEWOOD  Twentyeight years ago, Hy Hait, a pharmacist, bought a painting for the wall of his living room.

title: College Will Honor Watergate Guard
description: WAYNEFrank Wills, the security guard who discovered the Watergate breakin two years ago, will be honored at a convocation to be held in conjunction with Black History Week at William Paterson College.

title: FRENCH SOCIALISTS MEET AMID GAINS
description: PAU, France, Feb, 1  The French Socialist party struggled here today with the problem of keeping harmony on the left without losing its appeal to moderates.

title: The Nation
description: Not only the Senate but also the House of Representatives is preparing to examine all Government intelligence agencies, and it now seems likely they will address some fundamental questions about the role of secret police activity in a democratic nation.and Nixon. Mr. Church, who held hearings two years ago on reports of American efforts to undermine the Chilean Government of Salvador Allende, is likely to look harder into the C.I.A.'s role in that episode, among the agency's other foreign operations. Other gencies subject to review include the ional Security Agency, which special es in electronic intelligence intercepts, pe intelligence branches of the Defense,tate and Treasury Departments  ad the F.B.I.

title: And No Change in sight
description: ANKARA, Turkey  An American diplomat was asked recently if Washington would exert more pressure on Turkey to settle the Cyprus problem. He replied acidly: Who the hell do you exert pressure on?

title: 5 Dead and 11 Hurt as Land Company's Plane Crashes in Fog in Texas
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 1 (AP)land development company's airplane carrying a group of Oklahomans to inepect an East Texas lake reqort crashed in rain, fog, and darkness early today, less than three miles from the Houston Intercontinental Airport.

title: Frank Conroy Fiance of Margaret Lee
description: Margaret Davidson Lee and Frank Conroy plan to be married in May in Nantucket, Mass., where Mr. Conroy, a writer, lives.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Adirondack Guideboat a Work of Art
description: BLUE MOUNTAIN LAKE, N.Y. A marvelous blend of beauty and utility; the Adirondack guideboat had its moment of glory in the latter part of the last century.

title: Clash on Mekong Isle
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 1 (Reuters)  Government forces killed 75 insurgents today in a battle about seven miles northeast of here, the Cambodian command said. The encounter was said to have occurred on Koh Dach island in the Mekong River.

title: Inflation Widens the Gaps in the Interstate Highway System
description: WASHINGTON  Inflation Is making each unbuilt mile of the Interstate Highway System seem longer and longer. and so incredibly costly that some stretches may never be built.

title: New Ways of Battling the Bankruptcy Epidemic
description: Look out for files, warns a handwritten sign taped onto the door of the bankruptcy clerk for the Federal Southern District Court of New York.

title: Honda Challenges Detroit on Fuel Economy and Air Pollution Control
description: Can an automobile give 30 to 40 miles to the gallon, seat four people comfortably, beat air pollution and yet have enough performance to make driving on a freeway something less than a kamikaze mission?

title: Knicks Acquire Walk, Barnett For Bibby
description: Neal Walk, a strong rebounder, became a Knick yesterday, hours before the National Basketball Association trading deadline. The twoforoneplayer deal with the New Orleans Jazz was announced after the Houston Rockets edged the Knicks, 9593, on two free throws by Mike Newlin with 14 seconds remaining at Madison Square Garden.

title: COURT BACKS CURB ON VINYL CHLORIDE
description: New regulations designed to reduce the health hazard of vinyl chloride for workers in the plastics industry have been upheld here by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Hosick Takes Telemark Ski Jumping

title: Musicians In Montclair Hunt Talent
description: MONTCLAIR  The Montclair Chamber Music Society, a newly formed professional group, is reaching out for support and talent throughout the metropolitan area.

title: Correction
description: In an article by Richard J. Barnet and Ronald E. Muller the Dec. 22, 1974 issue of The Week in Review, it was stated incorrectly that Polaroid is the only major camera still being produced in the United States, Kodak also produces its cameras for the United States market.

title: Writers, Composers and Actors Collect RoyaltiesWhy Not Artists?
description: Seventeen years ago, when a young painter named Robert Rauschenberg was still struggling to pay his rent and feed his children, he sold a rotinting entitled Thaw for $900 to Robert Scull, the taxi tycoon and art collector. Over the succeeding years, Rauschenberg became famous for creating a new kind of abstract art which employed Pop Art materials, random objects, junk and so forth in order to make viewers ask what is real and what isn't. And so, when Scull got around to selling a number of the paintings in his collection at an auction at the Sotheby Parke Bernet gallery a couple of years ago. Rauschenberg's Thaw drew the tidy sum of $85,000. For Scull, not Rauschenberg, of course.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Craftsmen Invited To Vie in Festival
description: NEW BRUNSWICKCraftsmen desiring to exhibit in a prejudged show that will be held as part of the New Jersey Folk Festival at Douglass College are asked to submit their apolications by April 8. The festival will take place April 26.

title: Laver, Connors Play for $100,000 Today
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 1 The largest single prize ever offered for a tennis match5100,000 to the winner, plus a new carwill be at stake tomorrow when Rod Laver, the 36yearold Australian, and Jimmy Connors, the 22yearold American, face each other for the first time on a newly built indoor court at Caesar's Palace Hotel.

title: Guitarists Concert Is Set in Red Bank
description: RED BANKThe Romeros, known internationally as The Royal Family of the Guitar, will appear at the Monmouth Arts Center here on Feb. 27. Curtain time is 8:30 P.M.

title: The Great Detective
description: Of all the Sherlock Holmes books published or republished this season, The Sherlock Holmes Scrapbook, edited by Peter Haining, with a foreword by Peter Cushing, is the most evocative and informative as to the legends surrounding the Great Detective's life. The Great Detective, according to Ronald A. Knox, was so altogether real that one might some day look for Holmes in heaven, forgetting that he was only a character in a book. According to Peter Cushing, there can be no grave for Sherlock Holmes or Watson, and shall they not always continue in Baker Street?"live in a romantic chamber of the heart; in a nostalgic country of the mind; where it is always 1895.

title: Montessori Schools Under a Cloud
description: The books and records of the 12 New York Lttle Flower Montessori schools have been taken by Federal authorities and the sthools president has resigned and left the country.

title: Scientists Find Public Is Often Misled by Faulty Researeh Data
description: The quality of scientific information being produced by researchers, accepted in scientific journals and disseminated publicly by science reporters is often unacceptably sloppy or misleading, at least a dozen researchers asserted during last week's meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science here.

title: A Small Coal Mine in Colorado Revived by Heavy Demand for Cheap Fuel
description: HESPERUS, Colo.  Propane, butane and natural gas are clean and convenient fuels, and years ago, when people around here started heating with them, they didn't much need Violet Smith or the King Coal mine.

title: The World
description: Russia and China have canceled contracts with United States suppliers for 801,000 tons of wheat; the price of wheat has dropped and they apparently want to be free to buy it cheaper somewhere else. American exporters fear that Eastern European nations may follow suit.

title: Suffolk County Expects to Fill OTB Void in Time for Derby
description: SMITHTOWN, L.I., Feb. 1 Syd Askoff, a deceptively sleepylooking man, flashed a huge smile and said, The way things are going now, we should be doing business by Kentucky Derby day.

title: Kitchen Is Wired for Electronic Music
description: Just a few years ago, the kneejerk humanists among us were terribly nervous about electronic music. Our concert lives would be steadily destroyed by the creeping electronic monster, they worried. Only live music performed by live musicians could truly move the human spirit, and live music was being inevitably displaced by synthesized weirdness.

title: Divided New Hampshire G.O.P Elects Cotton as State Chairman
description: CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 31New Hampshire's fractured Republican party has rallied around retired Senator Norris Cotton, selecting him to be party chairman amid reports that Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. plans to push for a national conservative third party.

title: Pilot Dies in Copter Crash
description: MILFORD, Conn., Feb. 1 (UPI)A helicopter pilot from Ronkonkoma, L. I., wa,s killed today when his aircraft lost a rotor over Long Island Sound, plunging the craft and the pilot into the Sound about 500 yards off the Connecticut shore. The victim was identified as Sal Sciacca, 27 years old, a pilot for the Island Helicopter Company of Garden City, L.I., owners of the Bell helicopter he was flying.

title: International Clergy Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) President Ford has proclaimed the week beginning tomorrow as International Clergy Week. In a time of difficult choices and moral questioning, Mr. Ford said that clergymen of all denominations point the way to the higher values of conduct. As God's ministers on earth, practicing the human virtues of charity, humanity and compassion, they bring us closer to each other and nearer to creator.

title: Plane Crashes in Jersey
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 1 (AP)  A twinengine Lockheed Super Ventura on a flight from Columbus, Ohio, crashed today during its final approach to Atlantic City Airport. The police said two bodies, believed to be those of the pilot and copilot, had been removed from the wreckage. Neither was immediately identified.

title: A Woman Behind the Baton
description: MAHWAHThe Ars Musica Chorale, a chorus now in residence at Ramapo College, has something that few other musical organizations can claim: a woman conductor and musical director.

title: Valdes to Defend Title
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 1 (Reuters)Rodrigo Valdes of Colombia has agreed to defend his World Boxing Council middleweight title against Max Cohen of France next month in Paris or Grenoble, Melanio Porto Ariza, a promoter, said today. The fight will take place between March 22 and 28, he said.

title: Brooklyn Housing Aid Clustered In 2 Areas
description: More than 7,600 governmentaided housing units have been completed and made available for occupancy since 1970 in Brooklyn and the majority are clustered either in East New York or the Coney Island area.

title: FORD NOW CHARTS 52BILLION DEFICIT FOR BUDGET OF 76
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 President Ford announced today that he would send to Congress next Monday a $349billion budget calling for Federal spending of almost $1billion a day and a deficit of $52 billion$5billion higher than the Administration estimated just over two weeks ago.

title: Swiss Finish 1, 2, 3 in Cup Downhill Ski
description: MEGEVE, France, Feb. 1 (AP)Three Swiss skiers, led by 24yearold Walter Vesti, scored a sweep of the first three places today in the World Cup downhill race after the top Austrian contenders all crashed on the icy course.

title: North Vietnamese Learn East German Hotel Keeping
description: OBERHOF, East Germany  This resort in the Thuringian Mountains is only a train ride away from the North Vietnamese capital of Hanoias Vietnamese discover by making the trip in 13 days.

title: Peter Revson on Racing.: Don't Think About Death
description: From turn to turn around a race course, you are dealing with perfection. There are ways of bringing yourself to a state of prepanation tO accomplish that. I know I have to be perfect in order to win and so I get very edgy. Before a race I am not communicative, perhaps even a little sullen. And on the grid, no matter What anyone thinks or supposes, there are butterflies.

title: Detroit, Ensnared in Slump, Seeks the Right Kind of Car
description: DETROIT Like Gulliver in Lilliput, the automobile industry has awakened in 1975 to find itself held down by climbing prices, Government regulations and economic uncertainty.

title: Akhenaten Show Draws Large Brussels Crowds
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 1Europe's first major exhibition devoted to Akhenaten, the enigmatic Pharaoh who tried unsuccessfully to revolutionize Egyptian religion and art during his 17year reign, has opened to large crowds at the Brussels Royal Museum of Art and History.

title: R. E. Angevine Fiance of Miss Sundman
description: Mr. and Mrs. John E. Sundman of North Caldwell, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maureen Sundman, to Robert Edmund Angevine, son of Harry W. Angevine of Glen Ridge, N. J., and the late Margaret B. Angevine. A September wedding is planned.

title: Appeals Court Will Move Quickly on Nixon Records
Men of medicine and a medicine man
description: Experiments On Myself

title: School Working With Industry
description: FARMINGDALELong Island government officials, industrial leaders and the Polytechnic Institute of New York are planning mutual efforts to promote major new technological developments through industrycampus cooperation.

title: Slowdown Blocks Edition
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 1 (UPI)  The Washington Post said it would try to recover damages from the pressman's union for a work slowdown that forced it to cancel the final street edition of 55,000 papers today. John Dower, vice president for communications, said that the slowdown began after the ,pressman's union was notified that because of a reduction in 1 the number of pages to be printed today for Sunday's issue, fewer presses would be required. The union requested that the Post operate an additional press which would have required hiring nonscheduled pressmen at an overtime rate. The Post declined this request.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: A LaidOff Pipe Installer Finds Security an Illusion
description: Until a few days ago, Joseph Caracciolo, a 24yearold construction worker from Brooklyn, had what he thought was a secure job. But last week, like thousands of others who have been laid off because of the economic situation, he was standing in line applying for unemployment insurance.

title: Ostolozaga Loughlin's Latest Star
description: Less than a month ago, Luis Ostolozaga, 16yearold junior from Bishop Loughlin, was regarded as a future star in schoolboy track. Yesterday the Brooklyn youngster demonstrated that he has already reached that class.

title: Dredgers Begin Cleanup of Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn
description: Dredging equipment has begun removing the sludge and debris that has accumulated in Brooklyn's Gowanus Canal and has been the focus of community protests In South Brooklyn for more than a decade.

title: TOTAL OIL EMBARGO RULED OUT BY SHAH
description: Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran has declared that at least four oilproducing countries would not participate in an oil embargo against Western nations.

title: On Guard at London's Tate
description: HOW do, mum. Yes'um, be glad to speak to you, but if you've got questions, there's plenty at the front desk can inform you better than I could. They've got everything there at the desk: prints, cards, guides, slides. I made a bit of a rhyme, so's I could remember it all.

title: Black Sunday
description: The Arabsthe Arab extremists, at any rateare not making it easy even for those who might have a lingering sympathy for their cause. Not the way they go around blowing planes out of the sky, or holding innocents as ransom, or murdering athletes at Olympic games, or slavering whenever Israel is mentioned. They are today's universal villains and are celebrated as such in novel after novel, especially in crime novels. Black Sunday, in which Thomas Harris asks us to believe that the Black September group of Al Fatah will blow up a stadium during a Super Bowl game (taking the President of the United States along with other spectators), whips the Arab extremists with a leaded knout.

title: Colson, After Time With Family, To Do Religious Work and Write
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) Charles W. Colson, former Nixon administration aide, who has just been released from imprisonment for Watergate crimes, says he plans to devote as much time as possible to religious work.

title: H.Elliott Rogers Jr. to Marry Gail M.Underwood in Summer
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. Bruce Underwood of Chappaqua, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Marie Underwood, to H. Elliott Rogers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rogers of Locust Valley, L. I. and Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Disability Center to Open in East Orange
description: EAST ORANGEThe Kim Institute for Rehabilitation Medicine, a new center for disability treatment, wiii be opened here within a few weeks.

title: Fordham Beaten by B.C. Five
description: NEWTON; Mass., Feb. (AP) Bob Carrington, Wil Morrison and Bill Collins combined to score 16 points today as Boston College defeated Fordham, 9174, for its fifth consecutive basketball victory and the 10th in the last 11 games.

title: INVESTING
description: Despite a threatened court battle between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange over the S.E.C.'s p!an to abolish fixed commission rates on May I, it is clear that the commission rate trend for the small investor is up and will probably continue in that direction regardless of which organization prevails.

title: A Skeptical Eye for Earnings
description: During the next few weeks the stream of annual reports will become a flood. For people who know what to look for, there should be some interesting reading between the lines.

title: L.I. Conservation Problems Are Aired at SpeakOut Sponsored by the State
description: HEMPSTEAD  Ogden R. Reid, the new Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation, could not make it last week to the first of a series of environmental speak outs, but his aides listened as speakers discussed environmental problems that ranged from the deleterious impact of nonreturnable containers to nuclear fission.

title: Damascus Sees an Effort to Split the Arabs
description: DAMASCUS, Jan. 31 Syria as well as the Palestine Liberation Organization are looking with a great deal of suspicion on Secretary of State Kissinger's new mediation effort in the Middle East and on his announced plan to visit the area in midFebruary.

title: Jobless Coverage Broadened by U.S.
description: TRENTONWith 10.3 per cent of New Jersey's labor force now unemployed, the highest rate of joblessness since the Depression, the state's Department of Labor and Industry has announced a new Federal program to give benefits to those not covered by unemployment insurance.

title: The Day I Laid an Egg on a Quiz Show
description: No one knows the hardness of these times better than a New York actor. Even in the best of times, only a small percentage of actors living in and around Manhattan earn enough money on the stage to support themselves. Budding Bernhardts and Brandos all over, town eke out existences as temporary typists and cab drivers. A few months ago, I found myself between jobs, as actors are wont to put it. (In our business, between jobs can mean anywhere from a twoweek layoff to your last appearance having been with Mrs. Fiske.) It was then that I turned to a means of keeping the wolf from the door that several of my colleagues had found most rewarding: TV quiz shows.

title: June Bridal Set By Mary Stelle
description: Mary Medlicott SteIle and Robert Bruce Donin, a lawyer with the Department of Transportation in Washington, have made plans to be married in June.

title: Brock ShowStealer At Writers Dinner?
description: Lou Brock. who stole 118 bases last summer, will steal the spotlight tonight when New York's baseball writers review the fortunes and follies of the 1974 season in their 52d annual dinner.

title: Elizabeth Hadley Jones Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. Schuyler Lippincott of Chestnut Hill, Pa., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Lippincott's daughter, Elizabeth Hadley Jones, to John Dickson Ferguson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Ferguson of Wilton, Conn.

title: Sara Jean Lempereur Is Betrothed
description: Sara. Jean Lempereur of Weston, Mass., and Peter Alan Bostock, a special analyst with the Raychem Corporation in Menlo Park, Calif., plan to be married in April in Concord. Mass.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following may he obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Letters: More Tips On European Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE G.O.P. MAPS REVIVAL STRATEGY
description: After suffering its worst setback in many years, the Republican party in New York State has begun at the county level the arduous task of rebuilding its political fortunes.

title: Philadelphia Federal Reserve
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia will more than double its office space next year when it moves into this eightstory, 800,000squarefoot facility. The $50million structure occupies the block bounded by Sixth, Seventh, Arch and Cherry Streets. Designed by Ewing Cole, Erdman Rizzio Cherry Parsky, it will have a facade of polished red granite and glass, a recessed ground floor, courtyards and windows that wrap over the top of the building to provide extra light. Turner Construction Company of New York is the construction manager. Pietro Belluschi was the bank's architectural. consultant.

title: Lorin Maazel: s Heart elongs to Cleveland
description: The Cleveland Orchestra used to be a jewel within a jewel box, maintains Lorin Maazel, who succeeded the late, renowned George Sze11 three seasons ago as that orchestra's music director. In New York this week for a series of five Carnegie Hall concerts, Maazel adds: The orchestra is still a jewel, but occasionally we take it out of the box now  otherwise it might gather dust.

title: Radical Economists Under Fire
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Radical economists, many of them Marxists and all of them sharply critical of orthodox economics, have begun to feel like an endangered species on some American camDUSCS:

title: Halas Is 80 Today
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP)George Hales, patriarch and only living member of the hardy pioneers who founded the National FoOtball League, will celebrate his 80th birthday tomorrow.

title: Weak Dollar or Strong?
description: The language of finance is full of instances of the pathetic fallacy  the endowment of inanimate objects with human traits. Thus, one day the dollar is said be weak, the next strong, and on the third to be suffering a sinking spell. This does not mean, however, that the dollar is undergoing some sort of crisis. All it means that on particular days market forces have pushed the dollar up or down a bit.

title: In Memoriam
description: GURSKYAaron.One sad and lonely year; forever in our hearts. Ruth, children and grandchildren.

title: 120,000 Miners Get Living  Cost Raises Of 7 Cents an Hour
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The first costofliving wage increases ever granted in the coal industry took effect today, adding 7 cents an hour to the $6.15anhour average wage of 120,000 coal miners who belong to the United Mine Workers. The escalator provision was one of the major improvements in the threeyear labor agreement signed last Dec. 5 after a 54day strike.

title: Headliners
description: The appointment of Benjamin Ward as New York State's new Corrections Commissioner is apparently an attempt the Carey administration to please the two primary groups in the prison systems: employes and inmates. The fact that Mr. Ward is black should ease his acceptance among the inmates, 83 per cent of whom are black or Hispanic. His long experience in police work22 years with the New York City Police Department  should gain him support with employes and guards, 88 per cent of whom are white. Mediating the differences between the two groups will not be an easy task: racial antagonism between the mostly ruralborn guards and the mostly cityborn inmates has been boiling over since the Attica prison uprising in 1971, and recent stories abcrut guards who were allegedly Klu Klux Klan members have only fueled the conflict.

title: Jenny MacKenzie, Designer, Married
description: Jenny Stewart MacKenzie sand Bruce Chandler were married yesterday at noon in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Lake Forest, Ill. The Rev. Frederick W. Phinney performed the ceremony.

title: SPAIN IS SHAKEN BY LABOR UNREST
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Jan. 25  One of Spain's longest and most intensive waves of worker agitation in recent times is now receding, leaving the labor syndicate organization, a pillar of the political system, battered and weakened.

title: Forego Is Victor In Hialeah Stakes
description: MIAMI, Feb. 1  Last night In San Francisco, Martha Gerry accepted the Eclipse Award for her horse Forego, America's Horse of the Year in 1974. Based on Forego's perforMance in today's Seminole Handicap at Hialeah, Mrs. Gerry will be back on the same old stand, for the same purpose, next year.

title: Fire and Time Erode Life at the Hudson Piers
description: NORTH BERGEN  The charred remains of about 30 wooden barges loll in the Hudson River tides at the foot of 79th Street here. Garbage is heaped near the riverbank, and children on minibikes scoot around near what was once a thriving river community and long a familiar sight to motorists using River Road and Kennedy Boulevard.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: City Employe Slain in Queens Holdup
description: A 48yearold Fire Department electrician was shot and killed as his wife :looked on early yesterday in a holdup outside his home in Laurelton. Oueens. the police reported.

title: John Hansel Jr. And Sarah Hall Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eben Clarke Hall of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Elizabeth Hall, to John Parker Hansel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hansel of Harrisville, N. H. The wedding is planned for early spring.

title: New Tensions Break Dialogue Between U.S. and Latin Nations
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 1 Less than a year after Secretary of State Kissinger's call for a new dialogue, relations between the United States and Latin America have run into a series of irritants and aspirations that have caused serious new friction.

title: Lisbon Denies Port Bid
description: The Portuguese Foreign. Ministry denied yesterday reports that Portugal had been asked by the Soviet Union to provide port facilities for its Atlantic fishing trawlers. Despite the denial, informed Portuguese sources insisted yesterday that such a request had been made. Page 7.

title: ARABS VIEW SUDAN AS SOURCE OF FOOD
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 1Arab governments are looking to the Sudan to free them from their current dedendence on western countries for food, according to Abdulla Mahgoub of the Sudanese delenation here.

title: Roseland Debating Uses for Land
description: ROSELANDThis is one of the few communities in Essex County with a large amount of undeveloped land, and its residents are currently debating various ways to rezone the unused acreage. More than onethird of our land is undeveloped, and we're revising our master zoning plan to deal with the situation, said Robert D. Bosworth, the Borough Administrator. We are now probably going to allow a few garden apartments and connected townhouses, but essentially the area is zone for onefamily dwellings, just like the rest of our community.

title: BOOK PUBLISHERS GET BAD REDING
description: Major publishers of hardcover novels and nonfiction, peering into the gloom of a deepening recession, say they are facing the year with caution and apprehension.

title: BRIDGE
description: Nature occasionally imitates art at the bridge table. Once in a long while a hand with all the marks of a composed doubledummy problem appears, naturally dealt, at the table. When this happens, the odds are that the declarer will fail, and nobody will ever realize the full beauty of the deal.

title: Businesses Here Taking Steps Against Recession
description: There is now taking place a tremendous shakeout in this industry and we do not intend to be a part of this unfortunate satiation.

title: Hawks Bow, 41
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 1  Ed Giacomin thrives on work. So do Jerry Butler and Pete Stemkowski. While the two Ranger forwards were each picking up a goal and an assist tonight, Giacomin was turning away almost everything that got by the briskly forechecking New Yorkers as they halted their threegame road losing streak with a 41 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: CITY OVERHAULS POLLUTION PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1New York State and New York City environmental officials plan to meet on Monday with officers of the United States Environmental Protection Agency to submit a revised transportation plan to curb air pollution by reducing city traffic up to 50 per cent.

title: Douglas John Pettibone Fiance Of Marcia Frost Rickenbacker
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Edward Rickenbacker of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Hartford, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Macia Frost Rickenbacker, to Douglas John Pettibone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Pettibone, also of Upper Montclair.

title: Mackey Set To Battle Rozelle Rule
description: The next battle between the National Football League and the antitrust laws with respect to control of players will begin tomorrow morning in Federal Court in Minneapolis, when the Mackey case goes to trial before Judge Earl Larson, without a jury.

title: Auto Industry Fears New Rules Would Raise Costs and Lower Mileage
description: DETROITSafety and pollution standards have come under attack, but the car makers don't think they've won their battles with their critics. In fact, despite some distinct successes in recent weeks, the auto makers figure they've got no more than a 5050 chance to roll back rules they consider crippling.

title: Bergen Aide Seeks Funds to Improve Transport in County
description: HACKENSACKTwo commuter rail projects and the elimination of Jersey's worst traffic bottleneck top the list of Bergen County's transportation needs.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: WASHINGTON  If there's anything businessmen hate worse than the unions, a Capitol Hill sage said the other day, it's OSHA. The Occupational Svfety and Health Administration, an alp of the Labor Departnitrit, makes management unhappy because John Stender, OSHA's head, can almost singlehandedly mandate job safety and health improvement expenditures costing millions of dollars. And he has done it.

title: The Violence Plague
description: Like a dread plague in medieval times that moved relentlessly and invisibly from one walled town to another and that walls were powerless to keep out, terrorist violence breaks out today in one great city after another and sophisticated security systems are powerless to prevent it. Within days a bomb goes off in the State Department in Washington, there is a murderous explosion at Fraunces Tavern in New York, planes are shot up and hostages seized in an airport in Paris. No city  Stockholm or Rome, Birmingham or Buenos Aires  is immune, and in the least favored, such as Belfast, violence has become endemic.

title: KURT EPSTEIN
description: Kurt Epstein, twice a member of Czechoslovak waterpolo teams in the Olympic Games, collapsed and died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday on the street near his home at 67 Rivecside Drive. He was 71 years old

title: STAGE VIEW
description: It seems to me that the key to Edward Aline's interesting, sunbleached but taffythin Seascape is the part he hasn't written for Barry Nelson. Mr. Nelson, lined, grumpy, a grandfatherly fiftyish, is spending a day on the dunes with his much more animated wife, Deborah Kerr.

title: Cliff Keuter's Troupe Performs Two Disappointing New Dances
description: At his genially surrealistic best, Cliff Keuter has the knack of toying and dallying profitably with props like a kid loose in a playroom. Occasional happy epiphanies between dancer and prop can often form a pleasing whole, but did not in his painful new The Murder of George Keuter. His company presented this and the premiere of Voice at the New York University School of Education auditorium Friday evening.

title: Cranston Extends SkateTitle Streak
description: QUEBEC CITY, Feb. 1 (UPI)  Toiler Cranston of Toronto captured his fifth consecutive Canadian figure skating title today and 19yearold Lynn Nightingale of Ottawa retained the women's crown.

title: FACTORS TRACED IN PUPIL SUCCESS
description: Several long  held beliefs about the factors that affect learning have been challenged by a study of the Philadelphia schools that concluded that a school's general facilities and the amount of education a teacher has beyond the bachelor's degree do not appear related to pupil achievement.

title: PHILIPPINES DENIES ANY USE OF NAPALM
description: MANILA, Feb. 1 (AP) The Philippine Government denied this week a report by field commanders. that its air force was dropping napalm bombs in the fight against Moslem rebels in the southern Philippines.

title: Bill to Ban Public Smoking
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 1, (UPI) Two state Senators have introduced a bill to prohibit smoking in places of public assembly, or where more than 25 persons are gathered. The measure would allow smoking only in areas designated for that purpose.

title: ADMIRAL TRAPNALL, TEST PILOT IN WAR
description: Frederick M. Trapnall. a retired admiral who had been a test pilot in the Navy in World War H, died Thursday in San Diego Naval Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Coronado, Calif.

title: A Mortgage Plan From M.I.T.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. A team of economists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has proposed a radical departure in longterm borrowing that, they say, would make mortgage loans once again accessible to young, less affluent home buyers.

title: PERU'S PRESIDENT NAMES PREMIER
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 1Prcsident Juan tlelasco Alvarado today appointed a new Premier who is considered a strong favOrite to succeed him eventually at the helm of the leftleaning military government.

title: Gromyko Arrives With Enhanced Powers
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 1 Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, who set out today on a visit to Syria and Egypt, is apparently traveling with enhanced authority closer to the power enjoyed by his American counterpart, Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Barry Bryer to Marry Meryl Wiener
description: Meryl Elaine Wiener, a lawyer here with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Barry Alan Bryer, a lawyer with Cravath, Swaine & Moore, plan to marry in May.

title: Christina Hohl Plans Nuptials
description: Mrs. Clarence L. Hohl Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Christina Hohl, to Thomas R. Hubbard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Hubbard Jr., also of Greenwich. A wedding in the autumn is planned.

title: Getting Close (Very) To Great Gray Whales
description: MOORED at the H & M Landing at the foot of Emerson Street in San Diego was the Salado, a trim white vessel 85 feet long. She was no cruise liner; in fact, because of her merger tonnage exNavy types call her a boat or a tender rather than a ship. But for whalewatching she has a definite advantage; She draws less than six feet of water and her shallow draft enables her to cross the sandbars guarding the Mexican lagoons where whales bask and disport themselves by the hundreds.

title: Program Planned On Breast Cancer
description: BLOOMFIELDThe Essex County Cancer Society is the sponsor of a program on breast cancer that will be held Wednesday evening at the Bloomfield Public Library.

title: Girl, 9 Orphaned by Shooting, Ponders What Future Holds
description: Theresa Walker, who is 9 years old, spoke yesterday about her future.

title: How to Enjoy Skating: Pick Proper Equipment
description: Lives there a soul among us who has not eyed a frozen pond and immediately visualized himself swooping over it with the grace of a bird, the speed of an arrow and the agility of a gymnast? And lives there a soul among us who has not had his Walter Nlitty dreams smashed by the sight of ankles that flop, by toes that freeze and by corsets of warm clothes that straitlace the body?

title: The Great Stakes Race
description: PARIS  I am interested to read in book of political analysis published 43 years ago: No people in the world has the gift of infuriating Americans quite so much as the French. Whether in the field of social customs, politics, or business methods, they get the American goat with monotonous regularity.

title: Six Ravel Works Found; Premiere Here on Feb. 23
description: Six previously unknown compositions by Maurice Ravel hav& been discovered in southern France by a Queens College musicologist and will be given world premieres at a special Queens College Ravel centenary concert Feb. 23.

title: Mary Carmody Engaged to Francis Ryan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Barrett Carmody of Mount Vernon, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Ann Carmody, to Francis Xavier Ryan of New York and Point Lookout, L. I He is the son of Mrs. E. Gerard Ryan, who is Aileen B. Ryan, Bronx Councilmanatlarge, and the late Mr. Ryan.

title: Nixon White House Was Sent Files on Namath, Paper Says
HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: CHASE MANHATTAN and Morgan Guaranty reduced their prime rate from 91/2 per cent to 9 per cent. Citibank lowered its rate to 9% per cent. . . . United States banks raised $2.47billion in capital financing last year, according to an Irving Trust study. This was only $166million shy of 1972's record $2.63billion.... The Treasury sold $1.75billion of sixyear notes last week at an average interest rate of 7.49 per cent and $750million of 25year bonds an average yield of 7.95 per cent.

title: Everton Wins, Keeps Soccer Lead
description: LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP) Everton defeated Tottenham Hotspur, 10, today to maintain its lead in the English Soccer League First Division. Stoke City defeated, Manchester City, 40, and moved into third place in the standing, 2 points back of Everton and I behind secondplace Ipswich.

title: The Ballet: A Cocteau Period Piece
description: It really is a pity that American Ballet Theater is unable to hang the Waldievitch scenery properly at the City Center 55th Street Theater, for without the studio walls flying up to reveal the Paris skyline for Le Jeune Homme et la Mort, possibly the most dramatic moment of this quaint Jean Cocteau period piece is missing,

title: The Master of the Method Plays a Role Himself
description: Lounging in the darkened den, his thin arms stretched out on the sides of a Miamimodern chair, alongside a folding snack tray, Hyman Roth is watching the football game. He looks like any little old grandfather with a scrawny neck, a mild paunch above the belt, halfhidden by the sagging cardigan; a soft blur in the voice, his white hair a wispy crown. Michael Corleorie has come down to see Mr. Roth on business (big business, Mafia business) but Hyman Roth, nonetheless, sounds like a grandfather. Good health is the most important thing, he murmurs to Michael. More than succesz, more than money, more than power . . . His eyes leave the TV screen.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater

title: Dealers Struggle for Survival
Mostly for Looking
description: In this age of instant and incessant stardom, any mini  event becomes cause for celebration. So new picture books by four of our starriest luminaries should raise only two questions: how many flares do we send up and when do we let fly with the confetti?

title: It Links Prices to the General Rate of Inflation
description: WASHINGTON  Indexation is not a pretty word; but it is moving up fast in the vocabulary of international economics. Last week, the oil exporters agreed in Algiers to hold the price of oil steady this year, but in the following two years to raise it by 80 and 90 per cent of the amount by which the cost of their industrial imports increases  and by the full amount thereafter.

title: Maine Man Heads Program
description: BOSTON, Feb. 1 (AP) Phocion L. Sutherland, of Blue. Hill, Me., has been named managing director of the New England International Trade and Development Program designed to promote economic growth throughout the sixstate region. The new program is jointly sponsored by the International Center of New England, Inc. and the New England Regional Commission.

title: The Three Marias
description: There is no way that The Three Marias could ever accommodate its own fanfare. Consider its history. In 1971, three young Portuguese women, talented literary women in a country of macho men, languorous, assenting wives, fascist law and Latin church morality, agree to meet weekly to raise their consciousness and exchange notes, poems, fantasies and letters based on the famous Letters of a Portuguese Nun"five brilliant and anguished love letters written in the middle of the 17th century by a beautiful young nun, Mariana Alcoforado, to the French officer who had seduced her in her convent, peremptorily abandoned her to save his neck or his reputation or both, and who eventually became Marshal of France.

title: A Little Nudge to Buy a Car
description: The ingredients for the automobile mystique are all here: the spotlights glowing on gleaming enamel, the flash and glitter of chrome, and the rich odor of leather upholstery.

title: Adventures of the Littlest Travelers
description: YOU see them at airports in growing numbers these dayswearing little leather nooses or plastic pouches around their necks, with buttons or badges they often try to hide. They are the U.M.'s Unaccompanied Minors who roam the globe under the mostly watchful eyes of ground hostesses and flight attendantsand they represent a relatively new and increasjngly important class of air passenger.

title: Turkish Pilots End Strike
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 1 (Reuters)  Turkish Airlines pilots returned to work today after a 24hour strike in de. mand of better safety measures at state airnorts following Thursday's airliner crash in the Sea of Marmara. Turkey's Transnort Minister said that the dispute had ended hut the pilots said they were only postponing their campaign.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  It is a bit surprising to some people here that one option for dealing with the energy issue has hardly been considered at all.

description: Karen Margaret Sisson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Sisson of Greenville, Del., was married yesterday afternoon to Steven Cory Stang, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Stang of Sayville, L. I.

The United States, in turn, can no longer simply turn its back on the Soviet Union, with its huge economic potential, and on the inherent promise of international stability through EastWest detente.

description: WASHINGTON  The dark maroon carpet that covered the Senate floor in the heyday of such patriarchs as Lyndon Johnson, Richard Russell and Everett Dirksen has been replaced this year by a bright blue and white one. The chamber does not look so much like an old men's club, and the Senate does not operate so much like one either.

description: A bomb exploded in front of the offices of the Venezuelan Consulate General! at 7 East 51st Street last night, shattering three large plateglass windows in the consulate building.

title: Endpaper
description: There was a police colonel built like a heavyweight boxer waiting for me at the district division of the Czechoslovak State Security Police in Ceska Lipa. He had a voice that carried, and to look at him it was obvious that he preferred other duties to those of talking people into traveling to the West, which I later learned he was there to do.

title: David Fort to Wed Betty Ann Hogan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Hogan of Plainfield, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Betty. Ann Hogan, to David Bayard Fort, son of Mr. and Mrs. Osmun Fort of Plainfield and North Hatley, Quebec.

description: Barbara Thorne O'Brien and Dr. William Rigby, Beardslee, a member of the American Psychiatric Association, were married yesterday afternoon in Cambridge, Mass. The ceremony was performed at the Meeting house of the Religious Society of Friends in Cambridge.

description: Priscilla Croswell Perkins of Santa Monica, Calif., and Edward Sturgis Grew, research geologists, plan to be married in June in Groveland, Mass.

title: Candles and Groundhogs
description: This is Candlemas Day by the Christian calendar, the time of the purification of the Virgin and the blessing of the candles. It also is Groundhog Day, which believed far to predate Candlemas. The superstition that sunshine on Groundhog Day means six more weeks of winter.

title: Live composers, dead audiences; Why do people stay away from contemporary music? Because they don't hear right, or because there's so little worth hearing?
description: To set things straight from the start, dead definitely does not apply to that avid, fiercely independent audience for serious contemporary music. This audience is, if anything, 200 per cent alive. But, alas, it is tiny and growing at a snail's pace: a highwater mark was reached last season when 1,100 people attended an allWebern concert Carnegie ing the hall more than onehalf empty.

description: Alumni of public colleges have rarely heard financial appeals from their alma maters. But the pressures of a recessionary economy on the budgets of taxsupported colleges have changed that.

title: CURB ON FOOD DYE URGED BY U.S. UNIT
description: A committee formed by the Food and Drug Administration to study the possible harmful effects of the dye known as Red No. 2 has recommended that the artificial coloring be restricted in food use and has strongly urged that further tests be conducted to determine its safety.

title: Mrs. Max Has a Son
description: A son was born Jan. 11 at the Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N. J., to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Edward Max of River Vale, N. J. Mrs. Max is the former Diane Wolf of Forest Hills, Oueens. Mr. Max is vice president of Synkote Paints of Elmwood Park, N. J. The child has been named Ethan Daniel.

title: The Clockwork Testament or Enderby's End
description: The muchslighted English poet F. X. Enderby was born at dawn in a W.C. in Borneo and died 56 years later in an apartment at the corner of 91st and Columbus Avenue in New York City. He received no public attention until the early sixties, when Joseph Kell published the delightfully funny, grubby and perceptive biography Inside Mr. Enderby. "I'M Enderby is an Engushed Portrait of the Artist, with its middleaged Blooming poet struggling against church, state and his dead but unforgotten mother, ne Hogg. Among other disasters, Enderby falls into the arms of a Mrs. Vesta Bainbridge. No vestal she; her last name combines two of Dedalus's btes noires, bridges and baths; her initials reverse B.V.M.; and she spells trouble. Enderby is driven to suicide, fails at that too, and psychiatrists brainwash him into a docile Hogg. Some five years later, Kell (now named Anthony Burgess) published Enderby, restoring Enderby to himself and landing him in Tangier, writing again and visited by a charming irritable muse.

title: The Good Word: The Novel of Manners Lives
description: Joe Heller writes in: I was already seriously considering a novel of manners until you just pronounced the novel of manners dead. Maybe, though, I'll continue with it because it's dead.

title: 2 Norwegian Skiers Help Vermont Win
description: WILLISTON, Vt. Feb. 1 (AP)  The University of Vermont, led by two Norwegians, took jumping and overall honors at its Winter Carnival today.

title: Stranger Pushes Woman to Death Under a Train
description: A 25yearold woman was thrown to her death in front of an onrushing subway train in Brooklyn yesterday evening by a man who apparently was a total stranger to her, the police reported.

title: U.S. Trailing Mexico, 24, After 5Set Doubles Loss

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good. three as excellent and four as superb.

description: Betsy Carruth Cunningham and Leonard Walter Langer plan to marry In June.

description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto is shaping a frail democracy that has its odd aspects.

title: Tiger Lured Back Into Cage Aboard 707 at Kennedy
description: Calling her sweet lady in German and dangling a slab of raw meat, an animal trainer coaxed a 3yearold, 300pound Bengal tiger back Into her cage aboard a cargo plane early yesterday morning, nearly 10 hours after startled freight handlers unloading the plane found her roaming loose in the plane's cargo area.

title: Last Fall He Said Yes, But the Last Word Belongs to His Party
description: WASHINGTON  Will Gerald R. Ford be running for President next year? At the moment this lb a sort diagramless puzzle that intrigues only hardcore political buffs, but the town is full of them and the uncertainties surrounding the nation's latest accidental President leave lots of room for speculation.

title: BREITEL MODIFIES REFORM PROPOSAL
description: For the first time publicly, the state's chief judge has modified one of the key proposals in his courtreform package and said he could live with a plan providing for the appointment of judges who have been nominated by a screening committee. That plan has been backed by most bar associations and courtreform groups.

title: Article 2  No Title
ART VIEW
description: The career of the Russianborn painter Alexej von Jawlensky reads today like the scenario of a 19thcentury Russian novel carried over into the even harsher ideological climate of 20thcentury Europe. His early life sounds, indeed, like something out of Turgenev, yet the romance of the young Army officer turned expatriate artist, painting at Pont Aven and meeting the Fauves in Paris and becoming an important figure in the Munich avantgarde in the years preceding the First World War, ended in the nightmare of Hitler's Germany. Jawlensky died in Wiesbaden in 1941, after years of suffering the crippling effects of arthritis and the even more malevolent effect of the Nazi ban on modernist art.

title: TV VIEW
description: Exactly what is supposed to be funny? A recent news dispatch from Mogadishu, Somalia, reported that 10 men were executed there by a firing squad. Their crime was speaking against an equal rights decree for women. They had done their speaking in mosques, and Somalia's National Security Court found them guilty of exploiting religion to cause national disunity and of subverting the authority of the state. Another 23 men will go to prison for between 20 to 30 years on similar charges. It wouldn't have happened in Switzerland.

title: Hearings Set on Old Westbury Plan to Train Students for Careers
Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: CRUSADERS SEXTET RINGS JAZZ CHANGES
description: The Crusaders, a West Coast jazz sextet formerly known as the Jazz Crusaders, gave a concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening that was filled with fervent, emotional performances. The group, together for more than 20 years, rang the changes on emotional projection, much as a group of Gospel singers might, moving readily from fast and fervent to slow and fervent, from delicate shadings to wide, exuberant ensembles.

description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 1 Brown forged ahead with 8 straight points early in the second half tonight and went on to a 6261 victory over Princeton. The triumph moved the Bruins into a tie with the Tigers for second place in the Ivy League.

description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 28 A delegation of diplomats from the European Common Market is to arrive in Moscow Tuesday for a meeting that has taken almost two years to arrangethe first official market contact with the East bloc's economic group, known as Comecon.

However, the documentary is too often content to watch spectators watching the exhibitions, shifting the focus from the couple themselves, who are considerably more interesting.

title: DEAN SPEECH TOUR
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.,Feb, 2John W: Dean 3d. a month out of prison and fresh from a Caribbean vacation, stepped onto a campus stage here and hack into the limelight tonight as a $4.000anhour lecturer at the University of Virginia.

title: Books of The Times
description: I don't find writers who are drunk with words any more interesting than ordinary drunks. I'll show you why, with a sentence from A Shadow on Summer, by Christy Brown: And children, always the children, glorifying the day, making a hymn of it, splashing in the listing surf, taking the great harm out of the world, laughing as only children can in the rare ecstasy of their time, making sand castles, destroying them, building new ones, racing joyously to meet the ceaseless waves, crying in their freedom, squaring up to each other, causing sweet chaos in the sand, their very rowdiness lending an odd peace to the bay, water glistening down their small articulate limbs, happy and victorious, playing with life and sure of winning.

description: Music

title: Love Among the Slot Machines
description: LAS VEGAS, NeNt., Feb. 2At 7 o'clock this Sabbath morning, one craps table remained busy in the casino of Caesars Palace, the beauty and chivalry played quietly HY blackjack tables, the Clank and whir and occasional jingle of the slots had almost subsided, and out back in the tennis pavilion Rod Laver was practicing. I could never get. Jimmy up so early, said Bill Riordan, manager iinfiny Connors, who was packing an extra hour and a half in the sack before warming up for the most grossly opulent match ever played at the genteel game invented to amuse guests at a lawn party. Approximately six hours later, at the end of a fourset struggle that had brought wild animal cries from 3,800 witnesseswho had paid up to $100 a seatthey gathered at center court to whack up the loot: $100,000 for Connors and the use of a new car for a year, $60,000 for Laver, plus prearranged percentages of television revenue that might bring the winner's total to $150,000.

As the symphony orchestra and its public ossified over the last halfcentury, however, the businessman's outlook came to prevail: That is, if you hire 100 musicians for an evening, be sure they are onstage working at all times.
