description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 2 (AP)  The United Nations peacekeeping force said today that a Turkish soldier was killed during the night in a major violation of the sixmonthold Cyprus ceasefire.

title: Nassau Defendants to Be Given State Evidence, Starting Today
description: MINEOLA, L. T., Feb. 1A policy of fully disclosing to defendants in criminal cases material that could aid in their defense will start in Nassau County on Monday, Denis E. Dillon, the District Attorney, has announced.

title: TV: Saluting Charles and Ray Eames
description: An Eames Celebration, a 90minute documentary on Public Television at 8 o'clock this evening, wanders through the several worlds of Charles and Ray Eames. Charles, an architect by training, has been involved in projects of film making, science, mathematics and, pernaps Most notably, furniture desigu, which encompasses modern materials and massproduction techniques (the Eames chair"). Ray, an artist, has been his partner in marriage and professional work for about 30 years.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson Faculty Will Strike if Contract Talks Fail
description: RUTHERFORD, Feb. 2  On th eve of the first day of classes for the spring semester, more than 330 members of the faculty of Fairleigh Dickinson University voted today to sttike at noon Wednesday if agreement is not reached on a labor contract.

title: Allison F. Stanley, 78, Dies; ExHead of U.S. Playing Card
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 2  Allison F. Stanley, former president and board chairman of the U. S. Playing Card Company, died here yesterday at the age of 78.

title: ANDREW J. NOVAK
description: Andrew J. Novak, a retired stockbroker with Goodbody & Co. here, died Saturday in Belleair Bluff, Fla., where he lived. His age was 64.

title: RETAIL SUGAR COST A ILL REIAIN HIGH; Recent 50% Drop in Price for Refiners Will Not Be Reflected in Near Term
description: Consumers who expect retail! sugar prices to follow the recent 50 per cent drop in market quotations for raw sugar in bulk will be disappointed.

title: Miss Krupsak and Cuomo Are Given Similar Duties
description: ALBANY, Feb. 2  Two recent political rivals, Lieut. Gov. Mary Ann Krupsak and Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo, have been charged by Governor Carey with new localgovernment responsibilities, and some Democrats in the new administration are wondering whether there is enough room for the two of them among the state's grassroots.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Oil Indicated in Sri Lanka
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Feh. 2Soviet oil experts conducting offshore tests here believe they have found structures that could yield a minumum of 200 million tons of crude oil in the Palk Strait, the narrow strip or water separating Sri Lanka from neighboring lndia. Sri Lanka is now planning a crash program for oil with the first exploratory production well to he drilled in March.

title: Senator Baker Foresees WideOpen Race in G.O.P., With Ford Out
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. greeted former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson at the Alfalfa Club dinner last weekend with, I expect we'll be seeing a lot of each other in New Hampshire next year.

title: Alison P. Heydt Is Bride of Lawyer
description: Alison P. Heydt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman A. Heydt Jr. of New York and Oyster Bay, L.i., was married here yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents to B. KoYung Tung. He is a son of Mrs. Hung Fong Tung of Washington and C.Y. Chen of Brussels and Tainei.

title: Pro Slalom Race Taken By Kashiwa
description: MOUNT SNOW, Vt., Feb. Henry Kashlwa, the Canadianborn Japanese operator of a general store in the New York Adirondack community of Old Forge, hugged his 25yearold son, Hank, today after seeing him win the $15,000 Benson & Hedges pro slalom race.

title: Attacks on Oil Industry Grow Fiercer
description: The oil industry, one of the largest and most conspicuous in the country, has always had its share of critics, but the energy crisis, which spawned sharply higher oil and gas prices, as well as shortages and huge profits for the oil companies, has triggered a new series of public attacks.

title: Tomato Growers Await the Effect of Recession
description: CAMDEN South Jersey, aiready alarmed bout prospects of layoffs in its big glass industry because of a naturalgas shortage, now is concerned also about the effect of the recession on agriculture.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Except for the soft whir of an occasional bicycle, a ghostly quiet has settled on the city's biggest ruin, the old elevated West Side Highway south of 46th Street.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Britain's Very Special Prosecutor
description: LONDON, Feb. 2Britain's Independent special prosecutor is so independent that he has never met a prime minister and so special that people generally are unclear about what he does.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Another blow was struck for men's fashion freedom the other day, this time by the Anne Klein organization, which didn't have to wreak too much havoc on its concepts of dressing women to turn out respectable men's clothes.

title: City Considers Direct Sale Of Its Notes to the Public
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin is seriously considering an idea to sell municipal notes directly to the general public, bypassing the investment syndicates that have lately been charging interest rates the city deems excessive.

title: Panovs, on Eve of Debut,in Leg?al Snarl
description: On the eve of their joint American debut tomorrow at, Philadelphia's Spectrum arena, Valery Panov and his wife, Galina Ragozina, have becomed involved in a legal dispute with their former manager, who, their lawyer says, felt entitled to become a ,dealer in their services by buying low and selling high and keeping the profit fot himself.

title: Changes Announced At Interpublic Group
description: Armando M. Sarmento, one of the three vice chairmen of the lnterpublic Group of Companies, will retire on June 30 after 40 years with the company. Mr. Sarmento has been vice chairmaninternational of the world's largest agency organization and he will be succeeded in that post by Philip H. Geier, the 40yearold vice chairmaninternational of McCannErickson, Interpublic's largest component.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: Those who buy 1975 autoMobiles to take advantage of the rebates may find themselves spending some of that money on engine tuneups and adjustments, according to a petroleumindustry spokesman.

title: Fezler Is in Lead,. Palmer Tied for 2d
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 2Forrest (Fuzzy) Fezler, a 25yearold California pro who has made a remunerative career of secondplace finishes, took charge of the Hawaiian open today.

title: Machinists Threaten Strike
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 2 (UPI)Members of Machinists Union District 837 voted today to go on strike in one week at the McDonnell Douglas Corporationl plants if a new contract is no negotiated.

title: Nixon Said to Like Idea Of Being China Envoy
description: Richard M. Nixon has told close friends that, he would not turn, down a chanae to become United States Ambassador to China, Time magazine reported yesterday.

title: Taxing Gasoline . . .
description: The fatal flaw in the Administration's arguments against a gasoline tax is the assumption that all uses of petroleum are equalequally necessary or equally wasteful, equally desirable for social or economic health. Thus, President Ford insists on a tariff on all crude oil imports rather than a higher excise tax on gasoline alone.

title: Orr Gets Goal, 4 Assists As Bruins Check Flyers
Victory Is 6th for Expansion Club
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2 Pete Maravich ignited a fast break offense midway through the third period as the New Orleans Jazz broke open a tight game and defeated the New York Knicks tonight, 118114. It was only the Jazz's sixth victory of the season.

title: Title Bout Set
description: MANILA, Feb. 2 (AP)A world championship fight between the junior lightweight champion, Ben Villaflor of the Philippines, and Kim HyunChi of South Korea has been set here for March 14.

title: Ballet: Suzanne Farrell in Bug?aku
description: As the returned Suzanne Farrell edges her way back into New York City Ballet's repertory, fresh aspects of her development are revealed. Saturday night at the New York State Theater she danced the leading role in Bugaku for the first time since rejoining the company, partnered in it by Anthony Blum.

title: HURD TO TESTIFY IN BERGMAN CASE
description: T. Norman Hurd, who was executive secretary to Governors Nelson A. Rockefeller and Malcolm Wilson, will testify on Friday about his efforts on behalf of Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome promoter, it was disciosed yesterday.

title: . . . and Dust to Dust
description: AKRON, OhioRecycling has always been a part of the scheme of nature, and it probably always will be; it may even be considered to be a law of nature. The world consists of finite amounts of the various elements, and aside from the radioactive decomposition of some, these quantities will remain constant. The elements do not wear out and they are just as effective after many uses as they were originally.

title: About New York
description: The last time anyone counted. Manhattan was worth 818,980,155,521, which was the assessed value of its real estate, or about $10billion more than Queens. There are thinrzs in Manhattan that are worth as much as whole other cities; Radio City alone is assessed at $152.5million.

title: Magazine Research
description: Frank Stanton, president of W. R. Simmons & Associates, proclaimed last week a banner one for magazine research after two studies showed gratifying results. The Purchase Influence Study released on Tuesday showed a completion rate of 79 per cent and the Advertising Research Foundation reported on Thursday that Simmons had a 78 per cent recovery rate. Page 40.

title: Nearby Horse Shows
description: AT MELVILLE, L.I.

title: MANILA MATCH SITE IS FISCHER'S CHOICE
description: Bobby Fischer, the world chess champion, named Manila yesterday as his preference for the site of a title match later this year with Anatoly Karpov, the Russian challenger. Manila has offered a highbid purse of $5million for the match.

title: SYSTEMS OF EXAMS IN JAPAN ASSAILED
description: TOKYO, Feb. 2The new Education Minister, Michio Nagai, has spoken out against Japan's traditional reliance on entrance examinations from kindergarten to the university, terming them excessively competitive.

title: Taylor Beats Gerulaitis
description: ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 2 (AP) Roger Taylor of England, who said he hasn't won a tournament with a good field since early 1973, upset Vitas Gerulaitis of Howard Beach, Queens, 76, 76, in the final today of the Roanoke international tennis tournament.

title: 22 Senators Ask That Kissinger Take Charge of Sea Law Talks
Who Lost Vietnam?
description: BOSTON, Feb. 2  In arguing for continued American involvement in Vietnam, Henry Kissinger for years has stressed the need to avoid political trauma in this country. If the Saigon Government fell after what we had spent in lives and money, he warned, there could be a terrible rightwing reaction in the United States.

title: In Memoriam
description: WEINSTEINHarry. It has lust been one year, and you have been just one great LOVE. Our thoughts and feelings are forever with you.

title: Bye Bye, Blackbird
description: It is intolerable that the United States Army seriously contemplates the mass slaughter of millions of blackbirds that congregate each winter in pine groves adjoining Fort Campbell, Ky., and the Milan Army Ammunition Plant in Tennessee. The spraying of these huge flocks of starlings, grackles, cowbirds and redwing blackbirds with a detergent that dissolves protective oils in feathers and thereby causes death could begin as early as this week unless this ugly scheme is halted.

title: Mexico Ousts U.S. In Davis Cup Play; Connors Triumphs
description: Mexico scored only its second Davis Cup tennis victory in history over the United States yesterday when Raul Ramirez defeated Roscoe Tanner, a lefthander from Tennessee, 75, 79, 64, 62, in the North American zone final at Palm Springs, Calif. Mexico won the competition, three matches to two.

title: Icrseli Bus Bombed
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 2 (UPI)A small explosive device went, off on a Jerusalem city bus injuring two persons slightly, according to the police, who also said they found another bomb on the bus later. Another explosive device was found in an apartment house in East Jerusalem, but the police reported that they had dismantled it safely.

title: Space Rookies Set Soviet Orbit Mark On 22d Day in Lab
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 2 (UPI)Tho rookie astronauts, in their 22d day aboard Salyut4, set a Soviet space record today for time spent in an orbital laboratory.

title: Walk, Barnett Lift Playoff Hopes
description: Coming to New York may be the getwell prescription for an unhappy Neal Walk and the stumbling Knicks.

title: Islanders And Hawks In 11 Tie
Oil Consumers Could Ease Producer Fears, Briton Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain said in a television interview broadcast today that oilconsuming countries could do a lot to set producers fears at rest at a forthcoming conference of the two sides.

title: Civil Service Agency Bars Jobs Referrals by Members
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) The United States Civil Service Commission has banned its members and employes from recommending applicants for Federal jobs.

title: Conference Board Says U.S. Energy Could Be Reduced
description: The United States can reduce its energy growth rate significantly without damaging the economy, a Conference .Board study released today indicated.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 2 (UPI)Montreal Mayor Jean Drapeau said today that if he failed in his selffinancing scheme for the 1976 Montreal Olympics, future games would become the private preserve of rich cities and nations. Drapeau noted that the International Olympic Committee accepted Montreal's bid based partly on its promise to set an example for smaller nations.

title: Health Chief Assailed Ford Policy Before Quitting
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Dr. Charles C. Edwards, who resigned last month as the nation's chief health officer, told the Ford Administration in a memorandum that its health policies were bad medical judgment, bad politics and likely to be catastrophic for the American people.

title: 3 Die When Police in India Fire on Moslem Protesters
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 2 (UPI)Three persons were killed and 50 were wounded today when policemen fired on a crowd of Moslems protesting the arresti of their reliaious leader.

title: MRS. G. H. M'CRACKEN
description: MIAMI, Feb. 2Helen Kahl McCracken, wife of G. Herbert McCracken, cofounder of Scholastic Magazines and chairman of its executive committee, died here yesterday. She was 72 years old and formerly lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: 2 POLICEMEN DIE TRADING GUNFIRE IN MIDTOWN AREA
description: A city police officer and an offduty Housing Authority policeman were killed yesterday and another housing officer was wounded in a predawn shootout between policemen on Lexington Avenue just south of 51st Street.

title: South Korean Army's Loyalty to Park Shows Signs of Cracking
description: SEOUL, South Korea Feb. 1  The loyalty of the South Korean Army to President Park Chung Hee has begun to show cracks that could jeopardize his hold on power.

title: Suspect in Subway Death To Undergo Mental Test
description: A 43yearold mailman, accused by at least four witnesses of pushing a young womana stranger to himto her death under an IND train in Brooklyn, was remanded to Kings County Hospital yesterday for psychiatric examination at the request of his lawyer.

title: City Taxi Fleets Reported In Deep Trouble Fiscally
description: Despite last fall's 17.5 per cent taxifare increase, the economic health of the fleets has deteriorated to the point of crisis, according to Eric .J. Schmertz, the impartial chairman between the city's licensed cab owners and the drivers union.

title: DRISCOLL'S STATUS ON PANEL IN DOUBT
description: Governor Byrne is reported to be seriously considering not reappointing former Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll as chairman of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

title: Legal Abortions Up 53% Since Court Ruled in 73
description: More than 745,000 legal abor. tions were performed in thE United States in 1973an in crease of 27 per cent over the total for 1972according to thE findings of the first nationwide survey to measure the impact of the landmark Supreme Court decision on abortion two year ago.

title: Police Pay Last Respects To Slain Civilian Comrade
description: From early afternoon until late yesterday evening, bluecoated policemen from precincts in the city's five boroughs, together with Commissioner Michael J. Codd, paid their respects to Frank J. Walker, the 28yearold father of six children who died while going to the aid of a police officer.

title: Rangers Tie
description: Despite four goals by Rod Gilbert and a 40 lead, the New York Rangers could manage only a 55 tie yesterday with the jowly Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden,

title: Held in Death of Children, Man Tries to Kill Himself
description: Robert E. Mottershead, a New York stockbroker indicted for killing two of his children in a fit of despondency Last summer, was in critical condition yesterday after swal[owing an overdose of drugs at Trenton Psychiatric Hospital, where he had been committed.

title: Marine Midland Comments On Fidelity Mortgage Filing
description: Fidelity Mortgage Investors, which filed under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act last Thursday, did so because of the unexpected failure of parties to a. credit agreement to effect a timely renewal of that complex arrangement, Marine Midland Banks, Inc., announced over the weekend.

title: The Rabbit Punch
description: WASHINGTONIn a few days, Senator Henry Jackson is expected to announce officially that he is a candidate for President of the United States.

title: Ramirez Tops Tanner for Clincher
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 2The United States is out of the Davis Cup, beaten by Mexico's oneman band, Raul Ramirez. The 2Iyearold from Ensenada, now a national hero, won from Roscoe Tanner today, 75, 79, 64, 62, to go along with his firstday victory over Stan Smith and his doubles triumph yesterday with Vicente Zarazua. Bamirez and Zarazua upset Bob Lutz and Dick Stockton in a tremendous fivesetter.

title: Some Unstartling Contemporary Chairs
description: A small exhibition of contemporary seating, called Designer's Saturday, has opened at the Brooklyn Museum. The name requires an explanation.

title: 9 IN WEST TEXAS DIE OF OIL WELL FUMES
description: DENVER CITY, Tex., Feb. 2 (UPI)Nine persons, including an oil company employe summoned by a call for help, were killed by fumes today when an unattended carbon dioxide injection system designed to squeeze more oil from a West Texas well ruptured.

title: Kuwait, on Dollar's Drop, To Seek OilPrice Talks
description: KUWAIT, Feb. 2 (Reuters)Kuwait wants a meeting of oilproducing nations to discuss oil prices in light of a recent 6 per cent decline in the purchasing power of the dollar, Finance and Oil Minister AbdelRahman alAtioi said today.

title: White House Portrait of Washington Is Called Fake
description: Did Gilbert Stuart really paint the fulllength portrait of peorge Washington that hangs in the East Room of the:, White House? The question, which art historians have asked from time to time, has now been raised again by Marvin Sadik, director of the National Portrait Gallery in Washington.

title: Real Test for Carey
description: In moving to aholisil or consolidate 20 state boards, commissions and councils, Governor Carey has spotlighted the problem of seldomshow state government officials who receive substantial salaries and pensions for little work. Not that the Governor has by any means solved the problem. Even Carey aides concede that the Governor has hardly had time for a major attack on the problem of politicians who believe that the taxpayers should, in effect, reward them for their past politicking or underwthe it for the future. Indeed, a Carey spokesman pledged a continuing review of state agencies and their effectiveness.

title: Secessionist Movement Gnaws at Ethiopia's Existence
description: ASMARA, Ethiopia  Disintegration of the Ethiopian empire seems to be a real threat as the three million people of Eritrea express more and more support for secession.

title: . . . and Autos
description: The social and economic judgment that underlies President Ford's abhorrence of a gasoline tax centers on an exaggerated pride of place which he assigns to the automobile industry. However, the unpalatable fact is that the directions pursued in car design and marketing over the past decade and the infrastructure of highways and community development that this trend has promoted have distorted the economic growth and social wellbeing of the nation.

title: Israel Forms Special Committee To Decide Military Operations
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 2The Israeli Cabinet voted today to set up a ministerial committee to decide on military operations.

title: Britain and Sugar Nations Reach a Price Agreement
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 2 (Agence France Presse)Britain agreed last night to pay 260 pounds about $620 a ton for sugar delivered by African, Caribbean and Pacific countries under an agreement with the European Common Market.

title: A.T.&T. MONITORED MILLIONS OF CALLS;     Recorded Some in 196570 Bid to Curb Toll Fraud Sees No Illegality
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it monitored millions of longdistance calls between 1965 and 1970 as part of a campaign to stop cheating on toll charges.

title: Old Trouper on Social Security Circuit
description: HOLMES, N.Y.  Baby Face, you've got the cutest little baby face . . . Mortimer Cheshire on the bonestwo ebony rods clacking away in each hand, beating out the tune, the rhythm get.ting everybody humming.

title: Nets Rout Q's, 12690; 31by Kenon
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 2Not even a guest squad of championship cheerleaders from the Connetquot, L.I. school district could stir up much enthusiasm in a crowd of 8,822 in the Nassau Coliseum today, but the New York Nets didn't need any as they crushed San Diego, 12690.

title: CHURCH URGES FORD TO ASSIST INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, asked President Ford today to order the intelligence community to cooperate with the special Senate cmmittee investigating alleged illegal surveillance activities by Federal agencies.

title: CORRECTION
description: The New York Times, through an editing error, incorrectly reported yesterday that the Central Intelligence Agency was under a Justice Department subpoena in early August, 1972, when Richard Helms, then Director of Central Intelligence, ordered the agency to withhold information. The subpoena, ordering the C.I.A. to produce all Watergate communications, not in effect at the time.

title: NATO TOLD U.S. PLANS TO UPGRADE TROOPS
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Feb. 2 (AP)Secretary of the Army Howard H. Callaway said at a NATO conference today that American combat strength in Europe would be increased during 1975 and that this trend would continue over the next few years.

title: Tax DisDute Halts Canada's Potash Growth
description: SASKATOON, SaskatchewanTwothirds of a mile beneath the snowcovered wheat fields that stretch out in every direction here lies the world's richest deposit of potash, a fertilizer now urgently needed to grow food for a hungry world.

title: Stolid Ravel and Berlioz
description: The National Symphony Orchestra offered an afternoon of French music yesterday at Avery Fisher Hall, with two works by Ravel to help celebrate the composer's centenary.

title: Local Writers Touch All Bases While Honoring Brock, Aaron
description: New York's baseball writers buried the summer of 1974 under songs and citations last night, with Lou Brock emerging as the man of the year and Henry Aaron as the man of the hour.

title: U.S. Woman's Detention in Italy, In AbortionClinic Case Assailed
description: ROME, Feb. 2Attorneys for an American woman imprisoned more than two weeks ago on the ground that she was involved with an abortion clinic in Florence have issued a statement expressing amazement that authorities have not released her pending trial, as they have other such defendants.

description: Hickory Smoked Chicken or Game

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Representative Al Ullman, chairman of the taxwriting House Ways and Means Committee, said today that Democrats in Congress might offer an immediate tax cut as large as $22billion, or $6billion larger than Dcdnt Fnrci'c nronosal.

title: Nicolaysen Is Victor in Ski Jump
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 2Richard Nicolaysen of Ossining, a Columbia University student, captured the New York State ski jumping championship today with the longest official leap of 158 feet. There were longer jumps but the skiers fell.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Pact S et on Abbey Seizure; Indians Will Get Property
description: SHAWANO, Wis., Feb. 2An agreement was reached today to end peacefully the 33day occupation of an unused Roman Catholic abbey by armed Menominee Indians and to deed the property to the Menominee tribe.

title: DR. BALAN VENKATRAMAN
description: Dr. Balan Venkatraman, a professor in the aerospace engineering and applied mechanics department of the Polytechnic Institute of New York, died Saturday at his home in Irvington, N.Y. He was 52 years old.

description: Prisoner Attempts Suicide in Hospital

title: Promise of Substantial Aid From Iran Buoys Military Regime in Afghanistan
description: AT THE SALANG PASS, AfghanistanMohammed Afzal waved his arm toward the huge eagle newly emblazoned over the southern mouth of the Salang Highway Tunnel, which burrows between the snowy crags of the Hindu Kush.

title: 2 Thai Helicopters Crash
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 2 (AP)The rotors of two Thailand helicopters became entangled in midair on Friday and both helicopters crashed, killing. all 10 crew members, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today.

title: S.O.R.C. Event Won By Mondry
Paul Wilson Stocks His Dances With Spirit of Competitiveness
description: Paul Wilson's choreography is kwacky jumble of eccentric dramatic incidents_ and una;dorned movement pieces. He showed six dances Saturday evening at the American Theathe Laboratory with his Theater.Dance Asylum. The word Asylum should he understhod as a haven rather than a: lockup, for Mr. Wilson offered Rebecca Kelly the chance to show Night Migrations, arid Julie Maloney danced her Conversation.

title: Personal Finance: Consumer Disputes
description: The new Consumer Product Warranty Law, signed by the President on Jan. 4 and whose major provisions become effective six months later, contains many sections affecting the relationship between individuals and business. But perhaps none is more important than the one about procedures for informal settlernent of disputes.

title: Russians Laud James Bond as ExSpy
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 2James Bond, that suave superspy of novel and film, has been reviewed more kindly by the Soviet press now that he has given up matching wits with Soviet agents and turned his talents to foiling apolitical master criminals.

title: RETAIL SUGAR COST WILL REMAIN HIGH
description: Consumers who expect retail sugar prices to follow the recent 50 per cent drop in market quotations for raw sugar in bulk will be disappointed.

description: Feb. 3, 1975 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Commission on International Trade Law, working group10 A.M. and 3 P.M. DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM Governing Council3 P.M.

title: Consumer Complaints Can Be Made by Phone
description: TRENTON, Feb. 2 (AP) Two actionline telephone numbers established by the State Division of Consumer Affairs will begin operation tomorrow.

title: Mrs. Young Golf Victor By 3 Shots
description: MIAMI, Feb. 2 (AP)Donna Caponi Young closed with a fiveunderpar 67 today to win a 840,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament. Her 54hole total of 208, eight under par, was three strokes ahead of Kathy Cornelius.

title: Maurice Blitz Dies at 83; Club Mediterranee Founder
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 2 (AP)Maurice Blitz, cofounder of the Club Mecliterranee and former Olympic athlete, died today. He was 83 years old.

title: EGYPT SAID TO SHIFT TO ARMS FROM WEST
description: Egypt has adopted a fiveyear plan to reequip her armed forces with French and British weapons, according to an article in Newsweek magazine quoting highlevel Egyptian sources.

title: Bridge:
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Feb. 2A saddened American team returned to the mainland today after suffering a stunning defeat yesterday in the worldchampionship finals against Italy. The Americans had led by such a commanding margin that the Bermuda radio station even broadcast a premature report that they had won.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Tomorrow, Feb. 4

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Spring Lake Heights, a Monmouth County borough, has become the third shore community to adopt a controversial ordinance banning the rental of homes by more than two unrelated people. The ordinance, adopted at a Council meet, ing last week, is based on the liberalized wording of a Long Island zoning statute that was upheld by the United States Supreme Court last year:

title: Richard Wattis, 62, Is Dead; Character Actor in Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 2Richard Wattis, a British character actor who appeared in more than 100 films, died of heart attack yesterday. He was 62 years old.

title: IRAN SO TO VOW DEFENSE OF OMAN; Teheran Reported to Give Commitment to Protect Country on Oil Route
description: RUWI, Oman, Feb. 2 Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran has guaranteed Oman's airspace against intruding foreign aircraft by committing his air force to combat the intruders if Oman so requests, the commander of Oman's armed forces said today.

title: Blood Sports
description: A charge of aggravated assault brought by a Minnesota grand jury against a young man named Dave Forbes has caused a special kind of anguish in one of those precious worlds whose devotees attempt to set it apart from the necessary but dreary rules of ordinary life.

title: Advertising
description: It's been a banner week for magazine research. said Frank Stanton, an enthusiastic person by nature, last Friday. Mr. Stanton is president of W. R. Simmons & Associates, whose major function is syndicated magazine audience research. How so banner? he was asked.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Article 1  No Title
Thailand's Free Election
description: Thailand's freest and fairest national election in history has ended with the return of 22 parties to the 269seat House of Representatives, twelve of them with only one to four seats. The two main blocs of conservative and centrist parties have both fallen about thirty seats short of a likeminded majority.

title: Serge Taneyew, ExBanker And Russian Army Officer
description: Serge A. Taneyew, a retired banker and former Russian Army officer, died Saturday at his home, 16 East 96th Street. He was 86 years old.

title: LIEDER ARE SUNG BY HERMANN PREY
description: Since Hermann Prey's singing of Schubert's Die Winterreise Saturday night at Carnegie Hall was an event of considerable artistic distinction, it is a pity that the impact had to be weakened by the filming of it for German television. Why ticketbuyers for a serious concert should have to put up with this without prior warning Mr. Prey's management did not say. It did, however, ask for audience cooperation in making the evening an unforgettable occasion.

title: Ida Cook Farber, 77, Dies, Led B'nai B'rith Women
description: Ida Cook Farber, a past president of the Brooklyn Women's Bar Association and of B'nai B'rith Women, a national organization, died Friday in Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. She was 77 years old, the widow of Abraham Farber, an architect, and lived at 200 East 18th Street. Brooklyn.

title: EXF.B.I, OFFICIAL TESTIFIED AGNEW WAS RESTIGATED; Senate Staff Told of Check Before 1968 Election at Request of Johnson
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 The former No. 3 man in the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified under oath in 1973 that the bureau investigated Spiro T. Agnew shortly before the 1968 election at the request of President Johnson.

title: INTEREST LEVELS TRENDING LOWER
Head of Equal Employment Unit
description: The chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, John Powell, reportedly plans to place before the fivemember commission a set of proposed guidelines designed to resolve the growing conflict between union seniority claims and Federal laws on equal employment opportunity.

title: SOVIET IMPRISONS A BAPTIST LEADER
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 2Georgi P. Vins, leader of a Baptist movement here, has been sentenced to five years in prison to be followed by five years in exile for unauthorized religious activities, Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, reported today.

title: Suspect in Subway Death To Undergo Mental Test
description: A 43yearold mailman, accused by at least four witnesses of pushing a young womana stranger to himto her death under an IND train in Brooklyn, was remanded to Kings County Hospital yesterday for psychiatric examination at the request of his lawyer.

title: WANDA G. WRIGHT, EDUCATOR, 68, DIES
description: Wanda Grutzner Wright, who retired in 1972 as principal of Public School 106 for emotionally and mentally disturbed children in Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital, died Saturday at her home, 102 Quaker Path, Stony Brook, LI. She was 68 years old and the wife of Laverne Wright, a retired newspaper man and public relations aide.

title: Fatal Margin for Error
description: Though still incomplete, the inquiry by the National Transportation Safety Board into the crash of a jetliner during an approach to Dulles International Airport last December has already revealed incredible ambiguities in landing procedures. Two other aircraft had narrowly escaped disaster under similar circumstances. Yet pilots and aircontrollers continue to debate the meaning of instructions under conditions that allow for no margin for error.

title: U.S., in Difficult Decision, Weighs Easing Embargo on the Sale of Weapons to Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The United States is considering relaxing its embargo on the sale of arms to Pakistan to permitl her to buy certain kinds of military equipment barred for the last 10 years, Administration officials said today. The disclosure came in advance of the arrival here on Tuesday of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan.

title: The Screen: Rafferty
24 Aliens Found in Truck
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 (UPI) A routine check of a large truck in the Venice area early today led to the arrest of 24 illegal aliens who had been huddled together without food or water in the bay of the truck for two days. The driver, Arthur Nusoen, 48 years old, of San Diego, was arrested and charged with suspicion of smuggling aliens.

title: Vladimir Spivakov, A Soviet Violinist, Performs Winningly
description: Complaints are common about performer competitions. Musicians ruin their lives preparing for them, we are told, and then all but the winners sink from sight.

title: McKellen, Miss Hamill Head U.S. Skate Team
description: OAKLAND, Calif.: Feb. 2The East Coast took the individual championships, but the West Coast came up with three top skaters in the national figure skating competition that was concluded last night at the Oakland Coliseum. From these leading performers a United States team was selected today for the world championships in Colorado Springs in March.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
Conflicts in U. S. Tennis
description: Pride and politics, familiar doubles partners in bigtime tennis, produced yesterday's strange sequence of events that saw Jimmy Connors win $100,000 while the United States Davis Cup team again was beaten, this time by Mexico.

title: CORRECTION
description: The New York Times, through an editing error, incorrectly reported yesterday that the Central Intelligence Agency was under a Justice Department subpoena in early August, 1972, when Richard Helms, then Director of Central Intelligence, ordered the agency to withhold information. The subpoena, ordering the C.T.A. to produce all Watergate communications, not in effect at the time.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: WhereThat Smoky Taste Comes From
description: It is axiomatic that smoke cookery and the preservation of foods through smoking are almost as old as fire. It is also true that the original smoking process came about not to enhance the flavor of food but rather to make it last from one season to the next.

title: Judge Supports Consensual Sodomy
description: Homosexuals and other unmarried persons have the same legal right to engage in consensual sodomy as married persons, a Suffolk County District Court judge has ruled.

title: Ethiopia Reported to Hold A sirnara After Heavy Fight
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia , Monday, Feb. 3  Ethiopia's military Government ordered bombers, armored units and elite troops into operation against secessionist guerrillas in Eritrea Province yesterday, official sources said.

title: Obscure Bruin Gets A Place in the Sun
description: Pete Trgovich is the quickest and probably the least known of the U.C.L.A. basketball players. In three varsity seasons the 6foot5inch swing man has had to live in the shadows of Bill Walton, Keith Wilkes, Greg Lee, Dave Meyers, Richard Washington and Marques Johnson.

title: Spring's Coming Soon, Groundhog Indicates
description: PUNXSUTAWNEY, Pa., Feb. 2 (AP)Punxsutawney Phil, squinting from his interrupted winter sleep, missed his shadow today for the first time in 15 years. Local experts say it means spring is just around the corner.

title: Sifford Is Victor
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. (AP)Charlie Sifford rolled in a 25foot birdie putt on the first hole of a suddendeath playoff today to win the Professional Golfers Association Seniors tournament.

title: ROY CLARK REWRAPS A COUNTRY PACKAGE
description: Roy Clark brought a most expensive looking countrymusic package to the city for his part in the Country in New Nork series at the Felt Forum on Saturday. He surrounded himself with a iarge oichestra, five backup singers. Diana Trask (a fine Australianborn, Nashvillesounding singer) and, borrowing a trick from the rockers, a man to send dryice fumes across the stage.

title: ALEXANDER M. BURNHAM
description: Alexander M. Burnham, secretarytreasurer of Reader Mail, Inc., distributor of syndicated dress and needlework patterns to periodicals, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 83 years old and lived in Neponsit, Queens, and Montego Bay, Jamaica.

title: Article 7  No Title
Italy to Cut Oil Imports in New Energy Program
description: ROME, Feb. 3Premier Aldo Moro, warning that Italy could not hope to overcome her deep recession before late in 1976, announced today a new energy program to cut Italy's oil imports $500million to $600million annually.

title: Lefkowitz Moves Against Operators Of the Park Plaza
description: Calling the Park Plaza Hotel at 50 West 77th Street chamber of horrors, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that his office had started court action to dissolve the corporation operating the singleroom  occupancy hotel and to gain the appointment of a receiver to evict tenants engaged in unlawful activities.

title: Charter Agency Proposes `Service Districts for City
description: The administrative restructuring of the city into 40 50 service districts, each with its own police, sanitation, parks, health and other service units, was recommended yesterday by the State Charter Revision Commission.

title: Tricolor Cover Breaks Precedent for Document
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The cover of the new budget is a modernistic design in red, white and blue. It is the first time in history that redthe symbol of losses and deficits has been used on a budget. cover.

title: Uplift Through Shot and Shell
description: The average person rarely meets any terrorists, except those connected. with the Government, and so, in our ignorance of them, we tend to think of them as bestial and inhuman. This probably does them a cruel injustice.

title: TWA 747 Sets Speed Mark
description: LONDON, Feb. 3 (UPI)  A Trans World Airlines 747 jet carrying 196 passengers and crew of 15 set a speed record today for a commercial flight from Los Angeles to London. An airlines spokesman said Flight 760 covered the 5,458 mile route in 8 hours, 54 minutes8 minutes faster than the previous mark, also held by a TWA jet. The average speed was 662.25 miles an hour.

title: TV: Dialer's Quandary
description: With an unerring instinct for frustrating the public, ABC and NBC are running two aboveaverage drama productions against each other this evening. Death Be Not Proud, based on John Gunther's account of the death of his son at the age of 17 in 1947, is on ABC from 8 P.M. to 10 P.M. All Creatures Great and Small, James Herriot's bestselling book dealing with the early years of a British veterinarjan, is on NBC from 8:30 P.M. 10 P.M.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A group of officials representing 23 North Jersey towns in Passaic and Bergen Counties said they would raise $69,000 to fight a requested $8.7million rate increase Orange Re Rockland Utilities, Inc.

title: Market Place
description: The professionals in Wall Street are inclined to be very skeptical of stock tips, but there is one Wall Street trader who is a little upset that he did not listen to one he got three months ago.

title: SCOVILL AND BRUSH CUT COPPER PRICES
description: The price decline in various copper and copperbased products continued yesterday as several producers followed actions mons made by manfacturers Oast week

title: No.1 Indiana Wins, 7448; Streak at 24
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 3 (AP) Bobby Wilkerson led a balanced Indiana attack with 18 points tonight as the unbeaten, topranked Hoosiers trounced Michigan, 7446, in a Big Ten game.

title: Parties in War of Words Over Furniture in Albany
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3 In deserted corridors in the legislative office building, employes of Assembly Democrats turned passkeys in Republican office doors over the weekend.

title: Poor and Elderly
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Federal programs that serve the poor and elderlycommunity health and mental health centers, Medicaid, food stamps, welfare, child nutrition programs, Federal pensions and income plans are the object of cuts in the 1976 fiscal budget, which seeks to hold down Federal spending, especially in social programs.

title: Poll Finds Ford Standing At New Low With Public
description: President Ford's overall public standing has hit a new low,, with 60 per cent of the Amen; man people rating him negatively, the Harris Poll reported yesterday. It was down 10 percentage points from the previous month.

title: Reduction Planned At Willowbrook
description: New York State's top mental health official said that he hoped to reduce still further  by 8OO patients  the population of the Willowbrook Development Center, the muchcriticized state school for the mentally retarded on Staten Island.

title: Amerada Hess Net Off Atlantic Richfield Gains
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation announced yesterday 48.6 per cent decline in profits for the fourth quarter arid the Atlantic Richfield Corporation a 5.7 per cent advance.

title: DEFICIT IS VIEWED WITH RESIGNATION
Los Angeles Man Calls Miss Hearst Kidnapper
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 3 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that a Los Angeles man has identified a woman who kidnapped him last week as Patricia Hearst, the fugitive heiress.

title: A Call to Sacrifice for the Next 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 While President Ford and his aides have been warning for months that ending the recession without rekindling inflation would require the nation to make sacrifices, the scope of the sacrifices they had in mind remained undisclosed until today. The scope is stunning.

title: ATLANTIC CITY FIRE LEVELS 2 BUILDINGS
description: A fire destroyed a 72yearold, ninestory apartment building and an AAP. store in the heart of Atlantic City last night, forcing the evacuation of about 300 persons and slightly injuring three firemen.

title: Carey Selects State Patronage Chief
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3 Thomas Lynch, a Bronx lawyer closely identified with Patrick J. Cunningham, the new state Democratic chairman, has been quietly placed by Governor Carey in charge of the appointments office, the agency through which state patronage flows.

title: 2 Stations to Broadcast Ford News Conference
description: Two New York radio stations, WOR and the allnews station WINS, said yesterday that they planned to carry President Ford's news conference in Atlanta at 2:30 P.M. today.

title: Strip Mining Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) The House Interior Committee voted overwhelmingly today to set a Feb. 27 deadline for final committee action on strip mining bill vetoed by President Ford after passage by the last Congress. The legislation, as passed late last year, would impose strict controls on strip mining and estabilsh a fund to pay for reclamation of strip mined lands.

title: Suit Impugns Integrity of Judge On Freeing Drug Agent in Death
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3The parents of a man killed by a Federal narcotics agent in a 1972 drug raid have filed a suit, attacking the integrity of the judge who dismissed homicide charges against the agent.

title: Ash, Despite Huge Budget, Opposes Rise in Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Roy L. Ash, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, did not exactly practice what he preaches when he prepared President Ford's budget for the 1976 fiscal year.

title: Wood, Field &
description: The provisions of the Federal Boat Safety Act of 1971, as they apply to traditional unpowercd small craft were deplored by those who recently attended the Adirondack Guideboat Builders Conference at the Adirondack Museum in Blue Mountain Lake, N. Y.

title: Transportation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Ford Administration plans to propose longrange legislation that would permit part of the tax revenues now earmarked for highway construction to be spent for other purposes.

title: Jersey Seeking Data on Homes for Aged
description: Representatives of the New Jersey Attorney General will go before a grand jury in Trenton today, seeking authority to subpoena financial records of five nursing homes in the state, four of which have been associated with the interests of Bernard Bergman over a period of years.

title: Research
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The nation's growing appetite for energy accounts for most of the increase in the proposed budget for civilian research and development next year, while health research and the space program face lean and hungry 1976 fiscal year.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL. ROSE 2.3% IN WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended Feb. I advanced 2.3 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The trade association placed production for the week at 2,675,000 tons for production index of 109.6. This compares with production of 2,616,000 tons and an index level of 107.2 in the week of Jan. 25.

title: Gottfried Is Victor In Florida Tennis
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP)Brian Gottfried and Jeff Borowiak advanced to the second round of a World Championship Tennis tournament tonight.

title: TIMOTHY T. MERWIN
description: WILTON, Conn., Feb. 3 Timothy T. Merwin, a former coeditor of The Wilton Bulletin, a weekly newspaper, died Saturday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 19 Lovers Lane.

title: 120 Nations Meet at Geneva To Amend War Conventions
description: GENEVA, Feb. 3More than 120 nations began here today the second session of a conference convened by Switzerland to expand the four 1949 international conventions for insuring the humanitarian treatment of war victims.

title: PANAMA'S LEADER HOPEFUL ON CANAL
description: PANAMA CITY, Jan. 30Panama's Chief of Government has expressed confidence that the United States and Panama are moving toward agreement on a new treaty to govern the operation and defense of the Panama Canal.

title: $2.4MILLION GIVEN IN A MERGER SUIT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (UPI) A jury award of $2.4million in damages to a New Jersey businessman and three others was approved today by Judge Clarence C. Newcomer in United States District Court.

title: Gromyko, in Cairo, Hints Views Differ
description: CAIRO, Feb. 3  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and Ismail Fahmy, his Egyptian counterpart, hinted today at deepseated differences between the two countries in surprisingly frank public statements following three hours of talks.

title: Ranger Record Within Gilbert's Reach
description: One begins to wonder where Rod Gilbert of the New York Rangers would rank on the career scoring list if he hadn't suffered two serious back injuries. Despite spinal fusion operations in 1961 and 1965, Gilbert holds most of his club's career records. Last week he came down with the flu and missed four games. Last Sunday against the Detroit Red Wings he tallied four goals for the second time in his National Hockey League career, giving him 23 points in his last 10 games, including nine goals. No Ranger has ever scored more than four in one game.

title: Article 8  No Title
ExCommissioner Says Police Rate Higher Pay
description: Former Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday described the job of a police officer in New York City as the most complex and difficult in the country and gave testimony indicating that the police officer should have a higher salary than a fireman.

title: $17,000 Received by 6 Walker Children
description: Thousands of sympathy notes and cards accompanied by a total of more than $17,000 in checks and dollar bills yesterday poured into the offices of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and the Association for a Better New York. They came from residents of the Northeast concerned about the future of The six children whose father was fatally shot last Wednesday.

title: UDALL STUMPING FOR MONEY HERE
description: A harbinger of net. year's Presidential campaign, Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona quietly campaigned here yesterday not for votes, but for money.

title: Urn Kalthoum, Egyptian Singer, A Favorite of Millions, Is Dead
description: CAIRO, Feb. 3 (AP)  Urn Kalthoum, the Egyptian singer whose songs of love touched the hearts of millions of Arabs, died here today in a hospital, the official Middle East News Agency said. She was 77 years old and had suffered a cerebral hemorrhage Thursday.

title: Inferno DimThreat As Reality
description: Irwin Allen, the producer of The Towering Inferno, the film in which a 138story skyscraper burns as if it had been drenched with lighter fluid, says that he spent twoandahalf years researching the subject of highrise fires. But fire experts seem to agree that the film, which has set some New

title: People in Sports
description: When Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion, the coach of the Atlanta Flames of the National Hockey League since their inception in 1972 and Cliff Fletcher, the club's general manager, held a news conference early yesterday there was no indication that Geoffrion, a Hall of Fame member, might resign. The announcement of his resignation for personal reasons didn't come until last night. Geoffrion, who will remain with the Flames in another capacity, was adamant about not specifying his reasons for resigning. Geoffrion quit as Rangers Coach after stomach surgery, in January, 1969.

title: chess
description: When the sponsors of the Sombor, Yugoslavia, international tournament, in the interest of keeping down their overhead, decided to ask the participants to double up, it seemed natural to make roommates of countrymen. That way, if one player wanted to stay up all night analyzing, the other could complain irn their common tongue.

title: Inferno Dim Threat As Reality
description: Irwin Allen, the producer of The Towering Inferno, the film in which a 138story skyscraper burns as if it had been drenched with lighter fluid, says that he spent twoandahalf years researching the subject of highrise fires. But fire experts seem to agree that the film, which has set some New Yorkers worrying about whether the highrise buildings in which they spend their days are actually safe, is riddled with technical errors. Indeed, battalion chief Jack Cavallero of the San Francisco Fire Department, who served as technical adviser to the film, admits that the holocaust in The Towering Inferno was a way to sell a message to the people, a way to get a point across. But it wasn't very plausible, no.

title: Sonny Carson Sentenced To 7 Years in Kidnapping
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 3 Robert (Sonny) Carson, the civilrights activist and former director of Brooklyn CORE, was sentenced to up to seven years in prison today after having been convicted of seconddegree kidnapping.

title: JensenNew Man, New Ideas
description: Will Georg Jensen lose its Scandinavian accent for an Argentine one? Julio Tanjeloff, the store's new owner, says no, in English strongly flavored with the Spanish of his native Buenos Aires. Mr. Tanjeloff has just acquired the Madison Avenue specialty store and its five branches, from the Kenton Corporation, whose holdings are now down to Cartier and Mark Cross in New York. (Mr. Tanjeloff has also bought the Cartier wholesale division.)

title: 5 SAIGON PAPERS ARE CLOSED DOWN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 3The Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu closed down five opposition newspapers today and continued wave of arrests of journalists that began quietly during the weekend.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Mayor of New Britain Is Putting 509 Workers on a 4Day Week
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Feb. 3  To avert a projected $2.5million deficit, the Mayor of this old manufacturing city in central Connecticut today ordered half of the city's employes put on a fourday work week.

title: 2 THAI PARTIES PLAN A MINORITY REGIME
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 3 (AP)  The Democrat party and the Social Agrtarian party, both of which favor the continued presence of American troops in Thailand, announced today that they would try to form a minority government.

title: McDonnell Douglas Profits Off 31.4%
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, whose profits continued to slide for the fifth straight quarter, has slashed its estimate of the number of DC10 Trijets it expects to sell to 400 from 500 because of economic conditions. This disclosure was announced yesterday in its annual statement, which showed that fourth  quarter earnings fell 31.4 per cent and that annual earnings were down 20 per cent.

title: BITGET REQUESTS SHORT OF OUTLAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The $349.4billion that the Governin has said it plans to spend on the fiscal year 1976 is actually $90billion short of the real total of Federal outlays, according to a new method of calculating Government expenditures that is contained for they first time in the new budget.

title: Dr. Nathan Womack Dies; Professor at Chapel Hill
description: Dr. Nathan Anthony Womack, who retired in 1967 as professor and chairman of the department of surgery at the University of North Carolina, died Sunday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 73 years old.

title: Police Honor Slain Civilian With Inspector's Funeral
description: Nearly a thousand police oticers stood at attention yesterday morning in the cold shadow of the spire on St. Mary's Church in Long Island City, queens, to eulogize not one of their own, but an ordinary citizen, a widower with six children who was shot to death trying to help a policeman capture a deranged prisoner.

title: Cash Prices
description: METALS

title: Civic Redesign?
description: The first fruits of a twoyear effort by the State Charter Revision Commission to redesign New York City's government along lines of greater responsiveness to local needs provide a foundation for debate, if not much more.

title: Brown Coal Still Fuels East German Fires
description: KITTLITZ, East Germany  As giant coaldigging machines work unceasingly at the lignite strip mine near here, wild deer graze in a hayfield on reclaimed land beside it.

title: Some Businessmen Assert $52Billion Size May Cause More Inflation
description: Businessmen, traditional foes of deficit spending, yesterday seemed to be accepting with resignation the $52billion deficit that President Ford proposed for the fiscal 1976 Federal budget but, in a few cases, expressed support.

title: Film: Page of Madness
description: Fantasies and hallucinations mount and mingle and dissolve throughout Teinosuke Kinugasa's Page of Madness, a silent film set in an insane asylum that was made before The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari was ever shown in Japan. The print was believed to be long lost until a few years ago, when the director  who once studied with Eisenstein, and is mainly known in this country for Crossways (1928) and The Gate of Hell (1953)found a copy in his garden shed. That discovery is well worth celebrating, and the movie is at the Quad Cinema HI.

title: North Dakota Is 34th State To Back Equal Rights Bid
description: BISMARCK, N. D., Feb. 3 (AP) North Dakota became the 34th state to ratify the equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution when the House of Representatives passed the measure today. 52 to 49.

title: A RECORD DEFICIT; Figure of $51.9Billion Is Largest for Any Peacetime Period
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 President Ford submitted budget of $349.4billion to Congress today and disclosed his Administration's forecast that the nation's unemployment rate will hover at about 8 per cent of the labor force for the rest of this year and next year.

title: 5 Killed as Soldiers Clash With Blacks In Angolan Capital
description: LUANDA, Angola, Feb. 3 (Reuters)Five people were killed today when soldiers clashed with a crowd of black Angolans trying to ransack store in this capital city, Portuguese military spokesman said here.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Symphony No. 2, Beethoven; Ride of the Valkyrics and Magic Fire Music from Die Walkure, Wagner.

title: NURSING HOMES OFFER A DEFENSE
description: The executive director of the Metropolitan New York Nursing Home Association insisted yesterday that nursinghome, operators were not responsible for the medical care of their patients.

title: Notes on People
description: The Russians are coming. Some have already arrived at the Kennedy Space Center at Cocoa Beach, Fla., to check out the American equipment for the joint SovietAmerican manned space flight in July. Ten Soviet technicians are there now, and the twoman crew will arrive next weekend for three

title: Charter Agency Proposes Service Districts for City
description: The administrative restructuring of the city into 40 50 service districts, each with its own police, sanitation, parks, health and other service units, was recommended yesterday by the Slate Charter Revision Commission.

title: 4 Senators Plan Questions for Bergman
description: Four United States Senators, armed with the results of twoweek study of subpoenaed records, plan a rigorous questioning today of Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome promoter, according to aides of the Senate subcommittee on longterm care.

title: Aid to Localities
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The amount of Federal aid to state and local governments would increase by about $1.5billion in the Administration's proposed budget.

title: Patriarch Is Elected By Maronite Church
description: BKIRKI, Lebanon, Feb. 3A synod of 14 bishops of the Maronite Church elected Antonius Khreish, Archbishop of Saida, today as Patriarch of Lebanon's principal Christian community.

title: By Paul J. Growald and Paul R. Ehrlich
description: STANFORD, CalifFor many people the most sensible investment available today is neither gold nor Government Treasury notes. It's food. With the threat of bad weather and economic disaster, people with a cool, dry basement and spare cash should consider accumulating an emergency food supply.

title: KISSINGER UNVEILS U.S. PLAN TO SPUR NEW FUEL SOURCES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Secretary of State Kissinger unveiled an American plan today to aid the development of new sources of energy in the West. The plan calls for keeping the cost of imported oil high enough to encourage investment in the search for other forms of energy.

title: Bugner to Defend
description: MODENA, Italy, Feb. 3 (UPI)Joe Bogner of Britain has agreed to defend his European heavyweight boxing title against Dante Cane of Italy on March 1 in Bologna.

title: FISCHER AND KARPOV VIE ON CONTEST SITE
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 3The two contenders for the world chess title have shown preference for different sites for the match, in which Bobby Fischer of the United States is expected to play Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union.

title: Auburn Tops Tennessee
description: AUBURN, Ala., (AP)Dan Cox, thrust into Auburn's starting lineup because of an injury, scored six consecutive points in the closing minutes tonight to spark the 14thranked Tigers to a 6259 Southeastern Conference victory over No. 18 Tennessee.

title: Prisoner Accused Of Hospital Killing Attacks His Guard
description: A few hours after his arraignment on charges of killing a disabled widower and wounding a police officer, 19yearold Melvin Lewis last night assaulted a guard escorting him from the Criminal Court building in Manhattan, authorities reported.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: 1% Fall Registered In December Value Of New Construction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (Reuters)The total value of new construction put In place in December was at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $129.1billion, 1 per cent below the figure for November, the Commerce Department said today. Last year was the first year to show a decline since records began in 1958.

title: In Memorian
description: LAPINShmuel. A poetic soul and beautiful Jew, his menschkeit, devotion to Kial Yisrael, leadership, and trienuship are greatly missed. Murray and Aviva Cantor Zuckotf.

title: Senate Panel Subpoenas Ballots in New Hampshire
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)The Senate Rules Committee voted today to subpoena all paper ballots in the contested New Hampshire Senate election end have them brought here for safekeeping.

title: WHEAT ADVANCES ON EXPORT NEWS
description: Sizable export orders from Tunisia and South Korea helped firm wheat futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Corn and soybeans, however, showed weakness.

title: 44Story Plunge Kills Head of United Brands
description: Eli M. Black, chairman of the billiondollar United Brands Company, which has vast interests in bananas and meatpacking and other enterprises,plunged to his death at 8 A. M. yesterday from the 44th floor of the Pan Am Building.

title: Ants, Squirrels and Us
Shorter Crop Estimates In Sugar Seen in Cuba
Policeman Goes on Trial Again On Charge of Protecting Betting
description: MORRISTOWN, Feb. 3The onetime chief of detectives in Paterson went on trial here today for a second time on charges that he had protected the numbers operation of a Paterson bookmaker.

title: ETHIOPIAN PLANES BOMB REBEL POSTS
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Tuesday, Feb. 4 (AP)Ethiopian planes bombed Eritrean secessionist positions north of the provincial capital of Asmara yesterday for the second day, reportedly striking as well at Moslem guerrillas retreating to their hideouts,

title: Stan Musial's Mother Dies
description: DONORA, Pa., Feb. 3 (UPI) Mary Musial, mother of Stan Musial, the former St. Louis Cardinal player who is a member of Baseball Hall of Fame, died here Saturday. She was 78 years old. Surviving, besides her son, are another son. Edward; 2 daughters, Helen Daniels and Rose Lang; a sister, Veronica ButeIla; 14 granchildren and 10 greatgrandchildren.

title: MOSHE ST ARKMAN, 68, YIDDISH WRITER, DIES
description: Moshe Starkman, a Yiddish and Hebrew writer, who directed Yiddish publicity of the United Jewish Appeal and the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies Joint Campaign, died Sunday of a heart ailment in Miami Beach. He was 68 years old and lived at 4700 Broadway.

title: France's Energy Plan
description: France's new tenyear program to reduce the country's dependence on imported oil sets an example for the industrial nations, but also emphasizes again the economic power of the oil cartel.

title: Enters the Foreign Market to Halt More Erosion
description: The Federal Reserve has entered the international money market to prevent further erosion of the dollar's value against foreign currencies, Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the central Bank announced yesterday.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Armco Stl

title: Today's Entries at Hialeah
description: Horses listed In order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: NEW PARTICLEAIDS SUBATOMIC STUDY
description: Japanese physicists have announced the discovery of another particle in the growing family of subatomic fragments, the observation of which in recent weeks has created turmoil among theorists.

title: U.S. Reports Progress In CleanAir Plan Here
description: Federal environmental officials reported yesterday what they called the first real progress since 1973 in their attempts to get city and state officials to carry out a transportation control plan that would make New York City's air healthful.

title: One of 4 Is Freed as State Rests in Errichetti Trial
description: TRENTON, Feb. 3The state rested its case today against Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden and three others charged with conspiring to evade bidding laws to give preferential treatment to a painting contractor.

title: Rivers and Harbors Here Are Allotted $67.7Million
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 New York, New Jersey and Connecticut would receive $67.7million in Federal funds for rivers, harbors, beaches and lakes under the 15month budget submitted today by President Ford.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Asking LongView Approach on World Fuels
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Suppose the world price of oil tumbles a few years from now because of conservation by consumers and the development of new oilproducing capacity?

title: Coors: Beer of Beers or KoolAid?
description: GOLDEN, Colo.At the end of President Ford's skiing holiday in Colorado, White House aides and reporters bundled onto their chartered jet at Grand Junction to fly back to Washington. The pilot noticed that the plane was unusually heavyso much so, in fact, that as a precaution, passengers were asked to redistribute themselves to help balance the weight.

title: 4 BANKERS NAMED IN PENSION FRAUD
description: NEWARK, Feb. 3 A New York City produce broker, four Bankers Trust Company officials and four other executives were indicted here today on Federal charges of stealing $912000 from pension fund of the United Paperworkers International Union.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: U.S. TO INCREASE FOREIGN FOOD AID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Ford Administration announced today an increase of more than $600million in foreign food aid for the fiscal year ending June 30 over the total provided the previous year.

title: U.S. Plans Lumber Stockpile To Avert a Major Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 President Ford's budget included today a new plan of the Forest Service to accumulate a stockpile of timber from Federal lands to be ready for future sale as a reserve against expected increases in demand.

title: Run From Scrimmage Is Found Causing Most Football Injuries
description: Kickoffs and punt returns are no longer football's most dangerous plays, a computer at Penn State University is telling its programmers.

title: FORD, IN SUBMITTING BUDGET, SEES JOBLESS RATE NEAR 8% UNTIL 1977; DEMOCRATS ASSAIL HIS PROPOSALS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 President Ford submitted budget of $349.4billion to Congress today and disclosed his Administration's forecast that the nation's unemployment rate will hover at about 8 per cent of the labor force for the rest of this year and next year.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 3 (UPI)Mayor Peter Flaherty and the Pittsburgh Penguins owner, Tad Potter, asked the city's business community today to aid the financially troubled National Hockey League club by buying 84,842 unsold seats for 14 remaining regularseason home games. Flaherty told representatives of 40 city businesses who met with him and Potter that the situation with the Penguins critical. Potter had said previously that the Penguins were in debt to the league by $500,000.

title: Mabel Mercer, Storyteller in Song, Hailed at 75
description: Four hundred of Mabel Mercer's friends filled the St. Regis Roof last night to celebrate her 75th birthday and salute her as a singer who has had an influence on popular music far out of proportion to the relatively small audiences who hear her.

title: EXEMPTION ADOPTED ON PENSION FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) Two Government agencies announced today they had formally adopted a temporary exemption that permits securities firms to continue dealing with pensions funds.

title: Jerusalem Parley Told Outlook For Israel and Jews Is Gloomy
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 3  Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, warned tonight that relations between Israel and the nonJewish world were fast deteriorating, and he predicted that Jews everywhere might soon confront a crisis of double loyalty involving their support for Israel and their identification with the policies of the countries in which they live.

title: Bridge.
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Feb. 3 The Bermuda Bowl contest for the world team championship, which returned to its point of origin here last week after a gap of a century, will long be remembered for many things, some good and some bad.

title: OldTimers Harris, Herman And Averill Gain Hall of Fame
description: Three baseball players of a past generation  Bucky Harris, Billy Herman and Earl Averill were elected to the game's Hall of Fame yesterday by the special committee on oldtimers.

title: The More They Run
description: When Senator Howard Baker of Tennessee greeted Ambassadordesignate Elliot Richardson at a recent dinner with the remark that I expect we'll be seeing a lot of each other in New Hampshire next year, he was only drawing an obvious conclusion from the thesis he later stated to Christopher Lydon of The New York Times:

title: The Program

At the Quad Cinema, 13th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. Running time: 60 minutes.

title: REFORM EVIDENT IN NEW BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3  President Ford's new budget reflects in a number of ways the sweeping budget reform act passed by Congress last year, including figures for a transition quarter that will lead the way in 1976 to a new fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

title: DONALD D. GEARY, 81, MARITIME LAWYER
description: Donald D. Geary, who retired in 1962 as a senior partner in the law firm of Kirlin, Campbell & Keating, which he had joined in 1921, died Sunday in New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 984 Esplanade, Pelham, N.Y.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Simultaneously but not coincidentally, Jimmy Connors enhanced his stature as the world's hest tennis player by winning $100,000 in Las Vegas while the United States was being eliminated from this year's Davis Cup competition. Only in America.

title: Led Zeppelin Excites Crowd at Uarden But Somehow Delirium Wasn't There
description: By every commercial index, at least, Led Zeppelin, the British band that opened a series of six soldout performances in the New York area last night at Madison Square Garden, is the leading contemporary rock group, at least of those steadily touring and putting out records.

title: Colleges Resume Classes After Long Winter Vacation Resulting From Energy Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Many of the nation's colleges and universities began new semesters today after what for some has been the longest winter vacation in their history.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AB OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose yesterday, erasing early losses, in steppedup trading.

title: Westinghouse Seen Closing Sale
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 3The Westinghouse Electric Corporation hopes to complete the proposed sale of its majorappliances operations by March 1, Robert E. Kirby, chairman, said here today.

title: EMERSON M'KENZIE
description: Emerson L. McKenzie, director of the field operations division of the Boys Clubs of America, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N. Y. He was 58 years old and lived at 36 Wellington Terrace, White Plains.

title: TRUST SUIT SETTLED WITH BOSTON GLOBE
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP) The Justice Department and The Boston Globe have resolved out of court an antitrust case involving the right to print syndicated comic strips, political columns and other features.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Article 4  No Title
Article 5  No Title
Books of The Times
description: In A Homemade World, his latest work of literary criticism, Hugh Kenner is as usual endlessly surprising and provocative. He startles us, first of all, with his selection of the halfdozen major representatives of the American modernist tradition. Faulkner and Hemingway seem reasonable choices, and maybe Wallace Stevens. But F. Scott Fitzgerald? One thought he was either a hopelessly flawed genius or a brilliant lightweight. William Carlos Williams? One thoughtindeed Professor Kenner said it himself in his monumental The Pound Erathat Williams was a throwback to the Imagists. Wasn't Marianne Moore brilliant curiosity?

title: Justice Department Asks C.A.B. Study Of Route Structure
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (Reuters)The Justice Department petitioned the Civil Aeronautics Board today to begin a broad investigation with major emphasis on the route structures of international air carries.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Leading Democrats in Congress professed shock and indignation today that President Ford's proposed budget anticipated high; unemployment for the rest of the decade.

description: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Things are normal in the White House press room. The reporters who regularly cover the President are grumbling about the faults, real and imagined, of the Presidential press secretary, Ron Nessen, and Mr. Nessen, if he has no harsh complaints about the press corps, has at least some disappointments.

description: Incoming

title: Senate Judiciary Unit Approves Levi in Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) Without a dissenting vote, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved today the nomination of Edward H. Levi to be attorney general.

description: VIENNA, Feb. 3 (Reuters)The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has no plans for a new conference on prices but the issue could be raised during a series of meetings starting this weekend, OPEC sources said today.

title: Wohlhuter No. 1 In SullivanVote
description: Rick Wohlhuter won again yesterday. This time, it was the Sullivan Award as America's outstanding amateur athlete in 1974.

description: BEIRUT, LebanonThe traditional domination of the world oil trade by the integrated international oil companies, known as the majors, is being sharply curtailed by the new power of the oilexporting countries.

description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 3 (AP) John Mackey, a former professional football player, told .a Federal Court judge today that it hurt his pride to sit on the bench.

description: MOSCOW, Feb. 3 (UPI)The two Soyuz 17 astronauts set Soviet space endurance record today in their 23d day aboard the orbiting Salyut 4 laboratory.

title: Saudi Sees U.S. Bank as a Catalyse
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3  Thirtyfouryearold Ghaith Pharaon of Jidda, Saudi Arabia, is a stocky imultimillionaire who wears small goatee and moustache, dresses impeccably in white shirts and dark suits, and flies around the world in either Of two Lear jets to work out transactions that are giving him something of a boywonder reputation as a wheelerdealer in international finance.

title: Memorial for Brown Feb. 12
description: There will be a memorial service for Dr. Howard J. Brown,I former City Health Services Administrator who died on Saturday, on Feb. 12 at 4 P.M. in the VonGueratde Lounge on the 12th floor of the Bobst Library at New York University, where he was on the faculty.

title: Advertising
description: I've got my fingers crossed. Who wants to be cocky? said Hershel B. Sarbin, since October the president of the ZiffDavis Publishing Company.

title: House Unit Votes Tax Cut Of 8Billion on 75 Income
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The House Ways and Means Committee approved today an $8.4billion reduction in taxes on 1975 income for persons with low and moderate incomes.

title: Business Briefs
description: FINDLAY, Ohio, Feb. 3 (UPI)The Marathon Oil Com pany said today the Federal Emergency Court of Appeals in Washington over the weekend enjoined the Federal Energy Administration from enforcing the petroletun entitlements program against Marathon pending a hearing.

title: JACKSON TO GET TIME ON CBSTV
description: After turning down a request from the Republican National Committe for the purchase of three halfhours of prime time, CBSTV has agreed to sell five minutes on Thursday night to Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington.

title: ROCKEFELLER SEES LONGER C.I.A. INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)Vice President Rockefeller said today that his commission's investigation of alleged domestic spying by the Central Intelligence Agency might require more than the threemonth period set by President Ford.
