description: ALBANY, Feb. 3Shifting money from consumer protection to the special commission conducting the volatile investigation of nursing homes was denounced as unconscionable today by a State Senator who is a member of the commission.

title: City U. Economies Are Planned to Avert Layoffs
description: The Board of Higher Education, which had been ordered by Mayor Beame to dismiss 500 employes this month, said yesterday that it would instead try to reduce its budget by instituting economies.

title: Capital Paper Breaks Budget Embargo; Move Draws White House Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3President Ford's press secretary imposed sanctions against The Washington StarNews today after that newspaper printed details of Mr. Ford's budget about two hours before the noon release time set by the white House.

title: Ford Discerns Consensus Emerging for His Policies
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 3 President, Ford, going to the country in search of support for his economic and energy policies declared today that a broad national consensus was emerging.

title: Canada Urged to Favor FrenchSpeaking Immigrants
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 3Future immigration policy must favor French  speaking immigrant, over others if Canada is to remain a bilingual country, according to a report submitted to Parliament today.

title: Wissel, Fordham Coach, Calls Recruiting Violations Common
description: Most major colleges cheat in their basketball recruiting practices, according to Hal Wissel, Fordham's head basketball coach.

title: AllKreisler Concert Is a Happy Idea
description: Fritz Kreisler was born 100 years ago last Sunday, and who but Jens Nygaard would not only remember his birthday, but also give a marvelously lively party in his memory? Mr. Nygaard.

title: Owners of Tanker Seek $35Million Following Accident
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP) The owners of the Liberian tanker Corinthos, blown up and set afire in an accident in the Delaware River last week, filed a $35million lawsuit today against operators of an American chemical ship, charging gross negligence by reckless and careless navigation.

title: Guns A Daily Reminder
description: On a typical day last week, guns were used in two homicides, three assaults and five robberies; 38 persons were arraigned for possession or use of guns, and 46 illegal firearms were confiscated by the police.

description: (Volume 2,864,265 shares)

title: $28BILLION ASKED IN JERSEY BUDGET
description: TRENTON, Feb. 3Governor Byrne proposed what he called a rockbottom state budget of $2.82billion today that was, he said. replete with personal sacrifices and one that would require heavy new taxes to bridge a deficit of $487million.

title: ANNE H. HARMON
description: Anne Hallock Harmon, al former interior decorator and designer of children's clothes, ,died yesterday at her home. She I was 95 years old and lived at 1383 Grasslands Road, White Plains.

title: A Call to Sacrifice for the Next 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 While President Ford and his aides have been warning for months that ending the recession without rekindling inflation would require the nation to make sacrifices, the scope of the sacrifices they had in mind remained undisclosed until today. The scope is stunning.

title: Major Independents
description: (Yesterday's games not Included.)

title: Carey Blows Cold and Hot On MassTransit Subsidy
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3 After chas rising local public officials and the press for misunderstanding his proposed $10.69billion budget, Governor Carey proceeded today to add to the confusion by repeatedly stating that there were no funds in it for continuing masstransit operating subsidies.

title: P.L.O. Team Will Play In World Table Tennis
description: CALCUTTA, India, Feb: 3The Palestine Liberation Organization will participate in the 33d world table tennis tournament, which begins here Thursday.

description: ELTUR, Israelioccupied Egypt  Jacob Ashkenazi knows that everyone thinks he is crazy and he is delighted about it.

title: 140 Japanese Tourists Are III After Meal on Jet Over Europe
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 3 (AP)Danish health authorities said they believed that tainted ham omelets, served aboard for breakfast, were the cause of a mass attack of food poisoning that afflicted more than 140 Japanese tourists as their chartered jetliner arrived here this morning.

title: DEVELOPING NATIONS BEGIN PRICE TALKS
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 3 (UPI)  The world's developing nations, following the lead of oilproducing states, began highlevel talks today on increasing income from raw materials.

description: (In contracts)

title: Alaska Warns It Must Have a Say on U.S. Decisions on Offshore Oil Leases
description: ANCHORAGE, Feb. 3Gov. Jay S. Hammond said today that while Alaska intended to cooperate with the Federal Government's new program for offshore oil leasing, we will do everything in our power to delay leasing until assured that we can live with it.

title: PRIOR THREAT CITED IN POLICE SHOOTING
description: The exchange of gunfire in which a city policeman and Housing Authority policeman killed each other on the East Side Sunday started after the Housing Authority policeman threatened his brotherinlaw, another Housing Authority policeman, by putting a gun to his head, the police said yesterday.

title: MILLIONS OF BIRDS FACE DEATH DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Sometime in the near future, the Army high command plans to give orders to kill millions of blackbirds roosting for the winter at Fort Campbell in Kentucky and at an Army arsenal in Tennessee.

title: U. D. C. HEAD SEEKS BANKS GUARANTEE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3Edward J. Logue, president of the Urban Development Corporation, warned two State Assembly committees today that it would be futile for the Legislature to carry the foundering corporation through March with a $178million emergency appropriation without advance assurance that major banks would buy the agency's bonds again in April.

title: 44Story Plunge Kills Head of United Brands
description: Eli M. Black, chairman of the billiondollar United Brands Company, which has vast interests in bananas and meatpacking and other enterprises, plunged to his death at 8 A. M. yesterday from the 44th floor of the Pan Am Building.

title: Hockey Scoring
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Guard Evacuates Indians Peacefully After 34Day Occupation of Abbey Ends
description: SHAWANO, Wis., Feb. 3 The 34day seizure of a vacant Roman Catholic novitiate by armed Menominee Indians ended quietly tonight when the Indians voluntarily turned themselves over to the Wisconsin National Guard.

title: Military Funding Increased, Programs for Poor and Elderly Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3With a proposed $92.8billion defense budget, the Ford Administration has attempted to reverse the eroding effects of inflation on its defense program and to set the stage for a steady upturn in military spending, reaching $140billion by the end of the decade.

title: State Court Voids Women's Exemption From Jury Service
description: State Supreme Court Justice Irwin Brownstein ruled yesterday that the state law allowing women to exempt themselvesI from jury duty was unconstitutional. The decision follows the lines of a recent United States Supreme Court ruling voiding a Louisiana law. The Brownstein decision will be appealed by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office. Meanwhile, it will not go into effect.

title: Istomin and Mrs. Casais to Be Married
description: Eugene Istomin, the pianist whom Pablo CasaIs used to call my son, and Manna NIontariez CasaIs, widow of the Spanish cellistcomposer, announced yesterday that they would marrytwice, once in English, once in Spanishwithin the next few weeks. They have known each other for 25 years.

title: G.M. Quarter Profit Off 1.7%; Company Loses No. 1 Position
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3The General Motors Corporation reported today that its profit for the final quarter of 1974 fell 1.7 per cent from the same period a year earlier, and that its earnings for 1974 were down 60 per cent.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WORDS AND MUSES If  New York is a diversion mecca for seeing and hearing, some new, novel, spring semester courses open to the general public at schools are reminders that the city is also a place to dig in and learn, painlessly.

title: Alan Marks, in Excellent Recital, Proves Sensitive Piano Colorist
description: The Kaufmann Auditorium of the 92d Street Y.N1.Y.V$7.H.A. is closed for renovations, but the music goes on in other parts of the building, including the Unterberg Chapel, where Alan Marks gave an excellent faculty recital on Sunday. The pianist, who made his debut in 1971, proved to be the most sensitive of colorists in music by Schubert and Chopin, as well as highly convincing contemporary protagonist in pieces by Carlos Chavez and Pierre Boulez.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Union medical and clerical employes struck Eastern Long Island Hospital, a 66bed voluntary institution Greenport, L. I., after negotiations for a new contract were suspended at an impasse over wages and fringe benefits. The hospital, which serves Shelter Island on the north fork of Suffolk County, discharged or transferred its 30 patients over the weekend.

title: Highlights of Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Following are highlights President Ford's budget for the fiscal year 1976:

title: WNCN GUILD TO ASK REMOVAL OF WQIV
description: The WNCN Listeners Guild plans to petition the Federal Communications Commission this week to deny a license renewal next June to radio station WQIVFM, owned by the Starr Broadcasting Group.

title: King Put Off Team By Vols
description: Bernard King, the eighth highest college basketball scorer in the country, was suspended from the University of Tennessee team yesterday in what appeared to be another case of a former New York City high school player having his grade transcript altered.

title: Zoos, Good and Bad
description: Whether or not the Parks Department and the New York Zoological Society come to an agreement in the next few days on the future of the city's three small zoos, we are glad to note that their large animals will almost surely soon be gone from their present, cruelly restrictive surroundings. If the Society does not take over the municipal zoos of Central, Prospect and Flushing Meadow parks, Commissioner Edwin L. Weisl Jr. for closing them down; and William Conway, the Society's director, has served notice that if it does take them over, he cannot contemplate any biganimal exhibits. The dispersal of these big cats, elephants, bears and to more suitable locales is long overdue.

title: People and Business
description: The wise person wouldn't wait three or four years if he wants a home and can afford to buy it now, James T. Lynn, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said yesterday in Atlanta at a regional White House conference on domestic and economic affairs.

title: Exchanze Seat at $90,000
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported a seat sale yesterday at $90,000, up $5,000 from a sale Jan. 30 at $85,000. A week earlier, on Jan. 23, seat sold for $72,000.

title: Dow Index Up 7.75 After an Early Dip on Profit Taking
description: The stock market, after early weakness resulting from profit taking, made a broad advance yesterday in heavy trading.

title: Fiscal Seesaw
description: In an era of economic paradoxes, taxpayers in New York and New Jersey are facing yet another one: As the Federal Government prepares to put more money in their pockets by cutting taxes in an effort to prime the economy, state and local governments are planning to take it away in an effort ti balance their budgets.

title: Article 2  No Title
2 Hurt in Denver Blast
description: DENVER, Feb. 3 (AP) Two persons were injured today when what the police said was a dynamite bomb ripped through a restroom on the sixth floor of a downtown bank building. The restroom is situated between the United States Securities and Exchange Commission regional office and offices of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company.

title: JOBLESS ESTIMATE JARS DENIOCRATS; Leaders in Congress Vow Fight on Unemployment Projected in Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Leading Democrats in Congress professed shock and indignation today that President Ford's proposed budget anticipated high unemployment for the rest of the decade.

title: The State of Being Childless, They Say, Is No Cause for Guilt
description: The large yellow sign in front of a meeting room at the New York Sheraton Hotel included a quotation from Isaiah: Thou hast multiplied the nation and not increased the joy.

title: Boeing to Raise Dividend
description: The Boeing Company announced yesterday in Seattle that it was raising its regular quarterly dividend on common stock to 20 cents a share from 15 cents a share. The dividend is payable March 10 to shareholders of record Feb. 13.

title: Soviet Wants Its Allies to Assume a Greater Financial Burden
description: BUDAPEST, Jan. 29With all the Communist countries of Eastern Europe hastening completion of their new fiveyear economic plans, the Soviet Union is pressing its allies hard to assume greater shares of the bloc's financial burdens.

title: Royal Friendship Grows in Brooklyn
description: LONDON, Fb. 3The Royal Shakespeare Company sees its new season of repertory in New York as part of growing artistic friendship with the Brooklyn Academy of Music, something more valuable than the expected modest profit.

title: College Results
description: FENCING

title: Depressing Budget
description: The gloomy forecasts in President Ford's budget report if well groundedare strong evidence of the inadequacy of his own program to pull the nation out recession. Confronted with the reality of slowdown but still threatened by a recrudescence of inflation, the Pregident and his advisers seem to be managing somehow lose on both fronts at the same time.

title: 3YearOld Girl Raped At Nursery School Here
description: A 3yenold girl was raped at her nursery school last Thursday, according to the police, who said the girl's foster mother reported the incident to detectives of the 20th Precinct !last night.

title: A Rare Error Raises Hope, but Momentarily
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 If President Ford's budget document is to be believed, the cost of at least one part of the Government will decline drastically in the next fiscal year.

title: House Unit Votes Tax Cut Of 8Billion on '
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The House Ways and Means Committee approved today an $8.4billion reduction In taxes on 1975 income for persons with low and moderate incomes.

title: White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The executive budget released today promises sizable reduction in the White House staff. However, an examination of the figures shows that the staff that directly serves the President is to continue on about the same level, with some increase in costs because of inflation.

title: Delhi Oil Planning Sale to Australians
description: The Delhi International Oil Corporation announced in Dallas yesterday that it would sell a 50 per cent interest in its Australian petroleum and natural gas reserves and a 25 per cent interest in other Australian petroleum property to the Petroleum and Minerals Authority, an Australian Government agency.

title: SONGS STYLED TO FIT BY JOANNE BERETTA
description: Joanne Beretta, who has moved back and forth between singing and designing, is back into singing again in a series of Sunday evenings at Reno Sweeney, 126 West 13th Street.

title: G.E. to Give $2to$5 Rebates on 39 Small Appliances
description: Following the example of the automobile industry, the General Electric Company yesterday announced that it would give $2 to $5 price rebates on 39 small electrical appliances for two months starting March 21.

title: Yonkers Entries
description: Horses listed In order of Post position Letter designates OTB listing

title: CRIME FIGHT GETS LOWER ALLOTMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3  President Ford's budget request for fighting crime is one of the most modest in recent years even though the latest Federal Bureau of Investigation statistics showed reported crime up 16 per cent.

title: Concert: A Rubinstein Spectacular
description: Grandpa and grandma, it is safe to predict, will gather their clan about them on some distant evening and tell how they beard Arthur Rubinstein at the age of 89 play the Beethoven Fourth and the Brahms First concertos back . to back on one New York Philharmonic program. And how the puissant Arthur not only performed the mighty works notperfectly but also played with overwhelming conviction, ardor and musical authority.

title: Kennecott Copper Plans to Idle 1,700
description: The Kennecott Copper CorI poration said yesterday, it was laying off more than 1,700 employes at a number of its southwestern mining operations in the next few weeks, the Associated Press reports.

title: COACHES POLL
description: The top 20, with Points figured on a 10,9.8.74,54.3.2.1 basis for first throught 10th Place (firslplace voles in parentheses) and wonlost records through games of lst Saturday.

title: Praising Sure Hand Of Maazel
description: Perhaps the lesson to be learned from the Cleveland Orchestra's performance of the Berlioz Requiem in Carnegie Hall on Monday night was that where a work of great emotional range and originality is concerned exactness can be all.

title: POTATO FUTURES SHOW PRICE DROP
description: In slow trading May delivery potato futures set a new contract low of 3.48 cents a pound on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract then closed at 3.52 cents, compared with Monday's 3.55.

title: Errichetti's Defense Rests With Character Testimony
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4The defense rested its case today in the conspiracy and misconduct trial of Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden after presenting only character witnesses.

title: Five Years of N.E.P.A.
description: It is just over five years since Congress passed and former President Nixon signed the National Environmental Policy Act. While the law stirred hardly ripple in bureaucratic circles at the time, it has turned out to be one of the most farreaching measures for protecting this country's land, air and water that has ever been enacted.

title: Volunteer Army
description: Recruiting for the volunteer Army, in difficulty a year ago, has improved in recent months. But this trend, two years after the effective end of the draft, conceals more than it reveals.

title: 2 Fighters in Midair Crash
description: WINDHAM, Vt., Feb. 4 (UPI) Two Air Force FB111 fighters crashed in flight late last night seconds after four crewmen parachuted to safety. Spokesmen at the Plattsburgh Air Force Base, where the planes were based, refused to confirm reports that the planes were involved in an airborne refueling maneuver when the collision took place.

title: Article 1  No Title
Reserves of Britain Rose During January
description: LONDON, Feb. 4 (UPI)Britain has used all but $302.4million of the $3024billion Eurodollar loan arranged by Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey and the nation's big four banks last March, in an effort to protect the pound.

title: A RocketWeary Tay Ninh Awaits Attacks in Stillness
description: TAY NINH, South Vietnam, Feb. 3Cars, jeeps, buses and trucks move briskly along Route 22 to Tay Ninh.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Notes on People
description: For Dade County Republicans. Vice President Rockeler was too liberal so former Representative Charles W. Sandman of New Jersey got the nod as speaker for their annual Lincoln's Birthday fundraising dinner in Miami. Theevent will be held on Feb. 22, Washington's real birthday.

title: Jersey Will Supervise Reforms In Newark Public School System
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4Governor Byrne announced today that the state would oversee the reform of the administration of Newark's problem  plagued school system.

title: Richard Lindabury, 74, Dies; Editor Headed Poetry Society
description: Richard V. Lindabury, an editor and teacher who was president of the Poetry Society of America in 1953 and again last year, died yesterday of a heart attack on a cruise ship near Trinidad. He was 74 years old.

title: Nursing Home'sLosses Put at $841,620 Profit
description: The now closed Towers Nursing Home made an indicated profit of $841,620 from 1966 through 1973 instead of !a cumulative loss of $1,187,816 as it had reported to the State Health Department, according to to a final report yesterday by the state's Welfare Inspector General.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Suffolk County's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, James Lack, calls it a case of the shrinking candy  bar syndrome, only worse. Chocolate bars have been shrinking while they've become more expensive, but consumers expect the quality of the raining chocolate to remain the same.

title: Exxon Reported Close to Pact To Purchase Oil From Kuwait
description: The evolving nature of the international oil business was demonstrated yesterday with reports that the Exxon Corporation was close to an agreerripnt to buy oil from Kuwait.

title: Onassis Is Ailing With Two Diseases; Specialist on Way
description: ATHENS, Feb. 4 (AP) Aristotle Onassis is suffering from a potentially dangerous combamtion of influenza and myasthenia gravis, a muscular debility, and heart specialist has been flown from the United states to attend him, staff members at Mr. Onassis's villa said today.

title: Excerpts From the Statement by Percy
description: Mr. Chairman, I would like to say to Mr, Lewin: We've listened with interest to your dissertation. I find it totally unconvincing. I really say to you that you have done a disservice, I think, to your client, because when you presume to tell this committee that one of the reasons that Dr. Bergman cannot be here is because he didn't have adequate notice, or couldn't prepare or whatever it might be. We're asking him to testify about his business that he's in for a long time.

title: COMPANY PROFITS DOWN IN QUARTER
description: Corporate aftertax profits in the fourth quarter of 1974 fell 21 per cent below those of the third quarter, reflecting the deepening recession, the First National City Bank of New York said yesterday.

title: Litterbugs in Hong Kong Find That It Proves Costly
description: HONG KONG (UPI)  The government collected more than $200,000 from litterbugs in a I7month period.

title: Stuyvesant Wainwright Dead; Bridge Player and Broker, 84
description: Stuyvesant Wainwright, a descendantof Peter Stuyvesant and a contract bridge expert and a retired stockbroker, died yesterday in Naples, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: Concert: A Rubinstein Spectacular
description: Grandpa and grandma, it is safe to predict, will gather their clan about them on some distant evening and tell how they heard Arthur Rubinstein at the age of 89 play the Beethoven Fourth and the Brahms First concertos back to back on one New York Philharmonic program. And how the puissant Arthur not only performed the mighty works noteperfectly but also played with overwhelming conviction, ardor and musical authority.

title: Giscard and Schmidt Agree on Oil Parley
description: PARIS, Feb. 4  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing agreed today on plans for a conference of nil consumers and producers to start in March even though, a West German spokesman said, the Common Market countries have still not agreed on a joint energy policy.

title: Shaking Up A New Pattern
description: PARISDuring the past several weeks the French political kaleidoscope has shaken into a new pattern. When Charles de Gaulle produced the Fifth Republic with a strong executive and a stress on national pride and discipline, there were only two important parties in this country.

title: Soviet Union Cancels Wheat Order
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 4 (AP) The Soviet Union has canceled an order for 200,000 metric tons of United States wheat but has contracted to buy an additional 100,000 metric tons of corn, a Memphisbased commodities trading company said today.

title: Business Briefs
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4 (AP)The Interior Department drew more than $300.5million in total bids today on 148 tracts of sea bottom off the lower Texas coast the Gulf of Mexico's last big wildcat lease sale. The oilmen who gathered for the sale held in a hotel ballroom ignored 307 tracts offered by the department. Most bids were deemed on the low side.

title: Weather Cancels Racing
description: CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Feb. 4 (AP) Tonight's thoroughbred racing card at Charles Town Turf Club. was canceled because of bad weather. Track officials said racing was scheduled to resume tomorrow night.

title: Mackey: Schramm Favored 25% Pay Cut
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 4 (AP)  Tex Schramm, owner of the Dallas Cowboys, favored a pay cut of 25 per cent instead of 10 per cent for players who chose to play out their options with a National Football League team, a former N.F.L. player, John Mackey, said today.

title: Unequal Rungs Up Corporate Ladder
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Feb. 3Fifty per cent of the women managers or potential managers interviewed in a recent survey have turned down job promotions at one time, according to a study conducted at Marymount College.

title: Nilsson Will Replace Rysaneh in Wulkare
description: Birgit Nilsson has agreed to replace Leonia Rysanek as Sieglinde in three performances of Die Walltilre this season at. the Metropolitan Opera. Miss Rysanek, who was scheduled to sing the Wagnerian soprano role five times, informed the Metropolitan that she would enter a Vienna hospital on Sunday for surgery.

title: Market Summary
description: AMERICAN EXCHANGE

title: Article 2  No Title
Newspapers Joining Other Industries In Tightening Their Economic Belts
description: Like most other industries, newspapers across the country are undergoing an economic belttightening that in some cases is changing the way papers gather and present the news.

title: Moscow Denies That It Seeks Navy Base on Portugal's Coast
WNCNFM TO RETURN $14,000 IN DONATIONS
description: About $14,000 in public donations sent to WNCNFM to support a proposed new classical music station are being returned to the contributors.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Food Stamp Price Freeze Voted by House, 374 to 38
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The House voted overwhelmingly today to reject the Administration's plan to raise the purchase price of food stamps March I for almost all the 17.1 million recipients.

title: U.A.W, TO PROTEST DETROIT LAYOFFS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4The United Automobile Workers, whose members are bearing the brunt of the recession in the automobile industry, has turned to the only weapons it has during bad timespolitical pressure and public protest.

title: Ballet: Panovs Debut Is Pure Genius
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 So at last it happened. Galina and Valery Panov, the Israeli emigres from the Soviet Union, finally, after all manner of alarm and excursions, to say nothing of injuries, tonight made their American debut here in a sports arena surrounded by a blizzard that recalled Siberia rather more than Pennsylvania.

title: FITZGERALDS BACK ON WORAM MONDAY
description: Ed and Pegeen Fitzgerald, the redoubtable Mr. and Mrs. team of radio, whose daily broadcast went off the air two years ago after 34 years, will return to WORAM next Monday, the broadcasting company said last night.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph of President Franklin D. Roosevelt signing the Social Security Act, published in The New York Times on Monday, was made on Aug. 14, 1935, and not, as stated in the caption, in 1939.

title: TURKEY TO REVIEW LINKS WITH NATO
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 4 (Reuters)Premier Sadi Irmak said tonight that the suspension of United States military aid over the Cyprus issue would compel Turkey to review her ties with the North Atlantic Treaty Organizaticin.

title: Justice Unit Moves To Bar Illegal Aliens From Hiring in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)The Justice Department proposed today that all persons hired in the United States be required to furnish documentary proof of their United States citizenship or legal alien status as a measure to reduce employment of illegal aliens.

title: Marlboro Players Bring Out a Curio, 1903 Trio by Tovey
description: There was a genuine curio on Music From Marlboro's chamber music program at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night: Sir Donald Francis Tovey's Trio for Piano, Violin and English Horn, played in commemoration of the composer's 100th birthday this year. Of course, Tovey is far better known today for his scholarly writing on a wide variety of musical subjects  his famous collection of Essays in Musical Analysis is still required reading in schoolsand many people probably never realized that he composed music at all.

title: MRS. IRVING TENENBAUM
description: Gertrude Lyman Tenenbaum, wife of Irving Tenenbaum, lawyer in Mineola, L.I., and judge of the Village Court in Great Neck, LI., died Monday in North Shore Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived at 30 Piccadilly Road, Great Neck.

title: Some Food Prices Dip, But Trend Is Still Up
description: Average food prices went up only slightly last week in the New York City area. The increases were largely seasonal in such items as fresh produce while the decreases for the first time affected every item in the meat and fish category.

title: WEST SERS ASK SCHOOL PROJECTS
description: By the time the residents of West 86th Street at last night's meeting of Community Planning Board No. 7 got around to making their case against a proposed McDonald's hamburger outlet at the southeast corner of 86th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, the issue seemed almost frivolous.

title: City Center Will Keep 55th St. Theater
description: The City Center of Music and Drama, which had considered tearing down its 55th Street house, has decided to keep the theater and get more use out of it.

title: Dollar Rallies Strongly on Continent
description: LONDON, Feb. 4 The United States dollar rallied strongly today on the European currency markets in response to the disclosure of plans for centralbank intervention to support it.

title: REBELS DESTROY A MEKONG CONVOY
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 4A convoy of supply ships returning empty to South Vietnam from Phnom Penh was torn apart on the Mekong River yesterday when it reportedly ran into a minefield laid by the Communistled Cambodian insurgents who control most of the river.

title: Stocks Lose Ground; Dow Slides to 708.07
description: The SLOCK MarKet declined moderately, yesterday in continued heavy trading as profit taking and bearish economic news weakened most issues.

title: Arabs Seek Stake In U.S. Real Estate
description: LONDON, Feb. 4 A group of Arab investors is planning to acquire a stake in American, real estate through an international investment consortium that has just been formed in London and Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

title: Soviet Paper Critical of Fans For Drinking, Cursing, Scalping
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 4Drunken louts, foulmouthed boors, oleaginous scalpers and even female groupies are penetrating Moscow spectator sports in disturbing numbers, a leading newspaper said today.

title: HIGH COURT GETS SENIORITY ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4A civil rights organization has petitioned the Supreme Court to hear a case that could open the way for clarification in the controversy surrounding job seniority and layoff policy. The Justice Department says it will join in asking for a hearing.

title: Article 3  No Title
A Family Handcuffed in Home Accuse Police of Overreaction
description: FREEPORT, L.I., Feb. 4The members of a family held at gunpoint and handcuffed in their house by the village police after a neighbor called to report a possible burglary said today that the police had overreacted. But the village mayor and chief of police said the action had been justified.

title: Dollar Stages Rally
description: The United States dollar rallied strongly yesterday on European currency markets in response to the disclosure of plans for centralbank intervention to support it. Details on Page 53.

title: Revisions of Election Law Debated at State Hearing
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4Common Cause, which describes itself as a people's lobby, confronted practical politics today in the person of Senator John D. Calandra, at a hearing on the, state election law.

title: CAREY HALTS WORK ON NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4Governor Carey said today that he had in effect imposed a moratorium on the construction of nuclear power plants in the state until he was convinced that the plants were safe and that their radioactive wastes could be disposed of safely.

title: Open Interest
Sudden Tory Contender Margaret Hilda Roberts Thatcher
description: LONDON. Feb. 4Whether or not Margaret Thatcher is eventually elected leader of the Conservative partymaking her Prime Minister if the party comes to power she has already gone further than any other woman in modern British politics. Two months ago with 16 years in the House of Commons and with Cabinet experience behind her, she started as an outsider in the leadership battle. Today, with startling swiftness, she brought to an end the 10year reign of former Prime Minister Edward Heath.

title: Advertising
description: Americans, who are now eating one meal out of three away from their homes, are expected to increase the frequency to three out of five by 1980. That should have a considerable effect on the marketing methods of the food companies.

title: 2 DIE, GIRL, 2, SAVED IN BROOKLYN FIRES
description: Two men died early yesterday in a twoalarm fire that swept! through a fourstory frame dwelling at 1152 Lafayette! Avenue, between Bushwick Avenue and Broadway in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. They were identified as Herman Laguer, 26 years old, and Efrain Nieves. 31.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: INDIANS CHARGED IN ABBEY SEIZURE
description: SHAWANO. Wis., Feb.4Twentyeight of the 39 Menomince Indians who voiuntarily left an unused Roman Catholic novitiate seized on New Year's Day were arraigned in county court today on charges of criminal trespass and disorderly conduct.

title: Speaker Backs Away From His Earlier Stand
description: In a dramatic exchange with Representative Edward I. Koch, at a United States Senate hearing here yesterday, Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut backed away from his earlier insistence that he had never warned Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein not to investigate nursing homes owned by Bernard Bergman. Instead, Mr. Steingut said he could not recollect such conversations.

title: BERGMAN REFUSES TO TESTIFY
description: Bernard Bergman refused to appear at a United States Senate hearing here yesterday, his accountant pleaded the Fifth Amendment and Stanley Steingut, Speaker of the New York State Assembly, said he could not remember telling Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein not to investigate Mr. Bergman's nursing homes.

title: MEDICAID RATE CUT ON REIMBURSEMENT
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4 (AP)  The State Health Department has retroactively reduced the Medicaid reimbursement rate paid to a Bronx nursing home owned by Bernard Bergman, and the due bill could total $150,000, was disclosed today.

title: Advocate Sues the State On Alleged Jail Beatings
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4 The State Public Advocate sued the prison system on behalf of 58 inmates today, charging that they were systematically beaten by guards in a special unit for hardcore prisoners.

title: JUDGE CLEARS WAY ON NIXON DOCUMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) United States District Judge Charles R. Richey cleared the way today for the personal memorabilia and nonpresidential documents of Richard M. Nixon to be shipped to the former President at his home in San Clemente Calif.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Taxi Ridership Termed Stable

title: Eleanor French, 59, Dies; Cafe Singer of 30's and 40's
description: Eleanor French Booraem, who was a wellknown cafe singer in the nineteenthirties and forties, died Sunday at her home, 355 East 72d Street. She was 59 years old.

title: Blast Rocks Radio Stations
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 4 (AP) A powerful bomb rocked a threestory building containing three radio stations and other offices, causing up to $100,000 damage, the police reported today. Investigators said no injuries had been reported, although no one warned of the explosion last night in the Golden Pacific Center or claimed responsibilty for it.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Liguori in Ohio Mile
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 4 (UPI) Marty Liguori, a former Villanova track star, will run the mile in the Knights of Columbus track meet at the Coliseum here Friday. Liguori, running under the New York Athletic Club colors, was the National Collegiate mile champion three years in a row at Villanova, beginning in 1969.

title: Con Ed's Complaint Record Is Criticized
description: An independent management study by the consulting firm of Arthur D. Little, Inc., has foundl that the customerrcomplaint rate of the Cohsolidated Edison Company is higher than that for any other utility in the state, and that the company's system for handling these complaints is inadequate.

title: WINE TALK
description: The great wine book mystery has been solved.

title: Film Benefit Planned For Walker Children
description: The six young orphaned children of the late Frank Walker, who was killed by gunman last Wednesday when he attempted to aid policeman in St. Vincent's Hospital, will benefit from the world premiere of the film Rosebud.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Money
description: Tuesday. Feb. 4, 1975 DOMESTIC MARKET RATES IN PER CENT FEDERAL FUND

title: RUSSELL M. KERR
description: Russell M. Kerr, a former managing editor of the trade publication Musical America, coeditor of The Music Lovers Encyclopedia, died in Tallahassee, Fla., Friday. He was 76 years old and lived at 202 East 61st Street.

title: MACMILLAN ADDS ARTS SUBSIDIARY
description: Macmillan, Inc., one of the country's largest publishers of books, music and graphics, has formed a subsidiary, Macmillan Performing Arts, Inc., to create and package projects for the theater, motion pictures, television and the record industry.

title: WINE TALK
description: The great wine book mystery has been solved.

title: Auto Sales Up 42% in Jan. 2131 Period
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4 Newcar sales were up 42 per cent in the last third of January from the middle period of the month but analysts said the industry's pricerebate program cut little from its record inventory or some 1.7 million cars,

title: Market Averages
description: Tuesday, February 4, 1975 THE NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE

title: Maryland's Senate Admonishes Mandel for CompanyPaid Trip
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md. Feb. 4Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland was admonished by the Democratically controlled State Senate here today for a failure to use more prudent judgment in accepting a free airplane flight to a Jamaica vacation aboard the corporate jet of a Maryland oil company seeking a controversial refinery permit from the state.

title: DEVELOPING LANDS OPEN TRADE TALKS
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 4 (UPI) President Leopold S. Senghor of Senegal called on developing nations today to use their raw materials to create a new world economic order.

title: Nadjari Bribe Jury, Citing ExHogan Aide, Indicts 3
description: A Manhattan lawyer and two police officers were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to pay part of a S30,000 bribe to a former Manhattan assistant district attorney to fix a 1971 narcotics case.

title: MONOPOLY CHARGE DENIED BY AT. &
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) The American Telephone and Telegraph Company denied today that it was violating the antitrust laws and asked a. Federal court to dismiss a Justice Department suit seeking to break it up.

title: SelfDefeating Plans
description: President Ford is mincing no words. The economy is in a severe recession, begins his annual Economic Report to Congress, submitted yesterday on the heels of his discouraging budget. Pollyanna has lost her hold over public discourse; the sugarcoating industry is steep decline, along with everything else.

title: Canada to Invest $ 1 .4Billion To Save TarSands Oil Project
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 4 The Canadian Government and two provinces announced today that they would invest about $1.4billion to save a project to extract oil from the Athabasca tar sands in Alberta.

title: Philippines Orders Inquiry on Soldiers Accused of Torture
description: MANILA, Feb. 4The Philippine military, responding to charges of torture made by religious groups, took action yesterday against seven enlisted men and five officers.

title: Ullman Leads Democrats In GivingFord a Victory
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The House Ways and Means Committee, in what was at least a temporary victory for the Ford Administration. voted down today an attempt to attach repeal of the oil depletion allowance to the antirecession taxcut bill.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS ON MORE SPENDING OR BIGGER TAX CUT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 President Ford and his Council of Economic Advisers warned today that the grim outlook fot the nation's economy would not be made any better by more Government spending or bigget tax cuts.

title: Met to Visit Wolf Trap
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The Metropolitan Opera will give second season of performances this summer at the Wolf Trap Farm west of Washington, it was announced today. Between June 23 and 28; it will give seven performances, including La Bohme, Cavalleria Rusticana, I Pagliacci, La Traviata, La Forza del Destino and Falstaff.

title: Sadat and Gromyko Say Brezhnev Still Plans Trip
description: CAIRO, Feb. 4  President Anwar elSadat and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union announced today that Leonid I. Brezhnev was again scheduled to come to the Middle East. No date was specified for the trip.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 4 (AP)The Soviet Union swept the men's and women's crosscountry skiing events today in the opening competition of the eighth World Winter Games for the Deaf. Anatoly Grishanov, a 28yearold sports instructor from the Soviet Union, captured the men's 15kilometer crosscountry event. Aleksandr Poilov, Viktor Boubnov and Valery Kovia.sine, also of the Soviet Union, took second, third and fourth place, respectively, in the event, which was entered by 24 skiers.

title: EXPERTS DIFFER ON OZONE STUDY
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb, 4Sharp differences as to the significance of a fouryear study of potential supersonic transport effects on the stratosphere with regard to human health erupted here today as participants in the $20million Federal study met to discuss its findings.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Domestic and Foreign Matters
description: It's a privilege and a pleasure to be in Atlanta. I've enjoyed this day and looking forward to this press conference. Mr. Cutts of the Atlanta Papers.

title: Phils Deny Trying to Lure Braves Allen
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 (AP)The Philadelphia Phillies strongly denied today charge of tampering with the Atlanta Braves rights to Dick Allen, the retired slugger.

title: Auditor Cites $437,432 Overpayment in Computer Pact by 2 Local School Districts
description: The Board of Education's auditorgeneral charged yesterday that the city had overpaid $437,432 during 1970 to 1972 to a computerservices company headed by the brother of Dr.1 Edythe J. Gaines, then superintendent of one of two BronxI school districts that had hired the concern.

title: Wealthy Districts Facing School Fiscal Challenge
description: The prospect of finding new methods to finance public schools in the metropolitan New York regiona challenge now staring both New Jersey and Connecticut in the faceputs wealthy school districts in an uncomfortable and, to a large extent, an ambiguous position. On the one hand, few persons, especially educators, in such districts are willing to challenge the basic prin. ciple of bringing about more equity in school financing.: On the other hand, any change will inevitably bring with it a higher tax burden for wealthier districts with no benefits to their own edu= cational programs. As a result, some residents see possible threats to the very character of their towns.

title: City's Interest Rate Declines to 7.55% for $290Million in Notes
description: The city won an interest rate of 7.55 per cent yesterdaythe lowest in five monthson borrowing of $290million in shortterm notes.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS ON MORE SPENDING OR BIGGER TAX CUT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  President Ford and his Council of Economic Advisers warned today that the grim outlook for the nation's economy would not be made any better by more Government spending or bigger tax cuts.

title: President's Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4President Ford's forecast for 19767.9 per cent unemployment and 7.8 per cent inflation appears to constitute a prescription for further political trouble for an already sickly Re publican party. It is a dose of bad medicine, said Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who barely won reelection last year.

title: TV: Native Perceptions on Middle East Conflict
description: Arabs and Israelis, an eightpart series of weekly half hours beginning on public TV at 8 o'clock this evening, represents an ambitious project undertaken by Boston station WGBH. With Peter S. McGhee as executive producer, the station enlisted an Egyptian journalist and an Israeli televison producer to record separate contributions to a format that would attempt to provide contrasting perceptions of the Middle East conflict, personal expressions from some of the people who have the most at stake.

title: Vorster Balancing Hints of South African Change With Assurances
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 31Prime Minister John Vorster continues to drop tantalizing hints that he is willing to dismantle some of South Africa's elaborately constructed system of racial segregation and discrimination.

title: PoisonPen Police
description: Former Attorney General Saxbe has released evidence that the Federal Bureau of Investigation engaged in deliberate campaign of defamation against a radical professor at Arizona State University. The clandestine efforts, which included the writing of anonymous letters to a faculty committee dealing with the teacher's professional future, continued for a period of two years, between 1968 and 1970. They appear to have had the personal approval of the late F.B.I. Director J. Edgar Hoover.

title: Creditable City
description: The four weeks since New York City last went market for money have brought substantial improvement in receptivity to its security offerings by the financial community. The bidding yesterday on $290 million municipal shortterm notes reflected genuine competition, in refreshing contrast to the underwriters indefensible recent habit of ganging up to confront the metropolis with a single takeitorleaveit offer.

title: Aennchen Antonelli Dies; Breeder of Maltese Dogs
description: Aennchen Antonelli, a breeder of Maltese dogs and a dance teacher died Sunday at her home, 137 Dora Avenue, Waldwick, N.J. She was in her 50's.

title: Two More Junta Members Are Ordered Held in Greece
description: ATHENS, Feb. 4 (Reuters)Two more leading members of the former Greek military junta were ordered into custody today on charges of high treason and insurrection in connection with the Army seizure of power gn April, 1967.

title: Texaco Increases Its Price for Residual Fuel Oil
description: Texaco, Inc., said that effective last Friday it had increased posted prices for certain grades of residual fuel oil to all classes of trade.

title: Milwaukee Teachers Reach Tentative Contract Accord
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 4 (AP)Striking teachers and the school board reached a tentative agreement today on a twoyear contract that would end a twoweek strike.

title: INDIANS CHARGED IN ABBEY SEIZURE
description: SHAWANO, Wis., Feb.4Twentyeight of the 39 Menominee Indians who voluntarild left an unused Roman Catholic, novitiate seized on New Year's Day were arraigned in county court today on charges of criminal trespass and disorderly, conduct.

title: Audience Participation Part of Opera Showcase
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4New Jersey's efforts to instill love of the opera in schoOlage children was made to seem possible, if not easy, at the State Museum auditorium here today.

title: Ford Press Plane Diverted
description: A chartered plane carrying the press corps that had been with President Ford, was diverted by snowy weather from Washington to New York's Kennedy International Airport last night, according to The Associated Press.

title: DialaRide Bus Setup Is Planned for Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 4The Nassau County Executive, Ralph G. Caso, said today that the county would ask for a $501,000 grant from the Federal Department of Transportation for a DialaRide bus transportation system in two pilot areas in the county.

title: Soviet Sees Arms Pact Aiding U.S. Ties
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 4The Soviet Union indicated today that it wanted a new nuclear arms accord with the United States to help improve relations.

title: MRS. ABM SEEKS A SEAT IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Rep resentative Bella S. Abzug, the Manhattan Democrat whose vigorous feminism has made her a leader of the women's political movement, said today that she was a candidate for the Senate seat held by James L. Buckley, the ConservativeRepublican.

title: The View From Iran: World Reconstruction
description: TEHERANOne of the greatest mistakes anyone can make is to single out the rise in oil prices as the underlying cause of the world's economic problems today, because this view is not only false, but also it provides basis for postponing an effective and lasting solution to these problems.

title: Byrne's Budget Is Regarded As Another Part of Tax Battle
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4Governor Byrne delivered a new state budget to a joint session of the New Jersey Legislature this afternoon, but that document raised the same question that had plagued Mr. Byrne since he took office here a year ago; what are his chances of getting legislative approval of a state income tax? While the Governor, a Democrat, spent only 19 minutes summarizing what he proposed to tax and spend during the fiscal year that begins July 1, the budget document itself was as thick as the Newark telephone directory despite the wholesale cuts that Mr. Byrne went the

title: CAREY HELD COOL TO AN M.T.A. LOAN
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4Governor Carey is expected to turn down a request by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for a $110million loan to help the deficitridden agency get through the first three months of the year, an aide to the Governor said today.

title: MONDALE SCORES FORD ON TAX PLAN
description: Senator Walter F. Mondale last night criticized President Ford's proposal for a $12billion tax rebate as giving the most relief to those who need it least and the least relief to those who need it most.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two indictments charging Joseph Colombo Sr.. the reputed Mafia figure, with criminal contempt, grand larceny, weapons possession, robbery and conspiracy have been dropped by Judge Raymond L. Wilkes of the Nassau County Court in Mineola on motion of the District Attorney's office, because an examination by a federally appointed physician last Saturday showed Mr. Colombo still to be paralyzed from a bullet fired by an assassin on June 28, 1971, a spokesman for the District Attorney's office said.

title: William D. Coolidge, Inventor, 101, Dies
description: Dr. William D. Coolidge. the developer of the modern Xray tube and of the ductile tungsten filament used in electric lightllulbs, died Monday night at his home in Schenectady, N. Y. lie was 101 years old.

title: Getty Oil Raises Profit 12.3% And Sales 57.1% in Quarter
description: The Getty Oil Company reported yesterday a gain of 12.3 per cent in fourthquarter net income on a sales and revenue gain of 57.1 per cent. Net income for the full year rose 97.6 per cent as sales rose 61.1 per cent.

title: Lots of Books, Lots of Pots and Some Cooking Classes, Too
States Shift From Property Tax in Bid to Equalize School Funds
description: In Grosse Pointe, the wealthy Detroit suburb, the schools that educate the offspring of top automobile executives are being forced to trim their faculties and superior curricular offerings.

title: 100 Americans Flown Out Of Embattled Eritrea City
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Wednesday. Feb. 5 (AP)More than 100 Americans, mostly women and children, were airlifted along with other foreigners yesterday from the embattled Eritrean capital of Asmara to the safety of Addis Ababa.

title: G.O.P. Loyalist Opposes Some Key Ford Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Representative William C. Wampler is a Republican with impeccable conservative credentials. He abhors deficit spending. He has voted against most liberal programs through the years, and is considered a party loyalist.

title: Nurses Account Backs Doctor in Abortion Trial
description: BOSTON, Feb. 4 (UPI)Two nurses testified today that Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin could not have watched a wall clock while a fetus died during an abortion he performed because there were no clocks in the operating room.

title: New Stagflation Era?; Ford's Plan Raises Issue of Accepting High Inflation and Unemployment Rate
description: Has the United States entered a new era of high unemployment and inflation? It has at least according to President Ford's budget for fiscal 1976 and his justreleased Economic Report. The accompanying charts, based on those documents, tell the basic story of this new era, which has variously been called stagflation, slumpflation and now (by Albert T. Sommers, chief economist of the Conference Board) inflump.

title: CITIES AND STATES UPSET BY BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Spokesmen for local governments expressed disappointment today over President Ford's proposed budget and predicted a fiscal emergency if Congress goes along with it.

title: Lina Wertmuller Defines FreeWheeling Politics
description: In Lina Wertmuller's Love and Anarchy and The Seduction of Mimitwo movies that have been most enthusiastically received in this countrysexual hypocrisies and political dilemmas confront characters who merely yearn to lead peaceful private lives.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GOLDEN ECHOES The pastthe ripe years of the old Metropolitan Opera heyday and Chaplin moviesis beckoning today, from unexpected corners.

title: E.P.A. Marks $6Billion For Sewage Treatment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 4 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency said today it intended to obligate between $6billion and $7billion for municipal sewage treatment plants over the next 18 months.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: The First Lady and Her Daughter Shop for Prom Clothes
description: Betty Ford was the talk of Seventh Avenue yesterday, though hardly anybody saw her. But the word got out that she was visiting Albert Capraro, the young designer whom she had earlier invited to the White House, and everybody was gossiping about it.

title: 19thCentury Music Played With Ardor By Mirecourt Trio
description: There are players of 19thcentury chamber music who seek to reflect the genteel refinement of the aristocratic saIons, while others take the hightemperament road with performances of passion and fullblown romantic sweep. The energetic young men of the Mirecourt Trio?are obviously of the latter persuasion, and since their ardor is matched by stylistic cohesion and technical expertise, their Carnegie Recital Hall debut on Monday night was exceptionally satisfying.

title: PLO. ASKS ENTRY IN U.N. DIRECTORY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 4The Palestine Liberation Oroanization is seeking to enhance its international status by getting a special listing in the United Nations Blue Book of permanent missions in New York.

title: Hartford to Tighten Rules To Curb Nursing Homes
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 4Connecticut health officials said today they would adopt strict regulations forcing nursing homes to disclose their true owners and true profits.

title: REBELS DESTROY A MEKONG CONVOY
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 4A convoy of supply ships returning empty to South Vietnam from Phnom Penh was torn apart on the Mekong River yesterday when it reportedly ran into a minefield laid by the Communistled Cambodian insurgents who control most of the river.

title: 76ers Nip Braves in Overtime
Bucky Harris Never Pulled a Knife
description: The Red Sox were visiting Griffith Stadium in Washington and Elizabeth Sutherland Harris, bride of the Senators manager and second baseman, was watching from box with her father, the Senator from West Virginia. Red Ruffing, young and fast and just beginning to capitalize on the gifts that would win him a welcome in baseball's Hall of Fame, was pitching for Boston. The game went into extra innings, and as the afternoon light waned Ruffing grew stronger. Or so it seemed to Bucky Harris, who hadn't scratched a hit all day. At length the Senators got two runners on base with two out. Get on some way, Harris implored the next hitter. Fill the bases, and I'll get a run home somehow. Washington did fill the bases, and the manager walked to the plate with a silent prayer: Let him throw one close, please! Ruffing rocked back and fired. Shutting his eyes, Harris twisted like a contortionist. small moan escaped him when the ball thudded against his ribs, but the winning run came home.

title: Ford Says 1976 Economy Will Favor Reelection Bid
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 4President Ford, discounting his current low standing in some public opinion polls, said today that economic conditions would be favorable enough in 1976 for him to run for a full term in office.

title: Canada to Invest $1.4Billion To Save TarSands Oil Project
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 4The Canadian Government and two provinces announced today that they would invest about $1.4billion to save a project to extract oil from the Athabasca tar sands in Alberta.

title: Ford Confirms Justice Official Gave Him Douglas Inquiry Data
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 President Ford said today that he received information from the Department of Justice during his unsuccessful effort to get the House of Representatives to impeach Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court.

title: Kodes Bows To Kreiss In Upset
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 4 (AP)Unseeded Bob Kreiss of Beverly Hills, Calif., upset Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, 63, 64, in the first round of the $25,000 Arkansas international tennis tournament tonight. The 21yearold Kreiss, ranked only 33d in the United States, played well at the net.

title: Tennessee, N.C.A.A. Deepen Studies of King's Transcripts
description: The investigation into the eligibility of Bernard King spread yesterday when the University of Tennessee sent three top school officials here to inspect the basketball star's junior and senior high school grades transcript.

title: Ford Says 1976 Economy Will Favor Reelection Bid
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 4President Ford, discounting his current low standing in some public opinion polls, said today that economic conditions would be favorable enough in 1976 for him to run for a full term in office.

title: FIRST BOSTON'S NET UP 227% IN QUARTER
description: The First Boston Corporation, the investment banking house, reported here yesterday that profits rose by 227 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1974 and by 132 per cent for the full year.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER OFF
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchahge and in the overthecounter market dropped yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: Heath Out as Tory Leader; Woman Tops First Voting
description: LONDON, Feb. 4Former Prime Minister Edward Heath's 10year leadership of Britain's Conservative party came to an end tonight.

title: Revived Palmer Is Optimistic
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 4 (AP)Arnold Palmer has shrugged off the disappointment of his most recent defeat and is ready to make run to win the $160,000 Bob Hope Desert golf tournament for the sixth time.

title: Suit Against Village Voice Must Go to Trial, Court Rules
description: Justice Harold Baer has ruled in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that a trial should be held on a lawyer's complaint that his character was defamed by a 1972 article in The Village Voice.

title: Soviet Team Checks Apollo
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 4A 19man Soviet team of scientists and engineer's completed today their checkout of the Apollo spacecraft and linking device, which will be joined in space this July by ?? Russian Soyuz space ship.

title: EXTENSION IS SOUGHT ON AVISI.T.T. DEAL
description: Richard Joyce Smith, trustee for the 52 per cent interest in Avis, Inc., that the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, pursuant to a court order, turned over to him last month, reported yesterday to Federal Judge M. Joseph Blumenfeld that disposition of Avis shares by way of an exchange of these shares for I.T.8,ET. shares is not feasible at this time.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Port Authority Contract in Court

title: Nessen Lifts Sanction On StarNews Reporter
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 4 (UPI)The White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, today reinstated Fred Barnes, correspondent for The Washington StarNews, as one of the questioners at President Ford's news conference.

title: Gonzales Doesn't See Sponsor Buying ConnorsLaver Rematch
description: Fans everywhere were still buzzing yesterday over the Jimmy ConnorsRod Laver spectacular, and some were wondering about the possibility of an encore.

title: Wealthy Districts Facing School Fiscal Challenge
description: The prospect of finding new methods to finance public schools in the metropolitan New York regiona challenge now staring both New Jersey and Connecticut in the faceputs wealthy school districts in an uncomfortable and, to a large extent, an ambiguous position. On the one hand, few persons, especially educators, in such districts are willing

title: Individual Rights vs. Legislative Rights at Issue Again
description: The legitimacy of the United States Senate subcommittee's inquiry into the nursinghome business, challenged yesterday when Bernard Bergman refused to testify, dramatizes the tension between constitutional protections given to an individual and the purpose of a legislative body, which is to pass laws for the benefit of everyone. Members of the Senate subcommittee on longterm care have justified the hearings on the ground that they seek information to further pursue a legitimate legislative purpose. Civil libertarians, though, have complained that the treatment of Mr. Bergman, who now faces a contemptofCongress citation, may be unconstitutional.

title: Kissinger Oil Price Plan Finds Industry Skeptical
description: Secretary of State Kissinger's plan for putting a floor under oil prices to encourage investments in fuel sources other than imports drew a skeptical reaction from the oil industry and energy analysts yesterday although the concept was praised by some experts.

title: Mrs. King Heading For Sets?
description: Is Billie Jean King headed for the New York Sets in a desperate lob to save World Team Tennis?

title: Cab Board Calls Ridership Stable After Rise in Fares
description: The city's Taxi and Limousine Commission released taxi fleet figures yesterday indicating that ridership remained relatively stable during the first, two months following last fall's fare increase of 17.5 percent.

title: Suspect Is Accused Of 2d Strangulation Same as One in 71
description: VINELAND, Feb. 4  The police in this Cumberlandl County city disclosed todayn that a 21yearold paroled inmate of the Yardville Correction Center, charged with the strangulation of an assistant night manager of a restaurant. committed an identical slaying, in 1971 and served only twoandonehalf years of a 15year sentence for that crime.

title: SEATING OF VIETCONG IN U.N. PARLEY ASKED
description: VIENNA, Feb. 4 (Reuters)The Soviet Union jolted the opening session of a United Nations legal conference here today with a demand that the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government be invited to take part.

title: Dow Chemical Net Up 108% in Quarter
description: The Dow Chemical Company, a major diversified chemicals producer, reported yesterday 108.9 per cent increase in fourthquarter net income despite a change in inventory accounting to the lastin, firstout method. Earnings for the year rose 102 oer cent.

title: Led Zeppelin Excites Crowd, but Loses the Delirium
description: By every commercial index. Led Zeppelin, the British band that opened a series of six soldout performances in the New York area Mon!pay night at Madison Square Garden, is the leading contemporary rock group, at least of those steadily touring and putting out records.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: COLBY WITHHOLDS DATAMPOLICE AID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Willliam E. Colby, the Director of Central Intelligence, has refused to identify police departments he say his agency assisted until two years ago because such publication could hamper current police programs.

title: Venezuela Will Hold OilExporting Price
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 4 (Reuters)Venezuela, the United States biggest oil supplier, announced today it would maintain its oil export price at the present $13.61 a barrel for the next nine months. The Minister of Mines and Hydrocarbons, Valentin Hernandez, told newsmen after cabinet meeting that the decision was in accordance with an agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, of which Venezuela is a member.

title: JOHN R TUNIS, 85. AlliNR, IS DEAD
description: John Roberts Tunis, one of the country's most successful freelance writers, died yesterday at his home on Stanford Hill Road, Essex, Conn. He was S5 years old.

title: GEORGE E. M'LELLAN JR.
description: George E. MacLellan Jr., vice president and treasurer of American Woolen Company, a unit of Textron, Inc., at his retirement in 1961, died of heart ailment at his home. He was 80 years old and lived at 35 Roosevelt Avenue, New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Soviet Chided by U.S. On Parking Abuses Here
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 4The united States mission has told the Soviet delegation that its automobile parking abuses show a blatant disregard for New York City's regulations.

title: Saigon Arrests Put at 17 In a Crackdown on Press
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4Seventeen Saigon journalists have been arrested as Communist agents in the Government's crackdown on the press, an informed Government source said today.

title: PERUVIAN POLICE STRIKE OVER PAY
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 4The police in Lima and reportedly in other Peruvian cities have gone on strike, mainly for higher wages.

title: Jersey Education: $ + $ = Quality
description: The schools of Englewood Cliffs rest on a financial foundation as solid as the Palisades granite on which the prosperous New Jersey suburban community is built. Realestate taxes there yield more than $2,300 a year per pupil.

title: Investigators Link Airline Food Poisoning to Caterer's Meats
description: Federal and Alaskan health officials have imposed a temporary ban on ham and cold cuts served by International Inflight Catering of Anchorage, Alaska, whose meals Danish officials blamed for an outbreak of food poisoning that affected 144 passengers on a Japan Air Lines flight in Copenhagen on Monday.

title: MRS. ABE SEEKS A SEAT IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Representative Bella S. Abzug, the Manhattan Democrat whose vigorous feminism has made her a leader of the women's political movement, said today that she was a candidate for the Senate seat held by James L. Buckley, the ConservativeRepublican.

title: FRED P. LANG
description: Fred P. Lang, a retired hanker and broker, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Orange (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 56 Hilltop Road, Short Hills, N.J.

title: W. T. Grant and Levitz Report Big Sales Declines
description: Two large retail chains, the W. T. Grant Company and the Levitz Furniture Corporation, yesterday reported sizable sales declines in January compared with January, 1974.

title: Liberal Czech Exile in Italy Escapes a Package Bomb
description: ROME, Feb. 4Jiri Pelikan, head of Czechoslovak television during the Dubcek period, who now lives in Rome, received a package in the mail today that turned out to be an explosive device.

title: Wallace First on List In Funds for Campaign
Books of The Times
description: I can't understand why writers are always grinding out novels of the future when that future almost invariably turns out to be boring and unconvincing. It is usually the same future, too, that the last such novel described, as if there were only one version. In 1995 or 2000, or whenever it is, we find that life has been depersonalized. Instead of multiplying the possibilities of individual expression, the advance of technology has paradoxically reduced them.

title: Heath Out as Tory Leader; Woman Tops First Voting
description: LONDON, Feb. 4 Former Prime Minister Edward Heath's 10year leadership of Britain's Conservative party came to an end tonight.

title: GASIFICATION UNIT POSTPONED AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 A second oneyear postponement was disclosed today in the timetable of a pioneering, SIbillion plan to strip mine the country's vast reserve of Western coal for conversion into desperately needed, nonpolluting synthetic gas.

title: CAREY HELD COOL TO AN M.T.A. LOAN
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4Governor Carey is expected to turn down a request by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for a $110million loan to help the deficitridden agency get, through the first three months of the year, an aide to the Governor said today.

title: Bridge:
description: The French team that finished third in the world team championship in Bermuda last week has every reason to be satisfied with its performance. Its players beat the Americans twice in the qualifying stage, lost to them in the semifinsals after a close fight in which they had the worst of the luck, and were the most popular team in the event.

title: RESERVE SIGNALS EASING OF CREDIT
description: The Federal Reserve Board signaled easier credit conditions yesterday by reducing the discount rate it charges on loans to commercial banks. The action was interpreted as another move to stimulate the economy.

title: RESERVE SIGNALS EASING OF CREDIT
description: The Federal Reserve Board signaled easier credit conditions yesterday by reducing the discount rate it charges on loans to commercial banks. The action was interpreted as another move to stimulate the economy.

title: SCHOOL DISTRICTS FACING A FREEZE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4The State Senate voted final passage today of a measure that would freeze the current school decentralization lines in New York City for two years.

title: SIMON FIGHTS BILL TO EXPAND CREDIT
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 4 (AP)Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today that a plan, proposed by the Democratic leadership, to lower interest rates and allocate credit was unnecessary and unenforceable. He said the legislation would rob the country of many freedoms which we have long enjoyed.

title: People and Business
description: Oil companies exploring and developing the British sector of the North Sea were assured again yesterday that they won't lose financially from the British Government's planned 51 per cent takeover of the oil fields.

title: About New York
description: The great American dream show came into New York last weekend, and in its first two days it brought 142,000 people into the Coliseum to look at automobiles. The extraordinary thing is that the adults among them paid S3 each for themselves and $1.50 for their children to do this, and the whole exercise was devoted to getting them to buy cars.

title: Market Place
description: About six weeks ago, when the General Motors Corporation and the other auto makers began their massive layoffs because of the huge inventories of unsold new cars, Wall Street analysts predicted that the G.M. dividend was nonetheless safe.

title: Harris of Islanders Urged to Be Leader
description: Sitting in a plane flying from New York to Montreal last week, Bill Torrey, the Islanders general manager, was thinking about Billy Harris. Torrey was on his way to the National Hockey League's AllStar game and Harris, the club's dependable right wing, was not.

title: Washington's Role in Oil Industry Stirs Controversy
description: WASHINGTON  We're much more ensnared with Government, says a captain of the oil industry as he looks over his shoulder at the events of the last two years. Every place we turn we're much more involved with the Government.

title: BERGMAN REFUSES TO TESTIFY
description: Bernard Bergman refused to appear at a United States Senate hearing here yesterday, his accountant pleaded the Fifth Amendment and Stanley Steingut, Speaker of the New York State Assembly, said he could not remember telling Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein not to investigate Mr. Bergman's nursing homes.

title: SCALI URGES U.S. STAY IN THE U.N.
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 4John Scali, delegate to the United Nations, told a Congressional subcommittee today that the United States should continue paying its full share of assessments and remain an active member despite thirdworld actions found objectionable by the United States.

title: 84 Yachts Set Sail in Race to Fort Lauderdale Today
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 4The splendid marina of the St. Petersburg Yacht Club has been a fashion show this last week with the fleet of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference on display like fashion models walking a runway. The display ends tomorrow as the fleet goes to sea to start the 370mile ocean race round the southern tip of Florida to Fort Lauderdale on the East Coast that will take about three days.

title: State Utility Study Finds Con Ed Is Worst Offender on Complaints
description: An independent management study by the consulting firm of Arthur D. Little, Inc., has found that the rate of customer comPlaints of the Consolidated Edison Company is higher than that for any other utility company in the state and that its system for handling these cornplaints is inadequate.

title: Guerrilla Dissident Offers To Return Group to P.L.O.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 4George Habash, leader of the Iradical Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, offered to return today to the Pales1 tine Liberation Organization if Yasir Arafat, head of the organization, rejected any negotiated Middle East settlement that would recognize Israel.

title: Jersey Democrat to Head A Panel on Transportation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) Representative James J. Howard of New Jersey was chosen today by his Democratic colleagues on the House Public Works Committee to head its Subcommittee on Surface Transportation.

title: Jersey Education: $ + $ = Quality
description: The schools of Englewood Cliffs rest on a financial foundation as solid as the Palisades granite on which the prosperous New Jersey suburban community is built. Realestate taxes there yield more than $2,300 a year per nunil.

title: An American Village Looks On
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Feb. 4One of the remarkable things about all the current problems of the nation is the patience of the American people. They are obviously troubled but at least in this village, steady. After Vietnam, Watergate and all the other avoidable disasters of the last ten or fifteen years, it would not have been surprising if the present economic crisis had produced an alarming torrent of public protest, but it hasn't happenedat least not yet.

title: Lloyds Bank in Spanish Loan
description: LONDON, Feb. 4 (Reuters) Lloyds Bank International, Ltd., said yesterday it and the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce had jointly arranged $6.8million fiveyear loan to Empress Nacional del Uranto, S.A..

title: Thleu Replaces a Key General With One He Removed Earlier
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 5President Nguyen Van Thieu today re placed the commander of the strategic area around Saigon with a general who had been removed from his post three, months ago as a gesture to demands for a cleanup of corruption in the army.

title: DONALD TAYLOR, 55, A YALE DEAN, DIES
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 4Dr. Donald Wayne Taylor, dean of the Yale Graduate School, died of cancer this morning at the Yale Health Services Center He was 55 years old.

title: MRS. ABZUG SEEKS A SEAT IN SENATE
Excerpts From Testimony at Senate Subcommittee Hearing on LongTerm Care
description: SENATOR CHARLES PERCY: Mr. Stein, the comments made in this newspaper article are quite strong. The sum and substance of it is that Mr. Stanley Steingut, Speaker of the State Assembly, apparently telephoned you and asked you to divert the attention of your commission from investigating nursing homes owned by Mr. Bernard Bergman. And when Mr. Steingut was advised of this, he said, Assemblyman Stein is a goddamned I hate to use that word but have to quote it. Would you care comment that?

title: Dr. Frances Stillman Dies; English Professor at City, 65
description: Dr. Frances Jennings Stillman, assistant professor of English at City College and a writer and translator, died Monday at New York Hospital of complications resulting from kidney failure. She was G5 years old and lived at 24 Gramercy Park.

title: TWO TRADE GROUPS OPEN MOSCOW TALKS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 4Western Europe's Common Market and Comecon, the economic alliance of the Soviet bloc, opened their first formal discussions here today.

title: FORD PLANS EASE GOVERNORS FEARS
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 4  The South's Governors are not accepting all of President Ford's suggestions for solving the nation's energy and economic problems, but they seem greatly relieved that solutions have at last been proposed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C. State Conquers Clemson
description: RALEIGH, N.C.. Feb. 4 (AP) David Thompson scored 39 points tonight in leading North Carolina State to a 9289 basketball victory over Clemson.

title: Sabres Trounce Wings
The Text of President Ford's Economic Report to Congress Proposing Steps to Ease the Severe Recession
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Following is the text of the economic report of President Ford as submitted to Congress today:

title: People in Sports
description: Tommy Ivan, a dapper little man who transformed two tired franchises into National Hockey League powers, was named yesterday a winner of the Lester Patrick Award for outstanding service to hockey in the United States.

title: CORRECTION
