description: A photograph of President Franklin D. Roosevelt signing the Social Security Act, published in The New York Times on Monday, was made on Aug. 14, 1935, and not, as stated in the caption, in 1939.

title: If Winter Is Gray in Hungary, There's Always a Pastry Shop
description: BUDAPEST  Despite the depredations on gracious living wrought in Hungary by the halfhour lunch, world recession and a quartercentury of Communism, a few of the splendors of the Hapsburg Empire seem, if anything, to grow more lustrous. A conspicuous example is pastry.

title: Interior Department Planning to Share Offshore Oil Funds With Coastal States
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Feb. The Department of the Interior is working on a plan to share with coastal states the billions of dollars it garners from offshore oil leases, an official disclosed today.

title: JERSEY TO GUIDE NEWARK SCHOOLS
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4Governor Byrne announced today that the state would oversee the reform of the administration of Newark's problemplagued school system.

title: Vanderbilt to Step Down As N.Y.R.A. Head in May
description: Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt announced yesterday his decision to resign as chairman of the board of the New York Racing Association. The 62yearold Vanderbilt, who has been a forceful figure in thoroughbred racing for most of his life, will leave the post when his term expires in May.

title: Uganda Bars Newsmen Who Want to See Amin
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb. 5 (Reuters)Uganda will bar all foreign correspondents who want to interview President Idi Amin because most are spies, a military spokesman said today.

title: New World Symphony Cancels Sunday Date
description: The Symphony of the New World has canceled its concert next Sunday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall. Dick Campbell. the orchestra's executive director, said that the action was caused by a shortage of funds to meet immediate obligations. The season's remaining subscription concerts, on April 13 and May 4, and a First Bicentennial Concert, on May 22 in Carnegie Hall, will he given as planned.

title: Contract Awards
description: A $40million order has been received by Combustion Engineering, Inc., from the Public Service Company Oklahoma for two 430megawatt steam generators. These will be the first coalfired steam units in the Tulsabased utility's system.

title: Schools Seek Revised Playoffs
description: In the minds of many persons, last year's first statesanctioned New Jersey high school football playoffs to determine sectional champions were a multifaceted mistake. To begin with, a large number of observers, including many who covered the schoolboy scene for years, believed that several of the best teams in the state had been left out of the postseason games because of an antiquated pointrating formula the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association employed to determine sectional

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation was found guilty in Federal Court in Newark of age discrimination employment and the jury ordered the company to pay $750,000 to the estate of a research chemist who had been forced to retire at the age of 60. The award would be the highest ever granted under the 1967 Age Discrimination Act, according to a spokesman for the United States Department of Labor. The suit was brought by Gladys E. Rogers and her daughter, Margaret Ann Rogers, formerly of Summit, N. J.

title: Key NursingHome Figure Faces Stein Inquiry Today
description: Eugene Hollander, a central figure in the nursing home industry in New York, will be the principal witness today when the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy resumes its hearings on nursing homes.

title: Army Judge Tells G.I. His Moustache Must Go
description: FORT CAMPBELL Ky., Feb. 5 (UPI)A military judge ruled today that there was no place in the Army for an eightinch handlebar moustache, but decided not to penalize an enlisted man for refusing to cut his off.

title: Seton Hall on Top
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J ., Feb 5John Ramsay had 32 points and three teammates had 20 or more points tonight as Seton Hall defeated Villanova, 9991. It was the Pirates 11th victory in 16 starts.

title: Kenon Sparks Nets To Victory Over Q's
U.S. Resumes Conversion Of Minuteman to MIRV's
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (Reuters)The Defense Department disclosed today that it had re sinned converting 50 Minuteman missiles for multiple warheads after a suspension.

title: Miller, at 64, Leads Golf By 2 Shots
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif ., Feb. 5Johnny Miller's back and shoulder muscles were a bit taut today, so the best he !could shoot was a 64, eight strokes under par.

title: Snow and Traffic Tickets Fail To Stop Mahwah Jobless Rally
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Ronny, you're looking good," said Bernie Jackson, vice president of Local 906 of the United Auto Workers union, as the first of four buses pulled out of Ford's Mahwah assembly plant this morning.

title: JOB RALLY DRAWS 10,000 TO CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Nearly 10,000 automobile workers rallied in Washington today demanding action from the Ford Administration and Congress to end the recession and provide jobs.

title: Swiss Skiers Excel in Games for Deaf
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 5 (AP) Teenage Swiss skiers won gold medals today in the men's and woman's downhill events here at the eighth World Winter Games for the Deaf. Peter Wyss, 18 years old, of Wetzikon, led a Swiss sweep of the men's event with a time of 1 minute 44.39 seconds. Helen Sonderegger, 16, of Rehetobel, garnered first place in the women's competition with a time of 1:56.89.

title: Tennessee Reinstates Star
description: Bernard King, the acclaimed freshman star of the University of Tennessee's basketball team, was reinstated yesterday, although new evidence disclosed that his high school marks had been tampered with.

title: Lawyers for Errichetti Seek to Discredit Witness
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5  Defense attorneys told jurors today in the conspiracy trial of Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden and two others that the state's key witness was too unreliable to be believed.

title: Shyre Sheds New Light On Attitudes of Mencken
description: It's surprising how many young people who come backstage to tell me they enjoyed the show say they never heard of H. L. Mencken, Paul Shyre said the other day. They say, How can we find out more about him?'

title: Paying for Justice
description: The backbone of the Federal judicial system is the group of 497 District Court judges and the 95 Court of Appeals judges who decide the multiplicity of cases, civil and criminal, that normally do not reach the United States Supreme Court. The system itself is in trouble because there are too few judges to handle all the matters on growing dockets and the salaries of these judges have been frozen since 1969. The result: delays in the delivery of justice and resignations of able and experienced judges who cannot afford to serve.

title: Taking of Profits Is Shrugged Off by Broad Gain
description: The stock market shrugged off profit taking yesterday and finished with a broad advance in continued active trading.

title: L.I.U. Downs C.C.N.Y., 11488
description: In allowing more than 100 points for the second straight game, City College's basketball team was defeated by Long Island University, 11488, last night at the loser's Mahoney Gymnasium. The total was the most ever scored against the Beavers.

title: 2HourOld Boy Found Abandoned in Brooklyn
description: A twohourold boy was found abandoned in the hallway of a Brooklyn apartment building yesterday morning. wrapped in towels and nestled in a plastic shopping bag.

title: Advertising
description: John Macl Carter, once editor of McCall's magazine and then editor of The Ladies Home Journal, has been named editor of Good Housekeeping.

title: Ailing Brezhnev Is Still on Front Page
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 5  While ranking diplomats have pondered the whereabouts of Leonid I. Brezhnev over the last six !weeks, a hardworking Estonian !dairywoman seems to have had little trouble striking up a correspondence with the Soviet leader.

title: CHASE REALTY TRUST AT BORROWING LIMIT
description: The Chase Manhattan Martgage and Realty Trust, a Bostonbased real estate investment trust, reported yesterday that it had reached the limit cd is borrowing capabilityeight I times its net worth.

title: ExBacker Calls Nixon Political Schizophrenic
description: MUNCIE, Ind., Feb. 5 (UPI)  Former Representative David Dennis, who defended President Nixon in the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment hearings, said last night that the former President. was a political schizophrenic who could no longer speak for the Republican party.

title: I.B.M. Given Delay In Antitrust Suit
description: Federal Judge David N. Edelstein granted yesterday a delay in the beginning of the trial of the Justice Department's antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation. The judge did not set a new date for the trial.

title: EUGENE MACDONALD
description: Eugene L. Macdonald, who retired in 1956 as chairman and senior partner of Parsons, Brinckerhoff, Hall & Macdonald, civil engineers, architects and planners here, died Saturday in Princeton Medical Center. He was 84 years old, and lived in Pennington, N. J.

title: Opposition Likely Over Head of House C.I.A. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 House Democrats may face an, internal struggle over the chairmanship of a new committee that will investigate the conduct of Government intelligence agencies.

title: Oil Price Floor . . .
description: Secretary Kissinger's proposal to put an agreed, longterm floor under the price at which imported petroleum is sold within the domestic markets of the main industrial nations is an essential step if dependence on the oil cartel is to be gradually reduced.

title: Tennessee Reinstates King, Freshman Star
Technical Mastery Of Violin Prevails In Washio Recital
description: Yuko Washio, a Japanese violinist who made her debut here in 1973 after several years of study at the Juilliard School, came to Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night to give her second New York recital.

title: GRACE ROOT, AIDED HAMILTON COLLEGE
description: Grace Cogswell Root, daughterinlaw of Elihu Root, Secretary of State from 1905 to 1909 and Senator from New York from 1909 to 1915, died Monday in University Hospital. She was 84 years old.

title: Market Place
description: Small investors who have already found it difficult to et investment opinions about small to mediumsize companies are likely to find the situation even worse when competitive commission rates become the rule on May 1.

title: Rocket in Phnom Perth Kills 10 Schoolchildren
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Thursday, Feb. 6 (AP)  A rocket fired by insurgent forces hit a tree alongside an elementary school here today, killing at least 10 children and wounding more than 30, policemen reported from the scene.

title: REP. ADAMS HEADS NEW BUDGET UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Representative Brock Adams, a liberal Democrat from Washington, was chosen chairman today of the new House Budget Committee, which may come to exert substantial influence over Federal fiscal affairs.

title: Fugitive Maryland Lifer Is Freed Here
description: Nick Bagley, a 31yearold escaped convict whose cause has been embraced by hundreds of New Yorkers, walked out of State Supreme Court a free man yesterday after a judge dismissed the extradition charges that would have returned him to a Maryland prison for life.

title: Music
description: A program that begins with Beethoven and ends with Sehumann would seem to be pure gold. It did not hold true for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in its concert in Mice Tully Hall on Tuesday night. and part of the dross was the Beethoven work.

title: Key to Civic Efficiency
description: The report on the city's drive to increase productivity in the parks in the last half of 1974 underscores the importance of managerial competence at all levels in determining the efficiency of New York's civil service employes.

title: Indictments Dismissed
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Feb. 5 (AP)  A Federal judge dismissed today 11 count indictments against three of the original leaders in the 1973 armed takeover of the village of Wounded Knee, S.D. United States District Judge Fred Nichol . dismissed indicIments against Carter Camp, Stanley Holder and Leonard Crow Dog.

title: Meeting With Bergman Is Denied by Rockefeller
description: Vice President Rockefeller denied yesterday that he had ever attended a meeting with Bernard Bergman, despite testimony by Stanley Steingut, Speaker of the State Senate, implying that such a meeting had taken place.

title: MRS. E. K. FRETWELL
description: Mrs. E. K. Fretwell, chairman of the camp committee of the Greater New York Council of Girl Scouts in the nineteenthirties and forties, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn. She was 86 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
Italian Developer Proposes Huge South Bronx Project
description: The city and Renzo Zingone, a major Italian builder and developer, have signed a letter of intent under which Mr. Zingone would erect a complex of factory buildings in the Penn Central's Harlem River yards in the South Bronx, creating two million square feet of manufacturing space with a potential of 5,000 new jobs.

title: IRENE HARAND
description: Irene Harand, of 16836 88th Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, who was decorated by Austria and Israel for her opposition to Hitler and National Socialism in Austria in the nineteenthirties, died Monday in Jamaica Hospital. She was 75 years old.

title: Kissinger May See Gromyko
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5State Department officials said today that Secretary of State Kissinger was likely to meet briefly with Foreign Minister Gromyko Feb. 16 or 17 in Geneva after his next Middle East trip.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE LAND REMEMBERS. The Story of a Farm and Its People. By Ben Logan. 277 pages. Viking. $8.95.

title: A Correction
description: In the recipe for chicken ketjap published in yesterday's paper, onehalf cup of ketjap manis, a sweet Indonesian soy sauce, should have been added to the onion and garlic mixture in step 4. Ketjap manis is available at the Culinary Arts; Aphrodisia, 28 Carmine Street; Bloomingdale's and other outlets that sell imported spices.

title: 5 KILLED IN ISRAEL BY A HAND GRENADE
description: NATANYA, Israel, Feb. 5 (AP) A hand grenade thrown into a crowded night club last night killed five persons and wounded 30. Police officials believe it was a senseless act of hooliganism and not the work of Arab terrorists. [In Beirut, however, a splinter group calling itself the Palestinian Popular Struggle Front claimed responsibility for the grenade attack.]

title: Energy Independence
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5In the three weeks since President Ford sent Congress his energy independence plan, debate about it has undergone an important shift.

title: Battler of Legal Fires
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5Orville Schell was home with the flu last week when a friend telephoned to talk about affairs of state. Mr. Schell's friends are the sort who deal famifiarly with Governors and Senators and corporation presidents. Would he consider, the friend wondered, heading a special investigation into New York State's financially tottering Urban Development Corporation Corporation and the fiscal devices that had got it into trouble?

title: Seoul Jails a Demonstrator
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 5 (AP)  A theological student was sentenced to three months in prison today for leading a demonstration against President Chung Hee Park's Government last October. Kim Chin Soo, 20, a junior at Hankook Presbyterian Theological College, was found guilty of unlicensed assembly and demonstration, the court said.

title: Senators Question Inspection of Reactors by Utilities
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 5The chairmen of two Senate committees questioned today whether it was in the public interest for the Government to continue relying on public utilities to conduct safety inspections of their own reactors.

title: Dollar Shows Drop As Gold Holds Firm
description: LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP) The dollar declined today against most continental European currencies following the halfpoint cut in the United States discount rate to 63,4 oer cent.

title: Senate Confirms Levi
description: Edward Hirsch Levi, president of the University of Chicago, was confirmed by the Senate yesterday as Attorney General of the United States. Page 16.

title: MOSCOW ASSAILS PEKING'S CHARTER
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 5The Soviet Union denounced the new Chinese Constitution today as a document designed to perpetuate the ideology of Mao Tsetung.

title: Peruvian Troops Crush Police Revolt in Capital
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 5  Peruvian troops backed by tanks stormed a large police garrison here early today and crushed a revolt by policemen demanding wage increases.

title: CAR MAKERS SALES FELL IN JANUARY
description: DETROIT, Feb. 5 With final figures from the Ford Motor Company stronger than estimated, the four United States auto makers sold a total of 462,691 cars in January, off 16 per cent from last year and the lowest rate for the month since 1961.

title: Looking Backward Into the Future
description: CHICAGO To everyone's surprise, looking backward has again become a major industry. A few years ago the past had no future. Historians were taught to shuffle around feeling irrelevant. The Committee on the Year 2000 and its kith wrote scripts for alternative futures. Radicals turned against all pasts and dreamed of Utopia. PostVatican II Roman Catholics shed their traditions.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Marcos to Proceed With River Project Opposed by Tribes
description: MANILA, Feb. 5The Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos decided today to proceed with construction of the Chico River dam despite opposition from minority tribes that stand to be displaced.

title: People and Business
description: President Ford's Assistant for Economic Affairs, William Seidman, forecast yesterday that the real gross national product would fall at an annual rate of S or 9 per cent during the first quarter. He made the prediction at a luncheon of the MidAtlantic Club in Washington and said this figure would compare with the annual rate of decline of 9.1 per cent in the final quarter of 1974.

title: This Kennel Is Breeding Success
description: Dream Ridge is a name known to cocker spaniel enthusiasts on four continents. Owned by Thomas O'Neal of Woodstock, Ill., the I2yearold kennel has bred 47 champions in this country alone all parti colors. Dream Ridge cockers also have won titles in England, Venezuela, Brazil and Japan.

title: Bergman Aides Predicted High NursingHome Profit
description: When Bernard Bergman bought the Park Crescent Hotel in the nineteensixties and prepared to turn it into a nursing home, his associates advised Wall Street analysts that it should be clearing a net profit of $833,500 a year by 1973, according to a document in the hands of investigators.

title: Caso Rejects Findings of Panel In Dispute Over Nassau Schools
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 5 Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso today rejected recommendations of factfinders for salary increases of about $62milIlion in the next two years for Ithe county's 12,500 municipal employes. Mr. Caso said the raises could cause mass layoffs such as had been occurring in New York City.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: FASHION TALK
description: Summer is the fun time in the annals of fashion; weighty, serious designs are reserved for fall and winter. This week, in the face of unmitigated economic gloom, designers are determined to hold off bankruptcy by being more lighthearted than ever. Downright flighty, in fact.

title: Net Income Advances by 16.2% In Quarter at Times Company
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday a record net income of $4.3million, or 38 cents a share, for the fourth quarter of 1974, up 16.2 per cent from $3.7million, or 33 cents a share, in the yearearlier period.

title: The Supreme Court at Work: A Look at the Inner Sanctum
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 It might be the board room of an affluent, longestablished bank in Boston or Philadelphia. The walls are paneled in oak, a crystal chandelier hangs from the high, coffered ceiling, and a Colonial portrait above a marble fireplace overlooks a long table covered in black leather.

title: Morgan Cuts Its Prime to 8 3/4%; Stocks Rise 9.78 Points on Dow
Bergman Backs New Project
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP ) Bernard Bergman is the major financial backer of a proposed nursing home in the Washington suburb of Arlington. Va., according to an application. cording to an application.

title: INCOME RISES 10% AT CITIES SERVICE
description: Net income of the Cities Service Company rose 10 per cent in the fourth quarter and 50 per cent for the year, the company reported yesterday.

title: Charles Masson, Owner Of La Grenouille, Is Dead
description: Charles Masson, the owner of La Grenouille, widely regarded one of the best French restaurants in the United States died Tuesday of cancer at his home at 225 East 57th Street He was 60 years old.

title: AlIon Says Israel Favors Restoration of Soviet Ties
description: ROME, Feb. 5 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel, in an interview published here today, invited the Soviet Union to resume diplomatic relations with Israel to help the search for peace in the Middle East.

title: Ford Sees Bhutto and Hints U .S May Ease Pakistan Arms Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  President Ford told Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto today that the United States would give active consideration to lifting an embargo that has blocked Pakistan from purchasing American military hardware for nearly 10 years.

title: MALAGASY LEADER GIVES UP HIS POWER
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, Feb. 5 (Reuters)Mai. Gen. Gabriel Ramanantsoa, head of state of the Malagasy Republic, has handed over full executive Dowers to the Interior Minister, Lieut. Col. Richard Ratsimandrava, the Madagascar radio said today.

title: Thousands of Ducks Doomed by Oil Spill
description: WEST DEPTFORD, N. J. , Feb. 5Once again, there is oil and death on the Delaware River.

title: Ford Sees Bhutto and Hints U.S. May Ease Pakistan Arms Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5President Ford told Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto today that the United States would give active consideration to lifting an embargo that has blocked Pakistan from purchasing American military hardware for nearly 10 years.

title: Airline Talks Break Off
description: HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 5 (AP) Contract ncsotiations between Texas International Airlines and the striking Air Line Employes Association broke oi today after the union refused to accept a package offered by the airline, officials here said. No date for resumption of the Washington talks to end the twomonth strike was set by the national Mediation Board, which has been acting as referce in the bargaining.

title: Reagan Misses 3 Sessions Of C.I.A. Spying Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Former California Gov. Ronald Reagan, who has missed three of the four weekly meeting of the Presidential commission in NFestigating the Central Intelligence Agency, reportedly told President Ford when he was asked to join the panel that his speaking engagements might conflict with the meetings.

title: EXBANKER FLEES RHODESIAN PRISON
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 5  Kenneth McIntosh, a bank employe sentenced to 16 years in prison last October for revealing some of the methods by which Rhodesia circumvents international economic sanctions, has escaped from prison.

title: Howard Hill, Champion Archer Who Shot for Errol Flynn, Dies
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 5 (AP)Howard Hill, one of the world's top archers, died yesterday at the age of 76.

title: Finding the Sleeper Isn't Easy
description: This is a recruiter's dream. The scout, usually an assistant coach, takes all the high school basketball players from the metropolitan area, puts their names into a hat, shakes well and out falls a manytalented player whom no one else knows about. It is not that easy. Three coaches of leading local colleges  Roger Gaeckler of Hofstra, Lou Carnesecca of St. John's and Tony Yankovitch, a Manhattan assistant  were asked this week to choose the cream of the area's pool and if they could foresee any sleepers.

title: Venezuela to Cut Oil Output
description: Venezuela announced yesterday it would reduce its oil production by 200,000 barrels a day next week to about 2.6 million barrels a day. Venezuela, which is the largest foreign supplier of oil to the United States, has in the past produced as much as 3.3 million barrels a day. The Venezuelan cutbacks are part of an overall reduction by major oil exporting states to reduce the supply of crude oil available because of the present surplus condition on the market.

title: Snowstorm and Icy Condition of Highways Shut Down Some Schools
description: The first major snowstorm of 1975 in the East dumped almost five inches of snow yesterday in parts of northern and central New Jersey. Dozens of schools in Morris, Sussex and Warren Counties did not hold classes because of icy road conditions.

title: Notes on People
description: Three lawyers who headed major investigation involving the Nixon Administration have announced their departure from Government service to enter private practices. John M. Doar, the former Board of Education president here who directed the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment inquiry, has become a partner in Donovan, Leisure, Newton & Irvine at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

title: A StrayPet Campaign Backs Down on Penalty
description: ARVADA, Colo., Feb. 5 (AP)A drafting error in this city's animal control ordinance has just been discovered. It provides that if a stray pet picked up by the city is not claimed by its owner within 24 hours, the owner will be destroyed.

title: Phone Service Set Up To Aid State's Elderly
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5 (AP)  The state established a tollfree telephone number today to provide the elderly with information on food, fuel and medical assistance available to them.

title: Okun Says Ford Oil Plan Could Curtail U.S. Output
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Arthur M. Okun, who was chief economic adviser to President Lyndon B. Johnson, told Congress today that if President Ford's energy conservation plan is adopted, major oil companies might elect to curtail domestic production instead of imports.

title: Pan Am Loses $48Million in Quarter
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it lost S48.5million during the final quarter of 1974 and a $81.8million in the full year. The fourthquarter and 12month losses were the largest ever reported by a United States airline.

title: Anatoly A. Blagonravov Dies; Soviet Space Spokesman, 80
description: Anatoly A. Blagonravov, for many years a gentle spokesman for the Soviet Union in global cooperative efforts in space, died in Moscow on Tuesday, Moscow radio announced. He was 80 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Budget Expert to Head School Reform
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5  Governor Byrne announced today the appointment of Walter Wechsler, the cecently retired director of the New Jersey Division of Budget and Accounting, to supervise reforms the state has ordered for the highly criticized business management of the Newark school system.

title: Reactors Are Scrutinized for Cracks
description: PEACH BOTTOM, Fa., Feb. 5  The three technicians, dressed in white coveralls, gloves, hoods and yellow plastic boots to protect themselves against radiation, squatted around the large stainless steel pipe that jutted from the side of the 75foothigh reactor containment vessel.

title: INDIA WELCOMES CHINESE PLAYERS
description: CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 5The first conspicuous sign of a thaw in relations between India and China appeared here today when a Chinese team took part in the colorful formal opening of the 33d world table tennis championships.

title: 948,078 IN THE CITY USING FOOD STAMPS
description: New York City has 948,078 participants in the food stamp program858,984, or 89 per cent, of 970,000 welfare recipients, and 89,094 other poor eligiblesthe city's Human Resources Administration said yesterday.

title: EXXON RESEARCH IS GUILTY OF BIAS
description: NEWARK, Feb. 5  A subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation was found guilty of age discrimination in Federal Court yesterday and ordered to pay $750,000 to the estate of a research chemist who had been forced to retire at the age of 60.

title: Fed Unit Increases Target for Growth Of Money Supply
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee raised its targets for both shortrange and longrange growth of the nation's money supply at its meeting in midDecember, a summary of the meeting disclosed today.

title: Old Shell Kills 9 in Egypt
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Feb. 5 (Reuters)  Nine persons were killed and 18 were injuredmostly childrenwhen a World War II artillery shell exploded in an Alexandria suburb today. The shell was buried in a rubbish dump and went off when it was found by a group of children, the police said.

title: Business Briefs
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5, (Reuters) The Continental Investment Corporation said today it was in default on about $57million of bank debt that has been declared due and payable. The concern said a court supervised reorganization of the company was possible.

title: Flyers Turn Back Rangers, 43
Indians Are Uneasy
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 5Indian officials said today that a re!sumption of American arms supplies to Pakistan would seriously damage India's relations with the United States.

title: Avis, Inc., to Omit Dividend In 1975 Current Quarter
description: The common dividend for this quarter will be omitted by Avis, Inc., the company announced yesterday. The action by the company's board involves only the current quarter and no decision has been made with respect to dividend action for the remainder of 1975, the company said. Last year the company paid quarterly dividends of 10 cents.

title: Hard Times for U.D.C. and How They Came About
description: In 1968, when the urban crisis was a catchphrase and Nelson A. Rockefeller was Governor, the New York State Urban Development Corporation was created at his urging to rebuild decayed areas and battle News economic stagnation throughout the state. It was given an array of powers with which to carry out its taskthe authority to condemn property, override local zoning laws and raise revenue through the sale of taxexempt bondsand was the most powerful agency of its kind in the country. Many local officials feared it; urbanaffairs experts watched it closely.

title: Non politician Levi Approved as Attorney General
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 5Edward Hirsch Levi was routinely confirmed as the Attorney General of the United States by the Senate ioday on a voice vote and without debate. Mr. Levi may be the first man to hold that office in modern political history who had never met the President who appointed him.

title: Personal Finance: OneDay Surgery
description: Inandout, or oneday, surgical facilities  where other than serious operative cases can be handled  have been growing steadily in the United States. In the process, costs for such treatment have been reduced by 25 to 40 per cent or more.

title: Heath Out
description: In voting against Edward Heath as their party leader, the Conservative members of the House of Commons have ratified the judgment of Britain's voters in two general elections last year. As Prime Minister, Mr. Heath gravely miscalculated the drift of public opinion when he called an election a year ago on the issue of miners wages. Since independent voters were unconvinced that the Heath Government had the nation's many economic troubles in correct focus, his campaign on the wage inflation issue failed and his party lost its narrow majority in Parliament. A second general election in October widened Tory losses and irreparably impaired Mr. Heath's political position.

title: GOVERNOR ORDERS INQUIRY TO SAVE FALTERING U. D. C.
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5  Governor Carey, moving to avert what he said was the imminent and unthinkable collapse of the Urban Development Corporation, today named Richard Ravitch as chairman of the corporation's board and Orville H. Schell to head an investigation into both the corporation's specific problems and the general question of the financing of state housing construction through moralobligation bonds.

title: AN ACCORD AVERTS FAIRLEIGH STRIKE
description: TEANECK, Feb. 5  Fairleigh Dickinson University and its faculty members, who are represented by the American Association of University Professors, reached agreement on a twoyear contract here today at 1:30 P.M., 90 minutes after a strike deadline set by the union had passed.

title: New Snow Helps Ski Package Plan
A Survey on ItalianAmericans Finds Government is Ignoring Their Needs
description: A sixmonth study by an ItalianAmerican organization has concluded that government is blatantly insensitive to the needs of the ItalianAmerican community. A report on the survey, released yesterday, was based on a statistical analysis of Italian communities in the city.

title: E.P.A. URGES A DELAY IN OFFSHORE LEASES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency has urged the Interior Department to postpone for a least two years the opening of untouched offshore areas for oil and gas leasing, an to bar leasing off the Alaska coast indefinitely.

title: Msgr. William McKenna, 98, Oldest Priest in L.I. Diocese
description: Msgr. William K. McKenna, the oldest priest in the Roman Catholic diocese of Rockville Centre, L. I., died yesterday in the Ozanam Home for the Elderly, Bayside, Queens. He was 98 years old.

title: The Cypriote Refugees: 2 Family Case Studies
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus When Sophia's two older sisters were married, (hey each received houses side by side as dowry. Sophia, 19, shared a few small rooms with her parents.

title: Rockefeller Acts to Gain Domestic Council Control
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Vice President Rockefeller has proposed that two of his top. assistants be put in charge of the White House Domestic Council and reorganize its functions, but the suggestion has run into resistance on the President's staff.

title: Officer Hit With Cleaver Shoots Assailant in Leg
description: A man struck a police officer in the arm with a meat cleaver and was, in turn, shot in the leg by the officer in the Criminal Court building at 100 Centre Street, about midnight last night, the police reported.

title: Cold Horses at Belmont Touted as Hot Prospects
description: Young Ed, Miss Hippie II and Handsome Tod all got the day off at Belmont Park yesterday because of the snow.

title: ARABS SAID TO AGREE ON AID FOR LEBANON
description: CAIRO, Feb. 5, (Reuters)The Arab League's Joint Drfense Council tonight approved Lebanon's request for help against Israeli attacks, the league's Secretary General, Mahmoud Riad, reported.

title: John Dean's MotherinLaw
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 5 (AP)Irene Kane, motherinlaw of John W. Dean 3d, former White House counsel, died today at her home here. She was 66 year's old. Survivors include a son, Ronald Kane, and her daughter, Maureen Dean.

title: Rockefeller Acts to Gain Domestic Council Control
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Vice President Rockefeller has proposed that two of his top assistants be put in charge of the White House Domestic Council and reorganize its functions, but the suggestion has run into resistance on the President's staff.

title: Mrs. King Will Play For Sets
description: New York's pursuit of professional sports headliners continued yesterday when the Sets of World Team Tennis signed Billie Jean King to a fouryear contract that may be worth more than $600,000

title: OWNER OF CELTICS INDICTED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5Robert J. Schmertz, principal owner of the Boston Celtics basketball team, was indicted today on charges of bribing a public official to obtain approval for construction of a $200million retirement village.

title: Consumers Credit Shows Record Fall
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (Reuters) Consumer credit outstanding fell a record of $877million in December, seasonally adjusted, following a decline to $402million in November the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: CITY DRIVE SPURS FILM PRODUCTIONS
description: Production on eight films has started here since the beginning of the year as a result of recent efforts to create a better climate for filmmaking in the city.

title: Senate, 768, Votes Freeze In Price of Food Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  The Senate voted 76 to 8 today to freeze the price of food stamps for the rest of the year.

title: The Supreme Court at Work: A Look at the Inner Sanctum
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  It might be the board room of an affluent, longestablished bank in Boston or Philadelphia. The walls are paneled in oak, a crystal chandelier hangs from the high, coffered ceiling, and a Colonial portrait above a marble fireplace overlooks a long table covered in black leather.

title: Chess:
description: Emanuel Lasker, after losing his world title in 1921 to Jose Rani Ca.T.ablanca in Havana. deplored the rule that introduced castling into chess in the 16th century. So snug a defense did castling provide, he thought, that it was killing off the most exciting part of the gamecombinational mating attacks.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Nassau County Executive Caso rejected recommendations of fact finders for salary increases of about $62million in the next two years for the county's 12,500 municipal employes on the ground that they could cause mass layoffs such as have been occurring in New York City. He said that the reaommendations of two of three fact finders calling for wage increases of 9.5 per cent in the first year of a new contract and 9 per cent in the second year were unacceptable at a time when the county was involved in rigid

title: RATE RIFT SPLITS EXCHANGE BOARD
description: The 20member board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange appeared yesterday to be sharply divided on whether to challenge the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission to eliminate fixed brokerage commission rates by next May.

title: Fund for Walker Family Exceeds $50,000
description: Over $50,000 in checks, pledges and cash donations have poured in to help the six young children of Frank J. Walker, who died last week while trying to subdue a deranged gunman in St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: Crusaders Top Jets
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 5 (AP) Goals by Al McDonough and Ron Ward within one minute of each other in the third period tonight gave the Cleveland Crusaders a 32 victory over the Winnipeg Jets. in a World Hockey Association game.

title: Milwaukee Schools Closed
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 5 (AP)Milwaukee public school officials changed signals and called off classes again this morning after teachers who accepted a new contract refused to cross the picket lines of unions still on strike.

title: 2,500 Policemen Mourn a Slain Officer
description: SUFFERN, N. Y., Feb. 5 About 2,500 police officers from the New York area lined a slushy, bedrizzled Washington Avenue in front of the Church of the Sacred Heart of Jesus this morning during the funeral mass for Officer Frank I. Bugdin Jr.

title: . . . and Why It Helps
description: The simplest device would be a variable levy, similar to that used by the Common Market's agricultural program. Imported oil, whatever its price in world markets, would then pay an adjustable tariff that would lift its price above the floor level. Some countries may prefer to protect investments by means of subsidies, other public financing, tax concessions, import quotas, allocation systems and other methods separately or in combination. Each member of the seventeennation International Energy Agency, under Mr. Kissinger's proposal, would be free to choose its own methods.

title: 1 of Wives Sues on Policeman's Will
description: PATERSON, Feb. 5  Aaron J. Kalahjy, the deputy police chief, died here on Dec. 4, leaving an estate of $300,000 and at least two wives, according to suit, challenging his will and other legal papers, filed here today with the Passaic County Surrogate.

title: F.B.I. ADMITS BUGGING LAWYER IN DETROIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation has admitted that it covertly monitored 40 conversations of a Detroit lawyer and extensively questioned his associates although he himself was not under criminal investigation, an official of the American Civil Liberties Union said last night.

title: Rigid Health Tests Are Sought for Bus Drivers
description: A Federal accident investigation board urged yesterday that stringent new medical screening procedures, similar to those applied to airline pilots, be instituted for the nation's 20,000 intercity bus drivers.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: More than 150 businesses and public agencies in New Jersey secretly eavesdrop on telephone conversations between their employes and the public, according to a New Jersey Bell Telephone spokesman. Such monitoring systems, provided legally by the telephone company to subscribers, are called service observing, a Jersey Bell spokesman said. The monitoring is intended to be used by supervisors of the companies or agencies only for evaluating the job performance of their employes.

title: Grizzlies Are Put on Threatened List
description: DENVER"As Bob and the guide topped the ridge, the bear let out a bloodthinning bawl and came at them in an angry, headlong charge.

title: HOUSE APPROVES A 3MONTH HALT IN OIL IMPORT FEE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  The House of Representatives approved overwhelmingly today legislation suspending for 90 days President Ford's power to increase fees on imported oil.

title: Sales Plunged in January At Retail Stores in City
description: New York City retail business in January suffered one of its biggest declines in more than four years and fell sharply below the national sales level.

title: TV Review
description: Since the first Sony Portapaks were introduced to this country in 196S, halfinch videotape, offering increased portability and lower costs, has been hailed as the salvation of the electronic artist or journalist attempting to remain independent and personal. While the road to massaudience access and recognition has beenand still isrocky, the medium has produced work of outstanding quality.

title: Nightlife in Suburbia No Longer So Staid
description: JEFFERSON PARISH, La.Chris Trauth, who runs a beauty salon in New Orleans, was trying to explain about her earrings, which were attracting almost as much attention as Miss Trauth herself, billowing about in a melonpink chiffon gown.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Parks Chief Gives Schaefer Festival a Reprieve
description: Bowing to pressure from Mayor Beanie, the city's Parks Department yesterday granted a oneyear reprieve for next summer to the popular Schaefer Music Festival. at Wollman Rink in Central Park, which it has been trying to oust as a menace to the area.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: Sacramento, Calif.  Monroe Brooks, 143 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Jose Miranda, 147, Los Angeles, 5 rounds.

title: NESSEN SAYS RACE BY FORD IS SURE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 President Ford plans to seek election to a full term next year regardless of the nation's economic conditions at that time, his spokesman said today.

title: REPORT DEFINES GOOD EDUCATION
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5 (UPI)  The New Jersey Board of Education today received a draft copy of a report defining what constitutes a thorough and efficient education for the state's 1.4 million public school children.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports on changes in stockownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: SCHLESINGER ASKS ARMS FUNDS RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Detense Secretary James R. Schlesinger opened his case before Congress today for a S92.8billion defense budget with the principal argument that the United States must increase its military spending if it is to maintain a global balance with the Soviet Union.

title: GOVERNOR ORDERS INQUIRY TO SAVE FALTERING U. D. C.
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5Governor Carey, moving to avert what he said was the imminent and unthinkable collapse of the Urban Development Corporation, today named Richard Ravitch as chairman of the corporation's board and Orville H. Schell to head an investigation into both the corporation's specific problems and the general question of the financing of state housing construction through moralobligation bonds.

title: People in Sports
description: Dick Allen, who retired from the Chicago White Sox and baseball last September, told the Braves he would not play for them next season. Eddie Robinson, Atlanta general manager, said he had received a letter from Allen to that effect and had asked Allen for an official retirement statement. The Associated Press said from Atlanta that the Braves were placing Allen on the voluntary retirement list. They acquired the rights to him in a trade.

title: OilConsuming Nations Cautious on U.S. Plan for a Floor Price
description: PARIS, Feb. 5The United States presented today to its partners in the newly formed International Energy Agency the proposal for a common minimum price for oil imports that Secretary of State Kissinger made public Monday.

title: Egyptians Throng Funeral of Um Kalthoum, the Arabs Acclaimed Singer
description: CAIRO, Feb. 5  In the Arab world, she may well have been the most famous woman of Egypt since Cleopatra.

title: A Successful Operation
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5 Last December, just before it recessed. Congress put a ceiling of $275 million on military aid for Cambodia in the current fiscal year. The act used unusually firm language, prohibiting spending beyond the ceiling for any operation, project or program of any kind, or for providing any goods, supplies, materials, equipment, services, personnel or advisers. . .

title: HOUSE APPROVES A 3MONTH HALT IN OIL IMPORT FEE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The House of Representatives approved overwhelmingly today legislation suspending for 90 days President Ford's power to increase fees on imported oil.

title: Drive to Keep Franchise Gains
description: SHREVEPORT, La., Feb. 5 (AP) Shreveport Steamer officials said today they had raised nearly $500,000 in a drive to keep the World Football League franchise here. The W.F.L. has given them until March 15 to raise $1.2million through public stock sales to demonstrate community support.

title: First of Ethiopian Tank Force Reported at Embattled Asmara
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 5 (Reuters)Five tanks of an Ethiopian armored columnheld for two days when secessionist rebels blew up a bridge reached the beleaguered Eritrean capital of Asmara tonight, reliable sources here said.

title: Networks in 23 Countries To Carry Moyers Journal
description: Television stations in 23 countries will carry portions of the first installment of Bill Moyers JournalInternational Report featuring an interview with Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Justice Voids Life Terms for the Sale or Possession of Methadone
description: Portions of the state's drug law that call for life sentences for the unauthorized sale or possession of methadone were declared unconstitutional yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Parents Apply Pressure as Sons Take to Judo
description: The day of the judo games dawned bright and clear. With only a bite of breakfast under their yellow belts, the Diamond brothers of Peter Cooper VillageSteven, 8 years old, and Paul, 5were raring to get on the mat and show off their throws and holds.

title: Senate Confirms Levi
description: Edward Hirsch Levi, president of the University of Chicago, was confirmed by the Senate yesterday as Attorney General of the United States. Page 16.

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS DISAGREE ON AUDIT
description: The president and vice president of the Board of Education disagreed yesterday on the merits of a report by the board's auditorgeneral raising serious questions about a possible conflict of interest on the part of one of the school system's top officials, Dr. Edythe J. Gaines.

title: New York Gets Brief Taste of Snow, Followed by Rain
description: The metropolitan area experienced its first significant snowfall of the winter yesterday, causing train and fraffic delays in the suburbs. But the snow soon turned to rain in the city, leaving slush in the streets.

title: If You Pay Like a Man, Play Like a Man
description: In the hiss of traffic on the streets outside Madison Square Garden, most of the overnight .snow had rrielted. There hasn't been much snow hack home either, Ron Greschner was saying. Six or seven inches all winter. Back home. is Goodsoil, Saskatchewan, up where the Canadian prairies vanish into the bush, up where there are towns such as Loon Lake and Compass, up where nobody ever made the National Hockey League until Ron Greschner joined the New York Rangers three months ago. He was a poised 19yearold then. He's even more poised now at 20, although he's competing against players whorl) he knew only as faces on bubblegum cards not long ago. His boyish face will be on a bubblegum card soon. And for many seasons to come. He's considered to be the Rangers best young defenseman since Brad Park arrived six seasons ago. Some knowledgeable hockey people rate him better than Park at a comparable stage. In the Rangers 43 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers, he collected his 25th assist to go with eight goals as a significant candidate for the Calder Trophy as the N.H.L.'s rookie of the year.

title: ROBERT M. FARRELL
description: Robert M. Farrell, the last survivor of the small group that founded the Muncipal Credit Union in this city in 1907, died of a heart ailment Tuesday at his home, 11135 75th Avenuc, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 92 years old.

title: PRICES INCREASE ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: After a flurry of selling midway in the session, stocks on the American Stock Exchange rallied and prices closed higher in slightly decreased trading. Prices also closed higher in the overthecounter market where trading incread slightly.

title: $37,500 Is Awarded For Each Survivor Of Syphilis Project
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 3 (UPI) The Federal Government has approved a settlement of $37,500 for each survivor in a Government  sponsored Syphilis experiment in Macon County, Ala., court records showed today.

title: Ford Tells Congress That Turkey Aid Cutoff Imperils Security
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 President Ford urged Congress today to reconsider its cutoff of American military aid to Turkey, saying that the action might trigger farreaching and damaging consequences for Western security in the eastern Mediterranean.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: Sacramento, Calif.  Monroe Brooks, 143 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Jose Miranda, 147, Los Angeles, 5 rounds.

title: Developing Lands to Seek Higher Export Prices
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 5 (UPI) Developing nations unaniImously agreed today to follow the example of the oilproducing countries and try to get more in return for all their raw materials.

title: TV Biography of Hughes Deleted Unflattering Parts
description: The making of a television biography of Howard R. Hughes, broadcast on ABCTV last night, was described by its producer as a horrendous adventure that began with legal attempts to halt the production and ended with deletions of material described as unflattering to Mr. Hughes.

title: JOB RALLY DRAWS 10,000 TO CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Nearly 10,000 automobile workers rallied in Washington today demanding action from the Ford Administration and Congress to end the recession and provide jobs.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PEOPLE As the lights fade on the current Off Broadway revival of Clifford Odets's Awake and Sing, four things are apparent. Broadway's most eloquent spokesman of the Depression era never wrote a better play than this beautifully taciturn study of a middleclass Jewish family surmounting hard times and personal tensions. Secondly (and surprisingly, if you haven't read the play lately), for all its bleak, biting realism. Mr. Odets's second hit (after Waiting For Lefty") is essentially an ode to the human spirit that lifts you up, not a soap opera that gels you down. Thirdly, while riveted to 1935, it applies now in eight characters you recognize. Some you can love.

title: Louis Jordan, Bandleader, Dies; Recorded Popular Disks in 40's
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (AP) Louis Jordimi, a popular bandleader of the nineteenforties, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 66 years old. He leaves hi s wife. Martha.

title: Tests Set in Poison Case
description: CHICAGO. Feb. 5 (UPI)A judge ordered a psychiatric and physical examination today for Steven Pera, 22 years old, who is accused of trying to poison Chicago's water supply. Judge Frank J. Wilson ordered the examinations to determine if Mr. Pera is fit to stand trial on charges of conspiracy to commit mass murder and bond jumping.

title: Nassau to Prohibit Bettors Under 21
description: To placate groups opposed to offtrack betting, Nassau Downs OTB will raise the minimum betting age 21 years starting tomorrow. The 18year minimum will remain in effect in New York City's 0TB parlors and local race tracks.

title: Senate, 768, Votes Freeze In Price of Food Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The Senate voted 76 to 8 today to freeze the price of food stamps for the rest of the year.

title: Control Data Reports Loss for Quarter
STOCK OF DELTA SOLD BY STORER
description: Storer Broadcasting Company, Miami Beach, said yesterday that it had sold about 450,000 shares of Delta Airlines, Inc., for about $14.3million or an average of $32 a share. The sale was made mostly in the last week during the surge in stock activity.

title: Air Survivor Dies in Manila
description: MANILA, Thursday, Feb. 6 (Reuters)  The survivor of a Philippine Airlines plane crash here Monday died in a hospital today. He was Roger Douglas Collins, 51 years old, who had been in critical condition since the crash.

title: EuropeanAmerican Bank Plans 4 Branch Closings
description: The EuropeanAmerican Bank and Trust Company, which acquired selected deposits and assets of the defunct Franklin National Bank in October, announced yesterday it would close four branches during the next two months. This will leave EuropeanAmerican with 100 branches, 98 of which are old Franklin National branches.

title: Peruvian Troops Crush Police Revolt in Capital
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 5Peruvian troops backed by tanks stormed a large police garrison here early today and crushed a revolt by policemen demanding wage increases.

title: Television
Frank Pandolfi, Founder Of Connecticut Opera, 73
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 5 (UPI) Frank Pandolfi, founder and director of the Connecticut Opera Association, died yesterday in Hartford Hospital at the age of 73.

title: Indictments Dismissed
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Feb. 5 (AP)A Federal judge dismissed today 11count indictments against three of the original leaders in the 1973 armed takeover of the village of Wounded Knee, S.D. United States District Judge Fred Nichol dismissed indictments against Carter Cam'', Stanley Holder and Leonard Crow Dog.

title: CANADA INCREASES LEVY ON CRUDE OIL
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 5The Canadian government increased to??? ??? charge on Canadian crude oil, all of which is sold to the United States, by 30 cents a .barrel. The new levy, effective March 1, will raise the price of Canadian oil in the United States to $12 a barrel.

title: Onassis Reported Gaining In His Bout With Illness
description: ATHENS, Feb. 5 (AP)Aristotle Onassis showed improvement today from the potentially dangerous combination of influenza and myasthenia gravis, a muscle disease.

title: 4,000 JUDGES STAGE A WALKOUT IN ITALY
description: ROME, Feb. 5Thousands of judges started a twoday strike today to press Parliament for higher pay.

title: Spencer Reaches Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 5Mr. Spencer flew into London tonight on a Portuguese airliner. He said that Mr. McIntosh was in Europe and that he did not know when he would return to Britain.

title: Gromyko's Visit to Cairo Achieves a Limited Accord
description: CAIRO, Feb. 5Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union left Egypt today after two days of talks that improved the atmosphere between the two countries but failed to bring full agreement either on strategy for peace negotiations with Israel or on Egypt's demands for greater quantities of modern Soviet weapons.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 5 (AP) The National Football League Players Association sees as a good sign a ruling made today by the National Labor Relations Board that the N.F.L. must return more than $20,000 in fines to players.

title: Minh Accuses Thieu Regime of Tyranny
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 6Duung Van Minh, the titular leader of much of the nonCommunist opposition. denounced the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu yesterday as nothing but a tyranny.

title: Betty Allen Recital Put Off
description: The recital by Betty Allen at Hunter College Playhouse tomorrow night has been postponed because of the mezzosoprano's illness. it has been rescheduled for Friday. Feb. 28. Tickets for tomorrow will be honored on Feb. 28.

title: ELI BLACK'S RITES ATTENDED BY 500
description: More than 500 relatives, friends and business associates attended the funeral yesterday of Eli M. Black, chairman of the billiondollar United Brands Company and patron of the arts, who plunged to his death on Monday from the 44th floor qf the Pan Am Building. He had reportedly been under great strain because of business pressures.

title: American Motors, Citing High Costs, Omits Dividend
description: DETROIT, Feb. Ti  Stockholders of the American Motors Corporation were told at the annual meeting today that the company was omitting its semiannual dividend of 10 cents a share, which would have been payable this quarter.

title: The Multifaceted Art Children Put on Fences
RABIN SEES HOPE IN SADAT PLEDGE
description: TEL AVIV. Feb. 5Premier Yitzhak Rabin, addressing the Assembly of the World Jewish Congress in Jerusalem, said tonight that recent assertions by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt that his country and Syria did not intend to attack Israel could open the way to peace if the Egyptian leader would commit himself formally.

title: Orozco Is Brisk In Chopin Piece Led by Maazel
description: Rafael Orozco is one of those gifted young pianists who, technically, are safe at any speed. He is a sound musician, too. And yet it was not clear from his performance with the Cleveland Orchestra at Carnegie Flail on Tuesday night that he found great personal meaning in what he played. Mr. Orozco, a Spaniard still under 30 years old, has been burning up the international concert circuit since 1966, when he won the Leeds piano competition in England, and it is easy to see why.

title: Energy Crisis and Fuel Costs Expected To Increase Effect on Building Design
description: A year ago, when the energy crisis burst upon the public, it fooked as though excessive energy demands might well put an end to the sealedglass tower that has become a trademark of American downtowns. Instead, the recession did the trick, bringing largescale commercial construction almost to a halt.

title: Kialoa, Coast Ketch, Leads in Florida Sail
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla ., Feb. 5As the yachts disappeared into a rain squall on the outer limits of Tampa Bay the new 79foot ketch Kialoa III from Los Angeles appeared to be leading the fleet, her responsibility if not obligation as the scratch boat, following the start here today of the ocean race to Fort Lauderdale. The voyage of 403 nautical miles will terminate at the East Coast port sometime Friday.

title: UNIT IS BEING SOLD BY GENERAL FOODS
description: The General Foods. Corporation announced yesterday that it was withdrawing from the cosmetics business by selling a subsidiary, the Viviane Woodward Corporation.

title: Pattison Beats Gerulaitis In 2d Round, 26, 63, 64
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla ., Feb. 5Vitas Gerulaitis's hot streak came to an end tonight when the 20yearold New Yorker lost to Andy Pattison, 26, 63, 64, in the second round of the $60,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES OFF IN QUIET DAY
description: Soybean prices moved down under speculative selling in very quiet trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. The speculators were said to be wary about the market because of reports that Brazil was offering soybeans in Europe at a price about 14 cents below recent United States prices.

title: Rats for Neighbors
description: America's migrant workers regularly fall victim to this nation's wretched tendency to do injury to those least able to protect themselves. Their latest misadventure at the hands of the powerful involves the Department of Labor's effort to promulgate new standards for migrant worker housing. The proposed rules, ostensibly designed to reconcile two existing sets of regulations, substantially weaken already inadequate safeguards.

title: Stage: Royal Shakespeare's Gorky
The Watergate MoneyTree Harvest
description: I would like to enter the discussion that has started about the fees offered to and withdrawn from Ronald Ziegler and John Dean. I speak as a professor, not for all of them but perhaps for some.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: OWNER OF CELTICS INDICTED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5  Robert J. Schmertz, principal owner of the Boston Celtics basketball team, was indicted today on charges of bribing a public official to obtain approval for construction of a $200million retirement village.

title: Whitney Finds This Land Is Its Land
description: There is no such thing as fairness in art. At no time in history have talent, opportunity or the gift of personal development been equitably distributed.

title: OneYear Bills Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  The Treasury auctioned oneyear hills today at an average yield of 5.313 per cent.

title: Election of a Republican Hailed as Blow at Carey
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5Jubilant Senate Republicans today introduced their newest member, Dale M. Volker of Depew, asserting that his victory in a special election was a clear repudiation of Governor Carey's massive tax program.

title: SCHLESINGER ASKS ARMS FUNDS RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger opened his case before Congress today for a $92.8billion defense budget with the principal argument that the United States must increase its, military spending if it is to maintain a global balance with the Soviet Union.

title: Opposition in Brazil Demands Word About Missing Prisoners
description: RIO DE JANEIRO. Jan. 5The Brazilian Democratic Movement, the country's only legal, opposition party, is putting new Ipressure on the military Government to account for missing political prisoners.

title: Italian Developer Proposes Huge South Bronx Project
description: The city and Renzo Zingone, a major Italian builder and developer, have signed a letter of intent under which Mr. Zingone would erect a complex of factory buildings in the Penn Central's Harlem River yards in the South Bronx, creating two million square feet of manufacturing space with a potential of 5,000 new jobs.

title: Film: Benign Principles
5 Keystone Victors For Roger Turcotte
description: CORNWELLS HEIGHTS , Pa., Feb. 5 (AP)Roger Turcotte rode five winners and finished third in six races today at Keystone Race Track.

title: Bridge:
description: Bidding is not an abstract process, except perhaps in books. At the table, you must consider the ability and psychology of your partner, and to a lesser extent that of your opponents. Another factor to consider in tournament play is the state of the game in the closing stages an expert may judge that unusual action is called for.

title: Fugitive Maryland Lifer Is Freed Here
description: Nick Bagley, a 31yearold escaped convict whose cause has been embraced by hundreds of New Yorkers, walked out of State Supreme Court a free man yesterday after a judge dismissed the extradition charges that would have returned him to a Maryland prison for life.

title: C. W. Post Streak Ends
description: GREENVALE, L. I., Feb. 5 John Irving collected 24 rebounds and scored 22 points

title: NEW AGENCY PLANS STRATEGY ON OIL
description: PARIS, Feb. 5A new 17nation agency, which has its headquarters in a chateau here, has the task of trying to work out a strategy for oilconsuming countries to deal with the oil producers.

title: I Can Hear It Now
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 My fellow Americans:

title: Rosedale Still Tense 5 Weeks After Blast
description: When a pipe bomb exploded m a home owned by a black family last Dec. 31, many residents of Rosedale, Queens, insisted it was the work of a couple of nuts.

title: Hearne Swink, 74, Aide Of Cannon Milli 50 Years
description: Hearne Swink, a textile executive who had been with the Cannon Mills Company for half a century, died yesterday in Myrtle Beach (S. C.) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Myrtle Beach.

title: Chinese Quake Struck Industrial Area
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 6The epicenter of a major earthquake that hit Manchuria this week was in one of China's most important industrial districts and only 35 miles from the country's leading iron and steel center, according to a dispatch today from Hsinhua, the official press agency.

title: EXMAYOR IN BERGEN CITED FOR EXTORTION
description: Angelo J. Sarubbi, former Mayor of North Bergen, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of extorting $32,800 in bribes from two concerns that were awarded contracts by the town to build a new sewagetreatment plan.

title: Aid Request for Cambodia Said to Exceed Needs Now
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 6  President Ford has asked for $497million in military aid for Cambodia, but figures obtained here and from the Administration's own estimates show that as recently as a few weeks ago American officials believed a far lower amount would be sufficient.

title: Mayer, Ramirez Win
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. Feb. 6 (AP)Fourthseeded Alex (Sandy) Mayer and sixthseeded Raul Ramirez advanced today in a World Championship Tennis $50,000 Blue Group tournament. Mayer, of Mendham, N.J., beat Colin Dibley of Australia, 64, 62. Ramirez, of Mexico, halted Mike Estep of Waco, Tex., 62 61.

title: Ford to Seek a Reduction Of C.A.B Regulator Role
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Denouncing the impact of the Civil Aeronautics Board as inequitable, inefficient and uneconomical, the Ford .4,1:.iinistration said today that it would introduce legislation aimed at substantially reducing the power of the board to regulate the airline industry.

title: 2 Trust Funds Set Up for Orphaned Walker Children
description: Two trust funds have been set up to safeguard the thousands of dollars being contributed to the six, recently orphaned Walker children whose father was slain assisting a police officer who confronted gunman in St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: Bullets Barely Win
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 6  Phil Chenier scored 17 points in the final quarter, including two free throws with no time remaining, to give the Washington Bullets a 9897 victory over the Golden State Warriors tonight.

title: Standard Prudential to Sell Contract
description: The Standard Prudential Corporation announced yesterday that it was negotiating the sale of its contract to purchase a 53 per cent interest in the Talcott National Corporation owned by Fasco, Inc. Theodore Silbert, chairman of Standard Prudential, said it had entered into an amendment extending to April 1, 1975, its original agreement with Fasco, which is a subsidiary of Fasco, A. G., the Europeanbased personal holding company of Mich. ele Sindona, the Italian financier who is being sought for questioning by the Governments of Italy and Switzerland.

title: Hawks Victorious Over Pistons. 11198
description: ATLANTA. Feb. 6 (AP)Herm Gilliam scored 15 points in the final quarter to help the Atlanta Hawks to a 11198 victory over the Detroit Pistons in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Youth, 18, Fatally Stabbed While Playing Basketball
description: An 18yearold youth was stabbed while playing basketball at the University Settlement House last night and died an hour later at Bellevue Hospital.

title: F.A.L.N. Terrorists Tied To 10 Bombings in Region
description: Last Aug. 31 at 12:55 A.M., without any warning, a time bomb exploded in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center.

title: Top Women Advance
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 6 (UPI)Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova, young stars of women's tennis, and Margaret Court, one of the leading players for years, led the field into the quarterfinal round of the $75,000 Virginia Slims of Akron tournament today.

title: DoubleDutch Experts Get the Jump on Villella in Demonstration Here
description: Edward Villella, principal dancer of the New York City Ballet, tried jumping rope yesterday but was shown up by seven 11yearold girls.

title: Elizabeth, Citing Costs, Ends Work on Mansion
description: LONDON, Feb. 6Buckingham Palace announced today that Queen Elizabeth had abandoned a $600,000 project to modernize Sandringham House, the mansion on her privately owned estate in Norfolk.

title: NEW WHEAT SALES ARE CITED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) The Agriculture Department formally confirmed today reports that the Soviet Union has canceled orders for American wheat, but said large sales have been made to other buyers.

title: Annual Earnings Lag
description: Avon Products, Inc., which had an outstanding growth record until the start of 1974 in its doortodoor selling of cosmetics and toiletries, reported yesterday its fourth successive decline in quarterly profits. As a result, annual earnings retreated for the first time in more than 10 years.

title: Sir Keith Park, Whose Fighters Won the Battle of Britain, Dies
description: LONDON. Feb. 6Air Chief Marshal Sir Keith Park, commander of the Royal Air Force Group that bore the brunt of the German onslaught when the Battle of Britain began, died yesterday in New Zealand. His age was 82.

title: Contents of the Towers Are Sold at an Auction
description: The contents of the Towers Nursing Home, which ended its operation in December, were sold at auction yesterday.

title: U.S. PANEL ORDERS BERGMAN APPEAR; But Committee Votes Not to Cite Him for Contempt Hearing This Month
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The Senate Special Committee on Aging voted unanimously today to subpoena Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome operator, to appear at a Washington hearing later this month, rather than cite him for contempt for not appearing in New York last Tuesday before the Subcommittee on LongTerm Care.

title: Famed Renaissance Works Stolen in Italy
description: ROME, Feb. 6Three invaluable Renaissance paintingsone by Raphael and two by Piero della Francescawere stolen from the Ducal Palace in Urbino early today in Italy's most sensational art theft in years.

title: Sales Also Show Dip
description: The Anaconda Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday declines in sales, operating revenues and net income in the final quarter of 1974. However, results for the full year rose above 1973 levels.

title: Notes on People
description: Getting the Navajo and Hopi Indian tribes together to settle their almost centuryold Arizona land dispute is the new job of a former New Yorker thus far known for mediating labor stalemates. William E. Simkin, who now lives in Tucson and was director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service for eight years, has been given the assignment by the present director, W. J'Usery Jr. Born upstate 67 years ago, Mr. Simkin headed the science department at the Brooklyn Friends School whIle doing graduate work in economics at Columbia University and later taught at Harvard University and the University of Pennsylvania. Congress has ruled that the dispute, involving LS million acres that lie inside the Navajo reservation, must be solved within six months by negotiation. If not, Mr. Simkin is empowered to make a recommendation to the Federal court.

title: Iranian Troops Helping Oman to Quell Rebels
description: MUSCAT, Oman, Feb. 6In the craggy southwestern region of this Arabian sultanate, a radical Arab rebellion that has been sputtering along for a decade is being brought under control with the aid of a militarv force from Iran.

title: Carey Doctor Named Head of Health Group
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6Governor Carey appointed his family doctor today to coordinate all of the state's health programs.

title: Wharton Gives Forecast On President's Package
description: PHILADELPHA, Feb. 6 (Reuters)  President Ford's tax and energy package will lead to no more than a 2 p er cent overall increase in the in flation rate according to a report issued today by the Wharton Econometric Forecasting, Associates.

title: Lefkowitz Gets Change In CreditCard Practices
description: The State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, said yesterday that an investigation of creditcard divisions of major banks, stores and other businesses had shown that two of them transferred into their own miscellaneousincome accounts, credit balances totaling $1,190,000 that belonged to card holders whose accounts had beinactive.

title: Confusion Qualifies Customers'
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 6 Today's ruling by the Public Service Commission reducing charges to customers who heat their homes with electricity was welcomed with qualifications born of confusion.

title: College. School Results
description: BASKETBALL Colleges

title: EARNINGS RISE SEEN BY BROOKLYN UNION
description: Gordon C. Griswold, chairman of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, told stockholders yesterday at the company's annual meeting that earnings per share for the fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31, 1974, rose to $1.20 from 98 cents.

title: Cornelius Cardew, PianistComposer, Is Heard at Kitchen
description: Cornelius Cardew has been prominent member of the British musical avantgarde for some 15 years, first as a determined serialist and then as a Cageian indeterminist. About five years ago, however, he got religion in the form of modernday MarxistLeninism and a commitment to worldwide revolutionary struggle. And Wednesday night at the Kitchen, wrapping up a tour of United States college campuses, he arrived in New York to tell a smallish audience of local avantgardists what he has been up to.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc., offered yesterday 600,000 shares of common stock of the United Illuminating Company at 21% a share. The company said net proceed.; would provide capital for its continuing construction program, being applied to reducing shortterm borrowings.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose yesterday in increased trading.

title: Fun and Games With ManEaters
description: When Peter Benchley told friends he was planning a novel about sharks, the more sensible ones tried to dissuade him. He had just put in two years writing speeches for Lyndon Johnson. Why not do a book about LBJ, they asked, a subject where he might claim expertise? So he wrote a novel about sharks and called it Jaws and became therewith the third Benchley in direct line of descent (son of Nathanicl, grandson of Robert) to slap the bestseller lists into the next county. This is what people mean by the term, typical American success story. At last report, total production costs on a movie version of Jaws, which was filmed last year on Martha's Vineyard, were approaching $15million. Growing up on Nantucket, Peter Benchley learned early that islanders considered the mako shark good to eat and other sharks thought the same about islanders. His research for the book taught him that there were 250 known species of shark, but he hadn't met any of them personally until last November when he went to Australia with a television crew. The ones he met there will be introduced to viewers Sunday afternoon at 3:30 on the American Broadcasting Company series, The American Sportsman.

title: Sanity in Wisconsin
description: The settlement by which a Menominee Indian force peacefully evacuated a Roman Catholic novitiate in Wisconsin, and under which the 262acre property is to be deeded to the Menominee nation for $1 and future considerations appears to have been a triumph of good sense and humanity. Nobody was killed on either side, the forces of law and order are being officially served, and the Menominees will regain possession of a property they regarded as historically their own.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $737million, up per cent from the yearearlier $713million. Total retail store sales were about $10.48billion, up 6 per cent from last year's $9.86billion.

title: Jobless Marchers
description: The march on Washington this week by several thousand jobless auto workers was no counterpart the assemblage of bonus marchers demanding Government help in Herbert Hoover's Washington at the outset of the Great Depression. Unemployment insurance and supplemental benefits under their union contracts provide a degree of insulation for today's recession casualties from extreme privation of the kind that beset those on the breadlines in the early nineteenthirties.
