description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI)  The Justice Department said today that it was trying to de. termine whether George C. Wallace of Alabama illegally began a second consecutive second term in office without seeking prior Federal approval of the state constitutional amendment that allowed him to do so.

title: Told to Economize, College President Proposes His House Be Sold Instead
description: The resident of Queens College, balking at a request to pare $160,000 from this year's allocation, has proposed to the City University chancellor that the official residence of the college president be sold instead and the income be used to offset this current budget cut.

title: Stock Prices Mixed As Turnover Soars
description: The stock market, propelled by another reduction in interest rates, erupted in a burst of activity yesterday that sent volume to is secondhighest level in New York Stock Exchange history. Turnover soared to 32 million shares from 25.8 million on Wednesday. Despite the tumultuous activity, prices on the exchange finished mixed after some late profit taking erased many of the earlier gains. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.68 points to 714.17. So far this year, this key market barometer has climbed 98.93 points. Commenting on the market's recent upsurge Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said at a press breakfast in Washington, It is telling us the economy is going to improve. Mr. Simon said that some of the rebound resulted from bargain buying of bluechip stocks that had fallen to very low priceearning ratios.

title: BIG BOARD BOWS ON RATE DEADLINE
description: The New York Stock Exchange bowed last night to the Securities and Exchange Commission and said it would not sue to block the order to end fixed brokerage commission rates by May 1.

The triumph sent the Americans into the final round. The 6foot7inch Amaya defeated Javier Soler of Spain, 76, 64. title: 2 Elderly Sisters Held In ArsonInsurance Plot
description: Two elderly sisters, 73 and 66 years old, were arrested yesterday and accused by fire marshals of having participated in a conspiracy to hire professional torches to set hundreds of fires In Queens and Nassau Counties over the last 12 years for millions of dollars in insurance.

title: Correction
description: In this space the other day, I asked: Who are the friends of Israel? . . . those who urge her to give up territory occupied by aggression or those who urge her to hold on to everything she has? The use of the word aggression instead of force implied that Israel was responsible for starting the 1967 war, which I did not intend, and was a mistake. The Arab blockade of the Gulf of Aqaba and the Strait of Tiran, and the dismissal of the United Nations Emergency Force by the Arabs were widely regarded as acts of war which led to the Israeli blitz. Both the United Nations and the United States Government avoided the question of who the I am sorry was not equally careful.

title: ARABS SAID TO BLOCK JEWISH LOAN DEALS.
description: Two Arab investment groups have managed to keep several major Jewishcontrolled European banking houses out of two Eurodollar syndications, according to Business Week magazine. It describes the move as the first overt attempt to discriminate against Jewishcontrolled institutions since the big wave of petrodollar spending began.

description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 6 (AP)Topseeded Jimmy Connors was forced to bow out of the $25,000 Arkansas international tennis tournament today because of a painful inflammation in the area of his left knee.

description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 6Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's Minister for Petroleum, said today that his nation remained strongly opposed to a further increase in oil prices.

description: With the nomination yesterday of Rosemary Pooler as chairman and executive director of the State . Consumer Protection Board, Governor Carey moved toward his announced goal of making the state government a vigorous and aggressive guardian of consumer interests. Mrs. Pooler, a 36yearold Brooklynhorn lawyer who is now a Democratic member of the Syracuse City Council, is known throughout the state for her devotion to the concept of protecting the rights of the individual

title: Notes on People
description: Getting the Navajo and Hopi Indian tribes together to settle their almost centuryold Arizona land dispute is the new job of a former New Yorker thus far known for mediating labor stalemates. William E. Simkin, who now lives in Tucson and was director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service for eight years, has been given the assignment by the present director. W. J. Usery Jr. Born upstate 67 years ago, Mr. Simkin headed the science department at the Brooklyn Friends School while doing graduate work in economics at Columbia University and later taught at Harvard University and the University of Pennsylvania. Congress has ruled that the dispute,invoiving 1.8 million acres that lie inside the Navajo reservation, must be solved within six months by negotiation. If not. Mr. Simkin is empowered to make a recommendation the Federal courts.

title: The Pop Life
description: Comedians have long since moved from the borscht belt to rock concert halls. Linear descendants of the standup comedians of a previous generation have updated their routines with hip argot and casual reference to rock music and drugs, and transferred their acts onto the rock concert circuit.

title: That Rightists to Head A ssembly And Probably Lead Government
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 6Thailand's new National Assembly elected a Speaker and Deputy Speaker today in its first working session since the Jan. 26 general election.

title: U.S. PANEL ORDERS BERMAN APPEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The Senate Special Committee on Aging voted unanimously today to subpoena Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome operator, to appear at a Washington hearing later this month, rather than cite him for contempt for not appearing in New York last Tuesday before the Subcommittee on LongTerm Care.

title: Postal Workers Fear New Methods Will Cost Jobs
description: KOKOMO, Ind.  For 25 years, Harry Turnpaugh, a letter carrier here, has handled his mail tray at waist level from standing position. It is more comfortable for him that way, and letter carriers have always been allowed to sort mail any way they wished.

title: People in Sports
description: The New York Mets announced the signing of Jerry Koosman, the pitcher with the most victories on the staff last season, and three Others to their 1975 contracts. A total of 24 players signed up. Joining the 31yearold Koosman, who had a 1511 won lost mark, fourth best among National League lefthanders, were Jerry Cram, righthanded pitcher; Jack Heidemann, infielder, and Luis Rosado, catcher.

title: A Tolerant City
description: A recent review by this newspaper of the results the 1973 homicide cases which have been disposed in New York City shows that eight of ten people accused of homicide entered a plea which was usually the result of a bargain struck with the prosecutor. Of those who did so plead, almost eight out of ten were freed on probation or were sentenced to a prison term of less than ten years. This contrasts with results in upstate and suburban counties in similar cases, where nine out ten defendants who pleaded guilty or were convicted of homicides received a maximum sentence or more than ten years.

title: Ford Assails C.A.B.
description: The Ford Administration denounced the impact of the Civil Aeronautics Board and said it would seek to reduce substantially the agency's power to regulate airlines. Page 61.

title: Strong District Councils Proposed by Charter Panel
description: A twophase program for strengthening community government, leading by 1979 to the election of community councils with responsibility for some local services, was proposed yesterday by the State Charter Revision Commission for New York City.

title: Yanqui Dollars Flow to Mexican Banks In Bid for Higher Earnings and Secrecy
description: TIJUANA, Mexico Millions of United States dollars have been deposited in Mexican banks that offer interest rates almost double those paid in the United States as well as a safe hideout from Federal income tax agents and crime investigators.

title: 2 LAWYERS DECRY SNOOPING BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Representatives of the American Civil Liberties Union told a House subcommittee today that Government eavesdropping on citizens under the guise of national security had gone almost beyond control.

description: MOSCOW, Feb. 6Leonid I Brezhnev, the Soviet leader has been extended a fresh in vitation to visit Italy this year Western European diplomat: reported today.

title: Chinese Quake Struck Industrial Area
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 6The epicenter of a major earthquake that hit Manchuria this week was in one of China's most important industrial districts and only 35 miles from the country's leading iron and steel center, according to a dispatch today from Hsinhua, the official press agency.

title: Grandparents Given Rights of Visitation By Court in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Feb. 6Reversing an appealscourt decision, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a maternal grandmother was entitled to visit her grandchild over the objections of her former soninlawthe child's fatherand his second wife.

title: Purchasing by Producers Is Seen High
description: BONN, Feb. 6A chartered plane full of German businessmen lands at a desert airport in the Middle East. After two or three days of negotiations and deals, billions of petrodollars flow back to West Germany in exchange for technology, heavy machinery or manufacturing plants.

title: Truck Tonnage Off 22.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The American Trucking Associations, Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 22.5 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Tonnage last week was 5 per cent above the immediately preceding week. The A.T.A. reported that based on a terminal survey of 35 metropolitan areas, decreased tonnage from a year ago was reported at 34 localities. Compared with the immediate preceding week tonnage was up at 29 areas.

title: Exhibit of Paintings of Marines in Battle to Open in Trenton Today
description: TRENTON, Feb. 6The Ma. lines in the Revolution, an exhibit of 14 original paintings by Marine Mai. Charles Waterhouse, will open to the public tomorrow in the New Jersey State Museum here.

title: 200 Cases of Improper Care Discovered In City Inspection of 12 Nursing Homes
description: City Health Department inspectors turned up more than 200 cases of improper care requiring attention in unannounced Inspections of 12 nursing homes last November, according to a report just released.

title: Jackson Enters 1976 Bid; Vows Aid to Little People

title: Nets Beat Spirits, 11392, For 7th Time This Season
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 6 (UPI) Larry Kenon scored 24 points, 12 in the fourth quarter, and Julius Erving added 22 tonight in leading the New York Nets to a 11392 victory over the Spirits of St. Louis.

description: BOSTON, Feb, 6 (AP) Suffolk Downs in Boston and Lincoln Downs in Rhode Island postponed today their thoroughbred racing meetings until Saturday in the wake of a storm that dumped about 6 inches of snow on the tracks.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 6The Saigon Government held a long news conference today in which it presented what it called live evidence that it had cracked a ring of Communist agents who had infiltrated the press here.

title: Market Place

title: CHOOSING A CHIEF DISARRAYS TORIES

On Wednesday night it was Milton Babbitt's turn. His subject was his Arie da Capo, written for the ensemble and first played by it last year.

Wall Street's interpretation was that the nation's money manager, was still pushing for lower shortterm interest rates but that it wanted the market to move in a more orderly fashion.

description: John O. Bigelow, a retired judge of the appellate division of the New Jersey Superior Court, died Wednesday in the Inglemoor Nursing Home in Livingston, N. J. He was 91 years old and lived at 465 Highland Avenue in Newark.

title: Books of The Times
description: The annals of medicine list few experiments as daring and revolutionary as those that Dr. Werner Forssmann performed on his heart beginning in 1929. As a 25yearold interne who disobeyed orders from his superiors at a small hospital near Berlin, he pushed a catheter, or thin tube, into a vein in his elbow crease and then threaded it up past his armpit through a series of veins connecting with the right side of his heart.

title: Parise Scores With 1:02 Left for 22 Draw
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 6The New York Islanders came very close tonight to allowing the Buffalo Sabres to become only the second team this season to beat them in their home rink. Instead, New York came out with a 22 tie on a goal by J.P. Parise with 1 minute 2 seconds to .Play

title: Ethiopians Report 1,200 Dead In 7 Days of Fighting in Eritrea
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 6 (Reuters)  Reliable Ethiopian sources said here today that seven days of fighting between secessionist guerrillas and Ethiopian troops had left at least 1,200 dead in the northern province of Eritrea.

title: Milwaukee Teachers Return As Court Ends New Dispute
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 6 (UPI)Public school teachers here returned to work under court order today, ending a strike that had disrupted classrooms for nearly three weeks.

title: Industry Leader Calls College Aid Aim Of LeaseBack Sale of Nursing Homes
description: A leader of the city's nursinghome industry told yesterday how he tried to give a college a taxfree income of $45,000 year by selling it four nursing homes and leasing them back, billing Medicaid for the rent.

title: Africans Seeking Profits in Timber Cartel
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon  A commodity cartel on the lines of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is being formed herethe yet unnamed interAfrican organization for cooperation in timber trade and forestry conservation.

title: The Equal Rights Amendment: Missouri Is the Target Now
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 6  As they swept through the dim corridors on the third floor of the old state capitol here, the pinchfaced, middleaged man in hornrimmed glasses suddenly brought his followers to halt, jamming the passageway.

title: Lincoln Transit Is Struck, Affecting 4,000 Riders
description: More than 4,000 New Jersey commuters who daily ride Lincoln Transit Company buses between Atlantic City and New York and intermediate points were forced by a strike to find other means of transportation yesterday.

title: MARGARET O'CONNELL
description: Margaret Ellen Purcell O'Connell, who as a young woman had been secretary to Cordell Hull, then a freshman Representative from Tennessee and later Secretary of State, died last Saturday in a nursing home in Laurel, Md. She was 85 years old.

title: Market Averages
description: THE NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New sanity tests were ordered yesterday for Thomas V. Burns, a 23yearold Rutherford man who is accused the abduction last fall of George Kaloyerakis Jr., the yearold son of a neighbor. Mr. Burns and the boy, who are said to have a deep fatherson type of relationship, were found in Miami Dec. 12 by Federal authorities after their twoandahalfmonth odyssey along the East Coast.

title: DISTRICT 12 ROLE DENIED BY STATE
description: The State Education Department denied yesterday that it had had any role in approving a 1970 contract between a Bronx school district and company headed by the brother of the district superintendent.

title: Iran to the Rescue?
description: The complex deal toward which Pan American World Airways and the Government of Iran appear to be moving raises the important question of United States policy toward foreign investment in this country. The issue is heightened by Iran's position as a leading member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries whose enormous increase in wealth results from their monopolistic action in quadrupling the price of oil.

title: VISIT RIGHTS WON BY GRANDPARENTS
description: TRENTON, Feb. 6Reversing an appealscourt decision, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a maternal grandmother was entitled to visit her grandchild over the objections of her former soninlawthe child's fatherand his second wife.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan, Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx and a group of entertainers rallied quietly yesterday to the side of the popular Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park. Park Commissioner Edwin L. Weisl Jr. has said he wants to oust the concert series from the park because it would vitiate the millions of dollars worth of renovations planned for the area around the Wollman Rink.

title: Rise in Skin Cancer Seen if More S.S.T.'s Are Used
description: Measurements by a highflying research plane, combined with results of last year's Third National Cancer Survey, have shown that the more ozone there is overhead the fewer white Americans on the ground below contract skin cancer.

title: Suns Gain on Sonies
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 6 (AP)Charlie Scott, back after missing two games, with the flu, scored 35 points tonight to lead the Phoenix Suns to a 112103 victory over Seattle that moved the Suns within a halfgame of the secondplace SuperSonics in the Pacific Division.

title: LIEBMAN EXPLORES DIRECTIONS IN JAZZ
description: In the current confluence of jazz and rock, there is a definite trend, flowing out of Miles Davis, toward an electric rock emphasis over jazz. This is most notable in the work of two former Davis pianists, Herbie Hancock and Chick Corea, who have had considerabel commercial success. But another recent Davis sideman. Dave Liebman, who plays tenor, and soprano saxophones and flute, is turning much the same source material toward what. may be the basic jazz style of the nineteenseventies.

title: Errichetti Case Is in the Hands of Jury
description: TRENTON, Feb. 6A jury of four men and eight women deliberated more than four hours today without reaching a verdict in the conspiracy trial of Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden and two others.

title: Article 1  No Title
400 Safely Flee a Fire At E. 82d Street School
description: About 400 children and 21 teachers fled safely and calmly from a burning fivestory elementary school on the Upper East Side yesterday as flames spread through classrooms on the third and fourth floors.

title: Jackson Enters 1976 Bid; Vows Aid to Little People
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington announced today his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination, betting that his traditional liberalism would prove popular in hard times.

title: In Memoriam
description: CACCAVALLOCiro. In loving memory my dad who Passed away B years ago today.

title: Advertising
description: Freedom of choice (especially the choice of colas) is the underlying theme of the first Royal Crown Cola campaign from the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, that will break on network television on March 2.

title: Snowstorm Buoys Resorts
description: MANCHESTER, Vt., Feb. 6 Ski area operators throughout New England, their resorts fortified with the best conditions of the season, today were anticipating an all  out invasion News of skiers this weekend as the of result of a twoSkiing day snowstorm. Also benefiting in particular from the windfall were resorts in New York's Adirondacks and Catskills and Pennsylvania's Pocono's. Innkeepers reported reservations for the weekend had been pouring in for the last two days.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: 500 Spanish Officials Petition for a Democracy
description: MADRID, Feb. 6More than 500 Government officials have demanded that the Spanish state be made democratic.

title: Burns Opposes Bill To Allocate Loans And Reduce Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Dr. Arthur F. Burns, c hairman of the Federal Reserve Board, opposed today a Democratic bill aimed at reducing interest rates and allocating bank loans to priority borrowers rather than speculators.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Listing of Prices for Transactions in Commodity Futures
description: CHICAGO GRAINS7

title: ROBERT EVETT
description: Robert Evett, composer, music critic and literary editor, was found dead at his home in Washington on Tuesday morning. He was 52 years old.

title: OneHour First Period Filled With Fights
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6After getting the R knocked out of them the night before, the Rangers took on the Philadelphia Flyers on their own term tonight. Without an R", Ranger spells, anger, and 18 angry New Yorkers played the Flyers into submission, winning 31, at the Spectrum, where they hadn't won since the 197273 season.

title: Rocket Kills 14 Children In Cambodian Classroom
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 6One of the rockets that the Cambodian insurgents have been firing daily into Phnom Penh struck the classroom of a crowded primary school today and 14 children, all under 12 years old, were killed. At least 25 others were wounded.

title: Cavaliers Sink Blazers
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 6 (UPI)Bobby Smith and Jim Chones tossed in 34 of Cleveland's 58 secondhalf points tonight to spark the Cavaliers to a 9890 uphill victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Cambridge Loses Kennedy Museum
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6Faced with continued opposition, the John F. Kennedy Library Corporation dropped today its plans for a museum near Harvard Square honoring the late President.

title: Recently Published Books
description: American Review 22: The Magazine of New Writing, edited by Theodore Solotaroff (Bantam Paperback, $2.45). A collection of short stories, poems and articles.

title: 2 at State Theater Charged With Theft
description: Two boxoffice officials at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center was arrested yesterday on charges of stealing more than $150,000 in ticket receipts.

title: Nomination of Silberman As Trade Negotiator Due
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Laurence H. Silberman, the No. 2 man at the Justice Department for the last year, is expected to be named President Ford's Special Representative for Trade Negotiations, Administration officials disclosed today.

title: G.O.P. Challenges Need for New Taxes
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6The Assembly's minority Republicans said today that Governor Carey would not need any new taxes! to balance his proposed budget because the state's revenues for: the new fiscal year would actually be at least 6358million higher than the Governor predicted.

title: Kennedy Unit Drops Plans for Museum
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mas., Feb. 6Faced with continued opposition, the John F. Kennedy Library Corporation droped today its plans for a museum honoring the late President near Harvard Square.

title: Business Briefs
description: Pan Am, British Line in Route Accord

title: Woman in Wrigley Family Found Dead, Nurse Is Held
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Feb. 6 (UPI)The wife of millionaire member of the Wrigley chewing gum family was found dead early today, her body stuffed in a barrel filled with concrete. Her husband's male nurse was arrested on suspicion of murder.

title: MIDEAST DOUBTS ON PEACE EASING
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 6Arab commentators and Western diplomats have begun talking about a possibility that a political settlement the Middle East might be achieved through combined United States and Soviet intercession.

title: North Carolinian, 113, Dies
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 (AP) Lewis Batchelor, a North Carolina farmer for most of his 113 years, died here today.

title: Whoppers, Jingles, Graffiti
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind.There Is sad misunderstanding in American higher education about the teaching and study of folklore. Were folklore called by a highfalutin nameor even by folkloristics, a term now making headwayit would encounter less suspicion and derision from university administratois and faculties.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Apartheid3 P.M.

title: Women Pros Vote Ban on Wimbledon
description: Billie Jean King and her association of women tennis pros gave Wimbledon one more chance yesterday to give them equal prize money with the men or a promise of it or face a boycott by the game's top players.

title: Discount Rate Cut to 5'/2% by Bundesbank
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Feb. 6 (Reuters)The West German central bank said today it was cutting its discount rate to 51/2 per cent from 6 per cent. It also lowered the lombard rate to 71/2 per cent from 8 per cent, effective tomorrow. The lombard rate is the rate at which banks can borrow against securities. The discount rate is the rate at which banks can borrow money against bills as security.

title: CAREY AND BEAME SEE ROCKEFELLER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Governor Carey and Mayor Beame came here today to seek Federal funds from Vice President Rockefeller in a ritual reminiscent of other supplications involving the three men.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly stated in The New York Times yesterday that John Marshall was the first Chief Justice of the United States. John Jay was the first Chief Justice; Marshall was the fourth.

title: Hialeah Is Plagued by Problems
description: MIAMI. Feb. 6Past the alligator and tropical fish, past the macaws, pheasants, cockatoos and a parrot that says, Hello, and not far from four flamingos that pose for pictures, a 10foot model of a birthday cake stands sadly in the beautiful Hialeah Park paddock.

title: This First Fine Line
description: THIS first fine line signals youth spent like paper and the beginning of my climb into the earth.

title: 2 Elderly Sisters Held In ArsonInsurance Plot
description: Two elderly sisters, 73 and 66 years old, were arrested yesterday and accused by fire marshals of having participated in a conspiracy to hire professional torches to set hundreds of fires In Queens and Nassau Counties over the last 12 years for millions of dollars in insurance.

title: New Plan for Revenue Sharing Urged
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6A reslicing of the $700million state revenuesharing pie was proposed today by a study commission. But two of the most influential members of the group denounced the plan as catastrophic and anticity.

title: MAX ZIDES
description: Max Zides, who had been popular entertainer in New England, died at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston yesterday. He was 70 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES AID FOR RAILWAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)The House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee approved S347million in Federal assistance to cashstricken Northeastern and Midwestern railroads today.

title: Decline Continues In Business Loans
description: The main banking trends or the new year remained intact this week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed yesterday in its weekly statistics. Business loans declined, interest rates dropped, moneysupply growth remained stalled and banks were less cramped for reserves.

title: LifeSized Puppets to Join Atlanta's Battle on Blight
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6Sid and Marty Krofft, the puppeteers who have brought fantasy and innovation to the Saturday morning ghetto of children's television, are being hoisted centerstage in Atlanta to help combat urban blight.

title: Y. &
description: Creswell, Munsell, Schubert & Zirbel, the Cedar Rapids, Iowa, outpost of Y & R National, has just gotten its biggest assignment since it came under the Young & Rubicam umbrella. It is the Elanco Products Company, the Indianapolisbased, agriculturalmarketing division of Eli Lilly & Co.

title: U.S. Expects Industrial Partners To Agree to a Floor Price for Oil
description: PARIS, Feb. 6  Assistant Secretary of State Thomas O. Enders said today that the United States expected its industrial partners in the International Energy Agency to reach agreement on the concept of a common minimum price for oil imports before entering a preliminary meeting with oil producers.

title: Police List 2 Numbers For Calls on Bombings
description: Anyone who believes he may have information about the F.A.L.N. or any of the 10 bombings is urged by the Police Department to call (212) 3495844. The identity of the caller will be kept confidentia.

title: OFFSHORE OIL PLAN OPPOSED ON COAST
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 6  The Federal program for greatly stepped up development of offshore oil was denounced as a blueprint for disaster and defended as essential to energy self sufficiency as the Department of the Interior opened hearings here today on its California leasing program for 1975.

title: Illness on Japanese let Is Traced to Alaskan Cook
description: Health officials have tentatively identified an Anchorage cook as the source of the foodpoisoning outbreak that struck 144 passengers on a Japan Air Lines flight in Copenhagen Monday.

title: Ford Assails C.A.B.
description: The Ford Administration denounced the impact of the Civil Aeronautics Board and said it would seek to reduce substantially the agency's power to regulate airlines. Page 61.

title: MILLIONJOB BILL GOING TO SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Senators Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, and Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, announced today that they would introduce dipartisan legislation tomorrow to expand the public service employment program by one million jobs.

title: Right to Traditional Education Asserted by Investigating Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Public school systems should provide alternative schools or alternative classes in basic subjects for children whose parents want them taught by traditional methods within traditional curriculum, a panel sponsored by the National Education Association said today.

title: Ford Condemns Congress For Resisting His Policies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6President Ford struck back at Congress today, accusing it, through his press secretary, of inaction on his energy and economic programs and of doing basically nothing in a month of operations.

title: Scott Says A. &
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which operates more supermarkets than any other national food chain, plans to close many more stores this year than in any previous year, Jonathan L. Scott, A. & P.'s new chairman, said here yesterday. The largest number of stores closed in one year was 404, in 1972. The stores to be closed will be mostly smaller, older stores from 9,000 to 10,000 square feet, which have become obsolete, Mr. Scott said.

title: Slayings Fell 7.5% in 74, But Other City Crime Rose
description: Reported homicides in the city declined by 7.5 per cent last year compared with 1973, but all other categories of reported serious crime continued to increase, the Police Department said yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: When the fates offer choice between two lines of play, one of which is routine while the other is elegant, few can resist the elegant play when the percentages seem clase. The temptation is especially strong when the player is also a writer, motivated, perhaps subconsciously, by the need to have a hand to write about.

title: People and Business
description: John C. Sawhill, President  Ford's former chief energy adviser, joined other critics of the President's energy program yesterday and supported a 90day suspension of oil import fees.

title: BUYING HELPS STIR SILVER FUTURES
description: Speculative buying helped spur silver futures prices on the Commodity Exchange again yesterday, with March cry silver closing at $4.33 an ounce, up 9 cents. A week ago the same contract closed at $4.10.

title: THE TIMES PROMOTES TWO ON NEWS STAFF
description: A. M. Rosenthal, managing leditor of The New York Times, announced yesterday the appointment of Henry R. Lieberman as an assistant to the managing editor. Mr. Lieberman's successor as director of science news will be John Noble Wilford, an assistant national editor.

title: BURNS SAYS FORD IS UNDULY GLOOMY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI)Arthur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today the Administration was unduly pessimistic in predicting two years of high unemployment and inflation.

title: L.I. Ski Resort Draws 5,000 Each Week
description: FARMINGVILLE, L. L, Feb. 7Mary Ann Asimake checked to make sure her boots and bindings were fastened properly, took deep breath of the sharp night air and moved down the novice slope on her skis, twisting and turning, sending clouds of powder snow spraying behind her.

title: JAWORSKI WANTED AS APPEAL WITNESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Lawyers for H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman argued in Federal District Court here today that their clients should be permitted to summon Leon Jaworski, the former special prosecutor, to testify in connection with their attempts to have their convictions in the Watergate coverup case overturned.

title: For the Pet Owner: A Mutt Loaf That's Meatless
description: Frances Sheridan Goulart, the owner of three, healthy, semiherbivorous cats, occasionally shares a vegetarian dish called mock chopped liver with Dimsun, her youngest tabby. For health and budget reasons, Mrs. Goulart says, canines, felines and humans should avoid meatfilled meals at last two or three times a week and substitute other sources of protein.

title: Israeli Hawk Scorns Kissinger's Plan
description: REHOVOT, Israel, Feb. 6 The hardline views of the Israeli rightthe hawksare being articulated these days from a fourthfloor penthouse in this quiet, treelined Tel Aviv suburb.

title: MAYOR OF CAMEN FOUND NOT GUILTY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 7Mayor lAngelo J. Errichetti of Camden was found not guilty today of conspiracy and misconduct in office when he was Camden's Director of Public Works six years ago.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Juilliard Rehabilitating Antony and Cleopatra
description: Ever since Sept. 16, 1966, when the Metropolitan Opera christened its new house at Lincoln Center with a haircurlingly awful production of Samuel Barber's Antony and Cleopatra, the suspicion has been growing that the work itself might not be as bad as it seemed on that premiere night. Could anything be that bad, really? The night has gone down in the annals of opera as a landmark of vulgarity and staging excesses.

title: Impressionist Epoch at Met Sets Record for Attendance,. More Blockbusters in Offing
description: The house is big today, said Thomas P. F. Hoving, appreciatively auditing the distant roar of the crowd the other day from his director's office at the Metropolitan Museum. I can tell by the decibel count.

title: Floatable Breakwater Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7R. Buckminister Fuller, the scientist who is best known for his investion of the geodesic dome, is also a boating enthusiast. This week he was granted a patent for a folatable breakwater. Patent 3,863,455 describes the breakwater as a flex ible tubular envelope through whose open ends the water flows. A number of circular rubber tubes inside support the envelope and can move with relation to one another.

title: New Period For Trading Is Canceled
description: The baseball deal that wasn't made last winter but could have been made this March will not be made after all. The reason: The Major League Players Association has rejected the concept of a second interleague trading period.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Fell to 202.3 in the Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 202.3 from 203.4 last week.

title: Hughes Organization Reported Target Of Extortion Demand in 1974 Burglary
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 A middleofthenight burglary of Howard Hughes's headquarters here in 1974 Is under intense investigation following a $500,000 extortion demand made upon the Hughes organization.

title: Antiques: Patriotic Signs
description: What are the patriotic symbols that recur in American folk art?

title: CHANGES SOUGHT FOR SAVINGS UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (Reuters)Letting savings and loan institutions expand their services to meet the full financial needs of families would be the best way to helping them compete with commercial banks, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said in a report issued yesterday.

title: Art: Jane Freilicher Is Back
description: There is nothing more difficult for a painter today than to excel at the most traditional tasks. The onslaught of successive waves of modernist innovation has stripped these tasks of their historical sanction, and profound changes in taste have altered the way we respond to their realization. The contemporary painter who aspires to bring something fresh and individual to the depiction of a landscape or a stilllife, a portrait or an interior, risks a double jeopardy, for both the standards of the past and the tastes of the present are inevitably brought to bear on the results.

title: U.S. Delays a Decision on Pakistan Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The United States plans to announce in the next two to three weeks a decision on whether it will lift the 10yearold embargo on the sale of military equipment to Pakistan, Administration officials said today.

title: Arabs Said to Bar Deals Involving Jewish Bankers
description: LONDON, Feb. 7A number of major European banking houses connected with prominent Jewish families have reportedly been excluded from a series of routine international financings in recent months because of pressure from Arab governments.

title: At Chair Show, Sitter Beware
description: Experts have always known and design buffs have suspected that the best examples of modern furniture are not necessarily machinemade, architectural in inspiration or even very functional.

title: 5 Arrested in Israeli Blast
description: NATANYA, Israel, Feb. 7, (Reuters)  A young military deserter who is alleged to have stolen weapons and grenades has been arrested with four other men in connection with a grenade blast at a cellar discotheque here Wednesday in which six persons were killed.

title: Offshore OilLease Bids Disappoint Interior Agency but Cheer Opposition
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Up on the sixth floor of the Department of Interior, where the top policy makers ply their trade, it was pretty gloomy Wednesday after the results came in from the preceding day's sale of oil leases on the outer Continental Shelf off southern Texas in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: New Brazilian City Rises Next to the Old
description: SALVADOR, BrazilThis ancient colonial capital, famous for its mad carnivals, religious festivals, spicy cuisine and mellow, easygoing life, is acquiring a new modern image as it moves into the modern industrial age.

title: Kahane Faces Loss of Probation On Kidnap and Arms Charges
description: Rabbi Meyer Kahane, leader of the Jewish Defense League, was accused yesterday of having conspired to kidnap or assassinate a Soviet diplomat, to bomb the Iraqi Embassy in Washington and to ship arms abroad from Israel, when he was there in 1972.

title: Opera: Miss Price in Met's Manon
description: Leontyne Price's admirers have always felt that she has never sung at the Metropolitan Opera as much as she should have. A voice as glorious as hers deserved to be heard more often. There have been, of course, many landmarks in her career with the company: the early Aidas, the Donna Annas in Don Giovanni, the Leonoras in Trovatore, the CioCioSans in Madama Butterfly, to name some.

title: Bears Appoint Aide
description: CHICAGO (UPI) George Arneson, who resigned as ticket manager of the Minnesota. Vikings, has been named director. of stadium operations and admissions Manager for the Chicago Bears.

title: Year of Intelligence
description: The final fixture is about to fall into place for thorough and potentially farreaching review of United States intelligence practices and requirements. House Democrats are moving to centralize all the intelligence inquiries that have been proposed on their side of the Capitol in one bipartisan select committee. This is the same orderly procedure the Senate adopted with the aim of minimizing the dangers of fragmentation and competition among different members and vying committee investigations.

title: Impressionist Epoch at Met Sets Attendance Record
Oil CleanUp Slowed
description: BUZZARDS BAY, Mass., Feb. 7 (AP)Freezing water hampered cleanup efforts in Sippican Harbor where a 5,000gallon oil spill occurred early this morning, the Coast Guard said.

title: Not Those Old Wings Again!
description: The Republican party is famous for its wings. It may be the only party in the world that is all wings and no body. It has a right wing, which is conservative, and it has a liberal wing. which is conservative.

title: Threat to the Fare
description: The 35cent transit fare may soon go the way of the Second Avenue subway unless Mayor Beame and Governor Carey act quickly to find new sources of operational support for the floundering Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: TURKEY TELLS MOBIL AND B.P.: IMPORT OIL
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 7 (AP)The Government. of Turkey has warned the Mobil Oil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., that it will revoke their refining :licenses within three months unless the companies resume importing crude oil into Turkey, company officials said today.

title: DR. PAUL LOMAX, 84, EDUCATOR AT N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Paul S. Lomax, professor emeritus of education at New York University, died Thursday evening at his home, 21 Beach Place, Maplewood, N. J. He was 84 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: JOHN WNEILL, 89, EDUCATOR, IS DEAD
description: Dr. John T. McNeill, former professor of European Christianity at the University of Chicago Divinity School, died Wednesday in Chicago. He was 89 years old and lived in East Middlebury, Vt. He was considered the leading historian of Calvinism in the Englishspeaking world.

title: Uniform Medicaid Payment Bill Is Offered for Nursing Homes
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4 The chairmen of the Legislature's two health committees are sponsoring a bill that would establish a uniform schedule of Medicaid payments for nursing homes.

title: Recital
description: Pianists do not usually need a special excuse to give an allChopin recital, particularly a pianist as proficient as Daniel Pollack. Still, there was a rationale behind his program on Thursday night in Alice Tully Hall, and that was to mark the 25th anniversary of the Chopin Piano Competition and Scholarships of the Kosciuszko Foundation, an award Mr. Pollack won in 1955.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Jersey City Rent Law Is Upheld

title: PORTUGUESE DEFY BAN ON PROTESTS
description: LISBON, Feb. 7  Several thousand workers went into the streets tonight to protest rising unemployment, defying a Government ban on demonstrations.

title: DR. VIVIAN J. HORN
description: Dr. Vivian J. Horn, assistant professor of English atSuffolk County Community College in Seklen, L. I., died Wednesday in Setauket, L. I. Her age was 66.

title: Developing Countries Agree To Unity on Raw Materials
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 7 (UPI) Developing countries agreed today to work for a common front in using their raw materials to obtain better terms of trade with the industrial nations.

title: Pentagon to End All Subsidies To Commissaries in October, 76
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Over strenuous objections from within the military, the Defense Department 11;:.s decided to eliminate the Government subsidies that have permitted military families to buy food in commissaries at a substantial discount.

title: CAREY GIVES VIEW ON TRADE CENTER
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7 Governor Carey sought a bit of internationalist perspective for his fledgling administration today. urging that the bureaucratfilled World Trade Center in Manhattan be brought to life and live up to its name.

title: Lawyer Who Found Victim of a Client Is Cleared Upstate
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 7  An Onondaga County grand jury this afternoon cleared a lawyer, Frank H. Armani, of criminal wrongdoing in failing to disclose that his client in a murder case had told him where he had hidden two bodies.

title: Italian Judges End Strike
description: ROME, Feb. 7 (UPI)Judges returned to work today after a 48hour strike that halted most court hearings throughout Italy. But transportation workers walked off their jobs and butchers and farm workers anBounced plans for strikes.

title: DEMOCRATS STUDY A GAS TAX KEYED TO CUT IN JOBLESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7In an effort to shape energy and fiscal alternatives to the Administration's proposals, a committee of senior Democratic Senators is studying a staff outline of a plan that would assign first priority to a reduction of unemployment.

title: Today's Entries at Hialeah
description: Horses listed In order of post Positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Flu Deaths Decline In U.S., but Remain At Epidemic Level
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 7 (AP)Deaths related to influenza and pneumonia declined sharply last week but remained above the epidemic threshold, the National Center for Disease Control reported today.

title: Dissident in Hungary Protests Delay on Promised Exit Visa
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 7  A Hungarian sociologist who was arrested by the security police in Budapest last November and then invited to go into exile abroad has protested to Hungarian authorities that they have not kept their word to allow him to leave.

title: Senators Issue Subpoena For Bergman for Feb. 19
description: The Senate Subcommittee on LongTerm Care issued a subpoena yesterday calling on Bernard Bergman to appear at a hearing in Washington on Feb. 19.

title: Books of The Times
description: Alessandra Comini's Egon Schiele's Portraits, Emily Genauer's Rufino Tamayo and Benedict Nicolson and Christopher Wright's Georges de La Tour, three strong runners that didn't quite get to the gate in time for the 1974 Christmas art book derby, win the favorable answer to the first question about any new art book: Is it really needed, or is it just another hypedup rewrite of a proven salable subject? They are respectively the best book on the Viennese wunderkind so far and maybe forever, a duet in close harmony between the Mexican maestro and a North American admirer, and a handsome summary of all we know just now about rediscovered old master.

title: U.S. Court Upholds Penalty of $78,500 In 64 Rights Jailing
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb 7 (AP) A former superintendent of Mississippi's Parchman Prison must pay $500 in damages to each of 157 civil rights protesters illegally jailed in 1964, a Federal appeals court held today.

title: A Bit of Fashion Artistry for Summer
description: The buyers were ecstatic.

title: For the Hidden Jobless, a Drastic Impact
description: DETROIT, Feb. 7  Lewis Scott, a 26yearold black Detroiter with a wife and two preschool children, has been through it all.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AWARENESS Two special programs celebrating Black History Week, which officially begins tomorrow, will include uptown and downtown salutes to achievements in music, dance, art and history at the American Museum of Natural History and at the World Trade Center.

title: Armour and LibbyOwens Laying Off Workers in lowa
description: MASON CITY, Iowa, Feb. 7 (UPI)  Armour & Co. announced today the layoff of about 255 workers from its work force here because of a 25 per cent reduction in production.

title: ComeconMarket Talks End
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 7The first formal talks here between the European Common Market and Comecon, the economic alliance of the Communist bloc, have failed to work out the next step in contacts between the two trade organizations, sources close to the talks said today.

title: REV. CHARLES DOCHERTY
description: The Rev. Charles V. Docherty, who had been a member of the St. John's University faculty in Brooklyn and later in Jamaica, Queens, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Seminary, Princeton, N. J. He was 75 years old.

title: $1.6MILLION LOSS REPORTED BY AVIS
description: Avis, Inc., incurred a $1.6million loss in the fourth quarter last year and a $6million decline in 1974 profits, according to the company's report issued yesterday.

title: Bies 204 Sets Pace By Shot
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 7Into each reign a little strife must fall. The troops rebelled today and deposed Johnny Miller, forcing him back to second place in the third round of the fiveday Bob Hope Desert Classic. Chances are, though, that he'll be back tomorrow.

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Stock prices declined yesterday in much lighter trading as nervousness over the widening! recession weakened the list and kept many investors on the sidelines.

title: 7 L.I. Children Hurt in Crash
description: DIX HILLS, L. I., Feb. 7 (AP) Seven secondgraders were injured slightly today when their school bus and an automobile collided at Deer Park Road and Northern State Parkway. The children, en route to a planetarium with other pupils atending Canaan Lake Elementary School in North Patchogue, were treated at Huntington Hospital for cuts and bruises and later released.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: In Memoriam
description: GAGEJack. Never a dav goes by that rev thoughts are not with thee.

title: Soviet Said to Base Arms Aid for Egypt on Return of Advisers
description: Egypt has received four shiploads of ammunition and spare parts from the Soviet Union in the last month but, according to highly qualified Israeli sources, any decision to supply heavier military equipment has been made conditional on a return of Soviet military advisers and instructors to Egypt.

title: Article 1  No Title
Peru Is Calm Again After Riots
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 7Cairn returned to this city after two days of rioting and looting that left about 100 people dead, according to the Peruvian military Government's estimates.

title: Stage: Dandelion Wine
description: Dandelion Wine, Ray Bradbury's memoirasnovel, an ode to the. summer of 1928, has been transformed into a loving evening of theater. Adapted in Story Theater style by Peter John Bailey, the play opened on Thursday at Playhouse II as one of the Phoenix Sideshows and closes tomorrow, but it deserves to have an extended run.

title: Dave Anderson
description: For the New York teams, this wasn't exactly the week that was. But it was eventful. Almost all of them created headlines.

title: New Payment Option
description: DETROIT, Feb. 7The General Motors Corporation announced today that it had renegotiated its licensing agreement for the Wankel rotary engine, giving it an option to pay for the rights over a longer period of time.

title: MAYOR OF CAMDEN FOUND NOT GUILTY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 7 Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden was found not guilty today of conspiracy and misconduct in office when he was Camden's Director of Public Works six years ago.

title: CITY's DISMISSALS TOTAL 1,724 SO FAR
description: A total of 1,724 city employes have been dismissed outright from among the 11,985 Mayor Beame has ordered off the payroll since November.

title: The Program
description: THE RAMAYANA, a now interpretation In English by Gopal Sharman. Created and directed by Mr. Sharman; lighting and sound by Anasuya Valdya; direction by Helen Breed; settings by John C. Macgregor, sound by John W. Ackley 3d. Presented by Robert Hendrickson, by arrangement with the Akshara Theater, New Delhi, and HariwIck College, Onennta, N.Y. At the BarbizonPlaza Theater, 106 Central Park South.

title: Evidence of Water On Jupiter Found By Detectors on Jet
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Astronomers have discovered evidence of water in the atmosphere of giant Jupiter, a major advancement in learning whether the solar system's largest planet can support some form of life.

title: Columbia Presses For Transfer Signs On IRT Platforms
description: An alliance of educational, medical and religious institutions in Morningside Heights has criticized the Transit Authority for rejecting its request that signs be posted on several Broadway IRT station platforms to prevent Heightsbound passengers from winding up in Harlem.

title: AGNEW BREAKS TIE WITH LAND DEALER
description: CROFTON, Md., Feb. 7 (AP)Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew says he is terminating his contract with Walter J. Dilbeck Jr., an Indiana land speculator, because of the latter's exploitation of their business relationship.

title: Soaring Unemployment
description: Although the White House tried to take the surprise and sting out of the soaring jobless figures by forecasting an unemployment rate averaging 8.1 per cent for 1975 as a whole, the leap in the rate to 8.2 per cent January remains a shockerthe highest level in 33 years. Seven and a half million people are now out work, by the official count.

title: A $50,000 Reward Is Offered in Blast At Fraunces Annex
description: A $ 50,000 reward was offered yesterday for information leading to the capture and conviction of any of the persons responsible for the fatal bombing of the Fraunces Tavern annex on Jan. 24.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: 7th Fleet Gets Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (Reuters)Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger named Vice Adm. Thomas Haywood today as the new commander of the United States Seventh Fleet in the Pacific. Admiral Haywood, 50 years old, is now director of navy program planning. He succeeds Vice Adm. George Steele, who has commanded the Seventh Fleet since August, 1973.

title: Redeeming a Promise
description: The Administration dropped the other shoe on the right side of the bed when it finally decided to raise by 2.2 million tons the amount of food aid to be made available this fiscal year. By all accounts, President Ford opted for the highest of the three alternatives put to himthe one for which the food aid lobby in the Congress and the private coalition of humanitarian groups had been pressing. In doing so, he redeemed the promises which he and Secretary of State Kissinger made to the international community both at the United Nations and at the World Food Conference last fall Rome.

title: DEMOCRATS STUDY A GAS TAX KEYED TO CUT IN JOBLESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 In an effort to shape energy and fiscal alternatives to the Administration's proposals, a committee of senior Democratic Senators is studying a staff outline of a plan that would assign first priority to a reduction of unemployment.

title: Celtic Streak Ends As 76ers Win, 9895
description: BOSTON, Feb. 7 (Ap)Billy Cunningham led a Philadelphia outburst early in the second half and the 76ers held on for a 9895 Victory over Boston tonight, snapping the Celtics 11game winning streak in the National Basketball Association.

title: ExJustice Deckelrnan Dies; Prosecutor in Gang Slaying
description: JEFFERSONVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 7 (AP) Former State Supreme Court Justice William Deckelman died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 81 years old and lived here.

title: Onassis Is in Paris Hospital After Flight From Greece
description: PARIS, Feb. 7, (Reuters)  Aristotle Onassis entered the American Hospital here today for treatment for a muscular complaint affecting his heart. Mr. Onassis, 69 years old, arrived in Paris last night from Athens with his daughter, Christina, and his wife, Jacqueline. He spent the night at home he maintains here.

title: Arabs Said to tar Deals Involving Jewish Bankers
description: LONDON, Feb. 7 A number of major European banking houses connected with prominent Jewish families have reportedly been excluded from a series of routine international financings in recent months because of pressure from Arab governments.

title: Kissinger's Role Under Ford Worried Nixon, Colson Alleges
description: Charles W. Colson, former White House aide under President Nixon said yesterday that Mr. Nixon had considered resigning from the Presidency eight months before he actually did, but was worried that Vice President Ford could not control Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Donations Offered To Walker Family Ruled Not Taxable
description: Donations to the Walker children, whose father was killed by a gunman when he tried to aid a wounded police officer, are considered nostringsattached gifts, said an Internal Revenue spokesman yesterday, and as such are not taxable.

title: Kialoa HI First In 403Mile Race
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 7Kialoa III, the new 79foot ketch from Los Angeles, tonight was the first yacht to finish the 403mile ocean race from St. Petersburg on Florida's west coast. The achievement of this vessel, known among her competitors as the great white whale, was expected. Kialoa had led the fleet of 83 craft all the way through the voyage, which began on Wednesday and took the elite flotilla around the tip of the Florida peninsula.

title: Penn Coasts to Victory Over Columbia, 11369
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 Shortly after Pennsylvania trounced Columbia, 11369, at the Palestra tonight, Chuck Daly, the Quakers coach, said, They just didn't have any size inside against us. So in our place it made it a relatively easy game.

title: OFFSHORE OIL DATA FIELD INADEQUATE
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 7A 500page indictment of the Federal Government's rationale for stepped up development of offshore oil was set forth today by a coalition of local governments in Southern California.

title: JOHN J. TUCKER
description: John J. Tucker, chairman of the executive committee of Knox, Lent Se. Tucker, Inc., insurance agents, and a trusteel of the Home Savings Bank in White Plains, died there Thursday in St. Agnes Hospital. He; was 73 years old and lived at 29 Hathaway Lane.

title: DOLLAR ENDS DOWN AS GOLD ADVANCES
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 7 (UPI) The dollar finished the week slightly lower on European money markets today, while gold rose.

title: RAILCAR CHANGES TO BE URGED HERE
description: Federal investigators will urge major changes in the safety features of more than 1,050 railroad cars that serve Long Island, Westchester County and Connecticut commuters, Government transportation officials said yesterday.

title: Top Saigon Political Cartoonist Is Reported Held
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 7  Saigons leading political cartoonist, who pilloried Government figures and the Communists with equal vigor, has been arrested, wellplaced sources reported today.

title: Blast in Florida School
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. (UPI) A bomb placed in a student's locker blew out a classroom wal at MacArthur High School today 25 minutes after classes were dismissed for the day, Sally Brown, Broward County schoo spokesman, said. The blast tore a hole four by eight feet in the wall. There were..no injuries.

title: Drug Inquiry Clears Players
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 7The Drug Enforcement Administration absolved today National Football League players of charges they were supplied narcotics by a drug ring.

title: OBSCENITY TRIAL GETS POLL ON SEX
description: The defense in the obscenity trial of the movie The Life and Times of a Happy Hooker entered a poll into evidence yesterday that purported to show the attitudes of New Yorkers toward sexually explicit films.

title: 1974 Loss Expected At Cluett, Peabody OnV an Raalte Sale
description: Cluett, Peabody & Co., Inc., said yesterday that it was negotiating to sell its Van Raalte Company division and would establish an aftertax reserve of approximately $13million to cover losses that might be incurred.

title: Yesterday's Results at Bowie
description: BOWIE, MD. By The Associated Press

title: When The Farce Comes First
description: PARISUncle Sam and Henry Kissinger have lost considerable prestige during the Cyprus crisis festering since July. The United States Congress, which really isn't supposed to be diplomatic agency, should also have been diminished in foreign eyes. However, it hasn't had an impressive repute abroad since the Senate vetoed American participation in the Versailles Treaty more than half a century ago.

title: ARMY GIVES COST OF 3 NEW DIVISIONS
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 7 The Army estimated today that it could cost $2.5billion over the next five .!ears to increase the size of its combat forces from 13 to 16 divisions.

title: William Hazlett Upson Dies; Wrote Alexander Botts Stories
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. (AP) William Hazlett Upson, author of the Alexander Bolts stories that appeared for years in The Saturday Evening Post, died here Wednesday at the age of 83.

title: Reuben Jay Cole Is Dead; Jazz Pianist Toured Africa
description: Reuben Jay Cole, a jazz pianist and younger brother of the drummer Cozy Cole, died Tuesday at United Hospital in Newark. He was about 60 years old.

title: RUTH MATTESON, 65, CHARACTER ACTRESS
description: Ruth Matteson, an actress whose roles ranged from musical comedy to serious drama, died Wednesday. She was 65 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Brutality Study Clears Newark Police
description: NEWARK, Feb. 7 (UPI) A grand jury investigating charges of police brutality during Hispanic disturbances that began in Branch Brook Park last September found no evidence of criminal wrongdoing by the police, it was disclosed today.

title: 2 Philadelphia Newspapers Closed in Delivery Dispute
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP) The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Daily News, two of the city's three daily newspapers, suspended publication in??e??nitely today after truck drivers refused to deliver the papers yesterday and again today despite an injunction ordering them back to work.

title: Today's Entries at Bowie
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter deienates OTB lisling

title: 2 Soviet Astronauts Arrive To Prepare for July Flight
description: NEW YORK, Feb. 7 CAP)Two Soviet astronauts who will join American astronauts in the first United StatesSoviet Union space venture July 15 arrived at Kennedy Airport from Paris today with little fanfare.

title: Clashes Erupt Again After Ethiopia Warns Rebels
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 7 (Reuters)Fighting broke out again in the Eritrean capital of Asmara tonight only hours after the Ethiopian Government had made it clear that it had no intention of granting independence to the northern province.

title: BenGurion And Peace
description: LOS ANGELESWith Golda Meir retired and Israel's leadership transferred from founders to sons, with the sons now responsible for coming to terms with the Arabs, and with Henry A. Kissinger again involved in another round of Middle East diplomacy, this would seem the moment to remind Americans of the littleknown conditions for that peace laid down before he died by the greatest founder of them allDavid BenGurion.

title: Justice, Sentencing Killer, Urges Death Penalty Law
description: Justice Joseph A. Martinis of the State Supreme Court sentenced a 40yearold former convict yesterday to 25 years to life in prison for the murder of a young woman, but indicated he would have sentenced him to death if the law permitted.

title: Frenchhand Belgian Proxy Fight Ended
description: PARIS, Jan 28  The French Government has judged acceptable a plan put forward by a FrenchBelgian group to operate the key company in the French nuclear power program apparently ending a bitter proxy figit.

title: Slayings Fell 7.5% in 74, But Other City Crime Rose
description: Reported homicides in the city declined by 7.5 per cent last year compared with 1973, but all other categories of re!ported serious crime continued to increase, the Police Department said yesterday.

title: Ford Trims Layoffs
description: DETROIT, Feb. 7The Ford Motor Company said today would have a total of 63,000 workers laid off next week, down 11,000 from the 74,000 workers idle this week but still 36 per cent of its United States hourly employment.

title: Ecuador Upholds Boat Fines
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Feb. 7 (AP) An appeals court here today upheld the penalties against four Californiabased tuna boats fines totaling $464,400 and confiscation of their catches, worth more than $800,000. The vessels were seized more than two weeks ago for allegedly having violated the 200mile territorial waters claimed by Ecuador.

title: COURT REJECTS SUIT ON HIGHRISE PLAN
description: TRENTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The state's second highest court ruled today that developers could construct five highrise apartment houses in Ocean City, Cape May County.

title: Bundy Rebuffed Hammer Funding Plea
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, tried to persuade McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Foundation, to withdraw funding from a publicinterest law firm that had sued to block Occidental's drilling on the California coast in West Los Angeles, documents before the California Supreme Court show.

title: CAREY GIVES VIEW ON TRADE CENTER
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7 Governor Carey sought a bit of internationalist perspective for his fledgling administration today. urging that the bureaucratfilled World Trade Center in Manhattan be brought to life and live up to its name.

title: Notes on People
description: Because a chronically pinched nerve in her neck kicked up yesterday, Betty Ford missed two White House briefings that she had sponsored to promote the Equal Rights Amendment. Dr. William Lukash, the White House physician, said that Mrs. Ford was receiving her usual hotpack treatment for the osteoarthritic condition she has had for 12 years. It's going to be a recurrent thing, he said.

title: Vail Scores 2 as Flames Down Kings
Plan for 2d Landing System Stirs Dispute
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 4Westchester County is considering installing a second instrument landing system at the county airport that would not only increase overall safety but would also divert an extra 1,200 badweather landings each year to an approach over the Town of Rye.

title: LYKES NET ROSE 226% IN QUARTER
description: The LykesYoungstown Corporation, engaged in steel production, shipping, oil and natural gas drilling equipment and supplies, reported yesterday a 226.4 per cent increase in fourthquarter earnings and 232.4 per cent for all of last year. Sales and revenues showed modest gains by contrast.

title: Poor Market for Apples
description: LANSING, Mich., Feb. 7 (UPI)More than one million bushels of Michigan apples may have to be dumped because of a poor market, a spokesman for the apple industry said today. Thomas C. Butler, manager of the Michigan Processing Apple Growers Association, said, There is no interest on the part of processor to pack any substantial amount of apples because of low prices and reduced demand.

title: Rhodesian Black Leaders Fly to Tanzania for Talks
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. Rhodesian black leaders have flown to Tanzania for more discussions aimed at getting under way a constitutional conference on the future of this racially divided country.

title: Fire Department Against Plans To Barge Gas Through Harbor
description: The Fire Department has stated its opposition to plans to ship liquified natural gas by barge through New York Harbor, declaring that high risks to human safety were involved, spokesman for the city administration said last night.

title: Man Survives Plunge
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 (UPI) For the eighth time since the Golden Gate Bridge was opened in 1937, a wouldbe suicide has survived a jump from the span. John William Hart, 29 years old. of San Francisco, was in ?? condition today after plunging from the bridge. Some 528 persons have killed themselves by jumping from the bridge.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: A Question of Power
description: In the second in its series of reports, the State Charter Revision Commission has moved cautiously toward the controversial nub of the problem posed by its mandate to make New York City's government more responsive to the needs of its citizens. The question is howif at all to redistribute power between a now dominant City Hall and the dissatisfied boroughs and local communities.

title: Ling and Three Concerns Accused of Fraud by U.S.
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 7 (AP)An Atlantabased company, the North American Acceptance Corporation, and two other companies were charged today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with fraud in a petition filed in Federal court here.

title: New Delay In Cosmos, Best Talks
description: George Best, the temperamental soccer star with the lifestyle of a movie idol, advised the New York Cosmos through his attorney yesterday that he wouldn't be in New York this weekend as planned.

title: JaiAlai Coming to Connecticut
description: Jaialai fans in this area don't have much longer to wait before they can start betting close to home..

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Oregon's Ombudsperson
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 7 (UPI)Oregan has its first, ombudsperson. Gladys McCoy, a Portland school board member, said she would use the title because she considers the title, ombudsman sexist. Mrs. McCoy was appointed by Gov, Robert Straub.

title: Deaths
description: Acker, Maybele A.

title: SYNCRUDE PROJECT MAY NEED $1BILLION
description: TORONTO, Feb. 7 (UPI) The heads of two major oil companies, bolstered by $600million in Government money to save the Syncrude oil sands project, admitted today they could not guarantee they would not need an extra $1billion in the future to keep the program alive.

title: Rye DevelopersHope to Begin Complex in'75
description: The backers of a planned $200million luxury residential, office and recreational development on a 335acre site along the Connecticut border in the Westchester County town of Rye say they hope to begin construction this year..

title: CBS Substitutes Episode For Premiere of Khan!
description: In an unusual move yesterday, CBSTV replaced the scheduled premiere episode of Khan!, a TV Series about a San Francisco detective, with a substitute episode. The original episode had drawn poor response from several critics.

title: M.T.A. Says Trailing Engineer Caused 2Train Bronx Crash
description: A board of inquiry yesterday put the blame for the Jan. 2 commutertrain crash in the Bronx on a 65yearold Penn Central engineer who had not had the railroad's required annual physical checkup since 1965.

title: Costa Rica Ministry Bombed
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 7 (AP) A bomb exploded tonight in the Costa Rican Foreign Ministry building here, causing some damage to doors and windows, the police said. No casualties were reported.

title: Yesterday's Results at Hialeah
description: MIAMI By The Associated Press

title: Ford Plans Further Action If the Economy Worsens
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7President Ford, described as concerned about the sharp increase in unemployment last month, will keep close watch on the economic situation and will not hesitate to take further action if the economy worsens more than expected, his spokesman said today.

title: Ford Plans Further Action lf the Economy Worsens
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 President Ford, described as concerned about the sharp in. crease in unemployment last 1month, will keep close watch on the economic situation and will not hesitate to take further action if the economy worsens more than expected, his spokes. man said today.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Symphony No. Borodin; Piano Concerto No. 2, Liszt.

title: New Weather Satellite Stationed Over Pacific
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP)The nation's newest weather satellite stationed itself 22,300 miles above the Pacific Ocean today after ground controllers successfully fired on  board rockets to maneuver the spacecraft into an exact orbit.

title: Court Order Delays Close Of Over peck Creek Dump
description: HACKENSACK, Feb. 7 Appellate Judge Theodore I. Botter delayed today for a maximum period of three weeks implementation of a lowerI court order closing the Overpeck Creek sanitary landfill, used by 26 Bergen County communities.

title: Prices Drop on Amex and OTC as Volume Falis
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower yesterday as volume dropped sharply. Similar conditions prevailed in the overthecounter marked.

title: RAILCAR CHANGES TO BE URFED HEBE
description: Federal investigators will urge major changes in the safety features of more than 1,050 railroad cars that serve Long Island, Westchester County and Connecticut commuters, Government transportation officials said yesterday.

title: Boeing Vertol Strike Ends
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP)  Federal negotiators announced today a tentative contract settlement in the 80dayold Boeing Vertol strike by United Auto Workers. Details of the pact have been withheld pending a ratification vote scheduled for Feb. 9 at Widener College in Chester, Pa., according to Rex Marlowe of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

title: P.B.A. Study Says Police Pay Should Top Other Unions
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association made public yesterday a job evaluation study that concluded that police officers should have salaries 6 per cent higher than firemen.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Italian stateowned oil company, Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, has signed three contracts with the Soviet Union to construct fertilizer plants worth more than $160million, E.N.I. announced in Rome yesterday. Two of the plants will be at Togliattigrad on the Upper Volga River and the third will be near Moscow.

title: In Dinnerstein s Painting, an Echo Chamber
description: Simon Dinnerstein was born in Brooklyn in 1943, at a time when Germany was a foe to be overthrown at all costs. In 1970 that same Simon Dinnerstein went to Germany on a Fulbright scholarship. Fulbrights for Germany were easier to get than Fulbrights for France, Britain or Italy, and Mr. Dinnerstein responded in any case to the ancient German tradition of exact plain statement in art.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT NOW 8.2%; A JANUARY RISE OF 930,000 PUTS TOTAL AT 7.5 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The unemployment rate surged to 8.2 per cent in January. thus confirming fears that the current recession is by far the most serious since World War II.

title: Liguori Takes Mile in 3:55.8
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7With a bad tooth and an embarrassing race out of his system, Marty Liguori let loose and won the mile in 3 minutes 55.8 seconds at the Philadelphia Track Classic tonight, the second fastest performance anywhere indoors.

title: Yardville Is Replacing Trenton As Prisoner Reception Center
description: TRENTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Trenton State Prison ended its role as the reception center for state prison inmates today as the function was transferred to the Yardville Youth Reception and correction Center.

title: CALIFORNIA MOVES ON PENAL REFORM
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7Change in penal aspects of California's criminal justice administration appeared likely after the appointment of two new heads of two agencies, on top of a gathering trend toward reform among leaders of the executive and legislative branches.

title: Trial of Esposito, ExDetective Chief, Hears Confession
description: MORRISTOWN, Feb. 7 A Morris County Court judge today admitted into evidence purported taped confession from Capt. Joseph M. Esposito, the suspended chief of detectives of Paterson, at the captain's trial here on misconduct and conspiracy charges for allegedly protecting a gambling ring.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Princeton Routs Cornell
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 7Relying on tight defense and an effective fast break, Princeton overwhelmed errorprone Cornell, 5929, in an Ivy League game tonight at Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Market Summary
description: AMERICAN EXCHANGE

title: 18 Countries Set Tentative OilConservation Goals
description: PARIS, Feb. 7The 18 countries of the International Energy Agency agreed here today that measures must be taken to protect the search for new sources of fuel, to cut back dependence on Arab oil and eventually force down the price.

title: Ballet: Miss Farrell Returns to Balanchine's Quixote
description: George Balanchine's threeact ballet version of Don Quixote for the New York City Ballet has never had the popular success of the company's other fullevening productions.

title: Hard Economics the Key to World Livestock Supply
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7 American farmers who have been fattening cattle, hogs and poultry with corn and soybeans are eow cutting back on their feeding operations more sharplythan in any period since the nineteenfifties.

title: Business Briefs
description: West German Jobless Tops 1 Million

title: HOUSE UNIT CHECKS F.B.I. AND INFORMERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Representative Augustus F. Hawkins said today that the House equal opportunities subcommittee of which he is chairman, was looking into reports that the Federal Bureau of investigation hired informants in local antipoverty programs, and might conduct fullscale inquiry.

title: LAW CHIEFS'
description: MIAMI, Feb. 7 A twoyearlong feud between two high Federal law enforcement offi.dals here has had an adverse affect on the morale and investigative work of several Federal agencies in this area, according to prominent members of the Federal and local law enforcement establishments.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater:The Ramayana
description: The Ramayana, the epic of India, has finally opened in New York at the BarbizonPlaza Theater, after a halfdozen years of working out in New Delhi, the Fiji Islands, Britain and college campuses across America.

title: Blast in Florida School
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 71 (UPI)A bomb placed in a student's locker blew out a classroom wall at MacArthur High School today 25 minutes after classes were dismissed for the day, Sally Brown, Broward County school spokesman, said. The blast tore a hole four by eight feet in the wall. There were no injuries.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: P.B.A. Study Asks Higher Police Pay

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Matlack Signs Contract With Mets

title: Chavez's Union: A Future?
description: VISALIA, Calif.While many people deplore the heavyhanded Teamster raids on California vineyaras once under the jurisdiction of Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers, an argument is now being made by some that Teamster control may prove best for the farm workers because the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is big, powerful, and above all, efficient.

title: 2 Callers Seek Ransom in Theft Of Renaissance Works in Italy
description: ROME, Feb. 7Telephone calls demanding huge ransoms for three Renaissance paintings stolen from the Ducal Palace in Urbino early yesterday were received by local authorities today.

title: EDWARDS &
description: In a move to cut costs and improve customer service, Edwards & Hanly, the brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had completed arrangements to have retail customer orders processed through backoffice facilities of Shields Model Roland, Inc., effective about April 1.

title: 33% of DairyAided Candidates Lost 1974 Races, Report Shows
