description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)One out of three Senate and House candidates who received campaign donations from dairy cooperatives last year lost the election, the latest campaign finance reports show.

title: Market Place
description: Holders of American Telephone and Telegraph warrants despaired four months ago when the Justice Department announced an antitrust action aimed at forcing the company to divest itself of Western Electric.

title: JACKSON 5 (OR 8) AT THE MUSIC HALL; Talent and Charm Defeat a Psychological Trap
description: Radio City Music Hall has: lots of problems as a space for rock, pop and soul concerts, mostly having to do with its epic scale. But its gravest immediate problem would seem to! be psychological: artists apparently feel that because the Rockettes play there, popmusic shows must necessarily be tailored to a Rockettes audience. But, in fact, perfectly normal pop audiences show up, and, are generally put off by the kitschy, middleofthe road presentations they encounter.

title: Yunich Optimistic On Holding Fares Through the Year
description: David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, had an optimistic report yesterday on tho chances of saving transit and commuter fares through this year.

title: Prime Rate at Citibank Cut to 9% From 9%
description: The First National City Bank announced yesterday a reduction in its base lending rate to 9 per cent from 9 per cent, effective Monday. This action by the nation's second largest bank, followed by a similar move on the part of Marine Midland Bank, means that all major banks in the city now charge 9 per cent or lower on their prime rate the interest cost to their most creditworthy corporate customers.

title: U.S. HAS AIR AIDES IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (Reuters)The Defense Department said today that United States Air Force experts are in South Vietnam helping distribute aircraft carts.

title: Israeli Hawk Scorns Kissinger's Plan
description: REHOVOT, Israel, Feb. 6The hardline views of the Israeli rightthe hawksare being articulated these days from a fourthfloor penthouse in this quiet, treelined Tel Aviv suburb.

title: Article 3  No Title
Harvard Routs Yale
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7Led by Mike Griffin's careerhigh 17 points and an unyielding defense, Harvard won its third straight game tonight, defeating Yale 8164.

title: A Dilemma For Puerto Rico
description: Now comes a reminder of the turbulent late nineteensixties: Carefullytimed explosions are detonated in Manhattan, linked this time to groups favoring independence for Puerto Rico. Four persons are killed in a restaurant blast in the financial district.

title: Japanese Steel Industry Off but Less Than Others
description: MIZUSHTMA, Japan, Feb.7 The briefing began on somber note. Shigehiko Mera, the assistant genial manager of Kawasaki Steel's Mizushima works, said the cost of producing a ton of steel had risen 40 per cent, or about $53, in the last year.

title: Penance Ordered For Dairy Officials Over PriceFixing
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 7 (AP) A Federal judge sentenced four prominent dairy officials today to do public penance for fixing milk prices in Arizona, saying that traditional sentences would be like spitting in a blast furnace.

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED IN PAINTING THEFT
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 7A Hartford man was arrested this afternoon in connection with the theft yesterday of an oil painting by the 18thcentury English master Thomas Gainsborough.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.3 billion tonmiles, 11.2 per cent below the corresponding week last year. The A.A.R. also reported carloadings in the latest week totaled 458,672 cars, 13.6, per cent below last year.

title: Generous Concert By Philharmonic Recalls Old Times
description: In earlier times, symphonic programs held more or less to a pattern that is rarely found today. There would be a symphony, a concerto, a relatively new piece and then something colorful to provide a bangup finale. This is what the New York Philharmonic offered in its generous concert Thursday night under the direction of Bernard Haitink.

title: Jackson to Avoid the Campaign Trail And Seek Backing on Senate Record
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington said today that he intended to pursue the Democratic Presidential nomination largely on CaPitol Hill rather than the campaign trail.

title: Clarence S. Stein, Planner Of Garden Cities, 92, Dies
description: Clarence S. Stein, the pioneering town planner whose bestknown works were Sunnyside Gardens in Queens and the planned suburb of Radburn, N.J., died yesterday at his home, 1 West 64th Street, after a long illness. He was 92 years old.

title: City Payroll Cut by 1,724, As Accords Ease Ousters
description: A total of 1,724 city employes have been dismissed outright from among the 11,985 Mayor Beame has ordered off the payroll since November.

title: Transit Police Say Superiors Told Them to Alter Crime Data
description: Transit Authority patrolmen have told a special state grand jury that their superiors ordered them to falsify subway crime reports to make it seem that nighttime crime on the subways had diminished, attorneys close to the case disclosed yesterday.

title: Ford Is Hopeful of an End To Criticism of Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON. Feb 7President Ford said through his press secretary today that he hoped Secretary of State Kissinger would not have to face further criticism by political candidates as he embarks on his mission to negotiate for peace in the Middle East.

title: LARNE GIVEN A RENT RISE HERE
description: Lan??rds of many of the 600,000 ?? apartments in New York City were told yesterday that they could raise rents onehalf of one percentage point more than previously allowed, when leases are renewed or when new tenants move in.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Robert J. Schmertz, an owner of the Boston Celtics basketball team, and a codefendant pleaded not guilty Trenton to bribery conspiracy charges. Mr. Schmertz was freed without bail while the other defendant, Donald Safran, an insurance consultant from Lakewood, N.J., was released on a $1,000 personal recognizance bond.

title: For the Hidden Jobless, a Drastic Impact
description: DETROIT, Feb. 7Lewis Scott, a 26yearold black Detroiter with a wife and two preschool children, has been through it all.

title: Money
description: Fridav, Feb. 7, ?? DOMESTIC MARKET RATES IN PER CEI:T FEDERAL FUND

title: Chris Evert Triumphs Over Miss Navratilova
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio (AP) Chris Evert won from Martina Navratilova tonight and moved into the semifinal round of a $75,000 women's professional tennis tournament at the Coliseum. Miss Evert, seeded No. 1, put the I8yearold Miss Navratilova away handily, 63, 61.

title: Journalism Teacher Asks. Damages for Dismissal
description: FREEHOLD, Feb. 7 A State superior court judge today set April 28 for the opening of trial involving a former associate professor of journalism at Brookdale Community College who is suing the school for reinstatement.

title: FELICIA SANDERS, MOULIN SINGER
description: Felicia Sanders, the nightclub singer, died of cancer yesterday at her home, 845 West End Avenue. She was 53 years old.

title: Rangers and Islanders Face Mighty and Lowly
description: The Rangers can probably leave their expensive bridgework in their mouths today when they face the Canadiens in a rare afternoon game in Montreal.

title: State Energy Chief Quits Over Merger Of Unit With P.U.C.
description: TRENTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The Acting State Energy Administrator, Gordon M. Large, has turned in his resignation in letter sharply critical of the merger of his agency with the Public Utilities Commission.

title: The Opera
description: Based on the Metropolitan Opera's performance of Mussorgsky's Boris Godunov on Thursday night, it could be said that the company's new production of the work is so sumptuous it is becoming to anyone involved in it.

title: 14 Hurt in Bay State Fire
description: CANTON, Mass., Feb. 8 (UPI) Officials suspect, that leaking gas caused an explosion and fire that leveled a building yesterday, injuring 14 persons.

title: Cybis: The Last Word in Porcelains
description: TRENTON  The late Boleslaw Cybis, whose name is synonymous with fine porcelain, already had established himself as a successful painter before he first arrived in the United States in 1938. He was widely recognized throughout Europe and, even five years before his arrival here, several American museums had exhibited his works.

title: A new beginning after the end
description: The marginal person, according to sociologist Everett Stonequist, is the individual who leaves one social group or culture without fully entering another one, remaining on the margin of each but a member of neither. In the history of our multicultural immigrant nation almost every family has lived on this extended boundary at some time; it is perhaps the truest American frontier.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: United Press International

title: Endpaper
description: The action begins at a wedding party at the palatial Tudor home of Donald Corleone, the aging head of an oliveoil empire and an informal proponent of postbirth control. More important. Corleone is the beloved godfather of 238 relatives, friends and employes, 123 of them currently under indictment.

title: Who Is Angelina?
description: A gypsy fortuneteller in Menlo Park, Calif., tells Angelina Green that she is lost. True. And that she is going to meet a man  very tall, very dark. Also true. Angelina is 26, black and sophisticated enough to be confused by her options. Al Young sends his heroine on an odyssey that spells out the gypsy's prediction, and juxtaposes some contrasts of possibility.

title: Details of Program for Red Hook Given
description: In anticipation of becoming the temporary landlord for 220 families in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, the city will open two community offices this week to ease the transition of the neighborhood from a residential area to a new marine terminal.

title: Police Recover Stolen Gainsborough
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 8An oil painting by the 18thcentury English master Thomas Gainsborough, stolen two days ago from a small gallery in the Wadsworth Atheneum here, was recovered by the police early this morning, wrapped in a bedspread and left in a telephone booth near a supermarket in East Hartford.

title: Senate Traces the Successful Career Of Operator of Nursing Homes Here
description: Senate investigators, seeking to learn how profitable Medicaidsupported nursing homes really are, are exploring the success story of Samuel A. Klurman, who has just replaced Bernard Bergman as chairman of MedicTome Enterprises, Inc.

title: Susan B. Kolodny Fiancee of Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Armand Kolodny of Great Neck, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Beth Kolodny, to Steven L. Schwarcz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Schwarcz of Valley Cottage, N.Y.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I read The National Enquirer when I want to feel exhilarated about life's possibilities. It tells me of a world where miracles still occur. In the world of The National Enquirer, U.F.O.'S flash over the Bermuda Triangle, cancer cures are imminent, ancient film stars at last find love that is for keeps. Contacted by spiritualists on The Other Side, Clark Gable urges America to keep its chin up. Of all possible worlds, I like the world of The National Enquirer best.

title: Paperbacks
description: AMERICAN HEROINE: The Life and Legend of Jane Addams, by Allen F. Davis. (Oxford, $3.95.) She wasn't Just a respectable reformer of the preWorld War I era; this scholarly study reveals Hull House's founder as a dissenter and quite real woman.

title: DOWN AND OUT IN AMERICA
description: By members of the American Studies Program. SUNY at Buffalo

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in lime to appear in Section 2:

title: WORLD OF TEXTILES
description: New, shuttleless looms capable of weaving cloth at high speeds and in greater varieties are helping to slow the inroads that knitted flabries have achieved in the textile industry in the past decade.

title: LEGUIA, FELDMAN PLAY A PISTON DUO
description: Luis Legura, a member of the cello section of the Boston Symphony Orchestra who made his solo debut here some years ago, gave the first New York performance of Walter Piston's Duo for Cello and Piano (1972) in a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon. The assisting pianist was Jonathan Feldman.

title: Carey Names Brooklynite as Tax Commissioner
description: Governor Carey yesterday named James H. Tully Jr., a 43yearold Manhattan lawyer and an old Brooklyn neighbor and friend of the Carey family, as the state's new Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.

title: Money Back on Auto Loans
description: Just as automobile manufacturers are trying to stimulate sales these days with cash rebates and price reductions, so several banks are trying to attract muchneeded auto loans. In fact, if you go to the right bank and buy the right car, you can save more an $700.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Kids Stuff. Listed above, under New and Noteworthy, is The Clay Pot Boy, a picture book for 6to9yearolds. Other worthy children's books will be noted here in weeks to come. Although paperbacks have been published for 35 years, except for the Scholastic Book Clubs which operate through classroom teachers, juvenile publishers have had little traffic with softcovers, preferring to sell their wares in hardcover, largely (75 to 85 per cent) to schools and libraries. The recent shrinkage of Federal funds available to institutions has made publishers start pondering the paperbacks potentialities. At present the field is dominated by three firms Viking, Dell and Avon. Distribution is cautious 7,000 to 25,000copy print orders for sale through bookstores. Some day some publisher will take a plunge and bring hundreds of thousands of copies to parents through supermarkets and variety stores.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Spiking a Football, the Rule, the Penalty and Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Barbara T. Wieland Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. D. Alexander Wieland of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Thornton Wieland, to John Francis Lehman Jr. of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lehman of Glenside, Pa.

title: Hospital Study in Greenpoint
description: A twoyear struggle by the residents of the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn to save a neighborhood health facility made headway last week when Melvin N. Lechner, City Director of the Budget approved a $200,000 allocation for a reuse study of Greenpoint Hospital.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I am planning alterations in my kitchen and would like to box in the refrigerator with 2x3's to muffle the noise. What material would you recommend using inside this enclosure to absorb the noise?

title: This Week in Sports
description: Notre Dame, which took part in Madison Square Garden's first college doubleheader in 1934, will make its 44th Garden appearance on Thursday, playing St. John's in the second game of a twin bill. In the first game at 7 P.M., Manhattan will oppose Connecticut.

title: Queens Museum in Fight Over Control
description: Less than eight months after he was hired, the job of the executive director of the Queens Museum of Art is apparently in serious jeopardy as a result of a continuing dispute over control of the institution.

title: Nimeiry Seeks CeaseFire
description: CAIRO, Feb. 8 (Reuters)Maj. Gen. Gaafar alNimeiry, President of Sudan, appealed tonight to the Ethiopian Government and Eritrean secessionist forces to call an immediate ceasefire to clear the way for a peaceful settlement, the Middle East News Agency reported from Khartoum.

title: A Cleaner Breed
description: Joe Mason and Vernon Walker were buddies in Nam, where Walker saved Mason's life. But now, back in St. Louis alias Gotham City, the two are on opposite sides of the barricade. Walker, a black man, runs some kind of a terrorist assault on the system. Mason, a white man, has become a policeman, whose beat includes his old comrade's sandbagged headquarters. Fatalities run very high before the two veterans square off in the precinct station for a duel with shotguns. But it's too late to do much for the book's earlier casualties: plot, character, common sense.

title: 1,300 HELD IN PERU AFTER 2DAY RIOT
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 8 (UPI)Twenty Peruvian military judges began hearing the cases today against 1,300 persons arrested for looting, arson, resisting arrest, vandalism and curfew violations during two days of disorders here this week.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Those Old Player Pianos Roll Again
description: Thousands of tunes ago the old time player piano practically disappeared. Banished into barns, basements and tinderboxes, it was largely displaced by its lower cost, more versatile modern counterpartsthe radio and the record player. Approximately 2,500,000 player pianos were built between 1900 and the Depression years, and mostof these, like the blackiron wood stoves of the period, were never expected to be seen again.

title: These Plants, and Hundreds More May Soon Be Extinct
description: One tenth of the native plant species in the continental United States and Alaska may not survive. In a list of about 2,000 species, subspecies and varieties, 100 kinds have become extinct, 761 are endangered and 1,238 are threatened. Of Hawaii's 2,200 higher plants, almost 50 per cent are in danger or already extinct.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: TAP, the Portuguese airline, is expanding and relocating its midtown facilities from 601 Fifth Avenue.

title: Dr. V.F. Mileto Fiance Of Jacqueline H. Smith
description: Jacqueline Holly Smith and Dr. Vincent F. Mileto, who are with the St. Vincent Hospital and Medical Center, plan to be married in October. Their engagement has been announced by Mrs. James H. Smith of Bloomfield, N. J., mother of the bridetobe.

title: Ethnic Consciousness Is Definitely in the Ascendancy
description: A truism of political scientists is that one measure of a nation's humanity is the manner in which its majority population treats the minority groups of the country. The truism tends to reflect advantageously on parliamentary democracies such as Britain and Canada, some minority grievances notwithstanding, and, allowing that there is much room for improvement, on a constitutional democracy such as the United States. Across the broader spectrum of nations, however, the truism becomes wishful dream in many places.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Balletomaniacs And Other Wild Beasts
HONG KONG FEELS WINDS OF CHANGE
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 8Hong Kong, a bastion of 19thcentury laissezfaire capitalism and one of the last remnants of the British Empire, is gradually beginning to feel the stirrings of 20thcentury political ideas.

title: Charles Clifford Bellows 3d Will Marry Dena Kirkbride
description: Mr. and Mrs. David B. Kirkbride of New Canaan, Conn., and Keene Valley, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dena Kirkbride, to Charles Clifford Bellows 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bellows Jr. of Conyngham, Pa., formerly of New Canaan, Conn.

title: If I Was Bitter, I Wouldn't Have Chosen Comedy
Wagner's Gods, Dwarfs and Giants  Together Again After 13 Years
description: When the curtain rises on Das Rheingold at the Metropolitan Opera tomorrow night, New York operagoers will be given the opportunity to experience Wagner's mighty four  opera Ring cycle in its entirety for the first time in 13 years. New productions of the individual works  Das Rheingold, Die Walkre. Siegfried and Gtterdmmerung have, of course, been gradually added to the repertory one by one over the past seven years, but now we can view them in sequence and trace their complex musicaldramatic themes as the composer intended.

title: Some Questions and Answers On Kissinger's Trip to Mideast
Depression Takes Hold On 7th Ave.
description: The normal, noisy frenzy of New York's garment district is subdued these days. The women's fashion industry has fallen into one of its worst slumps in years.

title: It was a good school to integrate
description: When New York City first desegregated its highschool system 10 years ago, James Madison High School in the South Flatbush section of Brooklyn seemed a good place to start. Academically, it was one of the best in the entire city and regularly sent almost 90 per cent of its 1,000 graduates off to college. The faculty had a fair complement of civilrights sympathizers, and the surrounding community, a grid of neat brick and stucco houses set off by tiny but faultlessly trimmed lawns, was dominated by middleclass Jews, largely Democratic and loosely liberal, who presumably would offer little objection to giving blacks and Puerto Ricans a chance at a better education. When the blacks first came, recalls Rae Marcus, now an assistant principal at the school, there was none of the feeling of Why us? The community and faculty and kids were all ready. If integration would work any place, we thought, it would work at Madison.

title: Caso Wage Action Angers Union Head
description: MINEOLAA conflict between Nassau County and 12,500 of its municipal employes is expected to come to a head soon as a result of County Executive Ralph G. Caso's rejection last week of fact  finders recommendations for salary increases that would cost the county $62million in the next two years.

title: DUNLOP IS CHOSEN FOR LABOR OFFICE
Indoor Meet Won Easily By Baruch
RAYMOND CARTIER OF PARISMATCH
Letters
description: Onetrack minds

title: STATE MUST ALTER LAW ON ELECTION
Essex C.Y.O. Lists Annual Spelling Bee
description: CALDWELL  The Essex County C.Y.O. will sponsor its 26th annual Spelling Bee on Feb. 22. It will be held at the St. Aloysius Community Hall on Bloomfield Avenue.

title: U. S. Station Shelled
description: ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 8 (AP) Eritrean rebels shelled a United States communications station near Asmara during an attack today on an Ethiopian military headquarters, informed sources reported.

title: George Beneath A Paper Moon
description: Strong feelings simmer just beneath the surface of the middle class types in this Somerset Maughamish novel. George Hare, a 36yearold travel agent, tries to be a good sport about being married to an incurable malcontent. But his heart belongs to Sally, the 15yearold daughter of his best friend, a doctor named Catto. Not only is George old enough to be Sally's father, he suspects that he really is her fathera fine kettle of fish.

title: New Star Emerges In Track
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8If you thought you had heard it all in track and field with Dr. Delano Meriwether, consider the story of Angel Doyle.

title: Eleanor Emmons Sets March Bridal
description: The engagement of Eleanor Bradlee Emmons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Bradlee Emmons of Lincoln Center, Mass. to Charles Robert Swenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar L. Swenson of Portland, Ore., has been announced by the future bride's parents. The wedding is planned for next. month.

title: Stones Irate At Judges After Jump
Cities Charge New Ford Budget Creates Emergencies for Them
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Two national organizations that represent the interest of cities issued a 90page report to day critticizing the Ford Administration's budget and its impact on urban areas.

title: Legislature Is Being Pressed to Regulate HearingAid Dealers
Samaritan Statute Facing Court Test
description: TRENTON  Under state law, physicians and other medical personnel are immune from malpractice suits if they provide emergency care at the scene of an accident. However, an unusual case has raised the question of whether the immunity extends to a doctor who rushes to the aid of a colleague during an emergency that develops in a hospital.

title: Spain Moves Naval Units Into Enclaves in Morocco
description: MADRID, Feb. 8 (Reuters)Spain moved naval and marine units into two enclaves on Morocco's Mediterranean coast today in an apparent answer to Morocco's assertion of rights to the territories, the Europa Press agency reported here.

title: 102 DONORS SEND FUNDS TO NEEDIEST
description: The brief note from Brooklyn read: Forgive meI didn't forget youI've remembered for 10 yearsjust a bit tardy. A $10 contribution to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund accompanied the message, which was from Mrs. Harold Socolow.

title: Britain Hobbles North Sea Oil
description: LONDONThe pace of exploration for oil in the North Sea has been set back significantly by the British government's program to achieve greater economic control over its rich deepwater fields.

title: Atomic Energy Will Be a Prime Source Of Debate
description: WASHINGTONNo other new technology in the postwar era has promised such grand returns in exchange for such enormous potential risks as nuclear power. Nor, for that matter, has any other technology aroused so long, convoluted and polarized a controversy about its risks and benefits. Such issues as waste heat, with its potential dangers to the ecology of rivers, lakes and bays, and radioactive emissions, with their potential effects on human health, have taken second place over the last decade to even deeper concerns: the economic viability of nuclear generating plants, and the possibility of catastrophic accidents or sabotage, including the theft of potential nuclearbomb fuel.

title: Penn Trounces Cornell For 8th in Row, 83 to 64
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (AP)Ron Haigler scored 33 points in leading the University of Pennsyilvania, the Ivy League's leader, to a 8364 victory over Cornell tonight. It was the eighth victory in a row for Pennsylvania (164).

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Peruvian Awarded $50,000 For Wildlife Conservation
description: Felipe Benavides, a Peruvian conservationist and wildlife expert, has been awarded the World Wildlife Fund's $50,000 J. Paul Getty Wildlife Conservation Prize. The prize was described as the largest of its kind ever given for wildlife conservation.

title: Nixon Bids Staff GoodBy at Party
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8 Former President Richard M. Nixon spent 30 minutes saying goodby to his staff at a party today at his San Clemente estate.

title: The True Life Story of Jody McKeegan
description: For William Gass it was a countryheaded thing to say: that literature is language, that stories and the places and the people in them are merely made of words. While even citified readers may occasionally need this polite reminder, no novelist should forget and let his book compose itself of characters, actions and pictures, those large paragraph and chapter matters. The word's his world's beginning, and if that world is neither new nor strange then all the more must it be cunningly made to keep the reader in.

title: Colgate Six Upsets Boston University
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 8 (AP) A freshman goalie, Kevin Barry, made 52 saves and inspired Colgate to a 53 victory and a major hockey upset over Boston University today.

title: Patricia Wheeler To Be May Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard A. King Jr. of Newtown Square, Pa., have announced the engagement of Mrs. King's daughter, Patricia Nelson Wheeler, to Caleb Fellow Fox 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fox 3d of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia.

title: Pieces And Parts
description: When I was a boy there was an infuriatingly bright girl in our school who knew more about chemistry, optics, physics, and the other sciences related to photography than those of us who envied her even dreamed existed. She spent hours in her own darkroom developing, printing, enlarging, experimenting. Nevertheless, she took the dumbest pictures imaginable.

title: Brookdale Achieves a Record Enrollment
description: LINCROFTTotal enrollment at Brookdale Community College has surpassed the 7,000 mark for the first time in the county college's sevenyear history. The total number of students taking credit courses in the term 1974 fall totaled 7,007, an increase of 542 over 1973.

title: Keno Duke Jazz Contemporaries In a Strong but Uneven Program
description: Sustained rhythmic momentum was never a problem for Keno Duke's jazz quintet, Contemporaries, throughout its concert Friday evening at Cami Hall. But the group's repertory was divided between selections that were brimming with imagination, color and solo excitement and a few that were, in contrast, surprisingly routine and unimaginative.

title: Pamela Krusen, William Boyd 2d Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Andrew Krusen of Tampa, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Andrea Krusen, to William Young Boyd 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Boyd, of Panama City.

title: Old Ways Win at Ailing Belfast Shipyard
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland Harland & Wolff's, the Belfast shipyard that built the Titanic, is in trouble again. Since the British Government stepped in to save the company in 1966, it has swallowed a record $163.2million of taxpayers money without producing a penny's profit, and now it needs at least an additional $79million to stay in business.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
15Seat Legislature Backed by D'Amato
description: MlNEOLAAlfonse D'Amato, who is already running for chairman of the proposed Nassau County legislaturea proposal that is expected to go to the county's voters in late May or Junesaid last week that he favored a 15member legislature with members elected to fouryear terms.

title: Free Newspapers Sue to Void Laws That Them From Getting Legal Ads
description: MORRISTOWN  Is a newspaper that is delivered free to every home in a community as legitimate a publication as a paid circulation newspaper that goes to a smaller number of subscribers?

title: Rudolph J. Heinemann, 73, Dies; Was an International Art Dealer
description: Dr. Rudolph J. Heinemann, an international art dealer who worked behind the scenes in the sale of great paintings of the masters, died Friday in Lugano, Switzerland. He was 73 years old and lived at 907 Fifth Avenue.

title: U.S. Company Will Train Saudi Troops to Guard Oil
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8  Several hundred former members of the United States Special Forces and other Vietnam war veterans are being recruited by a private American contractor to train Saudi Arabian troops to protect oilfields.

title: A GunsorButter Decision for Congress
description: WASHINGTONThe inflation of the last two years has achieved what the Pentagon's Congressional critics never could do: It has reduced the nation's defense program. But the budget proposed by President Ford last week does far more than merely make up for the erosion caused by inflation. It calls on Congress to approve the first step toward a gradually increasing investment in the defense establishment over the next five years.

title: GHANA'S MILITARY GAINING STRENGTH
description: ACCRA, GhanaIn the three years since a group of military men took over the Government on Jan. 13, 1972, the soldiers. as Ghanaians call their rulers, have scored some solid gains and at the same time, achieved a perhaps intangible success that is of greater value.

title: Onassis a Bit Better, Paris Hospital Reports
description: PARIS, Feb. 8 (UPI)The medical condition of Aristotle Onassis improved somewhat today, a spokeswoman at the American Hospital said.

title: STATE MUST ALTER LAW ON ELECTION
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn has ruled that two sections of the election law dealing with the nomination of statewide candidates are unconstitutional and has directed the State Legiislature to amend the law.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Spiraling costs and inadequate rates may be the most widely publicized problems, but they are not the only problems challenging the profitability and future viability of the electric utility industry in the United States. The obsolete, fragmented structure of the industry is also a major contributing factor.

title: New Hughes Mystery: A Theft of Secret Papers and Ransom Demand Refused
Kissinger And the Campaign
Miss Saltonstall Wed to Executive
description: Elizabeth Zopfi Saltonstall a realtor with Gower & Co. in Providence, R. I., was married there yesterday afternoon to Malcolm G. Chace 3d, treasurer of the Wanskuck Company, a Providence conglomerate. The Rev. James Gambrill, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Chace Jr. of North Palm Beach, Fla., and Providence.

title: FORD ASSENT SEEN FOR PANAM AID
description: Backers of a proposer agreement for Iran to save Pan American World Airways from financial collapse appear confident that President Ford will give hs approval this week, but his decision could be delayed by his travel plans and the vigorous opposition of a diversified movement whose strength is stil Ito be determined.

title: What the New Yachts Look Like
description: Among the 26 new yachts competing in the Southern Ocean Racing Conference, Kialoa III at 79 feet is the largest and Merry Ann at 33 feet the smallest. New boats make up almost a third of the S.O.R.C. fleet of 83. Costs, which include a full complement of sails and electronic instrumentation, run about $4,000 for each foot of waterline length, a ratio that has quadrupled in the last two decades because of technical additions and inflation. Here is a brief look at the new yachts:

title: New Twain Integration Plan
description: Officials In Brooklyn's Community School District 21 are hoping to change the fortunes of a controversial Coney Island school by borrowing a leaf from Mark Twain's The Adventures of Tom Sawyer. Appropriately, the school involved is the Mark Twain Junior High School.

title: judging Program at Westminster Show
Sometimes Nothing Is Best
description: Ron Nessen was not really in the wrong but he was more than a little onesided the other day when he attacked the Democratic Congress for doing nothing. That is a phrase the Democrats will no doubt hear often, since Mr. Nessen's remarks obviously reflect the basic White House political strategy.

title: 4TH DEPUTY MAYOR IS URGED FOR CITY
description: A panel of management specialists said yesterday that the city's Criminal Justice Coordinating Council had not been fulfilling its role and recommended that Mayor Beame appoint a fourth Deputy Mayor to deal with criminal justice matters.

title: Letters: The Case of The Missing President
description: To the Editor:

title: F. W. Sackett Fiance Of Cynthia Geoghegan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Xavier Geoghegan of Coconut Grove, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Kane Geoghegan, to Specialist 4 Frederick William Sackett of the Army Medical Corps. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Sackett of South Deerfield, Mass.

title: EUROPEANS SEEK WARPLANE SALES
description: The major Swedish and French warplane makers are offering four Governments in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization financial inducements in an effort to head off the purchase by these countries of United States fighter aircraft.

title: Queens Forum Calls Aftercare Key to Rehabilitation of ExMental Patients
description: Four Queens legislators and a group of their constituens have expressed general agreement that the state policy of rehabilitating former mental patients within the community can be made to work with a properly planned and staffed program of aftercare  if a thorough effort is made to educate the public to all the facts involved.

title: Many Chs. Try To Be Top Ch. At Westminster Next Two Days
description: Westminster, the show of shows, opens a twoday run at Madison Square Garden tomorrow, with 3,035 dogs representing 129 breeds and varieties. They came from 49 statesNorth Dakota is the lone exceptionand the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Canada and Bermuda.

title: Opera: Miss Price in Met's Manon
description: Leontyne Price's admirers have always felt that she has never sung at the Metropolitan Opera as much as she should have. A voice as glorious as hers deserved to be heard more often. There have been, of course, many landmarks in her career with the company: the early Adas, the Donna Annas in Don Giovanni, the Leonoras in II Trovatore, the CioCioSans in Madama Butterfly, to name some.

title: Police Phone Reassures Haworth Aged
description: HAWORTHOne day last summer, a retired school teacher fell in her home, breaking her ankle and extensively bruising herself. Unable to move, and without family or friends, the woman suffered on the floor, hoping that someone would find her.

title: June Bridal Set By Miss Dodds
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dennis M. Dodds of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jerrilynn Dodds, to Eric Gustav Carlson of Swarthmore, Pa., son of Prof. and Mrs. Gustav G. Carlson of Cincinnati.

title: Dave Anderson
Pamela Piszel Bride of Shelley Braun
description: Pamela Piszel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Piszel of Rutherford, N. J., was married here last evening to Shelley R. Braun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Braun of Upper Brookville, L. I. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: Card of Thanks
description: HOSKINSThe famly of the late John Richard gretefully acknowiedges the large number of cares, letters and other warm expressions of sympathy received from their friends and associates in their recent bereavement.

title: Fight on Child Abuse Pressed
description: TRENTONIn a move designed to combat child abuse and neglect, reportedly increasing at a phenomenal rate, the state will implement two federally funded programs costing $1.9million.

title: IRAQI AIDE REPORTS A MAJOR OIL STRIKE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 8 (AP)An Iraqi official says Baghdad floats on a lake of oil that will make Iraq's reserves the second largest in the world, the Beirut newspaper Al Anwar said today.

title: Criminals At Large
description: For several years now, Joe L. Hensley has been corning out with crime novels involving lawyer in middle America. It has been a very good series, and SONG OF CORPUS JURIS (Doubleday, $4.95), the latest, maintains the high standard. Part of this is due to the authenticity of the legal scenesHensley at one time was an assistant district attorney. But these legal scenes have nothing to do with Perry Mason courtroom dramas. Indeed, none of the Hensley books has been a formula epic climaxed by witness  stand shenanigans. Rather, it is the spirit of the legal system that permeates Hensley's books.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ON the same day last week that the Canadian Federal Government and two provinces agreed to inject a massive investment into a joint venture with private industry to develop a major new source of energy, the word was received in this country that a private utility was again postponing a costly new plant for converting Western nonpolluting coal into gas because it was too expensive under present conditions.

title: Miss Neale Fiancee Of Jeffrey Brodlieb
description: The engagement of Claudia Neale to Jeffrey Brodlieb has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Neale of Mount Kisco, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son or Mr. and Mrs. Albert Brodlieb of Hewlett Neck. L.I.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in this section last Sunday contained an eror in transmission regarding projected connections to New York from a proposed restoration of commuter service on the West Shore line of the Penn Central Railroad. The proposed connections are as follows: At Weehawken, by bus to the Port Authority Terminal in midtown Manhattan; at the ErieLackawanna station in Hoboken, proposed terminus of the West Shore line, by PATH trains to Lower Manhattan.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: Want to tell the President of the United States what the country really needs? Or what's wrong with his economic program?

title: Harms: Bergen Impresario
description: ENGLEWOOD  Although John Harms is reluctant to adopt the sobriquet of the Sol Hurok of Bergen County, he is quick to point out that he does more work in bringing culture to Bergen County than any two people and without clerical assistance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A Bouquet or Two For Times Square

title: Marjorie Curtis Pile Is Bride Of Robert Perry Mountain Jr.
ARCHITECTURE VIEW
Moscow Wants to Charge More for Oil
description: BELGRADEThe cumbersome economic machinery linking members of the Soviet European bloc has begun to creak, as pressure from the economic crisis in the outer world pushes past the protective MarxistLeninist shield.

title: In Summary
description: When the House and Senate begin their separate examinations of all the Government's intelligence agencies, probably within the next two months, they may have to spend more time than they may have expected on the activities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. There is now a growing dossier of reports of possible misuse of the F.B.I. as well as of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Fire in Church Spreads
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass., Feb. 8 (UPI)A fire that started in an abandoned church spread to a row of twostory houses early today. Five or six homes caught on fire and about 50 persons were driven to the street.

title: Brendan Fay, Actor, Dies While Rehearsing a Play
description: Brendan Fay, a stage actor, died Friday evening, apparently of a heart attack, while rehearsing an Off Broadway play, God of Vengeance, at the Spencer Memorial Church in Brooklyn. He was 54 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Of Charmed Quarks
description: Those superlitists of nuclear science, the particle physicists, are agog over ideas that were once scorned as fairy talesfor example, the notion that charmed quarks and charmed antiquarks may collide to form a Wholly new class of nuclear particles.

title: After a Decade, Jackson 5 Have Gone Through Some Changes
Members of Orange Y Old and Young, Play and Act Before the Camera
description: ORANGE Beautiful, beautiful, the director said. Now let's try it again.

title: Virginia Hourigan of Candide Presents 4Woodwind Recital
description: It is not uncommon for jazz, pop or studio musicians to be proficient on several instruments, but a classical recital on four different woodwinds is certainly a novelty. This happened on Friday night when Virginia Hourigan, who doubles on clarinet and bassoon in the Candide orchestra on Broadway, brought both of those, as well as oboe and flute to the Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Redmen Conquer Fordham
STAMPS
Harvard Economics Teaching Criticized
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 5The Harvard University economics department, long regarded as the august source of strength and direction for much of modern economics, has come under attack. Both from without and from within, charges are flying at the department, which a generation ago brought the activist economic policy of Lord Keynes to this country and more than a decade ago helped President Kennedy try to forge his New Frontier.

title: Open Diplomacy, Dry Water
description: PARISSecretary Kissinger's forthcoming Middle East shuttle in search of a glimmer of ArabIsraeli peace is the most urgent and most difficult of his negotiating career. Threats of war resounding through the Palestine area are, despite diplomatic tranquilizers, fundamentally more ominous and more heavily supported by masses of modern armament than ever before.

title: City's First Flea Market for Used Automobiles Opens
description: His beefy frame stuffed behind the wheel of a 1969 Renault, Charlie Falzon chugged into the E.C.I. parking garage at 57 Allen Street shortly before 11 A.M. yesterday. Within minutes, the dented, dirtstreaked car was on display with a $100 price tag that quickly attracted potential buyers.

title: Coast Ridgeback Wins in Specialty
Brazil Seeks to Expand or Revive Old Gold Mines
description: NOVA LIMA, Brazil This drowsy old town with faded pastel houses in the green hills south of Belo Horizonte is dreaming of a new gold rush.

title: Editors Choice
description: Fiction

title: TAX AID REPORTED FOR 72 CAMPAIGNS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) An amendment to a bill passed in December in the last few days of the 93d congress, enabled the Presidential campaign committees of Richard M. Nixon and Senator George McGovern to escape huge tax debts, The Washington Post reported in its Sunday editions.

title: WILLIAM A. HEGARTY
description: William A. Hegarty, who retired in 1959 as a judge of the New Jersey Superior Court, died Thursday at his home in Morristown, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: SixGoal Blitz in 2d Session Seals Verdict
Weather Reports and Forecast
The South the South sees
description: Hubert Shuptrine, a painter, and James Dickey, the Georgiaborn poet, traveled through the South together and the result is an unusual book combining the talents of both artists with over one hundred water colors and drawings by Shuptrine and an accompanying text by Dickey.

title: Taxpayers Helping Set Property Values
description: A West Coast county has begun an innovative program under which property owners help assess their land and buildings.

title: Mr. Nixon Was Not the First to Use the Agency: Johnson Liked Its Reports
description: WASHINGTONTo many Americans, one of the most disturbing aspects of the impeachment proceedings against President Nixon was the disclosure of Mr. Nixon's misuse of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for his personal aims and political ambitions. The evidence is of a program of wiretaps and other abuses carried out with the far from reluctant cooperation of the bureau's late director, J. Edgar Hoover.

title: What's Doing in THE VIRGINIA HUNT COUNTRY
With More Peace Talks at Hand, It Is a Question of Whom to Trust
description: JERUSALEMFor the third time since the October, 1973, war, Israelis are preparing for a new round of negotiations with their Arab adversariesnegotiations that inevitably result in Israeli troop withdrawals from occupied Arab territory that Israel regards as both her protection and her bargaining chips. It is a process that gets no easier with practice.

title: Energy, the Economy: Setting Priorities
description: WASHINGTONToday, a year after the oil embargo jolted our selfconfidence and complacency, the new realities of energy seem finally to have penetrated our national consciousness.

title: Financing By Women, For Them
Miss Rosen Engaged To Rod Allen Raskin
description: Phyllis Abby Rosen, administrative assistant for Execuspace, a service for executives visiting New York on business, plans to be married next month to Rod Allen Raskin, a partner and board chairman of the R. D. Allen Realty Corporation here.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals trod the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly. one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: No An Elitist View
description: By rejecting a preference for high culture, Mr. Gans tries to convince us that bad things are as good as good things, since both satisfy tastes which differ only owing to basic differences in American society. Every culture, he intones, has its own esthetic standards, its preferred art, literature, music (which is true by definition) and all cultures must be judged as being of equal worth, until any culture is proven to be more harmful than another (which is not). Therefore, museums should exhibit the kinds of popular art enjoyed by Middle Americans, and everybody should be equally represented on television programs. Mr. Gans seems to agree with Senator Hruska, who complained that mediocrity was undemocratically underrepresented on the Supreme Court. (I hadn't heard that it is underrepresented on television, but defer to experts.)

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Jan. 19 reported incorrectly that the New Jersey Commissioner of Insurance had proposed that all insurance companies writing liability insurance in the state be required to form a pool to provide malpractice insurance. The proposal would actually involve only those companies already writing malpractice policies.

title: Visiting The Hague? what a Strange Idea
description: YOU'RE going on to The Hague? What a strange idea! the man from Amsterdam said. The biggest village of Holland, sophisated Amsterdamers call it, adding: Rottercam is where you work. Amsterdam is where you have fun, The Hague is  where you reside.

title: Design: An art in packaging
description: The exhibit of Japanese packaging which opened Friday at Japan House Gallery gives Westerners a rare view of an ancient, but continuing, art. Each of the 300 packages in the show (called Tsutsumu, The Art of the Japanese Package) was purchased in 1974 in Japan, where an object's wrapping can be as important as the object itself.

title: Plan On Perennial Vegetables
description: Perennial vegetables, though few in number, are a mainstay of my garden. One or another can be picked fresh almost year round, even in cold weather.

title: Body of Slain Girl Is Found at a Dump By Kennedy Airport
description: The body of an 18yearold Queens girl who had been stabbed to death was found in a garbage dump yesterday at Springfield Lane, north of Rockaway Boulevard near Kennedy International Airport.

title: Yes A Pluralist View
description: America's public policy toward the arts is largely elitist. It is grounded in the theory that high culture is desirable, that popular culture should melt away and public funds should be spent on raising people's tastes.

title: Garden Game Will Test Appeal Of Women's Basketball Teams
description: Sitting in Madison Square Garden one evening last week, Cathy Rush, the coach of the lmmaculata College women's basketball team, seemed nervous and worried.

title: In Belize With Palm and Pothole
description: LAST winter we were forced by circumstance to take a vacation. The circumstance: Our house had burned down, leaving us shivering in a bleak Catskill dawn, divested of all worldly possessions save ourselves and child, a middleaged hound and two used typewriters. We needed to go somewhere fast, somewhere that was warm, cheap, Englishspeaking, accessible to an ancient Saab and amenable to dogs.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Snurb and London Company Score at Hialeah
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Feb. 8Four years ago Gene St. Leon won the Eclipse award as America's best apprentice rider. Since then he has had only modest success, and with Hialeah reaching its midpoint today, he had not won a race at the meeting.

title: North Korea Aiding Tanzania
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb, 8 (Agence FrancePresse) North Korea will send 10 irrigation experts to help Tanzania cultivate irrigated rice at Wann Basin south of Dar es Salaam, according to an agreement signed here.

title: Lithography Exhibited at Rutgers
GOVERNOR WEIGHS A LIMIT ON M.T.A
Emile Francis Story: New Ways for Old Cat
description: In the New York fishbowl, one major league coach is the object of more analysis, secondguessing and vilification than any other: Emile Percy Francis nicknamed the Cat.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: Los ANGELES. AT the Music Center here, the Ahmanson Theater's production of Macbeth, with Charlton Heston and Vanessa Redgrave, is the current hotticket attraction despite unfavorable reviews. The real theatrical excitement, however, is next door at the smaller Mark Taper Forum, where a daring new production of S. Ansky's The Dybbuk, adapted and directed by John Hirsch, is being given its United States premiere.

title: The United States Stake in Southeast Asia
description: Our country is at a crossroads of history. The United States has promised small nations that it would stand by them. And, based on our repeated pledges, millions of people have committed their livesand those of their childrento the struggle. To turn away from them now would not be worthy of our great nation.

title: A's Lead In Use of Arbiter
description: The Oakland A's, baseball champions on the field for the past three seasons, now are campaigning to be winners off the field  in salary arbitration  for the second straight year.

title: To Keep Wood Floors Beautiful
description: Beautiful hardwood floors are an asset to any home and will normally last as long as the house itselfif properly protected with a good finish and then given reasonable care and maintenance.

title: GEN. FRANCIS KERR OF V.A., 85, IS DEAD
Book Ends
description: Woman. What do women wantto read, that is? Not being in the book business, Freud never asked that question, but Gloria Norris, editor of the Woman Today Book Club. does so daily as she eyes the publishers offerings for titles that will appeal to her 50,000 or so female members. Woman Today, one of several Macmillan book clubs, was launched a year ago this month under Miss Norris's tutelage (to put to rest any possible charges of tokenism, she also is in charge of Macmillan's law and architecture book clubs, which have a largely male component).

title: Gangs Are Minister's Flock
description: Last summer, 50 members of the Satan division of the Tomahawks, one of Brooklyn's most notorious street gangs, pledged to give up a life of violence and criminal behavior and vowed to devote themselves to efforts that would make their community, the East New York Section, a better and safer place in which to live.

title: Deceiving Females Kill Male Fireflies
description: Some female fireflies are able to mimic the illuminated mating signals of other species of fireflies, luring wouldbe suitors into what quickly becomes a deadly embrace, a Florida biologist has found.

title: Daughter to the Pages
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Albert L. Page of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, Jan. 20 in the Kaiser Foundation Hospital in Cleveland. Mrs. Page is the former Jane Meenes. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Meenes of New York.

title: Flushing Town Hall Getting a New Role
description: The landmark Flushing Town Hall, vacant since 1962, will soon be opened as a dinner theater.

title: A Dissident Joins Sholokhov Dispute
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8As Soviet literary officials prepare to lavish more praise on Mikhail Sholokhov this year, the controversy over whether he is the original author of And Quiet Flows the Don has been agitated again by a detailed analysis of the epic novel.

title: Artist Will Direct Jamaica Arts Unit
description: Paul Waters, former director of the Department of Community Affairs at the Newark Museum, has been appointed director of the Jamaica Arts Center at The Register in Queens.

title: Dunlop Expresses Confidence
description: BELMONT, Mass., Feb. 8 (UPI)John T. Dunlop, President Ford's newly appointed Secretary of Labor, said today that he believed the United States can solve its economic woes, but that it would take time to do so.

title: Face in the Mirror
description: Throughout most of history, men have acted as if life were cheap. In the ancient era, there were brief, sunlit interludes in Athens and in Rome when life was highly valued but even then only in the governing classes. In most Western history, men have routinely squandered livestheir own and those of othersin the waste of war, they have fatalistically accepted high death rates from disease and accident, and have casually engaged in cruel and lifeendangering customs.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A: WOODPECKER HOLES [Jan. 19]

title: MISS MANCHESTER BUILDS OWN STYLE
description: It is about two years since Melissa Manchester came from behind Bette Midler, from backup singer to center stage, and in those days there were definite echoes of that association in Miss Manchester's work. This is not so now judging from her Friday night appearance at the Bottom Line all has been eradicated and she also seems (like Barry Manilow who also came from the Midler industry to solo) to have her own audience, her own style.

title: Bicentennial Center to Open At Los Angeles Site in 76
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)Pacific 21, a bicentennial exhibition and conference center in Los Angeles, will open June 19, 1976, as a major West Coast focal point for the nation's 200th birthday celebration, sponsors have announced.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1975

title: Shelter Island Mood:Wary
description: SHELTER ISLANDIt was a cold, bright day and the waters off Cuckles Harbor were calm as Evans K. Griffing prepared to board his motorboat for a morning of scallop harvesting, which is a pastime with him.

title: Notes: TollFree Travel Shopping
Commission Calls Hearing on Lack of TV Coverage of State
description: TRENTONA special legislative commission investigating television coverage of the state is scheduled to hold its first public hearing next month, with the initial witness to be a representative of the New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting.

title: Red Smith
description: Question: What do the following have in commonBillie Jean King, Muhammad Ali, Tom Seaver, Lee Trevino, Bobby Orr, Hank Aaron, John Havlicek, O. J. Simpson, Janet Lynn, Jimmy Connors? Yes, they all earn their living with their muscles, but that is only part of the answer. The rest is that all are active members of Athletes vs. MS, which is not an organization of jocks against Gloria Steinem. It is national campaign to defeat the mysterious maker of cripples, multiple sclerosis.

title: LETTERS
description: NOW Challenges George Gilder On Sex Bias Among Employers

title: Valentine's Day: A Time for Candy
description: SOUTH ORANGECandy is dandy, the late Ogden Nash once quipped. And as Valentine's Day draws near, one candy man, Herman Gruning, is getting set for this week's buying onslaught at all of his stores. The main one is here, at the front end of his large candy and ice cream plant at 59 South Orange Avenue.

title: Environmental Suits
description: Michigan's Supreme Court has unanimously upheld a concept that one would logicallybut erroneouslysuppose was everywhere taken for granted. This concept is that citizens have a legal right to bring suit to block projects that they have good reason to believe will harm the environment. If an act could be stopped because it financially damages a single individual, such an act should not be shielded from legal action just because it hurts the public interest as a whole.

title: Nina Laughlin Fiancee Of John T. Bottomley
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Mellon Laughlin of New York and East Hampton, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nina Laughlin of Boston, to John Taylor Bottomley, son of Dr. and Mrs. George T. Bottomley of Little Boars Head, North Hampton, N. H. A May wedding is planned.

title: Conquer Capitals
Shop Talk
description: HACKETTSTOWN  One way to cope with rising prices is to buy directly from manufacturers and wholesalers through their outlet stores. There are two outlets here.

title: America at Sea
description: The request of a bipartisan group of 22 Senators that Secretary of State Kissinger be placed in personal charge of United States negotiations at the resumed Law of the Sea Conference in Geneva next month merits urgent attention at the White House.

title: U.S. May Take On Farm Inspections
News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1975

title: Recession? Bah! A Tract Builder Builds On
description: MEDFORD, L.I.At a time when other builders have retrenched, Sid Farber is confidently embarked on his most ambitious project, a 400acre development with a thousand homes.

title: Salyut Makes 700 Orbits
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8 (UPI)The Salyut 4 orbital laboratory today completed 700 revolutions of the earth, 430 of them with a crew of two aboard, the Tass press agency said.

title: Dunlop for Cabinet Job
description: President Ford has an nounced that he will name John T. Dunlop, a Harvard economist, to succeed Peter J. Brennan as Secretary of Labor. Details, page 39.

title: Victoria Elizabeth Manes Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Manes of CrotononHudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Elizabeth Manes, to William Elton Larzelere Ir., son of Mr. and Mrs. Larzelere of Seneca Falls, N.Y.

title: THAILAND THRIVING IN A TROUBLED ASIA
Gillian Joy Carter Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Carter of Milnertown, Capetown, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gillian Joy Carter, to Charles Edward Stewart 3d of Pawling, N.Y., son of United States District Judge Charles E. Stewart Jr. of the Southern District of New York, and Mrs. Stewart of ArdsleyonHudson, N.Y., and Pawling.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Ford's Plan: Spur to Productivity or Prelude to a Deeper Crisis?

title: Tuning down with TM
description: It was a Saturday morning, and I was going to get my mantra. Does this handkerchief look absolutely fresh and like it's never been used before? I asked, hurrying into the kitchen where my 15yearold daughter, Susie, sat drinking coffee with her best friend. Patty. I don't know, said Susie with a shrug, looking at the starched white square. I already had my fruittwo big apples and a tangerinewrapped in Saranwrap and set aside. The only other thing that I needed was a bunch of fresh flowerssix, to be exact. I hastened out into the back garden to retrieve six of the last of the autumn's hardy chrysanthemums, which had all been laid flat by a violent rainstorm the night before. I brought the bouquet into the kitchen, picked off the brown petals of the flowers and wrapped the stems in foil. What is your mother doing? my daughter's friend asked.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Gardeners who are eager to find something to do outdoors might take pruning shears in hand and go to work on a few trees and shrubs. But be careful what plants are cut. Some may be deprived of their bloom if whittled down too much at this time of year.

title: South Korea Stressing Nuclear Energy
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 1 Driven by the high cost of oil, South Korea is moving as fast as possible into nuclear energy to diversify its sources of electricity.

title: Winner of 3 Oscars to Discuss Movie Music
description: On the wall hangs a platinum record marking the sale of one million copies of the theme Mint The Sting. On a table stands the record jacket for the soundtrack of The Way We Were. And on the couch sits Marvin Hamlisch, the 1969 alumnus of Queens College who excited the entertainment world last year by winning three Academy Awards for his musical contributions to these two movies.

title: Stage: Inge's Bus Stop
description: Twenty years after its Broadway opening, William Inge's Bus Stop remains an admirable comedy, full of unforced humor and sympathetic insights and so deftly crafted that it must be esteemed not only for its capacity for diverting an audience but also for the pleasures it holds before its cast.

title: Night Ski Carnival Keeps Officials in Dark
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 8 Some new life was pumped into Dartmouth College's winter carnival last night. The booster shot was administered with the aid of 108 wellspaced 100watt spotlights strung through the woods of the local Oak Hill region. The lighted terrain, provoding the backdrop for the carnival's crosscountry race, attracted the largest crowd in the history of that event. But it also attracted gremlins, who did their meanest work where It counted mostat the final checkpoint.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATING 2 A.T.&T CONCERNS
CAMERA VIEW
description: Why do camera repairs take so long? And why do they cost so much? There are many reasons: Modern cameras are more complex than they used to be with many miniaturized components; training of repair technicians has not kept up with the demand; the camera may have to be sent away to a specialized facility; parts may be unavailable and there may be a long, delay in waiting for their arrival from overseas;

title: Valentine in (Costly) Chocolate
description: Chocolate lovers are running into doublebarreled price increases as they shop for Valentine's Day this year some 20 per cent at one New York candy store. A onepound box of assorted chocolates costs $3.95, up from $3.25 a year ago; a pound of pure Swiss milk chocolate sells for $3.50, up from $2.95.

title: Blood Red, Sister Rose
description: We all know the story, the big scenes: the Voices, the Dauphin's court, Orleans, Rheims, Rouen, the pyreIt would seem. foolhardy to attempt to revive these worn tales again. Yet Australian novelist Thomas Keneally has done it and carried it off with aplomb. Saint Joan lives again, robustly, in a way we have not known her before.

title: Alan Rosenberg to Marry Wendy Cutler
description: Mrs. Joseph Cutler of New Rochelle, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Wendy Patricia Cutler, to Alan David Rosenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Rosenberg of Hallandale, Fla.

title: Trade Paperbacks
description: Trade paperbacks are sold, for the most port. in bookstores. This analysis Is based on reports from chains With more than 550 stores across the United States.

title: N.C.A.A. Declares Mosley Ineligible
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 8The National Collegiate Athletic Association has ruled that Seton Hall's basketball star, Glenn Mosley, is ineligible to play for 21 games, the university's president said today.

title: Essex Lists Parks Program
description: NEWARK  The Essex County Park Commission has begun a $1million program to renovate facilities at 16 of its parks and other recreation areas.

title: Joan Garrity, Gregory Flynn Wed in Suburb
description: Joan Mary Garrity, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lawrence Garrity of Rye, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Gregory Charles Flynn, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Flynn 3d of Weston, Mass.

title: Music in Review
description: Musicians who make debuts in this city and who are careerist about it usually fall into predictable patterns. They book a prestigious midtown hall (Alice Tully Hall is the most prestigious at the moment), they generate some publicity and they present a program that will show off their artistry in a range of repertory.

title: Braves Smith Is Considering A Summer Job With N.A.S.L.
description: Randy Smith, a starter for the Buffalo Braves of the National Basketball Association, said last Friday that he had been seriously considering playing pro soccer in the offseason.

title: London Conference To Discuss System Of Grain Reserves
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs, will head the United States delegation to a meeting of major grainproducing and trading nations in London Monday and Tuesday to discuss the creation of a effective worldwide system of grain reserves, the State Department announced today.

title: $5,866 Returned In Double Exacta
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation's fourth doubleexacta offering of the winter produced a payoff of $5,866.50 for $3 yesterday.

title: Gender Gap
description: You will have noticed in the Letters column (page 28) that all three authors were unhappy with Larry McMurtry's recent review of books on male behavior. So were a number of readers. I find the fuss inordinate. As it happens, I read two of the books carefully. Herewith another report:

title: Colgate's Plans Irk Paulus Hook
description: JERSEY CITYPlans by the ColgatePalmolive Company to fence in its industrial plant in the Paulus Hook area have stirred a controversy that is pitting homeowners against the company.

title: In the Adfroodocks With Stag and Bun
description: THE Adirondack Park of northern New York is an incredible hodgepodge of true wilderness and typical American vacationland. Within its delineating blue line on state maps it contains special wilderness areas of mountain peaks, wild rivers, expansive forests and shimmering lakes contrasting with supercharged resorts and other tourist allures. Nestled intermittently among the wilderness and the plastic is the Adirondacks of quiet villages, good people and rustic taverns.

title: A Homemade World
description: It's always an unexpected pleasure to find serious literary criticism written as if the English language still mattered, as Hugh Kenner's writing insists that it does. In book after bookmy own favorites are The Stoic Comedians and his studies of Eliot, Beckett and Buckminster Fullerstrong and supple thought finds its proper medium in a style of uncommon wit and pungency, writing whose powers of intellectual entertainment brazenly violate the first law of academic criticism: Be Thou Dull.

title: FORD OFFERS LIMIT ON AID TO INDOCHINA
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (UPI) President Ford says he is prepared to stop largescale military and financial aid to South Vietnam within three years if Congress agrees to appropriate sufficient funds during that time.

title: Geoffrey Frankel to Wed Patricia Sachs
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Sachs Jr. of Hanover, N. H., and Keane Valley, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Sachs, to Geoffrey Frankel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Frankel of Briarcliff Manor, N. Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: Federal SpendingToo Little?
The Plight of India's Women
description: NEW DELHINearly half the women in India today eat their meals after their husbands, sons and fathersa custom that leads to higher malnutrition anong the women in poor families.

title: BRONX MAN IS KILLED BY A POLICE OFFICER
ART VIEW
description: In place of a hermeneutics, Susan Sontag wrote at the close of her famous essay Against Interpretation, in 1964, we need an erotics of art. It was this essay, with its stunning declaration of independence from the traditional obligations of criticism, that gave the title to Miss Sontag's first volume of essays, published in 1966, and it was this sentimentfor it was clearly a sentiment even more than an ideathat helped to make Against Interpretation one of the most widely read and widely influential works of criticism in the 1960's. Hermeneutics, the attempt to analyze or interpret works of art for their hidden meanings, was resoundingly rejected in favor of an erotics that, though never defined, invoked a promise of untroubled esthetic delight: untroubled precisely because it would no longer be burdened by intrusions of moral discrimination.

title: GEORGE E. BRUNNER, CAMDEN EXMAYOR
description: George E. Brunner, who was Mayor of Camden, N.J. from 1936 to 1959. died yesterday at his home in Haddon Township, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: Lancers Winners Over Cosmos, 87
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 8 (AP) Frank Odio's second goal with seven seconds remaining propelled the Rochester Lancers to an 87 victory tonight over the New York Cosmos in a North American Soccer League regional indoor tournament.

description: The chess diagram on Page 37 of Section 2 is inaccurate. A black knight should be shown at QN5.

title: Fashion
description: The Tshirt may have started as a lowly undershirt, but it achieved fashion status when blue jeans became a way of life for young and notsoyoung, rich and notsorich. Tshirts were tiedyed, printed with anything from rosebuds to zodiac symbols, handpainted and signed by artists, festooned with rhinestones and appliqud with all manner of patches. Then last summer, with the acceptance of the flowered big skirt, Tshirts went back to basics in pretty colors. This year's skirts, in solids or understated stripes and plaids, call for Tshirts with a bit of detailing: buttons or collars or geometric patterns.

title: Dual Purpose Funds: Down but Not Out
description: During the bull market of the late nineteensixties, half a dozen investment companies sprang up offering investors a choice between two types of shares.

title: A Frightening Momentum
description: The nation is in its worst economic crisis since World War II, thrust there by an enormous increase in the number of. Americans who have no jobs, and the potential for still greater dislocation is being magnified by the vacillation and futility that have characterized the search for solutions.

title: 64% in Harris Poll Still Say Nixon's Pardon Was Wrong
description: Sixtyfour per cent of Americans surveyed for a Harris pail still believe that President Ford was wrong in pardoning his predecessor, Richard M. Nixon, according to the pollster.

title: Deletions in Book on C.I.A. Upheld by Appeals Court
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit has ruled that the Central Intelligence Agency has a right to suppress information in a hook about the agency's secret activities.

title: Douglas Soe Lin Marries Mydali, N.Y. U. Student
description: Mydali, daughter of U Kin Oung and Mya Mya Kin of West New York, N. 3., was married here yesterday morning to Douglas Soe Lin, son of U San Lin and Daw Soe Soe of Bethesda, Md. The Burmese Buddhist ceremony took place, at the Cosmopolitan Club.

title: Insurance Johnny Can Read
description: The prose style of the typical insurance policy, long criticized as perhaps the ultimate in legal mumbojumbo, may become less difficult for policyholders to penetrate.

title: Business Index Falls
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity fell to 381.3 from 388.2 a week earlier. A year ago it was 394.4.

title: Carneen Fischer, R. T. Jackson Wed
description: Carneen Fischer, a language consultant in the Middletown, Conn, school system, was married last evening to Roger T. Jackson, operations manager of Worth's of Waterbury, a Connecticut women's wear chain store. Rabbi Arnold Miller performed the ceremony in mole Israel in Waterbury. He was assisted by Rabbi Theodore Levy of Syracuse.

title: He Coached a Girls Team
description: During our first full year of coeducation, when girls interscholastic sports began at St. Paul's School, my career as a male girls basketball coach was launched. After three seasons of working with a group of athletes who have given everything to their sport and who have transmuted their untested potential into an inspired proficiency, I have been touched deeply. I will always remain a girls basketball coach.

title: Wertmuller: The Foremost Woman Movie Director
description: She is a tiny, birdlike woman with white rimmed eyeglasses that have become her trademark and cropped brown hair that stands up in clumps because she has this habit of constantly running her fingers through it as she speaks. And now, as she sits in an easy chair in her Algonquin Hotel suite, she speaks mostly in Italian, chainsmoking all the while, her leatherbooted legs propped jauntily the coffee table.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Profittaking blunted the stock market's recent sharp advance last week but prices still finished higher in continued hectic trading.

title: Robin F. Kirk Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Robin Fields Kirk to Richard King Lintern, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Lintern of Kirtland Hills, Ohio, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Kirk of Orford, N.H. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Saudi Oil Official Favors Longer Freeze on Prices
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 8Saudi Arabia's Minister of Petroleum, Sheik Ahmed. Zaki Yamani, said today that his nation opposed an increase in oil prices this year and hoped to keep the price freeze in 1976.

title: In Summary
description: Secretary of State Kissinger is leaving for another swing through the Middle East, reportedly believing. he has a 5050 chance of arranging a new partial peace agreement between Israel and Egypt. Perhaps more significant for the future, he and most other interested parties suggest that, whether he succeeds now or not, it will soon be time to resume fullscale negotiations in Geneva, with both the Soviet Union and the United States present.

List of Forbidden Items In Feingold KP Diet
description: Dr. Ben F. Feingold's diet for hyperkinetic children eliminates two groups of food.

title: FILM VIEW
description: I was happily watching Ulzana's Raida modest and excellent cavalryandIndian western on its network television premiere the other night when it occurred to me that it is probably a movie of far greater historical significance than its producerdirector, Robert Aldrich, or its star, Burt Lancaster, intended it to be when they made it in 1972. I don't mean merely that it came out better than most genre pieces do (though it did) and I'm not predicting that it will develop a cult following. No, the gloomy thought that stole over me as I watched grizzled scout Lancaster guide a troop of cavalry in pursuit of a renegade (and mercilessly sadistic) Apache band was that it is probably the last movie of Its kind that will ever be made.

title: Trina L. Schurenstedt Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Schurenstedt of North Salem, N.Y., halve announced the engagement of their daughter. Trina Lucile Schurenstedt. to George S. Ledyard 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Ledvard Jr. of Houston, formerly of Montclair, N.J.

title: Golf Lead Regained By Miller
BRIDGE
description: There are times when a bridgeplayer is entitled to think that the gods of the game are toying with him, teasing him in subtle fashion. He can suspect this is happening when a close inspection of the dummy reveals that the spot cards in one suit are perversely divided. He can be sure of it when, as in the diagramed deal from the NorwayDenmark match in the recent European Championships in Israel, this cariciousness extends itself to a second suit.

title: Pyles Captures Pro Giant Slalom
description: EAST TROY, Wis., Feb. 8 (AP)Rudd Pyles of Aspen, Colo., won his first event in two years on the world pro ski tour today. He upset the circuit leader, Hank Kashiwa, in the giant slalom final by more than a second on their first run down the Alpine Valley course.

title: Carey Clouds LILCO Plan
How to Improve Bowling: Get Consistent Delivery
Gala Double Triumphs In Vertex
description: BOWIE Md., Feb. 8Gala Double came along on the outside in the stretch to win the $33,050 Vertex Handicap today. Guided by Leroy Moyers, Gala Double carried the silks of Gertrude Leviton to a 1length triumph in the 1111mile event for Maryland, breds. Backed hesitantly by the crowd of 15,445, Gala Double paid $14.80 for $2 after covering the fast track in 1:45.

title: Independence Day Is June 25

description: Though the city is in the grip of recession, office leasing during 1974 managed to cut slightly the record inventory of vacant space.
