description: Louise Maria Ruspini and William Hector Mackenzie 3d, who is studying for a master's degree in photography at the University of Buffalo's Visual Studies Workshop in Rochester, plan to marry in June.

title: Food
description: The traditional Black Forest cake, with its kirschscented chocolate layers and its tantalizing blend of sour and sweet cherries, is one of Germany's proudest contributions to the world's cookery. The version here is that of Albert Kumin, a leading pastry chef at the Culinary Institute of America, in Hyde Park, N. Y.

Smith; costumes by Marianne PowellParker; production stage manager, Judy Goldstein. Presented by Equity Library Theater, Riverside Drive at 103d Street, through Feb. 16th.

title: Inmates Charge Illegalities
description: CRANSTON. R. I., Feb. 8 (AP)  Inmates at the Adult Correctional Institutions here have filed a $25million Federal lawsuit charging an illegal lack of proper treatment and rehabilitative programs and asking a Federal takeover of the prison.

title: Internist to Marry Karen A. Strauss
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morris Strauss of Westbury, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Anita Strauss, to Dr. Martin W. Oster of Bethesda, Md., son of Joseph A. Oster of New York and the late Bella Oster. The wedding is planned for May.

title: If Nothin Don't Happen
description: Our nearest neighbors was close enough so that on a clear right you could see the lights from their stills, reminisces Billy Driggers. Fifty years or so ago, Billy is growing up in The Hammock, a bit of Florida's backwoods, somewhere between Fort Myers and the Gulf of Mexico.

description: Daniel A. Lynch Sr., a lawyer who had specialized in industrial relations for 40 years, died Friday at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was in his sixties and lived in Eastchester, N.Y.

description: TOMS RIVERThe oncepowerful Ocean County Republican organization, weakened by two years of Democratic victories and a heavy fallout from Watergate, is trying desperately to rebuild.

title: The Politicalization of The Board of Regents
description: When the New York State Board of Regents was organized into its present form at the turn of the century, it was conceived of as an aloof and protected body of citizens entrusted with the management of the state's educational system and free from the pressures of competing political and educational factions.

description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 8 (UPI) Lawrence Weingarten, the movie producer, died Thursday of leukemia. He was 77 years old.

description: HEMPSTEADJob losses and spiraling costs are breeding a new group of casualties from the ranks of the previously stable middle class, according to the Jewish Community Services of Long Island.

title: Middlesex College Seeking a President
description: EDISONMiddlesex County College has begun a search for a successor to Dr..Frank M. Chambers, its founding president. Dr. Chambers has resigned after 10 years of service and will leave the Host next Dec. 31.

title: Bishop Threatens to Resign
description: PERRYSBURG, Ohio, Feb. 8 (UPI)The Right Rev. John H. Burt, Episcopal Bishop of Ohio, said today that he would resign as an act of conscience if the national church's convention did not lift its ban on ordination of women as priests next year. If we are unsuccessful at the general convention in persuading our church to permit the priesting of women, then I intend to resign from the episcopate, Bishop Burt said in his opening address at the weekend convention of the Ohio diocese here.

title: Search Behind The Lines
description: The Second World War is so distant so distant now for all of us. So many wars have intervenedIsrael, Korea, Vietnam, brush wars here and civil wars there and interventions elsewhere and the upheavals in Africa (Algeria, the colonialist Congos and so on). There have been so many wars since the second War to End All Wars that it seems almost never to have happened, save for scholars and writers; for the young, it is mostly rumor. We do not even hear much from the veterans of the Second World War, aging men all. Rommel is dead, and Patton is dead, and Zhukov is dead.

title: MICHAEL A. BUCCERI, ANESTHESIOLOGIST
description: Dr. Michael A. Bucceri, attending anesthesiologist a French Polyclinic Medical Center, died Friday of a heart attack at his home, 180 East End Avenue. His age was 56.

title: The Secret
description: February is still winter, beyond argument; but change is in the air. Literally in the air, if you watch and listen to the blue jays.

description: TRENTONAlthough the recession has bitten deeply into employment do New Jersey, the state is still attracting new corporate headquarter at a pace that officials see as a continuing deterrent to the slack in the economy.

title: At Chinatown Restaurant, a Young Chef Puts on a Virtuoso Performance
description: For the Chinese, Tuesday begins year 4673, the year of the rabbit. It should be a mildertempered one than the departing year of the tiger, and a good year for money, since the rabbit promises financial luck.

title: Leonard Cohen Gives His Songs In Concert Here
description: There is a lot one could dislike about Leonard Cohen, the Canadian poet and songwriter who gave his first formal concert here since 1969 Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall (he was at the Bottom Line for three nights two months ago). His voice is limited in range, his tunes sound repetitious and his persona is strange indeeddefensiveness elevated into art, with downright peculiar imagery and a constant, lugubrious pall over all.

title: Books: A Flawed Analysis of Banking
description: For the first time since the Depression, Americans today are seeking serious questions about the quality, structure and performance of the banking system in this country. This is Plainly evident in a number of developments:

title: Child to the De Lisis
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. John De Lisi of Brooklyn on Jan. 30 in the Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn. Mrs. De Lisi is the former Deborah Genge. The child has been named Michelle Rose.

title: Miss Capin Is Wed To David S. Cutten
description: Michelle Ann Capin and David Sanders Cutten were married yesterday morning in the Alumni Memorial Chapel of the University of New Mexico. The Rev. Mark Farrel, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Harry Johns, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Temporarily Out of Business may soon replace the Clearance Sale sign on the Government's inventory of Carson City silver dollars.

title: False Idols
description: You just can't get dependable domestic help these days. The Rubenses of suburban Randolph Harbor think they have a treasure from Peru in greeneyed Ayesha, when suddenly they are hit with a diabolic epidemic of foul smells, seizures and suspicious deaths. Fran Rubens's aged motherinlaw expires in a mixture of superstitious terror and inaccurate Yiddish.

title: PAY FIGHT HURTING NIGERIAN SERVICES
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 8 Work stoppages have disrupted essential services in several Nigerian cities in recent weeks as some Government workers have expressed dissatisfaction with recent pay increases and private employes have demanded similar gains.

description: Continued

title: DANCE VIEW
description: American Ballet Theater, which last Sunday ended a triumphant season at the City Center 55th Street Theater, is probably one of the oldest theatrical institutions with a continuous history in the entire country. Indeed, apart from the Metropolitan Opera, it may be, at a still youthful 35 years, just about the granddaddy of them all.

title: Expert Guides School Boards on Labor Relations
description: EAST WINDSOR  From October through March, Herbert Rogin, a businessman who resides in this Mercer County township, spends the major portion of his time as a labor  relations expert for New Jersey boards of education. His job, he frankly admits, is to keep the residents of a communityoften as much as 75 per cent of the populationfrom losing control over their public schools because of their ignorance or apathy as to what can happen in the course of tough contract negotiations with teachers and other personnel.

title: So what else is new?
description: Thirty years ago, the Second World War came to its end, and much else besides. April 25, 1945, was a Wednesday, the day when in the middle of Germany American and Soviet soldiers met, clasped hands, broke out the vodka and the whisky and, to the strains of wild and awful accordion music, celebrated into the night.

title: CITY EASES FREEZE ON BUILDING PLANS

description: Listening acuity was challenged at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night when Lester Trimble's Quadraphonics (Panels VI) was given Its premiere by Today's Percussion Quartet in a Juilliard School chambermusic concert.

description: San Francisco Consumer Action has come a long way since its early days in the summer of 1971 when British Motor Cars, Ltd., sued the group for $6million on libel charges, causing Kay Pachtner, the group's executive director, to respond in astonishment Six million dollars? We haven't got six cents.

title: 6.7 Sets Mark for 70 Yards
CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Jan. 19 reported incorrectly that the New Jersey Commissioner of Insurance had proposed that all insurance companies writing liability insurance in the state be required to form a pool to provide malpractice insurance. The proposal would actually involve only those companies already writing malpractice policies.

title: Ukrainian Debutante Ball
description: The Ukrainian Doctors and Engineers Associations of America held their annual benefit Debutante Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre Hotel here last night. Eighteen young women from American Ukrainian families were presented at the event, for which Olga Hnateyko, Nanna Sochynski, Vera Kushnir and Maria Honcharenko were cochairmen.

title: In Istanbul With Mobile Midriff
description: THE scent of musk and ambergris fills the air. Dark blue Turkish tiles cover the walls of the long room. Tile women of the harem in their silk and velvet costumes lounge on couches, the blindfolded musicians on the balcony stroke the strings of their dulcimersand beneath the baldequin, diamonds glinting in his turban, golden chalice raised to his lips, the sultan sits upon his throne.

title: Corporations Borrow Shorter to Save Money
description: Heublein, Inc., famous for its Smirnoff vodka, registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission last wednesday a $125million offering that is expected to reach the public market later this month.

title: Cavaliers Top Kings In Overtime
David Hubbard Fiance Of Devika C. Crowell
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Arthur R. Crowell of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Devika Constance Crowell, to David Hubbard of New York, son of Mrs. Florence Hubbard, and David Hubbard, both of Baltimore.

title: Hammer Will Exhibit Art Works From the Hermitage in Museums in U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8Dr. Armand Hammer, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation of Los Angeles, announced today that he had arranged a sixmonth exchange of art works that will include 30 classic paintings from the Hermitage Museum in Leninggrad.

title: Edmund Garrison, 81, Dies; Maker of Fly Fishing Rods
description: Edmund E. Garrison, who made the internationally known Garrison fly fishing rod, died yesterday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 81 years old and lived on Piping Rock Drive in Ossining. N.Y.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  The Assembly approved a number of new rules last week, one of which will require the taping of all routine floor debates. While it seemed like a good idea to most legislators, a few have expressed some misgivings that they may be creating a monster that will come back and devour them on Election Day.

title: Close Bhutto Ally Killed in Blast At Student Meeting in Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Feb. 8(UPI)A bomb blast at Peshawar University today killed the fiery home minister of Pakistan's politically troubled NorthWest Frontier Province. He was a close friend of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto who is visting New York.

title: Pot Cove Residents Protest Proposed Changes Along East River in Astoria
description: Residents of the Pot Cove section of Astoria. Queens, objected last week to proposed zoning and streetmapping changes they said would channel an unwarranted flow of traffic through their quiet enclave on the waters of Hell Gate in the East River.

title: Schussing and Touring On a Homemade Trail
description: IN the northwest corner of Massachusetts there's a very special ski trail. For three and a half miles it gently descends the eastern flank of the Taconic Range through forest, field and glen. The trail, running into the valley That embraces Williamstown, is equally attractive for beginning and intermediate skiers and not uninteresting to the expert. It can be skied with crosscountry or downhill skis, can be used in nonskiing seasons as a hiking or horseback riding trail and the year round as a naure walk. It is called the Triple R Brooks Trail after former Williams Col. ege Dean Robert R. R. Brooks who, 20 rears ago, with the help of a few of his students, pieced together dry river beds and the remnants of old farm roads to fashion one long trail for skiers. In going so Brooks created something rare a free trail that combines the excitement of downhill skiing with the serenity of the crosscountry variety. But the fact is, it doesn't have to be rare. Other locales have the wherewithal to create such trails (see box); what's needed are inspiration and a modicum of perspiration.

title: Artful Gem in Huntington
description: HUNTINGTON  Anyone who saw the Heckscher Museum in the nineteenfifties might not think that it could possibly be the same institution today.

title: Yacht Race Captured By Stinger
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 8  Stinger, the small but fancy yacht that won the 403mile ocean race from St. Petersburg that ended here today, is for sale and Dennis Conner, her ownerskipper, is unemployed, although not seeking work. So the boat and the man made a statement in keeping with these perilous times, although the world of yachting as usual had its own distinctions.

title: Charles Petersmeyer Is Fiance Of Margaret Fitzgerald Grogan
description: Margaret Fitzgerald Grogan, of New York, who is with the corporate relations department of Philip Morris, Inc., and Charles Gregg Petersmeyer of Bronxville, N. Y., who is studying at Oxford University, plan to be married in September.

title: Five Million Birds Darken Army Post Sky
description: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., Feb. 8Col. Robert Peach of the 101st Airborne stood in front of the briefing map and tapped an area with a redtipped pointer.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An explosion apparently caused by a bomb destroyed the interior of an empty prekindergarten school in Oceanside, L. I., at 3:30 A.M. yesterday. A spokesman for the Nassau County police in Hewlett said that the kitchen the school, the Alphabetland Preschool Center at 2785 Brower Avenue, was damaged by a suspicious fire last Dec. 4.

title: FOREIGN FINANCING IS SOUGHT BY CITY TO PRODUCE JOBS
description: Mayor Beame disclosed yesterday that the city was actively seeking foreign capital to create new industries and new jobs here and asserted that New York is becoming increasingly attractive to overseas investors.

title: The Dance: New Lubovitch Troupe
description: After a couple of seasons in which he was primarily working as a freelance choreographer, Lar Lubovitch has reformed his own company. This has been appearing at the American Theater Laboratory on West 19th Street this weekend, and will also be there next weekend from Thursday to Sunday. In the spring, the company embarks on a lone European tour.
