description: WASHINGTONHenry M. (Scoop) Jackson formally entered the Democratic Presidential race last week, if not as a frontrunner, at least as a certifiable heavyweight.

title: Miriam Hughes Marries Here
description: In the chapel at Lowenstein Center on the Lincoln Center Campus of Fordham University yesterday afternoon, Miriam Meredith Hughes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Theodore Hughes of Fairfield, Iowa, became the bride of Philip Roger Carroll, son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Carroll of Bridgeport and Milford, Conn.

title: 102 DONORS SEND FUNDS TO NEEDIEST
description: The brief note from Brooklyn read: Forgive meI didn't forget youI've remembered for 10 yearsjust a bit tardy. A $10 contribution to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund accompanied the message, which was from Mrs. Harold Socolow.

title: Prospect of Australian Election Silences Whitlam's Critics at Party Meeting
description: TERRIGAL, Australia, Feb. 8 At Terrigal, a resort town where a foaming white surf boils in from the Tasman Sea, it was difficult this week to distinguish Australians on vacation from delegates to the Australian Labor party's policymaking conference.

title: What's Inside You It Shines Out of You
description: When JeanJacques Rousseau was an old man, persecuted and more than a little mad, he turned to a fantasy that had given him pleasure all his life. In the midst of A passage that reads like a shrill, selfjustifying inner dialogue, he suddenly interrupts himself and ashs the reader to imagine a world exactly like ours in all respects, except that in it the impressions of nature are more penetrating.

title: Scallop Harvest Bountiful on L.I.
description: AMAGANSETT  Early last summer, experienced hands who knew how to interpret the signs were predicting a good harvest of local bay scallops. When the season opened in September, their forecast proved to be on target.

title: Ramage's Prize
description: Lieut. Nicholas Ramage, the secret weapon of Nelson's navy, is dispatched on a mission to find out what is happening to the postal service. Seems the Post Office packet ships are disappearing regularly on the homeward passage from the West Indies. Once aboard the brig Lady Arabella bound from Jamaica to Falmouth, Ramage soon discovers that the ships have not been vanishing into the Bermuda Triangle or the Sargasso Sea. As a matter of fact they have not really been vanishing at all, but changing hands among French privateers in cahoots with forces who had better go unnamed.

title: On the Careful Art of Potting Plants
description: Just as the painter must learn the tools of his craft, so must the house plant grower learn the gentle art of potting. Late winter or early spring is the time when plants best respond to repotting. Increased daylight stimulates more efficient photosynthesis and more rapid root growth.

title: POLICE JOB ACCORD OPPOSED IN RANKS
description: Rank and file police officers, in a spot check around the city have expressed overwhelming opposition to a compromise solution agreed on by municipal and union officials to save the jobs of more than 500 police rookies and recruits.

title: FIVE HEARINGS SET ON CAPITAL BUDGET
Letters To the Editor
description: Men and Women

title: Byrne's Budget Has Builtin Tax Pressures
description: The battle over tax reform between New Jersey's Democratic Governor Brendan Bryne and the Democratic State Legislature has been joined again, and while the Governor has lost twice before in efforts to get an income tax, he may succeed this time because the alternatives appear even more distasteful.

title: HOUSE ON HOLIDAY AS CONGRESS LAGS
Heritage Festivals Will Begin May 31
description: HOLMDEL Twelve heritage festivals have been scheduled for the Garden State Arts Center this year and more may be added to the list.

title: Music Notes: A Crescendo in the Women's Movement
Brookhaven Weighing a Resolution to Give More Power to Town Supervisor
description: PATCHOGUE In a move to update and streamline its governmental structure by concentrating more power in the hands of the Town Supervisor, the Brookhaven Town Board is expected shortly to approve a resolution to change Brookhaven from a Town of the First Class to a Suburban Town.

title: Reporter's Notebook: A Look At Equal Rights and Hockey
Theater Notes: Of Women and Angels With Hollywood Tans
description: It's an acepted cliche on Broadwayand indeed in the film world toothat they're not writing good parts for women any more. Well, the film world aside, they do seem to be providing some pretty good roles for women on Broadway these days. Admittedly, a good part of the stage action centers on revivals, but all in all this is surely the most fruitful season for actresses in a long time.

title: An Agrarian Past Is Still Hampering Education in South
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 8Though urbanization and industrialization have forced the South to upgrade its elementary and secondary schools in recent years, a diehard agrarian past still affects the quality of education in much of Dixie.

title: CHESS
description: Currently some of the newer grandmasters are bringing back oldfashioned king pawn openings that had been eclipsed by the Ruy Lopez. Dragoljub Velimirovic and Ljubomir Ljubojevic of Yugoslavia often employ the Goering gambit and Jan Timman of the Netherlands has dusted off the Giuoco Piano, the oldest recorded opening.

title: ETHIOPIANS FIGHT TO MAINTAIN LINK TO OIL SUPPLIES
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 8Ethiopia's military rulers said tonight that Eritrean guerrillas had tried but failed to cut the vital road between Addis Ababa and its only supply of oil.

title: NAVY YARD DREAM NOW A NIGHTMARE
description: After six years of trying to cope with obsolete buildings, soaring utility costs, job reductions, bankrupt companies and political battles, the city has drastically scaled down its onceambitious plans for the old Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: New Star in Circus Ring
description: FLORENCEFor the first time in 50 years, an American circus is going to have a woman as an owner and managing director. However, the name she will carry into the center ring is a familiar one to generations of bigtop fans.

title: Headliners
description: It's not unusual for photographers to be aboard the Presidential press plane, but when one of them is Candice Bergen, well, that appears to be something else again. It happened last week on President Ford's trip to Atlanta. In addition to being an actress, model and writer, Miss Bergen is a professional photographer and she was on an assignment for a magazine. Escorted by David Kennerly, the bearded bachelor who serves as the White House photographer, Miss Bergen took some pictures in the President's hotel suite, flew back to Washington on Air Force One and then attended a White House dinner. Her presence caused a bit of a stir among the regular press corps, but veteran newsmen attributed it more to envy of Mr. Kennerly than to objection to Miss Bergen's special privileges.

title: MUSCOVITES TRADE REFUSE FOR BOOKS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8It is now possible for David Copperfield or Gulliver to be recycled for reappearance in Moscow as Sherlock Holmes or the Ugly Duckling.

title: Mary Lou Takes Her Jazz Mass to Church
description: How does a jazz musician get booked into St. Patrick's Cathedral, a place where no jazz musician has ever played? Mary Lou Williams, the jazz pianist and composer, knows the answer for on Tuesday afternoon at 2 P.M. her Mary Lou's Mass will be performed there. Here is how the event came about.

title: Miss LawsonJohnston Fiancee of T. K. McNeil
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter O. IawsonJohnston of Princeton, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Hammond LawscnJohnston, to Thomas Kerney MeNeil, son of Mrs. J. Robert McNeil of Pinehurst. N. C., and Lawrenceville, N. J., and the late Mr. McNeil.

title: IMPORTS AN ISSUE IN EAST GERMANY
description: LEUNA, East GermanyIn an East German petroleum processing plant, totally dependent on a pipeline from the Soviet Union, the watchword this year is efficency.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: UNEMPLOYMENT in January rose to 8.2 per cent of the work force, the Labor Department reported, up from December's revised 7.2 per cent  President Ford projected an unemployment rate of about 8 per cent for the year, an increase in the consumer price index of 11.3 per cent and a 3.3 per cent drop in real gross national product  Car sales in January totaling 462,691 units were down 16 per cent compared with January, 1973.

title: Dungan Assays College Freeze
description: TRENTON  Chancellor Ralph A. Dungan of the Department of Higher Education has concluded that the freeze imposed on student enrollments at the state colleges and at Rutgers, the state university, may not be such a bad thing after all.

title: Kerry Kleid, Motorcyclist, to Marry
description: Kerry Kleid. the first woman licensed by the American Motorcycle Association to race professionally, and Richard F. Schroeder, manager and instructor at the Pacific View Tennis Club in Garland, Calif., plan to be married on March 1.

title: Martyn Green, 75, Dies on Coast
description: Martyn Green, the British actor who set the standard in Gilbert and Sullivan interpretation for half a century, died early yesterday of a blood infection at Presbyterian Hospital in Hollywood, Calif. He was 75 years old.

title: Relay Race Is Captured By Loughlin
Subway Tokens To Be Sold on L.I.
description: An experimental program to enable some Long Island commuters to purchase subway tokens at Long Island Rail Road stations, was begun last week by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: 120 Flee a Supermarket in Queens as 2 Tear Gas Grenades Go Off
Italy Urged Not to Pay Ransom for 3 Paintings
description: ROME, Feb. 8 (AP)The art detective assigned to track down three Renaissance masterpieces stolen from the Ducal Palace in Urbino urged the Italian Government today to refuse to pay a $4.8million ransom.

title: U.S. Supplying Missiles And Instructors to Oman
description: SALALA, Oman, Feb. 8  A shipment of United Statesmade Tow antitank missiles arrived recently in Oman, highly placed informants reported today, and two United States military men have arrived to provide the Omani armed forces with instruction in their use.

title: LETTERS
description: Capital

title: Substantial School Tax Rise on L.I. Held Likely If Carey Budget Plan Passes
Wood, Field and Stream: Record Deer Kill
description: In 1974, for the first time since such records have been kept, New York State's annual take of deer by hunters went over 100,000.

title: Procter & Gamble's Wary Eye on New York
description: Speculation about when Procter & Gamble, Inc., would move its Folger's brand coffee into the metropolitan New York market has become speculation about why it hasn't.

title: So Far, Promises
description: WASHINGTON'I'll do whatever the President wants, Vice President Rockefeller said last week, as he has repeatedly since he took office Dec. 19. President Ford may yet want more than the usual amount of authority and responsibility for the new Vice President, who has come with more than the usual amount of resources to an Administration with more than the usual amount of need. Yet in the first six weeks, Mr. Rockefeller's role has been so in keeping with tradition that there were echoes of Vice Presidents past.

title: Sally Denby Engaged to R. L. Hoffman
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Reed Denby of New Hope, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Reed Denby, to Robert Lawrence Hoffman, son of Kenneth Hoffman of New York and Mrs. Shelda Salvi of Port Washington, L.I.

title: Mrs. Abzug Says Women Are Losing In Labor Market
description: Nearly a third of the 7.5million Americans without jobs in January were women even though women make up only about 20 per cent of the total labor force in the United States, Representative Bella Abzug of Manhattan told a conference on women and the law here yesterday.

title: No. 101418 Tries Again to Cope With World Outside Prison Walls
description: FORT MADISON, Iowa, Feb. 7 Robert Ray Ferguson Number 101418 is a free managain.

title: He Had Title Insurance, and Collected
description: Like millions of other home buyers, Clem Schimikowski knew little about title insurance when he plunked down $270 three years ago for a policy on his house and four acres in Highland Mills, N. Y.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Rangers Get 3 in Minute and Win, 73
description: For 58 seconds last night the New York Rangers outplayed the Washington Capitals. Three goals in that short stretch broke a 22 tie and helped New York go on to post a 73 victory over a team that has won but our games in its brief National Hockey League history.

title: HELMS SAID NIXON SEUGHT CHILE COUP
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Richard Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence, told a Senate committee in testimony released today that there was no doubt in 1970 that the Nixon Administration wanted to have President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile overthrown.

title: Bridge:
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Feb. 9A local tournament with an unusual international flavor ended here last night, with United States competitors taking the Swiss teams laurels.

title: I.R.A. ANNOUNCES NEW CEASEFIRE
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 9The I.R.A. Provisionals announced tonight an openended renewal of their ceasefire in Northern Ireland and Britain.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The decline in the economy has apparently inspired an increase in sharp practices in the marketplace.

title: Machinists Strike McDonnell Douglas Jet Plant
description: ST. LOUIS, Monday, Feb 10 (UPI)The 12,000member machinists union at McDonnell Douglas Corporation, where Phantom fighter jets are manufactured, set up picket lines at 12:01 A.M. today in a strike that could spread to 13,000 other workers.

title: Carnival In Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Carnival has burst across Brazil, four days of dancing, drums and wild cries in the street before the austerity of Lent. Those who have never come south for the celebration may have seen Black Orpheus, with its scenes of hillside slumsfavelaswhere Carnival compensated for a year of misery and despair.

title: Firing Is Renewed Near Eritrean Capital
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 9 (Reuters)Fire from machine guns and light weapons was heard in the outskirts of Asmara tonight after a day of quiet in the troubled Eritrean capital.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Arts and Leisure section of The New York Times yesterday, the date for the performance of Mary Lou's Mass by Mary Lou Williams at St. Patrick's Cathedral was incorrectly given. It will be performed Feb. 18 at 2 P.M.

title: Kay and Arnold Constable End Agreement on Tweed
description: An agreement whereby the Kay Corporation would transfer its chain of Tweed Ladies Fashion Boutiques to the Arnold Constable Corporation has been terminated by mutual consent, it was announced over the weekend.

title: 29 Die in Mexico as Train Smashes Bus at Crossing
description: TULTEPEC, Mexico, Feb. 9 (AP)An overloaded bus was struck by a freight train that it apparently tried to beat at a crossing at this town 17 miles north of Mexico City last night. Twentynine people aboard the bus were killed and 28 injured.

title: Congressman Meets With 700 Constituents
description: PARAMUS, Feb. 9  Andrew Maguire, the freshman Representative from New Jersey's seventh Congressional District, met here today with more than 700 of his constituents in an open exchange of questions, answers and ideas dealing with the current economic and power crises.

title: Companies Reduce Their Inventories, Slowing Economy
description: Inventory reductions continue to intensify the recession, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday in its January report on business conditions. Fully 45 per cent of purchasing executives surveyed by the association are cutting their stocks of materials in contrast with only 9 per cent who were reducing their stocks last summer.

title: Infant Girl Falls to Death
description: An 18monthold girl fell five stories from her bedroom window to the sidewalk last night, the police reported. She was identified as Marvelous Brown, of 235 143d Street. The police said the child's mother, Barbara Brown, was in the apartment at the time of the incident.

title: 50 Injured in Brussels
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 9 (Reuters)More than 50 people were injured in a demonstration against alleged antiFlemish discrimination here today, police sources said. It was the bilingual capital's worst violence over FrenchFlemish ethnic rivalry in several years.

title: Beame to Start Layoffs If P.B.A. Rejects Plan
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that he would have no choice but to lay off more than 500 police rookies and recruits if the rank and file of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association rejected a plan to save their jobs that had been agreed to by union leaders.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A stubborn fire in two East Harlem tenements on Third Avenue, near 106th Street, last night forced the evacuation of 48 tenants, including eight children. Fourteen firemen were injured, none seriously.

title: John H. Secondari Dead at 55; Made Noted TV Documentaries
Ousted Stanford Professor Gets a Position at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 9The Yale Corporation approved today a teaching appointment for H. Bruce Franklin, who was dismissed from a tenured position at Stanford University in 1972 for allegedly inciting violent student demonstrations.

title: '74 TAXES OUTRACE OTHER PRICE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9A Congressional economic survey made public today has found that higher tax payments outstripped all other price increases in the 1974 consumer budget and that this rise had a greater impact on lowincome and middleincome taxpayers than on the wealthy.

title: A CanDo Congress
description: President Ford is embarked on an aggressive, highrisk strategy when he goes around accusing the new Congress of doing basically nothing about the nation's urgent problems. His criticism is unwarranted by the facts up to now, but an element of justification might appear if certain institutional shortcomings are not resolved more fully in the weeks ahead.

title: Renee Payson Is the Bride of Rabbi
description: Renee Payson, a teacher in the Central Synagogue's Nursery School, was married yesterday noon to Rabbi Mark Jay Panoff, the synagogue's assistant rabbi. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, the senior rabbi, performed the ceremony in the synagogue's sanctuary. He was assisted by Rabbi David J. Seligson, rabbi emeritus, Rabbi Harvey J. Fields, and Richard Botton.

title: Quintuplets Born in Illinois; Mother on Fertility Drugs
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (UPI)Quintuplets, three boys and two girls, were born today to a 27yearold woman who had been taking fertility drugs.

title: Troubles Pale in Rhineland Karneval
description: BONN, Feb. 9A mason who lost his job three weeks ago sat in a restaurant bedecked with balloons in Plittersdorf and said: I'm not even going to start looking for another job until Karneval's over. Nobody ever works then, anyhow, so it doesn't feel any different for me.

title: WATER PIPE BURSTS; HARLEM SPAN SHUT
description: A 12inch water main ruptured last night near the southern end of the Broadway Bridge in upper Manhattan, forcing the police to close that span over the Harlem River and disrupting service on the IRT line's elevated No. 1 train, the Broadway local.

title: HEARING ON TRAINING OF SAUDIS IS SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Two Senators called today for a Congressional investigation of a Defense Department contract with a private firm to train Saudi Arabian troops to guard oil wells in the Persian Gulf.

title: Civilian Boards on Wane As Watchdogs of Police
Crash Foils a Cabby In Bid to Halt Suicide
description: A taxi driver tried vainly for 20 minutes yesterday to dissuade a Brooklyn man from leaping off the Verrazano Narrows Bridge by locking the passenger in the rear seat and pleading, Don't do it, don't do it.

title: A Doubleday Account Seems Ready to Move
description: No official confirmation yet, but it looks as if the Doubleday & Co. business that has been at SSC&B will be moving over to Foote, Cone & Belding. When SSC&B got the account in 1969, annual billings were estimated at $3million.

title: Japanese Women to Everest
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Feb. 9 (Reuters)Ten members of a Japanese women's expedition to climb Mount Everest left here today to begin their attempt on the world's highest mountain.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1975

title: A.D.A. SEES LEFT TURN IN HOUSE BY SOUTH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) Americans for Democratic Action said today that Southern Democratic Congressmen elected to the House two years ago continued in 1974 to make a gradual break with what the organization calls a conservative RepublicanDixiecrat coalition.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Just as we're beginning to get used to the big, voluminous look in fashion, European designers are getting ready for the next step. Enrica Sanlorenzo shows what that's going to be with her knitwear collection for next fall and winter.

title: THOMAS F. OLMSTED, U.S. CAMBODIA AIDE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 9Thomas F. Olmsted, director of the United States economic aid program in Cambodia, died last night in Thailand in a Bangkok hospital, where he was rushed a week ago after a sudden attack of pancreatitis. He was 45 years old.

title: Freshmen Representatives Find Awe and Ah! in Capital
description: WASHINGTON  Tom Downey, at 26 years old the youngest member of Congress, was dining with his parents at a Capitol Hill restaurant last week when he caught the eye of a young woman dining alone at a nearby table.

title: Ship's Captain Dies, 2d Man Is Missing After Boat Capsizes
CHARLES ZABRISKIE
description: Charles Zabriskie, who retired in 1956 as a vice president of the County Bank and Trust Company, Paterson, N.J., died Friday in the Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. He was 87 years old and lived in Sloatsburg, N.Y.

title: Skate Title Is Captured By Kuipers
description: OSLO, Feb. 9 (AP)Harm Kuipers returned the world speed skating title to the Netherlands today for the first time since Ard Schenk, the Olympic champion, turned professional in 1972. Schenk had taken three straight world titles.

title: Ceremonies Mark The 128th Birthday Of Thomas Edison
description: EDISON TOWNSHIP, Feb. 9 About 125 residents attended wreathlaying ceremonies here today commemorating the 128th birthday Tuesday of Thomas Alva Edison.

title: Coffin Says He'll Leave Yale in 76
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 9The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., Yale University's chaplain for 17 years, announced today that he was resigning next year to seek a change and new challenges.

title: MOVE SET TO BAR DEAL WITH IRAN
description: An American agreement to sell six desroyers to Iran for an amount estimated at $700million or more brought a move yesterday to block the transaction.

title: State Bill Offered to Revise Campaign Financin
description: The Citizens Union and the City Club, two of the oldest nonpartisan civic organizations here, called yesterday for revising the state laws on campaign financing to reduce contributions and spending and harden the provisions for enforcement.

title: MISS ZYKINA SINGS RUSSIAN FOLK SONGS
description: Bravos may aboundand justifiablywhen the Lenin Prize winner Ludmila Zykina takes the stage, but credit must also go to the cohesiveness of the 13piece Moscow Balalaika Orchestra, which provides the sometimes fragile, sometimes tough backgrounds to her Russian folk songs. So it was at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon with Miss Zykina, something of an institution on the Soviet folk scene, on another American tour.

title: Soyuz 17 Returns to Earth After Record 30Day Trip
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 9The twoman crew of the Soyuz 17 returned to earth today after spending 30 days in space, a record for Soviet astronauts.

title: Spot On, a Fox Terrier, Proves Father Shows Best
Freshmen Representatives Find Awe and Ah! in Capital
CAMDEN MAYOR DUE BACK ON JOB TODAY
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 9 (UPI)Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti returns to his office for the first time tomorrow since his acquittal of misconductconspiracy charges.

title: ROBERT C. NICHOLAS
description: Robert Carter Nicholas, a lawyer here for 40 years, died Friday at the Hunterdon Medical Center, Flemington, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Oldwick. N.J.

title: Ford to Promote Plans For Economy on Trip
description: THURMONT, Md., Feb. 9 (UPI)President Ford completed a weekend of relaxation and paperwork at Camp David today in preparation for another round of traveling, public meetings and private appearances on behalf of his economic recovery proposals.

title: Rubinstein in Life and on the Screen
description: I love to be at a performance where I don't have to play the piano, said Arthur Rubinstein to an admiring crowd.

title: Screen: De Sica Finale
Article 2  No Title
description: How to fly to Dallas/Ft. Worth.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP)Mark Donohue, warming up for an attempt at a world closedcourse speed record Thursday, whipped a turbocharged Porsche 917 around the Daytona International Speedway at an unofficial 201.734 miles an hour today. It was the fastest lap ever recorded on the 2mile trioval. The lap record at Daytona is 194.015 m.p.h., set by Cale Yarborough in a Mercury in 1970.

title: Inquirer Walkout Ends
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9, (AP) The Philadelphia Inquirer resumed publication today after a threeday wildcat walkout by delivery drivers.

title: Italy and Vatican Set to Start Talks On 1929 Concordat
Miss Haynie Is Golf Victor
18 New Representatives Find Awe and Ah! in Capital
description: Continued From Page 29 cratic Assemblyman from Flatbush.

title: Widow, 84, Donates $6 To Walkers
description: An 84yearold widow who lives alone in a Bronx apartment has sent six $1 bills from her weekly budget to the six children of Frank J. Walker, who was killed when he tried to aid a seriously wounded police officer.

title: PROF. RENA L. FOY
description: Dr. Rena L. Foy, professor of education at Bowling Green State University in Ohio, died Friday in the Ohio State University Hospital in Columbus. She was 45 years old.

title: Stein to Question Wagner on 60 Report
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. and former Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan are among the witnesses scheduled to be called next week by a state commission trying to unravel a 15yearold mystery: What happened to the Kaplan report?

title: HELMS SAID NIXON SOUGHT CHILE COUP
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Richard Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence, told a Senate committee in testimony released today that there was no doubt in 1970 that the Nixon Administration wanted to have President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile overthrown.

title: DOROTHY L. FERRIS
description: Dorothy Laphan Ferris, an artist and the widow of Hugh Ferriss, architect and painter, died last Friday in Amherst, Mass., while visiting her daughter. She was in her 80's and resided until two years ago at 35 East 9th Street.

title: SINDONA ACCUSED OF ITALIAN BRIBES
Power of Conglomerates Worries Japan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 7A recent study by Japan's increasingly vigorous Fair Trade Commission indicates that the concentration of economic power held by the socalled zaibatsu, or huge conglomerates, here is even greater than previously known.

title: Study Shows Volcanic Activity Surged in Ice Ages
description: The distribution of ash layers in sea floor sediment extracted from deep holes at 84 sites scattered across the world's oceans has shown that of the periods of global eruptions in the last 20 million years the greatest period coincided with the ice ages of the last two million years.

title: Tanker Leaking in Atlantic
description: PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Feb. 9 (AP)A Cpyriote tanker, damaged several days ago in rough seas, was taking on water and leaking fuel oil in the Atlantic Ocean about two miles east of Portsmouth harbor today, the Coast Guard said. A spokesman said that the tanker, the Athenian Star, with 36 aboard, was not in any immediate danger of sinking.

title: REAGAN IS CHEERED BY CALIFORNIA G.O.P.
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 9  Republican state leaders cheered former Gov. Ronald Reagan, scoffed at thirdparty talk and laid plans for a comeback at their biennial state convention, which ended today.

title: 800 Labor Israel Delegates Give Committee $1.5Million
description: Some 800 delegates contributed more than $1.5million yesterday to the National Committee for Labor Israel that will he used by Histradrut. Israel's labor federation, to carry out its program of health, educational and socialwelfare services among workers and new immigrants.

title: Auto Industry Backlog Declined a Bit in January
description: DETROIT, Feb. 9 (AP)The auto industry's backlog of unsold cars at the end of January showed the first decline since the diastrous 1975 model year began last September, but was still far larger than what the industry considers necessary, according to Ward's Automotive Report.

title: Russell Shuns Hall of Fame Bid
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 9 (UPI) Seattle SuperSonics coach Bill Russell, the former Boston Celtics star who was elected to the National Basketball Hall of Fame yesterday, said today he would refuse induction.

title: Liberal Democrats Seek Strong, Viable Candidate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9"The liberals can't find a horse, said Anne Wexler Duffey, a prominent Democratic organizer, and when they can't find a horse they feel insecure.

title: Nine Months After Lisbon Coup, Jubilance Gives Way to Conflict
Quotation of the Day
description: We must measure Orson Welles by his courage and the intensity of his personal vision. He has combined a mighty will with a child's heart to produce a legacy of enduring creation.George Stevens Jr., director of the American Film Institute, presenting the institute's Life Achievement Award to Mr. Welles. [22:3.]

title: RalphP.Suechting Weds Susan Hardy
description: Susan Hardy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Hardy of New York and Durham, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Ralph Porter Suechting of Troy, Mont., son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Suechting of Neenah, Wis. The Rev. Robert K. Fell of the United Church of Durham performed the ceremony at the Hardy's Durham home.

title: Battle for Mekong River Critical for Phnom Penh
The Other News
description: International

title: State Housing Starts in 74 Were Lowest in 25 Years
description: TRENTONThe number of new homes authorized for construction in New Jersey last year plunged to half of the 1973 total, a 25year low.

title: Copper Companies Curtailing Production
description: United States copper companies, squeezed by rising inventories and tumbling prices, are curtailing mine and smelter operations and laying off thousands of workers.

title: CENTRAL BANKERS TO STUDY DOLLAR
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 9 (Reuters)  Governors of the Western world's main central banks will review recent. support operations to shore up the dollar when they open a twoday meeting tomorrow at the Sank for International settlements.

title: A New Dean Is Named At New York Medical
description: Dr. Samuel H. Rubin, a professor of medicine at New York Medical College since 1965 and its executive dean since 1972, has been named dean of the medical college and vice president for academic affairs.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: No Shortage of GrainFed Beef Foreseen
description: DALLAS, Feb. 6if you are fond of tender, juicy, grainfed beef, you'll find that it will still be available in the coming months, despite the recession and a financially painful year for cattle feeders.

title: 76ersb Win,10997, Halt Bulls Streak
10 U.S. Judges in State Report No Extra Income
description: TRENTON, Feb. 9 (AP)None of the 10 Federal District Court judges in New Jersey received income in 1974 for extrajudicial services, such as speechmaking or lectures, according to financial statements they have filed.

title: Ballet: Tinkering Again With Quixote
description: When George Balanchine's spectacular Don Quixote was new, nearly 10 years ago now, much could be forgiven it. For one thing it represented New York City Ballet's emergence as a great national ballet in its own splendid, and then new, theater, the New York State Theater. Don Quixote was almost a symbol of necessary grandeur.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Colby, 11, Victor in Ski Jump
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 9Rhett Colby, an 11yearold Lake Placid athlete, won the junior Division 4 championships in the New York State crosscountry and ski jumping tournaments today. He covered the four kilometers crosscountry course in 14 minutes 35 seconds and came back to win the jumping championship with two jumps of 63 feet for 119.1 points.

title: Art: Capturing the Spirit Of the Rubens Creativity
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.Of all the great European painters the one now least loved is Sir Peter Paul Rubens. Something in his godlike and inexhaustible assurance is offensive to today's tastes. We prefer what is fragmented, ambiguous, angst  ridden. People who have been brought up to think of the conditions of human life in terms of alienation, of the divided self and of the state as the natural enemy of the individual are not going to care for Rubens. Rubens lived at one with himself, at one with the international establishment, at one with the church and at one with the state.

title: Split on Study Panel Is Said to Endanger City Charter Revision
description: The first two reports of the State Charter Revision Commission for New York City have disclosed a split in the commission that, some politicians say, could jeopardize the proposed new City Charter when it goes before the electorate in November.

title: Kissinger Off to Mideast To Seek Interim Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Secretary of State Kissinger left for the Middle East tonight on an exploratory mission that he hoped would lead to a further interim agreement between Israel and Egypt next month.

title: Turkey's Rule in North Cyprus Firm and Secretive
description: NICOSIA, CyprusThe Turkish Army rules northern Cyprus with a strong hand, raising doubts even among Turkish Cypriotes about its willingness to yield territory or control.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: It will be of more interest, perhaps, to those who write about food rather than those who like to read about it to learn the name of the first newspaper food columnist as well as the meal served to inaugurate the institution.

title: China Completes Pipeline To Step Up Oil Exports
description: China has enhanced her growing role as a petroleum exporter by completing her first largediameter pipeline from Manchurian oilfields to a tanker terminal on the Yellow Sea.

title: 2Year Extension Asked by State Panel to Finish Catskills Study
description: STAMFORD, N. Y., Feb. 9 The Temporary State Commission to Study the Catskills asked today for two more years to complete a detailed program to meet the main needs of the Catskill Mountains region  a control of land use to protect the scenic beauty of the area and economic development to provide more jobs for local residents.

title: Mr. Kissinger's War: I
description: WASHINGTONA letter from Saigon: The writer says he is amazed at the American debate on aid to Vietnam. The argument seems to be all about war, he saysabout arms to help President Thieu fight the Communists tor years more. Does no one in America think of politics instead of war? Does no one realize that even rightists in South Vietnam now want Thieu out of office so a deal can be negotiated with the Communists and the fighting ended?

title: BASKETBALL
description: Colleges

title: KENNEDY FAVORS U.S. TIES TO CUBA
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 9 (UPI) Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the trade embargo against Cuba was a mistake, and ineffective anyway, and called on the United States to normalize relations with the Government of Premier Fidel Castro.

title: Dentist on Errand Of Mercy Is Slain In Holdup Attempt
description: A 65yearold dentist from Newburgh, N.Y., was shot and killed by two holdup men here yesterday afternoon as he walked to a neighborhood drug store to pick up medicine for his invalid motherinlaw in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: Leader of Guardsmen Is Credited With Peaceful Ending of Indians Seizure of Wisconsin Novitiate
description: GRESHAM, Wis,The peaceful ending last week to a volatile, potentially bloody occupation by armed Indians of a vacant religious facility came about in large measure, observers here believe, because of the presence of the Wisconsin National Guard under the command of a colonel who practiced tact and restraint.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Arts and Leisure section of The New York Times yesterday, the date for the performance of Mary Lou's Mass by Mary Lou Williams at St. Patrick's Cathedral was incorrectly given. It will be performed Feb. IS at 2 P.M.

title: Advertising
description: It looks as if New York may well turn out to be a battleground for the country's two major cigarette companies seeking dominance in the new superlength field.

title: AGNES CULVER DIES; ARCHIVIST OF PRINTS
description: Agnes Moe Culver, president of Culver Pictures, Inc., here, died yesterday in White Plains (N.Y.) Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 1 Lynwood Road, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: City Welfare Rolls Expected to Reach 1.2 Million in 1976
description: Welfare officials are forecasting increases of 250,000 people on New York City's relief rolls in a 20month period starting this spring.

title: NBC Radio Will Sell a News Service
description: NBC Radio announced yesterday plans to begin a 24houraday national news service, separate from the NBC radio network, that would package an allnews format for local stations around the country, using the resources of NBC News.

title: Sir Robert Robinson, Chemist, Nobel Winner in 1947, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Feb. 9Sir Robert Robinson, who won the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1947 died yesterday at his home in Great Missenden, 30 miles northwest of here. He was 88 years old.

title: WALTER RYDD
description: Walter Rydd, an industrial nurse in the medical department of The New York Times, died yesterday afternoon at his home. He was 63 years old and lived at 218 Broad Avenue, Leonia, N. J.

title: Gamblers Lucky in Crash
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Feb. 9 (UPT)A gambler's special chartered aircraft with 44 persons aboard lost power and crashed today during takeoff in a snowstorm. None of the 38 passengers and six crew members were seriously injured. the Federal Aviation Administration reported. The tour group was returning from a casino to Houston when the accident occurred.

title: Dr. Goldmann ReElected
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 9 (Reuters)Dr. Nahum Goldmann was reelected tonight to the presidency of the World Jewish Congress. Dr. Goldmann, 79 years old, was the only candidate.

title: ELLIS REEDHILL
description: Ellis ReedHill, a retired rear admiral in the Coast Guard who had been the service's engineer in chief in Washington, died Friday in Charleston (S.C.) Hospilaf. He was 85 years old and lived in Summerville, S.C.

title: FUND CUTOFF URGED FOR NURSING HOMES
description: The head of the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy urged the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare yesterday to cut off Federal payments to nursing homes that did not remove substantive violations within three months.

title: 1974 BILL CALLED AID TO M'GOVERN, NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) The Senate acted last year to turn a minor bill helping the upholstery industry into a benefit reportedly worth $800,000 to the 1972 Presidential candidates, Richard M. Nixon and George McGovern, according to a news account.

title: Books of The Times
description: Near the beginning of Here at The New Yorker, Brendan Gill describes very accurately what his 50thbirthday present to the magazine might well have been. My intention, he writes, is to follow the principle upon which the Talk of the Town department of the magazine is based: I will try to cram these paragraphsfull of facts and give them a weight and shape no greater than that of a cloud of blue butterflies.For such an image of fancifulness and inconsequentiality serves well to describe corporation biography, especially one turned out by someone who has been serving the institution for four decades and is presumably beholden to his job, his fellow workers, his employers, and theimage of his corporation. A cloud of blue butterflies exactly! And a puff of hot air to waft it. But though it's true Mr. Gill's text is broken up into paragraphs filled with facts and other things, and though they now and then turn blue in a way that The New Yorker in its primness has never done, the image couldn't possibly be less descriptive of what Mr. Gill has turned out.

title: Distant Drummer Is Named Best of Irish Setters
Dog Writers Honor Fletcher of Times
description: For the 11th successive year, Walter R. Fletcher of The New York Times has been honored by the Dog Writers Association of America.

title: Dangers in Ethiopia
description: Twice in less than a year Asmara, capital of the northern Ethiopian province of Eritrea, has played a key role in the suddenly greatly increased tempo of change in a country that once seemed almost changeless. It was in Asmara late last February that the military mutiny first broke out, a mutiny that led to the downfall of Emperor Haile Selassie and produced an almost clandestine provisional military government which has promised revolutionary socioeconomic changes.

title: Pope Paul Beatifies French EducatorNun
description: ROME, Feb. 9Pope Paul VI today officiated at the beatification of Marie Eugene Milleret, a 19thcentury French educator and nun who founded the order of the Sisters of the Assumption.

title: Portugal's Torment
description: Nine months after a coup that set Portugal on a democratic course, the nation is drifting in suspicion, fear and intolerance. Page 8.

title: Fraud Is Increasing Costs to Consumers
Music: Adroit Variations
West German Chemical Giants Plan Additional Expansion in U.S.
description: BONN, Feb. 9The purchase of the FosterGrant Plastics Company in December by the giant Hoechst Chemical Company marks a turning point but by no means an end to the expansion of German companies in the United States, according to officials of chemical concerns.

title: Soviet Astronauts Enjoy Flight Into Fantasies of Disney World
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 9  Soviet astronauts soaked up some Disney World fantasy today with their American counterparts before starting their nexttolast training session for the joint ApolloSoyuz flight this summer.

title: A Few Landlords Accused Of Many Brooklyn Abuses
description: A handful of landlords in Brooklyn are responsible for a disproportionate number of complaints from tenants, housing inspectors and community leaders about poorlyrun apartment houses, city records show.

title: CORPORATE BONDS EXPANDING RALLY
description: The corporate bond market, riding on the crest of heavy demand and rising prices, faces a relatively light calendar this week because of the Lincoln's Birthday observance on Wednesday. Spurred initially by the Federal Reserve's push to lower interest rates, the rise in corporate bonds now bears all the signs of a classic rally. The topgrade issues responded first, with January's offerings of $3.6billion in straight corporate debt snapped up by purchasers.

title: Stardust Mel Wins Stakes In California
Where Coffee Green Is Money Green
description: It's one job that has no coffee break. The men who do it really love coffee, but they never swallow a drop on duty. They can be pokerfaced and demanding, but unlike El Exigente, they have never, as far as they know, inspired fiesta or revolution.

title: Orson Welles Gets Film Institute Award
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9Orson Welles, the film maker and actor who remains one of Hollywood's most enigmatic personalities, received tonight the American Film Institute's Life Achievement Award.

title: Farewell Party
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP)Rabbi Korff said today that he did not attend a party given by Mr. Nixon last night for his departing staff.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1975

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: It's dog day, no doubt about it, today and tomorrow at Madison Square Garden, as the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show returns for its 99th competition. There will he more than 3,000 dogs, more than 125 breeds and varieties (such as ShihTzus, Lhasa Apsos, Kuvaszok and Keeshonden) with hopeful owners nearby, yearning for that grand prize. Judging will begin at 9 A.M. and benching areas will be open until 11 P.M. both days, with appraisals of dags in the working, terrier and nonsporting groups on Monday and of sporting, hound and toy classes Tuesday.

title: 82 in Congress Urge Ford To Phase Out Indochina Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)Eightytwo members of Congress asked President Ford today for a dialogue on phasing out all United States aid to South Vietnam and Cambodia.

title: RUSSELL K. BRANSCOM
description: Russell K, Branscom, who retired at the end of 1969 as a director and vice president for industrial and public relations of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, died Thursday in Bethlehem, Pa. He was 62 years old.

title: Nets Trounce Squires by 11790
Knicks Routed, 105 to 88
description: BOSTON, Feb. 9for the second time in 24 hours, the New York Knicks today were on the receiving end of a thrashing from the Boston Celtics, the defending National Basketball Association champions who, after some early season problems that included the loss of Dave Cowens for 17 games, seem to be rolling in championship form again.

title: C.I.A. Got Credentials of Police To Use in Domestic Operations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Central Intelligence Agency has, on at least two occasions, obtained credentials from local police departments for use in operations inside the United States.

title: State Budget Director
description: One of Albany's most illconcealed secrets came to an end over the weekend when Governor Carey's duplicating machine admitted what everyone had known for a coupleof weeksthat 34yearold Peter C. Goldmark Jr. would be the $47,800  a  year State Budget DiMan in the Newsrector. Governor Carey knows political imagery and Mr. Goldmark knows staff politics, so neither had been eager that the new appointee should be identified with the controversial $10.6billion tax and spending program that Mr. Carey disclosed recently.

title: The Future of U.D.C.
description: Only two things are certain in the current crisis and confusion about the New York State Urban Development Corporation. First, under the creative leadership of Edward J. Logue, the agency has made impressive progress in doing a necessary and difficult job. Second, this billiondollar program of vital public construction, now near bankruptcy, must not go down the drain. It has fulfilled its mandate of producing affordable housing in places where conventional builders will not go, and at a time when that is almost impossible to do.

title: Sakamoto Wins Marathon
description: KYOTO, Japan, Feb. 9Mineteru Sakamoto overtook favored Seppo Nikkari of Finland at the 35kilometer mark and won the seventh Kyoto marathon (26 miles 385 yards) in 2 hours 17 minutes and 15.4 seconds today.

title: Philadelphian Is Named Yasir Arafat Colbert
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 9  Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, has reeived a letter from Mr. and Mrs. Robert Colbert of Philadelphia saying that they had named their 2monthold son Yasir Arafat Colbert:

title: MEANY FORECASTS RATE OF JOBLESS MAY BE 10% BY JULY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that the nation's unemployment rate may reach 10 per cent by July.

title: More NonHispanic Whites Go on Home Relief Here
description: Steadily increasirg numbers of nonHispanic whites have joined the city's welfare rolls in recent years and, by various informal estimates, now constitute 13 or 14 per cent of all welfare recipients here.

title: Sticking With It
description: WASHINGTON  A Communist rocket, fired with the intent of killing civilians in the capital of Cambodia, exploded in a school and slaughtered a score of children.

title: BLACK BUSINESSES ARE HARDPRESSED
description: The deepening recession is taking a heavy toll of the nation's blackowned businesses.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An offduty Newark policeman traded shots with and killed an alleged holdup man in a Newark bar when the officer interrupted a robbery. The patrolman, Robert Embry, was grazed in the chest by one bullet and three other bullets fired at him pierced his clothes, the police said. He was treated at Beth Israel Medical Center and released.

title: MEANY FORECASTS RATE OF JOBLESS MAY BE 10% BY JULY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that the nation's unemployment rate may reach 10 per cent by July.

title: A P.L.O. SPOKESMAN TELLS OF EXECUTION
description: ROME, Feb. 9A spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization has stated that the leader of guerrillas who attacked a United States airliner at Rome's airport in December, 1973, has been executed, the Italian Communist newspaper, L'Unita reported today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Korff Reports Nixon Plans No Public Role at Present
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 9Rabbi Baruch Korff said today that former President Richard M. Nixon, in view of his poor physical and emotional health, had no intention at present of seeking either Republican party chores or foreign policy assignments.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Stock Prices of Major Copper Companies

title: West German Military Plane With 42 Missing Off Crete
description: SUDA, Crete, Feb. 9 (AP)A West German transport plane with 42 persons aboard apparently crashed into the sea today as it approached this Greek island during a severe storm, an airport spokesman said.

title: Bruins End Islanders Streak, 51
description: BOSTON, Feb. 9 Steamrollered the last time they visited the Bruins yellow ice, the Islanders were flattened again tonight, 51, before a crowd of 14,519.

title: Portugal's Torment
description: Nine months after a coup that set Portugal on a democratic course, the nation is drifting in suspicion, fear and intolerance. Page 8.

title: Information, Ltd.
description: One of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's better ideas was its rediscovery after a lapse of many years of the Limited Stop Bus. For many New Yorkers tired of traveling to and from work at the normal stopandstart snail's pace, this particular reinvention of wheels that move was a welcome indication that somebody at the M.T.A. thinks and cares.

title: Farming Is Set Back in Vietnam
description: LONG TRACH, South Vietnam; Feb. 5  The farmers here have never heard of protecting the ecology. But they have stopped using American insecticides to kill the worms in their rice.

title: I.R.A. ANNOUNCES NEW CEASEFIRE
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 9The I.R.A. Provisionals announced tonight an openended renewal of their ceasefire in Northern Ireland and Britain.

title: Excerpts From 1960 Kaplan Report to Wagner on Nursing Homes
U.S. Role in Wage Dispute Is a Clue to Dunlop Aims
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Administration intervened last week in a labormanagement situation for the first time since wageprice controls lapsed nine months ago.

title: High and Low Notes Mark Black Week
description: In one miniature amphitheater called a pit, in the American Museum of Natural History's People Center, there is a demonstration and talk on African influences in Puerto Rico. In another pit a lecture on Haitian history ends and one on how the English language puts down blacks begins.

title: Ramirez, Miss Evert Take Tennis Finals
Sabres, Montreal Tie, 44
Police Kill Slaying Suspect
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9 (UPI) Michael Darnell Car, wanted on a murder charge in Versailles, Ky., was shot and killed by sheriff's deputies early today at a motel in the Pico Rivera district. The police said they had been watching the motel, waiting for the fugitive to return, after a teenaged girl who was traveling with him told officers about the Kentucky slaying. The subject, who was later discovered not to have been armed, was shot after he made threatening moves toward them, the officers said.

title: Indiana, U. C. L. A. Title Choices
description: Indiana and U.C.L.A. are shaping up as the class of college basketball.

title: Keeping Ma Bell in One Piece
description: NEW HAVENThe Government is suing to break up the longdistance telephone network of the United States, and to divorce the Bell System's manufacturing unit, and perhaps even Bell Laboratories, from its operating companies.

title: Personal Finance: CreditCard Liability
description: One of the most important sections of the Truth in Lending Act is a 1970 amendment limiting the liability of credit card holders to $50 for unauthorized use.

title: IRAN SAYS TROOPS REPULSED IRAQIS
Hamburg Staatsoper Reverts to Type
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Feb. 7Things have changed at the Hamburg Staatsoper. A few years ago, when Rolf Liebermann was running the house, a visitor to the opera had a good chance of encountering an avantgarde work by Penderecki, Tai or Kagel, or a 20thcentury stage work by Stravinsky, Krenek, Kiebe, Henze and a dozen so others.

title: Red Smith
description: A gentleman named Harold Gordon of Miami, Fla., has been reading the letters from Phil Bieber that occasionally enrich this space and this has inspired him to take to the typewriter on his own. Nothing surprising about that. Mr. Bieber is a horseman of long experience and a raconteur of inexhaustible resources whose tales of the turf would strike a responsive chord in a dead man. And, Mark Twain wrote in another connection, I don't mean a fresh dead man, either. I mean one who has been dead for years and years. As his letter shows, Mr. Gordon isn't dead at all. He writes: Ths incident happened in about 1934 at Rockingham Park, Salem, N. H. I was working there at the time and had a fivehorse win parlay going for me. Four of the horses had already won and I had it all to win on Phil Bieber's horse Pytchley.

title: Abuse and Assault Case Plague Forbes's Return
description: BOSTON, Feb. 9  His Bruin teammates have been calling him Jailbird in a blundering attempt to help him make light of his troubles. But Dave Forbes says it will take a little longer than he expected to get back in shape, physically and especially psychologically, after a 10came suspension.

title: TURKS MAY CLOSE SOME U.S. BASES
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 9Turkey will probably order the closing of some United States military installations here it Congress does not restore military aid to Ankara soon, according to diplomatic and Government sources here.

title: Crash Foils a Cabby In Bid to Halt Suicide
Papa Guilty on 2 Counts In U.S. Drug Trial Here
FRANK PERLS DIES; COAST ART DEALER
description: Frank Richard Perls, an internationally known art dealer, died Saturday in Beverly Hills, Calif., where he had his art gallery. He was 64 years old and underwent open heart surgery last Dec. 19.

title: TV: Lizzie Borden, Temple Drake Are Portrayed
description: Tonight's schedule is domiDated by two American women: the fictional Temple Drake and the notorious Lizzie Borden of Falls River, Mass. Temple is the centerpiece of Requiem for a Nun, the William Faulkner novel adapted for the stage by Ruth Ford. A 90minute Hollywood Television Theater production of the play begins on public television at 8 o'clock. At 9, on ABC, Elizabeth Montgomery plays the title role in The Legend of Lizzie Borden, a speculative retelling of one of the most infamous and bizarre murder cases of the past century.

title: Westminster Show Opens Here Today
description: With the opening of the 99th annual Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden this morning, New York becomes the dog capital of the world for two days.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
BOB SYLVESTER, 68, COLUMNIST, DEAD
description: Bob Sylvester, entertainment columnist for The Daily News, where since 1951 he had written Dream Street, died early yesterday of a heart ailment at his home. Mr. Sylvester, who became 68 years old last Friday, lived at Old Montauk Highway, Montauk. L.I.

title: Miller Takes Hope Golf By 3 Shots on 68339
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 9 It was never in doubt. Johnny Miller, the 27yearold superman of the pro golf tour, easily won the Bob Hope Desert Classic today by a margin of three strokes.

title: About New York
$35,000 Loss Declared In Sale of Hitler's Car
description: DUNEDIN, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP)A Wisconsin car dealer paid $141,000 today for Adolf Hitler's sleek black parade car, but the price was $35,000 below what the seller said he paid for the car a year ago.

title: Stein to Question Gagner on 60 Report
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. and former Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan are among the witnesses scheduled to be called next week by a state commission trying to unravel a 15yearold mystery: What happened to the Kaplan report?

title: but Not in Energy
description: In the field of energy, there is no equivalent on Capitol Hill to the traditional taxwriting committees or the newly formed budget committees. The defeat in the House last year of the committee reorganization plan urged by Representative Richard Bolling, Missouri Democrat, deprives the House of a unified committee on energy. Responsibility in the Senate likewise remains fragmented among a halfdozen rival committees.

title: G.O.P. Right Wing Seems to Rule Out Support for Ford for 1976 Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Leaders of the conservative movement in Republican patics are talking about campaign strategy for 1976, seemingly with scarcely a thought of supporting President Ford as a candidate.

title: Kissinger Off to Mideast To Seek Interim Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Secretary of State Kissinger left for the Middle East tonight on an exploratory mission that he hoped would lead to a further interim agreement between Israel and Egypt next month.

title: CITY PLANNING USE OF FEDERAL GRANT
description: The city is preparing to apply for $101million as its share of the first $2.5 billion in Federal aid available under the block grant approach embodied in the Housing and Community Renewal Act of 1974.

title: Judge Wright Sues to Be Reassigned To His Seat on Criminal Court Bench
description: Judge Bruce McM. Wright, who was transferred last month to Civil Court, sued yesterday to be reassigned to Criminal Court.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CALCUTTA, Feb. 10 (UPI)China turned back the clock 10 years today and recaptured the men's and women's team titles in the 33d world table tennis championships. The men's team posted a 53 victory over Yugoslavia for the Swaythling Cup and the women dethroned South Korea, 32, for the Corbillon Cup. The double triumph was a repeat of a 1965 performance which was matched by Japan two years later.

title: New Labor Secretary
description: John T. Dunlop, the former Harvard dean, whom President Ford has chosen as Secretary of Labor, represents an admirable blend of pragmatist and scholar. For three decades he has proved both innovative and skillful in promoting civilized labormanagement relations, particularly in the frozen wastes of the construction industry.

title: U.S. Agency Issues Show Drop in Prices
description: Government security prices fell yesterday amid signs that the Federal Reserve, while continuing a policy of easier credit conditions, may be slowing the downward pace of interest rates. Treasury coupon and Federal agency issues, notably in the intermediate maturities of five to seven years, dropped by as much as threeeighths to onehalf point.

title: Exxon Discloses Pact for Sale Of 50% of Alaskan Natural Gas
description: The Exxon Company, U.S.A., said yesterday it had reached an agreement with two gas transmission companies to sell 50 per cent of the expected production of Prudhoe Bay natural gas from the North Slope of Alaska.

title: Pressure Shield
description: The most useful activities engaged in by foundations often tend also to be the most controversial. Intervention on behalf of the disadvantaged, the weak or the unrepresented frequently leads to clashes with entrenched special interests.

title: A.&P. Told to End Ads for Products Not in the Stores
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) One of the nation's largest food chains, A.&P., has been ordered to stop advertising goods at a stated price unless the company insures that it has the advertised products to sell, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: H. L. WENGER, DOCTOR DEVISED SPINAL AID
description: Dr. H. Leslie Wenger, an orthopedic surgeon who devised the spinejack operation to correct a spinal curve known as scoliatic deformity, died of cancer Feb. 3 in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 78 years old and lived at 123 West 197th Street.

title: City Loses $120,000 In Meter Receipts In 3Ton Coin Theft
description: Approximately $120,000 in nickels, dimes and quarters from the city's parking meters was stolen over the weekend from a safe by burglars who apparently escaped with their three tons of loot in trucks that would have been used to move the money to the bank, the pclice said yesterday.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Rapt attention is rare at fashion showsthere's often music to distract you, friends to catch up with. But you could hear a pin drop at the showing of James Galanos's spring collection yesterday afternoon at the Plaza. Not that the designer would leave one carelessly in any of his dresses so it could fall out.

title: Texas Studies Phone Rates Bell Has Charged Since World War II
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 10Telephone rates levied by the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company in Texas, where there is no statewide public utilities commission to regulate rates, are embroiling the thirdlargest operating subsidiary of the Bell System in new problems.

title: ISRAELI RIGHTISTS ASSAIL KISSINGER
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 10The Israeli rightwing Opposition called on the Government today to hold new elections before agreeing to withdraw from the Mitla and Gidi passes and Abu Rudeis oilfields in the Sinai Peninsula as part of a new interim peace arrangement with Egypt.

title: Capital Evasion
description: Mayor Beame's proposed 197576 Executive Capital Budget is a revealing document which helps to expose both the extent and a principal cause of this city's fiscal distress.

title: Most Brokers in the Black Last Year, Exchange Says
IRAQ SAID TO SEEK ARAB TALK ON IRAN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 10 Iraq was reported today to be seeking a highlevel meeting of Arab countries bordering on the Persian Gulf to seek support against Iranian military aid to Kurdish rebels northern Iraq.

title: BANKER IS TERMED H.U.D. LOAN CONTACT
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 10 (AP)Joel Kline, a bankrupt financial manipulator, testified today that he knew that an Annapolis banker, who is under Federal investigation, was the man to contact about payoffs to get loans from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: BOMAR WILL ASK REORGANIZATION
description: The Bowmar Instruments Corporation, a pioneer in the handheld calculator market said yesterday that it would file today for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Senator Ammond Put On Party Panel Again
description: TRENTON, Feb. 10The Democratic majority in the State Senate decided today to readmit Senator Alene S. Ammond to its closed caucus, at the order of the Federal Court and on the advice of a special majority committee.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: United Press International

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday stated incorrectly that Bayer, A. G., the West German chemical concern, is organized in the United States under the Baychem Corporation, based in New York. Bayer's chief affiliate in this country is the Mobay Chemical Corporation of Pittsburgh.

title: People and Business
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company announced last night the naming of its president and chief operating officer, Raymond H. Herzog, as president and chief executive officer, effective immediately.

title: 2,000 Soviet Jews in Rome Area Await U.S. Immigration Visas
description: ROME, Feb. 10About 2,000 Soviet Jews are reported living in or near Rome awaiting visas to emigrate to the United States.

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market paused to catch its breath yesterday. Prices finished slightly lower in subdued trading after two weeks of hectic volume and sharp advances.

title: Rail Unit Contends Subsidies to Total Less Than Budgeted
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 10 (AP) The United States Railway Association said today the total cost of subsidizing rail service on lines not included in the reorganization of Northeast railroads would be less than the amount already budgeted for those subsidies.

title: Mazowsze Troupe Dances and Smiles In Varied Program
description: Warmed by the glow of official benevolence, national song and dance companies have flowered in the various regions of Poland. Rzeszowiacy is the latest one to visit, and while it does not have the highenergy thrust we associate with the Mazowsze troupe, it did project the friendly ambiance of a good local celebration, at Town Hall on Sunday.

title: Protesters Break Up Meeting of Students And Cavanagh Here
description: First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh walked angrily out of a lecture at Fordham University last night when a score of protesters interrupted his informal talk to three dozen urbanaffairs and politicalscience students.

title: U.S. Court Delays Army's Plan to Kill Birds at Two Bases
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10A Federal appeals court today blocked for at least several days the Army's plans to eradicate some millions of blackbirds roosting for the winter at Army bases in Kentucky and Tennessee.

title: Early Celebration
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 10 (UPI)Balloons and streamers adorned balconies, and tipsy revelers sought to catch doubloons and beads from parade floats today on the eve of the city's Mardi Gras celebration.

title: Menuhin Rejects Appeal to Join Boycott of UNESCO Over Israel
description: PARIS, Feb. 10  Yehudi Menuhin and the executive committee of the International Music Council, an affiliated body of UNESCO, have come out against any boycott of the organization because of its attitude toward Israel.

title: Music: Ciccolini Returns
description: Aldo Ciccolini first broke into international attention in the late nineteenforties, when he won a spate of contests, and he made his New York debut in 1950. Since an appearance with the New York Philharmonic in 1957, however, the Italian pianist had not been back here until his Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday. It can be chalked up as a brilliantly successful return, even though an often puzzling one.

title: Assembly Passes Bill to Curb Hiring of Illegal Aliens
description: TRENTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) The State Assembly voted unanimously today to penalize New Jersey employers who take jobs away from United States citizens by hiring illegal aliens.

description: LONDON, Feb. 10Arab efforts to exclude Jewish banking interests from financial deals on the international loan market have touched off a conroversy in the London financial community over whether to oppose such moves with a united front.

title: DR. MARGARET G. RIGNEY
description: Dr. Margaret Gardiner Rigney, a child psychologist who founded the nursery school at St. Joseph's College for Women and later taught at Hunter College from 1957 to her retirement in 1972, died Saturday at her home, 215 East 68th Street. She was 64 years old and the wife of Edward E. Rigney, a lawyer.

title: Malice Toward None, Charity for All
description: All these years, Muhammad Ali always had so much faith in himself, he didn't need hope. Now he's discovered charity. Under crystal chandeliers in the Hotel Plaza yesterday, the world heavyweight boxing champion disclosed his philanthropic plans for underprivileged blacks and Chuck Wepner, his accomplice in their March 24 title bout. Ali described his new life causefor all my championship fights from here on out, after I pay my taxes, after I pay my expenses and my helpers, I don't want no money. He mentioned that his earnings will be distributed by the United Negro College Fund, by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, by the Black Muslims, among other organizations. I got about $2million I can put my hands on for myself, he said. I got enough for me. But it won't be enough unless he organizes a foundation with honest supervision. It won't be enough unless the Internal Revenue Service approves the details of his donations. Joe Louis once thought he had all the money he needed, too. Ali's promise, while admirable, must be suspect until proven. Equally suspect is Ali's promise that he will rely on body punches to deflate Wepner, whose credentials as a challenger have been questioned by purists because of his tendency to bleed around the eyebrows. At least Chuck didn't bleed at the Plaza yesterday when the title bout in the Cleveland Coliseum was formally announced. But even with Wepner's repuation for bleeding at the weighin, Ali's attitude toward him is more insulting than charitable.

title: Abraham Tow, Pediatrician At Polyclinic Hospital. 75
description: Dr. Abraham Tow, a pediatrician here until 1959 when he moved to Logan, W. Va., died there Wednesday. He was 75 years old.

title: Briefs On The Arts

He will be replaced by Claude Frank, who will play Beethoven's First Piano Concerto instead of the one by Mozart scheduled by Mr. Serkin. Mr. Frank is also playing the Beethoven work, as announced, in the orchestra's Thursday and Saturday night concerts.

title: Tough Chinese LineDiscipline, Orderis Emerging
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 10The first political pronouncements of the realigned and supposedly moderate leadership that was installed in Peking last month are heavily emphasizing the need for discipline and social order. Between the lines, they seem to be saying there will be less room for dissidence and debate in the Communist party.

title: LOCAL VETO VOTED ON OTB PARLORS
East Side Apartments Popular at Any Price
description: Item: A fourbedroom cooperative apartment on Park Avenue was put on the market recently and one prospective buyer estimated that it needed $70,000 to $100,000 in renovations to put it in good condition. The windows were loose. The electrical wiring was inadequate. The walls had not been painted in years and there was linoleum on the bedroom floor. the asking price for the apartment was $150,000.

title: Grosz Show Sparks Purchase Museum

Y., Feb. 10 Nine months ago, the Neuberger Museum on the campus of the State University at Purchase, in upper Westchester County, was inaugurated with a good deal of fanfare. Since that time, the museum has been very little heard from, and has evidently been undergoing a reorganization. Bryan Robertson, the British critic who came over from London to be the founding director, has now departed, and under its new acting director, Jeffrey Hoffeld, the museum has for the first time announced a busy program of forthcoming exhibitions and events.

description: Sarah T Portrait of a Teenage Alcoholic, a twohour production that NBCTV will present at 8 o'clock tonight, uses fiction to grapple with a real nationwide problem. One teenager in 20 has a serious drinking problem. One in 10 will become an alcoholic. And the problem is growing.
