title: Pakistan Ties Opposition Party to Killing
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Feb. 10The Government imposed a ban today on the National Awami party, in a move meant to eliminate the main opposition organization from national politics.

title: KISSINGER OPENS TALKS IN ISRAEL ON SINAI ACCORD
Mendell N. Fisher, Zionist, Dies; Active in Land Purchase Fund
description: Mendel N. Fisher, a major figure in the programs and activity of the Jewish National Fund of Americathe land development arm of the World Zionist Organization in Israel died yesterday of cancer. He was 77 years old and lived at 382 Central Park West.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES REGISTER DECLINE
description: Soybean sales by farmers over the weekend and reports that Brazilian soybeans were still priced under United States beans in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, led to a decline in soybean futures prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Law Revised to Extradite Kallinger's Son to Bergen
description: TRENTON, Feb. 10  The State Senate overwhelminglyn approved and, sent to the Assembly today an amendment, designed to close a loophole in the state's criminalextradition act as it relates to juveniles.

title: Portable TV Sets Recalled Because of Possible Peril
description: BLUE BELL, Pa., Feb. 10 (UPI)The PhilcoFord Corporation announced today that it would recall more than 10,000 black and white nineinch portable television sets because of a possible electric shock hazard.

title: Alfred A. Beckwith Dead; A Consulting Engineer, 82
description: Allred A. Beckwith, a retired consulting engineer and former construction adviser to the State Housing Authority, died Thursday in North Salem, N.Y. His age was 82.

title: College and School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Impact of Watergate Abroad Found Slight
description: TOKYO, Feb. 10The American experience with Watergate has led to the selection of a new Premier in Japan, stronger emphasis on ethics by public officials in Canada and a greater determination in some countries to use the press to uncover malfeasance.

title: Year of Rabbit Uplifts Chinese Bettors
description: YONKERS, Feb. 10Hundreds of bettors from Chinatown helped Yonkers Raceway celebrate the Year of the Rabbit tonight, a time for thinking only good thoughts about horses that don't go off stride.

title: Oil Countries Slow to Aid India Despite Her Diplomatic Support
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 10India's strong support of the Arab nations has failed to yield substantive economic benefits, according to Indian and foreign economists.

title: What Does Wagner Ring Really Mean?
Counterfeiting Suspect Lost Job as Instructor
description: NEWARK, Feb. 10A 32yearold printer charged with making $1million in highquality counterfeit $10 and $20 bills lost his job as a highschool printing instructor in 1972 because his work was considered unsatisfactory.

title: Theater: Shtetl at Eden
description: A Wedding in Shtetl is an oldtime Second Avenue Yiddish musical comedy done in exactly the same way that they have been turned out for generations. If you haven't been to one of these standard productions for a long while and for some reason miss them, you will find this production at the Eden Theater a rewarding trip backward.

title: Phnom Penh Exodus Early This Year
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 10Every year a number of foreigners leave Phnom Penh during the Communistled insurgents annual son offensiveand almost all come back when the easy life is possible again.

title: Connors Is 61, 62 Winner
West Highland White Takes Westminster Terrier Group
Russell's Decision Remains Puzzle.
description: Bill Russell titled his book, Go Up For Glory. But actually Russell has never been one for personal glory. He has always been outspoken, opinionated and an individualist.

title: U.S. CHARGE SETTLED BY UNION PLANTERS
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 10 (AP)The Union Planters National Bank, its holding company and the investment firm of A.S. Hart & Co. have agreed in Federal court to an order forbidding concealment of losses in future security transactions.

title: 5 Give Up on Coast On Texas Warrant That Alleges Fraud
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 (UPI) Five officials of a company that promoted plans for the Dale, a threewheeled vehicle that backers said would go 70 miles on one gallon of gasoline, surrendered today on Texas arrest warrants charging fraud.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET MEET ON CIVIL ATOM TESTS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 10  The United States and the Soviet Union resumed negotiations here today on a possible ceiling on the force of underground nuclear tests for peaceful purposes.

title: Opera: Das Rheingold, Back at Met, in Near Magical Program
Lower Courts Are Settling 80% of City Felony Cases
Adm. W. C. Chambliss Dies; Was With Halsey in Pacific
description: Rear Adm. William C. Chambliss, retired, who served with Adm. W. F. Halsey in the Pacific during World War II, died last Wednesday in Long Beach, Calif. He was 67 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn drops a lot of names in a new 630page book published in Russian yesterday in Paris by Y.M.C.A. Press, the exiled writer's longtime Russianlanguage publishers. When the Calf Horns the Oak, a title based on a Russian proverb, presents memoirs in the form, of a novel. The calf is said to be Mr. Solzhenitsyn himself, represented as powerless in his attempts to horn the Soviet state. The book covers his life after 1961, when he emerged from clandestinity after deStalinization, and was written mainly in 1967, but has a recent chapter on his expulsion from the Soviet Union and exile in Switzerland.

title: Boy on Snowmobile Killed
description: SOMERSWORTH, N. H., Feb. 10 (AP)The state recorded its first snowmobiling fatality of the year over the weekend when a 12yearold Dover boy was killed. The poice said that Dale Ducharme was killed and a man was injured when the snowmobile they were riding crashed into a tree in a field in Somersworth Friday night.

title: 19 Airlines Agree To Admit to Roles In Illicit Kickbacks
description: Nineteen of the 23 major foreign and domestic airlines that fly between this country and Europe agreed yesterday to admit to Federal prosecutors that they had given illegal kickbacks to travel agents and passengers.

title: Market Averages
description: Monday, February 10, 1975

title: City's Lobbyist Pushes Big 6 Mayors' Projects
description: ALBANY, Feb. 10  The Big 6 Mayors will be in town Wednesday to disclose this year's version of the aid package they will ask from the state.

title: Iranian Oil Revenues Said to Quadruple
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 10 (AP)Iranian oil revenues quadrupled to almost $20billion in 1974, the chairman of the National Iranian Oil Company. Manuchehr Eghbal, showed in the annual report published today.

title: For Coffee Buffs, Clues on Labeling
description: Coffee buffs who buy sacks that bear fancy names of certain coffeegrowing areas may not be getting all they bargain for in their coffee beans.

title: OWNERS CHECKED ON NURSING HOMES
description: The State Health Department has begun what it describes as a crackdown on secret ownerships of nursing homes, a violation of the state Medicaid code that has been reported to be widespread in the industry.

title: Exxon in Gas Accord
description: The Exxon Company, U.S.A., said yesterday it had reached an agreement with two gas transmission companies to sell 50 per cent of the expected production of Prudhoe Bay natural gas from the North Slope of Alaska. Details on Page 59.

title: Bill Proposes Local Votes To Allow Abortion Clinics
description: TRENTON, Feb. 10Assemblyman Robert M. Ruane today introduced a bill requiring that the establishment of abortion clinics within a community be subject to local referendum.

title: City Loses $120,000 In Meter Receipts In 3Ton Coin Theft
description: Approximately $120,000 in nickels, dimes and quarters from the city's parking meters was stolen over the weekend from a safe by burglars who apparently escaped with their three tons of loot in trucks that would have been used to move the money to the bank, the police said yesterday.

title: Policy to Even Exchange Rates Reaffirmed by Central Bankers
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 10 (Reuters)  Western central bankers reaffirmed today existing policy of ironing out exaggerated exchangerate fluctuations but said they made no major new decisions.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 19,000 Now Out in McDonnell Strike in 2 States
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 (AP)Some 19,000 production workers have struck McDonnell Douglas plants in Missouri and California in a wage dispute. Company officials say that jet fighter production will be halted if the strike is a long one.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday stated incorrectly that Bayer, A. G., the West German chemical concern, is organized in the United States under the Baychem Corporation, based in New York. Bayer's chief affiliate in this country is the Mohay Chemical Corporation of Pittsburgh.

title: 2 Committees to Run United Brands On an Interim Basis Under Goldman
description: Jacob E. Goldman, 53yearold chief scientist and group vice president of the Xerox Corporation, announced yesterday that he would head two committees that will assume management responsibility of the United Brands Company.

title: Points Not Always True Guide for N.H.L. Playoffs
description: If the National Hockey League playoffs were to start tomorrow, this is how the teams would line up: Montreal, Buffalo, Philadelphia and Vancouver would receive firstround byes since each tops its division. The remaining eight qualifiers would be grouped by points, with the highest team (Los Angeles, 73 points) playing the lowestranked team (Toronto, 48); the nexthighest (Boston, 71) facing the. nextlowest (St. Louis, 50); the Rangers (66) going against Chicago (56), and the Islanders (58) playing Pittsburgh (57).

title: All Will Donate Purses to Minority Poor
description: Muhammad Ali, who is scheduled to defend his world heavyweight championship against Chuck Wepner in Cleveland on March 24, said yesterday that from now on all my fights are free. All the profits will be given awayfrom both the live gates and closedcircuit television, I will keep only training expenses.

title: Montreal Talks Start With I.O.C.
description: MONTREAL. Feb. 10 (UPI) Members of the Montreal organizing committee for the 1976 Olympics begin talks with the International Olympic Committee tomorrow on problems facing the upcoming summer games.

title: Acrimony Marks L.I. Hearings On Mental Center Accreditation
description: WEST BRENTWOOD, L. I., Feb. 10A woman's fruitless threeyear search for her brother, a mental patient discharged from Pilgrim Psychiatric Center here whose remains were found last December at the edge of the center grounds, was among the accounts related today at a public information interview in the hospital.

title: Study Urges Check on Oil Companies to Guard National Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10A $300,000 federally financed study has concluded that the Government should adopt new techniques to make certain that the behavior of the international oil companies will be consistent with the national interests of the United States.

title: JERSEY BELL WINS RATERISE RULING
Dry Dock Savings Scores High Court In Bankruptcy Case
description: The Dry Dock Savings Bank accused the United States Supreme Court yesterday of unconstitutional action in promulgating new rules of procedure in bankruptcy cases.

title: THREAT TO FREEZE IS CITED BY OPEC
description: VIENNA, Feb. 11 (Reuters)The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries warned today that a major drop in the value of the dollar could threaten OPEC's current oil price freeze.

title: Backlog of Felonies Rose Sharply Here Despite Court Drive
SILVER FUTURES SHOW PRICE GAIN
description: Speculative buying sent silver futures sharply higher on the Commodity Exchange yesterday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 (AP)Bing Crosby reiterated today that the terms offered by the Professional Golfers' Association for his annual tournament were unacceptable. But he added that he hoped an agreement could be reached so the tournament could be played for the 35th time in 1976. We negotiate every year with the P.G.A, said Crosby by telephone from his Hillsborough, Calif., home. I've talked to Bob Hope about this, and we both agree that the terms offered for next year are unacceptable.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: LaMar Watson, an 18year old Newark laborer, was Sentenced to life imprisonment after he was found guilty of a fatal stabbing last June of William J. Aldridge Jr., a law professor at Seton Hall University. The verdict was reached after five and a half hours of deliberation by a jury of four women and eight men following a sevenday trial in Superior Court in Newark. Judge William J. Camarata handed down the mandatory sentence for firstdegree murder, and ordered the defendant taken to the Trenton State Prison.

title: INVESTING IN U. S. FROM ABROAD OFF
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) A Treasury Department official said today that foreign investment in the United States had slowed and lending to other nations had increased as a result of lower United States interest rates.

title: Toros Down Oilers
description: TORONTO, Feb. 11 (UPI)Secondperiod goals by Paul Henderson, Frank Mahovlich and Brian Gibbons led the Toronto Toros to a 43 victory over the Edmonton Oilers Tuesday night. The victory was the Toro's third in a row and moved them 10 points ahead of the thirdplace Oilers in the World Hockey Association's Canadian Division. The Toros other goal was scored by Tom Martin in the first period.

title: Year of Hare Begins With Traditional Bang
BROOKLYN SCHOOL IS CALLED UNSAFE
description: City Councilman Howard Golden shook a loose railing on a fire escape clinging to the brick wall of a 68yearold publicschool building in the Bedford  Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Bowrnar in Chapter XI Step
description: The Bowmar Instrument Corporation filed in Federal District Court here yesterday a petition under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The manufacturer of handheld calculators had announced earlier its intentions to do so. The corporation reported assets of $48.87million and liabilities of $47.47million.

title: Democratic Hopefuls Visiting the City
description: The vanguard of three Democratic Presidential hopefuls visiting the city this week, Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona, went to City Hall yesterday to discuss urban probHems with Mayor Beame and not incidentally pose for pictures with the Mayor.

title: U.S. Life Insurance Office Wrecked in Lebanon Blast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 11An explosion tonight wrecked the offices of the American Life Insurance Company in the southern town of Tyre.

title: Man Held in Boy's Abduction Found Fit for Trial
International Paper Net Up 40% Rubber Concerns Profits Mixed
Effects Will Be Limited On Lincoln's Birthday
description: The observance of Lincoln's Birthday today will affect some, but not all, government and business operations.

title: Contemporary History
description: The advent of Black History Week and of a criminal proceeding in North Carolina against a young woman named Joanne Little conjoin to prove William Faulkner's observation that the past is never really past. Miss Little is black, and the facts surrounding her indictment reek so of injustice that her story conveys the ugly aura of Southern black history of forty and fifty years ago.

title: The Lincoln Legacy
description: Nothing can haunt a politician more than his alleged principles, which is one reason why so many speak boldsounding platitudes and stand foursquare behind the words of nobler men.

title: Unions and Communists Pivotal in Italy
FINANCING ACCORDS REACHED AT MATTEL
description: Mattel, Inc., a major toy producer, announced yesterday it had established agreements with principal lenders covering its longterm financial requirements over the next five years as well as its shortterm working capital needs.

title: College Defends Discharge Of Woman Court Coach
Fire Sends Pupils to 3 New Schools
description: There was a routine fire drill at Public School 6 yesterday, but for some of the youngsters who quietly left the school and lined up at 81st Street and Maclison Avenue, it was a stark remainder of a real fire a few days ago.

title: Israeli General Calls Sinai Passes Vital
description: MITLA PASS, IsraeliOccupied Egypt. Feb. 11Israeli authorities sought today to underscore their reluctance to give up the Mitla Pass and the nearby Gidi Pass in the current round of two Americansponsored EgyptianIsraeli negotiations.

title: Need Help for That Special Gift on Friday?
description: Many people take the line of least resistance and buy candy as a Valentine gift. Nothing wrong with that, though there are more imaginative ways of expressing affection.

title: DR. R. T. MANCINELLI
description: Dr. Ralph T. Mancinelli, a general surgeon and specialist in reconstructive hand surgery in Newark and New York City hosiptals, died Sunday at FlowerFifth Avenue Hospital. His age was 47. He lived at 108 High Street, Orange, N. J.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Egyptians Cite Peace Aim But Rule Out Any Pledges
U.S. DOLLAR VARIES IN EUROPE TRADING
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 11 (UPI)The dollar had neither marked losses nor gains over opening rates on European currency markets today.

title: McFeeley Rallies P.B.A. Behind Plan to Save Jobs
description: Ken McFeeley, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, went into the station houses yesterday to rally his men behind a plan to save the jobs of more than 500 rookies and recruits, promising them that I'll quit before I sell you down the road.

title: W.R. GRACE VOTES ON POLUMBUS BID
description: The board of directors of W. R. Grace & Co. approved yesterday the acquisition of approximately 73 per cent of the outstanding shares of the Polumbus Corporation of Denver for $13.4million. Under a previously announced letter of intent, Grace agreed to pay about $15 a share for the interest in Polumbus, which is engaged in exploration and production of gas and oil in the Rocky Mountain states. Grace also agreed to offer approximately $15 a share to the remaining Polumbus stockholders.

title: Not Hoover, Not Truman
description: PARISWhen Gerald Ford became President of the United States last Aug. 9 there was a massive hope among Americans and also foreigners that the new chief of state would be the kind of unexpected leader, honest, strong and forthright, that Harry Truman proved himself to be when he succeeded Franklin Roosevelt as World War II was ending.

title: Market Place
description: During the Depression consumer finance companies provided a haven for the sophisticated investor. While hundreds of other companies struggled to keep their heads above water, these lenders thrived on the need for personal loans in time of unemployment that reached as high as 25 per cent.

title: Court Refuses to Halt Sale of Detroit Bank
description: DETROIT, Feb. 11 (Reuters)A Wayne County Circuit Court declined today to interfere with the proposed sale of Bank of the Commonwealth stock to Ghaith Pharaon, a Saudi Arabian businessman.

title: ARCHER CANCELED; TWO NEW SERIES SET
description: NBCTV has canceled the detective series Archer, based on the novels of Ross Macdonaid, which is seen Thursdays from 9 P.M. to 10 P.M. and wil rearrange its Thursday night schedule.

title: City Jobless Rate of 12% Is Termed Conceivable
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11The unemployment rate in New York City could conceivably reach 12 per cent in the next two to three months, the head of the State Labor Department told the fiscal committees of the Legislature here today.

title: Black Historians Report Inattention
description: Most black Americans believe that slavery explains not only their presence in the United States but also their present predicament.

title: U.S. Veterans Aid Copter Training for Iranians
description: Recently retired United States Army aviators working for a private American company run by their former commanding officer are providing Iran's emerging army with the latest tactical training in combat helicopter assault warfare.

title: CHALLENGE FOILED BY U.M.W LEADER
A PRESS PROBLEM: VICTIMS OF CRIME
description: One problem confronting a newspaper is the question of how to handle information about crime victims. Will identification of a victim, for example, be needlessly embarrassing, even dangerous, to the victim?

title: Capitals Defeat Rangers
J. P. Melton Named By Carey as Head Of Motor Vehicles
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11Governor Carey' office today announced the appointment of James P. Melton, a Suffolk County lawyer who has long been active in Democratic politics on Long Island, as Commisisoner of Motor Vehicles to succeed Arnold R. Fisher, whose resignation becomes effective Feb. 28.

title: Physicians Link Patients Response to a Drug to the Site of the Injection
description: European and American doctors have made a surprising new observation that challenges traditional concepts about the conventional medical practice of injecting drugs into the muscles of the arms and buttocks.

title: Warning on Candy Pacifiers
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Feb. 11 (UPI) Candy pacifiers made in Belgium and Spain may be hazardous for infants and young children, the American Academy of Pediatrics Accident Prevention Committee said today. The candy can break from its holder and cause a youngster to choke, the committee said in a request that the Federal Food and Drug Administration ban the imports.

title: PoliceHiring Bias Laid to Jersey City
Trouble on B1 Test Flight
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 11 (UPI)The new B1 bomber ran into minor trouble today on its third test flight when cockpit warning lights indicated excessive heat in the huge jet's electrical system.

title: Restaurant Bombed
description: ELIZABETH, Feb. 11 (UPI)A bomb exploded outside an Elizabeth restaurant today and a second was defused, the police reported. There were no injuries, and damage was described as minimal.

title: Music: Rustic Wedding
description: Karl Goldmark's Rustic Wedding Symphony, one of those comfortably appealing works from the last quarter of the 19th century, used to be a regular feature of orchestral programs in this country. It is seldom played any more. The New Yo rk Philharmonic revived it in 1968, and on Monday night the Philadelphia Orchestra presented it in its Avery Fisher Hall series. Two performances within seven years scarcely constitute a trend, but if Leonard Bernstein and Eugene Ormandy, its two conductors here, are advocates, perhaps others will take it up.

title: Norwegians to Study U.S. Recruitment Ads
description: The United States, which already has a reputation for expertise in many areas, apparently has added a new onemilitary recruitment.

title: THOMAS STOKES
description: Thomas Stokes, who retired last year as a partner of the law firm of Battle, Fowler, Stokes & Kheel here, died yesterday after suffering a stroke a week earlier. He was 68 years old and lived here and in Fenwick, Conn.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: In the largest paperback artbook deal to date, Harry N. Abrams, Inc., has sold a special printing of half a million copies of The Art of Walt Disney by Christopher Finch to New American Library for $1.2million. The paperback, to be published in April, will sell for $7.95. The book's hardcover price was $45 when it was issued in the fall of 1973, and it sold some 200,000 copies.

title: Agents Say Artist Smuggled Cocaine In 6Quart Wine Jug
Rozelle: No Shift In Policy
description: The National Football League will not defy any final law of the land, says Commissioner Pete Rozzlle, but neither will it change any of its draft or reserve policies until legal wrangles are concluded.

title: Advertising
description: Although in the past it has been a sponsor of TV specials, Encyclopaedia Britannica is now using its television advertising budget in direct support of its magazine ad schedule for the first time.

title: St. Patrick's and EmanuEl Plan Dialogue
African Leader Killed
description: Col. Richard Ratsimandrava, the new head of state of Madagascar, was assassinated yesterday, the radio there reported. Page 11.

title: Erie Petition Withdrawn
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 11Trustees of the Erie Lackawanna Railroad withdrew today their petition for permission to shut down operations. A hearing on the request was to have been heard tomorrow by United States District Court Judge Robert B. Krupansky, but has now been cancelled.

title: Mrs. Kissinger Treated At Jerusalem Hospital
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 11 (UPI) Nancy Kissinger was treated for an ear ailment at the Hadassah Hospital here today and then chatted with a 16year old American girl who had been wounded in a terrorist bombing in December.

title: Guepe Resigns Post
description: NASHVILLE, Feb. 11 (AP)Art Guepe, Ohio Valley Conference commissioner since 1963 and the only fulltime commissioner the conference has had, resigned today effective June 30.

title: Speedy Appeal Ordered on TV's Prime Time Rule
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 11A new phase in the battle over the prime time access rule of the Federal Communications Commission began today when a Federal court ordered a speedy appeal and scheduled a review of all arguments during the week beginning March 3.

title: L.I. POLICE CLEARED OF BEATING SUSPECT
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 11  A State Supreme Court jury absolved the Nasseu County po lice today of a charge of beating a murder suspect, but awarded him $35,000 on his claim of illegal detention.

title: Year of Hare Begins With Traditional Bang
description: The cardboard and paper shrapnel from spent fire crackers was inches deep around Mott and Pell Streets yesterday and policemen patrolled the area with cotton in their ears as Chinatown welcomed the Year of the Hare with millions of rounds of ladyfingers and cherry bombs.

title: GRUMMAN AND G.E. PLANNING LAYOFFS
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Feb. 11 (UPI)  The Grumman Aerospace Corporation announced today it would dismiss 300 to 500 of its 24,000 employes over the next several weeks to reduce operating costs.

title: Tanzanian Says Blacks Expect Brisk Progress on African Rule
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 11 (AP)President Julius K. Nyerere has declared that black guerrillas will not start a racial war in whitecontrolled southern Africa as long as they are convinced that peaceful progress can be made toward majority rule.

title: STOCK PRICES DIP IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Stock prices ended lower in heavier trading yesterday as uncertainty over whether the decline in interest rates would continue weakened investor enthusiasm.

title: BUDGET DEADLINE EXPIRES IN STATE
C. W. Post Scores Over L.I.U., 6159
description: C.W. Post, led by Bert Platt's 28 points, beat Long Island University, 6159, in basketball last night at Founder's Hall Gymnasium in Brooklyn. It raised the Pioneers wonlost record to 193 and dropped the Blackbirds to 810.

title: O'DOHERTY URGED FOR POSTAL PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Kieran O'Doherty, a founder and vice chairman of the New York state Conservative party, has been recommended by Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican, to the $38,000ayear post as a commissioner of the Postal Rate Commission.

title: HORNBLOWER GETS A CHIEF EXECUTIVE
2 Governors Say Their Views on Oil Impressed Ford
Policeman Commits Suicide
description: A 27yearold police officer committed suicide yesterday morning after having quarreled with his wife in their home in St. Albans, Queens. The officer, James Hopper shot himself in the head with his revolver at about 1:40 A.M. after the argument with his wife, Melanie, liat 11558 Mexico Street. A Police Department spokesman said Officer Hopper, who was attached to the 113th Precinct, had been severely depressed over the recent death of his sister.

title: A SUSPECT GIVES UPIN $13,000 ROBBERY
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 11 (UPI)A suspect in a $13,000 armed robbery surrendered to authorities here today after the police persuaded him in a longdistance telephone call to turn himself in.

title: A MOVE BY TRUMAN 0N ITALY REVEALED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The State Department has just published documents showing that President Harry S. Truman was so concerned over a possible Communist takeover in Italy in 1948 that he approved a secret recommendation that the United States make full use of its political, economic, and if necessary, military power to prevent it.

title: DR. ERNEST H. WOOD, RADIOLOGY EXPERT
description: Dr. Ernest H. Wood, the author of Diagnostic Neuroradiology, a standard text on Xray examination of the brain and spinal cord, died yesterday in his office at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived at 425 Knollwood Road, Ridgewood, N. J.

title: Utility to Buy 3 Marinas Damaged by Shipworms
description: MORRISTOWN, Feb. 11 (AP) The Jersey Central Power & Light Company will purchase for $2million three private marinas in Waretown in Ocean County that have been damaged by shipworm infestation, which has been attributed to effluent from the utility's Oyster Creek nuclear power plant.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Feb. 11, 1975

title: Goodyear Dips but Goodrich Gains
description: Two major rubber companies the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the B. F. Goodrich Companyreleased divergent earnings reports yesterday.

title: Plan to Tax Professions Scored in Albany Protest
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11Governor Carey's plan to make selfemployed professional people, such as doctors, lawyers, architects, auditors and accountants, pay a 5.5 per cent unincorporated business tax would be unfair, a group representing those professions argued here today.

title: Walter LaM. Sparry, 73, RealEstate Figure Here
description: Walter LaM. Sparry, vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York from 1946 to 1950 and governor in 1951, died yesterday in Mt. Sinai Hospital after a short illness. His age was 73.

title: People and Business
description: Senator Russell B. Long, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, raised the possibility yesterday of further United States sales of gold to raise revenue if Congress does not approve a new debt ceiling by midFebruary.

title: Bankers Trust Dismissed Officer for Dealings With a SelfProfessed Briber
description: A Bankers Trust Company officer was dismissed in November because of his dealings with Joel Kline, a bankrupt former Maryland millionaire who reportedly gave testimony that helped lead to Spiro T. Agnew's resignation from the VicePresidency.

title: Backlog of Felonies Rose Sharply Here Despite Court Drive
description: The backlog of undisposed felony casesa key indicator of the effectiveness of the criminal justice system  rose sharply in the cify last year, according to figures released by the Office of Court Administration.

title: TORY LEADERSHIP IS WON DECISIVELY BY MRS. THATCHER
description: LONDON, Feb. 11Margaret Thatcher won the Conservative leadership today in a burst of party enthusiasm that, if it can be transmitted to the electorate as a whole, may some day make her Britain's first woman Prime Minister. She is the first woman to lead a British political party.

title: SteinSteingut Clash Spurs Legislators to Study Roles
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11The simmering debate between Speaker Stanley Steingut and Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein is causing the state's lawmakers to examine some of the basic ways they deal with constituents and one another.

title: Music: Cleveland Here
description: The Cleveland Orchestra is so good that any of its programs give pleasure, if only the simple sound of the ensemble. Monday night's concert at Carnegie Hall, however, was problematic from other points of view.

title: McFeeley Rallies P. B. A. Behind Plan to Save Jobs
description: Ken McFeeley, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, went into the station houses yesterday to rally his men behind a plan to save the jobs of more than 500 rookies and recruits, promising them that I'll quit before I sell you down the road.

title: Islanders Victors Over Penguins, 21
New U.S. Catholic Missal Is Being Published Today
description: For the first time since the end of the Second Vatican Council in 1965, Roman Catholics in the United States will be able to use a single, authorized volume containing all readings and prayers for Sunday mass.

title: C.A.B. Drops Bid to Lift CutRate Charter Prices
description: Bowing to pressure from the Ford Administration, Congress and consumers, the Civil Aeronautics Board abandoned yesterday its eightmonth effort to raise the price of cutrate charter flights to aid ailing Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines.

title: U. of Penn. Tuition Rise
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 (AP) The University of Pennsylvania has approved a 10 per cent tuition increase for the 197576 academic year. Dr. Martin Meyerson, president of the university, said the increase approved by the board of trustees yesterday would raise tuition by $340 to $3,790. About 25 signcarrying students protested outside the trustee's meeting.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1975

title: Insurer Pays $100,000 For MeterCoin Theft
description: Mayor Bcame received yesterday an insurance company's check for $100,000 as part payment for the loss of $120.000 in parkingmeter coins stolen over the weekend.

title: Court Rules Undue Pressure Was Put on C.I.A. Over Book
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 11 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit has ruled that a lower court judge used excessive pressure on the Central Intelligence Agency to establish whether information in a book about the agency was classified information.

title: States to Get Highway Funds on FirstCome Basis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The $2billion in impounded Federal highway funds ordered released today by President Ford will be sent out to the states quickly on a firstcome. firstserved basis to accelerate construction projects and employment. according to Department of Transportation officials.

title: General Phone Increases Quarter Sales and Profit
description: The General Telephone & Electronics Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in revenues and sales and net income for the fourth quarter. However, net income for the full year trailed the 1973 level because of the writeoff of certain unprofitable segments within G.T.E. Information Systems.

title: GINSBERG INQUIRY TO HEAR NEWSMEN
description: ALBANY, Feb, 11A reporter and a former reporter for the Daily News and their wives have been subpoenaed to testify before an Albany grand jury investigating allegations that Martin Ginsberg, former Nassau County Family Court judge, illegally used public money to help pay for campaign publicity while he was an Assemblyman.

title: Old English Sheepdog Gains Best in Show at Westminster
description: When Ch. Sir Lancelot of Barvan was picked by Harry T. Peters last night as winner of the 99th Westminster Kennel Club Show, it marked the first time in 61 years that a bobtail had been selected for the honor.

title: Behind a Glossy Facade, Italy Sinks Deep in Crisis
description: ROME, Feb. 11 A Midwestern voice in the tourist bus said: If this town is having a depression, it sure doesn't show it.

title: Books of The Times
description: I started reading Moe Berg: Athlete, Scholar, Spy, by Louis Kaufman, Barbara Fitzgerald and Tom Sewell, because I recalled the book's subject as a curiosity who used to pop up every so often in the talk of older baseball fans and the columns of older sports writers; and I had mixed feelings about him.

title: Mildred Woodbury, Teacher And Labor Economist, Dies
description: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Feb. 11 (AP)  Mildred Fairchild Woodbury, a labor economist and educator who fought for improved working conditions for women and the young, died Sunday. She was 80 years old.

title: Police in Madrid Break Up Demonstration by Students
description: MADRID, Feb. 11 (Reuters)Riot policemen today dispersed 200 students demonstrating outside the Supreme Court in support of 10 leftwing opponents of the Franco Government who were appealing against their conviction on charges of unlawful assembly and belonging to an illegal organization.

title: Absenteeism Delays Oil Import Vote
New Jersey Briefs
description: Stanley C. Van Ness, the State Public Advocate, announced the appointment of Thomas S. Smith Jr. of Nep tune Township to direct the Office of the Public Defender program for childabuse cases. Mr. Smith has been serving as a legal aide to Mr. Van Ness since last July, when the office of the Public Defender became part of the new Department of the Public Advocate.

title: Bridge
description: One of the game's greatest personalities celebrates his 70th birthday here today. Richard Lincoln Frey, who owes his middle name to the date, has played almost every possible role in his 45year career in bridge: teacher, lecturer, commentator, writer, editor and winner of national titles.

title: PENNSY CANCELS SHUTDOWN PLANS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 (AP) The bankrupt Penn Central railroad abruptly canceled plans today to halt all its trains in two weeks after being promised swift Government help to meet an endofmonth payrol.

title: For Tories, A Quotable New Chief
description: LONDON, Feb. 11Margaret Thatcher, one of her party's better performers on the floor of the Commons, is known for her forceful comments on a variety of topics. Here are a few of them:

title: Bulls Subdue Knicks, 10184
Soviet Ratifies Convention Banning GermWar Arms
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11 (AP) The Presidium of the Supreme Soviet today ratified an international convention banning development, production and tockpiling of bacteriological and toxic weapons, Tass, the official press agency, reported.

title: President's Next Move: Retreat on Federal Spending?
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Some members of the Ford Administration, which recently staged a spectacular turnabout in fiscal policy, are beginning to ponder a retreat from the White House's new line of economic defenses. In their public statements, President Ford and his chief spokesmen continue to warn of the dangers of increased Federal spending to fight the deepening recession. The President has said repeatedly that, while he has proposed a tax cut and a big budget deficit, to increase government expenditures now would imperil the private capital market and touch off a new wave of inflation.

title: Absenteeism Delays Oil Import Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Senate attempts to block President Ford's imposition of oil import fees and to draft an alternative to the White House energy program were delayed today by Senate absenteeism.

title: U.S. ADDS 7 PLANES TO CAMBODIA AIRLIFT
U.S. Asks Quick Trade Accords
description: GENEVA, Feb. 11 World trade negotiations opened here today with the United States urging that quick agreements be made wherever possible, without waiting for an overall accord.

title: Honest Greyhounds Keep Gamblers Happy
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 11 Tim O'Brien, who used to be the organist with the Allman Brothers Band, says it has happened five times recently that someone threatened to pull a gun and offered to send him to that great rockandroll band in the sky.

title: Rockefeller's Panel Holds Private Talk With Colson
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) Investigators for the Rockefeller commission met privately today with Charles W. Colson, former White House special counsel, to study allegations that he had made concerning domestic operations of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: For Cajuns, Mardi Gras at a Gallop
FORD RELEASING UP TO $2BILLION TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: TOPEKA. Kan., Feb. 11President Ford announced today that he had ordered the release of up to $2billion in impounded highway construction funds to help stimulate the sagging economy.

title: VINCENT GUILLOTON
description: Vincent Guilloton, who retired in 1962 as Shedd professor of French language in literature at Smith College, died Sunday in his home here, 4 Washington Square Village. He was 80 years old.

title: S.E.C. Sets Hearing On More Disclosures
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would hold a public proceeding to determine whether, and to what extent, it should require companies subject to its jurisdiction to disclose environmental and other matters of primarily social rather than financial concern.

title: WINE TALK
description: Rex Mottram was a swine. Not that he did anything evil, actually. He just happened to represent the modern, acquisitive, insensitive world in Evelyn Waugh's Brideshead Revistited. And he used the wrong glass.

title: Notes on People
description: The former Governor of West Virginia, William Wallace Barron, was paroled from Federal prison yesterday, but a decision was postponed on an appeal for the immediate release of the ailing Otto Kerner, former Governor of Illinois, who has served six months of a threeyear sentence.

title: Habash Says Guerrilla Group Hopes to Provoke Mideast War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 11 (AP)  George Habash, the Marxist  oriented Palestinian guerrilla leader has said that his splinter guerrilla group will do everything it can to provoke a new Middle East war according to an interview printed here today.

title: Simon Returns to Paterson and Is Briefed on Plans for Revitalization
description: PATERSON, Feb. 11Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon returned here to his birthplace today to receive an award and be briefed on plans that, it is hoped, will revitalize an unused 63  year  old electric power plant at the base of the Great Falls.

title: Ford Would Accept Lower WindfallProfit Oil Tax
MISSILE BUILDUP PLANNED BY U. S.
Behind a Glossy Facade, Italy Sinks Deep in Crisis
description: ROME, Feb. 11 A Midwestern voice in the tourist bus said: If this town is having a depression, it sure doesn't show it.

title: Workshop Sparks Changes In Some Farnily Eating Habits
description: On the days her preschool children are willing, Arlene Haims gives them a peanut butter sandwich for breakfast. Evelyn Pliego has rejected fad diets. Clairie Freimann has stopped buying frankfurters. The sodas have gone from Susan Weiner's refrigerator. Linda Newman buys less red meat and more chicken. Marjorie Needleman blocks the aisle in her supermarket when she stops to read and compare labels.

title: Composite Tape Date Set
description: The Composite Tape Association, representing the securities industry, said yesterday it had set June 16 as the target date for the start of the industry's composite stock tape. The tape, which eventually will list all the stock trades of all the nation's exchanges on a single ticker, was originally to be introduced on Feb. 21, but was delayed for technical reasons.

title: Hong Kong's Market Hangover
NEWARK LABORER GUILTY OF MURDER
description: NEWARK, Feb. 11An 18yearold Newark laborer was found guilty today of the fatal stabbing last June of William J. Aldridge Jr., a low professor at Seton Hall University.

title: Social Democrat Will Try To Form a Danish Cabinet
Carey Task Force, 3 to 2, Urges Interstate Plan for the West Side
description: A fivemember task force named by Governor Carey to study the question of deteriorated West Side Highway has voted 3 to 2 to recommend replacing it with an Interstate System highway from the Battery to 42d Street.

title: HARDDRIVINGPOWER FROM WATROUS BAND
description: Bill Watrous and his 17piece band, Manhattan Wildlife Refuge, helped Jack Kleinsinger celebrate the second anniversary of his Highlights of Jazz series on Monday evening with a concert at New York University's Loeb Student Center that emphasized the bristling, harddriving power. The band started off in high gear, tearing into Chick Corea's Spain with crisply vivid ensemble playing and solos that tumbled along relentlessly over a buoyant rhythm section, and stayed on that level most of the evening.

title: State Bars Rebates On Auto Sales Tax
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11Buyers of new automobiles who receive rebates of from $200 to $500 from manufacturers will not he entitled to refunds on sales taxes paid based on the purchase price of their vehicles, State Tax Commissioner Mario A. Procaccino said today.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW A DECLINE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday. The overthecounter market dosed mixed.

title: BROWN U. WEIGHS 16.5% FACULTY CUT
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 11  Brown University may be forced to cut its faculty by up to 16.5 per cent over the next few years, Donald F. Hornig, president of the university, announced today. He also said tuition would rise by about 10 per cent next year from the Present $3.500 a year.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Bonomi Quits at Boating Peak
description: With one hand tucked into his dark pinstriped jacket pocket, Dr. Carlo Bonomi stood on the dais yesterday at the New York Athletic Club and accepted accolades for having won the world offshore powerboat championship.

title: Metreveli Upset in U.S. Tennis
South African Stresses Efforts For Normal Ties to Neighbors
KISSINGER HEARS ISRAELIS ON SINAI
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 11Secretary of State Kissinger emerged this evening from an intensive opening round of discussions with Israeli leaders and said he remained optimistic about the prospects of reaching a new interim agreement between Israel and Egypt.

title: Great Southwest Corp. Sets A $154Million Refinancing
description: The Great Southwest Corporation, real estate and amusement park operators, said yesterday it had arranged a $154million refinancing involving 83 crditors and equity holders.

title: Malagasy Head of State Killed Six Days After Taking Office
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, wednesday, Feb. 12 (Reuters)The new head of state of Madagascar was mortally wounded when assassins armed with machine guns ambushed his car yesterday, the state radio said today.

title: STUDY FORECASTS MAJOR SHORTAGES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The world faces a future plagued by shortages in those resources ital to modern industrial civilization, according to a major study made public today by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: TORY LEADERSHIP IS WON DECISIVELY BY MRS. THATCHER
description: LONDON, Feb. 11Margaret Thatcher won the Conservative leadership today in a burst of party enthusiasm that, if it can be transmitted to the electorate as a whole, may some day make her Britain's first woman Prime Minister. She is the first woman to lead a British political party.

title: Red Smith
description: The news conference opened at 10 A.M. on a note of unbending formality. I can't recognize half of you crumb bums at this hour, said the star of the piece, a man named Bernard Shor. He surveyed the newspaper and television types assembled in the Offtrack Betting headquarters at 1501 Broadway. there was a day when some of them would be saying good night to Toots Shor at 10 A.M., not good morning. That was when their home away from home was the brick house at 51 West 51st Street, or its bigger successor at 33 West 52d, or the man's last saloon at 5 East 54th. Now, as Toots gazed around the OTB boardroom, a man from The Associated Press arrived. You creepy burn, Mr. Shor said, how are ya? The meeting came to order. Paul Screvane, the horseplayer's friend who heads OTB, announced the appointment of Toots Shor as a special liaison officer to help set up a system of making book on football, baseball, basketball and other amusements such as the numbers game. Before OTB could handle such action legally, a bill must pass two sessions of the legislature and be approved by the voters in a statewide referendum. That makes 1977 the earliest target date possible.

title: Britain to Maintain Contact With I.R.A to Keep Truce
description: LONDON, Feb. 11To safeguard and monitor the ceasefire announced on Sunday, Britain will set up a network of centers to maintain contact with I.R.A. units throughout Northern Ireland.

title: Acting Principal Ousted By Board in District 16
description: Sheldon Roach, acting principal of Whitelaw Reid Junior High School 57 in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant section since 1971, was dismissed by the board of Community School District 16 last week on general charges of having failed to maintain good relations with staff and to run a well organized school.

title: Books of The Times

title: JOB ACCORD SEEN WITH ROCKEFELLER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11A tentative agreement is reported to two been reached giving two of Vice President Rockefeller's top aides key roles in running the Domestic Council.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Sindona Issues a Denial Of Italian Bribery Report
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who was reported in a dispatch from Rome in The New York Times Monday to be under investigation in connection with charges of bribery of Italian politicians, yesterday denied the allegations.

title: Stock Market Outlook
description: What is the stock market saying? It doesn't seem to be saying anything clearly at the moment, just asking questions: Where is the economy going? Is this a recession or a depression?

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1975

title: 2 Governors Say Their Views on Oil Impressed Ford
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 11 The Governors of two of the nation's largest oil producing statesOklahoma and Texassaid today that President Ford seemed impressed by their conconcern voiced at a private dinner last night, that his proposed domestic oil policies could lead the United States into a serious oil and gasoline shortage.

title: Kennedy Museum Blocked By Combination of Forces
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 11 The plans for a museum honoring President Kennedy near Harvard .Square fell victim to determined local opposition, chaneine times and inflation.

title: At Hamburg Opera, No Financial Woes
description: HAMBURG, West Germany The Hamburg Staatsoper is a modern, unostentatious building on the corner of Dammtorstrasse and Grosse Theaterstrasse in the heart of town. As a structure it is not nearly so imposing as the big opera houses in Paris, Munich or Vienna, and there is nothing in its appearance to suggest that it is one of the three leading opera houses of Germany and one of the important ones of the world.

title: Byrne Threatens He Will Sue If U.S. Spurs Ocean Oil Drilling
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11Governor Byrne threatened today to sue the Department of the Interior unless Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton postponed an invitation to oil companies to nominate areas of oil lease off the midAtlantic coast.

title: African Leader Killed
description: Col. Richard Ratsimandrava, the new head of state of Madagascar, was assassinated yesterday, the radio there reported. Page 11.

title: Key Eritrean Bridge Reported Blown Up By Separatist Rebels
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 11 (Reuters)  Secessionist guerrillas today knocked out a major bridge north of Asmara, the capital of Ethiopia's northern province of Eritrea, according to diplomatic sources here.

title: Vocational School Combats Sex Stereotyping in Classes
description: I'm for women's lib 200 per centwhen it's a question of who takes out the garbage, boomed Nathan Mayron, principal of Eli Whitney.

title: Embarrassment in Paris
description: PARIS, Feb. 11  French bankers and officials expressed embarrassment today to the impact of the Arab blacklist on some Jewish banks, but none was prepared to take a clear stand.

title: GRAIN RESERVE PLAN IS AIRED AT MEETING
description: LONDON, Feb. 11 (UPI)Representatives of the major grain importing and exporting countries discussed a plan to day for a 60millionton world grain emergency reserve, but deferred a decision until further consultations with their governments, American officials said.

title: STUDY FORLCASTS MAJOR SHORTAGES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The world faces a future plagued by shortages in those resources it al to modern industrial civilization, according to a major study made public today by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Cavaliers Top Jazz By 10086
Miss Rallins Takes Hurdles Race, Dash
description: KAGOSHIMA, Japan, Feb. 11 (AP)Ann Ewa Karlsson of Sweden won the women's high jump and Mamie Rallins of the United States captured the women's 100meter dash and 100meter hurdles today in an international indoor track and field meet.

title: City Bonds Are Sold At 7.16%, Lowest In Last 10 Months
description: After a fourmonth absence from the municipal bond market to give it more breathing space, the city borrowed $141million yesterday at an average interest rate of 7.1697 per centthe lowest in 10 months.

title: The Met Returns With a NearMagical Das Rheingold
RED DORAN
description: DETROIT, Feb. 11 (AP)John (Red) Doran, a former defenseman for the Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League, died today. He was 63 years old.

title: A P.O.W.'s Faith
description: AUSTIN, TEX. I was captured by the Vietcong in October, 1963, deep in the Mekong Delta. As Americans we were of value to the enemy for propaganda and exploitation. Whether we ate or starved, received medication or not, lived or died, depended on their evaluation of our political attitude.

title: Revive Railroads
description: Congress and the Ford Administration cannot, much longer postpone a fundamental decision about the restoration of adequate railroad service. The trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central have just canceled another in a long series of melodramatic threats to shut down all service after getting assurance that. the Federal Government would put enough money into the railroad's bottomless tin cup to permit them to meet their next payroll.

title: Stage: O'Neill's Hughie and David Milton's Duet
Elevating the Bench
description: It always seems to be one step forward and one backward through the minefield of New York State court reform. The latest mover in both directions is Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel of the Court of Appealsforward by boosting a merit system of selecting judges, backward by giving Governor Carey an assist in defusing effective discipline for those already on the bench.

title: Business Briefs
description: The S. S. Kresge Company, which has had the most dramatic growth of any of the nation's large retail chains in recent years, said yesterday that its earnings for the fiscal year ended Jan. 29 were very disappointing and could go as low as $1 a share compared to $1.15 a share in fiscal 1974.

title: PLATINUM PRICE CUT BY NO. 1 PRODUCER
description: Rustenburg Platinum Mines, Ltd., Johannesburg, the world's biggest producer of the metal, cut its price by $20 an ounce to $170 yesterday.

title: CITY CITES COSTS OF P.B.A. DEMANDS
description: The city presented data to an arbitration panel yesterday showing that salary and benefit costs would rise to $30,994 a year for each police officer if the demands of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association were granted.

title: Market Countries to Drop National Bars to Doctors
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 11 The European Common Market today decided to give the approximately 400,000 doctors in its member countries to right to practice medicine wherever they evant in the ninenation community.

title: People in Sports
description: The New York Cosmos traded their top player. Randy Horton, to Washington yesterday because the soccer star wants to commute to Bermuda for the first two months of the season.

title: The Common Sea
description: Representatives of sixteen countries bordering on the Mediterranean have just concluded a week's conference on ways to rescue that historic sea from further degradation. The meeting in Barcelona under the auspices of the United Nations Environmental Program represented the first genuine effort of the Mediterranean states to develop a common plan of action.

title: LEON YANKWICH, U.S. JUDGE, IS DEAD
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 (AP) Leon Rene Yankwich, a Federal judge who decided the historic case that preserved the Elk Hills oil fields for the public in 1937, died Sunday. He was 86 years old.

title: 86th Street Neighborhood Group Claims Hamburger War Victory
description: Claiming victory in the West 86th Street hamburger war, a local community group announced yesterday that the McDonald's Corporation had agreed to seek a buyer for the property at the corner of 86th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, where the company had planned to build a fastfood outlet.

title: London Banker Opposes Resistance To Arab Boycott of Jewish Interests
description: LONDON, Feb. 11A British banker predicted today that the exclusion of Jewish interests from financings involving Arab investors would continue as long as the Arabs wished.

title: Bright Wins in Ring
description: LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP)Freddie Bright of New York stopped Billy Knight, a former Commonwealth Games champion of Britain, in the sixth round of a scheduled eight  round light  heavyweight boxing bout tonight.

title: For Cajuns, Mardi Gras at a Gallop
description: MAMOU, La., Feb. 11One might suppose that the talk of Mamou this week would be the stabbing and wounding a leading citizen by a jealous husband on a downtown street last Friday night.

title: A Young American's Palate Gets an Education at Troisgros
description: The incident was real but it followed a plot line nearly as old as stagecraft itself: an aspiring young actor waiting in the wings; a star performer suddenly indisposed; a virtuoso turn by the youth; thundering applause and shouts of bravo bravo.

title: BOND PRICES DROP; CALENDAR GROWS
description: Bond prices declined yesterday, affected partly by prospects of $600million in new corporate offerings scheduled to reach the public market later this month or in March.

title: Effects Will Be Limited On Lincoln's Birthday
description: The observance of Lincoln's Birthday today will affect some, but not all, government and business operations.

title: Holiday Closings Set
description: All major securities exchanges will be open today, Lincoln's Birthday. However, all banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed. The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Commodity Exchange, Inc., and the New York Cocoa Exchange will be closed, but all other commodities markets, including those in the Midwest will be open as usual. The Government bond market will be closed.

title: Another View Of America
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Feb. 11It is hard to cross America from Massachusetts to California these gloomy days without feeling a lot better about the strength of the nation.

title: Ohio Paper Fills Posts
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 11 (AP)The Columbus Dispatch annonuced today that John F. Wolfe has been named publisher of The Dispatch and John W. Wolfe chairman of the board of The Dispatch Printing Company.

title: Carey Turns Down Pleas To Continue Stein's Panel
Contract Awards
description: The Bell Helicopter division of Textron, Inc., has been awarded by the Army two contracts, totaling $169.3million, to operate flight and technical training programs to run a supply and maintenance program for the Iranian armed forces.

description: LONDON, Feb. 11To safeguard and monitor the ceasefire announced on Sunday, Britain will set up a network of centers to maintain contact with I.R.A. units throughout Northern Ireland.

description: ROME, Feb. 11  Pope Paul VI broached the question of Jerusalem in a talk today with Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations.

title: Michael L. Freilich Dead at 62; Operated Roko Gallery of Art
description: Michael Leon Freilich, who operated the Roko Gallery on the parlor floor of an old brownstone at 90 East 10th Street, died yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he had been recovering from openheart surgery last August. He was 62 years old and lived at 55 Perry Street.

title: Executive From Citibank in Australia To Take Charge of Finance Company
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 11 Charles W. Kelly, a senior vice president of the First National City Bank of New York, arrived in Sydney last month to assume control of Australia's second biggest finance company.

description: BRUSSELS, Feb, 11  The European Common Market today decided to give the approximately 400,000 doctors in its member countries the right to practice medicine wherever they want in the ninenation community.

title: About New York
description: The hottest action in town yesterday, better than OTB, the cock fights on the Lower East Side or the numbers game anywhere else, was at the General Post Office on Ninth Avenue. It was an auction, and while a good auctioneer might move up to, say, 80 items an hour, the auctioneers at the Post Office were moving 100. A citizen could buy anything he wanted to.

title: Army Discharges, With Full Benefits, A Wronged Recruit
description: FORT; DEVENS, Mass., Feb. 11 (AP)Philip Cameron Jr., who has sued the Army for failing to live up to a recruiter's promises, has been given an honorable discharge with full military benefits.

title: The Screen: Shampoo
MAN IN BRIDGE LEAP IS IN FAIR CONDITION
description: A 21yearold New Jersey college student was reported in fair and stable condition yesterday after plunging 230 feet from the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge into the icy waters of Lower New York Bay early Monday night.

title: GEORGE A. WEISS
description: George A. Weiss, a tax lawyer and partner in the firm of Stapper & Weiss here, died of cancer yesterday in New York University Hospital. He was 45 years old and lived at 91 Central Park West.

title: Dance: Mexico's Ballet Folklorico at City Center
description: It's fiesta time again at el City Center, where Mexico's Ballet Folklorico whirled in last night for its 10th visit and a twoweek run.

title: A.M.C. Plan Announced
description: DETROIT, Feb. 11  The American Motors, Corporation, which has a 94day supply of cars in inventory and has experienced a 37 per cent sales decline this year, said today it would lay off 8,500 workers for one week beginning Monday. Production of its Gremlin, Hornet and Matador models will be halted during the week.

title: Howes Paces Aeros
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 11 (AP)  The Howe family paced the champion Houston Aeros to a 52 World Hockey Association victory over the Baltimore Blades tonight. The Howes, Gordy and his sons. Mark and Marty, accounted for 7 points.

title: Not Highways
description: What the nation clearly does not need is largescale new construction of highways. By releasing another $2 billion in highway funds, President Ford perpetuates the wrong drift of national transportation policy. With gasoline increasingly expensive and the need for gasoline conservation selfevident, it makes no sense for the Federal Government to invest additional large sums encourage more automobile and truck traffic. It takes four times as much fuel to move a ton of freight by truck as it does by railroad. When will this elementary fact penetrate the minds of Government policymakers?

title: CONSUMER NOTES
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Newark Prelate Opens Drive to Erase Deficit
description: NEWARK. Feb. 11The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark announced today it would begin a drive on April 1 to wipe out its current $25million deficit.

title: Lincoln Brigade Recalled
description: The Abraham Lincoln Brigade seems to mean nothing to nearly two generations of Americans. When I speak to college students and tell them Americans fought as volunteers for the legally elected Spanish Government, they stare at me in astonishment.

description: It was to honor and to remember the photographers and reporters who still missing in Indochina, and it was also a reunion for many of the journalists who have covered the wars of Southeast Asia.

description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa. Feb. 11 (Reuters)  The United party, South Africa's main opposition group, was shaken today by the resignation of 10 provincial legislators.

description: With a twist of the pastry tube, the Larsen Baking Company once triedand failedto prolong the life of the hot cross bun beyond the 40 days of Lent.

description: BOWIE, Md., Feb, 11 (UPI) Chris McCarron, who set the record for most victories in one year in 1974 while still an apprentice jockey, rode five winners today at Bowie.

description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that a Brooklyn school district might have wasted more than $200,000 a year by failing to make effective use of teachers work time, inflating figures on pupil attendance and permitting poor business practices.

description: Beef prices declined again last week. This time the drop was significant and reflected, after a delay, price reductions that had occurred at wholesale.

title: Buckwalter Dismissed, Nissalke Hired by Stars

He will be replaced by Tom Nissalke, whom Buckwalter once replaced as coach of the Seattle Supersonics of the National Basketball Association.

description: KORALSol. 4 years goneyet with me always. RUTH.

title: Music: Sergin Luca, Violinist, Borrows From Tradition for His Period Effects
description: It is perfectly possible to play golf with a croquet mallet or tennis with a potato masher, but the best results would probably be obtained by using the instruments designed for the game. Sergiu Luca is a violinist who thinks along similar lines, and his recital last night at Alice Tully Hall testified to his belief in playing every composer's music with the tools suitable to the period.

title: Byrne Threatens to Sue if U.S. Acts to Spur Ocean Oil Drilling
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11  Governor Byrne of New Jersey threatened today to sue the Department of the Interior unless Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton postponed an invitation to oil companies to nominate areas for oil leases off the midAtlantic coast.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Toxan Charged in 7 Killings Points Out 2 More Victims
Filipino Gains Decision
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Feb. 12 (AP)Socrates Batoto of the Philippines, a former Orient flyweight champion, scored a unanimous 10round decision tonight over Beaver Kajimoto of Japan in a nontitle fight. The Filipino floored the Japanese in the sixth round for a mandatory eight count. Batoto weighed 118 pounds and Kajimoto 117.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Obituary 2  No Title
description: MILOSLAV SEEMAN

title: Bulls Down Pistons and Widen Lead
Liberal Democrats to Meet on 1976
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Frustrated by initial developments in the contest for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination, a group of party liberals has called a meeting in Chicago next month to consider Possible strategies.

title: Chess:
description: Every once in a while a player may become caught up in an idea of strategy, a formula for shaping his play, that he had previously neglected and now wants to try out. If he is very successful with his newfound mode of play he may assimilate it as a permanent style and, if he is not enthusiastic about it, he can discard it as a fling that at least deepened his appreciation of various types of positions.

title: Moderate Chosen to Be Thai Premier
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Thursday, Feb. 13 (Reuters)Seni Pramoj, 69yearold leader of the Decomrat party, was chosen to as Premier of Thailand.

title: R. J. Reynolds Profit Up 3% in Quarter
description: BY CLARE M. RECKERT Sharply higher earnings in the transportation and petroleum divisions lifted the earnings of R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc. in the fourth quarter by 3 per cent and by 18 per cent for the year 1974, the nation's largest cigarette producer reported yesterday.

title: MORTGAGE RATES THAT VARY ASKED
Market Place
description: ROCHESTER, N. Y.In this snowy city of 300,000 on the banks of the Genessee River there is relatively little unemployment4.2 per cent against the national average of 8.2 per cent. Rochester attributes its relative prosperity to widely diversified light industry and, of course, to the venerable Eastman Kodak Company, which employs 48,000 of Rochester's working citizens. (Worldwide Kodak employment totals 120,700).

title: As Snow Piles Up in Queens Streets, Residents Recall Infamous 69 Storm
description: When the citizens of Bayside, Queens, arose yesterday to what looked like a blizzard, not a few of them thought hack to the snows of yesteryear  specifically tothe snows that came six years ago on Feb. 9 and did not go away for more than week.

title: Ranger Defense Deserved Capital Punishment
20 State Farmers Buying a Sugar Mill
'Female Trouble'
description: When, at age 16 or so, Dawn Davenport (Divine) doesn't get the cha-cha heels she wants for Christmas, she wraps the Christmas tree around Mom's neck, tells Dad he knows what he can do with himself, then stalks out of the house and is quite happily raped by a passing motorist, a slob of heroic proportions also played by Divine, a 200-pound-plus female impersonator.Thus begins "Female Trouble," the story of Dawn's search for stardom that opened yesterday at the 59th Street Twin 1 Theater. The movie was directed, written and photographed by John Waters, the Baltimore film maker responsible for "Pink Flamingos".A lot of people would say that Dawn goes from bad to worse, but it's just one of the dozens of often predictable reversals in "Female Trouble," that Dawn sees herself as going from good to better, finally winding up in the electric chair for murder, an occasion she proudly describes as "the page one of my life.""Female Trouble" is regional camp of very limited appeal, a movie that celebrates tackiness in a way that was revolutionary and sometimes very funny in the sixties when Andy Warhol and Paul Morrissey did it. Now it seems almost provincial, though I realize that too could be interpreted as a plus by people who are willing to work very hard to rationalize small laughs.Divine, who looks like a hippo in drag even when he's not in drag, may not be an untalented comedian, though it's impossible to tell in a movie in which the second-rateness of everything is the point. In the Warhol-Morrissey films such as "Trash" and "Women in Revolt," the wit and the idiosyncracies of the performers (Holly Woodlawn, Jackie Curtis, Candy Darling) had the effect of reversing the reversals, so that the films were funnier (and more serious) than was immediately apparent.Mr. Waters's actors work hard to achieve some of that same quality, but with one exception they never achieve it. The exception is an actress named Mink Stole, who occasionally displays a fine madness as Dawn's 14-year-old daughter who doesn't look a day less than 30.

title: JOHN L. TOOHEY DIES; STAGE PRESS AGENT
description: John Latham Toohey, a theatrical press agent who wrote A History of the Pulitzer Prize Plays (1967) and On Plays, Playwrights and Playgoers (1959), died Sunday of cancer in Brook Hospital, Brighton, Mass. He was 58 years old and lived on Chebeague Island in Maine.

title: People in Sports
description: David F. Rice, a Greenwich (Conn.) High School physical education teacher, was named Fordham's 35th head football coach yesterday by the Rams athletic director, Peter A. Carlesimo.

title: JAPAN INTERVENES TO BUOY DOLLAR
description: TOKYO, Feb. 12 (AP)The Bank of Japan bought from $70million to $100million today to stem a sharp, speculative decline in the value of the dollar sparked by a similar drop in London yesterday, dealers reported.

title: Human Rights Nominee
description: Governor Carey nominated yesterday as the state's new Commissioner of the Division of Civil Rights a longtime civilrights advocate. Though he has not been involved in demonstrations, picketing or court battles, associates have described him as a humanist liberal who believes in government's ability to solve human problems. The nominee 48yearold Werner Hans Kramarsky, said he was a bit surprised when Governor Carey asked him last week to take the 43,050ayear post.

title: 4 Children Killed by Fumes From Furnace in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (UPI)Four children were killed today by toxic fumes from a malfunctioning oil furnace, officials said. Three other members of the same family were overcome by the fumes.

title: Utility in Canada Gets 100Million Arab Loan
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia, Feb. 12 (Reuters)Provincial Premier Dave Barrett said today that the British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority had borrowed another $100million from an unnamed Arab country in a deal negotiated through White, Weld, Inc.

title: Langella Hones His Craft as Star in the Lizard's Skin
Dave Anderson
description: Resembling a 2iron with a cashmere shaft and a solid gold clubhead, Johnny Miller tees it up again in the Andy Williams San Diego open. If he wins this tournament, too, he will have earned nearly $150,000 on the golf tour this year, halfway through February.

title: Southern Company Outlays
description: The Southern Company expects to spend about $1.1billion on construction this year, Alvin W. Vogtle, Jr., president, told yesterday's luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts. This would be about the same as in 1973. The big utility holding company had cut $430million from earner projections of 1975 spending and now expects to spend $3.3billion through 1977.

title: ELLIOTT GODOFF, LABOR OFFICIAL
description: Elliott Godoff, executive vice president and director of organization of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employes, an A.F.L.C.I.O. union, died, apparently of heart attack, in a Washington hotel room Monday evening. He was 66 years old.

title: Gertrude H. Sergievsky, Tolstoy Foundation Officer
description: Gertrude Hochschild Sergievsky, widow of Capt. Boris Sergievsky, a Russian air ace in World War I, died Tuesday, of cancer at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She lived at 27 East 65th Street and at Blue Mountain Lake in the Adirondacks, and was in her 80's.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2 No Title

title: Loss Costs Lyle $300,000 Bout
description: Ron Lyle woke up yesterday to discover he had lost $300,000.

title: Currency of Iran Linked to S.D.R.'s Instead of Dollar
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 12 (UPI) The Central Bank of Iran announced today it had terminated the direct link between the Iranian currencythe rial and the dollar and linked it instead to the International Monetary Fund's special drawing rights.

title: Soviet Delegate to Border Talk Back in Peking After 6 Months
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12The soviet Union's negotiator in the longstanding border dispute with China has flown to Peking, apparently to resume the border talks after an absence of six months.

title: KISSINGER SAYS TALK WITH SADAT YIELDS PROGRESS
description: CAIRO, Feb. 12Secretary of State Kissinger, after a review of the Middle East situation with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, said today that progress had been made in clarifying issues between Israel and Egypt and in pointing out the direction in which a solution could be found.

title: 6INCH SNOWFALL CRIPPLES TRAVEL AND TRADE IN CITY
U.S. Sues to Condemn 71 Cases Of Bon Vivant Soup Now on L.I.
Carey Will Keep Levine As Labor Commissioner
Foolish Pleasure's 75 Debut a Pleasure
description: Foolish Pleasure, the undefeated colt who was voted the 1974 champion of his division, launched his 3yearold campaign yesterday by registering an easy victory in an exhibition sevenfurlong race at Hialeah. With Jacinto Vasquez riding, Foolish Pleasure, who is owned by John L. Greer, romped to a 4length triumph over Ambassador's Image who preceded Circle Home across the wire in the treehorse field. A nonbetting event, the exhibition was run before the regular program at Hialeah began.

title: For and by Youngsters, the Jokes Will Fly at Town Hall
Bridge:
description: The title of New York player of the year for 1974, awarded on the basis of performance in local tournaments, was won by Alvin Roth of New York. This title is now open to players outside the boundaries of the territory covered by the Greater New York Bridge Association, and three of his closest rivals came into that category.

title: Major Colleges Woo Unselfish Monroe Star
Soviet Player Scores in U.S. Tennis
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 12 (AP)Teimuraz Kakulia of the Soviet Union, playing in the tournament for the first time, upset Karl Meiler of West Germany, 16, 75, 64, and advanced to the quarterfinals of the national indoor open tennis championships today.

title: JURY TO EXAMINE DEMOCRATS DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) The Watergate special prosecution force has subpoenaed finance reports of the Democratic party for 1970 and 1971 in a grand jury investigation into possible violation of a campaign reporting law.

title: Williams Opens Hearings on State's Economic Woes
FUNGUS MAY END CHESTNUT BLIGHT
description: Several decades after the great chestnut blight struck down the most valued hardwood of the Eastern states, a small ray of hope has appeared for controlling the disease.

title: Mobil Discovers Oil and Gas In Well Southeast of Saigon
description: SAIGON, Feb. 12 (AP)The Mobil Oil Corporation has found oil and gas in its first exploratory well off the coast of South Vietnam, oil sources said today. The sources said a production test was run on the well yesterday and found a flow of oil and gas at a depth of more than 9,000 feet.

title: School Cuts N.A.I.A Ties
description: ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Feb. 12 (UPI)  Augustana College will withdraw its membership in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics at the end of the scholastic year, school officials announced today the Augustana athletic board said economic considerations had made it impossible to continue its dual membership in the N.A.I.A. and the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: School to Cite Black Parent for Unity Efforts
description: While Black History Week is celebrating the contributions of historic black figures, Public, School 49 in the South Bronx is planning a ceremony tomorrow honoring Marion E. Rose, a 31 yearold mother of tour whose efforts to unite black and Puerto Rican parents are worthy, school officials feel, of a place in history.
