description: The flow of surplus oil revenues into the United States from Arab nations and other foilproducing states was substantially larger last year than official Government figures indicate, and the inflow is almost certain to increase sharply in 1975, according to a number of commercial bankers, brokerage officials and economists.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE MUSIC MAN An extensive exhibit commemorating the life and career of Sir Arthur Sullivan, the composer half of the Gilbert and Sullivan team, begins today and runs through April 20 at the Pierpont Morgan Library (6850008), 29 East 36th Street. The display includes new material in addition to the library's resident Gilbert and Sullivan collection, which ranks close to that of the Library of Congress. The newly acquired, original score of Trial By Jury will be on view in the entrance hall, along with loaned scores of The Pirates of Penzance and H.M.S. Pinafore.

title: Carter and Artis Again Lose Appeal for New Murder Trial
description: For the second time. Judge Samuel A. Larner of New Jersey Superior Court has rejected an appeal by Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and a codefendant for a new murder trial based on defense contentions of newly uncovered evidence.

title: COLUMBIA GETTING MORE APPLICANTS
description: Freshman applications, a vital sign of a college's academic and financial health, are up sharply at Columbia and New York Universities for next fall.

title: Notes on People
description: Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court entered Bethesda Naval Hospital with a respiratory infection Tuesday night and was said to be in satisfactory condition yesterday, resting comfortably and undergoing tests. According to Barrett McGurn, the Supreme Court spokesman, the 56yearold justice returned Tuesday from a trip to the West Coast and Las Vegas, Nev., with his wife and, after developing a slight fever, checked in with the medical unit at the Court. Mr. McGurn said results of the hospital tests would be known within a couple of days.

description: The Chemical Bank denied yesterday that any of its offi cers received any money from Joel Kline, a convicted stock manipulator who borrowed money from the bank.

title: A.T.H. AGREES NET SET RECORD OF $5.27
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company confirmed yesterday that its 1974 net income had reached a new high of $5.27 a share, compared with $4.98 in 1973. John D. deButts, chairman, made the confirmation yesterday in releasing the final annual report. A preliminary earnings statement had been made public on Jan. 15.

title: Fitting Words of Love CustomMade
description: When Western Union discontinued its singing telegrams, it left a void for the sentimentalists who prefer to say Happy birthday or I love you to music.

title: Canadian Economic Drop Spurs Spending Demands
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 12A drastic downturn in the Canadian economy has touched off demands in Parliament that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Government resort to huge spending programs as a stimulant.

title: Common Cause Dismisses Albany Lobbyist
Parker Pen Stock Split
description: A twoforone stock split was announced yesterday by the Parker Pen Company. On April 16, the company will distribute certificates for one additional share of Parker common stock for each share owned on March 14.

title: Common Cause Dismisses Albany Lobbyist
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12The lobbyist for Common Cause, the goodgovernment group, was dismissed today after being denounced overwhelmingly on the floor of the Assembly and condemned for bragging that he had used dirty tricks, armtwisting tactics and alluring women in his efforts to sway legislators.

title: An Optimistic Mrs. Gandhi Angrily Denies India Is Floundering

description: Special to The New York Times

title: Government to Classify Pen Guns as Firearms
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) The Government said today that some of the small tear gas devices used by women to repulse attackers were being used to commit crimes and would be classified as firearms.

title: British Leyland to Close Authi Unit in Spain
description: MADRID, Feb. 12The British Leyland Motor Corporation, Ltd., has decided to close its money  losing automobile plant in Spain after the collapse of negotiations between the Spanish Government and the General Motors Corporation for its purchase.

title: LARRY CROSBY DEAD; SINGER'S BROTHER, 80
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 (AP) Larry Crosby, the older brother of Bing Crosby, died of cancer today at Century City Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: Alexandria Gazette Sold
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 12 (UPI)The Alexandria Gazette Corporation, publishers of the oldest newspaper in the United States, has been purchased by the StateRecord Company. The Alexandria (Va.) Gazette is published every day except Sundays and Christmas.

title: A Lincoln's Birthday Gift
description: For RumrillHoyt and Young & Rubicam, Lincoln's Birthday turned out to be a special daynew business.

title: Sports News Briefs
Knick Flaws Endanger Playoff Berth
description: The Knicks are in trouble. The false sceurity their fans enjoyed when the team rang up 17 victories in its first 25 games is being replaced by reality.

title: Italy Holds Man in Theft of Renaissance Paintings
description: ROME, Feb. 12A man has been arrested on suspicion of being implicated in the theft of three celebrated Renaissance paintings from the ducal palace in Urbino last Thursday, the judicial authorities announced today.

title: Italian Wins Ring Title
description: NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 12 (UPI)  Elio Cotena of Italy won the European featherweight boxing title tonight with an 11thround technical knockout over the defending champion, Jos Antonio Jimenez of Spain. Jimenez had knocked out Cotena in the final minute of their first title fight in Zaragoza, Spain, last year.

title: Edward Barsky, Surgeon, Dies; Joined Spanish Republican Side
description: Dr. Edward K. Barsky, who left his post as a surgeon in New York to join the republican side in the Spanish Civil War in the nineteenthirties, died Tuesday evening at University Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 38 East 85th Street.

title: Rabin Ties Sinai Pullback to End of State of War
description: JERUSALEM, Feb, 12Premier Yitzhak Rabin said in Parliament today that Israel would not withdraw from the mountain passes and the Abu Rudeis oilfields in the Sinai. Peninsula until t Egypt renounced any intention of resuming war.

title: Benjamin Homer, Composer Of Sentimental Journey
description: Benjamin Homer, who composed the music for Sentimental Journey, a hit song of the nineteenforties with lyrics by Bud Green, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Los Angeles. He was 57 years old.

description: MRS. B. O. M'ANNEY

title: COLUNIBIA GETTING MORE APPLICANTS
description: Freshman applications, a vital sign of a college's academic and financial health, are up sharply at Columbia and at New York Universities for next fall.

title: Kuwait Quits 2 Deals Here With Boycotted Financiers
description: KUWAIT, Feb. 12  A Kuwaiti investment firm withdrew today from two international lending syndicates led by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. of New York because participants include an underwriter that is on the Arab boycott list.

title: 6INCH SNOWFALL CRIPPLES TRAVEL AND TRADE IN CITY
description: New York's winter luck ran out yesterday when a storm bringing 6.3 inches of snow blustered into the metropolitan area, blanketing streets and highways, snarling ground and air traffic and touching off a major mobilization of the city's snowfighting forces.

title: POSITION ON LEASING CLARIFIED BY TRAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Russell E. Train, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, has told the Interior Department that the agency does not recommend a twoyear delay in leasing potential oil and gas acreage on the outer continental shelf.

title: Bullets Go Overtime to Beat Bucks
PENTAGON TO URGE AIR RADAR SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Sometime this week Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger will send to Congress a letter seeking to justify the construction of a squadron of airborne radar command posts at a cost of about $4billion.

title: POLICE KILL BOY HERE IN STOLENCAR CHASE
description: A 15yearold Bronx boy was shot and killed early yesterday by a policeman who said the boy lunged at him with, a knife following a chase of a stolen car.

title: Phone Privacy Hearings Set
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP)  Representative Robert W. Kastenmeier, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee's) Subcommittee on Civil Liberties announced today that the subcommittee would hold hearings! next Tuesday on allegations of Bell System monitoring of private telephone calls. The Wisconsin Democrat said the witnesses would include William Caming, chief attorney for the Bell System and Earl Conners security chief for the Washington office of the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company

title: Mrs. Thatcher Names Whitelaw as Her Deputy
description: LONDON, Feb. 12 Margaret Thatcher, the new leader of the Conservative party, today chose William Whitelaw, her main rival in yesterday's election, as her deputy.

title: CBS Drops Plan to Extend News Time
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 12CBSTV, which for several years has been trying to expand its network news programs, has had to abandon the idea of adding 15 minutees to the halfhour Evening News With Walter Cronkite because of opposition from a number of its affiliated stations.

title: Loss of Job and Insurance A Growing Welfare Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The nation's growing unemployment rate has produced a new and controversial socialwelfare issue: whether the Federal Government should provide health insurance coverage for people who lose their jobs and also their medical insurance.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: NEWSCHOOL COST PUT AT 2.4BILLION
description: NEWARK, Feb. 12 (UPI)Even though enrollments may be declining, New Jersey will need $2.4billion over the next 10 years to build new schools or refurbish old ones, Dr. Fred G. Burke, the State Education Commissioner, said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CERVINLA, Italy, Feb. 12 (AP)The first mishap in four days of training for the world twoman bobsled championships occurred today when the American sled guided by Jim Morgan and Tom Becker flipped during the second heat of official trials. Neither Morgan, of Saranac Lake, N. Y., nor Becker, of Indianapolis, was hurt.

title: ARMSTRONG IS RULED A PATENT INFRINGER
description: The Armstrong Cork Company said yesterday it had been notified that the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Pennsylvania held that the company had infringed on the chemically embossed floor coverings patents of Congoleum Industries, Inc.,. The decision applies to Armstrong's domestic manufacture of certain types of retovinyl flooring during the period from 1967 through 1972.

title: Ship Losses Set Record
description: LONDON, Feb. 12 (Reuters) The value of ships lost at sea in 1974 was the highest ever, Lloyds Shipping Agency said today. Lloyds Intelligence Services showed that a total of 71 vessels were lost last year. Their gross tonnage was 681,706 and they had an insured value of about $273million. In 1973, 54 vessels with an insured value of some $212mililon were lost.

title: MarketValue List Of Holdings Asked
description: Companies holding current investments in stocks and bonds are likely to have to list them at market value in financial statements published this year, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants indicated yesterday in a new auditing interpretation.

title: Stage: Weller's Fishing at the Public Theater
description: The playwright Michael Weller, who found fame as the author of Moonchildren, has done it again. In fact, it is possible that he has done too much of it again. There are times when his new play. Fishing, which opened last night at the Newman Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater complex, is so much like its predecessor in mood and tone that it might have been called Moongrandchildren. No matter, Fishing is a perceptive picture of a generation or at least one aspect of it.

title: PROFITS ROSE IN 1974 AT GOLDMAN, SACHS
description: Goldman, Sachs & Co., the privately owned investment banking house, said yesterday,  without disclosing actual numbersthat profits rose last year, although by less than in the unusually profitable 197072 period.

title: Manila Tightens Sugar Curb; Sale Is Temporarily Stopped
description: MANILA, Feb. 12The Philippine Government tightened its control of sugar today. It stopped all sales until stocks of sugar, a main source of export revenue, had been inventoried.

title: They Gave Up the Concert Hall, Temporarily, for Motherhood
description: Any woman who gives up her career to look after her children and then tries to go back to it is. likely to find the going rough. For musicians, it is so difficult that it seldom happens. But then, musicians rarely take much time out. They know how much they lose if they neglect their talent and they also know that the concertgoing public had better not be given a chance to forget. Three musicians whose careers were off to flying starts they were all child prodigiesstopped performing just as their careers were beginning to scar. Now they are trying to regain the spotlight.

title: UNIONS HAIL MOVE ON HIGHWAY FUNDS
SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW DECLINES
description: Prices fell on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after soybean oil futures dropped the limit of 100 points, or I cent a pound. Soybeans declined 15 cents a bushel, while soybean meal lost about $1 a ton. Corn and wheat fell about 3 cents a bushel each.

title: Human Rights Nominee
description: Governor Carey nominated yesterday as the state's new Commissioner of the Division of Civil Rights a longtime civilrights advocate. Though he has not been involved in demonstrations, picketing or ourt battles, associates have described him as a humanist liberal who believes in government's ability to solve human problems. The nominee 48yearold Werner Hans Kramarsky, said he was a bit surprised when Governor Carey asked him last week to take the $43,050ayear post.

title: Americans in Turkey Encountering Signs of Strain
description: ANKARA. Turkey, Feb. 11 An American woman who works for Boeing here was joking with Turkish friends the other day. They asked me if I had bought my airplane ticket yet, she related, and I said, Yeah, the Russians are coming to get you, and I'm going.

title: Mothball Fleet Shut Down
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 12 (UPI) The San Diego Mothball fleet, which was the home for 223 World War II ships in 1960, will be reduced to zero by June 30, the United States Navy announced today. The six combat and 18 service ships still remaining at the Naval Inactive Ships Maintenance Facility will be sold for scrap or used as targets, the Navy said.

title: These Dodgers Win (Super Team) Final
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 12 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Minnesota Vikings yesterday to win the Super Teams championship.

title: City Offers a $4 Book On Rights of Tenants
description: The Beame administration announced yesterday the publication of a 129page book on tenant's rights that provides simple explanation of the laws here dealing with rents, landlord and tenant responsibilities and evictions. It tells which city agencies to call for a variety of housing related problems.

title: Cosmos 708 Launched
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (AP)The Soviet Union launched its 708th unmanned Cosmos satellite today, the press agency Tass announced.

title: Kuwait Quits 2 Deals Here With Boycotted Financiers
description: KUWAIT, Feb. 12  A Kuwaiti investment firm withdrew today from two international lending syndicates led by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. of New York because participants include an underwriter that is on the Arab boycott list.

title: We Are Free to Go
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 12The husband of Gloria Bentley said she had telephoned him at their home in the Chicago suburb of Highwood this afternoon and said, We are free to go.

title: Would Rename Nixon School
description: HIAWATHA, Iowa, Feb. 12 (UPI)A clergyman here says he wants to see the Richard M. Nixon Elementary School renamed the Abraham Lincoln Elementary School. The Rev. William Harnish said in a letter to the school board the name change would provide a memorial in honor of Abraham Lincoln, a great President, and, in turn, remove the name of a President who resigned office in disgrace.

title: Economic Warfare
description: While some Arabs talk softly about coming to terms with Israel, other Arab interests are showing no hesitation in using their newfound financial power for unabashed harassment of firms and institutions believed sympathetic to Israel. More distasteful even than current attempts at money market blackmail is the appalling willingness of some otherwise distinguished European financial institutions to cave in to Arab demands.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1975

title: Dantley, Core of the Irish, Is Apple of Scouts Eyes
description: Student No. 731193007 has emerged into something special at Notre Dame. He is Adrian Dantley, the sophomore basketball star whose 6foot5 inch, 225  pound frame makes tight ends envious.

title: Rhodesians Political Discussions Appear to Hit a Snag
STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW ADVANCES
description: Despite closing an hour and onehalf earlier because of the snowstorm, the American Stock Exchange saw an increase in volume yesterday as prices finished slightly higher. Prices also were up in the overthecounter market.

title: Ford Considering A Woman Attorney For Cabinet Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Carla Anderson Hills, Assistant Attorney General for the Department of Justice's Civil Division, is under consideration as the possible nominee as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, a White House source confirmed tonight.

title: Sizable Money Growth Is Urged by Senate Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (Reuters)Three Democratic Senators introduced today a bill calling on the Federal Reserve Board to increase the money supply by a substantial rate.

title: SENATE UNIT, 122, SUPPORTS FREEZE ON OIL LEVY RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The Senate Finance Committee approved today legislation that would for 90 days bar President Ford from imposing higher import fees on oil.

title: Sweden Enacts Programs to Make Workers Both Safe and Happy
CORRECTION
description: The obituary of Mrs. Mildred Fairchild Woodbury, labor economist and educator, in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly referred to her as Miss Woodbury.

title: CBS Shows Profit Rise; Losses Cut by Memorex
Released Funds to Repair Highways
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP)The $2billion in highway funds released by President Ford will be used mainly to update and renew existing road systems and not for new construction, Federal Highway Administrator Norbert T. Tiemann said today.

title: UNIONS HAIL MOVE ON HIGHWAY FUNDS
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 12 President Ford's release of $6billion in impounded construction funds over the last two weeks and a visit today by the Secretary of Labordesignate have produced some signs of optimism among leaders of the building trades unions.

title: Palestinians Reported to Agree To Halt South Lebanon Action
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 12Palestinian guerrillas agreed at the meeting of the Arab Defense Council in Cairo last week to suspend operations against Israel from southern Lebanon, it was reported here today.

title: CITY TO SELL NOTES WORTH $260MILLION
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin announced yesterday that the city would sell $260million. worth of taxanticipation notes next Wednesday to replace funds the city had expected to receive from another, postponed sale.

title: OIL NATIONS CASH SURGING INTO U.S.
Kirtland I. King, 62, Dies; ExState Manager for U.P.I.
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12 (UPI)Kirtland I. King, a political writer and columnist who retired in 1972 as New York State manager of United Press International, died today at a hospital here. He was 62 years old.

title: An Israeli's Open Letter To Kissinger
description: Following are excerpts from an open letter to Secretary of State Kissinger written by Yirmiyahu Yovel, head of the Hebrew University philosophy institute and an outspoken dove. It appeared in the daily Haaretz just before Mr. Kissinger began his latest round of Middle Eastern diplomacy, and was translated front the Hebrew by the author.

title: Lincoln's Birthday Closings
description: The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, the Commodity Exchange and the New York Cocoa Exchange were closed yesterday because of the Lincoln's Birthday holiday. There was no foreignexchange trading because New York banks were closed. Government bond markets were also closed.

title: Levitt Says State Favors Charity Nursing Homes
description: Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that the State Health Department provided funds for more space and better equipment in charitable nursing homes than for those that were privately owned.

title: CORRECTION
description: The obituary of Mrs. Mildred Fairchild Woodbury, labor economist and educator, in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly referred to her as Miss Woodbury.

title: Levitt Scores State On Nursing Homes
description: Controller Arthur Levitt said the state Medicaid program had created two classes of nursing care: a higher grade in voluntary homes and lower in proprietary ones. He criticized the State Health Department for inadequate regulation, and for giving advance notice of inspections of nursing homes.

title: Hearings on Condominium Rules End
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Three days of public hearings marked by sharp differences over whether the Government should regulate condominium sales were completed today by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Report Asserts Fairfield Needs No New Expressways for Years
Art of Max Ernst. Undiscovered Master, Shown
Personal Finance: Jobless Insurance May Be Paid With Social Security
description: Men and women who retire and collect Social Security benefits often wonder if they are also entitled to unemployment insurance.

title: Wide Impact Seen Should Arbitrator Rule for the P.B.A.
description: The city warned at a contract arbitration hearing yesterday that a decision in favor of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association would probably result in immediate demands for similartreatment from higherranking policemen as well as firemen, sanitationmen, correction officers and housing and transit policemen.

title: Pentagon Chief Defends Training of Saudi Force
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today there is no impropriety involved in a Government contract with the Vinnell Corporation to provide training to internal security forces in Saudi Arabia.

title: School Honors A Black Parent
description: While Black History Week is celebrating the contributions of historic black figures, Public School 49 in the South Bronx is planning a ceremony tomorrow honoring Marion E. Rose, a 31yearold mother of four whoes efforts to unite black and Puerto Rican parents are worthy, school officials feel, of a place in history.

title: Art of Max Ernst, Undiscovered Master, Shown
description: Max Ernst at his very best looks more and more like a major artist in a minor world. His very best tends to come into sight, moreover, at a time in life when most major artists have long ago been pinned down and documented.

title: PAUL PHILLIPS, LED PAPERMAKERS UNION
description: Paul L. Phillips, president of the International Brotherhood of Papermakers from 1948 to 1968, died last Thursday in Leesburg, Fla. He was 70 years old.

title: KISSINGER SAYS TALK WITH SADAT YIELDS PROGRESS
description: CAIRO, Feb. 12Secretary of State Kissinger, after a review of the Middle East situation with President Anwar elSadat lot Egypt, said today that progress had been made in clarifying issues between Israel and Egypt and in pointing out the direction in which a solution could be found.

title: Miss Goolagong Wins in Return
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (UPI)Chris Evert had a battle, but Evonne Goolagong and Margaret Court advanced easily in their opening matches in the $75,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament last night.

title: C.I.A. and Police in Virginia Admit Agency Got Badges
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Suburban police and the Central Intelligence Agency acknowledge today that the police had provided the agency with police credentials in connection with an investigation into security leaks.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A state commission recommended that the state's Health Department be given special monitoring power over the New York City Medical Examiner's office in compiling statistics on methadonerelated deaths. The panel, issuing an interim report on the drug laws to the Legislature and the Governor, said such a step was advisable because of the controversy over methadone death statistics in New York City. The report, which was made public by the Temporary State Commission to Evaluate the Drug Laws, made about 30 other recommendations. Generally, it was critical of the drugfree, therapeutic communitytreatment programs and more positive in its conclusions about methadone treatment programs.

title: Expert's Memory Leads to Recovery Of L.I. Estate Loot
description: An art expert's memory coupled with a hunch about $100,000 burglary has led to the recovery of a number of important stolen objects just few days before they were scheduled to be auctioned off by the Sotheby Parke Bernet Galleries here.

title: S.S. Hope Beached To Prevent Sinking After Tug Ramming
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 12 (AP)The hospital ship S.S. Hope, a worldwide symbol of United States aid to underdeveloped nations, was deliberately run aground just south of here after a tug towing the ship to the scrap pile accidentally rammed her.

title: Yugoslavia Expels 2 American Women On Politics Charge
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Thursday, Feb. 13Two American women, detained by the police in their hotel for the last three days on charges of engaging in hostile political activity, have been ordered to leave Yugoslavia within 24 hours.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: BERNARD R. WILSON

title: Real Campaign Reform
description: In recognition of the voters mandate for searching and fundamental reform in campaign financing, Governor Carey promised in his State of the State Message last month to press legislation that would provide partial public financing of candidates for state office and also place rigorous new limits on private campaign contributions.

title: U.S. Starts Bigger Airlift Into Cambodia to Replenish Supplies
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 12  An expanded American airlift went into operation today in an attempt to replenish some of this city's dwindling vital suppliesammunition in particular.

title: McFarland Testifies on Rozelle Rule
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 12 (AP)  Jim McFarland, a St. Louis Cardinal tight end, said today he thought he was to he sent to Kansas City as a free agent but was told the Cards wanted too much, a secondround draft choice. That's the reason given him by the Chiefs coach, Hank Stram, two years ago, after he'd played an option year without a contract, McFarland testified in United States District Court.

title: Velez Gains Ground as Top Badillo Rival
description: City Councilman Ramon S. Velez, who came here from Puerto Rico 14 years ago and is still virtually unknown outside the South Bronx, is becoming such a major figure in the Bronx Democratic organization that he is now a likely challenger of Representative Herman Badillo as the most powerful Puerto Rican politician in the city.

title: Albert Perkins, 70, Writer, Teacher, Magazine Editor
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP)Albert R. Perkins, who wrote motionpicture scripts and had been managing editor of Outdoor Life, Sport and American magazines, was found dead Monday in the surf of the Pacific Ocean. Circumstances of his death were not immediately known. He was 70 years old.

title: Esther Shephard, 83, Wrote Of Paul Bunyan for Young
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 (UPI)Esther Shephard, a writer and professor emeritus of English at San Jose State University, died here Monday. She was 83 years old.

title: Snow Dashes Hopes of Merchaints as It Freezes Sales
description: Not only did yesterday's snowstorm bury the city's streets and highways, it also buried the hopes of retail merchants throughout the metropolitan area who had looked forward to Lincoln's Birthday, one of their busiest sales days of the year.

title: REPORT BY AIRLINE IS DENIED BY C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Spokesmen for the Civil Aeronautics Board and the White House denied today that any action had been taken on a major route agreement between Pan American World Airways and American Airlines.

title: A Destiny Not So Manifest
Books of The Times
description: When I read that, in order to support himself, Samuel Johnson reviewed, among other things, A Treatise on Distilling Sea Water, and on Curing an Ill Taste in Milk, I felt a warm sympathy toward him. The most formidable literary mart of the 18th century also had to eat the plat du jour.

title: CITY TO SELL NOTES WORTH $260MILLION
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin announced yesterday that the city would sell $260million worth of taxanticipation notes next Wednesday to replace funds the city had expected to receive from another, postponed sale.

title: U.S. IS CRITICIZED AT TRADE TALKS
description: GENEVA, Feb. 12The United States was criticized today at the world trade talks here for excluding members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries from benefits accorded developing nations under its Trade Reform Act.

title: Jersey Reckoning
description: Governor Byrne's $2.8bilIion rockbottom budget confronts the recalcitrant New Jersey State Senate with what the Governor rightly terms a moment of reckoning.

title: Scovill and Hewlett Packard Announce Price Reductions
description: The Scovill Manufacturing Company said it would reduce the base price of all freecutting brass rod items effective immediately.

title: Albany Police Pension Bill Proposed to Avert Layoffs;
description: A bill will be filed in the State Senate today that, its sponsors say, could forestall the threatened layoff of 500 New York police rookies and students at the Police Academy by improving police pensions at no cost to the city.

title: Advertising
description: Frequently when an advertiser wants to pick a certain kind of target audience on television he will do it by finding out what folks watch which programs. Radio advertisers know that certain stations reach certain types. Many magazines intentionally appeal only to a segment of the entire market.

title: Mr. Kissinger's War: II
description: WASHINGTON Why is Henry Kissinger so determined to hold back the process of political change and accommodation in South Vietnama process that even rightwing Vietnamese want to begin? Why does he support President Thieu in his refusal to carry out the political terms of the 1973 peace agreement?

title: Under Review
description: Representatives of the governments of the Arab League are scheduled to meet in Cairo later this month for a periodic review of the old Arab boycott against Israel. Ever since the start of Jewish settlement in Palestine, neighboring Arab regimes have attempted to enforce economic sanctions, not only prohibiting the most routine contacts between Israel and the Arab states but also attempting to exclude foreign companies which invest in Israeli ventures from simultaneously doing business in the Arab world. Over the decades, this boycott has often seemed more of a monument to futility than an effective economic weapon; indeed, it forced the Israelis to develop their own economy and industrial base more rapidly than they might otherwise have done.

title: SENATE UNIT, 122, SUPPORTS FREEZE ON OIL LEVY RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The Senate Finance Committee approved today legislation that would for 90 days bar President Ford from imposing higherr import fees on oil.

title: Ski Conditions
description: (Reports are supplied by resort owners.)

title: F.B.I. DIRECTOR BARS NEW DALLAS INQUIRY
description: DALLAS, Feb. 12 (AP) Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that the F.B.I. would not reopen the investigation into the assassination of President Kennedy.

title: Morton Retreats on Ocean Oil Drilling
description: TRENTON, Feb. 12Threatened with court action by both New Jersey and New York to block its offshore oil leasing program, the Department of the Interior withdrew today an invitation to oil companies to designate midAtlantic Coast drilling sites they might want to bid on.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Lamson Sues A. G. Edwards Over Hiring of Employes
description: Lamson Bros. & Co., a Chicago brokerage firm, reported yesterday that is it had filed a $1.5million antitrust suit against A. G. Edwards & Sons, Inc., a St. Louis stockbrokerage house on charges that it tried to hire Lamson employes and encouraged them to take their clients with them.

title: Petrodollar Outlook
Hearings on Condominium Rules End
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Three days of public hearings marked by sharp differences over whether the Government should regulate condominium sales were completed today by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Petrodollar Outlook
Deafness No Handicap To jersey Court Star
description: For nearly four seasons now, Ernie Goodis has been causing excitement with his basketball scoring exploits, much like any other talented high school youngster who can contribute 30 points a game. His 6foot2inch size dictates that he perform in the forecourt, although he has the dribbling ability and the court sense to play at guard. He has a better than 50 per cent shooting average, scores well off the drive and is a strong rebounder.

title: Checks on Snoops
description: Although the Watergate irregulars gave unregulated snooping in the name of national security a black eye, no better safeguards than the unchecked judgment of the Attorney General and the Federal Bureau of Investigation against more such abuses have yet been developed by the Congress. If the case for erecting tighter safeguards needed additional support, it received it last week when a House subcommittee heard testimony about a warrantless wiretap on a person's phone which was maintained for twentyfive years. The panel also was told about the tapping of forty conversations between a lawyer and his clients, presumably on the ground that some of those clients were Arab students, and the interception by Army agents overseas of a host of conversations between lawyers and their clients.

title: Loss by Lobstermen Laid to Soviet Vessels
description: EATONTOWN, Feb. 12 (AP)  Daniel Waldman, a lawyer representing five Monmouth County lobstermen, says a claim will be filed in Washington within a week seeking reimbursement for lobster gear allegedly destroyed by Soviet fishing trawlers.

title: Ford Wins Praise for His Energy Efforts, but Not for His Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12President. Ford, in his campaign through the country to sell his economic and energy program, has been winning high marks for his efforts, but he has been encountering strong opposition, even within his own party, to his plan to cut oil consumption by raising prices.

title: Enter Mrs. Thatcher
description: One need not share Margaret Thatcher's political philosophy to applaud her overwhelming and historic victory in the struggle for leadership of Britain's Conservative party. For the first time a woman has become head of one of the two major parties in Parliament, thus putting herself in line to become Prime Minister should the Conservatives win the next national election. The stunning nature of her triumph deals a mortal wound to the assumption that male chauvinism and political conservatism must inevitably go together.

title: 2 Plants Will Be Added to the 5 Shut Down
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12  The chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Thomas A. Murphy, said today he hoped G.M. would be able to begin recalling by spring workers it had laid off indefinitely. He also expressed hope there would be no more temporary layoffs after next month.

title: Scheinblum in Japan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 12 (AP)Richie Scheinblum, a former major league outfielder arrived in Japan today to play professional baseball for the Hiroshima Carp of the Central League.

title: Mayor Tells Chemical Company To Get Rid of Its Fumes or Close
President Park Is Easy Victor In Korea Referendum on Policy
Sperry Rand Sets Venture With Saab To Sell Computers
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation and SaabScania, A.B., of Sweden announced yesterday the formation of a joint venture to market and service electronic data processing equipment in Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden.

title: H. GORDON SMITH, 84, EXUNIROYALOFFICER
description: H. Gordon Smith, former director and executive vice president of Uniroyal, Inc., died Tuesday at McDuffy County Hospital, Thomson, Ga. He was 84 years old and lived in Thomson.

title: Snowfall Puts Icing On Cake at Resorts
description: Since the era of the rope tow and ski train began four decades ago, skiarea operators have considered a substantial snowstorm in metropolitan centers, the best advertisement for attracting crowds. Yesterday they were joyful for just that reason as New York, Philadelphia and Hartford had sizable snowfalls. Actually they didn't need such promotional help.

title: China Plans to Enter Frankfurt Book Fair
description: China, emerging further from her cultural isolation from the West, will participate in this year's Frankfurt Book Fair, Peter Weidhaas, the fair's director, said yesterday.

title: Leadership in Justice
MADAGASCAR REBELS SAID TO SURRENDER
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, Feb. 12 (Reuters)Most of the police rebels blamed for the assassination of the Malagasy head of state surrendered tonight at their camp outside the capital, informed sources said.

title: Lakewood May Pay Bounty to Informers
description: LAKEWOOD, Feb. 12Officials here are scheduled to formally propose tonight a $3,000 appropriation to finance regular rewards for information leading to the conviction of burglars and robbers who have plagued the township in recent months.

title: Hearings on Increase In Rail Fares Slated
description: TRENTON, Feb. 12 (AP)The State Department of Transportation has announced that public hearings will begin March 11 on a proposed 25 per cent fare increase for the state's four subsidized commuter railroads.

title: Inflation's Grip Tightens on Poor
Ford to Speak at Fete For Rockefeller Here
description: President Ford will address the New York Society of Security Analysts here this afternoon and attend a testimonial dinner for Vice President Rockefeller tonight.

title: Film: Trying to Sum Up Janis Joplin
Thieu Sets Back His Saigon Opponents
9 PLANTS CLOSED BY M'GRAW EDISON
description: ELGIN, Ill., Feb. 12 (UPI)The McGraw Edison Company announced today it had temporarily closed nine manufacturing plants in seven states and laid off 9,500 employes, more than onethird of its work force, because of poor sales.

title: Ethiopia National Survival Seems at Stake in Eritrea
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 12The continuing fighting in the northern province of Eritrea, now in its 12th day, has begun to be regarded by some foreign diplomats and a number of prominent Ethiopians as a war for Ethiopia's survival as a nation.

title: Holiday and Snow Cut Bond Trading
description: The combination of the Lincoln's birthday holiday and a snowstorm in the New York area brought light activity in the bond market yesterday. The Government markets were idle as New York banks closed for the holiday. In the municipal market, further progress was reported in two large offerings that were, marketed Tuesday. New York City's $141million of Arated bonds, priced to yield 6.5 per cent in 1976 and 7.5 per cent in 2025, were reported to be about threequarters sold, with some additional retail buying reported yesterday.

title: Support Given Farm Workers
description: KEENE. Calif., Feb. 12 (UPI) Ralph D. Abernathy, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, has endorsed a consumer boycott of Gallo wines, the United Farm Workers said today after a meeting of Mr. Abernathy and Caesar Chavez, the head of the farm workers union. The boycott began in 1973 over the issue of union representation.

title: Scheinblum in Japan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 12 (AP)Richie Scheinblum, a former major league outfielder arrived in Japan today to play professional baseball for the Hiroshima Carp of the Central League.

title: Expert's Memory Leads to Recovery Of LI. Estate Loot
description: An art expert's memory coupled with a hunch about a $100,000 burglary has led to the recovery of a number of important stolen objects just a few days before they were scheduled to be auctioned off by the Sotheby Parke Bernet Galleries here.

title: Stock Prices Show A Broad Advance
Westminster's Best Turns Clock Back to 1914 and 1918
description: For the first time, in 61 years. an Old English sheepdog is the Westminster Kennel Club show champion of champions. Late Tuesday night, after 22 minutes of contemptation, Harry T. Peters chose Ch. Sir Lancelot of Barvan as best of 3,035 dogs in Madison Square Garden at the 99th edition of America's blueribbon classic.

title: New Senate Panel May Study F.B.I. Drive on Arab Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Efforts of the. Federal Bureau of Investigation to combat Arab guerrilla terrorismthe efforts allegedly included a burglary of the Arab Information Center in Dallas by Government agentsare likely to come under the scrutiny of a new Senate committee, according to Senate sources.

title: Mich. State Star Put on Probation
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (UPI)Terry Furlow, the Michigan State star and Big Ten basketball scoring leader, was placed on probation by Commissioner Wayne Duke today for striking Rick Schmidt of Illinois in a game Feb. 2.

title: Queen Seeks Rise In Expense Budget
Abdullah Confirms India Accord Giving Him Kashmir Leadership
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 12Reports that India had reached agreement with the Kashmiri Moslem leader, Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, allowing him to take over as chief minister of the Indiancontrolled part of Kashmir, were, confirmed today by the sheik.

title: Libyan Oil Output Down
description: VIENNA, Feb. 12 (Reuters)Libya reduced oil production by 303 per cent in 1974 to 1,515.000 barrels a day from 1973's 2,174,900 barrels a day, according to provisional figures issued today by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: People and Business
description: The New York Stock Exchange has an unexpected problem on its hands. Three directors have told the Big Board that because of the press of business they will not stand for reelection when their terms expire next May.

title: 3 Americans, Held 4 Years In Cuba, Return to the U.S.
description: MIAMI, Feb. 12  Three Americans jailed in Cuba for four years on charges of smuggling a ton of marijuana, arrived here tonight from Kingston, Jamaica, after being freed earlier in the day.

title: Morton Retreats on Ocean Oil Drilling
Guns and Butter
description: WASHINGTONI can recall few documents as shocking and as sobering as the Administration's proposed budget for the 1976 fiscal year.

title: Contract Awards
description: Venezuela has signed a $70million contract with the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., to produce animal food based on protein extracted from crude oil. The Venezuelan Government will have a 60 per cent share in the plant be constructed at Puerto La Cruz. British Petroleum will have a 20 per cent share with the remainder divided among local companies. The protein, extracted from crude oil under a process developed by B.P., will be designed for poultry and pigs.

title: Westminster's Best Turns Clock Back to 1914 and 1918
description: For the first time in 61 years, an Old English sheepdog is the Westminster Kennel. Club show champion of champions. Late Tuesday night, after 22 minutes of contemplation, Harry T. Peters chose Ch. Sir Lancelot of Barvan as best of 3,035 dogs in Madison Square Garden at the 99th edition of America's blueribbon classic.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1975

title: TV: Imaginative Queen of the Stardust Ballroom
description: Queen of the Stardust Ballroom a play with music that CBS will present at 9 this evening, is a stunningly imaginative project defeated by a woefully inadequate ending.

title: Carey Budget Denounced At Legislative Hearing
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12Members of the Legislature heard Governor Carey's proposed budget and new taxes dissected and deplored today by dozens of mayors, civic leaders, school officials and advocates for a wide array of special interests at the first of two daylong public hearings.

title: Police Pension Bill May Avert Layoffs
description: A bill will be filed in the State Senate today that its sponsors say could forestall the threatened layoff of 500 New York City police rookies and students at the Police Academy by improving pensions at no cost to the city.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Two oil companies, the Exxon Corporation and the Marathon Oil Company, lost interlocutory rounds today in their legal battles to overturn the Federal Energy Administration's costequalization regulation for refiners. A Threejudge panel of the temporary emergency court of appeals vacated a Jan. 31 order by Chief Judge Edward A. Tamm enjoining the agency from requiring Marathon to pay $3.6million to other refiners under the regulation. Within hours, Marathon applied to Chief Justice Warren E. Burger for a stay.

title: RALPH FABRI DIES; ARTIST AND TEACHER
High Jump of 71 To Stay Unofficial
description: NEW ROCHELLE, Feb. 13 The 7foot 1inch high jump made by Rudy Reavis of New Rochelle High School on Tuesday will not be submitted for approval as a national interscholastic indoor record, his coach, Joe Soprano, said today. Two schoolboys have cleared 7 feet, Noel Ruebel of Highland High, Ind., last year and Tim Walker of Rogers High of Providence, R.I., this season.

title: Options Trading Found Free of Discord
description: A study of trading in stock options, conducted by a prominent economic consulting firm, has found no significant evidence of a disturbing effect on the stock market.

title: Maker of Household Items Advances
Jury in Boston Abortion Trial Listens to the Final Arguments
description: BOSTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)The Jury hearing the abortionmanslaughter trial of Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin was urged today to find the physician guilty of the white coat killing of a fetus in a legal abortion.

title: When It's Midnight in Manhattan
description: Arbitration hearings on baseball salaries open today in New York, where the docket is relatively uncrowded because Charley Finley isn't around. Proceedings have been under way since Wednesday in San Francisco, where there is a glut of cases matching members of the Oakland A's against the feudal lord who owns them. It is expected that in a week or so, impartial referees in New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Chicago will have fixed the 1975 wages of 35 or 40 players. This is the second year of salary arbitration and the case load is larger than in 1974, partly because of Finley's reluctance to reward his employes for winning the world championship three times in a row and partly because awards last year ranged as high as Reggie Jackson's $60,000 increase (from $75,000 to $135,000.)

title: Bergen Grand Jury Hears 5 Witnesses On Leonia Murder
description: HACKENSACK, Feb. 13Five witnesses appeared today before a Bergen County grand jury investigating the Jan. 8 murder of Maria Fasching in Leonia and the assault on a housewife in Dumont a day earlier.

title: Bergen Request for New Dump Rejected by Meadowlands Unit
description: The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission yesterday rejected Bergen County's request for permission to turn a 90acre site on the North ArlingtonLyndhurst line into a garbage dump.

title: Suicide of Big Executive: Stress of Corporate Life
Ford Will Name a Woman T o Be Secretary of H.U.D.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The White House announced today that President Ford would nominate a woman, Carla Anderson Hills, to be Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and the nomination immediately ran into opposition.

title: Business Briefs
description: The nation's mutual savings banks gained $225million in deposits in January as interest rates in the money market tumbled and depositors were less tempted to shift funds into higher yielding fixedincome securities.

title: INQUIRY ORDERED AT GIRLS' CENTER
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13The fiscal committees of the Legislature heard testimony today charging that the Hudson State Training School for Girls is dangerous and unsanitary, with poor mediical care, lax administration, a high incidence of homosekual activity and security so poor that many and sometimes most of the residents run away.

title: Sun Oil Increases Prices; FMC Raises Costs of Acid
description: The Sun Oil Company increased its prices far No. gaseline kerosene and No. 2 distillate and diesel fuel by 2 cents a gallon yesterday to ail customers in its marketing area. Earlier this week, Sun Oil raised prices on heavier fuels.

title: The Woman Who Is to Be Named to H.U.D. Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13One year ago yesterday, a California lawyer named Carla Anderson Hills was named the new head of the Justice Department's Civil Division.

title: Ford Says He Has Named Rockefeller To Oversee Work of Domestic Council
description: In his first joint appearance here with Vice President Rockefeller, President Ford announced last night that he had designated Mr. Rockefeller to oversee the Domestic Council and had appointed two Rockefeller aides to key positions on the council.

title: CAIRO DESCRIBES TALKS AS BUOYING
description: CAIRO, Feb. 13Egyptian officials declared themselves encouraged today by their talks with Secretary of State Kissinger but emphatically reiterated that Egypt would not give a pledge of nonbelligerency to Israel in exchange for an Israeli withdrawal in Sinai.

title: Gov. Grasso Offers $1.4Billion Budget
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 13  Gov. Ella T. Grasso tonight presented the Connecticut General Assembly with a record $1.43billion budget request with little relief for the hardpressed cities and towns and a proposed 1cent increase in the sales tax.

title: Liddy's Father Dies at 75
description: Sylvester J. Liddy, a New York patent lawyer and father of G. Gordon Liddy, a figure in the Watergate breakin, died Wednesday evening, apparently of a heart attack, at the home of a friend in Caldwell, N. J. He was 75 years old and lived at 55 Hillcrest Road, West Caldwell. Also surviving are his widow, the former Maria Abbaticchio; a daughter, Mrs. John McDermott, and nine grandchildren.

title: Bond Industries Receivables To Be Sold to Citicorp Unit
description: Bond Industries, Inc., which operates the 119 Bond clothing stores, announced yesterday a fiveyear agreement with Citicorp Custom Credit, Inc., under which Bond Stores will sell to Citicorp present and future receivables arising from credit sales under the Bond chargeaccount plans.

title: U.S. Panel Is Told State Expects 11% Jobless Rate
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 13A halfmillion hungry children and an 11 per cent rate of unemployment in New Jersey were predicted here today by state officials testifying before the United States Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee.

title: DETAILED TALKS ON TRADE SLATED
description: GENEVA, Feb. 13Industrialized and developing nations agreed here today to begin on March 3 the detailed bargaining phase of their trade talks. The steering committee formed by all 90 nations that are participating in the talks approved at the close of a threeday planning session a timetable that will have the negotiations on most key issues under way before the end of next month.

title: DRUG DEALER GETS 20 YEARS IN PRISON
description: Anthony Torres of 29 West 65th Street was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison and $70,000 in fines for the sale of 330 pounds of heroin and cocaine that had been concealed in antique pictute frames and smuggled through customs here.

title: Brezhnev, Back in Public, Meets Wilson
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 13Leonid I. Brezhnev, smiling and looking fit, emerged today from seven weeks of seclusion to greet Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain when he arrived at the Kremlin on an official visit.

title: Books of The Times
Dollar Down Again In Europe Markets
Stein Implies Carey Bowed To Steingut on Commission
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein suggested yesterday that Governor Carey had decided to terminate the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs, which Mr. Stein heads, in deference to the Speaker of the Assembly, Stanley Steingut.

title: Dr. Henry Van Dusen, 77, Of Union Seminary, Dies
description: Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president of Union Theological Seminary from 1945 until he retired in 1963 and a leading ecumenist, died yesterday, apparently of a heart ailment, at the Carrier Clinic in Belle Meade, N. J. He was 77 years old and lived at 27 Armour Road, Princeton, N. J.

title: STERNDENT GETS OFFER FOR STOCK
description: The Cable Funding Corporation said yesterday it was making a cash tender offer of $14 share for 1,080,000 of Sterndent Corporation's common stock shares. The offer, through Salomon Brothers, involves $15  million for just over half of Sterndent's stock.

title: City's Plan Voted by Sanitation Union
description: The Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association has approved the agreement that its president, John J. DeLury, worked out with Mayor Beame last month to avert the layoffs of 235 sanitationmen, Mr. DeLury said yesterday.

title: Silver Lining?
description: After the dreary forecasts he has been receiving from his own economic advisers, President Ford must have found it refreshing to visit Wall Street and find the stock exchanges forging upward on record trading volume.

title: Cuomo Warns on Premature Judging Of Lobbyist Ousted by Common Cause
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo warned today against premature judgment of Albert Podell, the lobbyist dismissed yesterday by Common Cause following a twohour attack and resolution of disapproval by the Assembly.

title: FINE PIANO RECITAL BY MISS PETROWSKA
description: Christina Petrowska, the Canadian pianist who specializes in 20thcentury music, came to Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night to play Book Two of Debussy's Preludes and works, composed since 150 by Stockhausen, Boulez, Giles Tremblay, Valentin Silvestrov and her husband, MichelGeorges Brgent.

title: Thrift Shops: Money in Bank For Customers and Charities
description: It might have been any department store on a busy, bargainsale afternoon: customers picking avidly over things, getting in one another's way. But there was also a rare kind of camaraderie between salesclerks and customers.

title: Business Records
Visa Extensions Ending In LaborSaving Move
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that as a manpowersaving measure it would cease extending tourist visas as of midnight Saturday.

title: EDITH STERN, WRITER ON MENTAL HEALTH
description: Edith Mendel Stern, a wellknown writer on mental health, died Saturday at Suburban Hospital, in Bethesda, Md. She was 74 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Music: Masnadieri, a Neglected Verdi, Revived
description: The revival here of Verdi's early, neglected operas goes on by fits and starts, but it does, fortunately, go on. On Wednesday night it was the turn of I Masnadieri, which was presented in concert form by the Opera Orchestra of New York in Carnegie Hall.

title: Bronx ScatterSite Project Welcomed by Its ExFoes
description: Three years ago, residents of the predominantly middleclass Kingsbridge section of the Bronx protested the construction of a lowincome housing project, but only smiles and applause greeted Mayor Beame at the building's dedication yesterday.

title: The Right Focus on the C.I.A.
description: Official documents just published by the State Department disclose that in 1948, President Harry Trumanthen facing dim reelection prospects himselfapproved a secret recommendation that the United States make full use of its political, economic and, if necessary, military power to prevent a Communist election victory in Italy.

title: Contract Awards
description: A contract for the design, engineering, procurement, construction and management services of a new petroleum refinery at Santa Cruz, Bolivia, and for the supervision of the expansion of an existing refinery at Cochabamba, Bolivia, has been awarded to Arthur G. McKee & Co., Cleveland. The company would not disclose the value of its part of the projects, which are valued at a total of $100million, the contracts for which were awarded by Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales Bolivianos, a public corporation of the Bolivian government.

title: Judge in Virginia Killed by Gunman In His Courtroom
PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: For most of this century the trend has been toward feeding infants more solid foods earlier. It was once common to feed only milk for the first year; it now common to supplement that milk with other foods such as cereal or strained fruit in the first month or two.

title: LEFKOWITZ FAULTS U.S. OFFSHORE PLAN
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13Louis J. Lefkowitz, the New York State Attorney General, took a critical view today of the Ford Administration's proposals for vastly accelerating oil and gas production on the Atlantic Outer Continental Shelf, while the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry gave the proposals enthusiastic support.

title: Brezhnev, Back in Public, Meets Wilson
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 13Leonid I. Brezhnev, smiling and looking fit, emerged today from seven weeks of seclusion to greet Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain when he arrived at the Kremlin on an official visit.

title: About Real Estate
description: The clock is ticking for the city's rent stabilization system. At some point, officials seem to agree, something will have to be done. But when? And what?

title: Nicholas Gesoalde, 90, Dies; Was Pharmacist 69 Years
description: Nicholas S. Gesoalde, who had had a career of 69 years in pharmacy, died Monday in Port Jefferson, L. I., where he lived. He was 90 years old.

title: Ginsberg Spared Prison For Perjury Conviction
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 13Martin Ginsberg, who was removed as a judge of the Nassau County Family Court upon his conviction for perjury last Dec. 27, was spared a prison term today when he received an unconditional discharge at his sentencing in County Court.

title: Montana Embroiled in Controversy in Inquiry on Workmen's Compensation
description: HELENA, Mont., Feb. 13A yearold investigation of the Montana Workmen's Compensation Division has jailed a State Senator, raised questions about the Governor's campaign financing, drawn accusations of political motivation and moved toward an inquiry by a grand jury with broader investigative powers.

title: F.C.C. Finds WBAI Show Indecent
President Won't Veto Food Stamp Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 President Ford announced today that he would allow a bill freezing the price of food stamps for the rest of this year to become law without his signature.

title: 3 Competing Rail Groups Proposed for Northeast
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The United States Railway Association Board has approved a preliminary plan to restructure the bankrupt Northeastern railroads into three competing, independent railroad systems, it has been learned.

title: La Scala, Battling Money Crisis, Holds On Day by Day
description: MILAN, Italy  The Government of Italy supports 13 opera houses, as well as symphonic groups and traditional theater. All of those performing  arts organizations are in trouble, and one of themthe Teatro La Fenice in Venicehas been forced to cancel its opera season.

title: Drug Issue Perils Aqueduct Opening
description: New York's thoroughbred trainers hinted yesterday there would not be enough starters for Aqueduct's Feb. 24 opening unless horses were permitted to race with certain painkillers.

title: PRICES UP SHARPLY ON AMEX AND OTC
ME, TOO PROVISION ASSAILED BY P.B.A.
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association filed an unfairlaborpractice charge yesterday that accused the city of attempting to impose a pattern contract settlement on the 23,000 P.B.A. members by including me, too provisions in agreements with other city unions.

title: WALLACE SEEKING NEW PRIMARY LAW
City Ends Snow Emergency as Traveling Conditions Approach Normal
description: The city's first snow emergency of the winter was officially ended at 5 P.M. yesterday, but snow  clearance operations had apparently brought traveling conditions close to normal hours earlier.

title: CHARLES LAWRENCE, CUSTOMS JUDGE, 96
description: Charles D. Lawrence, a senior judge of the United States Customs Court, died Wednesday at his home, 69 Fifth Avenue, at the age of 96.

title: C.A.F. Asks Revised Law To Spur Charter Flights
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The Civil Aeronautics Board, in what was called a basic shift in favor of expanding lowcost charter flights, said today that it was ready to develop a broad program for cutrate group travel but insisted that a change in the law was necessary first.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on New York Stock Exchange trading in yesterday's New York Times incorrectly reported that the price of the stock of the Armstrong Cork Company had declined and that the company had omitted its quarterly dividend. The figures given and the omission of the dividend were for the Armstrong Rubber Company. Armstrong Cork's stock rose  on Wednesday.

title: THE LEADING SCORES
Moran Loses Suit Against Giants
description: A $2million damage suit filed by a former New York Giant football player, Jim Moran, was denied yesterday by the New York State Supreme Court. The defendants named in the suit were the Giants, former Coach Allie Sherman, and Dr. Anthony Pisani, the former team physician.

title: On Broadway, Adela Holzer Is Now a Leading Light
description: So far this season, Broadway's most productive producer has been not David Merrick, Joseph Papp, Harold Prince or any of the other men who have dominated the New York theater. She is Adela Holzer, a selfpossessed Spanishborn businesswoman.

title: WOMEN ADVOCATE OPTION ON LAYOFFS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13A group of women economists proposed today that the Government provide tax incentives to business that are forced to cut back on employment so as to help them reduce the hours worked by all their employes rather than laying off some of them.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MAGNET Lovelace Watkins is a singer with a new show at the WaldorfAstoria. He flashes a smile and easy warmth, belts out Once in a Lifetime in a piercing in a Lifetime and instantly connects with the audience. He shakes hands around the rim of the stage, asking people to clap tempos and talks pleasantly about his career overseas and in Las Vegas, while modestly expressing hopes of catching on here, in his local debut.

title: INDUSTRY OUTPUT IN JANUARY FELL MOST SINCE 1937
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Industrial production showed an exceptionally huge decline of 3.6 per cent last month following a drop of 3.1 per cent in December, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The new figure on the output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities is further confirmation that the nation is in its deepest recession since World War II.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on New York Stock Exchange trading in yesterday's New York Times incorrectly reported that the price of the stock of the Annstrong Cork Company had declined and that the company had omitted its quarterly dividend. The figures given and the omission of the dividend were for the Armstrong Rubber Company. Armstrong Cork's stock rose  on Wednesday.

title: Recapturing the West That WasBlack Style
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Black History Week lasts for seven days in February, from the 9th to the 15th, but the story of the black man's travailpast and presentis a subject of everyday interest to the Anacostia Neighborhood Museum, one of the most unusual museums in the land.

title: Ford Exhorts Democrats To Aid His Foreign Policy
description: President Ford appealed to the Democraticcontrolled Congress in a speech here last night for a return to nonpartisanship in setting the nation's foreign policy.

title: AFRICAN NATIONS OPEN CONFERENCE
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 13  Foreign ministers from black and Arab African countries opened a meeting of the Council of Ministers of the Organization of African Unity here today without a mention of the organization's principal founder, deposed Emperor Haile Selassie.

title: Denmark Swears In A New Government Led by the Minority
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 13 (UPI)A new minority Government formed by the Social Denmocratic party with Anker Jorgensen as Premier, took office today.

title: Ford Won't Veto Bill
description: President Ford announced that he would allow a bill freezing the price of food stamps through 1975 to become law without his signature. Congress had passed it by large margins. Page 12.

title: Plan for Tax Cut Aims at Lower Incomes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 Well over half the $16.4billion in tax cuts for individuals that were approved last week by the House Ways and Means Committee would go to taxpayers with incomes of $10,000 or less. Only 10 per cent would go to those with incomes of $20.000 or more.

title: Market Place
description: Concern is increasing in Wall Street that as the major institutional investors concentrate on the stocks of a few major corporations, the smaller companies, lacking sponsorship among professional investors, will be unable to raise capital, and their stocks will continue to bear low priceearnings multiples.

title: Odor Empties Queens Homes
description: A block of about 20 homes in Astoria, Queens, was evacuated for more than two hours last night when burning electrical insulation, in a manhole, giving off an odor similar to that of natural gas, caused fears of a gas leak. Houses on Ditmars Boulevard between 26th and 27th Streets were evacuated from shortly after 6 o'clock to 8:30. P.M., police and Consolidated Edison officials said.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Martin Ginsberg, who was removed as a judge of the Nassau County Family Court upon his conviction for perjury last Dec. 27, was spared a prison term when he received an unconditional discharge at his sentencing in County Court.

title: Party Here for Bentsen, or Esposito?
description: Mayor Beame, Carmine G. De Sapio, Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut, Borough Presidents Sebastian Leone and Donald R. Manes, National Committeeman Basil A. Paterson, Senate Minority Leader Manfred Ohrenstein and various other Democrats turned out last night for a cocktail party in an East Side apartment.

title: Warrants Issued For an Executive Of a Neat Packer
description: PIERRE, S.D., Feb. 13 AP)South Dakota Attorney General William Janklow has issued warrants for the arrest of Frank R. West, president of American Beef Packers, Inc. and three other company officials.

title: ALIDA MILLIKEN, 95, AIDED SOCIAL UNITS
description: Alida Leese Milliken, who had been active in social and charitable work, died yesterday in her home, 131 East 69th Street. She was 95 years old.

title: A BLESSING OF WOMEN
description: Remember me is all I ask, And, if remembered be a task, Forget me.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Checking the dinner menu the other night at Chalet Suisse. 6 East 48th Street, I figured that we could order bratwurst with sauerkraut at $6.25 or fondue Neuchateloise at $6 with a glass of wine at $1.85, indulge in any one of several $1.50 desserts, have a cup of coffee at 60 cents, and get out heartily fed for about $12.50 per person after tax and tip. I mention this to begin with because I don't want to discourage anyone from visiting this extremely pleasant restaurant, but what we actually ended up with that first night was twice that amount, a flat 50 smackers for the two of us.

title: Oosterhuis's 66 Leads by Shot
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 13Peter Oosterhuis, a primequality British import in his first full year of American professional golf competition, and three unsung spear carriers of the tour achieved today what few others have been able to do lately. They led Johnny Miller by seven and six strokes, respectively.

title: Vast U.N. Complex Rises On Banks of Blue Danube
description: VIENNA  A cluster of huge concrete structures going up on the north bank of the Danube River as a new home for United Nations, agencies  and maybe more than that  has almost overnight become a sightseeing attraction in this old city.

title: RIVAL GROUPS CLASH IN ANGOLAN CAPITAL
description: LISBON, Feb. 13 (Reuters)Several people were killed or injured in the Angolan capital of Luanda in overnight shooting between the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola and a dissident faction, the Portuguese Government press agency ANI said today.

title: Chen Leads Manila Golf
description: MANILA, Feb. 13 (AP)Chen ChienChin of Taiwan posted a fourunderpar 68 for a onestroke lead today in the first round of the $40,000 Philippine open golf championship. Another Taiwan golfer, Hsieh MinNan, was second at 69, followed by four golfers, including Sandy Gsilbraith and Martin Bohen of the United States, tied for third place with 70.

title: U.S.SOVIET STUDY OF CANCER URGED
description: The head of the Soviet Union's main cancer research center said yesterday that cooperative studies by Russian and American scientists on the incidence of various cancers in the two countries might help mankind find the causes and means of preventing the leading cancer killers.

title: ACCRUING IS HALTED BY CHASE MORTGAGE
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, the nation's largest real estate investment trust, reported yesterday that it had ceased accuring interest income on 47 per cent of its $986million real estate and investment sportfolio.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off
description: Special to The New York Times

title: The Pop Life
description: Barry Stuart appears to be having trouble in his attempt to revive Bill Graham's Fillmore East on Second Avenue. Renamed the N.F.E. Theater and reopened handsomely last Dec. 7 with BachmanTurner Overdrive, the facility looked like a welcome addition to New York's rockconcert scene.

title: Connecticut to Begin Its NursingHome Inquiry Today
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 13The Connecticut General Assembly begins its investigation into the state's nursing homes tomorrow, a situation far different from that confronting New York investigators.

title: In Memoriam
description: BRANDTShirley. February 14, 1974. A real sweetheart. We miss her. The JOEL BRANDT FAMILY.

title: About New York
description: Congressman Morris Udall was in town this week, looking for money, calling Meade Esposito on the phone, meeting with Mario Cuomo, and in general behaving like any other old barefoot boy from Arizona who wants to be President. Mr. Udall, who comes into New York frequently now that he is running for President, also met with what he called the literati. This can be tricky business because the literati are highly fickle. Still, they love to be courted. Mr. Udall knew what he was doing.

title: Dagmar Godowsky, 78, Vamp Of the Silent Screen, Is Dead
Ford Met Connally Accidentally, Aide To President Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Robert T. Hartmann, President Ford's chief political adviser on the White House staff, said today that the President had not intended to meet alone with former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally when in Houston on Monday.

title: Market Ministers, in Dublin, Offer Aid in Cyprus Dispute
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 13  The Foreign Ministers of the European Economic Community met in Dublin today and decided to offer assistance in resolving the Cyprus dispute.

title: Nancy Lammerding, Ford Aide, Is Married to L. Nicholas Ruwe
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Nancy Lammerding, social secretary to Betty Ford, was married here today to L. Nicholas Ruwe, who resigned last week as assistant chief of protocol at the State Department. Both the President and Mrs. Ford, who was the bride's oniy attendant, were present at the small, noontime ceremony in the chapel of the residence of the Apostolic Delegate here.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: 4 Killed and 4 Wounded By Gunmen in Canada
description: BROSSARD, Quebec, Friday, Feb. 14 (UPI)Four persons were killed and four others were wounded in a shooting last night in a nightclub in this suburb of Montreal. the police said.

title: Ziegler Concedes Press Problems on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) Ronald L. Ziegler said today the Nixon Administration's public relations and press programs concerning Watergate may have been the worst in the nation's history.

title: TURKS OF CYPRUS PROCLAIM A STATE IN NORTHERN AREA
Queens Project to Be Upgraded
description: In an effort to reverse the deterioration of a set of 21 apartment buildings in a middleclass Flushing, Queens, neighborhood, representatives from the borough, the city's Housing and Development Add ministration, and a private development company have announced plans for a $10million rehabilitation project.

title: BIAS SEEN IN USE OF SHARED FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The United States Civil Rights Commission said today that there was evidence of widespread discrimination in the use of general revenuesharing funds, and asked Congress to appropriate $7.5million to hire more people to monitor the program.

title: Connors, Mayer Gain In U.S. Indoor Tennis
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 13 (AP)Jimmy Connors and Alex Mayer advanced to the semifinals of the United States indoor open tennis championships today with straightset victories.

title: Congress Gets Bill On Federal Grants To Public Television
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) President Ford said today that Congress should approve legislation guaranteeing $1 in Federal funds for public broadcasting for every $2.50 raised from private sources, with ceilings on the total amount.

title: Help for Detroit
description: A year before Pearl Harbor, Walter P. Reuther, then head of the General Motors division of the United Automobile Workers, put forward an imaginative plan for converting the nation's auto factories to production of planes, tanks and other arms.

title: College and School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: LEGISLATORS TO GO TO SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)  A bipartisan Congressional delegation will go to South Vietnam and Cambodia in the next few weeks at President Ford's behest. Ron Nessen, the White House press spokesman said today.

title: JERSEY EMPLOYES DENOUNCE BYRNE
Dolphins Black Out Lawyer Who Sued
description: MIAMI, Feb. 13 (UPI)Ellis Rubin, the attorney who led the fight that lifted local area television blackouts of sellout football games, accused the Miami Dolphins today of dealing him a cheap shot by refusing to renew his season tickets.

title: People in Sports
description: Pat Dobson, the New York Yankees ace righthanded pitcher called off his arbitration hearing scheduled for today, and signed yesterday for the 1975 season after meeting with Gabe Paul, the Yankee president. Dobson, the only Yankee to file for arbitration this year started poorly last season, losing 11 of his first 17 games. He rebounded to a 134 wonlost record the second half and tied Doc Medich for the club lead in victories with 19. He is believed to have got a raise of about $15,000 from $65,000 to $80,000.

title: Entreaties Mark CapitalBudget Session
description: The annual hearings on the city's capital budget, which covers construction projects, are often raucous affairs. But yesterday's hearings in Manhattan was notable for its meek, tone, as speaker after speaker sought to make sure that their projects were not cut.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Losers in the Conn. Game
description: STAMFORD, Conn.Experts have rediscovered the suburbs, and the natives tremble. We have been rediscovered and now we are being chastised. We are told we waste energy, that we are inefficient, and that our taxes are insufficient for our needs.

title: CAIRO DESCRIBES TALKS AS BUOYING
description: CAIRO, Feb. 13Egyptian officials declared themselves encouraged today by their talks, with Secretary of State Kissinger but emphatically reiterated that. Egypt would not give a pledge of nonbelligerency to Israel in exchange for an Israeli withdrawal in Sinai.

title: Golf Club in Princeton Rejects Black Applicant
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13Marvin Trotman, a black Princeton high school basketball coach land guidance counselor and a native of Princeton, has been refused membership in the private 260member Springdale Gold Club in Princeton Township.

title: Jets Give Top Post To Ward
description: Al Ward, whose arrival in the Dallas Cowboys front office in 1966 coincided with the start of the team's string of eight straight playoff appearances, was named yesterday as general manager of the Jets.

title: Leaders of British Miners Accept New Wage Offer
description: LONDON, Feb. 13 (Reuters)Leaders of Britain's 270,000 coal miners today accepted a new wage offer from the National Coal Board that is well above wage guidelines set by the Labor Government.

title: Court Refuses Plea To Block Army Plan For Freezing Birds
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) A Federal appeals court refused today to block the Army's plan to kill more than 10 million blackbirds at Army bases in Kentucky and Tennessee but expressed concern over the project's environmental implications.

title: California High Court Denies Sirhan's Bid for New Trial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 (UPI)The California Supreme Court denied today a request by Sirhan B. Sirhan, convicted assassin of Robert F. Kennedy, or a new trial.

title: CARTER LAWYERS CRITICIZE JUDGE
description: Defense lawyers in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case yesterday accused Judge Samuel A. Lamer of the New Jersey Superior Court of refusing to hear all vital evidence before he rejected an appeal for a new trial.

title: West Rejects Eastern Bid For Troop Freeze in Europe
description: VIENNA, Feb. 13 (Reuters)Th North Atlantic alliance and the Soviet bloc faced a new impasse in troopreduction negotiations today when the West rejected a Communist proposal for an immediate military manpower freeze in central Europe.
