title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1975

title: Approaching 100, Be Still Skis and Hikes
description: Herman (Jack Rabbit) Smith  Johannsen, the 99yearold outdoorsman who still skis daily to pick up mail at the post office in Piedmont, Quebec, captivated a luncheon crowd at Gallagher's in Manhattan yesterday. The wiry oldtimer, anticipating his 100th birthday in June, was here to receive the Dubonnet Skier of the Year award. The presentation was made by Lowell Thomas, the 82yearold news commentator, who also is still skiing.

title: Cavaliers Rally Tops Warriors
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 13 (AP) Fred Foster, Jim Chones and Jim Cleamons sparked a fourthquarter rally by the Cleveland Cavaliers that gave them a 9693 victory over the Golden State Warriors tonight in the National Basketball Association.

title: SPAIN FREES CROATS WHO HIJACKED PLANE
description: MADRID, Feb. 13Three Croats serving 12year sentences for hijacking a Swedish airliner were pardoned today by Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

title: Food Chain Results Reflect Accounting
Ford Seeks to Bar G.I. School Benefits To Future Veterans
Arbitration Round Won By Finley
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 (AP)  Charles O. Finley, owner of the Oakland A's, gained a favorable decision in his arbitration case against Ken Holtzman today, Finley's first case of 1975. Finley also came to contract terms with Vida Blue in a morning negotiating session, canceling their scheduled afternoon trip to the arbitration table.

title: TRADING IS QUIET ON BOND MARKETS
RIGHTS AMENDMENT REJECTED IN ARIZONA
description: PHOENIX Ariz., Feb. 13Arzona's state Senate defeated today the Equal Rights Amendment to the United States Constitution apparently assuring that the amendment would not be passed by the state Legislature this session.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1975

title: GEN. BEAUFRE, 73, LED SUEZ INVASION
New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners ordered New Jersey Bell Telephone and seven small independent companies yesterday to appear Feb. 28 to explain how and why they monitored telephone calls and provided large business subscribers with means to monitor employes conversations.

title: Recapturing the West That Was  Black Style
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Black History Week lasts for seven days in February, from the 9th to the 15th, but the story of the black man's travailpast and presentis a subject of everyday interest to the Anacostia Neighborhood Museum, one of the most unusual museums in the land.

title: Congress Told U.S. Plans To Sell 24 Jets to Spain
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (Reuters)The Air Force has notified Congress that the United States plans to sell 24 Phantom jets to Spain, it was disclosed today.

title: SHUTDOWN DELAYS NEWHAVEN RIDERS
description: Homebound commuters on the New Haven division of the Penn Central had to abandon trains again last night as tangled power lines forced a shutdown of the system at the height of the evening rush hour, stranding thousands of passengers on trains stalled between stations for the second time in two days.

title: Blue Haze
description: As people whose duty brings them into daily contact with crime and danger, the city's police officers might be expected to have a highly developed sense of realism. But it is apparent that, as union members, they live in a dream world when it comes to recognition of the abysmal state of New York City's finances.

title: 100 in Village Seek More Protection
description: About 100 Greenwich Village shopkeepers paraded through slushy streets to the Sixth Precinct police station at 233 West 10th Street yesterday to ask for more help to combat robberies.

title: Gov. Grasso Offers $1.4Billion Budget
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 13  Gov. Ella T. Grasso tonight presented the Connecticut General Assembly with a record $1.43billion budget request with little relief for the hardpressed cities and towns and a proposed 1cent increase in the sales tax.

title: FLOOR PRICE IN OIL ASKED FOR EUROPE
description: BRUSSELS. Feb. 13A proposal for a common minimum price for oil imports lower than what the United States is suggesting was presented today to a meeting of energy ministers of the nine European Common Market countries.

title: Advertising
description: Charles B. Jenkins, who is black, and Gilbert S. Wald, who is white, quietly opened a new advertising agency last November to specialize in marketing to the black and Spanishspeaking communities.

title: Bankers See Blacklist Harming Trade
description: LONDON, Feb. 13A senior partner in a leading investment banking house tilted back in his chair and said: As a good gentile working in a Jewish bank, I think the whole thing's a great pity.

title: SALE OF U.S. CARS OFF 5% IN 10 DAYS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 13American newcar sales declined 5.1 per cent in the Feb. 110 period from last year, but this was the best showing since the 1975 models were introduced last fall. Pricerebate programs obviously helped the industry's performance.

title: FORD OPTIMISTIC ON JOBLESS RATE
description: President Ford, sounding a note of toughminded optimism, said here yesterday that he did not think the unemployment rate would reach the magnitude of 9 to 10 per cent, as some economic analysts have been predicting.

title: Irish Down St. John's On 2 Foul Shots, 6867
description: Toby Knight, the powerfully built Notre Dame sophomore from Port Jefferson, L.I., stole the spotlight that was supposed to belong to Adrian Dantley last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Humain, Trop Humain, a Film of Stunning Images
CITY PLAN VOTED BY DELURY UNION
description: The Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association has approved the agreement that its president, John J. DeLury, worked out with Mayor Beame last month to avert the layoffs of 235 sanitationmen, Mr. DeLury said yesterday.

title: 3 Utilities Will Not Appeal S.E.C.'s Merger Rejection
description: The Boston Edison Company, Eastern Utilities Associates and the New England Electric System said yesterday that it would be fruitless to appeal the Securities and Exchange Commission's rejection last week of the merger, plan. The three utilities had submitted the proposal to regulatory authorities in 1968, asking that they be allowed to merge into a new holding company to be known as the Eastern Electric Energy System.

title: Kissinger Flies to Israel To Relay Views of Sadat
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 13Secretary of State Kissinger presented Egypt's detailed views on a new Sinai agreement to Israeli leaders tonight, in the hope that this would spur Israel to take a more flexible approach when he returned to the Middle East in a few weeks.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Marvin Trotman, basketball coach and guidance counselor at Princeton (N.J.) High School, who is black, has been refused membership in the Springdale Golf Club. Mr. Trotman is believed to be the first black to have applied formally for membership in the 50yearold club. Harry Volweider, the club president, said that race was not an issue when the 12member board of governors ruled against Mr. Trotman's membership application. We didn't turn him down, Mr. Volweider said. We didn't accept him.

title: SINGER'S DIVIDEND IS CUT 40C TO 10C
description: The Singer Company, which two weeks ago reported a $10.4million loss from continuing operations in the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, yesterday announced that it had cut its regular quarterly dividend from 50 cents a share on the common to 10 cents a share.

title: PARK ACTS TO COOL SEOUL OPPOSITION
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 13 President Park Chung Hee suggested today that he would seek reconciliation with his opponents in the political parties, the Christian churches and the universities.

title: 35.16 MillionShare Volume Sets a Record for Exchange
description: Another strong surge of buying swept into the stock market yesterday sending prices sharply higher in the heaviest trading day in the New York Stock Exchange's history.

title: Thai PremierDesignate Pledges Democratic Rule
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 13 (AP)A 69yearold antimilitarist was elected by Parliament today as the next Premier and said he would try to bring permanent democratic rule to Thailand.

title: Aborting the Law
description: A trial jury in a Boston homicide case now faces the unenviableand perhaps impossibletask of deciding just when human life begins in order to determine whether a doctor committed the homicide of which he is accused.

title: Turkish Boomerang?
description: President Ford has argued strongly for reconsideration by Congress of its cutoff of arms deliveries to Turkey over the Cyprus dispute.

title: MADRID BATTLES GROWING UNREST
description: MADRID, Feb. 13The Spanish Government, on the first anniversary of its reform program, finds itself much busier repressing subversive challenges than promoting democratic reform.

title: Entreaties Mark CapitalBudget Session
description: The annual hearings on the city's capital budget, which covers construction projects, are often raucous affairs. But yesterday's hearings in Manhattan was notable for its meek tone, as speaker after speaker sought to make sure that their projects were not cut.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 5%
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Seafarers Gave Tiernan $1,000 During Rhode Island Campaign
FORD OPTIMISTIC ON JOBLESS RATE
description: President Ford, sounding a note of toughminded optimism, said here yesterday that he did not think the unemployment rate would reach the magnitude of 9 to 10 per cent, as some economic analysts have been predicting.

title: Music: Kubelik Leads Philharmonic
description: Karl Bhm is not well, and under doctor's orders to cut back his conducting schedule, so Rafael Kubelik turned up in his stead last night to lead the New York Philharmonic, beginning a twoweek engagement. Mr. Kubelik is a substantial artist, seldom terribly exciting but seldom a great disappointment, either.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Detective Chief Is Guilty Of Protecting Gambling
description: MORRISTOWN, Feb. 13Capt. Joseph M. Esposito, the suspended Chief of Detectives of Paterson, today was found guilty of misconduct and conspiracy for protecting the illegal lottery operation of a bookmaker.

title: PIZZA PARLOR OWNER HELD IN MURDER PLOT
description: A Brooklyn pizza  parlor owner has been accused of taking an order for a $5,000 murder contract and farming it out to a gangland gunman.

title: Valentine's Day: A Helping Hand
description: Today is St. Valentine's Day, the most romantic holiday of the year. And because of a reedslim blonde Manhattan woman named Natalie Willner, three couples will celebrate in the following manner:

title: Suicide of Big Executive: Stress of Corporate Life
description: The day after Eli M. Black died, a suicide at the age of 53, a notice appeared in the papers. It announced that a West German chemical concern had bought a major subsidiary from the United Brands Company, the $2billion conglomerate of Chiquita bananas and John Morrell meat products that Mr. Black had created in the late nineteensixties.

title: G.O.P. Asks Inquiry on Carey's Funds
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13The state Republican chairman, Richard M. Rosenbaum, called today for a grandjury investigation of a series of campaign contribution shifts in which $1,250 from Governor Carey's campaign eventually reached an upstate Conservative party worker who had embroiled former Gov. Malcolm Wilson in a campaign controversy.

title: 6 Children in a Jersey Family Are Killed in House Fire
description: RINGWOOD, N.J., Feb. 13Six brothers and sisters died late last night when a fire engulfed their parents frame house here.

title: Bridge:
Congress Support Of Israel Is Strong, But Not Automatic
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Despite the soaring prices growing out of the demonstration of Arab oil power, the changing Arab image and the threat of war hanging over the Middle East, there is still a strong Congressional majority supporting Israel. That support is no longer automatic, however.

title: Paris Bars Intercession In Jewish Bank Dispute
description: PARIS, Feb. 13  Premier Jacques Chirac said today that the French Government would not intervene to prevent proIsraeli banks from being barred by Arab banks against participation in bond issues.

title: C.C.N.Y. Faculty Senate Censures 5 History Professors Over Refusal to Assist in Inquiry
description: The faculty senate of City College voted 36 to 25 yesterday to censure five members of the history department for allegedly refusing to cooperate with the senate's investigation of the bitter personal, political and academic conflict in the department.

title: Sister of Navy's 5 Sullivans.
description: WATERLOO, Iowa, Feb. 13 (UPI)  Genevieve Sullivan Davidson, the sister of the five Sullivan brothers, killed in World War II when their ship was sunk by the Japanese, died of cancer in a hospital here.

title: Geographic Programs On P.B.S. With Gulf Aid
description: The National Geographic documentaries, dropped by the commercial networks, are moving to the Publlic Broadcasting Service. The Gulf Oil Corporation has donated $3,720,000 for the next three years to National Geographic Television Films and WQED, the Pittsburgh P.B.S. affiliate, to produce the programs. Gulf, whose headquarters is in Pittsbargh, has funded local shows for WQED, but this is its first donation for Nationwide Public Broadcasting.

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball
description: SCORING LEADERS

title: 3 Ulster Catholics Injured by Bombs In Valentine Cards
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 13Two Valentine's Day cards, sealed with explosives in envelopes marked S.W.A.L.K., exploded today injuring three persons, all Roman Catholic.

title: 6 Children in Family Killed In Fire in Ringwood Home
description: RINGWOOD, Feb. 13Six brothers and sisters died late last night when a fire engulfed their parents frame house here.

title: Vast U.N. Complex Rises On Banks of Blue Danube
description: VIENNA  A cluster of huge concrete structures going up on the north bank of the Danube River as a new home for United Nations agencies  and maybe more than that  has almost overnight become a sightseeing attraction in this old city.

title: Brooklyn Congressman Gets Lift by Kissinger
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: Less than a quarter of a century ago, a tidal marsh was regardedexcept by a few enlightened naturalists or biologistsas little more than a haven for water birds and muskrats.

title: TRADE CENTER HIT BY 6FLOOR FIRE
description: A threealarm fire broke out in the 11thfloor offices of the B. F. Goodrich Company in the north tower of the World Trade Center just before midnight last night, and spread through an innerservice core to the ninth and 14th floors.

title: Money Supply Decreases In Spite of Fed's Efforts
description: The nation's money supply decreased at an annual rate of 0.6 per cent during the latest three months, despite Federal Reserve efforts to make it grow faster.

title: People and Business
description: The Pritzker family of Chicago yesterday completed its takeover of the Cerro Corporation. Under a previously announced plan for transfer of executive authority, Jay A. Pritzker, 53, who had been vice chairman, was elected chairman, while his brother Robert A. Pritzker, 48, who was chairman of the executive committee, was chosen president.

title: Congress Support Of Israel Is Strong, But Not Automatic
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Despite the soaring prices growing out of the demonstration of Arab oil power, the changing Arab image and the threat of war hanging over the Middle East, there is still a strong Congressional majority supporting Israel. That support is no longer automatic, however.

title: Ford Exhorts Democrats To Aid His Foreign Policy
description: President Ford appealed to the Democraticcontrolled Congress in a speech here last night for a return to nonpartisanship in setting the nation's foreign policy.

title: 18 Seconds for Senate; 16 Minutes for House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13, (Reuters)The Sanete, criticized by President Ford for its slow pace of action, met and adjourned today in 18 seconds.

title: Bridge
description: One of the marks of a good dummyplayer is the ability to form a contingency plan. He foresees the possibility of a bad break, and prepares for a change of course.

title: NursingHome Fund Ban Aims At 69 in New York and Jersey
Notes on People
description: The 90th birthday of Bess Wallace Truman yesterday in Independence, Mo., brought a wicker basket of spring flowers from President and Mrs. Ford, 90 sweetheart roses from Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago and red roses from the city of Independence and from the artillery company captained by Harry Truman in World War I. The flood of greetings on the cityproclaimed Bess Wallace Truman Day included presents, cakes, a telephone call from her daughter, Marget Truman Daniel of Washington, and resolutions and best wishes from the United States Senate the Missouri Legislature.

title: COAST INQUIRY OPENS ON HUGHES BURGLARY
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13Under unusual security, a county grand jury has opened an investigation into a 1974 burglary of Howard R. Hughes operation headquarters here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Emission Control: Henry Ford's Errors

title: Flu Brings Quarantine At Old Soldiers Home
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13 (AP)The state said today it had quarantined the Home for Disabled Soldiers at Menlo Park because of an outbreak of flu.

title: Funds for Housing Urged Over Funds for Highways
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)  Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that the Government could created a lot more jobs by releasing funds for housing than funds for highways.

title: Texas in Warm Appeal To Get New Business
description: On Feb. 3 the Texas Industrial Commission, Austin, began running commercials here on WNBCTV (Channel 4) during the evening news and the Today and Tonight shows intended to lure local businesses to the alledgely warmer climes enjoyed in the Lone Star State.

title: Bangladesh Gets U.S. Loan To Build a Fertilizer Plant
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb. 13 (Reuters)The United States is lending Bangladesh $30million to help build a fertilizer plant, with an annual capacity of 500,000 metric tons, according to an agreement signed here.

title: World Use of DDT Feared on Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 Worldwide use of DDT is probably as high today as it was more than a decade ago when United States production was at its peak and may be higher, a scientist said here today.

title: Target of Nadjari Investigation Retires as Transit Police Chief
description: Robert H. Rapp, the 58yearold chief of the Transit Authority police, under investigation by a special grand jury for alleged corrupt activities, retired Tuesday, a spokesman for the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: Seton Hall Thwarts Rally and Triumphs
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 13 (AP)  Seton Hall survived a secondhalf rally by Mount St. Mary's of Emmitsburg, Md., tonight for an 8583 victory.

title: Sales Are Down at Apparel Concern
U.S. and Soviet Units Confident On a Joint Space Mission in July
Reserve Report
description: In Billions DAILY AVERAGES

title: ECUADOR EXPECTED TO FREE U.S. SHIPS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13A State Department official said today that he expected the release soon of seven United States tuna ships and their crews seized by Ecuador in the last two weeks within her disputed 200mile offshore fishing limit.

title: Ford Won't Veto Bill
description: President Ford announced that he would allow a bill freezing the price of food stamps through 1975, to become law without his signature. Congress had passed it by large margins. Page 12.

title: Flyers Defeat Hawks
VOLUNTEER FORCE CALLED A SUCCESS
JACKSON SUPPORTS OIL EMBARGO PLAN
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 13Senator Henry M. Jackson, an announced Presidential contender, expressed today basic agreement with the Ford Administration on standby authority to deal with another oil embargo and said he would move promptly to send a bill to the Senate floor.

title: Expulsion of 2 Americans Explained by Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 13 (UPI)  Yugoslavia expelled two American opera singers today for distributing AntiYugoslav leaflets, the press agency Tanjug reported.

title: Forgotten Candidates
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The Presidential election campaign of 1976 has already startedover a year before the first primary in New Hampshire, 18 months before the nominating conventions, and almost 21 months before the final voting.

title: Ford Will Name a Woman To Be Secretary of H.U.D.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The White House announced today that President Ford would nominate a woman, Carla Anderson Hills, to be Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and the nomination immediately ran into opposition.

title: Greeks Assail Turkish Move in Cyprus
description: ATHENS, Feb. 13Greece tonight denounced the proclamation of an independent Turkish zone on Cyprus as an arbitrary and illegal act that endangers the peace in this delicate region.

title: Beame Agrees to Be Victim Of Inner Circle's Lampoon
description: Mayor Beame yesterday accepted an invitation to be the guest of honor at the annual lampoon dinner and show of the Inner Circle to be held at the New York Hilton on the evening of March 1.

title: Haughton Sets a Fast Pace at Florida Barns
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13This is Billy Haughton's favorite time of the year.

title: Madagascar Units Attack Rebel Camp; Death Toll Put at 21
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, Feb. 13 (Reuters)Twentyone people were killed today when loyal forces overran a camp held by rebel paramilitary police accused of having assassinated Madasgascar's head of Sate Tuesday.

title: CARTER LAWYERS CRITICIZE JUDGE
description: Defense lawyers in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case yesterday accused Judge Samuel A. Lamer of the New Jersey Superior Court of refusing to hear all vital evidence before he rejected an appeal for a new trial.

title: FUTURES IN GOLD SHOW ADVANCES
description: Sharply higher gold prices quoted in London yesterday influenced an $8 rise in gold futures on the Commodity Exchange here. The March delivery closed at $184.50, up from $176.50.

title: ARELE DIAMOND
description: Arele Diamond, who had been cantor of the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn since 1957, died yesterday in Brookdale Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 53 years old and lived at 167 Hastings Street, Brooklyn.

title: Leroy Watson, Normandy General, Dies
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 13 (AP)Maj. Gen. Leroy H. Watson, U.S.A. retired, who won the respect of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower even though demoted by him, died Wednesday his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: SOUTH JERSEY GAS ADDS TO SUPPLIES
description: NEWARK, FEb. 14 (UPI)The South Jersey Gas Company has obtained supplemental supplies of gas from the Transcontinental Pipeline Company and other suppliers, the Public Utilities Commission said today.

title: U.S. AND MARIANAS TO SIGN PACT TODAY
description: GUAM, Feb. 14 (Reuters)Representatives of the United States and the Marianas Islands will sign an agreement on Saipan tomorrow to establish a commonwealth of the northern Marianas Islands under the United States.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Jackson Predicts Congress Will Block Oil Import Tax
description: PORTLAND, Oregon, Feb. 14 (Reuters)Congress will vote to block President Ford's oil import tariff of $3 per barrel even if it means overriding a Presidential veto, Senator Henry M. Jackson said tonight.

title: BISHOPS IN BRAZIL REPLY ON PRISONERS
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 14The Roman Catholic church in Brazil announced today that it would continue its efforts to safeguard human rights and specifically to clarify the fate of missing political prisoners.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: (In Pounds sterling per Metric ton)

title: 60 Indians Ejected From Courthouse In Novitiate Case
Penn Five Sets Back Dartmouth
description: HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 14 (AP)  The University of Pennsylvania's front line of Ron Haigler, Bob Bigelow and Henry Johnson combined for 57 points tonight as the Quakers scored an 80.70 Ivy League basketball victory over Dartmouth.

title: Maureen Amy Sheridan Married
description: Maureen Amy Sheridan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Sheridan of Santiago, Chile, was married here yesterday afternoon to Willard Stewart LeCount, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter K. LeCount of Berwyn, Pa. State Supreme Court Justice Arnold Guy Fraiman performed the ceremony at the Summit Hotel.

title: FORTUNAT BARONAT
description: Fortunat Baronat, who was for 33 years editor of Universal Pictures's overseas newsreel operations and director of the company's foreign publicity department, died Tuesday in Forest Hills, Queens. His age was 72. He joined the company in 1933 and retired in 1969.

title: EgyptIsrael Gap Still Big After Kissinger Probing
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 14  A major gap still separates Israel and Egypt on the terms of a new interim agreement after Secretary of State Kissinger's preliminary round of talks.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES DOWN IN JANUARY, 2D MONTH IN A ROW
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The nation's oncesevere inflation continued to abate in January in parallel with the steep decline in production and employment, new Labor Department figures indicated today.

title: STEPHEN STRONG, 68, TRIAL LAWYER, DIES
description: Stephen Van Rensselaer Strong, a trial lawyer who had represented the Pennsylvania Railroad, died Wednesday at his home in Piscataway, N.J. He was 68 years old and also lived at 1150 Fifth Avenue.

title: Critic of Air Regulation Blames C. A. B. for High Cost of Fares
description: BOSTON, Feb. 14Air fares in the United States are 40 to 100 per cent higher than necessary because of the industry's regulation by the Civil Aeronautics Board, according to testimony presented today by Dr. William A. Jordon, a leading critic of air regulation.

title: A GlassFiber Telephone Line
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14Scientists at Bell Laboratories predict that glass fibers will be useful some day in transmitting light beams carrying vast amounts of telephone messages, business data and computer information. This week Bell Labs received a patent for a method of using a powerful, invisible laser beam to melt a glass rod so that it can be drawn into a hairthin fiber about a mile long.

title: Owner of Daily in India Ties Ouster of Editor to Politics
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 14K. K. Birla, the industrialist who owns The Hindustan Times, a prominent English language newspaper in New Delhi, has admitted that he was under political pressure last fall when he gave his editor, B. G. Verghese, six months notice of dismissal.

title: Miss Larrieu Breaks Mark In 1,500Meter Run at 4:10.4
description: TORONTO, Feb. 14Canadians got an exciting preview of next year's Olympics with worldrecord performances by Francie Larrieu and Annelie Ehrhardt and a victorious 3  minute  58second mile by John Walker during the Maple Leaf indoor games tonight.

title: LOWCOST FLIGHTS ASKED AT HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14Travel entrepreneurs and student representatives, criticizing restrictive charter flight policies of the Civil Aeronautics Board, appealed today for Congressional action to expand cutrate group travel.

title: Appeal of an Order Dooming Blackbirds Rejected by Burger
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) Chief Justice Warren E. Burger rejected without comment today a request by the Society for Animal Rights that he grant a temporary reprieve to millions of blackbirds scheduled to be destroyed by the Army.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE Second Division

title: 4 ExNixon Aides Lose Bid To Void CoverUp Verdict
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Federal District Judge John J. Sirica refused today to set aside or to change in any way the guilty verdicts returned in the Watergate coverup case against four former Nixon Administration officials.

title: Children First
description: The city has no shortage of organizations and support groups involved in the issues and problems of public education. In the main, however, these associations and forces are either limited in their activism by prohibitions on political action in the tax laws, or are themselves deeply committed to policies dictated by their special or professional interests.

title: New Form of Math Said to Resolve Old Paradoxes of Numbering System
description: A form of mathematics that seemingly resolves old paradoxes, increases the available numbers and is believed to have broad implications for economics, physics, biology and concepts of time has generated unusual excitement in the mathematical community.

title: Jerusalem Blasts Kill Two Believed to Be Guerrillas
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 14 (UPI)Two explosions rocked an empty lot today less than a mile from the King David Hotel, where Secretary of State Kissinger stayed during his latest Middle East peace mission, the police said.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Tennessee Williams will receive the gold medal for literature awarded annually by the National Arts Club. The presentation will be made Thursday at a dinner in the club's headquarters, 15 Gramercy Park.

title: Bigger Role for Bonn in the World: Leadership in Handling Oil Crisis
description: BONN, Feb. 14West Germany, long accustomed to a comfortable international role as economic giant but a political dwarf, is increasingly being asked to assume a position of greater leadership in a time of world economic crisis. There has been some embarrassment here about flexing German muscle, but, it has become possible since Willy Brandt came to terms with the Communist countries to the east during his chancellorship.

title: Notes on People
description: Since stepping down as Federal Energy Administrator in December, John C. Sawhill has been an intermittent consultant to his successor, Frank G. Zarb, drawing the maximum Federal fee of $133 a day. On one of those paid days, Jan. 29, Mr. Sawhill testified before a Congressional committee in opposition to President Ford's energy program. He gave similar testimony before two other committees on Feb. 7 and 12.

title: 40th Colonial Ball Held
description: Six young women descended from revolutionaries against the British were presented last evening, at the 40th annual Colonial Ball of the Sons of the American Revolution, at the Plaza. The debutantes are the Misses Victoria Lee Kane, Lucy Alexandre Elizabeth Myers, Lindsey Mary Stansfield, Alice Jean Weston, Annemarie WhittakerDavis and Margaret Carole Russell. Proceeds of the event aid the organization's patriotic education and scholarship funds.

title: Kroger Earnings Gain
KEITH AND ROONEY ENLIVEN BLUEGRASS
description: Any bluegrass group that plays such pieces as Duke Ellington's Caravan, the jazz standard Jordu and the Rolling Stones No Expectations is obviously not awed by the more starchy traditions of bluegrass practice.

title: Cambodians Pushing to Clear Mekong
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 14  Western military sources reported today that Phnom Penh Government troops were making determined efforts to open the blockaded Mekong River, this capital's main supply link to the outside world. As yet there are no reports of progress.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A 43yearold Freehold obstetrician was indicted yesterday on charges of fraudulently collecting $2,742 from the state's Medicaid program. The obstetrician, Dr. Murray Horowitz, was charged with submitting claims for payment for child delivieries that the state contended had never been performed. A Monmouth County grand jury indicted him, charging lb specific violations in which he allegedly submitted the names of the mothers and gave details of the deliveries. The state charged that the alleged fraud occurred during 1970 and 1971.

title: Article 1  No Title
British Hope for Controlling Inflation Dims
description: LONDON, Feb. 14The prospects for controlling inflation in Britain have received a severe setback at a critical moment for the national economy.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Rose to 202.8 in the Week
Is France Warming To NATO?
description: PARISLast week's quiet visit by NATO Secretary General Luns to French President Giscard d'Estaing could signal the start of a closer relationship between this country and the Western alliance.

title: EgyptIsrael Gap Still Big After Kissinger Probing
Stress Is Placed on Inspections Of Connecticut Nursing Homes
MAKARIOS PLEDGES TO RESIST DIVISION
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 14President Malcarios today denounced the Turkish Cypriotes' proclamation of a separate state in northern Cyprus and said Greek Cypriotes were prepared to resist and if necessary to sacrifice themselves to prerent partition.

title: Forego to Carry 131 Pounds in Widener
description: MIAMI, Feb. 14No horse has ever won Hialeah's historic Widener Handicap carrying more than 130 pounds. But it is an oddson proposition that history will be made tomorrow when Forego carries 131 pounds in the mileandaquarter, $100,000 added feature.

title: Niederhoffer Sees No Decline in Role As the Caesar of Squash Racquets
description: Of the more than 300 entrants in the 64th United States squash racquets singles championships here, one player may be bigger than the tournament itself.

title: Yields Decline on Bills At Treasury's Auction
Contract Award
description: The Southern California Edison Company said it had signed a letter of intent with the Babcock & Wilcox Company to supply and erect four steam generators costing more than $200million for the proposed 3,000megawatt coalfired Kaiparowits Power project in Southern Utah.

title: Appeals Court Wants Panel to Study Issues of Ownership of Nixon Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The United States Court of Appeals here provided today that a panel of three Federal judges should take up legal issues surrounding the ownership of former President Richard M. Nixon's tapes and documents without being bound by the precedentmaking decision by a Federal district judge that almost all the materials belonged to the Government.

title: Ninth Bombing in Viareggio
description: VIAREGGIO, Italy, Feb. 14 (Reuters)  A bomb damaged railway lines just outside the Viareggio station during the night but no one was hurt, the police said today. It was the ninth explosion here in eight days, and the police attribute the blasts to neoFascist extremists.

title: P. G. Wodehouse Is Dead on L.I. at 93; Creator of Jeeves and Bertie Wooster
P.R. Forever
description: After the monstrous revelations in the Watergate tapes and trials that established involvement of the Nixon inner, circle in an incredible web of crime and duplicity. Ronald Ziegler remains a prisoner of the American mythgood public relations conquer all.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Iowa Power and Light Company said yesterday it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a planned public offering of 600,000 shares of common stock. The offering, to be comanaged by underwriters headed by Halsey Stuart & Co. land Piper Jaffray & Hopwood, Inc., is expected to be made March 20.

title: N.F.L. Sued on Use Of Broncos Symbol
description: DENVER, Feb. 14 (UPI)Gerald and Tom Whatley say they love the Denver Broncos so much they want to make Tshirts with the Bronco symbol on them. And the two brothers have gone to court to get permission to do so.

title: Dow Is Up 7.28 to 734.20; Volume Off to 23 Million
description: The stock market, buoyed by signs that inflation and interest rates were continuing to ease, moved higher yesterday in slower but still heavy trading.

title: Mickey Mouse Music Barred From Sex Film
description: Federal District Judge Kevin Thomas Duffy in Manhattan issued a preliminary injunction yesterday against the use of the Mickey Mouse Club song in the soundtrack of a movie depicting an orgy.

title: The Money Dilemma
description: Is the nation's central bank, the Federal Reserve System, doing enough to check the recession and rising unemployment? And, if it were to do more than it already is doing, would it rekindle inflationwhose flames now seem to be dying down?

title: VETERINARY SCHOOL DELAYED IN JERSEY
Hoboken Ship Repair Yard Is Booming Along
description: HOBOKENA tanker that lost its rudder in an accident in a Canadian port is the newest tenant of a Bethlehem ship repair yard here, one of the few industrial facilities in the metropolitan area that have increased their employment rolls in recent months.

title: Add 9 Pounds of the Green Thing, With Candies
Harris, in Quest of Presidency, Arrives Here Carrying Own Bag
LYMAN J. BALLARD
description: Lyman J. Ballard, a former naval architect and professor at the Webb School of Naval Architecture and later a science teacher at the Collegiate School, died here Thursday. He was 79 years old and lived at 404 Riverside Drive.

title: Basketball Suit Gains in Court
description: A Federal Judge denied yesterday a motion by the National and American Baskeball Associaions o dismiss a players charge that they consipered to restrain competition for player services. Judge Robert Carter of the Southern District of New York, in a 71page ruling in which he expressed sympathy for the player's position, also denied bid by the two leagues to dissolve a preliminary injunction issued in May, 1970, against their merger. The Sherman Act complaint was brought by Oscar Robertson and 13 other wellknown players in the spring of 1970 following reports of the pending N.B.A.A.B.A. merger.

title: Judge Rules. That Tips Aren't Taxable Income
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov., Feb. 14 (UPI)A Federal judge ruled today that tips were gifts, not taxable income.

title: A.M.A. Head Urges a Pool For Malpractice Insurance
Ricci Fills In For Bumbry
description: Ruggiero Ricci, the violinist, will give a recital at the Hunter College Assembly Hall tomorrow at 2:15 P.M. He will substitute for Grace Melzia Bumbry, the soprano, who was forced by illness to cancel her appearance.

title: TRENTON WILL GET NEIGHBORHOOD AID
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14This financially troubled state capital will become the first recipient of the benefits of a twoyear, statewide $4million Neighborhood Preservation Program designed to halt the kind of deterioration that New Jersey's urban centers are suffering.

title: Victor Tretyakov Projects Tension in Violin Recital
description: Victor Tretyakov, the Russian violinist who won the 1966 Tchaikovsky Competition, gave his first New York recital in six years Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, and reestablished his credentials with ease.

title: Art: A Survey of Surrealism
description: We are in the midst of a season of surrealism. Fifty years ago last fall, Andr Breton published his First Surrealist Manifesto in Paris. Galleries and museums in New York, where surrealism came to rest, so to speak, in the early years of World War II, have eagerly responded to this anniversary occasion with a succession of ambitious exhibitions.

title: Price of Gold Rises By $9 in Europe; Dollar Shows a Dip
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 14 (UPI)The price of gold rose $9 an ounce on European exchange markets today, while the dollar dropped slightly.

title: People and Business
description: The Bowmar Instrument Corporation, the early entrant in the handheld calculator market that filed last Tuesday for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, came up with a new president and chief executive officer yesterday. He is William M. Crilly, 50, who until Thursday of this week had been executive vice president  international services division of Pan American World Airways.

title: OilNation Investing Soars
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14Shortterm investments by oilexporting countries in the United States soared to $10.2billion in 1974 but the investment pace slackened in the fourth quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Jayne Casey Wed to Robert A. Gillespie
description: Jayne Lynn Karsten Casey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth S. Karsten of Westport, Conn., was married there last evening to Robert A. Gillespie, a chemical engineer with the Stauffer Chemical company of Westport. The Rev. David Powers performed the Congregational ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Antiques: National Show
description: The slush was shoedeep outside Madison Square Garden on Thursday evening when antiques dealers, jostled by a corps of aspiring Golden Gloves boxers, entered, headed for the elevators and, on arrival at the rotunda level, unloaded their cargoes of curios.

title: 1,000 Inmates Escape in Eritrea With Guerrillas Help
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 14About 1,000 political prisoners reportedly escaped from two jails in the northern province of Eritrea last night with the help of secessionist guerrillas.

title: Beame Bars Early Retiring Of Police as a Job Saver
description: Mayor Beame yesterday rejected a plan to encourage police retirements that had been proposed as a means of saving the city money and thus eliminating the need to dismiss more than 500 rookies and recruits.

title: Standards Are Suggested For the ChildProof Match
description: WASHINGTONSuppose 5yearold child, left alone for a while in a living room, drops a flaming match on his clothes? The result, in all likelihood, will be a tragic burn. But if the match just goes out after a few seconds, a tragedy may well be averted.

title: City Hopes to Ride Out Cruise Slump
description: When the Italian Line's majestic though ruststreaked Michelangelo arrived here from the Mediterranean yesterday. there were only 200 passengers aboarda commentary on to day's diminished transAtlantic business.

title: Bergman Quits Zionist Post
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 14  Mr. Bergman has offered his resignation from the leadership of the world religious Zionist movement this week, and it was promptly accepted.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: LIQUIDATION AGENT APPOINTED FOR FIRM
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that Federal Judge Charles H. Tenney of Manhattan Federal Court had appointed Cameron F. MacRae 3d, a New York lawyer, to act as trustee for the liquidation of the Executive Securities Corporation, 25 Broadway, a brokerdealer headed by Richard O. Bertoli, president.

title: People in Sports
description: Japanese players have made tremendous improvement since 1 first came to Japan in 1951, and I think that in five years the time will be ripe for a real World Series, Joe DiMaggio said last night after completing a oneweek batting  coach assignment with the Lotte Orions in their spring training site at Kagoshima on Thursday.

title: Police Suspects Accused Of Coercing a Witness
description: NEWARK, Feb. 11 (UPI)Two Hoboken policemen under indictment for loansharking devised a scheme to frighten the key prosecution witness into remaining silent, an agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified in Federal District Court here today.

title: F.A.A. OFFICIAL SEES PILOT COMPLACENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) A Federal Aviation Administration inspector said today at an airline crash that it is possible jet crews have grown complacent because of technology.

title: Hirkala Backed in Handling Of NursingHome Matter
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14 (AP)State Senator Joseph Hirkala, Democrat of Passaic County, announced today that he had been cleared of any improper conduct in the handling of a resolution on a nursinghome investigation.

title: Markets Idle Monday
description: Securities and commodities exchanges, as well as most banks and state and Federal offices, will be closed Monday in observance of Washington's birthday.

title: Hydroculture in Chapter XI
description: A spokesman for Hydroculture, Inc., Glendale, Ariz., announced yesterday that it had filed for Chapter XI bankruptcy proceedings. He said the move was a result of a cashflow problem and some large contracts that fell through last year.

title: 4 ExNixon Aides Lose Bid To Void CoverUp Verdict
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Federal District Judge John J. Sirica refused today to set aside or to change in any way the guilty verdicts returned in the Watergate coverup case against four former Nixon Administration officials.

title: Italy Frees Man in Art Theft, Accuses Another of Slander
description: URBINO, Italy, Feb, 14 (UPI) The police today released, Antonino Arcidiacono, who had been arrested in the Feb. 6 theft of three celebrated Renaissance paintings, and charged another man with slandering him.

title: TWO VIEWS GIVEN OF HUDSON SCHOOL
description: HUDSON, N. V., Feb. 14a Two analysts from the State Legislature's fiscal committees heard conflicting testimony today about the Hudson State Training School for Girls, which was described at a legislative hearing yesterday as a deplorable place that subjected its residents to shabby, neglectful and often abusive treatment.

title: TESTIMONY GIVEN ON AID TO BERGMAN
Queens Museum Director Calls Control Too Narrow
description: A charge that the Queens Museum is run by a closed corporation, representing a narrow spectrum of the community was aired yesterday by Kenneth Kahn, the museum's director, in the presence of two dissident representatives of the museum's board, Carola Micbael and Helen Schiavo.

title: Nets Beaten, 176166, in 4 Overtimes
Zumwalt Suggests Israel Be Made a U.S. Dominion
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Feb. 14 (AP)Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., retired, a former Chief of Naval Operations, says that one solution to the Middle East turmoil could be to make Israel a dominion of the United States and to place troops there.

title: JAMES FORDYCE, 82, LED MANHATTAN LIFE
description: James P. Fordyce, honorary chairman of the Manhattan Life Insurance Company here, died yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: Bullets Next Worry for Knicks
description: With their worst midseason National Basketball Association record in seven years, the Knicks seem headed for more adversity this weekend. One game below the 500 mark as a result of decisive losses in their last three games, Coach Red Holzman's slumping club faces a twogame series against the Washington Bullets, one of the league's superior teams.

title: East Is West,West East As Twain Meet on S.I.
description: Mayor Beame signed a local law yesterday changing the name of West Buchanan Street in Staten Island to East Buchanan Street and that of East Buchanan Street to West Buchanan Street.

title: White House Reporters To Undergo Bag Search
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (Reuters)  Briefcases and camera bags brought into the White House by reporters and photographers are to be searched under a steppedup security system aimed at preventing a repetition of the bomb explosion that damaged the State Department on Jan. 29.

title: 4 Overtimes: Nets Lose
description: The San Diego Conquistadors defeated the New York Nets, 176166, last night in four overtimes, in San Diego, an American Basketball Association record and the highest scoring professional game on record. Julius Erving scored 63 points for New York. Details on page 19.

title: A Gothic Tale of a Manor House in Modern France
description: ST. NAUPHARY, France, Feb. 9The crumblina hilltop manor house near this village in the Toulouse region of the southwest stands shuttered and empty. The savage dogs are gone and it is guarded now by gendarmes, who shiver in the wind.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES DOWN IN JANUARY, 2D MONTH IN A ROW
A. E. Staley Sells Asmus Products To Oscar Mayer
description: Oscar Mayer & Co., meat processor of Madison, Wis., has agreed to purchase the assets of Asmus Products, a division of the A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company, for an undisclosed sum, it was announced yesterday. Asmus, a processor of natural spices, will be merged into the Quality Control Spice Company, an Oscar Mayer division.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1975

title: Andean Pact Fears Effects of U.S. Trade Law
description: LIMA, Peru, Fcb. 14 (AP)Delegates to the Andean Pact's political council meeting reportedly agreed today that the new United States trade law hurts the pact's six member nations and strains ties with Latin America.

title: Gulf Oil Set to Discuss Cooperation With Soviet
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14 (Reuters)The Gulf Oil Corporation said today that its president, James E. Lee, would meet next week in Moscow with high Soviet officials to discuss scientific and technical cooperation in five petroleumrelated areas.

title: MIRACLES PERFORM AT BARNEY GOOGLE'S
description: It's always nice to see an act as big as the Miracles in a small club, and one always applauds when a new club joins the ranks of those attempting to offer name acts. But the performance of the Miracles at Barney Google's on Thursday night (the club is at 225 East 86th Street, and the Miracles will be there through tonight) had its problems.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: A Modern Couple Confound Statistics and Get Married
description: Just after Christmas, Marilyn Stone and Steve Keenan decided to get married on St. Valentine's Day.

title: AMEX IN ADVANCE AS TRADING EASES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose again yesterday for the second straight day in moderate but decreased trading.

title: Article 2  No Title
Evelyn Lear Experiments In Tully Hall Song Recital
description: Since audiences for most solo recitals have been declining for several years, some performers have begun to experiment with the recital format in the hope of attracting and holding more listeners. Such experimentation generally involves a relaxation of traditional recital formality.

title: Jackpot Pool $400,000
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board announced yesterday that the Jackpot pool for the New York Lottery that is to be drown next Friday will be raised from $50,000 to $400,000.

title: CARE Helped 29 Million
description: Almost 29 million people were helped by CARE in 36 countries during 1974, according to the agency's annual report. More than 20 million people, mostly chlidren, received daily supplemental feeding. Emergency relief went to 7 million victims of droughts or floods.

title: People in Sports
description: Japanese players have made tremendous improvement since I first came to Japan in 1951, and I think that in five years the time will be ripe for a real World Series, Joe DiMaggio said last night after completing a oneweek batting  coach assignment with the Lotte Orions in their spring training site at Kagoshima on Thursday. At one time I believed that it would take a long time before the Japanese would beon a par with major league players because we were bigger physically, ran faster, hit harder and threw harder but there no longer is a pronounced difference.

title: G.E. Sees Economy Rising in 2d Half After a Slow Start
description: The General Electric Company expects a slow first half this year, but the company's economists are forecasting provements in the economy during the second half.

title: SEOUL TO RELEASE ALL JAILED CRITICS BUT COMMUNISTS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Feb. 15 President Park Chung Hee announced today that he would release all political prisoners except those he said were Communists.

title: Misplaced Places on Map
description: SKOKIE, Ill. (UPI)Motorists driving through the state of Louisiana shouldn't be surprised if they happen across Iowa. According to the 1975 Rand McNally road atlas, Iowa is in the southwestern part of the bayou state. Then there's Florida, Missouri and would you believe Wyoming, Delaware?

title: Boston Jury Weighs Case Against Doctor in Abortion
description: BOSTON, Feb. 14The case of Dr. Kenneth Edelin, who is charged with the death of a baby boy fetus in a legal abortion, went to the jury at 12:30 P.M. today after six weeks of testimony.

title: On the Highway With Willie Mosconi
description: Whitehaired and chunky in a tuxedo, Willie Mosconi quickly chalks his cue and hurries around the greenfelt table with the graceful assurance of a champion. Stroke, click, thunk. Quickly he chalks his cue again and hurries to his next shot. Willie Mosconi held the world pocket billiards title 13 times in the 17year span from 1941 through 1957, a domination unmatched in almost any game. Except for Sam Snead, the golfer, Willie Mosconi's contemporaries have faded as their skills have deteriorated.

title: Court Holds Union Locals Must Accept Journeymen
Music: Bergsma Wishes
description: William Bergsma's Wishes, Wonders, Portents, Charms was given its first performance at Avery Fisner Hall Wednesday night by the National Chorale, which had commissioned the piece, and it turned out to be a mostly affecting affair.

title: Role of the Fed
description: Despite all these efforts, the money supply of the nation has been growing very sluggishly. In the latest three months, it actually seems to have declined slightly. Without getting lost in a complex numbers game, it is obvious that by any measuring rod the stock of money has been growing too slowly to reverse the real decline in the economy.

title: P. G. Wodehouse Is Dead on L.I. at 93; Creator of Jeeves and Bertie Wooster
description: P. G. Wodehouse, one of this century's most prolific, popular and durable writers of light fiction, died of a heart attack last evening in the Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived in nearby Remsenburg, a village on Long Island's South Shore.

title: Conservative Parley Taken Up With Talk of 3d Party
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14Discussion of a third party dominated the formal programs and conversations in the corridors today at the second annual Conservative Political Action Conference

title: SUGAR CONTRACTS DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Most commodity futures prices drifted lower or held barely steady yesterday, as traders tended to sell in order to even out their positions before the threeday Washington's birthday. Many traders, especially speculators, do not like to be in the market over a long weekend because of the chance of major domestic or international news breaking that might affect markets.

title: F.T.C. SUIT OF GRANT REQUIRES $150,000
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (Reuters)The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had filed a consent agreement with the W. T. Grant Company that requires the compay to pay a $150,000 penalty for alleged vioations of the TruthinLending Act.

title: Receivership Entered By Northern Ohio Bank
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 14 (UPI) The Northern Ohio Bank, a small downtown financial institution, which listed assets of more than $115million last December, went into receivership tonight after a fourweek examination of its books and financial status.

title: APPEALS FROM I.R.A. FOR JAILED 12 DENIED
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 14  The Government refused tonight to make any further concessions to 12 jailed I.R.A. Provisional members who are on a hunger strike. One is dangerously ill. that they be separated from

title: Suffolk Democrats Celebrate A Victory With Carey on Hand
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Feb. 14 One hundred days after they won unexpected victories in Congressional and local elections, Suffolk County Democrats formally celebrated tonight and vowed to change even further the political landscape of this traditionally Republican County.

title: Civil Rights Hearings
description: Special to The New York Times

title: On St. Valentine's Day, Cupid Strikes and, on Many Occasions, Strikes Out
description: St. Valentine's Day was just another day in the divorce courts. Said an aide to Supreme Court Justice Manuel A. Gomez, They come in in droves every day.

title: Le Style C'est la Nation
description: PARISWhen the police here tow away an illegally parked car, no chain or even rope touches it; no one forces the locks. A low fourwheeled platform is positioned under the car, which hydraulic jacks lift clear. The platform, not the car, is hooked to the towtruck.

title: 2 SLAIN IN BROOKLYN; DEATHS LAID TO MOBS
description: Two men with police records were shot to death about 12 hours apart in Brooklyn yesterday in what the police said were apparent gangland slayings.

title: A Day Like All Others in Divorce Courts
description: St. Valentine's Day was just another day in the divorce courts. Said an aide to Supreme Court Justice Manuel A. Gomez, They come in in droves every day.

title: Executive Admits Fraud in Purchase Of Metals From U.S.
description: NEWARK, Feb. 14A Wayne Township trophy manufacturer acknowledged in Federal court today that he had made $143,000 in illegal profits by selling Governmentsurplus zinc and lead that he obtained by fraud.

title: U.S. Concern Makes Major Soviet Deal
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14 An American company announced today that it had sold the Soviet Union $23million worth of machinery, marking the first Soviet  American business transaction to be completed since the collapse last month of the trade agreement between the two countries.

title: Claudia Petersen Wed To Leonard Forman
description: Claudia Petersen of Glendale, Calif., was married here yesterday morning to Leonard M. Forman of New York. The Rev. Mel Hawthorne, chaplain of the Church Center for the United Nations, performed the nondenominational ceremony there.

title: MAKARIOS PLEDGES TO RESIST DIVISION
N.F.L. Sued on Use Of Broncos Symbol
description: DENVER, Feb. 14 (UPI)Gerald and Tom Whatley say they love the Denver Broncos so much they want to make Tshirts with the Bronco symbol on them. And the two brothers have gone to court to get permission to do so.

title: Deterioration of Quaint Old Tombs Provokes New Orleans Controversy
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14For generations, the burial customs here have been different from those in the rest of the country.

title: JURY GETS INQUIRY ON TRANSIT POLICE
description: A special state grand jury is investigating whether a group of highlevel Transit Authority police officials entered into a conspiracy to accept and share bribes from transit policemen seeking promotions.

title: BUSINESSES SHOW INVENTORIES RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14Total business inventories continued to rise strongly in December as sales declined, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Sterndent Asks Rejection Of Tender Offer by Magus
description: The Sterndent Corporation announced yesterday that its board was urging shareholders to reject a tender offer of $14 a share, by the Magus Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Cable Funding Corporation, for 1.08 million shares of Sterndent's common stock.

title: Issue of Permissible Research On Fetus Is Argued at Hearing
New Form of Math
description: A form of mathematics called nonstandard analysis, which seemingly resolves old paradoxes, increases the available numbers and may have broad implications for economics, physics and biology, is causing excitement among mathematicians. Details on Page 22.

title: LAYOFFS IN AUTOS RISING NEXT WEEK
description: DETROIT, Feb. 14The Ford Motor Company said today it would have 60,700 workers laid off next week, about 3,000 fewer than this week but still almost 35 per cent of its hourly work forcein the United States.

title: Vandals Damage Yeshivah
description: The police reported that 12 stainedglass windows at the Yeshivah of Bensonhurst, at 2025 79th Street in Brooklyn, were damaged sometime yesterday afternoon by rockthrowing vandals who escaped. A police spokesman said the damage had been placed at 5300. He said the school had been the target of similar attacks before.

title: THREE SOUL GROUPS SING AT MUSIC HALL
description: Soul music may be the trendy rage in the discotheques, but it certainly wasn't at Radio City Music Hall on Thursday. Three groups, Ohio Players, Graham Central Station and ParliamentFunkadelic, appeared and collectively seemed to outnumber the audience.

title: STATE PAY URGED FOR PREGNANCIES
description: Legislation to provide disability benefits to pregnant women under the state's Workmen's Compensation Law was urged yesterday by the assistant director of the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: Market Place
description: While bad news on the economic front pours in from Washington, the stock market continues to show vigor. Meanwhile, brokers, always partial to potential bull markets, are pointing to encouraging technical factors that they hope will extend the market's sixweek advance.

title: Keith Carlson, 34, Director Of Zoom Program on TV
description: SCITUATE, Mass., Feb. 14 (AP)Keith Carlson, producerdirector of the nationally televised children's program Zoom, was killed Wednesday night, when his car struck a utility pole along Massachusetts 123 during a snow storm, the police said. He was 34 years old.

title: Bergman to Remain Silent If Senators Bar Demands
description: Bernard Bergman yesterday notified a United States Senate committee investigating the nursinghome industry that he would appear but refuse to testify at a committee hearing in Washington next Wednesday unless certain assurances were made to him in advance to safeguard his rights.

title: GEORGE S. EVELETH
description: George S. Eveleth, former executive vice president of International General Electric Company, who retired in 1960 as manager of its overseas operations, died Thursday in Rye. N. Y. He was 76 years old.

title: Fund Release to Give State $12Million
description: New York State can expect to get $12million of the $2billion in impounded highwayconstruction funds reeased this week by President Ford, Federal transportation officials estimated yesterday.

title: Body Found on Tracks
description: An unidentified man about 47 years old who apparently had been hit by a train was found dead yesterday in the underground section of the Long Island Rail Road on Atlantic Avenue near Milford Street in the East New York section of Brooklyn. He apparently had been walking on the eastbound side of the tunnel.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: Teacher Here to Marry a Dutch Princess
Welcoming a Friend Back to Park Avenue
description: The eve of Valentine's Day. Old store. New image. Fine art. Heart Fund benefit.

title: Big Snow and Holiday Lure Skiers to Slopes
description: A threeday holiday rush for the ski country began late yesterday afternoon as enthusiasts, attracted by outstanding ski conditions, headed toward northeastern resorts from urban and suburban centers. The stage for the great exodus was set Wednesday when the largest snowfall of the winter dropped on New York, Philadelphia and Hartford. Such a development at big population areas whets the apetites of city and suburban dwellers for the outdoor sport.

title: Casper, Funseth and Lister Share Golf Lead at 137
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 14The Andy WilliamsSan Diego open is turning into a sort of bonanza for old pros, some of whom have frankly known better days, and for a couple of relatively anonymous young pros.

title: The Dance
description: Everything is not for everybody, as the Brooklyn Academy of Music's continuing Experimental Dance Series makes clear. To most theatergoers, the works on these programs would not fit the traditional definition of dance. That is the whole point, in fact, of the series.

title: Jackpot Pool $400.000
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board announced yesterday that the Jackpot pool for the New York Lottery that is to be drawn next Friday will be raised from $50,000 to $400,000.

title: Books of The Times
description: BLUE COLLAR COMMUNITY. By William Kornblum 260 pages. University of Chicago Press. $9.95.

title: Small Farms Increased in New York State Last Year
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19  The New York Crop Reporting Service has reported that the number of farms in New York State rose to 57,000 in 1974 from 56,000 the year before, an apparent reversal of a longterm declining trend in agriculture in the state.

title: Business Briefs
description: OSLO, Norway, Feb. 14 (Reuters)Oil companies operating in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea may have to pay up to threequarters of their profits in tax, Finance Minister Per Kleppe said today.

title: 4 Sugar Concerns Named In Coast Suit on Prices
description: TACOMA, Wash., Feb. 14 (AP)An antitrust suit alleging conspiracy to control prices was filed today in Federal District court against four sugar companies by the State Attorney General's office.

title: Agnes I. O'Neil, 77, Dies; Pioneer in Early Child Care
REP, JERRY PETTIS DIES IN AIR CRASH
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Feb. 14 (AP)Representative Jerry L. Pettis was killed today when a private plane he was piloting crashed, the Air Force reported. He was 58 years old.

title: Music: Nelson Freire
description: Nelson Freire must have provided some of the most satisfying pianism of the season in his recital in the Hunter College Playhouse on Thursday night. The Brazilian artist, now 30 years old, was appearing here for the first time in four years, in a series sponsored by the Center for InterAmerican Relations.

title: Polemic and Poetic Art by Beuys
SEOUL TO RELEASE ALL FOES IN PRISON BUT COMMUNISTS
U.S. COURT LIMITS STRIKEFORCE ROLE
Mrs. Ford to Continue Equal Rights Lobbying
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI)Betty Ford vowed today to stick to my guns and keep lobbying for the Equal Rights Amendment in spite of heavy criticism from opponents of the measure who picketed the White House.

title: LAZARD WINS ROLE IN SALE BY FRENCH
News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1975

title: REBELS ARE CRUSHED BY MALAGASY FORCE
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, Feb. 14 (Reuters)Troops loyal to the Government of Madagascar today overcame the last resistance from insurgents blamed for the assassination of the head of state, Col. Richard Ratsimandrava.

title: Javits Visits 2 Neighborhood Manpower Centers Here
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits visited two neighborhood manpower centers here yesterday to find out if publicservice jobs and training financed by the Federal Government were available for the city's unemnloyed.

title: Offshore Oil: Changes in Leases Are Likely
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14For two weeks now, at Federal hearings in Alaska, California and New Jersey on offshore oil leasing, oil industry representatives have been discounting any longterm effects from the 1969 Santa Barbara oil well blowout. What they don't say, but are realizing increasingly. is that perhaps the biggest repercussion of Santa Barbara is only now materializing: impending major changes in the Federal pattern of leasing offshore oil tractsa multibilliondollar business.

title: 2 SENATORS ASSAIL ARABS BLACKLIST
description: Two influential United States Senators said yesterday that an attempt by Arab interests to extend their economic boycott to banking houses with Jewish members was contrary to United States policy. They called for a prompt investigation by the Ford Administration.

title: Nordiques Sink Fighting Saints
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 14 (AP)Steve Sutherland fired in three goals and Serge Bernier added four assists tonight, powering the Quebec Nordiques to a 73 World Hockey Association victory over the Minnesota Fighting Saints.

title: A COAST REPORTER LOSES ON CONTEMPT
FEMINISTS PRAISE HILLS SELECTION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Two leaders of the women's rights movement today praised President Ford's selection of Carla A. Hills to be Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and one of them attacked those who have said she is unqualified.

title: Brezhnev Speech Shows No Major Policy Shifts
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14Leonid I. Brezhnev, who emerged yesterday after more than seven weeks out of official view, reaffirmed the Kremlin's position today on an array of international issues, indicating that no major policy shifts had occurred during his absence.

title: TESTIMONY GIVEN ON AID TO BERGMAN
description: Three political figures and a lawyer representing nursinghome groups testified yesterday about influence reportedly exerted in behalf of Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome entrepreneur.

title: Princeton Triumphs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: It's EducationalIn Lots of Ways
description: When John brought up this center, then we really loved school. If John hadn't brought up this center, we wouldn't all be here nowwe'd be down the drain.

title: MAFIA ROLE HINTED IN ROME ABDUCTION
description: ROME, Feb. 14A Rome court that in December cleared an American journalist, Jack L. Begon, of charges of faking his own kidnapping has stated that the newsman could have been abducted by Mafia elements allegedly connected with the business empire of Michele Sindona, the financier.

title: CON ED CITES NEED FOR NATURAL GAS
Detente in Space
description: Soviet and American astronauts have been fraternizing at Cape Canaveral and nearby Disney World in recent weeks, evidence of how much the world has changed since the late nineteenfifties when the first Soviet sputniks created nearpanic among American policymakers and Soviet Premier Khrushchev boasted that Moscow's space achievements proved the superiority of socialism over capitalism.

title: Bando Set To Play Out His Option
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 (UPI)Sal Bando, the Oakland A's third baseman, withdrew today from his scheduled salary arbitration hearing and revealed he would test baseball's reserve clause if he cannot agree on a nonarbitrated contract with the club owner, Charles O. Finley.

title: Killing of 4 in Montreal Believed Act of a Gang Settling Accounts
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 14Three masked gunmen fired into a crowded nightclub last night, killing four persons and wounding five others. It was Montreal's second mass killing this winter.

title: Two Lawyers Suspended
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 (UPI)The California Supreme Court today suspended Mr. Ehrlichman and Mr. Mardian from the practice of law. The court based its action on their convictions in Watergate offenses.

title: Market Summary
description: AMERICAN EXCHANGE

title: East Is West, West East As Twain Meet on S.I.
description: Mayor Beame signed a local law yesterday changing the name of West Buchanan Street in Staten Island to East Buchanan Street and that of East Buchanan Street to West Buchanan Street.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Wagner's Das Rheingold, 2:30; Puccini's Manon Lescaut, 8.

title: Black Youths Hijack School Bus In Boston and Assault the Driver
description: BOSTON, Feb. 14 (UPI)About 50 black high school students hijacked a school bus today, beating and threatening the white driver, the police said.

title: Skeleton Fossils Linked To Ancient Near Man
description: The most nearly complete skeleton yet found of an early manlike creatureconsisting of about 40 fossil bones believed to be of a female who lived about three million years agohas been displayed at a news conference in Cleveland.

title: PROFESSOR QUITS WHITE HOUSE POST
Israelis Romp on Mt. Hermon As Gunfire Echoes in the Hills
description: MOUNT HERMON, IsraeliOccupied Syria, Feb. 8The ski patrol members carry Uzi submachine guns; an armored personnel carrier stands guard in the parking lot and instead of yodeling, the sound of small arms and artillery fire reverberates off the snowcovered peaks.

title: Tears for Mayor Daley
description: A man telephoned and said come over and meet Morris Udall who is in New York running for President.

title: Steps Urged to Bolster Racing Here
description: A white paper by the state's thoroughbred trainers and owners warned that unless urgent action was taken, racing here could deteriorate. The report was released yesterday by the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association and the Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association. Among reforms it suggested was that the state take over drugtesting and racetrack security. It also concluded that New Jersey will be a vigorous competitor once the Hackensack Meadows track is completed, and that New York should increase the tracks share of the takeout and decrease the state tax.

title: GRAND JURY INDICTS 2 AIRLINES IN TEXAS
Issue and Debate
Bridge:
Quarter Net Drops 26.5% for Gimbel
description: Gimbel Brothers, Inc., operator of the Gimbel department stores and the Saks Fifth Avenue specially stores, had 26.5 per cent lower net income in its first fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31 on slightly higher sales.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Malpractice Insurance: We Face a Crisis

title: Zarb Lays Inaction On Oil to Democrats
Saigon Attacks OnceFriendly Sect in Mekong Delta
Sports News Briefs
description: CERVINIA, Italy, Feb. 14 (AP)Two West German stars, Wolfgang Zimmerer and Peter Utzschinneider were rated today as favorites to win their fourth straight world twoman bobsled championship. The No. 1 West German sled has clocked the fastest time in five days of trials covering the 1,540meter Blue Lake course, which runs on the slopes opposite the Matterhorn. Zimmerer slowed down considerably as a thick snowfall hindered the trials Wednesday and yesterday, but the sun was out today and the weather was expected to remain clear for the four championship heatstwo tomorrow and two on Sunday.

title: ARAB MAY BUY PART OF A GUARD CONCERN
description: ALHAMBRA, Caif., Feb. 14 (UPI)  An Arab banker may become a major stockholder in the United States concern charged with training Saudi Arabian oilfield guards, according to plans filed with California business regulators.

title: U.S. ALLOWS LITTON TO SELL TO CUBANS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) The United States has temporarily waived its trade boycott of Cuba to allow a Canadian subsidiary of Litton Industries, Inc. to sell $500,000 worth of office equipment to the Castro Government.

title: Nastase, Gerulaitis Win at Net
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 14 (AP)llie Nastase of Rumania, the sole surviving foreigner, and young Vitas Gerulaitis of New York advanced tonight to the semifinals of the United States indoor open tennis championship.

title: Sprinklers Urged for Trade Center
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that he would make a vigorous effort to have a sprinkler system installed in the World Trade Center towers as a consequence of the fire that burned for three hours in one of them early yesterday morning.

title: Reforming the Regents
description: The introduction, on a trial basis, of new procedures for selecting members of the Board of Regents represents a laudable and essential emergency effort to halt the alarming deterioration of that body's quality and independence. The reforms, initiated by Assemblyman Leonard Stavisky of Queens and adopted by the four education committees of both houses, will be put to the test immediately as the State Legislature prepares to fill three vacancies on the 190yearold board.

title: DAVID DIRINGER, 74, EPIGRAPHY EXPERT
description: Dr. David Diringer, professor emeritus of epigraphy at Cambridge University, died Thursday in Cambridge, England. He was 74 years old and also lived in Tel Aviv.

title: >Railroads Report 32,000 Idle
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) The nation's railroads laid off more than 32,000 workers in December and January and even more employes could be out of a job unless traffic and financial conditions quickly improve, the Association of American Railroads said today.

title: Gilman Out Of 2d Post With Oilers
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 14 (AP)Sid Gillman, the Houston Oiler's general manager who stepped down as head coach three weeks ago, also resigned as general manager tonight, according to the Oilers owner, K. S. (Bud) Adams.

title: $5Billion Price Tag Is Put On Jersey's Transit Needs
description: NEWARK, Feb. 14  New Jersey will require $5billion in the next decade in order to complete a viable Interstate System of highways and a masstransit system, the State Transportation Commissioner, Alan Sagner, said today.

title: CAREY CAMPAIGN OFFERS PAYMENT
description: Governor Carey's election campaign is offering payment at 70 cents on the dollar to more than 100 creditors because of a $2.1million shortfall in fundraising, the campaign treasurer said yesterday.

title: Kissinger Says He Is Very Satisfied After Discussions in Egypt and Israel
description: AQABA, Jordan. Feb. 14 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he was very satisfied with his exploratory talks with Israeli and Egyptian officials in advance of next month's negotiations for a new Sinai agreement.

title: SOVIET CHURCHMEN COMING FOR A VISIT
description: A 20member delegation of Soviet church officials is scheduled to arrive here tomorrow for a threeweek visit in the United States.

title: Woman Tennis Player Enters Men's Tourney
description: Traditionalist won't believe It, but an 18yearold Connecticut woman will be making tennis history by becoming the first female to play in a men's international tournament.

title: Compromise Called Possible in Dispute Between Nassau and County Workers
description: MINEOLAIt is possible ttat a compromise can be reached in the contract dispute between Nassau County and the 12,500 members of the Civil Service Employes Association, Francis T. Purcell, vice chairman of the Board of Supervisors, said last week.

title: Phoenix College's Faculty Reopens in Rented Center
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 15 Prescott College has filed bankruptcy papers, while the ad hoc facultyrun Prescott Center for Alternative Education, which rose out of Prescott College's ashes, has announced that it is carrying on and doing well.

title: Rutgers Recruiting Minority Students
BRIDGE
description: Tournament players are only the tip of the bridge iceberg. The vast majority of bridge is played by private foursomes in a domestic setting, or perhaps in a club. The club games are nearly always Chicago: Four deal are played with a complete range of vulnerability situations, and each deal is scored as a unit.

title: Whereand howare they now?
description: The formal dissolution of the Beatles partnership by a London court last month leaves four men in their early 30's a lot richer (millions of dollars in earnings had been held in escrow), free from any possible legal ties to each other, and each increasingly successful on his own.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercial agricultural loans, carloadings, steel, oil, electric power and business failures are for the preceding week and latest available.

title: Yugoslavia Presses a Drive on Academic Dissidents
KISSINGER MEETS FAISAL FOR TALKS ON LONG OIL PACTS
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 15Secretary of State Kissinger flew to Bonn today after discussing with King Faisal the American plan for longterm oil agreements between producers and consumers at prices lower than the current world price of $11 a barrel.

title: PROSOVIET PARTY IN INDIA TROUBLED
