description: NEW DELHI, Feb. I5India's proSoviet Communists are facing an ideological and political problem: Should they move closer to the dominant Congress party or abandon the policy of supporting Prime Minister Indira Gandhi?

title: Gerard Souzay And the Sport Of Singing French Songs
description: The waitress deposited the diet special in front of Gerard Souzay, and he surveyed it with distaste. Twentyfive years of eating in American hotels had made the baritone prudent enough to order something simple, but 56 years as a Frenchman made the thing impossible to contemplate. No matter, Ravel was the important subject at hand, for Souzay sings an allRavel recital Friday night at the Metropolitan Museum to commemorate the hundredth anniversary of the composer's birth.

title: Archeologists Report Inca City Is Discovered
description: SANTIAGO, Chile. Feb. 15 (Reuters)Chilean archeologists today reported the discovery of an Inca city believed to be 2,000 years old.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Harold Lord Fickett 3d Fiance of Mary Baker
description: Mary Messinger Baker, a teacher at the Montessori School in Los Angeles, and Harold Lord Fickett 3d, a senior at the University of California at Los Angeles, plan to marry June 26.

title: TV VIEW
description: I was going to write an essay about the latest hamburger commercials. Of course, on television they don't call them hamburgers any more; they call them beef patties, which are wrapped in garbage and filmed lovingly, as though by Japanese cameramen under water during an algae attack, while a Hungarian rock group, Buddha and the Seven Pests, stomps on a jingle. It's enough to make one want to eat linoleum. But the subject proved too complicated, and so I checked out the new programs on Thursday night instead.

title: C. Arnholt Smith Is Sued; Unsound Banking Charged
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 15 (AP) C. Arnholt Smith, the financier, has been sued for $45million by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for allegedly engaging in unsafe and unsound banking practice.

title: Here's Something Else to Add On a Greenhouse
FEDERAL PENSIONS PROVIDE A BONUS
Answers/Questions
description: A APPLE STORAGE (Feb. 2) Mrs. A.P., Bayside. N.Y., has a productive Golden Delicious apple tree but she has had difficulty in storing the apples which usually shrivel by Christmas. She asked for suggestions. Here is an idea. From Mrs. L.E. Caldwell, a Connecticut reader, Many years ago when we bought a larger refrigerator, we kept the old one for apple storage. We buy apples in fall, put them in heavy plastic bags (22 x 24inch size), and store them in the old refrigerator. We can keep two bushels this way. ASPARAGUS WEEDS (Feb. 2)

title: In Aura of Fear, Babylonian Descendants Thrive as Detroit Grocers
description: DETROIT, Feb. 15It used to say A & P on the wall of a, supermarket on Joy Road in the West Side black ghetto, but now it says Soul Train Food Center.

title: Song Contest Aids Scholarship Fund
description: WESTFIELDThis area's 14th annual Barbershop Quartet Contest will be held at Roosevelt Junior High School on March 1.

title: Nyquist Hears Great Neck Dispute
description: ALBANY  Why don't you both shake hands? asked Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Commissioner of Education, last Tuesday.

title: KLAN HOLDS RALLY IN TEXTBOOK FIGHT
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 15A crowd of 200 school textbook protesters attended a fourhour Ku Klux Klan rally near here today and were told by Ohio Grand Dragon Dale Reusch that the battle against textbooks in Kanawha County schools was a fight against government indoctrination and nationalized education.

title: New NursingHome Curbs Considered by State Aide
description: Morris B. Abram, chairman of the state commission that is to investigate nursing homes, said yesterday that he was considering the advisability of a moratorium on the building of nursing homes, a ceiling on their escalating costs and the channeling of their Medicaid funds to homecare services.

Letters to the Editor

title: Gerulaitis Topples Nastase
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 15 (AP)  Vitas Gerulaitis, 20 yearold New Yorker, ran off eight consecutive games in the third set and scored a stunning upset over Ilie Nastase, 46, 63, 62, 61, in the semifinals of the $50,000 United States indoor open tennis championships tonight.

title: $1.68BILLION GAP PROJECTED BY CITY IN EXPENSE BUDGET
College Sports and the Dollar Squeeze
description: Some college and university presidents I have known have looked upon intercollegiate athletics much in the same light as they would regard the illegitimate son at the family reunion. On a good day and in the right company, a relationship might be acknowledged. On a bad day and in other company, it might be played down or charged off to one of those nuisances or accidents of life. And in some company, the subject simply is avoided altogether.

title: WILLIAM C. PLENGE
description: William C. Plenge, a cofounder in 1926 of the Acme Fire Alarm Company, died on Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in Shannock, R.I. He was 73 years old and lived on Kinderkamack Road, Oradell, N.J.

description: Feb. 24March 1

title: A Company Most Closely Held
description: The New Yorker Magazine, Inc., is a family controlled company whose shares are publicly traded in the overthecounter market. Through the years, some shares have dribbled into outsiders hands as the insiders sold their stock, but the company itself has never had a public offering.

title: Whether to Weed Grass on Wailing Wall Is Debated With Humor in Israeli Press
Leaders Skeptical on Beanie's Aid Pleas
description: State and city legislative leaders expressed skepticism yesterday that Mayor Beame would receive more than a small fraction of the aid he wanted from Albany and Washington to close the huge deficit projected for next year's expense budget.

title: Card of Thanks
description: GREENMollie. The family of the late Mollie Green are deeply appreciative of the many expressions of sympathy and condolences extended to us and gratefully acknowledge the contributions to the many worthy causes in her memory.

title: Antiques Show Set by Chatham Charch
description: CHATHAMThe 19th annual Chatham Antique Show and Sale will be held Tuesday through Thursday at the Chatham Methodist Church, 460 Main Street. Hours are noon until 10 P.M. on Tuesday and Wednesday, and noon until 6 P.M. on Thursday.

title: Job Status Accorded To Veterans May Change
description: TRENTONFor nearly 30 years, military veterans have been accorded a privileged status in competing for Civil Service jobs in New Jersey. The idea, supported by most segments of the public, is to reward duty performedand to ease a veteran's return to civilian lifeby according him preferential treatment in qualifying for a Government position.

title: ROADBED CALLED DEFECT OF AMTRAK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) Deteriorating railroad tracks must be repaired if passenger trains are to compete with air and highway travel, Amtrak said today.

title: APlant Opposed in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 15 (AP) A stand against construction of additional nuclear power plants in Maine has been taken by the Natural Resources Council, a council spokesman said today. Wayne Cobb, coastal and energy consultant to the council, said the council wanted comprehensive testing of all safety systems used at nuclear plants, and a system of waste disposal that would not allow radioactive matter to escape.

title: Agreements to Limit Weapons Have Been Signed and Ignored Before
description: RIO DE JANEIROThe twomonthold Ayacucho Declaration on the limitation of arms in Latin America, which United States diplomats hailed at the time as extraordinary and unprecedented, is soon to be given its first test. Early next month Brazil expects delivery of the first three supersonic F5E fighters of an order of 42 to be supplied by the Northrop Corp.

title: National Starting Early On ForeignEntry Plans
description: Ted Cushny has been reelected president of the National Horse Show, and he said the other day that plans already are being made to bring a group of foreign teams to te event this year.

title: $3,234.60 Return For Double Exacta
description: The double exacta at New York's Offtrack Betting Corporation paid $3,234.60 yesterday, based on the onetwo finishes in the seventh race at Bowie and the ninth at Hialeah.

title: The Section Is Greatly Dependent on Imports
***for the Green Guides of Michelin
description: THE weeks leading up to spring bring a stirring to the blood of Europe. For those past the age of meeting lovers under budding chestnut trees on the quais of Paris, the imminent publication of the annual Michelin red guides has something to do with it. The Michelin guides to restaurants and hotels in Italy, Germany, Spain and Portugal arrive in the bookstores in February, those for France and the Benelux countries on March 15, for Britain and Ireland a fortnight later. It would be a pity, though, if the traveler, bedazzled by the headlines that aceach red guide pronouncement, is led to overlook the other side of Michelin, the green guides to the sights and sites, the roads and beaches of Europefor they may be the most reliable of all guidebooks.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Thomson & McKinnon Auchincloss Kohlmeyer, Inc., a brokerage concern, has leased 115,000 square feet at One New York Plaza. The 20year lease has an aggregate rent of $25million.

title: U.S. SAID TO ASSENT IN IRANPAN AM DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) The White House will announce tomorrow President Ford's approval of an Iranian offer to buy a reported 13 to 15 per cent of the stock of Pan American World Airways, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Senate Abuse of Payroll Rule Alleged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) Members of the United States Senate engage in a widespread pattern of using committee employes as personal aides despite a Senate rule to the contrary, The New Republic magazine reported today.

title: Politicking on Wall St.
description: On Aug. 29, 1972, Senator George McGovernthen running for the Presidencymade a celebrated journey to 15 William Street in the heart of the New York financial district, hoping to dispel any notion that he was the devil incarnate.

title: Pact Is Signed to Make North Marianas a U. S. Area
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 The United States signed a covenant today that will eventually make the Northern Marianas Islands in the Pacific a commonwealth, under American sovereignty, much like Puerto Rico.

title: Soccer Film to Aid College Italian Club
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Coalition Fights Hunt for Oil
description: TRENTONA coalition of 18 New Jersey environmental organizations has asked the Federal Government to delay its plans for oil exploration off the state's coastline until the nation has adopted a series of measures to conserve energy.

title: SCHOENBURG BESET BY AGING PROCESS
description: On the third floor of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, two young women sat side by side at an old library table one day last week, carefully mounting newspaper clippings on special cards for processing into a microfiche system.

title: Fifty years old and all grownup
description: Next Friday The New Yorker, the weekly magazine most educated Americans grew up on, will be 50 years old. Whether we read it or refused to read itwhich depended, of curse, on the sort of people we wanted to beit was as much a part of our class conditioning as clean fingernails, college, a checking account and good intentions. For better or worse, it probably created our sense of humor.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Algeria Reports Arresting 99 Transporting Marijuana
Hudson Reformer Scoffs at Retirement
description: BAYONNEAt 71 years of age, Francis George Fitzpatrick is serving as a painful reminder to some factions of the Hudson County Democratic organization that there is no such thing as a retired politician.

title: Late TV Listings

title: MONEY SHORTAGE HALTS HIGHRISE
description: Construction has been halted on four major luxury apartment developments in Manhattan and one in Fort Lee, N. J., apparently because cost overruns and rising interest rates created severe financing problems for the owners.

title: Ah, Sweet Mystery
description: A richly imaginative and highly unauthorized biography of Howard Hughes was quashed, while the sometimes vagrant reminiscences of Lucky Luciano are subjected to a severe buffeting on the front page of this newspaper; yet a book called The Bermuda Triangle rises serenely to the number one position on the Best Seller List with scarcely a discordant murmur. Although the zany success of Charles Berlitz's book, which now has over 215,000 copies in print, may be dismissed as simply a mutation of popular taste, students of the delusions of crowds might want to mount it in their specimen trays.

title: Funseth, on 206, Leads Tight Field
Lana Jacobs Is Bride of Porter L. Hovey
description: Lana Jacobs, a product publicist with the General Foods Corporation in White Plains, was married yesterday afternoon to Porter Lamson Hovey, a financial analyst with the Foreign Credit Insurance Association in New York. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren Jr. performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church.

title: Trinity Square Repertory Adapts Brightly to Home Screens
description: The Public Broadcasting Service, through its Theater in America series, has been giving a few regional theatersa few of the besta chance to display some of their wares in the nation's living rooms. And two of this season's Theater in America. productions come from the Trinity Square Repertory Company, the resident professional theater of Providence, R. I. Feasting with Panthers, a semidocumentary work about Oscar Wilde, was taped and shown a year ago, and brought back for another showing last month. Brother to Dragons, derived from a dramatic poem by Robert Penn Warren about a bloody crime in old Kentucky, will be broadcast on WNET/13 at 9 P.M. this Wednesday. These two productions may finally serve to focus some national attention on Trinity Square, where one of the most creative of American stage directors and one of the most adventurous of American stage designers work together in one of the most exciting theater buildings in the country.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: McINTYRE AS WOTAN HAS DEBUT AT METDas Rheingold, beginning a Saturday afternoon Ring. cycle at the Metropolitan Opera yesterday, introduced a new singer with the company. He is Donald McIntyre, a native of New Zealand, who has sung here with the New York Philharmonic and the Boston Symphony and is known also through some major opera recordings. He sang the role of Wotan in the Wagner opera, as he will in Die Walkiire, plus the Wanderer in Siegfried and Gunther in Gottertammerung.

title: Ideas &
Mayor's Proposals for Aid
description: To help meet the expensebudget deficit projected for next year, Mayor Beame presented $631.4million worth of proposals for Federal aid and $658million worth of state aid.

title: How to Play Baseline Tennis And Keep Opponents Running
description: Serve  and volley tennis may be fine for the hitters of the men's professional tour or even for accomplished and energetic club players. They have the strength and the speed for that style of playhammering across hard serves and then rushing up to take command of the net.

description: Feb. 22MG Car Club, Long Island Center 60mile night rally, first of Nocturne Trophy Series; start at Howard Johnson's Restaurant, junction of Motor Parkway and Wicks Road, (exit 54, Long Island Expressway). Commack, L. I. Registration: 7 P.M., first car off 8:01. Information: Ross Evans, phone. (516)671 8951.

description: 3 ANTHROPOLOGICAL FILMS, directed by David Hancock (camera) and Herbert Di Gioia (sound); produced by Norman Miller for the American Universities Field Staff; with English subtitles. AFGHAN NOMADS: THE MALDAR, 18 minutes; WHEAT CYCLE, 16 minutes; NAIM AND JABAR, 48 minutes. At the Film Forum, 256 West 88th Street. today and Thursday through next Sun. day, 8 P.M.

title: Handicapped Children Get Horseback Therapy Upstate
description: VERNONSituated on the border between this Sussex County town and Warwick, N.Y., is an unusual riding academy called Borderland Farms.

title: Peter Dalzell Jones Marries Christina Palmer Clare Here
LETTERS
description: Mideast Jobs

title: New Bonds for the Old
description: And now, another opportunity to send your, money to Washington.

title: The Dance
description: Valerie Bettis's Theater Dance Company is presenting a oneact play and some poems by Arnold Meyer iri a production directed by Miss Bettis. The program is being given through tomorrow night in a new loft studio, Eden's Expressway, at 537 Broadway.

title: Goodyear Clubs to Put Fans Closer to Racing
description: When Firestone Tire and Rubber Company withdrew from major motor racing last year, some people were making dire forecasts concerning the future of the sport. They said others would follow Firestone's lead because, after all, if one of the two leading tire manufacturers was getting out, it must be a sign of things to come. Other people, perhaps with a little more vision, didn't see it that way at all. They saw it as an end to the dollar war, the highpriced bidding for the top teams and drivers. They saw it as a possible break for the independents, the drivers who race on a budget and in no way could compete with the teams getting $1million or more over the course of a season.

title: Boat Show Is Offering a Clinic on Fishing
description: ASBURY PARKA fishing clinic is a nightly feature at the Jersey Coast Boat Show, now being held at the Asbury Park Convention Hall. The show opened yesterday and will continue through next Sunday.

title: Taste is falling! Taste is falling!; The fable of chicken that tasted like chicken (and not cardboard, sawdust or chemicals)
description: In the course of my childhood reading, I made the acquaintance of a scatterbrained fowl named Chicken Little, who, when raindrops fell on her head (I think it was raindrops, but I have not brushed up on this work recently and no longer remember all the ramifications of the plot), scuttled dementedly through the farmyard screeching, The sky is falling! Chicken Little was not as crazy as she seemed. Since then her sky has fallen, and she lies flattened beneath it, all taste squeezed out. The Cassandra of the countryside.

title: Dynamism +Dior = Hiroshima +30
description: BY night, we went to pleasure palaces as huge as the show spots in Las Vegas. The Hong Kong had 204 hostesses. The Honolulu had a like number; I especially remember Tomoko, who spoke English. By day we found the city dazzling with new buildings. Chic Japanese girls walked the shopping boulevards in Paris dresses. Young men stopped by at record shops (Any new vocals by Naoko Kin?) and practiced their golf swings while waiting for taxis. Shoppers thronged a fashionable little street where they could buy Gucci or copies of Gucci, Halston or copies of Halston, Dior or copies of Dior.

title: Hofstra Offers Crafts Courses
description: HEMPSTEADCraft skills as ancient as weaving and as up  to  date as sculpturing plastic will be taught, beginning Tuesday, at the new Crafts Center of Hofstra University, 808  812 Fulton Avenue.

title: London's Art Dealers Are Keeping Stiff Upper Lips
description: LONDON. January is always a slow month in the London art world, but this year, some of the dealers on Cork Street and Bond Street are wondering whether January is going to last all year. Rumors of financial doom and devastation abound. Like farmers and fishert'nen, art dealers are notoriously unreliable witnesses to their own situation, but there is no doubt they are being exceedingly friendly, even having lunch with one another  which to some observers of this gentlemanly cutthroat trade means that business must be grim.

title: A JURY CONVICTS CHIEF OF POLICE
description: TOMS RIVER, Feb. 15An Ocean County jury last night convicted Police Chief Edward Dolton of extortion, but found him not guilty of official misconduct.

title: Henry Lawrence Thompson 3d And Mary Willis Set Nuptials
G.O.P. Devises New Tax Plan
Middlesex Fights Joblessness
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  A lawyer, a corporate vice president and a stockbroker, all close friends since their grammar school days, have joined forces to organize and direct a program designed to help combat unemployment in Middlesex County.

title: U.S.L.T.A. Drops Lawn in Name. .
description: AMELIA ISLANDS, Fla., Feb. 15 (UPI)The United States Lawn Tennis Association deleted Lawn from its name today and henceforth will be known as the U.S.T.A. The move was voted at the 94th annual meeting here.

title: Endpaper
description: By Adam Smith

title: ARMENIAN PARTY CHIDED BY LEADER
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15The recently appointed Communist party chief of Armenia has castigated his fellow Armenians for forsaking Communist goals to pursue private enterprise and profit in nearly every sphere of life in the Soviet republic.

title: RABBI DISCUSSES CAMPUS MINISTRY
description: His ministry on the campus spanned 35 years, or nine student generations, no two of which were precisely alike, says Dr. Alfred Jospe.

title: CLYDE
description: They call Walt Frazier Clyde and Mr. Cool and The Prince of Madison Square Garden, and most basketball buffs assumed that, what with old pros Willis Reed and Dave DeBusschere and Jerry Lucas hanging up their sneakers this season, Fraziei would emerge as the undisputed superstar of the New York Knickerbockers. Well, frankly, so did the 29yearold millionaire guard, and he rather relished the idea. First, Coach Red Holzman named him captain of the 197475 team. To celebrate, Frazier had his $20,000 RollsRoyce with the WCF license platesfor Walt (Clyde) Frazierrepainted in more dynamic shades of honeybeige and burgundy because so many New Yorkers had copied his old color combination of antelope over garnet. And then he went out and spent $10,000 of his $300,000ayear salary in one day, mostly on a new white mink coat for bouncing around town.

title: Roberta Bates Bride of Joseph Jamin
B. R. Fisher Jr. to Wed Linda Crawford
description: The engagement of Linda Belle Crawford to Benjamin Reeves Fisher Jr., son of Mr and Mrs. Fisher, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Slater Crawford 3d. Both families live in Pittsburgh.

title: Etlilopian Fuel Convoy Reported Turned Back by Eritrean Rebels
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 15 (Reuters)Eritrean secessionists today turned back a convoy of fuel tankers heading for the provincial capital of Asmara, setting one of them on fire, reliable sources here said.

title: Palisades Park's Medic 1: Quick Help for Heart Victims
Veterinarians Start Push To Place Unwanted Pets
description: The Veterinary Medical Association of New York City, alarmed by the number of pets that owners are leaving on the street to fend for themselves, has started a campaign to help remedy the situation.A pet needs a good home and a responsible owner, said Dr. J. Lloyd Tait, the organization's president. If an individual has a dog or cat he no longer wants, or is unable to care for, he shouldn't keep it. But it is his duty to find a new home for the animal. Unless you have a friend or relative willing to adopt the pet, we urge you take it to an animal shelter, where it will receive proper care and may be put up for adoption.

title: Despite Some Uneven Positions, Mr. Kissinger Is at Least Serious
description: WASHINGTON  From the beginning of LatinAmerican relations with the United States more than a century ago there have always been two levels.

title: Mets Fate Decidedly Iffy
description: Consider the New York Mets, the onceamazing Mets: Hopelessly last or nexttolast for seven years, stunningly first in one melodramatic burst in 1969, then third for three years running, then from last place to the National League pennant in 1973and finally fifth last summer with 71 victories, 91 defeats, uncounted injuries and 17 lengths back.

title: Michigan Post pones Switching To Daylight Saving by 9 Weeks
description: LANSING, Mich., Feb. 15 When the rest of the nation; goes on daylight time Feb. 23, Michigan will remain on Eastern standard time.

title: MALE TROUBLE
description: Every man has one, and no woman has. It an organ associated with sexual function. Yet it not likely, to excite pornographers or the prurient, largely because it is tucked away out of sight, inside the body, against the wall of the rectum. Although it is thus much less aphrodisiacal than the female breast, it appears remarkably similar, under the tissue specialist's microscope, to that conspicuous sex symbol. When it becomes cancerous, other resemblances emerge: Its disease is related to, and sometimes controlled by, the sex hormones. And the controversy regarding the treatment of the male affliction parallels that among breast surgeons over how radical a mastectomy to performif any.

title: National League: Dodgers, Loaded With Talent, Are Team Reds Have to Beat
description: What can you say about a baseball team that won 102 games last summer with the best record in the business, that produced the Most Valuable Player in the National League, that owns one of the two 20game winners in the league plus a relief pitcher who worked 106 times, that drew 2,632,474 customers and that is holding the price line at $3.50 for a box seat for the 18th year in a row?

title: Marianas Pact Signed
description: The United States signed covenant yesterday that would eventually make the Northern Marianas Islands in the Pacific a commonwealth, much like Puerto Rico. The 17 islands have a population of 14,000, most of whom would become American citizens. Page 3.

title: U.S. CITIZENS USED BY F.B.I ABROAD
The Jets' Direction
description: Al Ward is an experienced, efficient and capable administrator in the pro football business. But his appointment last week as the New York Jets general manager shows the direction the club owners have chosen. Al Ward will be more a business manager than a general manager. Al Ward will negotiate player contracts (except Joe Namath's), bookexhibition games, handle TV and radio deals, supervise the operation of the front office. Ward's role means that the construction and development of the team on the field has been entrusted to Charley Winner, the controversial coach. It also means that Phil Iselin, the Jets' president, plans to take command of the front office.

title: Galleries Turn the Spotlight on State's Artists and Others
Hotel Clerk Here, First Night on Job, Killed by Robbers
description: A hotel night clerk who was working his first night, was shot dead yesterday as he prevented two gunmen from entering and robbing his office at the Sutton East Hotel at 330 East 56th Street, the police reported.

title: Witch Hazel Previews Spring
description: Blossoms that appear during the colorful summertime are more or less taken for granted. But those that choose odd seasons win special affection.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: I think there is a popular misconception to the effect that actors develop one set of muscles for farce and quite another set for serious materials, the twain neveror hardly evermeeting. Not so, as I realized with some astonishment a week ago watching two superlative performances on two successive nights. The same controlled tendons, the same jacknife reflexes, even the same vocal cords do duty in both.

title: 'Dry Town University Hopes to Get A Pub Soon
description: RUTHERFORDA bill now awaiting Governor Byrne's signature will enable Fairleigh Dickinson University, the largest private college in New Jersey, to have a pub on its campus here.

title: Ecumenical Aide Is Named By Greek Orthodox Head
description: Archbishop Iakovos, head of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America, has named the Rev. Dr. Nicon D. Patrinacos as archdiocesan director of interchurch relations and social concerns.

title: Making Things
description: There are those among us who, having been bitten by a savage shop teacher, are impervious to the charms of industrial arts. Ray_Brock, author of these four pamphlets (Dell/Dial, $1.50 each) on beginningor possibly remedialcarpentry, takes a gentler tack (!). Billed as howtodoits for Young (and youngatheart) carpenters. the appeal is to gradeschool craftsmen and women: If you're 8 or 9 years old you might not have the money to buy a hammer, saw, or square. But maybe you can borrow them from your dad uncle or an older friend.

title: NEW ANOMALIES IN CLIMATES SEEN
People Seeking a Place Are Expert in Giving the
description: Among our considerations when we purchased a summer cottage a couple of years ago was the rental income that would offset some of our expenses. According to what we heard, we would soon be fighting off hordes of potential renters trying to shove money at us.

title: Miss Carasso, George Bulow Plan Marriage
Richard B. Klarberg, Lawyer, To Marry Emily H. Gawthrop
description: Emily Hoskins Gawthrop plans to be married in May to Richard B. Klarberg, special counsel to the American Health Foundation here.

title: City Council Sessions Scheduled This Week
description: The following public meet ings of City Council committees will be held this week:

title: $5Million Allocated For Brooklyn Tech

title: Montreal To Report On Games
description: MONTREAL Feb: 15 (AP) The organizing committee for the 197f Summer Olympic Games will face some stiff questioning Thursday when it appears before an executive meeting of the International Olympic Committee in Lausanne, Switzerland.

title: Music in Review
description: The list of talented emerging young American pianists had a name added high on it last Tuesday night when Jeffrey Swann made his debut here in the Young Concert Artists series at Hunter College Playhouse. At the age of 23, the Texas virtuoso has already accumulated several honors, the most recent being the gold medal (second prize) at the Queen Elisabeth of the Belgians International Competition in Brussels in 1972. His teachers have included Alexander Uninsky in Dallas and Beveridge Webster at the Juilliard School. His current teacher is Adele

title: Modern Lawyers Don't Do It as Darrow Did
description: Clarence Darrow, when he was 79 years old, set down in writing for Esquire Magazine his formula for choosing a jury apt to be friendly to an underdog client:

title: Optimism Marks Start of Long Island Boat Show
description: A buoyant optimism and predictions for brisk sales marked the opening of the nineday Long Island Boat Show yesterday at the Nassau Coliseum. With the recession  depression horrors we've had over our heads, what better way is there to get away from everything than to get out on a boat? said Eadie Van Nostrand, the show promoter. Also, think a lot of people are buying boats rather than spending the money on vacations. And what better place is there for a boat than Long Island?

title: Assembly Panel to Meet on Problems Faced by Public and Private Colleges on L.I.
description: The disparate views on the adequacy of higher education facilities and programs on Long Island and the expansion of the State University College at Old Westbury will be aired at hearings scheduled by the Assembly Committee on Higher Education this Thursday and Friday in Hempstead.

description: The formation of a new politicalaction group in the field of education, known as the Alliance for Children, has been Announced by its organizers.

title: Article 4  No Title
Eritreans in Addis Ababa Beginning to Show Strain
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 15We work, we wait and we worry about what happens next, a middle level civil servant said in a calm voice, but his face showed the strain of recent weeks.

title: By machine, by hand
description: All machines have been thought out and constructed by human beings, and what one person can make, another person can understand, or so Martin Keen tries to convince us in this his second volume about the principles behind the engines and machines we encounter in our everyday lives.

title: ABDUCTION REPORT STIRS WIDE SEARCH
description: A Brooklyn cab driver reported to the police that a gunman, who had first abducted and then robbed him, kidnapped a young woman at gunpoint and forced her to drive off with him.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ARGENTINE CONGRESSMAN IS SLAIN: The wife of Hiplito Acuna screams in horror as she finds her husband slumped over the wheel of their car, on a Santa Fe street. Machinegun fire from a passing car had wounded him fatally moments before. A terrorist group, the Montoneros, claimed responsibility for the assassination of the rightwing politician. Elsewhere in Argentina, eight persons were reported killed in guerri]la and police raids. Police also reported having arrested 1,000 in widespread security raids.

title: WALL STREET
description: A longsmoldering dispute over the sale of socalled moral obligation bonds flared up this month, highlighting important questions of public policy and clouding an important sector of the debt market.

title: Charity Cage Game to Feature Jets
description: EAST BRUNSWICKThe third annual East Brunswick Jaycee charity basketball game will pit members of the 1974 New York Jets against an East Brunswick Jaycee team. The contest will be played next Saturday at Vocational Technical High School, Rues Lane, starting at 8 P.M.

title: The New Yorker: Mannerly Maverick at 50
description: The 50th birthday of The New Yorker will be celebrated next Friday, in the magazine's imitable style, with a party at The Plaza Hotel at which champagne may or may not be served, which The Editor may or may not attend, to which advertisers and other useful outsiders have courteously not been invited.

title: Marjorie E. Balgooyen Betrothed
Home Clinic
description: Q: My marble table top has rings left by alcohol glasses. Despite repeated application of special marble wax the Stains won't come off. Can you advise me what to do? G.B., Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Nuns Discuss Euthanasia
description: In a time of growing depersonalization and sophisticated lifeprolonging medical techniques, what are the legal rights of dying persons? At what point should extraordinary means not to be used to keep a patient alive, and who is to make such a decision?

title: Shop Talk
Racing Fans to Stage Daytona Festival Today
description: DAYTONA, Fla., Feb. 15 Forty machines resembling automobiles and more than 100,000 fingerlickin spectators will pay tribute tomorrow to God, country and the suffering carmakers of America.

description: RIDGEWOODThe Heritage Exhibit, now in its 26th year as an annual event of the Paramus Historical and Preservation Society, is not the usual kind of crafts show.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Shampoo showers us with signals. An opening line on the screen notifies us that the time is election eve, Nov. 4, 1968ah, the resonances of that dateand we are never allowed to forget it. See the NixonAgnew posters  see NixonAgnew on those TV sets, playing away with obtrusive unobtrusiveness in every house we enter  see HuntleyBrinkley doing their electionnight routine  hear the returns. Clearly we are being prepared for something more stimulating than a rinse.

title: Fresh Mushrooms Are a Flavorful Winter Offering

Miss Wagner Is Wed To James Herrmann
description: Rosemarie Wagner and James Herrmann were married yesterday morning in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral in Rockville Centre, L. I. The bride's uncle, the Rev. Andrew Drew, performed the ceremony.

title: Compliance With New Fire Code Lagging Drastically
description: New York City's Local Law 5, the most stringent highrise fire safety law in the nation, is in trouble. Unlike other cities, which require major innovations in new construction only, New York has ordered the upgrading of all office buildings, old or new, that are more than 100 feet tall. The law affects 971 structures, and the cost of the work it requires will run to hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Repairing Auto Dealerships
description: For automobile dealers. 1974 was the roughest year on record. Of the 30.000odd dealers in the country, 284 went out of business.

title: LifeStyle Is Called a Key to Health
description: STONY BROOKA radical change of lifestyles and an increase in the role of environmental planning may be necessary if the American public is to reduce heart disorders and cancer, according to the dean of the Medical School at the University Center here.

title: DR. JOY PALM
description: Dr. Joy Palm, a member of the Wistar Institute of Anatomy and Biology of Philadelphia, died of cancer Friday in Providence, R.I., where she had been visiting her mother. She was 49 years old.

title: A Tough Year In Toy Making
description: Randolph P, Barton, president of Parker Brothers, calls it the toughest profit year we've ever looked at. Jerome M. Fryer, president of Gabriel Industries, Inc., says that it is a period when consumers may buy fewer toys and less expensive toys.

Some 3,000 members of the society, guests and auto industry leaders are expected to attend the banquet, which will be held during the society's 1975 Automotive Engineering Exposition and Congress.

description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 15The Federal Communications Bar Association has proposed a legal aid plan that would provide free or low cost legal advice to needy broadcasters accused of violating Federal regulations but no such services for public groups challenging the licenses of broadcasters.

title: Film Notes: How Do You Find a New Clark Gable?
description: Los ANGELES Finding actors to play well known personalities is always difficult, and the difficulty is compounded when the characters to be portrayed are reallife movie stars. For that reason, casting is the major problem with a new film called Gable and Lombard, based on the legendary romance of two of Hollywood's biggest stars. Universal paid $100,000 for the original screenplay by Barry Sandler, a young graduate of U.C.L.A.'s film school, and will spend $3 or $4million on the movie, to be directed by Sidney J. Furie. Shooting is scheduled to start in Mayprovided the movie can be cast by then.

title: FETAL REEARCH REPORTED ON RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  A substantial amount of research involving the human fetus has beeit done in the United States and elsewhere during the last five years, according to a preliminary study done for a national commission.

title: Huntington Symphony Is Finding the Road to Professionalism to Be a Bumpy One
description: HUNTINGTON  In its effort to move from a largely community orchestra to an allprofessional symphony group, the Huntington Symphony has found that professionalism can involve unions, contracts, fringe benefits and even, as in the case of its most recent scheduled concert, cancellation because of a labor dispute.

title: Cardiology College Elects
description: HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 15 (AP) Dr. Charles Fisch of Indianapolis has been named president of the American College of Cardiology. Other new officers of the organization, which held its 24th annual meeting here, include Dr. Warren J. Taylor of Winchester, Mass., presidentelect; Dr. Dean T. Mason of Davis, Calif., vice president, and Dr. Robert J. Hall of Houston, secretary.

title: DISPUTE GOES ON OVER AEGEAN SEA
description: ATHENS, Feb. 15While the Cyprus issue has been attracting international attention, Greece and Turkey have been waging another battle over their respective rights in the Aegean Sea.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: President Ford has proposed a comprehensive energy program that relies on market forces rather than allocation and rationing, and his initiative and the general direction of his proposals are praiseworthy. I do have some reservations, however, about the magnitude and timing of his shortterm energy recommendations.

Last year, we had Robert Snyder's fine documentary on the writer, made in 1969; now, Tom Schiller's Henry Miller Asleep and Awake (1973) yields another highly enjoyable visit with this scribacious person. The film at the Whitney Museum of American Art, will run through Tuesday.

description: WASHINGTONSo far at least, the public service employment program created by the Federal Government has made no real impact on the nation's unemployment, which has now reached emergency proportions.

title: Plead guilty whether you are or not
description: The art of legal jailbreaking is an old arid honorable tradition in American history. The most imaginative practitioners were West Coast members of the Industrial Workers of the World who, 60 years ago, used it as part of their famous freespeech fights. If, say, a Wobbly soapboxer was arrested on a street corner in San Diego, the word would go out to other members, and they in turn would hitch into town, get themselves arrested and flood the jails to the point where the authorities had no choice but to let everybody go. Eight years ago two S.D.S. friends and I were jailed in Columbia, Mo., during a freespeech, antiwar campaign. It happened that we were also I.W.W. membersthe organization was by then a relic, but we had joined it looking for political grandfathersthe only Wobblies in the state. We amused ourselves by chalking Wobbly slogans on our cell walls, and by telling our fellow inmates, mostly drunks and vagrants, that any day now thousands of revolutionaries would descend upon Columbia and bust us all out. The drunks scoffed at us. Quite properly. We sat in those cells until, convinced that less dramatic and more uptodate methods were called for, we pleabargained ourselves back onto the

title: Who's Afraid of Foreign TakeOvers?
description: Foreign takeovers in key industries have become an increasingly sensitive issue in the United States. The Iranian Government has negotiated a complex stock and loan agreement with Pan American World Airways that is receiving Presidential attention. Possible stock deals involving the Lockheed and Grumman Corporations were discouraged by the Department of Defense. A Saudi Arabian businessman purchased control of a bank in Michigan, while a fellow countryman was frustrated in an attempt to do so in California.

title: Port Richmond Is 6665 Winner
description: Port Richmond High scored a stunning upset yesterday in openinground play of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs. The Staten Island school, which surprised Canarsie, 6665, moved into the quarterfinals, along with Lane, Taft and Lafayette.

description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 15 (AP) Senator Charles Percy said today that he would go to Iran next week to question formeri Director of Central Intelligence Richard Helms about domestic spying.

title: Frame Analysis
description: In a series of strikingly original, often brilliant books, Erving Goffman, a Canadian by birth who has taught at Chicago and Berkeley and at present occupies a chair in sociology and anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania, has exhaustively examined the petty transactions that make up everyday life. Virtually everything he writes is informed by the same impish dialectic, for he delights in making us see the most simple transactions as complex and mysterious gamelike strategies, and then in exposing the rules of the game to reduce the whole once again to a comprehensible simplicity. Not since Veblen laid bare the socioeconomic significance of walking sticks and Pekingese dogs has there been an author capable, as Goffman is, of explaining why there are mirrors facing the counters in lunchrooms, why a man mutters an oath when he stumbles over a crack in the pavement, or why loitering, the simple act of standing still on a public sidewalk, constitutes a breach of civic order.

title: Spy Ship Reported Sunk
description: SEOUL, Feb. 15 (AP)South Korean forces sank a 50ton North Korean spy boat in South Korean waters off the east coast today, the Defense Ministry said.

Even reading the information on the package seldom helps  many manufacturers claim that their product is good for bonding almost anything, and they use such descriptive phrases as allpurpose or super  strong indiscriminately on every package.

Today's announcement said that Dr. Parrott will assume his new duties Aug. 1. A committee will be set up to find a new president of Eastern Nazarene.

title: A Park That Gives Washington His Due
description: GEORGE Washington's Birthday has become a day for department store sales, the dollar is shrinking right under his etched nose, and Valley Forge is fast deteriorating into a turnpike turnoff marked by a picket line of motel billboards. But thereis a place where the Father of his Country is still honored properly, a peaceful enclave tucked into the rolling hills of Pennsylvania's Bucks County and the farms of gentleman farmers in New Jersey. It is Washington Crossing State Park, which stretches along the Delaware River on both its Pennsylvania and New Jersey banks and preserves the sites involved in what is generally recognized as the turning point of the Revolutionary War.

title: The Region
description: The Federal Government's plans to make the United States more reliant on its own energy resources received a momentary setback at regional hearings last week: Offshore oil drilling was attacked verbally and legally. Nonetheless, drilling off the MidAtlantic coastline seems almost Inevitable.

title: Stronger Congress?
description: A weakened Presidency does not necessarily mean a correspondingly stronger Congress. The House and Senate with their substantial Democratic majorities are now being urged by their constituencies to provide constructive alternatives to the Ford Administration policies. But, like a man who has just had a cast removed from his broken leg, Congress is sound of limb but its muscles have atrophied.

Design

However, the space was almost a railroad flat: two large roomsone measuring 24 by 22 feet at the front of the building and another 13 by 22 feet at the backwere linked by a corridor with alcoves on either side. A closetsized kitchen adjoined the back room. How does one deal with this kind of space? Mr. Easton and

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
Beautiful Ethnographic Documentaries
description: A series of three pensive, extraordinarily beautiful ethnographic documentaries by David Hancock and Herbert Di Gioia convey the rhythms and the rigors of primitive agricultural life in northern Afghanistan. (The films are part of a series produced for the American Universities Field Staff, concerning the effect of modernization on the lives of country dwellers.) Clearly, the film makers put their subjects at ease; one senses a rapport between these rural people and the camera. The program appears today and Thursday through next Sunday at the Film Forum, 256 West 88th Streets

title: Revenues at Record
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) Amtrak reported today that it carried more passengers and had higher earned revenues in 1974 than during any year since its founding in 1971. It was spurred especially during the more acute phases of the energy crisis when demand often exceeded our capacity, Amtrak said.

description: DUMONTWe're a purely residential town, said David Roche, Mayer of this Bergen County borough of 20.250 people. We have no industry, our work force commutes to New York City and other places in New Jersey and we're not facing any major problems. Life is good here.

He is, determined and resourceful, has a nose for news, has an editor that he has to fight tooth and nail, and he ends up dictating stories to rewrite on his own. He also has mordant sense of humor.

His last novel appeared in 1968. Since then, by all accounts, he has been hard at work on a truly big book, his magnum opus. title: Yanks Hope This Is Year
description: With the addition of Jim (Catfish) Hunter and Bobby Bonds and the subtraction of George Steinbrenner, the Yankees must be given their best chance for winning a pennant since 1964, the last year they won a pennant.

title: Notes: A Return to Chaos at Campsites?
description: THE outlook this year is bleak for people who expect to camp in the national parks and would like to know in advance if they have a campsite. As the result of a decision by the National Park Service not to renew a contract for computerized reservations, campsites in all but four of the 38 national parks and 10 national seashores have reverted to the firstcome, firstserved basis that was in effect two years ago. No change is expected before June, 1976, and it might be 1977 before a satisfactory reservations system is worked out, according to a Park Service spokesman.

title: Business Index Rises
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity rose to 390.1 from 381.3 a week earlier. A year ago it was 409.4.

title: College Schedules Triangle Author
description: PARATMUS  Charles Berlitz, author of The Bermuda Triangle, will speak at Bergen Community College on Feb. 26. The program, to be held in the library, will begin at 1:15 P.M.

title: New & Novel
description: When Robert Nathan back in the 1930's invented some people subsisting in Central Park, it was fantasy. When Evan H. Rhodes envisions a little boy surviving in Central Park in the present day, it's got to be a mystery. Even if he lives in a tree with a cute little dog, as does JayJay (for John, John), an 11yearold runaway. No matter how clever he is at breaking and entering the TavernontheGreen for rations and stealing stuff to build his house.

title: Poet Helps Turn Children's Apathy to Verse Into Delight
description: FREEPORTIn an unusual program to give children a deeper understanding of the role of poetry in their lives, a public school here had its own poetinresidence.

title: Schussing Through Dixie: : !&? ?? %#*!
description: MUSH, rocks, short slopes, fickle weather: Okay, there is something about skiing in Dixie that resonates of dancing bears and talking dogs. But it exists, for the wonderment of visitors from other climes, and the bedevilment of a stubborn band of hardy locals.

title: Role of Psychiatric Institute Is Debated
A. & P. GUARD FOILS A $12,000 ROBBERY
description: A security guard for A. & P. Stores foiled a robbery of about $12,000 by two armed men outside a bank in Brooklyn! yesterday by wounding one of the men and struggling with the other until the police arrived.

title: ART VIEW
description: The Biennial (formerly Annual) exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art is the closest thing we have to the official Salon exhibition of the last century: a survey of what established taste currently deems admirable and permissible in the creation of new art. Such exhibitions are, by their very nature, unsatisfactory. They are obliged to serve too many interests. They lack exacting standards. They aspire to a disinterested representativeness that is always specious. They are, fundamentally, committee enterprises, and they look it. No single sentient intelligence could possibly embrace with equal favor all that such exhibitions dump on the public Consciousness without standing accused of a fatal ineapacity for making the most elementary discriminations.

title: Wages Drop as the Jobless Invade Citrus Groves
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) Unemployed workers desperate for jobs at any price are pouring into Florida's citrus groves by the thousands, creating the largest harvesttime labor surplus here in 25 years, officials say.

title: Prices of Food On Rise in Nassau
description: MINEOLAThe cost of a family's market basket of basic foods hit a new high of $57.06 in February, according to the monthly price survey of 16 Nassau County supermarkets conducted by the Nassau County Office of Consumer Affairs.

title: Miss LeFevre Bride Of Gary Van Vlandren
description: Jeanne C. LeFevre, daughter of Ada Marie LeFevre of Greenwich, Conn., and William M. LeFevre of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Gary Van Vlandren, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Van Vlandren of Naugatuck, Conn.

title: Glow Over Debt Collection
description: If ever there was a bogeyman in the business world of yesteryear, it was the debt collector. Traditionally, he was thought to have the generosity of Scrooge, the kindness of Iago and the compassion of Robespierre.

title: Gentleman Jimmy Walker
description: When speech time rolls around in politicsit's one of the nation's longest seasonsthe orator usually gets around to braying that soandso's name will live forever in the hearts of his countrymen. It's an upbeat thought, but when it comes to mayors of New York City, state governors and Federal Vice Presidents, the name of the man, unless he's moved on to something else, usually recedes with stunning swiftness from the public consciousness.

title: TEACHERS DECLARE DELAWARE STRIKE
description: DOVER, Del., Feb. 15A statewide teachers strike, illegal in Delaware, was called here today after legislation that would have increased teachers pay was vetoed earlier this week by Gov. Sherman Tribbitt.

title: Nuclear Sub Due Overhaul
description: KITTERY, Me., Feb. 15 (AP) The Polaris submarine Henry Clay will be overhauled at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard beginning in April, the Navy says. Work on the submarine is expected to take 18 months, a Navy spokesman said Wednesday, and cost more than $50 million.

title: Canadiens Win
TransitHub Plan for Belmont Doubtful
description: Nassau County officials say they intend to push ahead with plans for an unusual transportation hub for commuters at Belmont Park raceway despite an unexpected demurrer on the project from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: 4 Goals by. Polls Pace 92 Victory Over Stars
Lloyds Living Tradition
description: LONDONFew institutions evoke such feelings of confidence and security as Lloyds of London, perhaps the world's most unusual insurance organization and certainly one of the most prominent members of the British financial community.

title: Kidnapping Victim Found
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 15 (UPI)A man who was kidnapped by bank robbers three days ago was found beaten but alive yesterday in a vacant shack. The police said today that Don Lowery, 24 years Old, was suffering from a beating, a gunshot wound and exposure and could not remember details of his past 48 hours.

title: KEY COSTA RICANS PROTECTING VESCO
description: SAN JOSE, Costa RicaDespite growing public demands for his expulsion, Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier, remains ensconced here, thanks to the continued friendship and protection of the Costa Rican Government.

title: Greeks Jail U.S. Sailor
description: ATHENS, Feb. 15 (Reuters)An Athens criminal court today sentenced a sailor of the United States Sixth Fleet to 11 years and six months imprisonment on charges of attempted homicide. Seaman Charles Mills Davis, 20 from Florida, was accused of stabbing a taxi driver with a knife last September.

title: THE ECONOMISTS ARE CONFUSED, TOO
description: A bevy of economists and social thinkers got together here yesterday at a conference on full employment, and one of the few things that emerged was that there is no more agreement in academe on what ought to be done than there is in government.

title: Sheepmen Ask Disaster Aid
description: GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 15 (UPI) Colorado sheepmen want the state to be declared a disaster area because of damage by coyotes. State officials say there is nothing they can do about it. An official of a wool group said that killing of sheep by coyotes had increased because of Federal action preventing the poisoning of coyotes.

title: Editors Choice
description: BEFORE MY TIME, by Maureen Howard. (Little. Brown. $6.95.) Quotidian lives of two interrelated IrishAmerican families, one welltodo, the other poor, by a writer with a talent for graphing the aimless fever chart of events. FAITH AND THE GOOD THING, by Charles Johnson. (Viking, $7.95.) An ebullient novel in the form of a folktalecumblackgirl'sodyssey.

title: Penn Pins 10381 Loss On Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 15 (AP)  Penn, led by its big front three of Henry Johnson, Ron Haigler and Bob Bigelow, pulled away with a 65point second half tonight and defeated Harvard, 10381 in an Ivy League basketball game.

title: 40 Nursing Homes Face Miami Inquiry; 2 Linked to Bergman
Plant Fruit Trees Early
description: Early spring is an ideal time to plant fruit trees. The yearlings will be dormant and will have time to establish roots before growth begins. These trees need an open sunny site where the ground drains well. Dwarf trees are recommended for home gardens as they do not require the greater space of fullsized trees and they are easier to care for. These trees are grown by nurseries where the fruiting variety is grafted on a dwarfing rootstock which controls the size. The fruit produced is normal size and the harvests are generous. Apples, pears, plums and sweet cherries are not selffertile and two different varieties of each fruit must be planted for crosspollination. Peaches are selffertile. The local office of Cooperative Extension can supply lists of recommended fruit varieties for the area. Grafted trees are available from many mailorder nurseries and from some quality local garden centers. Buyers should select oneyearold whips or twoyearold branched trees because they are easier to transplant and easier to prune.

title: Outsiders in the Board Room
description: Serving as a director of a major corporation is losing some of its glamour these days, and many of them are asking whether it's worth it.

title: Those Attic Wasps
description: Wasps begin to appear in country houses about now, and even in some suburban houses. One sees them dart uncertainly about, hears them buzz and bang on window panes, and one wonders where they came from. They probably came from the attic, where they spent the early part of the winter hibernating. Now, with longer hours of daylight, the wasps begin to rouse and start exploring.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: ROBERT CORAM is a freelance writer who lives on St. Simons Island, Ga.

title: Doctor Guilty in Death Of a Fetus in Abortion
description: BOSTON, Feb. 15Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin was found guilty today of manslaughter in the death of a male fetus after a legal abortion that he performed at the Boston City Hospital on Oct. 3, 1973.

title: Stones. Sets High Jump Mark: 75
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 15 (AP)Dwight Stones broke his world indoor record in the high jump with a leap of 7 feet 5 inches tonight in the United States Track and Field Federation's national indoor championship meet.

title: Ann Beth Goldenberg Is Engaged
Judith Ann Kidera to Be Married To Daniel S. Odell in Summer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Kidera of Fairfield, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Judith Ann Kidera of Albany, to Daniel Sherman Odell, son of Dr. Daniel W. Odell Jr., of Altamont, N. Y., and Mrs. Beth Odell of Guilderland, N. Y. A wedding in the summer is planned.

title: Chester Gets Land for a Park
description: CHESTER  One family's concern for vanishing open space has led to the preservation of more than 120 acres of land In two adjoining Morris County communities.

title: Homes Will Rise On Old Orchards
Independent Voice
description: For decades the Voice of America has struggled to attain a clear sense of mission and of corporate identity. Founded at the beginning of the cold war with the Soviet Union, it has labored under a misleading motto, telling America's story to the world. That motto invites interference by White House and State Department policymakers who, in every Administration, are naturally eager to see to it that America's story coincides with their current policy line.

title: Wood, Field and Stream, Cornell Plans A Project to Release Peregrine Falcons
description: Now that Cornell researchers have completed their second successful season of breeding peregrine falcons in captivity, plans are being made for release of these birds in selected areas across the country, says Dr. Tom Cade of the New York State College of Agriculture and Life Sciences at the university.

title: Miss Blount Plans Bridal
description: Winton Malcolm Blount, former Postmaster General of the United States, and Mrs. Blount of Montgomery, Ala, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Blount, to James Verner Miles 3d of Vail, Colo., son of Dr. and Mrs. James Miles Jr. of Fargo, N. D.

title: Sunday Observer
N. Hempstead Curbs FastFood Outlets
description: Fastfood chains such as Burger King, McDonald's, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Wetson's will be limited in the number of establishments they build within the town of North Hempstead under a new zoning ordinance.

title: BRAZILIAN STATE PINS HOPE ON CARS
description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil This old mining state of Minas Gerais is counting heavily on new automobile Industry to bring it an industrial boom, world recession notwithstanding.

title: ILLNESSES CLOUD COURT OPERATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The hospitalization of Justice Thurgood Marshall for pneumonia has raised a further cloud of uncertainty around the operation of the Supreme Court during the remaining months of its 197475 term.

title: Lower East Siders Adopt A Pocket Alarm System
description: About 50 Lower East Side residents stood by yesterday morning and watched as two young men mugged grayhaired Helen. Nlichaele on the corner of East Third Street and Avenue A.

title: TV VIEW
description: The F.C.C. commissioner, deceptively projecting the image of a meek, smalltown clerk out of a painting by Norman Rockwell, spoke about the need for appropriateness and good taste in television. The big studio executive, noting that all three networks say they intend to devote the daily 8to9 P.M. hour to family programing, complained that all of this smacks very strongly of censorship to me. And the network official in charge of broadcast standards insisted that it is not our job to be a censorour job is to go forward.

title: Iran and Oman Combat Oil Spills in Gulf
Erosion Need Not Be Fatal
description: Senator Charles Percy of Illinois recently came home from the Middle East to say that Israel should no longer count on automatic American support for any policy she might choose. This week Representative John Rhodes of Arizona said that as a matter of justice, Americans should be better acquainted with the position of the Arab nations in their controversy with Israel.

title: The Theater: Bertolt Brecht's Mother Courage
Dormitory Ruling Is Upset
description: An unusual dispute has resuited in a court decision to prevent the children of married students from living in dormitories at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: Goldin to Seek to Delay TainyDay Fund Money
description: In a separate report on the city's fiscal picture, Controller Harrison J. Goldin cautioned yesterday that although Mayor Beame could get state legislation, he intends to see kto postpone a $93.3million payment due the DainyDay Fund next year, suc ha move might jeopardize the city's credit ratings.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: A remarkable breakthrough has come in petunias this year. Champagne, a tawny white with yellow throat has proved it an perform well during heat and humidity of summer, when botrytis knocks out many petunias. This new variety is a single grandiflora with compact habit, and highly praised for its tolerance of the botrytis problem.

title: Marriage Planned By Catherine Paulo
description: Judge Frank D. Paulo, Surrogate of Richmond County, and Mrs. Paulo of Grasmere, S.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Maria Paulo, to Stephen Jeffery Brown. He is the son of Mrs. A. H. Brown of Melbourne, Australia, and the late Mr. Brown.

title: ATOM DEVICE USED FOR SOVIET CANAL
A NearUniversal No on the President's Energy Plan
The Insiders' Lament
description: In nominating Carla Anderson Hills as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, President Ford has predictably aroused the opposition of a housing establishment that sees its interests threatened by anyone from outside its selfprotective circle. The insiders are apprehensive about any fresh, uninhibited scrutiny of their own airless closet of timeworn ideas.

title: Brooklyn Schools Seek Aid
People/Business
description: In 1937, when Edward J. Simmons joined Triangle Industries, Inc., a Holmdelbased company whose 1974 sales were estimated at a record $265million, his salary as a stenographer was $18 a week.

title: 14 Bus Lines Fear Shutdown
description: TRENTON  At least 14 New Jersey bus lines carrying an estimated 50,000 riders a day may shut down in two weeks if the Legislature does not authorize new funds to continue subsidizing masstransit operations.

title: Discrimination in Reverse
description: OAKLAND, Calif. Feb. 15 (UPI)A judge has ordered the City of Berkeley to promote eight white firemen who were passed over in favor of minority race candidates. Judge Lyle Cook of Alameda County Superior Court ruled that ignoring competitive examinations to hire and promote minority persons violates the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment to the United States.Constitution, the Berkeley Charter and the Federal Civil Rights Act.

title: Winners Selected In Energy Contest
description: TRENTON  A Secaucus junior high school student and a fourthgrade pupil from Warren have won top awards in two state energy contests.

title: CORRECTION
description: The performance of Mary Lou Williams's Mass, referred to in last week's article Mary Lou Takes Her Jazz Mass to Church, by John S. Wilson, will take place in St. Patrick's Cathedral Tuesday, Feb. 18, at 2 P.M.

title: Bill May Define Civic Groups
description: A bipartisan legislative effort is under way in Albany to write standards that would define representative civic associations in what is believed to be the first effort in the state to set such legislative criteria.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONThe onagain, affagain decision of the State Senate's Democratic majority to open its closed caucuses to the public and the press was off again last week.

title: DONORS CONTINUE TO AID NEEDIEST
description: The 63d annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which has two weeks to go to its official conclusion March 1, has collected $1;033,026.30 since the drive opened Dec. 9. This was little more than $25,000 below the record sum received by the Fund in the 197273 drive.

title: Indoor Flea Marts Gain in Popularity
40 Freed as Seoul Begins Release of Park's Foes
description: SEOUL, South Korea. Feb. 15 (Reuters)About 40 persons, including the wellknown dissident poet Kim Chi Ha, were freed from prison tonight after President Park Chung Hee announced he was releasing most of the 203 persons jailed last year for antiGovernment activities.

title: New York's GoGo Art Market Has GoneGone
description: Announcing Our First Annual January Art Sale!!! So ran the advertisement a few weeks ago for the Wally Findlay galleries, a 57th Street showplace for highpriced art which caters to popular tastes. Prices of paintings were slashed from 10 to 60 ner cent. An oil by Jean Dufy(not to be confused with the more acclaimed Raoul Duty) whibh formerly sold for $10,500 was marked down to $9,925; two Leger gouaches were reduced from $20,900 and $15,400 to $16,720 and $11,550 respectively; and a $75,000 Utrillo could be had for $60,000.

title: Full of bad paintings
description: Two centuries isn't much time to build up an esthetic tradition, especially for a country with a strong bias against art and a prurient attitude toward the human body. Religion here began as a matter of words, of original sin and the Ten Commandments, not images: naked Christs on the Cross never took root in American consciousness. It was the noble savage, the naked Indianthe people we were seeking to displacewho constituted the first genuine American subject matter. The Indian as captive or war rior, history painting, and American portraiture (fullfaced views of ministers, generals, statesmen and their wives) were the professional artist's mainstays. The backdoor discovery of the European nude, especially of the works of Titian, early in the 19th century, was something of an esthetic disaster that took us almost 75 years to get over.

title: Argentina Goes to Bat For World Cup Plans
description: Argentine delegates last week convinced the International Federation, the world governing body of soccer, that Argentina was in a position to stage the next Wold Cup in 1978 as originally planned. The of delegation, howSoccer ever, ran into strong European opposition with its plan to increase the number of participating countries from 16 to 20.

title: but One Is Not There
description: It all started when a photographer was sent to take pictures of the champion trees in Brooklyn. The Botanic Garden could not find the garden plum that was supposed to be there.

description: ALBANYSixteen trees in Brooklyn and Long Island have been certified as national champions in the American Forestry Association's register of the biggest trees in the country.

title: Schools Unit Bars Book But Agrees Not to Burn Copies
description: BUTLER, Pa., Feb. 15The Butler District School Board has voted to remove from tenthgrade class a collection of short stories including Battle Royal by Ralph Ellison, a black author.

title: Busing Teachers
description: For the teacher who would like to travel this summer and be paid for itdriving a bus for Greyhound might be just what you're looking for.

title: Gallup Survey Finds 5% Drop In Use of Cars to Get to Work
description: The automobile long a mainstay of the American way of life, is becoming a less essential item in the minds of many Americans, the Gallup Poll reports.

title: Skiers Find Bargain at $7 a Day, But It May Get a Little Crowded
description: JACKSON, N.H.All you can eat for breakfast, plus a bed, is a $7aday bargain that brings many people to Abbotts Ski Lodge on weekends. When the slopes at nearby major ski resorts as Wildcat, Attitash, Black, Cranmore and Tyrol are well covered with snow, getting a late reservation at Abbotts is as difficult as getting a lift ticket for nothing.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's special halffare program will be in effect on subways, buses and commuter railroads tomorrow, the day Washington's Birthday is observed this year. Saturday schedules will be followed by the Long Island Rail Road, the city's subway and bus systems, the Staten Island Rapid Transit line and the Nassau County buses operated by the Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority. The Harlem, Hudson and New Haven commuter trains will operate on holiday schedules.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 15 (AP)Anton Stipancic of Yugoslavia and Istvan Jonyer of Hungary defeated Japanese opponents and gained the final of the biennial world table tennis championships tonight. Stipancic beat Norio Takashima, 2110, 216, 2023, 1921, 2113, in a match interrupted for an hour by a torrential rain that leaked through the roof of the new Netaji Indoor Stadium. Earlier, Jonyer breezed past Mitsuru Kohno, 2113, 2115, 2523.

title: Sarah Percy Triumphs By 2 Lengths at Bowie
Frederick Manfredparallels with Homer
description: After 19 published novels Frederick Manfred remains comparatively little known outside his native West. Many readers, presuming on the slightest kind of acquaintance with his work, would have him to be a writer of mere Westerns. Others not much better acquainted seem to regard him as a sort of rude romantic giant who, while glancing over his shoulder at Homer's example, hacks out his heroic fiction with a blunt instrument.

title: TRAVEL IN WINTER UP DESPITE SLUMP
description: In the Rocky Mountain City of Grand Junction, Colo., more than 1,600 skiers recently piled out of 24 United Airlines jets on a single day.

title: PriceList Inaction Scored

title: F.B.I OFFICE HERE GETTING NEW HEAD
description: J. Wallace LaPrade, the 48 yearold assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who will be taking charge of the agency's New York regional office next month, is a slighty built lawman who believes in democratic office management and who, in 23 years as a Federal agent, has never fired his gun while making an arrest.

title: CAREY TO DECIDE ON SAFETY CODES
description: ALBANY, Feb 15Governor Cary is expected to decide next week whether to go forward with a state plan for job safety or to abandon the state's threeyearold plan and leave the field to the Federal Government.

description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15  Seventeen illegal aliens who would normally have been forced to leave the country upon their apprehension have gained a reprieve through the intervention of a labor union.

Landlords Pressing For Tenant Meters
description: Landlordssome of them, anyway are moving to convert their buildings from master metering, under which the owner pays the electric bill, to direct metering, under which each tenant is billed by the utility. If the action is successful, the practice of including electricity costs in the rent may be rewired out of existence in the city.

description: OTTAWA, Feb. 15Canadian police officials, members of Parliament and a number of citizen's groups have joined a nationwide movement urging the restoration of the death penalty for murder after an outbreak of killings in recent weeks.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Increased institutional activity enabled the prices on the New York Stock Exchange to register another advance last week in continued heavy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week ahead 22.29 points at 734.20.

title: Oil: The Bright Side
description: KHARTOUM  These days any Middle Eastern journey concentrates the mind powerfully on one word, oil. Never before has a single raw material so affected the international balance. Not even the possession of iron in ancient times nor the immense influence of South American gold on European power politics were remotely comparable.

title: A Court of Appeals Decision on Prior Restraint
description: A court decision that has not yet had much attention is regarded by some lawyers as among the most significant ever made in the First Amendment area. The decision was handed down nine days ago, in Richmond, Va., by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Unless the Supreme Court rules otherwise, the, effect will be to give the United States something approaching the much criticized British Official Secrets Aet.

STAMPS
description: Great Britain is putting out this Wednesday a set of four commemoratives to mark the 200th anniversary of the birth of Joseph MaHord William Turner, regarded widely as England's greatest painter.

title: Cardiology College Elects

Other new officers of the organization, which held its 24th annual meeting here, include Dr. Warren J. Taylor of Winchester, Mass., presidentelect; Dr. Dean T. Mason of Davis, Calif., vice president, and Dr. Robert J. Hall of Houston, secretary.

title: Irish Show Solid Hockey Line Despite Losing Record of Team
description: Somehow, Notre Dame seems like an alien atmosphere for college hockey_ Oh, it's cold enough in South Bend, Ind., but the football and basketball traditions are so rich and overwhelming that hockey is at best tolerated, and sometimes ignored. One problem over the last two seasons has simply been too many losses and, as an institution. Notre Dame has never tolerated losing. But amid this sea of indifference exists one superb jewelthe Irish forward line of Brian Walsh, center; Clark Hamilton, left wing; Alex Pirus, right wing.

description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 15To skycap at the St. Louis international Airport, striking workers at the nearby McDonnell Douglas Corporation have a lot of guts to go out at a time like this.

title: Clean Gasoline
description: Unleaded gasoline may not be all that it's cracked up to be for limiting pollution.

title: Judge Rules Dogs That Detect Drugs May Invade Privacy
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 (UPI) A Federal judge has ruled that the United States Customs Bureau's drugsniffing dogs can be too efficient, detecting narcotics so unerringly that they constitute an illegal invasion of privacy.

title: BlackPower Movement Fosters A Nationalist Party in Trinidad
An Angry Young Man
description: Dwight Stones can jump higher than any other mortal living or dead, indoors or out, except in Madison Square Garden lip to this weekend he had won his event with comparative ease in eight track meets this winter in places like Pocatello, Idaho. Albuquerque, N.M., San Francisco; Portland, Ore.; San Diego and Louisville but in New York he lost to a Harvard man. A New York official bugged him by pulling a stop watch on him. He'll never forget the stuffed shirt in Stockholm who insisted that he wear his number while competing even if it got in his way. He burned after one of the best jumps in his life when the waxworks in Los Angeles remeasured and said no, the bar wasn't as high as he thought it was. At University of California, Los Angeles he got sore at his coach and quit school.

title: They changed rock, which changed the culture, which changed us
description: They have not performed together on stage for more than eight years. They have not made a record together in five years. The formal dissolution of their partnership in a London courtroom last month was an echo of an ending that came long ago. Now each of them is seeking to overcome the shadow of a past in which they were bound together by wealth, fame and adulation of an intensity unequaled in our culture. George Harrison scorns talk of reunion, telling us to stop living in the past. John Lennon told us years ago that the dream is over.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION declined 3.6 per cent in January, the largest monthly drop since December, 1937  The Wholesale Price Index declined threetenths of 1 per cent for the month while retail sales rose I per cent; both figures seasonally adjusted  Sales of new automobiles in the first 10 days of February were 5.1 per cent lower than last year's comparable level.

title: Jesuit Congress Reconfirms Arrupe as Order's Leader
description: ROME, Feb. 15The general congregation of the Society of Jesusa gathering of more than 200 representatives of the Roman Catholic Church's largest religious order today reconfirmed the Very Rev. Pedro Arrupe as the order's Superior General.

description: Eight municipal hospitals have been marked for possible closing or conversion to other healthrelated uses in a confidential study prepared for the board of directors of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: FORD URGED TO ACT IN BOSTON DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The United States Commission on Civil Rights, in a letter signed by all six members, has strongly urged President Ford to take firmer action in the Boston school dispute.

description: ART

title: A State Report Urges Esthetic Standards to Curb Visual Blight
