description: MIAMI, Feb. 15Lazy F. Ranch's Forego was America's Horse of the Year in 1974 and if he manages to stay sound he is oddson to attain that honor again this year. Not even an impost of 131 pounds could stop him today as he came from last place to win the $124,700 Widener Handicap at Hialeah for the second straight time.

title: Reservoir Plan Allows Owners to Keep Homes for 25 Years
Weakened Presidency
description: As the nation struggles to master its severe economic problems, its political institutions shift and strain accommodate the stress of change. The central fact today's politics is that President Ford is in the White House only because the elected President and VicePresident were driven from office for criminal misconduct.

title: Woman to Umpire In Dodger Game
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 (AP)ctristine Wren, a 26 yearold woman who aspires to be a baseball umpire, will be behind the plate tomorrow when the Los Angeles Dodgers and University of Southern California play a fiveinning exhibition baseball game.

title: FM ASKS 76 AID OF CONSERVATIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 President Ford says he needs responsible conservative backing to be elected in 1976 and believes the formation of a third political party on the right would probably defeat the real objectives of a conservative movement.

title: Boycotts by Italian Leftists Cut Into Vote in StudentParliament Elections
description: ROME Feb 15Elections for newly established student parliaments were held throughout Italy this week, and with ultraleftist groups boycotting them the turnout in most universities and colleges was low.

title: Ellen Lee Granruth Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Ellen Lee Granruth to Duncan Keith Mackay has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Walter Granuth Jr. of Baltimore and Stone Harbor, N. J., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Alexander Duff Mackay of Washington.

title: Philadelphia Can Combine To Dump Sludge in Atlantic
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (AP)The city of Philadelphia has received Federal approval to continue dumping millions of gallons of sewage sludge in the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Ocean City, Md.

description: Mutsuko Takavama, a secretary in the Tokyo office of Alitaha Airlines, plans to be married in June in Pittsburgh to Robert Stuart Mcllroy, a lawyer in the Tokyo office of the Coudert Brothers law firm.

title: Sharon Kay Ritchie Is Wed to Robert M. Fomon
description: Sharon Kay Ritchie of Greenwich. Conn. Miss America of 1936, was married yesterday morning, to Robert M. Fomon of New York, president and chief executive officer of the E. F. Hutton Group. Inc. holding company for E. F. Hutton & Co. Inc. stockbrokers. The ceremony in the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwhich was performed by the Rev. Donald Ostroth assisted by the Rev. Arnold C. Miller.

title: Mildred Thompson, Historian, Vassar Dean Emeritus, Is Dead
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 16 (AP)Dr. C. Mildred Thompson, dean emeritus of Vassar College and historian, died today. She was 93 years old.

title: Peace Award for Kennedy
description: BOSTON, Feb. 15 (UPI)The World Affairs Council of Boston has announced that Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, would be this year's recipient of the Christian A. Herter Medal, in recognition of his efforts to bring about peace.

title: PENNSY MAY SELL SPARE EQUIPMENT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (UPI)Penn Central Transportation trustees have asked the Federal District Court here for approval of a plan to sell unused equipment to the Federal Government if Congress fails to provide the line with emergency funding.

description: BELO HORIZONTE, BrazilBrazil is a land of space and opportunity for the Japanese, says Toshiharu Ogawa, a 33 yearold economist.

title: SPEEDERS ON COAST GET POLICE ESCORT
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16A branch of the California Highway Patrol is experimenting with a plan it hopes will curb the steady increase in drivers who exceed the 55 mileanhour speed limit.

title: Many Jobless in French City but Few Worry
description: MAUBEUGE, FranceSeen from Paris, 140 miles southwest of here, Maubeuge is a bad joke, a nondescript industrial town whose reputation for gray ugliness made a song called Moonlight Over Maubeuge a national hit a decade or so ago for the irony of attaching a romantic image to so grim a town.

title: Cocker Spaniel Best at Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 16A buffcolored cocker spaniel, Ch. Westphal's Limelight, followed in his mother's footsteps today and won best in show at the First Company Governor's Footguard Athletic Association dog show.

title: Study Shows Birth Control Pill Alone Can Increase the Chance of a Stroke
description: A followup study of strokes among young women has shown that use of the birth control pill by itself can increase a woman's chances of having a stroke. The study showed that this increased risk was present even in the absence of other risk factors that have been associated with stroke, including high blood pressure, migraine headaches and heavy cigarette smoking.

title: A Visit by Vorster to Liberia For Secret Talks Is Reported
description: LONDON, Monday, Feb. 17The Times of London reported today that Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa had paid a secret visit to Liberia last week and had told the Liberian President, William R. Tolbert Jr., South Africa would be glad to give up the administration of SouthWest Africa.

title: Bullets Trounce Knicks, 125104
Recession Fails to Faze Austin Street
description: Merchants throughout the city may be crying the recession blues, but not on Austin Street in Forest Hills, Queens, where if business is not all that good, at least it is not all that bad.

title: NADJARI STOPPED ON COMPUTER PLAN
description: A plan by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, for computerized monitoring of 6,000 felony cases as a device to spot judicial corruption has been jeopardized by a state decision forbidding him to use $100,000 instate funds for the project.

title: F.B.I. AIDE CONFIRMS USE OF INFORMANTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) Informants paid by the Federal Bureau of Investigation often travel abroad voluntarily to keep watch on organizations that have activities extending beyond the borders of the United States, a bureau spokesman says.

title: Books of The Times
description: Histories of cultural institutions are with few exceptions weighted down with such wooden prose and leaden thinking that one would imagine they were written by foundation executives. No one who valued his time would think of reading them. When they happen to be capably researched, of course, they deserve a space on the reference shelf alongside your variorum edition of Vanity Fair and the collected works of Anatole France. But read a cultural history? Come, now.

title: Bonn Weighs Turkey Aid By CRAIG R. WHITNEY
description: BONN, Feb. 16West German officials said after Secretary of State Kissinger's talks in Bonn today that the Government was considering the resumption of arms aid to Turkey, but not under American pressure.

description: Janice Clare Griffith, general counsel to the New York City Housing and Development Administration, was married yesterday to Richard Stanley Perles, a lawyer with Windels & Marx. The Rev. Allen Clark performed the ceremony in the Congregational Church in Union, N.H.

title: STUDY OF 3D PARTY FOR '76 APPROVED BY CONSERVATIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Arguing that a growing number of independent voters reject both major parties, participants in a conservative conference voted today to establish a 13member committee to study the possibilities of a third party for the Presidential campaign in 1976.

Union leaders recommended approval of the plan, put forth by a Federal mediator as a way to break the deadlock in the 62day strike by 800 drivers.

title: Eleven Who Didn't Vote for Ruth
description: Fred Lindstrom, Jimmy Dykes, Travis Jackson, Joe Gordon, Johnny Vander Meernot many days pass, espedaily at this season, without letters explaining why this worthy character or that one should be stuffed and mounted for the Baseball Hall of Fame. It has been remarked here in the past that there were two schools thought regarding admission to the little brick house in Cooperstown, N.Y., and that peace would come to Israel and the Arnbs before these conflicting views were reconcited; even if Henry Kissinger were the baseball commissioner. To some, the absence of Pete Reiser, John Mize and Terry Moore from the shrine proves the incompetence of the electorate; to others, the presence of Joe Tinker and. Lefty Gomez confirms it. Well, a few of us are. privileged to receive from time to time. communications from an authority who signs. himself Landis and appears to have access to information not readily available to people. Recently he forwarded a complete breakdown of voting in the first Hall. of Fame election of players of the 20th century. It reveals a great deal about how members of the Baseball Writers Association 40 years ago regarded players of their time and the recent past.

title: Share the Work
description: A panel of economists has, in effect, given the Washington chapter of the National Organization of Women some sound advice: Where two valid principles clash, it is betteras far as possibleto preserve them both than to champion one at the total expense of the other. One of the principles is the right of workers to enjoy a security in their jobs commensurate with their seniority. The other is to keep equal opportunity from being eroded by the formula of lasthired, firstfired.

title: About New York
description: Today is Washington's birthday, and as usual in New York it is a day when the department stores have sales, the schools and banks close, and many citizens look to either the end or the beginning of a long weekend. Washington's birthday no longer has much to do with our first President at all. Actually, New York was never a good town for him, anyway.

title: Rangers Gain 55 Tie With Leafs,. Park Hurt
description: Home ice offered little solace for the upanddown Rangers last night. Not only did they have to come from behind four times to tie the Toronto Maple Leafs, 55, but they lost Brad Park. their captain and allstar defenseman, for what might be two weeks with a strained left knee.

title: Paris: At Opera, Display Still Counts as Much as Play
description: PARISVictor Hugo called it a worldly reply to Notre Dame. Claude Debussy wrote that it reminded him of a railroad station outside and of a Turkish bath inside. To us, it stands as the very symbol of the bourgeoisie at the hour of its greatest triumph: under Napoleon III. It? The Paris Opera, of course, which was inaugurated exactly a hundred years ago and which is currently celebrating this anniversary with a most amusing and revealing exhibition devoted to its builder, Charles Ganier.

title: Eyes On Rockefeller

He has an apparently easy relationship with a President not susceptible to jealousy. One of his longtime aides is to direct the Domestic Council, giving him something of an operational base. And with the exception of one clumsy venture on Vietnam, he has avoided the potholes of public controversy.

description: An attempt by 11 inmates, including some alleged members of the black Liberation Army, to escape from a maximumsecurity ceilblock on Rikers Island was thwarted last night when Correction Department guards overpowered a detainee who had thrust a pointed stick into an officer's back and seized celiblock keys from him.

title: The Cycle
description: First the good news; Inflation is slowing. The wholesale price index dropped by threetenths of 1 per cent in Januaryfollowing a halfpercent decline in December. Interest rates are also coming down.

title: MOSS TO CONFRONT BERGMAN AT HEARING
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 16 (AP)  Senator Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, says his subcommittee on longterm care will confront Bernard Bergman, New York nursinghome proprietor, with facts he will have a hard time explaining if he appears before the subcommittee on Wednesday.

title: Damaged Oil Tanker Emptied
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Feb. 16 (AP)  Barges took the last lof the 130,000barrel cargo of diesel oil from the stormdamaged tanker Athenian Star today. The tanker, which had been ordered anchored two miles outside Portsmouth Harbor since Feb. 8, lost several thousand barrels of oil, but the Coast Guard said most of it had been jettisoned far out to sea.

title: Lowell Thomas's Wife Dies
description: PAWLING, N.Y., Feb. 16 (UPI)Frances Ryan Thomas, traveler, hostess and wife of the broadcaster and writer Lowell Thomas, died today at the couple's estate here. She was 81 years old. Her husband and a son, Lowell Jr., Lieutenant Governor of Alaska, survive.

title: STUDY OF 3D PARTY FOR 76 APPROVED BY CONSERVATIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16Arguing that a growing number of independent voters reject both major parties, participants in a conservative conference voted today to establish a 13member committee to study the possibilities of a third party for the Presidential campaign in 1976.

title: More U.S. Tax Returns Are Being Filed Early
description: NEWARK, Feb. 16 (UPI)The Internal Revenue Service says New Jersey residents are submitting their incometax returns earlier this year and receiving larger refunds.

title: U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh Recommends Limited Evacuation
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia. Feb. 16One of Phnom Penh's hallmarks has been its ability to withstand apocalyptic predictions of its imminent collapse.

title: Music: In Twelve Parts
description: When Philip Glass, the composer, first presented his Music in Twelve Parts last June at Town Hall, he did it in a sixhour marathon. It was an impressive, even overwhelming event, but by necessity it didn't allow one much opportunity to dwell on the individual parts.

title: Heavy Case Load Hinders P.S.C.'s Control of Rates
description: Inflation and the energy crisis have combined to create a record case load that is hampering the ability of the State Public Service Commission to control rates charged by New York's public utilities.

title: 51,000 See U.S.C. Top Dodgers, 20
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 (UPI)  George Milke, Pete Redfern and Jeff Reinke held the Los Angeles Dodgers hitless for five innings today as University of Southern California scored a 20 victory before an admissionfree crowd of 51,000 fans at Dodger Stadium. Milke and Redfern each pitched two innings for the National Collegiate champions in the fiveinning exhibition.

title: Grand Central Listed As U.S. Historic Place
description: Grand Central Terminal, whose landmark designation by the city was invalidated last month by a State Supreme Court justice, has been listed in the National Register of Historic Places, a citation that amounts to Federal landmark status.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The legislative commission created to investigate New Jersey's nursing homes will expand its inquiry to include treatment of the elderly housed in boarding homes and the state's mental institutions. We are concerned with the whole spectrum of extended health care for the elderly, no matter what kind of institution or facility they live in, Senator John J. Fay, Democrat of Middlesex, the commission chairman, disclosed.

title: Communist Leader Warns That Italy Needs Party's Help
description: PERUGIA, Italy, Feb. 16Italy's Communist party leader Enrico Berlinguer, said today that the nation's need for the party's contribution in government has increased as the economic crisis has deepened.

title: SPAIN SAFEGUARDS AFRICAN ENCLAVES
description: MADRID, Feb. 16Spain intends to speed up development of her North African enclaves of Ceuta and Melilla in a clear demonstration of resistance to Morocco's claims to them.

title: RoundtheClock M.D.'s
description: Unionized internes and residents in the city's voluntary hospitals are being polled on whether to strike protest against work schedules that sometimes require them to put in 100 hours of duty a week, including on occasions 50 hours or more without a break.

title: Oil From the Shelf
description: A sudden aboutface by Secretary of the Interior Morton means that the oil companies will have to wait a bit longer before staking claims on the Outer Continental Shelf. It does not mean, as some industry spokesmen would have the public believe, that in the face of a critical energy shortage and an economic slump, the country is being asked to endure interminable and needless delays in obtaining oil supplies that would relieve those situations.

title: In Memoriam
description: STERNSara trousseau. Passed away Februerr 17, 1970. She still lives on earth in the good deeds she performed and in the hearts of all who loved her.

title: Miss Bauer Bride Of Michael Meyer
description: Roberta L. Bauer and Michael J. Meyer, Cornell University graduates, were married yesterday afternoon at Temple Sholom in Roslyn Heights, L. I., by Rabbi Joseph Sternstein.

title: Ethiopians in March for National Unity
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 16Thousands of Ethioplansincluding many Eritrean Moslemsparaded through the streets here today in a Governmentbacked demonstration in support of the fight to keep the northern province of Eritrea a part of Ethiopia.

title: Richardson Hinted at Tap On PreNixon Lawmaker
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson told a Senate hearing that he believed the Federal Bureau of Investigation had wiretapped at least one member of Congress and possibly two Congressional aides before the Nixon years, according to a report issued today by the two Senate subcommittees that conducted joint hearings last year.

title: Koch Promotes Bill for Home Care for Elderly
description: Arguing that up to onefourth of the people in nursing homes need not be there, Representative Edward I. Koch sought yesterdap to rally support for his legislation to encourage home care for the elderly.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENT ALLOWED TO LEAVE
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 16Aleksandr Glezer, a nonconformist art collector who was harassed for having helped to organize unofficial art exhibits, flew today to Vienna with an exit visa for Israel.

title: Motels With XRated Films Thrive on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16In 1970, an enterprising lawyer from Hollywood converted a dingy downtown motel into a lowlit, suggestively furnished establishment aimed at middleaged, middleincome married couples and called it The Experience.

title: Secretary Kissinger's Malicious Canard Roti
description: WASHINGTONJust before leaving for the Middle East, Secretary of State Kissinger took a few hours of his schedule to write a threepage letter to the editor of Harper's magazine denouncing an article of mine in its current issue.

title: Kuwait Separates Oil and Finance Posts
ExNewsman Marries Geraldine F. Eckhouse
description: Geraldine Folb Eckhouse of of Brooklyn, widow of Abraham Eckhouse, was married yesterday afternoon to Edward M. Swietnicki, news manager of Albert FrankGuenther Law, Inc., advertising and publicrelations company here. The ceremony was performed by a rabbi in the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: AUSTRALIA FINDS POVERTY IS ACUTE
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 16 As many Australians face unemployment and financial distress for the first time because of the economic recession, a Government commission of inquiry has reported that in normal times poverty here is more severe than previously believed.

title: Doctor, Convicted in Abortion, Charges Prejudice Barred Fair Trial in Boston
description: BOSTON, Feb. 16 (UPI)Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin, convicted of manslaughter in an abortion operation, said today that racial and religious prejudice had made a fair trial in Boston impossible.

title: 83 Arrested at Cockfight; Raiders Outwit Lookouts
description: TOMS RIVER, Feb. 16Eigtythree men were arrested last night and $15,000 was seized by the police during a raid by lawenforcement authorities on what was described as one of the state's biggest cockfight operations.

title: HAWAII IS SEEKING TO CURB PAPERS
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 16Despite failures over the last several years, Hawaii's legislators have renewed their efforts to enact laws curbing Honolulu's newspapers. They have introduced bills that would do the following:

title: CAREY APPOINTS URBAN ASSISTANT
description: Bernard H. Jackson, a lawyer and former director of the city's Civilian Complaint Review Board, was named yesterday by Governor Carey as his special assistant for urban affairs.

title: A Workshop Where Designs Burst Into Life in Neon
description: There it goes zapping all the dirty specks out, announced Jeanne Pine as vacuum pumps chugged and wheezed.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OTHER SIDE Many people are unaware that Ernest Bloch, the Swissborn composer who died here in 1959 at the age of 79, was also a prolific photographer. Starting with early portraits made when he was a 17yearold violin student in Brussels, the composer recorded a wide variety of subjects, from human interest pictures to rustic closeups and landscapes in Switzerland, New Mexico and Oregon, where he spent his last years. Mr. Bloch was a friend of Alfred Stieglitz, the American photographer.

title: Law Opening School Files Has Slight Impact So Far
description: When a new Federal law went into effect last fall giving parents and adult students the right to examine their school records, one of the first in line at Brown University was Wilma Schiller.

title: Markets Idle Today
description: Securities and commodities exchanges, as well as most banks and state and Federal offices, will be closed today in observance of Washington's birthday.

title: Giscard Will Confer Today With the Shah at St. Moritz
description: PARIS, Feb. 16President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France will wind up a skiing holiday with a quick visit to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran in St. Moritz tomorrow, the President told reporters at the mountain resort of Courchevel today.

title: Plan to Help Public on Utility Rates Lags
Minority Neighborhoods To Get 4 Nursing Homes
description: Four new nursing homes, the first in the city designed for the elderly in black or Hispanic neighborhoods, are being constructed under a fiveyearold state program.

title: JAMES H. HIGGINS JR.
description: James H. Higgins Jr., senior partner in the Providence, R. I., law firm of Higgins, Cavanagh & Cooney, died Saturday at the New England Baptist Hospital in Boston. He was 65 years old and lived in Woonsocket, R. I.

title: Heavy Case Load Hinders P.S.C.'s Control of Rates
description: Inflation and the energy crisis have combined to create a record case load that is hampering the ability of the State Public Service Commission to control rates charged by New York's public utilities.

title: Princeton Assailed on Minority Hiring
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 16Princeton University has been criticized by the Office of Civil Rights of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare for inadequacies in recruiting, hiring and promoting women and minorities. The, university has been ordered to bring its affirmativeaction program up to date within 90 days.

title: R. HANDFORTH ZINSSER
description: R. Handforth Zinsser, artist and widow of Dr. Hans Zinsser, bacteriologist and author of Rats, Lice and History, died Saturday at her home here. Her age was 94.

title: More BeltTightening Expected in Israel
description: TEL AVIVTough belttightening measures and currency devaluation last November have stemmed a buying spree and a drain on foreigncurrency reserves in Israel.

title: Transferring Power in the Kremlin: General Rules of the System
description: PARISHistory does not have the habit of repeating itself, and it would be pointless to try to imagine, based solely on past experience, the nature of the transfer of power in Moscow. Even so, it is perhaps valuable to recall the general rules that the Soviet system follows.

title: Henry Ford, Seeing Scarcity, Calls for More U.S. Planning
description: DETROIT, Feb. 16Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, predicts that the auto industry will have to learn to live with continuing shortages of key materials and that more national planning will be needed to match resources with consumption.

title: Farmers 1975 Crop Decisions Are Anxiously Awaited
description: These winter days may be a relatively easy time on the nation's farms, but it is also a time of critical choices for farmers, most of them smarting from rising operating costs and weakening commodity prices.

title: Seeing God's Chillun for What It Is
description: Fiftyone years after All God's Chillun Got Wings opened to the accompaniment of a bomb threat and a mayoral investigation, Eugene O'Neill's play about the tormented marriage of a white woman and a black man is being revived.

title: Arab Boycott Official Disavows Racial Bias
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 16 (UPI)The Arab office for the boycott of Israel has not placed a single bank or company on its blacklist because it is owned by Jews, the office's commissioner general, Mohammed Mahgoub, said today.

title: WILDER FOOTE, 69, A U,N. PRESS CHIEF
description: Wilder Foote, who retired in 1960 as director of the United Nations press, publications and public services division, died Friday of a heart ailment in Rockland, Me. He was 69 years old and lived in Camden, Me.

title: Bucks Beaten By Jazz
Flyers Top Bruins, 43, on Leach Goal
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (UPI)Reggie Leach's 28th goal broke a 33 tie today and the Philadelphia Flyers scored their first victory in four games this season over the Boston Bruins, 43, in the National Hockey League.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CERVINIA. Italy, Feb. 16 (LIPI)Giorgio Ai era and Franco Perruquet of Italy captured the world twoman bobsled championship from West Germany today, winning all four runs with a margin of more than two seconds.

title: Parsons Finishes First In Daytona 500 Car Race
New Latin Economic Body Excluding U.S. Is Proposed
description: CUCUTA, Colombia, Feb. 16 (AP)  Venezuela and Colombia today proposed the establishment of a new LatinAmerican economic consultative body that would exclude the United States but welcome Cuba and all other LatinAmerican nations.

title: Janice Griffith Has Nuptials
description: Janice Clare Griffith, general counsel to the New York City Housing and Development Administration, was married yesterday to Richard Stanley Perles, a lawyer with Windels & Marx. The Rev. Allen Clark performed the ceremony in the Congregational Church in Union, N.H.

title: Hosick Captures Final In Met. Ski Jumping
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y.Feb. 16 Jack Hosick, a construction worker from Little Falls, N. J., won the jumpoff trophy today as the 1975 ski jumping season ended with the metropolitan championship.

title: Abortion Foe Cites Role
description: BOSTON, Feb. 16For six weeks Thomas M. Connelly Jr. was a fixture at the trial of Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin, sitting slightly apart from the other spectators in a folding chair by the courtroom door.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Of Butter and Guns and Bankruptcy

title: Carey's Chances in 76
description: The visits here last weex or three Democratic Presidential hopefuls provided ammunition for supporters of Governor Carey who argue that the Governor. while admittedly a long shot, has at least as much and probably a better chance of winning a spot on the Democratic national ticket next year as last week's visitors. One of them, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas. is scheduled to announce his candidacy today in Washington while the two others, Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona and former Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma, have already made themselves officially available for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Ford Preparing Busy Schedule Of Trips Overseas in the Fall
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) President Ford is tentatively planning a busy autumn schedule of foreign travel with trips to Europe and China, White House sources said today.

title: Recession Is Putting More Whites on Welfare Lines
description: Two young men leaned against a whitepainted column on the sixth floor of the factory building In Long Island City where most residents of Queens go to apply for public assistance. They smoked and made small talk, waiting, with perhaps 75 others, to be called for an interview.

title: PRIESTS SUE FIVE IN PARISH FOR LIBEL
description: MERIDEN, Conn., Feb. 17 (AP)In what their lawyer says is a rare case, two Roman Catholic priests are suing five parishioners for libel.

title: Youth, 16, Topples Santana
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 17 (LPI)Manuel Santana, the aging former Wimbledon and United States champion, was ousted in the opening round of a $25,000 international tennis tournament today by 16yearold Larry Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: While the young weekend watchman at a Chinatown jewelry store was out looking at films of Chinese swordplay and the elegant oriental martial arts, the store was invaded Sunday night by thieves and picked clean of its gems.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: $67Million in Aid For M.T.A. Trains Proposed by Carey
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17Governor Carey proposed $67million in immediate state aid to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority today to stave off what he said was the threatened halt of commuter rail service early in March, and to help the New York City subway system get through the next two months.

title: Schultz Ice Battle Leads to Debates
description: Dave Schultz of the Philadephia Flyers, already on record as the National Hockey League's most violent character, increased his television ratings in thatcategory over the weekend. In the Spectrum last Sunday afternoon, where elbows, fists, sticks and even skates were flailing from the opening faceoff of the FlyersBoston Bruins contest, Schultz stole the show when he took on Terry O'Reilly, the Boston bad boy.

title: $60,000 IN GEMS STOLEN AT STORE
description: While the young weekend watchman at a Chinatown jewelry store was out looking at films of Chinese swordplay and, the elegant oriental martial arts, the store was invaded by thieves Sunday night and picked clean of its gems.

title: Advertising
description: With the help of the University of Pennsylvania AnheuserBusch learned how to cut Budweiser advertising expenditures and increase sales.

title: At Whitney, the Emphasis Is Today
description: Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, the new director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, prefers the present to the past, and believes that the Whitney should, too. Not that he'd ditch the past entirely at the 45yearold museum, one of the few in the country devoted entirely to American art.

title: Washington's Birthday Sales Attract Droves of Shoppers
description: Washington's Birthday retail business here easily reached its best level of 1975and augured to become one of the year's best shopping daysas thousands of New Yorkers yesterday crowded into the city's stores to buy heavily advertised items.

title: Israelis Say British Tanker Has Transited Suez Canal
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 17 (Reuters) Israeli military correspondents reported today that the Suez Canal was open and that some shipping had already transited the waterway.

title: Neighborhoods: Steinway Area of Astoria Scratches a Landmark
Angler's Economics
description: MARCO ISLAND, Fla.The kingfish are running in the blue waters of the Gulf of Mexico near here, and a morning's combat with these unambiguous fighters, some going over twenty pounds, ought to be just the thing to take your mind off the economy, the oil crisis, the Middle East, and all those Presidential candidates lurking in the uncertain future.

title: Police Investigate Apparent Escape Effort by Black Liberationists
description: What apparently was a combined sea and land attempt to free 11 alleged members of the Black Liberation Army from their maximumsecurity cellblock on Bikers Island remained much of a mystery yesterday as the police searched for more clues.

title: Cambodians Failing To Reopen Lifeline
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 17The vital military attempt to open the blockaded Mekong River, the main lifeline to this supplyshort capital, is in trouble.

title: ExC.I.A. Security Chief Testifies With a Lawyer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) Accompanied by an attorney, Howard J. Osborn, the former security chief for the Central Intelligence Agency, was questioned for more than three hours today by the Rockefeller commission about the agency's domestic surveillance activities.

title: PRISONER IS SLAIN ON WORKRELEASE
description: CLARK, Feb. 17 (UPI)A New Jersey state prison inmate was fatally shot today when he allegedly tried to burglarize a store after being allowed to leave the jail to drive another prisoner to a job in the workrelease program.

title: BusinessCycle Analysts Deny 1929 Is Revisited
description: Strictly speaking, every business cycle is a unique historical episode, differing in significant ways from all its predecessors and never to be repeated in the future.

title: MAKARIOS REQUESTS U.N. COUNCIL TO MEET
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 17The Cyprus Government of President Makarios called tonight for an urgent session of the Security Council, protesting, the proclamation last Thursday by Turkish Cypriotes of a separate state in the Turkishoccupied northern part of the island.

title: Yugoslavs Sentence 15 as Secessionists
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 17  Fifteen persons accused of plotting to bring about the secession of the Republic of Croatia from Yugoslavia were sentenced today to prison terms up to 13 years.

title: Pro Transactions
description: HOCKEY

title: Nixon Is Planning to Donate Some Papers to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) Former President Richard M. Nixon has declared his intention to offer 1,300 cubic feet of prePresidential papers to the United States, the General Services Administration said today.

title: GENE SCHROEDER
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 17 (UPI)Gene Schroeder, former pianist in Eddie Condon's jazz club in New York, died yesterday in a nursing home. He was 160 years old.

title: 20th Century, Fund Plans Black Middle Class Study
description: The Twentieth Century Fund, will conduct an analysis of the nation's black middle class.

title: Niederhoffer Wins Fifth U.S. Crown
description: He's a piece of elastic, not a squash player, said Victor Niederhoffer here yesterday after defeating Peter Briggs, 10, 1, 12, to win the 64th United States squashracquets singles championship. He doesn't run. I've never seen anyone stretch for a ball like he does. He's like a New York City mayor stretching to meet a budget.

title: Ethiopia Wants Arms
description: Ethiopia, fighting Eritrean guerrillas, has requested an emergency airlift of arms, ammunition and equipment from the United States. The State Department said it was studying the request, but officials indicated there was some reluctance to comply. Page 10.

title: Portrait of a Great Man
description: Here is a series of vignettes attempting to answer that most difficult question, Why was George Washington a great man?

title: Indiana Wins 28th. Clinches Share of Title
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 17 (AP)Topranked Indiana clinched a share of its third straight Big Ten basketball championship tonight with a 98 romp over Wisconsin.

title: St. Francis Trackmen Top Molloy
description: St. Francis Prep was an upset winner, but Power Memorial and St. John the Baptist won as expected yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association sectional track championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: RABBI ELIAS GREENBERG
description: Rabbi Elias Greenberg, who for 50 years had led the Talmud Study Circle at Congregation BethEl of Borough Park, Brooklyn, died Friday at the age of 81. He lived at 1311 49th Street, Brooklyn.

title: U.A.W. Rebuffs I.A.M. Bid
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17 (UPI Members of the United Auto Workers have voted not to join members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace workers in picketing McDonnell Douglas plants in Southern California, it was announced today.

title: 2 NEW SECRETARIES APPOINTED BY CAREY
description: Special to The New York Times

title: GEORGE MARSHALL, FILM DIRECTOR, 84
description: George E. Marshall, who made more than 400 movies in his 62 years as a Hollywood director, died in a Los Angeles hospital yesterday, three days after becoming the third director inducted into the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences Hall of Fame. He was 84 years old.

title: In Big Cities, Realistic Voters in This Election Year Are Aware of How Limited Are Mayors Powers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17In most of the big cities of the country this is an election year an uncommonly cairn one, so far, after the racial turmoil and polarizing lawandorder campaigns of the last decade.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden has announced a first step toward development of a proposed 300acre port facility on his city's riverfront. He said he planned to hire a consultant within two weeks to find a method for financing the project. He said he hoped the consultant would make a recommendation by June, with constriction to begin shortly thereafter. The complex the Mayor has in mind would be midway between the Benjamin Franklin and Walt Whitman Bridges. It would be able to accommodate oceangoing vessels.

title: 1971 Nursing Home Fire To Be Studied as Murder
description: HONESDALE, Pa., Feb. 17 (AP)Wayne County Coroner Robert Jenings says a 1971 nursing home fire that killed 15 people and was ruled an accident will now be investigated as a murder.

title: Doctor J: The Young Old Pro at 25
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 17Julius Erving's birthday also is George Washington's birthday, but like the rest the nation, he celebrated it today. He scored 25 points match his 25 years. When he was born, somebody suggested to his mother that he be named George Washington Erving, but she replied, You have a baby and name him after George Washington. My baby's name will be Julius Winfield Erving Jr. Her son developed into Doctor J, instead of Doctor G or even Doctor Wash, but by any other name, he would be unique. With him, the Nets have upstaged the Knicks, at feast artistry if not appreciation, in New York basketball. No longer do knowledgeable basketball people wonder how good the Nets are; they wonder how many members of the current Knick team would be able to make the Nets squad. Walt Frazier and Earl Monroe would be the starting guards, but Bill Bradley and Phil Jackson would be backup forwards and John Giannelli would be the backup center. And so the pendulum swings, with Doctor J riding it as if he were floating in for a dunk shot. In his fourth American Basketball Association season, he is the game's most exciting player. But beyond that he is an old pro, with an attitude and an understanding that some players never develop. And for all his remarkable repertory on the court, he prefers to understate everything else. That was obvious before the 1204 victory over the Virginia Squires today as he sat in the Nets dressing room with electrodes from a galvanic stimulator on each knee. When he was asked the Nets had a special name for the he

title: Jersey City Will Drop 472, Including 65 Policemen
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 17Mayor Paul T. Jordan announced today that 472 Jersey City employes, including 65 policemen and an equal num ber of firemen, would be dismissed beginning this Friday because of a projected $20.4 million shortfall in the city's current budget.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 17 (Reuters)Common Market finance ministers have reached a holding agreement enabling the European Investment Bank to value its assets in a unit of account that reflects more closely presentday exchange rates, informed sources said today.

title: Manila Rejected by Soviet As Title Chess Match Site
description: AMSTERDAM, Feb. 17 (UPI) The Soviet Union today, rejected on a technicality the ruling by the International Chess Federation (F. I.D. E.) in favor of Manila as the site for a world chess championship match starting June 1 between Bobby Ftscner and Anatoly Karpov.

title: House to Delay Work a Day Out of Respect for Pettis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)  Speaker Carl Albert announced today that legislative activity in the House this week would be delayed one day out of respect for Representative Jerry L. Pettis, Republican of California.

title: Bridge:
description: A leaderless team captured the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship at Temple Israel, 112 East 75th Street here on Sunday.

title: President Unveils Gerald Ford Medallion at George Washington Hall
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)President Ford paid tribute today to George Washington, saying that when the nation's first President was asked about bad times he urged Americans to work and change the situation.

title: Running of State Likened To Floating Crap Game
O.A.U. Reaction to Move
description: ADDIS, ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 17The news that Prime Minister Vorster had confirmed reports of his visit to Liberia caused excitement here at Africa Hall, where the Organization of African Unity is meeting.

title: ITT Grinnell Post Filled
description: Daniel P. Nugent has been named president of ITT Grinnell Corporation, the Providence, R.I., producer of piping products and valves owned by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. Mr. Nugent was previously president of Phelps Dodge Brass Company, New York.

title: Technical Excellence Sustains New Hungarian String Quartet
description: Any string quartet that programs Schubert's Quarteltsatz, Bartok's Fifth Quartet and Beethoven's Quartet in B flat major (Op. 130) complete with the Grosse Fuge is obviously trying to make some sort of statement about its capacity for virtuosity and the projection of grand passion in music. The New Hungarian Quartet, which presented that program Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, certainly proved itself on those grounds, even if the performances weren't quite ideal from other points of view.

title: People in Sports
description: The New York Giants will play the New York Jets tomorrowin tennis. Going for aces instead of touchdowns will be Ron Johnson, Spider Lockhart and Chuck Crist of the Giants, plus Willie Williams, formerly of the Giants and now with the Hawaiians of the World Foctball League. Two broadcasters, Pat Summerall and Frank Gifford, both former Giants, also may play.

title: Martin, Miss Leiss Win Junior Final
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Freak Malaysia Storm Kills 5
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Feb. 17 (UPI)  At least five persons W ere crushed to death and several others injured by trees uprooted in a freak hailstorm today that caused flash floods and traffic pileups, the police said.

title: Fire Attributed to Client Empties Massage Parlor
description: An Eighth Avenue massage parlor was emptied by a onealarm fire last evening after a disgruntled customer allegedly threatened to bring the Mafia's vengence on the place, started the blaze and left.

title: Cambodians Failing To Reopen Lifeline
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 17The vital military attempt to open the blockaded Mekong River, the main lifeline to this supplyshort capital, is in trouble.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: 2 From State Rebuffed by Florida In Bid to Operate Nursing Home
description: MIAMI, Feb. 17Two New York builders were turned down today for the second time in their efforts to reopen a nursing home in Miami Beach.

title: KISSINGER'S TALKS WITH GROMYKO END IN RIFT ON MIDEAST
description: LONDON, Feb. 17  Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union wound up their talks in Geneva today in disagreement over the Middle East.

title: Judgeship Battle at Hand For Albany Democrats
description: ALBANY  The Democrats chronic battle of reformers vs. regulars is expected to be renewed in the Assembly this week over the proposed election calendar for thisyear. Insurgent politicians charge that it has been rigged to let organization leaders fill a number of Civil Court judgeships in New York City without their having the opportunity to make primary challenges.

title: $9.40 Chance Wins Coast Turf Race
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 17Madison Palace, a Frenchbred stretch runner, found racing room on the inside today and captured the eighth running of the $67,100 San Luis Obispo Handicap on Santa Anita's turf course.

title: Women Rally for Doctor Convicted in Abortion
description: BOSTON, Feb. 17Lighted candles were placed on the State House steps tonight by crowd of about 1,500, mostly women, to protest the manslaughter conviction of Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin in the death of a male fetus after a legal abortion.

title: BEAME'S TAX PLAN DECRIED AS FUTILE
description: Mayor Beame's proposal to raise $350.3  million toward closing next year's budget gap with a 10 per cent increase in the real estate tax will fail because the higher tax will not be collectible, Ken Patton, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said yesterday.

title: Schooling Here Poses a Major Quandary for Japanese
description: The Japanese nickname for college is semakimon, the narrow gate, through which only a few at a time may enter.

title: New Orleans Bus Drivers Vote to Accept Arbitration
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 17 (UPI)  City bus drivers voted overwhelmingly today to end their 63day strike and submit unsettled contract issues to arbitration.

title: A Fair for Seekers of Perfect Wedding
description: Diamond rings of all shapes and sizes glinted on fingers at the Americana Hotel here last weekend as more than 1.200 bridestobe, accompanied by mothers and friends, enthusiastically swarmed through a trade show where The Perfect Wedding was offered for sale. It was a marriage of romance and finance, attended by 4,000 people, and its prospects appeared to be fruitful.

title: CHRYSLER SHOWS BIG QUARTER LOSS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 17  The Chrysler Corporation reported today a net loss of $73.5million for the fourth quarter of 1974, which is the biggest loss for a quarter in the company's history.

title: Ethiopia Wants Arms
description: Ethiopia, fighting Eritrean guerrillas, has requested an emergency airlift of arms,. ammunition and equipment from the United States. The State Department said it was studying the request, but officials indicated there was some reluctance to comply. Page 10.

title: $5MILLION IN ART IS STOLEN IN MILAN
description: ROME, Feb. 17  Thieves broke into Milan's Municipal Museum early today and made off with 28 paintings, among them works by Cezanne, Gauguin, Renoir and Van Gogh.

title: Jaworski Says Keeping Tapes Proved to Be Undoing of Nixon
description: FORT WORTH, Feb. 17 (UPI) Leon Jaworski, former special prosecutor, said today that former President Richard M. Nixon could have weathered the Watergate investigation if the White House tapes had been destroyed.

title: Bentsen of Texas 5th Democrat in Race
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Senator Lloyd Millard Bentsen of Texas is the fifth Democrat to enter the 1976 Presidential race.

title: Released Koreans Allege Torture for Confessions
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 17 All I can remember is that I was halfconscious and screaming. They would alternate the type of treatmentno sleep, beatings, electric shock treatment  and then they would hang me, hang me upside down and pour water down my nostrils.

title: U.S. Tuna Men Held in Ecuador Are Bitter and in Fighting Mood
description: SALINAS, Ecuador, Feb. 15An old man, weighed down by an ancient tripod box camera, trudged along the sands by the turquoise Pacific until he came across a young couple lying on the beach.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NEW SOUNDS Jazz will be heard for, the first time in St. Patrick's Cathedral today at 2 P.M., with the liturgical performance of a jazz mass composed and conducted from the keyboard by Mary Lou Williams, with her instrumental ensemble and a choir of young people from Catholic schools in New York. The sermon for the mass will be delivered by Rev. Peter F. O'Brien, Miss Williams's personal manager The event is open to the public.

title: CHRYSLER SHOWS BIG QUARTER LOSS
News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1975

title: THOMAS J. TIGHE
description: Thomas J. Tighe, president and owner of the Vanderburgh & Co., Inc., foreign trade concern at 11 Broadway, died Sunday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old and lived at 139 Edgemont Place, Teaneck, N.J.

title: The United Kingdom: Can It Survive?
description: LONDONFrom the Battle of Waterloo in 1815 until World War I. the British Empire ruled supreme. As an island Britain was virtually immune from invasion, so she had no need to maintain a large standing army like her Continental neighbors. Her navy ruled the seas.

title: Girl, 19, Slain in Home in San Francisco; Brother, 20, Her Best Friend, Is Seized
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. I7The daughter of the late Howard Luck Gossage, one of the nation's leading advertising executives was found murdered here last week, and her only surviving relative, her older brother, has been charged with the crime.

title: Support in Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 17Gov. Dolph Briscoe and Lieut. Gov. William P. Hobby Jr. gave warm support today to Mr. Bentsen's Presidential aspirations.

title: Albany Caucus and N.A.A.C.P. Differ
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17The Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus met with 500 members of the State National Association for the Advancement of Colored People at the group's annual legislative mobilization here today, and it quickly became clear that the two bodies were often at odds on action toward similar goals.

title: BRITAIN OFFERING SOVIET $2BILLION IN TRADE CREDITS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17  Britain has agreed to extend to they Soviet Union about $2billion in lowinterest credits for pur chases of British technology over the next five years, Prime Minister Harold Wilson said today.

title: Soviet Border Negotiator Meets Official in Peking
description: PEKING, Feb. 17 (Agence FrancePress)A Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Leonid F. Ilyichev, Moscow's negotiator in border talks with China, met on Saturday with the Chinese negotiator, Deputy Foreign Minister Han Nienlung, a Soviet source here confirmed today.

title: JERSEY CITY CUTS 472 FROM PAYROLL
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 17Mayor Paul T. Jordon today announced that 472 Jersey City employes, including 65 policemen and an equal number of firemen, would be dismissed beginning this Friday because of a projected 520.4million shortfall in the city's current budget.

title: SAIGON DROPS CASE AGAINST SIX PAPERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 17  The Government today dropped libel charges against six newspapers that had been accused of defaming President Nguyen Van Thieu by publishing allegations of corruption. Four of the papers have been closed.

title: Apartment Tower at 96th St. May Include Major Store
Pacers Triumph, 10099
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 17 (UPI)George McGinnis scored 29 points today, including a tipin with just under a minute to go, helping the Indiana Pacers beat the Spirits of St. Louis, 109.

title: Knights of Columbus Parade Up 5th Ave. To St. Patrick Mass
description: Resplendent in blackandwhite plumed hats and redlined capes that furled in the cold February breeze, a contingent of the Knights of Columbus Fourth Degree led several hundred fellow Knights up a nearly deserted Fifth Avenue yesterday morning to St. Patrick's Cathedral for their annual Washington's Birthday memorial mass.

title: Play: Unreality at de Lys
KILLING OF FETUS IS CHARGED ON L.I.
description: Denis E. Dillon, the Nassau County District Attorney, said yesterday that he would investigate the complaint of a Long Island antiabortion group that a fetus allegedly aborted at the Nassau Medical Center at East Meadow, L. I., on Jan. 19 was a victim of infanticide because it had been denied lifesupport systems.

title: Photos Capture Richness Of Art Deco Streetscape
description: In a sense it is almost too bad that art deco architecture has become so outrageously popular these days, since the current wave of interest has all the earmarksof a fad, and these buildings of the nineteentwenties and thirties are really much too good for that. If they do not last physically, the great art deco skyscrapers will at least continue to be remembered as esthetic objects long after the last Third Avenue glass box has been forgotten.

title: Bentsen Announces
description: Can a suave millionaire from the executive suites Houston find success as the leader of a liberal, sometimes radical, party? That is a question posed by the Presidential candidacy of Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas. Even though he is almost totally unknown to the public, Senator Bentsen is seeking national office on the basisof a solid background of service in both houses Congress and experience in law and business.

title: Knicks to Divest Holzman of Either Coach or Manager Role
description: The faltering Knicks are due to have either a new coach or new general manager next season. The dual job held for five years by Red Holzman will be divided, according to sources at Madison Square Garden's parent company. Holzman will stay, these sources revealed, but no decision has been made as to which position he will retain.

title: A Third Party?
description: Despite the presence in the White House of Gerald Ford, a solid Middle Western conservative, and the presence in the leadership of the Democratic party men like Senator Bentsen, many conservatives in this country continue to feel politically homeless. At the second annual Conservative Political Action Conference held in Washington last weekend, delegates talked enthusiastically of forming a new party and appointed committee to review and assess the possibilities.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1975

title: Foes Intensifying Drive Against Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 17Four main opposition parties boycotted the opening of India's Parliament today as they planned an intensified nationwide campaign against Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Damaged Tanker in Boston
description: BOSTON, Feb. 17 (AP)The Cypriote tanker Athenian Star, damaged in a fierce Atlantic storm, arrived at an east Boston shipyard today for repairs. The vessel, damaged more than a week ago, had been anchored for more than a week off the coast of Maine, near Portsmouth, N. H.

title: U.S. TRAVEL RULES EASED FOR CUBANS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)  The State Department reported today that it had changed travel regulations for members of the Cuban mission to the United Nations. But a spokesman said this did not represent a change in United States policy toward the Communist nation.

title: U.S. Studying Request
Dollar and Gold Value Off; Stocks Slump in London
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 17 (UPI)The United States dollar again in value against European, currencies today as it pent into the ninth week of one of its worst slumps.

title: London Denies Report
description: LONDON, Feb. 17 (Reuters) President Ford has been invited to visit Britain, but definite arrangements for the trip have not been made yet, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

title: Ethiopia, Battling Secessionists, Asks U.S. for Airlift of Arms
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 17The Ethiopian Government, which for 17 days has been fighting secessionist guerrillas in Eritrea, the country's northernmost province, has requested an emergency airlift of arms, ammunition and equipment from the United States.

title: STUART R. STEVENSON
description: Stuart Riddle Stevenson, a senior partner in the brokerage firm of Stevenson & Bartram until 1972, died Sunday at his home in ArdsleyonHudson, N. Y., He was 78 years old.

title: VORSTER VERIFIES VISIT TO LIBERIA
COLLEY E. WILLIAMS
description: Colley E. Williams, a corporate lawyer who specialized in public utility cases with Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died Sunday night in his home, 131 East 69th Street. He was 82 years old.

title: Kenneth Lane Weds Nicola Waymouth
description: Nicola Samuel Waymouth was married in London yesterday to Kenneth Jay Lane, costume jewelry designer. The civil ceremony took place at Caxton Hall.

title: Crime and the Streets
description: Crime and fear are unwelcome but fairly constant elements of life in this city. A returning resident asks his Harlem barber to describe the major change that occurred during his years of absence. The response is short and clear: Mainly it's the fear. Up here, people don't go out at night any more unless it's urgent.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 17 (AP)  Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto's Government took over direct rule of the troubled NorthWest Frontier Province today, accusing neighboring Afghanistan of fomenting subversive activities there.

title: OilPrice Drop May Give Consumers Slight Benefit
description: World crudeoil prices have begun to sag noticeably under the impact of reduced consumption by the industrialized nations.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Collectors of Holmegaard glassware are likely to flip over the variety of items being introduced here by the 150yearold Danish firm.

title: WILLIAM G. DOOLEY, AUTHOR, CRITIC, 70
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 17 (AP)William Germain Dooley, editor, author, critic and public relations man, died yesterday at Mount Auburn Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Staying on Base
description: In reality, the power factors are of another kind entirely. In this country, as in all advanced industrial nations, the business community provides the base for the conservative party. Today; the business community has no serious reason to be dissatisfied with the policies of the Administration headed by President Ford and Vice President Rockefeller. Individual businessmen disagree with this or that specific program; but on thecritical issues of tax policy, of Federal regulation pf business, of voluntarism rather than wage and price controls, of oil policy, and the level of military spending, business in general finds this Administration's outlook congenial. If many businessmen are distressed at the size of the Federal budget deficit, the President and his Secretary of the Treasury profess themselves to be equally horrified.

title: CHANGE IS URGED ON RIGHT TO KNOW
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17  New Yorkers would have an easier time making government officials let them see public records under a proposal worked out by a stateappointed citizen cornmittee on freedom of information.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Market Place
description: Some publicly owned companies, concerned about the increasing tendency in Wall Street to focus on the nation's largest corporations, are trying to reach investors directly.

title: Cleveland Acquires a Key Picasso
Paying the Family Bills: It's Often a Wife's Chore
description: When the wife's hand controls the family purse strings, it is not always because she is a dominating shrew or even because she wants the job.

title: U.S. Plane Out of Running For FourNation Purchase
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 17 (Reuters) Four NATO countries seeking a replacement for their aging F104 Starfighter aircraft have eliminated one of the two American contenders, the Norwegian Defense Minister, Alv Jakob Fostervoll, said today.

title: BANKRUPT SCHOOL WILL KEEP GOING
description: The board of trustees of Bloomfield College has announced its decision to continue operations of the financially pressed, 106yearold institution situated on 13 acres in the center of Bloomfield in Essex County.

title: HOUSING POLICEMAN KILLS AN ASSAILANT
description: A Housing Authority patrolman wounded in a shootout in a Harlem apartment complex last night, shot and killed his assailant, firing 12 rounds and emptying two revolvers.

title: L.I. Town on Tenterhooks In 15Day Hospital Strike
description: GREENPORT, L.I., Feb. 17The men and women of this small fishing village on Long Island's north fork, uneasy because of a local hospital walkout, are waiting anxiously for disaster not to strike.

title: Italians Preparing to Send U.S. Extradition Request for Sindona
description: ROME, Feb. 17A request by the Italian Government for the extradition of Michele Sindona, the financier who at one time was in control of the Franklin National Bank in New York, is expected to reach the United States this week.

title: KISSINGER'S TALKS WITHGROMYKOEND IN RIFT ON MIDEAST
description: LONDON, Feb. 17  Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union wound up their talks in Geneva today in disagreement over the Middle East.

title: EAST ORANGE FIRE EXPELS 35 FAMILIES
description: EAST ORANGE, Feb. 17 (UPI) A fire destroyed a fourstory apartment house late today, leaving homeless some 35 families who were safely evacuated. At least four firemen were injured.

title: BEAME'S TAX PLAN DECRIED AS FUTILE
description: Mayor Beame's proposal to raise $350.3million toward closing next year's budget gap with a 10 per cent increase in the real estate tax will fail because the higher tax will not be collectible, Ken Patton, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said yesterday.

title: Security Talks Moving to Finale
U.D.C. Head Calls Banks Cooperative About Debt
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17The Urban Development Corporation will be able to get past Thursday's deadline for repayment of a $30million emergency bank loan without prior need for legislative action, the acting head of the agency said after a meeting today with Governor Carey and his top advisers.

title: Bentsen of Texas 5th Democrat in Race
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Senator Lloyd Millard Bentsen of Texas is the fifth Democrat to enter the 1976 Presidential race.

title: Shah of Iran Sees Lower Oil Prices If Goods Decline
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 17 (UPI)The Shah of Iran said today it might be possible for oil producing countries to lower prices if this was accompanied by a reduction in prices of agricultural and industrial products which the oil producers need.

title: GRAZIANO ZARA
description: Graziano Zara, founder of the Zara Construction Company of Hicksville, L.I., died Sunday in Fort Lauderdale. Fla. He was 72 years old and lived in Brookville, L.I., and Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: Empty Plate Is Focus Of CARE Ad Campaign
description: Working on a volunteer basis some creative people at Doyle Dane Bernbach have come up with advertising and a slogan and symbol for the CARE World Hunger Fund.

title: Books of The Times
Issue and Debate
description: Contending that the present system of Federal airline regulation is inefficient and possibly costs the nation $1 billion annually, the White House has disclosed that it will propose legislation soon to deregulate the airlinesthat is, seek to remove most of the Federal Government's control over determining the price of airline tickets and in designating which companies may enter the airline business and what the routes they may fly.

title: London Stocks Tumble
description: LONDON, Feb. 17 (Reuters) Share prices tumbled today on the London Stock Exchange, leading to fears that the market's recent upsurge is at an end.

title: Bill to Give Senators $35aDay for Travels
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)A littlenoticed provision of legislation due for House action this week would give Senators a $35 per diem travel allowance for the first time, even while campaigning for reelection, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: Condition of Apartments Is Protested in Brooklyn
description: I used to lie awake nights, crying, watching the roaches crawl all over my little boy.

title: MILITANT ZIONISTS OCCUPY U.N. ROOM
description: About 15 members of Betar, a militant Zionist youth organization, locked themselves in the Meditation Room of the United Nations headquarters yesterday in an effort to force the organization to take action on behalf of Soviet Jews and, particularly, Mikhail Shtern, a physician convicted of bribery.

title: $5MILLION IN ART IS STOLEN IN MILAN
description: ROME, Feb. 17  Thieves broke into Milan's Municipal Museum early today and made off with 28 paintings among them works by Cezanne, Gauguin, Renoir and Van Gogh.

title: Notes on People
description: Queen Elizabeth II had to cross a picket line of striking dock workers in Bermuda yesterday when, accompanied by Prince Philip, she went to the Government dockyards to dedicate a maritime museum.

title: Norman Treigle, 47, City Opera Bass For 20 Years, Dies in New Orleans
description: Norman Treigle, the spidery thin, blackvoiced bass who sang with the New York City Opera for 20 years, died Sunday at his New Orleans apartment. He was 47 years old.

title: Kirov's Fedicheva, in Rome, Hopes To Continue Her Career in the U.S.
description: Kaleriya Fedicheva, a leading ballerina of the Kirov company of Leningrad until she applied to emigrate a year ago, was allowed to leave the Soviet Union on Sunday and said in Rome yesterday that she hoped to rejoin her American husband shortly and to continue her dancing career in the United States.

title: Payout Is $1.25 a Share
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., announced yesterday a cut in its first quarterly interim dividend for 1975.

title: 2 Health Aides Say Blumenthal Resisted View Bergman Wasn't Fit to Run Homes
description: Two officials of the State Health Department say that they tried to convince Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal that Bernard Bergman was unfit to run a nursing home, but that the Assemblyman disputed their views.

title: South African Crash Kills 16
description: POTCHEFSTROOM, South Africa, Feb. 17 (AP)  A Cape Town to Johannesburg passenger train and a freight train collided near here early today, killing at least 16 people and injuring 44, railway officials announced.

title: Stars Set Back Sounds
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 17 (AP)The Utah Stars got 30 points from Ron Boone and 29 from their rookie, Moses Malone, to defeat the Memphis Sounds, 1100, in the A.B.A. tonight.

title: Bank inCleveland Moves To Take Over Another
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 17 (AP)The National City Bank of Cleveland moved today to gain Federal approval of its proposed takeover of the defunct Northern Ohio Bank.

title: Vietnamese Communists Making Biggest Gains in Mekong Delta Area Since the Sixties
Quiet Pigeon Exterminator a Bird Lover Myself
description: POINT PLEASANT, Feb. 17 (UPI)  Herman the pigeon catcher has a mean job.

title: Apartment Tower at 96th May Include a Major Store
description: A proposal to add a major department store to an apartpent house planned at Broadway and 96th Street, the site where community opposition blocked an Alexander's department store, in. 1970, is under consideration by the City Planning Commission.

title: Saved After 25 Days Adrift
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 17 (UPI)A Puerto Rican fisherman who drifted 800 miles for 25 days in a 16foot open boat without food and water was rescued in good condition today by a merchant vessel about 100 miles east of Nicaragua, the United States Coast Guard reported. No indication was given on how the fisherman, Fundador Velez, had survived.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Court of Appeals removed two legal roadblocks that have stopped the owners of the Parkchester apartment development in the Bronx from converting the rental complex to condominiums.

title: Ford to Decontrol Price of Old Oil, Energy Chief Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17President Ford will decontrol the price of old oil even if Congress does not impose an excess profits tax to keep oil companies from benefiting unduly by the action, his energy administrator said today.

title: Monroe to Miss 2 More Games
description: Earl Monroe, the Knicks No. 2 scorer, will miss the next two games. The backcourt man, who is suffering from the flu, will remain at St. Luke's hospital for another 48 hours. He entered the hospital Saturday before the Knicks game against the Washington Bullets.

title: Teaneck Gunman Slays Homeowner, Wounds Boarder
description: Bergen County authorities are on the alert for a tall, baldish gunman in his early 40's who, after being let into a Teaneck home Sunday night, killed the owner and critically wounded a 23yearold boarder with shots in the head.

title: OilPrice Drop May Give Consumers Slight Benefit
description: World crudeoil prices have begun to sag noticeably under the impact of reduced consumption by the industrialized nations.

title: Riessen Sees Davis Cup Change
description: Marty Riessen, who plays tennis and Simon Says better than he rows a boat, foresees the day when the Davis Cup competition no longer will be an amateur event run by amateur organizations.

title: VIC DAMONE RETURNS WITH BIGGER PUNCH
description: Vic Damone, who began his singing career in New York 30 years ago following the fashion of the ultracasual Perry Como and the then lightvoiced Frank Sinatra, is making his first New York nightclub appearance in eight years, reopening the Rainbow Grill. It had been closed for a month while it underwent a change in management.

title: Saudi Denies Price Talks With Kissinger Over Oil
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 17 (AP)The Minister of Oil of Saudi Arabia, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, denied today reports that Saudi officials and Secretary of State Kissinger; had discussed a longterm contract for the sale of oil to the United States at reduced prices.

title: Syria Bids Arabs Bar a Limited Peace
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 17 President Hafez alAssad of Syria is urging other Arab nations to resist partial settlements in the Middle East that could divide the Arabs.

title: Sayre's Good Idea For Recital Proves Too Much Novelty
description: Robert Sayre, a Piatigorsky protg who was highly praised at his debut in 1958, decided to feature rarely performed cello works of the Romantic period for his first solo recital here in 15 years. The idea was excellent, and Mr. Sayre played with high expertise on Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Chagrin Over Appointment Denied by Saigon Embassy
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 17A spokesman said today that the United States Mission was not chagrined by the appointment of Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Toan to the command of the important military region around Saigon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Gas Compromise: A Rebated Supertax

title: CARE OPENS DRIVE TO AID THEST ARVING
description: CARE, the international relief agency, yesterday opened a fundraising drive for faminestricken nations overseas by asking Americans to forgo or reduce one meal a week this year and donate the money thus saved to the agency.

title: Midpoint of Environmental Decade: Impact of National Policy Act Assessed
description: In the span of a few days last December, a group of Long Islanders sued to block sewer projects considered hazardous to drinking water sources; development plans for Yosemite National Park were ordered to be completely overhauled; and a Federal court ruled that 11,000 corporations had to weigh the environmental effects of changes in their processes and products.

title: U.A.W. Rebuffs I.A.M. Bid
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17 (UPI) Members of the United Auto Workers have voted not to join members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace workers in picketing McDonnell Douglas plants in Southern California, it was announced today.

title: Chess:
description: Many years ago Savielly Tartakover, the FrancoPolish grandmaster, was denied a brilliancy prize for a game that featured a marvelous rook sacrifice for a longterm mating attack because the judges believed that he had not foreseen the fantastic finish in detail.

title: Wasted Homage
description: The basic question raised again by the decision not to build the Kennedy museum in Cambridge as part of the Kennedy Librarywhich itself may also be moved somewhere elseis whether the concept of Presidential libraries does not need thorough reexamination.

title: APPARENT EASING BY RESERVE SEEN
description: The Federal Reserve apparently has lowered its target for a key shortterm rate once again as part of its plarr, to foster easier credit conditions. This latest move will provide some impetus for further reductions in the prime lending rate of commercial banks.

title: MRS. ANSON M'LOUD
description: Mrs. Anson McLoud, a member of the hoard and secretary of the Westchester Symphony Orchestra, died Friday in her home, 176 Garth Road, Scarsdale, N.Y. She was 76 years old.

title: Sindona Repeats Denial
description: Mr. Sindona, reached by telephone today at the Hotel Pierre in New York, repeated his denials of any wrongdoing.

title: Recession Is Putting More Whites on Welfare Lines
description: Two young men leaned against a whitepainted column on the sixth floor of the factory building In Long Island City where most residents of Queens go to apply for public assistance. They smoked and made small talk, waiting, with perhaps 75 others, to be called for an interview.

title: Meany, Citing Worsening Unemployment, Calls for Tax Cut of $30Billion
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 17 George Meany, citing worsening unemployment, said today that he now thought a tax cut of $30billion$10billion more than the A.F.L.C.I.O. proposed last monthwas necessary to stimulate the economy through increased purchasing power.

title: 19 CITY HOSPITALS TO ABOLISH 450 JOBS
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation has ordered the executive directors of its 19 municipal hospitals to reduce their staffs by 450 positions through attrition beginning immediately.

title: Markets Were Closed
description: Securities and commodities exchanges were closed yesterday in the United States in observance of Washington's birthday.

title: UTILITIES RATES STIRRING DEBATE
description: Customers of electric companies in several states and Washington, D.C., have been overcharged by millions of dollars through automatic fuelcost adjustments during the last three years, according to public utility regulators.

title: LTV Cites Record Profit; Du Pont Cuts Its Dividend
description: The LTV Corporation, the Dallas  based conglomerate James J. Ling built and others reconstituted into an operating company since his departure, yesterday reported record seles and earnings for the fourth quarter of 1974 and for the year.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On Gun Care
description: A good shotgun or rifleeven if it is not in the $1,000 plus classis one of the few articles a sportsman owns that grows in value over the years.

title: Ford to Decontrol Price of Old Oil, Energy Chief Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17President Ford will decontrol the price of old oil even if Congress does not impose an excess profits tax to keep oil companies from benefiting unduly by the action, his energy administrator said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: For the first time since 1962 DeWitt Clinton's basketball team has been eliminated before the semifinal round of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs. Clinton, last season's runnerup and the champion in 1973, was dei feated yesterday by South Shore, 78, at Franklin D Roosevelt High in Brooklyn. In the day's other opening round game, Haaren rallied in the fourth period and beat Morris, 72.

title: HEAVYMETAL ROCK BY QUEEN, A QUARTET
description: Queen, a British quartet still subscribing to the principles of blitzkrieg rock, headlined its own concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Sundaya potent example of its escalation into New York cult rockers. Its last time here, six months ago, it was at the bottom of the bill in a Broadway rock season.

title: Notes on People
description: Queen Elizabeth II had to cross a picket line of striking duck workers in Bermuda yesterday when, accompanied by Prince Philip, she went to the Government dockyards to dedicate a maritime museum. Earlier, the couple drove to Hamilton's city hall in an open carriage drawn by two white horses. For other events they used a 20footYong 1968 RollsRoyce limousine said to have been made originally for Alexander Dub cek of Czechoslovakia and returned to the factory after he was deposed as Communist party chief. Dr. Erie Heath of Pittsburgh, owner of the car, lent it to Bermuda, where cars cannot exceed 166 inches in lengthexcept for the Daimler used by the Governor.

title: City Hall Fantasia
description: Mayor Beame's preliminary 1976 expense budget projections grimly confirm what has been evident to even the most casual students of New York City affairs for a long, long timethat this metropolis faces a fiscal crisis from which there can be no escape without drastic cuts in personnel and services and substantial increases in taxes.

title: BRITAIN OFFERING SOVIET $2BILLION IN TRADE CREDITS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17  Britain has agreed to extend to the Soviet Union about $2billion in lowinterest credits for purchases of British technology over the next five years, Prime Minister Harold Wilson said today.

title: RIGHTS AMENDMENT LOSES GEORGIA VOTE
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 17 (AP)The Georgia Senate voted 33 to 22 today to reject the Equal Rights Amendment to the United States Constitution.

title: Seton Hall Trackmen Win; Pushing Match Mars Meet
CLOSINGS ARE SET BY SPRINGS MILLS
description: FORT MILL, S.C., FEb. 18 (UPI)Springs Mills has announced that it will shut down 17 of its plants for one week beginning next Monday.

title: Bluhdorn Urges OPEC As an Antitrust Target
description: Charles G. Bluhdorn, chairman of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., said yesterday that the conglomerate had begun a legal study to determine whether the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries might be subject to prosecution under United States antitrust laws.

title: New York Tech Wins. 8176
description: New York Tech snapped a 5252 tie with three straight field goals and went on to defeat Brooklyn College, 8176, last night in a Knickerbocker Conference basketball game on the loser's court. Earl Thomas of Brooklyn led all scorers with 27 points.

title: HEALTH PERIL SEEN IN POLLUTION DEVICE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) A medical researcher warned the Government today that it would be risking a widespread health hazard if it allowed exhaust control devices now being placed on cars to spew sulphuric acid into the air.

title: More Exchanges Join Tape Quotation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it had granted permission to the Boston, Cincinnati and Detroit Stock Exchanges to join the consolidated tape quotation network already in operation among the nation's other leading stock exchanges.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Easiest Food in the World to Cook? Perhaps It's Persian
Squeeze on Farmers' 1975 Profits Seen
