description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Agriculture Department warned farmers today that they might face an uncomfortable squeeze between rising costs and declining prices this year, with a resulting drop in income.

title: Man Cleared in Abduction Of Boy, 7, From Rutherford
description: NEWARK, Feb. 18a 23year  old Rutherford bachelor who took a neighbor's 7yearold son on a twoandahalf month journey without the consent of the child's parents was exonerated today of Federal kidnapping charges.

title: Turnpike Agency To Propose a Rise Of 19.3% in Tolls
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced yesterday that it planned to recommend to Governor Byrne an immediate turnpike toll increase averaging 19.3 per cent.

title: MARKET IS LOWER IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: The stock market, although it rebounded from a sluggish start yesterday, finished lower in continued active trading.

title: Cheat, Warrior Says After Knicks Win Here
State Is Urged to Join 6 Others In Suit Challenging Relief Curb
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18Abe Lavine, State Commissioner of Social Services, today urged New York to join six other states in a suit against a Federal program that threatens to withhold millions of dollars from states that are deemed to have too many ineligible or overpaid recipients on their welfare rolls.

title: Ramirez Trounces Emerson
Pro Tennis Defies Peril Of Inflation
description: This is the week in which more tennis balls are being pounded, more linesmen bawled out and more tempers are flaring than at any other time on the winter professional tours.

title: 33 MINES CLOSED BY ANGRY WORKERS
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va. Feb. 18  Disgruntled members of the United Mine Workers who have not yet received copies of the new wage contract closed 33 mines in the southern West Virginia coal fields today.

title: Underground Atlanta Complex Is Beset by Problems
description: ATLANTAA1, a good old boy from Dallas, had a hig grin on his face, like a horse eating briars. Shimmying in front of his ringside table at the Grecian Goddess Restaurant, a belly dancer deftly wrapped a piece of gossamer pink fabric around his head and down over his shoulders. creating a fanciful burnoose and turning him into a slightly bemused sheik in lace mufti.

title: Bridge:
Developing Nations Finish Plan to Raise Share of Economy
description: ALGIERS, Feb. 18 (UPI)A conference of 104 developing nations finished work today, on a program to raise their share of the world's economy from 7 per cent to 25 per cent by the end of the century.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: MIRING IS GIVEN KEY TORY POSITION
description: LONDON, Feb. 18Margaret Thatcher, the Conservatives new leader, has brought one of the party's bestknown figures. out from semiretirement and given him a major post.

title: Audley Farm Posts 3 Victories in Row
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Feb. 18 (AP)Audley Farm Stable, its trainer, Mark Wallerstedt, and Burl McBride, the jockey, scored three straightvictories today at Garden State Park, including the eighthrace feature event with a frontrunning effort by Star Fanny. It was the second victory of the year for Star Fanny, who was a twolength winner over Charlie's Red Head.

title: Mother Fights to Teach Boy, 6, Reading at Home
description: Why can't Johnny read? His mother says it is because the school system requires children to memorize rather than sound out words.

title: Young ExPro Smooths Details To Keep Bowling Tour Rolling
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 18 Tournament play in the $60,000 Long Island open at the Garden City Bawl doesn't officially begin until tomorrow, but one of the most important members of the Professional Bowlers Association tour has already been hard at work for a couple of days.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Dauphin County Judge in Harrisburg, Pa., recessed until March 6 a hearing for a Philadelphia teenager accused with his father in a threestate crime spree. Judge William W. Lipsitt of the Juvenile Court also said Michael Ka!linger, 13 years old, would undergo psychiatric and psychological examinations as part of the hearing to determine if he was a delinquent.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Feb. 18 (Reuters)Ecuadors oil income last year was about $414million compared with $220million in 1973, the Ecuadorean Finance Ministry said today. Oil shipments fell by an undisclosed amount in 1974 from about 70 million/ barrels in 1973.

title: Kallinger Boy to Undergo Tests
description: A Dauphin County Judge in Harrisburg, Pa., recessed until March 6 a hearing for a Philadelphia teenager accused with his father in a threestate crime spree. Judge William W. Lipsitt of the Juvenile Court also said Michael Kallinger, 13 years old, would undergo psychiatric and psychological examinations as part of the hearing to determine if he was a delinquent.

title: ERIC BURDON IS BACK WITH NEW ROCK BAND
description: Eric Burdon, who was at the Bottom Line for a twonight stand beginning Monday, has been a force in rock music for more than 10 years, first with the Animals and then with War. But throughout the nineteensixties he was enmeshed in battles with his record company, and finally he retired to the desert to give himself a break from music and to brood about the films he wanted to make.

title: Missionaries, in New Role, Are Amazon Indians Buffer
description: YARINACOCHA, Peru  Brownskinned children dived into the green Ucayali River to escape the mosquitoes swarming out of the jungle underbrush. Older Indians in dugout canoes stared silently at the waters, waiting for the fish to enter the crude string nets.

title: Soviet MIG23 Shipment To Egyptians Is Reported
description: The Soviet Union has resumed the shipment of advanced weapons to Egypt by delivering six MIG23 fighters, according to United States intelligence sources.

title: WINE TALK
description: If you really want to know who drinks what in the world and how much, you have to ask the Dutch.

title: Red Smith
description: If you can't heat them in the alley, you can't beat them on the ice.'Conn Smythe, a patron saint of ice hockey.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Undewriters headed by Goldman, Sachs & Co. made secondary offering of 718,000 common shares of the Ralston Purina Company common at $42 a share. The shares being sold are for the account of the National Life and Accident Insurance Company, a subsidiary of the NLT Corporation.

title: The Emphasis Is on the Yogurt in Mrs. Manocherian's Recipes
description: A PERSIAN SPINACH OMELET (Coocoo)

title: Skyscraper Renovation
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 18 (UPI)Gov. Christopher S. Bond said today the state was ready to proceed with renovating St. Louis Wainwright Building, one of the first skyscrapers in the nation, into a state office building. The building was constructed in 1891.

title: Harvester Profit Up
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Advertising
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies, which was on the verge of financial disaster seven years ago, has just become the first advertising and marketing company to pass $1billion in annual billings

title: African CountriesPlanning Financial Aid for the P.L.O.
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 18 (Reuters)Foreign ministers of the 43nation Organization of African Unity called today for a new African approach to the Middle East situation, including financial assistance to the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Plato, on Women
description: Are dogs divided into hes and shes, or do they both share equally in hunting and in keeping watch and in the other duties of dogs? or do we entrust to the males the entire and exclusive care of the flocks, while we leave the females at home, under the idea that the bearing and suckling their puppies is labor enough for them?

title: Oil Perils Spain's Shellfish
description: VIGO, Spain, Feh. 18 (Reuters)A big oil slick is threatening to wipe out the rich shellfish beds along the northwest coast of Spain, port officials here said today. They said the oil spill came from a tanker that ran aground off the coast of Portugal, south of Vigo.

title: TV Review
description: The bulk of television programing for children can be classified as either tolerable or intolerable. Subcategories might include effective or ineffective. Once in a great while, for instance tonight at8:30 o'clocx on CBS, the pattern is disrupted by a product that can only be described as utterly charming, for child and nonchild alike. The unusual, half hour is called Maurice Sendak's Really Rosie.

title: For PotassiumRich Diets Bananas Are One Answer
description: One of the richest food sources of potassium is partly defatted almond meal. This might he good news to the thousands of Americans who are obliged to supplement their daily diets with this vital mineral because one of the medications they receive for high blood pressure depletes the body's normal potassium level.

title: Plan Would Tax Cars That Get Low Mileage
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (Reuters)  Democratic Congressmen are considering a stiff tax on cars that get poor gasoline mileage to reduce fuel consumption, the chairman of the House Democratic Task Force said today.

title: Islanders Lose To Sabres, 32
Wide Walkout in Canada
description: OOTOWA, Feb. 18 (UPI) Thousands of federal bluecollar workers today manned picket lines at Government buildings and installations across Canada in a strike for higher wages. Most of the strikers are employed in the Departments of Agriculture, Defense and Transport and the Post Office.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: To hire public rooms to give entertainments is a common practice in New York, a historian wrote a hundred years ago. It is also the source of a stream of consumer complaints to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's Bureau of Consumer Frauds and Protection, according to Stephen Mindell, the bureau's deputy head.

title: JOSEPH BREED 3D, 60, LED AMAX GRAPHICS
description: Joseph B. Breed 3d, manager of publications and graphics at American Metal Climax, Inc., here, died Sunday in New York Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 340 Riverside Drive

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW A DECLINE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market fell yesterday in moderate but slower trading.

title: The Policy Planners
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18There are three popular theories about how Henry Kissinger runs the State Department. The first is that he doesit all by himself, having fired anybody intellectually inferior to himself, which means almost everybody. The second is that he still has a few staff members around but devours them, one by one, usually at breakfast time. And the third is that he doesn't run the State Department at all, but leaves the whole thing to his principal administrative assistant, a patient and driven man named Larry Eagleburger.

title: $2.5Million Botanical Garden Project Begins
description: They began the immense job of renovating the turnofthecentury Conservatory at The New York Botanical Garden yesterday, a $2.5million project that will involve digging up some 8,000 plants and trees and removing every one of the thousands of panes of glass in the great domed rotunda and its ten connecting greenhouses.

title: Gold Trading by Central Bankers Asked
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 18 (Reuters)Central Bankers of the Common Market have proposed to governments in initial twoyear arrangement enabling them to buy and sell gold among themselves and on the free market, provided free market prices remain high, informed sources said today.

title: Greece Striving to Protect Acropolis From Pollution and Tourists
description: ATHENS, Feb. 18  The glory that was Greece is threatened by some of the less glorious aspects of Greece today  traffic, air pollution and tourists.

title: About New York
description: Harold Russell was once a star, and in the first scene of the movie that made him a star he sat in the bomber that was bringing him and Fredric March and Dana Andrews home, unfolded his arms and showed that he had hooks where his handsshould, have been. The movie was The Best Years of Our Lives, and Mr. Russell won an Oscar for it. It was the only movie he ever made.

title: BERGMAN OFFERED RIGHTS AT HEARING
description: Senator Frank Church, chairman of the Senate Special Committee on the Aging, announced yesterday that he had offered Bernard Bergman what he called an unusual package of rights for a witness at a Congressional hearing.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: WARREN P. SMITH

title: Dollar Firmer Abroad
description: BRUSSELS,. Feb. 18 (UPI)The dollar strengthened slightly in most European markets today but dealers said trading was light.

title: C.A.B. AIDE IS DEAD IN APPARENT SUICIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) The director of enforcement of the Civil Aeronautics Board. William Miles Gingery, 36 years old, was found shot to death in his suburban Virginia apartment today, the Fairfax County police said.

title: Arms Negotiators Meet
description: GENEVA, Feb. 18 (Reuters)United States and Soviet negotiator's working on a new agreement limiting offensive nuclear weapons met for almost two hours at the United States diplomatic mission here today, conference sources said.

title: RULES TO WEAKEN BUMPERS ARGUED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety cited new test results today indicating dramatic savings from stronger automobile bumpers, but car manufacturers replied that the economic benefits were illusory.

title: Books of The Times
description: A MONTH OF SUNDAYS. By John Updike. 228 pages. Knopj. $6.95. John Updike is fascinated by religion because it offers such elegant metaphors, such spacious ironies. His clergyman hero, Tom, is thankful for his belief in God, which, he says, has made my life one long glad feast of inconvenience and unreason. Inconvenience and unreason, for Tom, are prerequisites for romanticism, and he gladly feasts on the women in his flock, ministering to their needs according to his own casuistical conception of his calling. As his organist Alicia sees it, he seduces them by writhing on the cross of his doubt, sweating it out on the edge of eternity, putting on a personal psychodrama that is the latest wrinkle in religion.

title: First Boston Saudi Venture
description: The First Boston corporation announced yesterday an agreement with the National Commercial Bank of Saudi Arabia, the largest bank in that country, to establish a joint investment banking department in Jeddah. The joint office will help arrange financing for Saudi and international projects and engage in other general investment banking activities.

title: Lon Nol's Defense Position Continues to Deteriorate
EDUCATION BOARD VETOES I.D CARDS
description: The Board of Education has vetoed, at least for the present. a move to require officials of school parent associations to carry photobearing identification so they can readily prove they are not intruders in school buildings.

title: Ads for Nixon Tapes Lead to Old Speeches
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 18 (AP)Mail order advertisements are appearing in newspapers around the country offering the reader a personal copy of the Nixon tapes for just $10.

title: Soviet MIG23 Shipment To Egyptians Is Reported
description: The Soviet Union has resumed the shipment of advanced weapons to Egypt by delivering six MIG23 fighters, according to United States intelligence sources.

title: Ecuador's Oil Income Up
Legislators, Told of Unfair Penalties, Hear Request for Easing Drug Laws
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18Selling a twoounce cup of orange juice containing a drop of methadone or merely attending a party at which marijuana is passed around can make a New Yorker into a felon, a committee considering changes in the state drug laws was told today.

title: Discovering a Gorky of Greater Depth
description: When Maxim Gorky died in his villa outside Moscow in 1936 at the age of 68, The New York Times said that the  cause of his death was reported as heart disease. In its appreciation of Gorky the day of his death, The Times of London said: The success of his plays was probably due more to admirable presentation by the Moscow Art Theater than to intrinsic merit? Both statements, generally accepted at the time, have in subsequent years been seriously questioned.

title: Psychological Trend Perceived in Arab World Toward Accepting Existence of Israel
description: CAIRO, Feb. 18Foreign diplomats as well as Arab officials and intellectuals feel that a farreaching psychological change has taken place in the Arab world and that there is now a growing, but still conditional, willingness to accept the existence of Israel. The conditionand it is a major oneis, in the words of an Egyptian journalist, Israeli reciprocitythat is, Israel's willingness to withdraw to the lines of before the 1967 war and to accept the right of the Palestinians to create their own state.

title: One Killed, Scores Hurt By Tornado in Georgia
description: FORT VALLEY, Ga., Feb, 18 (AP)  A tornado struck this central Georgia community today, killing one person, injuring scores of others and carving a pat hof destruction four blocks wide and a mile long.

title: British Press Leader Says Pay Cannot Match Inflation
description: LONDON, Feb. 18 (Reuters) A leader of Britain's aling newspaper industry said today that papers could no longer keep wages abreast of inflation.

title: Lawyer Presses Dolphin Ticket Fight
description: MIAMI, Feb. 18 (UPI)Ellis Rubin, an attorney who was denied renewal of his five season tickets for Miami Dolphin home football games, has appealed to Senator John Pastore of Rhode Island, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, and Pete Rozelle, National Football League Commissioner. In letters to the two, Rubin, who appeared before Pastore's committee in 1972, when it was holding hearings on television blackouts of sports events, charged that the Dolphins had put him off the season list in retaliation for the appearance. He has threatened court action.

title: No Defenders of Fair Trade Are Found at Repeal Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The chairman of the Senate Antitrust Subcommittee said today that he had been unable to find anyone willing to take a stand, in public testimony, against repeal of what are known as the fair trade laws.

title: HUNTER THEATERS SEEK $2.5MILLION
description: The Hunter Arts Concert Bureau of Hunter College is undertaking a twoyear campaign to raise $2.5million to renovate the Hunter College Playhouse and the Assembly Hall and to cover deficits resulting from the presentation of concerts and other performing arts events.

title: FORD SEEKS VOTES TO SUSTAIN A VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18A day before the Senate planned to vote to delay President Ford's increased fees on imported crude oil, Mr. Ford lobbied hard today to rally enough Republican votes to sustain his exnected veto of the measure.

title: The Gift Horse's Mouth
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan,  Americans are often regarded as strange creatures and one of their eccentricities, as seen by many other countries, is insistence thaf their public servants should not acept gifts from governments abroad.

title: COURT TO REVIEW COLLEGE AID CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Maryland can give some $500,000 worth of state aid a year to one Methodist college and three Roman Catholic colleges without breaching the constitutional barrier between church and state.

title: Chrysler Sees Quarter Loss
description: DETROIT, Feb. 18  Lynn Townsend, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, predicted today that the company would report a loss for the first quarter of 1975. He said also that Chrysler, the No. 3 auto maker, was continuing to trim down to operate profitably in a reduced car market.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtiantic

title: CHIVU STOICA DIES; EXRUMANIAN LEADER
description: VIENNA, Feb. 18 (Reuters)Chivu Stoica, a longtime Communist revolutionary who was Premier of Rumania from 1955 to 1961, died today at the age of 66, the Rumanian News Agency reported.

title: DISNEY WILL JOIN IN BICENTENNIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Federal Government and Walt Disney Productions jointly an nounced today an $8million, bicentennial extravaganza at the film company's parks in Florida and California.

title: A Rudderless Sailboat Proves a Dream Boat
description: PATCHOGUE, L. I., Feb. 18 A rudderless sailboat under construction on the Patchogue River is helping Michael Krug change the course of his professional life.

title: ANN L. SCOTT DIES; FEMINIST LEADER
description: BALTLMORE, Feb. 18Ann London Scott, vice presidentlegislation of the National Organization for Women, died here last night of cancer at her home. She was 45 years old.

title: House Delays Vote on Bill Raising Senators Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Feb., 18 (UPI) The House leadership held up today immediate consideration of a bill that would allow Senators and their aides to collect $35 a day expenses while traveling in their home states, even on reelection campaigns.

title: Food Prices Down
description: The cost of feeding a family of four dropped slightly last week, O.1 per cent below the previous week's level, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday. It was the first fractional drop in a month.

title: Market Summary
description: AMERICAN EXCHANGE Tuesday, February 18, 1975 (Volume 2,461,495 shares)

title: Here's a Chair That Cradles You
description: That's not a sleeping bag it's a chair, said Steve Kiviat of Atelier International, Ltd., explaining the puffy pad design that stopped traffic at the recent Milan Furniture Fair.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 18The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: 21 Cigarettes
description: More than a year and a half after Federal officials enthusiastically approved a citystate Transportation Control Plan to help clean up the air in New York City, carbon monoxide levels in the central business district are higher than ever.

title: SOVIET PRICE RISE FOR OIL CONFIRMED
description: BERLIN, Feb. 18East Germany's Deputy Premier, Gerhard Weiss, confirmed today that the Soviet Union was asking higher prices for oil and other raw materials from its East bloc trading partners as of this year.

title: Market vs. the State
description: Economics lacks a theory of power. Built on the foundations of Adam Smith's 18thcentury liberalism, contemporary economics either ignores the significance of power or seeksways to minimize the use of power in matters affecting the production. and distribution of wealth.

title: Mishaps Mark Bobsled Trials
description: CERVINIA, Italy, Feb. 18 (AP)Giorgio Alvera of Italy clocked the fastest time today in the second day of trials for the world fourman bobsled championships, escaping a string of accidents that forced cancellation of part of the run. Alvera, who won the twoman championship on Sunday, was timed in 1 minute 9.75 seconds for his run down the 1,540meter Lake Blue Course. He was allowed only one run because of the accidents.

title: Unusual Frozen Foods New and Fabricated
description: They look like ham, sausages. shrimp, eggs, cream, bologna and salami. but they're not. They're new fabricated frozen foods that will soon start showing up in the freezer sections of area supermarkets and some of the items will appeal to those who try to keep a control on their intake of cholesterol and saturated fat.

title: PANEL EXAMINES DEFENSE BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The House Armed Services Committee began today its consideration of the defense budget with a new chairman and eight new members, but otherwise there, appeared to be little change in the panel's traditional attitude of support for the Pentagon.

title: Cavanagh Stresses Need for U.S. Aid
description: Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh told a collectivebargaining arbitration panel yesterday that manpower reduction and other economies would be necessary if the city did not receive increased Federal or state aid or could not enact new taxes to help reduce an anticipated $1.6billion deficit in the 197576 city expense budget.

title: Connecticut and New York Share Of Windfall Put at $690Million
description: Environniental officials in New York and Connecticut estimated yesterday that the two states would eventually receive at least $690million as a result of the Supreme Court deceision that Richard M. Nixon lacked authority to impound $9billion in funds to combat water pollution, an action taken when he was President.

title: Bentley Five Seeded No. 1
description: WALTHAM. Mass., Feb. 18 (UPI)Bentley College, with one loss in its first 20 games, was named the host and top seeded team today of the National Collegiate Athletic Association New England regional college division basketball tournament March 7 and 8. Assumption College of Worcester, last year's regional winner, was seeded second.

title: State's Supreme Court Rejects Petition For $120Million Rise in School Aid
description: TRENTON, Feb. 18  The New Jersey Supreme Court rejetted today a legal move to force the Byrne administratior to spend $120million additional in state aid to public schools.

title: 76 WALLACE BID OPPOSED IN SOUTH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama found himself today in the novel position of fighting direct challenges from fellow Southerners to his credibility as a Presidential candidate.

title: Labor to Shun Role In Political Parties
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb, 18 In what appeared to be a major policy change, George Meany asserted today that the A.F.L.C.I.O. would no longer involve itself in political party affairs and would take no part in the selection of delegates to the Democratic National Convention next year.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: R. NORRIS SHREVE

title: WAGE PROGRESS SEEN IN GERMANY
description: BONN, Feb. 18 Acceptance by two of West Germany's largest unions of annual wage increases of less than 7 per cent appears to have improved the country's chances of pulling out of the current economic slump while still maintaining its low inflation rate of 6 per cent

title: MAYOR OF VENICE QUITS IN DISPUTE
description: ROME, Feb. 18  Giorgio Longo, the Christian Democratic Mayor of Venice, announced his resignation today,reportedly, because of the objections of his party's national leadership to his administration's acceptance of Communist help for a new way of governing.

title: Prisoner, 29, With Less Than a Year to Go Escapes in a Downtown Chase
description: A city prisoner with fess than a year to serve in jail bolted from a corrections officer outside the Criminal Court building on Centre Street yesterday morning and then, raced several blocks through traffic with the officer in pursuit, and escaped through a commercial building.

title: Canadian Official Asserts Police Had Approved F.B.I.'s Informer
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 18 (Reuters) An informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation was alFlowed to infiltrate a proMaoist group in Canada with the approval of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the Canadian Solicitor General, Warren Allmand. conceded today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Student, 23, Stabbed to Death By 3 on Crowded Subway Train
description: A 23yearDold graduate student was fatally stabbed by three teenage robbers on a crowded rushhour subway train in upper Manhattan last night. He died as the train was proceeding directly to the 168thStreet and Broadway station, where emergency personnel had been summoned to carry the young man to the nearby Columbia  Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: Raymond Moley Dies
description: Raymond Moley, a leader of the Brain Trust that shaped President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal, died yesterday in Phoenix, Ariz., at the age of 88. Details on Page 38.

title: Husband Flies to Rome To Join Miss Fedicheva
description: ROME, Feb. 18 (AP)Martin Friedman, American ballet dancer, arrived here tonight for a reunion with his Russian wife, Kaleriya Fedicheva, formerly of Leningrad's Kirov Ballet.

title: Senate Democrats Agree On Plan to Spur Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  Democratic leaders in the Senate agreed unanimously today to a program designed to stimulate the economy this year, with energy conservation measures given a much lower priority.

title: 5 Youths Die in Crash
description: DOUBLE SPRINGS, Ala., Feb. 18 (UPI)Five young persons from this little Alabama town burned to death last night after their car ran off a road, overturned and burst into flames.

title: CAMPAIGN REFORM LAGS DESPITE LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) Though Congress passed a new campaign finance law last year to help prevent future Watergate scandals, there is still no commission to enforce it, no staff has been hired and no regulations have been written.

title: Aussies Call Off S. African Tour
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 18 (UPI)The Australian cricket tour of South Africa scheduled for the 197576 season has been canceled, the chairman of the Australian cricket board, Tim Caldwell, said today. He said the board did not want to go ahead with it in defiance of the Government's wishes. The Government is opposed to tours of South Africa by Australians until teams there are selected on a multiracial basis. Prime Minister Gough Whitlam said in Canberra that If Australia was to send an eleven to South Africa, it is quite likely no Australian eleven would be received in Caribbean countries, India or Pakistan, nor would teams from those countries visit Australia.

title: Nevada Senate Panel Backs Equal Rights Amendment
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Feb. 18 (UPI)  The Equal Rights Amendment cleared the Nevada Senate's Judiciary Committee today and went to the floor for a showdown vote in the Legislature.

title: 3 C.A.B. Members Would Give Hearings for New Air Service
description: WASHINGTON, Feb., 18 Three members of the Civil Aeronautics Board testified today that they would vote to grant hearings to airlines applying for a license to provide new air service in the United States.

title: Bird Massacre
description: The United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia had upheld the legality of killing millions of starlings, grackles and redwing blackbirds that roost near military installations in Kentucky and Tennessee but suggested the Army delay the slaughter until scientists had time to evaluate its environmental consequences. Yesterday, with extraordinary speed, presumably after consulting a panel of scientists, the Army approved this ruthless and questionable procedure.

title: India Cautions U.S. Against Resuming Arms Supplies to Pakistan
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 18India has officially warned the United States that any decision to resume arms supplies to Pakistan would jeopardize IndianAmerican relations.

title: Handicapped Workers Face Layoff by Goodwill
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 18 (UPI)Goodwill Industries, Inc., announced today that it would lay off 12 handicapped workers of its staff of 60 because of a decline in contributions of used items for the workers to repair.

title: BID TO REORGANIZE MADE BY REA, INC.
description: REA Express, Inc., the nation's largest ground and air express service, filed a petition in Federal District Court here yesterday for a voluntary bankruptcy arrangement to pay its debts.

title: Rare Filipino Bambo6 Organ Plays Again
description: BONN, Feb. 18A Philippine bambo organ, a historic instrument built in a parish church by a Spanish missionary a century and a half ago, trumpeted its return to the musical world today after more than a year of restoration here.

title: PHOTON BANKRUPT, U.S. COURT DECLARES
description: After failing to devise an acceptable repayment plan for its creditors, Photon, Inc., was declared bankrupt yesterday by the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Mass.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Backs Ward for State Post
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18The state chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. in a turnabout, today strongly supported Governor Carey's nomination of Benjamin Ward as State Commissioner of Correction.

title: U.S. ARMS EXPERTS MAY AID KUWAITIS
description: KUWAIT, Feb. 18Kuwait, concerned about the possibility of a confrontation with Iraq, intends to bring United States military experts here to instruct her armed forces in the maintenance and use of the more than $250million in Americanmissiles, planes and military transport vehicles bought in December, highly placed sources said today.

title: Movie Security Group Will Hunt for Pirates
description: The country's major movie producers and distributors plan to establish a special security organization to ferret out and help prosecute pirates who obtain prints of films and show them illegally around the world.

title: Abductor of Rutherford Boy, 7, Cleared of Kidnapping Charge
description: NEWARK, Feb. 18A 23yearold Rutherford bachelor who took a neighbor's 7yearold son on a twoandahalfmonth journey without the conSent of the child's parents was exonerated today of Federal dnapping charges.

title: A.M.C. Set to Resume Its Output Next Monday
description: DETROIT, Feb. 18 (UPI)The American Motors Corpoiation, which virtually halted auto production this week, will recall 8,500 workers from temporary layoffs and resume normal operations next Monday, the company announced today.

title: HIGH COURT KILLS NIXON'S BLOCKING OF WATER FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that President Nixon did not have the right to impound $9billion in water pollution funds approved by Congress because the legislation authorizing the program had not given him that authority.

title: Turnpike Agency To Propose a Rise Of 19.3% in Tolls
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced yesterday that it planned to recommend to Governor Byrne an immediate turnpike toll increase averaging 19.3 per cent.

title: U.S. ARMS EXPERTS MAY AID KUWAITIS
description: KUWAIT, Feb. 18Kuwait, concerned about the possibility of a confrontation with Iraq, intends to bring United States military experts here to instruct her armed forces in the maintenance and use of the more than $250million in American missiles, planes and military transport vehicles bought in December, highly placed sources said today.

title: Hospital Reopening In Suffolk County After 16Day Strike
description: Hospital trustees and striking union employes agreed late last night to reopen the Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenpoint at 7 A.M. today, ending a 16day strike.

title: Ashe, Borg Triumph
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Feb. 18 (AP)Arthur Ashe breezed to victory today but Bjorn Borg had to struggle in the opening round of a W.C.T. tournament.

title: ISRAEL'S PRESIDENT CANCELS NEPAL TRIP
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 18  The Israeli Government announced today that President Ephraim Katzir had canceled his scheduled participation in the coronation of King Birendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva of Nepal.

title: Richard Crossman's Son Found Hanged in Britain
Chemical Bank Cuts Prime Rate to 8%
description: The Chemical Bank reduced yesterday its basic interest charge on business loans to 8 per cent from 9 per cent the first time since last spring that a major bank has movedthe prime rate so low. Some analysts see the prime falling to 7 per cent by the end of March. This halfpoint reduction by Chemical, the nation's sixth largest bank in deposits, occurs during a period of weakening loan demand and follows ongoing efforts by the Federal Reserve to lower the general structure of interest. rates in a slack economy. The prime, or the charge offered to the most creditworthy clients, is the rate accorded most public prominence.

title: 3 Die as Copters Collide
description: EL TORO MARINE AIR STATION, Calif., Feb. 18 (UPI)Four crew members killed today in the collisionof two Marine Carps helicopters on a training flight over the Santa And Mountains. One of the CH53 helicopters, the largest in the Marine fleet, was able to land on a ridege near Majestic Canyon, but the other spiraled down out of control, according to a witness.

title: 28 New Jersey Senators Ordered to Trial For Closing Caucus to Woman Colleague
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 18A Federal judge today ordered 28 Democratic State Senators and four aides to stand trial here on charges of having violated the constitutional rights of the 29th Democratic Senator, Alene S. Ammond, when they barred her from their party caucus.

title: Larrieu: A Woman On the Run
description: Francie Larrieu is confident about breaking four minutes some day, but she may have to settle for 1,500 meters, not the more familiar mile.

title: AwardWinning Toys: Nonsexist, Nonracist and Peaceful
description: A consumer watchdog group called Public Action Coalition on Toys (PACT) changed its tack from picketing to prizes yesterday, when it announced its first annual awards to toy manufacturers.

title: Shah Hints at Assurances Of Oil Supplies for Israel
description: PARIS, Feb. 18Shah Mohammed Rita Pahlevi of Iran, after a discussion today with Secretary of State Kissinger in Zurich, appeared to assure the Israelis that they could rely on additional Iranian oil supplies if they relinquished occupied Egyptian oilfields in the next round of negotiations about the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Watchmen Had Cut Off Alarms at Milan Gallery
description: ROME, Feb. 18The five watchmen on duty at Milan's Gallery of Modem Art when 28 paintings were stolen early yesterday had disconnected thee, electronic burglar alarm system, probably to be able to sleep, the museum's director said today.

title: Stationary Cyclist Claims Record
description: Jack Simes 3d of Closter, N.J., completed his 24hour stationary, roller bicycle riding marathon to nowhere yesterday and claimed a record of 681 miles. The 32yearold Olympic cyclist, a featured performer at the International Cycle Show at the New York Coliseum, topped the old mark of 421 miles at 11:30 P.M. Monday. After a rest period of 5 hours 26 minutes, he resumed riding the bike and completed the 24hour run at an average speed of 28 miles an hour.

title: At Wodehouse Funeral, Friends And Neighbors Laud His Humor
description: REMSENBURG, L. T., Feb. 18  P. G. Wodehouse was eulogized by his friends today for bringing humor and happiness into the lives of millions and yet being unaffected by the fame that his work brought him.

title: SENATE ASKS AID OF FORD IN INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence agreed unanimously today to ask President Ford to instruct Federal agencies In cooperate fully with the Senate investigation of the Intellicence community.

title: Polaroid's Net Slumped 55.8% in the 4th Quarter
Queens Man Shoots Four in One Family, Then Kills Himself.
description: A 27yearold Queens man killed himself early yesterday after shooting four members of one family in the Ridgewood section of Queens following a longstanding personal feud, the police. said.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Raymond Moley, Roosevelt Aide, Dies; Brain Trust Leader Coined New Deal
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 18 (AP) Raymond Moley, who coined the term New Deal during President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Administration in 1933 and who was a leader of the original Brain Trust, died today. He was 88 years old.

title: Mileage Meter Tampering
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration called today on 36 states to join with the Federal Government in eliminating tampering of automobile mileage meters. Dr. James B. Gregory, the agency administrator, said the effort was needed to halt this Continuing, multimillion dollar fraud on the public.

title: Convicted Boston Doctor Put on Probation for Year
description: BOSTON, Feb. 18Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin, convicted of manslaughter in the death of a male fetus after a legal abortion, was sentenced today to one year's probation.

title: The Toy Awards
description: Here are the 10 manufacturers and their toys commended by the Public Action Coalition on Toys (PACT):

title: 28 New Jersey Senators Ordered to Trial For Closing Caucus to Woman Colleague
description: CAMDEN. N. J., Feb. 18A Federal judge today ordered 28 Democratic State Senators and four aides to stand trial here on charges of having violated the constitutional rights of the 29th Democratic Senator, Alene S. Ammond, when they barred her from their party caucus.

title: Raymond Moley Dies
description: Raymond Moley, a member of the brain trust that shaped President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal, died yesterday in Phoenix, Ariz., at the age of 88. Details on Page 38.

title: Mary Lou Williams, at Piano, Leads Her Jazz Mass at St. Patrick's
description: The first jazz performance given in St. Patrick's Cathedral, a jazz mass composed and performed by Mary Lou Williams, was heard yesterday afternoon by more than 3,000 persons who filled the Cathedral's pews and stood four and five deep along the sides and at the rear of the huge edifice.

title: Senate Democrats Agree On Plan to Spur Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  Democratic leaders in the Senate agreed unanimously today to a program designed to stimulate the economy this year, with energy conservation measures given a much lower priority.

title: High Court to Decide on Insider Deals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal law prohibiting insider trading applies to companies that sell certain assets in exchange fer securities, then profit on the subsequent sale of the securities.

title: Ads for Nixon Tapes Lead to Old Speeches
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 18 (AP)Mail order advertisements are appearing in newspapers around the country offering the reader a personal copy of the Nixon tapes for just $10.

title: Mills Back in the Hospital For Further Examination
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, has been readmitted to Bethesda Naval Hospital for further tests, and his wife. Polly, has entered a hospital for a physical examination and minor surgery, a Mills aide said today.

title: Ethiopian Strongman Declares Six Million Are Ready to Fight
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 18The deputy chairman of Ethiopia's ruling military council declared today that this nation has more than six million volunteer militiamen prepared to sacrifice themselves to prevent the dismantling of Ethiopia.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BANBURY, England, Feb. 18 (AP)The 17yearold son of the late Richard Crossman, an outspoken Labor party Cabinet minister, was found hanged with a judo belt today.

title: 2 More Abortion Inquiries on L.I.
description: Two additional investigations were reported into allegations by an antiabortion group that a fetus allegedly aborted at the Nassau County Medical Center at East Meadow, L. I., had beeen denied lifesupport systems. The investigations are being conducted by the United States Attorney's office for the Eastern District in Brooklyn and the medical center. The Long Island Coalition for Life had complained that the fetus had been a victim of infanticide.

title: Shah Hints at Assurances Of Oil Supplies for Israel
description: PARIS, Feb. 18Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran, after a discussion today with Secretary of State Kissinger in Zurich, appeared to assure the Israelis that they couldrely on additional Iranian oil supplies if they relinquished occupied Egyptian oilfields in the next round of negotiations about the Sinai Peninsula.

title: PANEL TO ASSESS OZONE PROBLEM
BLEAK VIEW TAKEN IN MATHEWS DANCES
description: The emotional spectrum of Fred Mathews's dances extends from black to dark gray. Utter despair occasionally cedes place to abandoned hope, but at the most optimistic the outlook is bleak.

title: Queens Museum Drops Director
description: The board of directors of the Queens Museum last night voted 13 to 3 not to renew the contract of its controversial director, Kenneth Kahn, who recently charged that the museum was run by a closed corporation, representing a narrow spectrum of the community. Mr. Kahn said that the board had decided to terminate his contract forthwith, for cause, but that he had not yet been informed of the cause.

title: Doubleday Sets Up $2,500 Fiction Prize
description: An annual $2,500 cash prize for fiction has been established by Doubleday in the name of LeBaron R. Barker Jr., its executive editor for almost a quarter of a century, starting in 1945. The award, open to writers of all nationalities, is designed to encourage an author whose work represents a distinct advance in his craftsmanship.

title: Market Place
description: Attempts by corporations to buy out their public shareholders and go private are often met with despair by the minority owners.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: MILTON E. HARRIS

title: House Panel Backs a Diluted Bill for Lower Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) A House Banking subcommittee approved today diluted legislation ordering the Federal Reserve Board to take action to lower interest rates.

title: Concert: Perle's Songs
description: George Perle's Songs of Praise and Lamentation, an ambitious three  movement work for choruses and orchestra that received its premiere performance last night at Carnegie Hall, is dedicatedto the memory of Noah Greenberg, founder of the New York Pro Musica. Perhaps that was why one was most taken with the score's final section, whose allusions to the Renaissance composers Binchois, Ockeghem and Josquin called to mind Mr. Greenberg's long and successful proselytizing in their behalf in his oldmusic programs.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Heavy selling pushed prices of soybeans, meal and oil down sharply yesterday. Many contracts closed down the daily limit on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: BERGMAN OFFERED RIGHTS AT HEARING
News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1975

title: MARITIME AID BILL PASSED BY CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Congress completed action today on a bill that would authorizebut not appropriate$562million for the Federal Maritime Administration, mainly as subsidies for ship construction and operation.

title: 3 Governors Assail Ford on Recession
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Democratic Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut variously accused President Ford today of proposing an economic program based upon planned unemployment, failure to address the economic undertow and failure to appreciate the full impact of this depression.

title: People and Business
description: Government housing officials are voicing increasing confidence of a turnaround soon in the depressed housing industry. The latest is James L. Mitchell, Under Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, who said in Washington yesterdaythat forcasters now agree that housing, after experiencing the worst decline since World War II, will reach a turning point within the next few months.

title: Dresden Bombing Exhibit Shut in Austria as ProNazi
description: SALZBURG, Austria, Feb. 18 (Reuters)  The rector of Salzburg University today shut down an exhibition devoted to the Ailed bombing of Dresden 30 years ago, saying it was aimed at glorifying the Nazis.

title: George G. Ellner, Pioneer In UltraViolet Purification
description: George G. Elinor, executive vice president and director of engineering for UltraViolet Purification Systems, Inc., of Scarsdale, N.Y., died Monday while visiting White Plains. Mr. Ellner was 75 years old and lived at 5 Tudor Place, Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: 3 Governors Assail Ford on Recession
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Democratic Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut variously accused President Ford today of proposing an economic program based upon planned unemployment, failure to address the economic undertow and failure to appreciate the full impact of this depression.

title: Newspaper Joins Dix Unit
description: CAMBRIDGE, Ohio, Feb. 18 (UPI)The Daily Jeffersonian has joined the Dix Newspapers group, Robert W. Amos of the Jeffersonian and Raymond Dix of Dix Newspapers in Wooster announced today.

title: The Universities Return
description: In an important but little publicized meeting last week, President Ford demonstrated a desire to rebuild the bridge between the White House and higher education. By giving a group of university leaders the opportunity to explain how the universities can once again be placed in the nation's service, Mr. Ford took an important step to lift the curtain of distrust that his predecessor had brought down between Administration and academia.

title: East Carolina Picks Aide
description: GREENVILLE, N. C., Feb. 18 (AP)Richard Kupec rejoined the East Carolina University football coaching staff today. Kupec will serve as offensive line coach.

title: Elliott Sullivan Memorial
description: A memorial service for Elliott Sullivan, the stage and screen actor who died last June 4 at the age of 66, will be held Sunday at 6 P.M. at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. Among those scheduled to pay tribute to Mr. Sullivan are Ossie Davis, Ruby Dee and Pete Seeger, the entertainers.

title: Military in Lisbon Says It Will Retain A Role in Politics
description: LISBON, Feb. 18, (Reuters) The Armed Forces Movement, Portugal's dominant political power since the coup last April, announced today that it would continue to play an active role in politics after elections this year.

title: Hungary Strikes It Rich With Restruck Old Gold Coins
description: BUDAPESTSpurred by surging American demand, the state mint of Communist Hungary has, been striking gold replicas of Habsburgera coins in such quantity that they were Hungary's major export to the United States in 1974.

title: Polis's Goal Gives Rangers A 22 Standoff With Scouts
Superstars Title Won By Simpson
Handicapped Workers Face Layoff by Goodwill
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 18 (UPI)Goodwill Industries, Inc., announced today that it would lay off 12 handicapped workers of its staff of 60 because of a decline in contributions of used items for the workers to repair.

title: $2.5 Million Botanical Garden Project Begins
Delaware Teachers Strike Over Pay
description: DOVER, Del., Feb. 18The state's largest teachers union went on strike today, shutting 10 of the state's 26 school districts and crippling eight other districts. The union, the Delaware State Education Association, is seeking an 8 per cent pay increase.

title: Hatfield Says Food Aid Sent Abroad Should Be Humanitarian, Not Political
description: WASHLNGTON, Feb. 18 Senator Mark 0. Hattield, Republican of Oregon, proposed today that all American food aid abroad go to the most needy regardless of their or our political inclinations as long as a world food shortage continued.

title: POLICEMEN FIGHT PLANNED LAYOFFS
description: JERSEY CITY Feb. 18  More than 100 members of the Jersey City Police Department, most of whom would be directly affected by Mayor Paul T. Jordan's plan for a police layoff, met in a closed meeting here today to map strategy aimed at preventing the move. Leaders of the Police Officers Benevolent Association said that another meeting would be held Thursday at a place and time to be announced. Plans to oppose the mayor's decision are to be disclosed then.

title: Student, 23, Stabbed to Death By 3 on Crowded Subway Train
description: A 23yearold graduate student was fatally stabbed by three teenage robbers on a crowded rushhour subway train in upper Manhattan last night. He died as the south bound train skipped a stop to proceed directly to the 168th Street and Broadway station, where emergency personnel had been summoned to carry the young man to the nearby ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center.

title: Palace by Seashore To Be Sold by Auction
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 18 (UPI)The Palace by theSeashore, the 450  room Dennis Hotel, will be auctioned on Saturday, a spokesman said today.

title: BADILLO ATTACKS CAPITAL BUDGET
description: In an attack that produced echoes of the last mayoral election campaign, Representative Herman Badillo accused the Beame administration yesterday of failing to provide essential services for the people of New York City.

title: 10 Teams Accept Division II Berths
description: MISSION, Kan., Feb. 18 (UPI)Ten basketball teams accepted bids today to play in the National Collegiate Division II basketball championship, which begins with regional tournaments March 7 and 8.

title: Monday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press

title: LAWYER IS INDICTED ON 5 PERJURY COUNTS
description: A defense lawyer was indicted yesterday on charges that he had lied before a 1971 Manhattan grand jury investigating whether he had bribed judges, prosecutors and police officers to fix criminal cases in Manhattan.

title: Untouchable Wages
description: With refreshing candor, George Meany acknowleages that his forecasts of how high unemployment is likely to go are pulled out of the air the same air that generates the subjective estimates of White House economic advisers and all the other seers currently giving Congress divergent prescriptions on the precise degree of Federal stimulus needed to revive the economy.

title: Grant Reports It Is Considering Sale of 50.2% Interest in Zeller's
description: The W. T. Grant Company, financially troubled retail chain, announced yesterday that it was considering the sale of its 50.2 per cent interest in Zeller's, Ltd., a Canadian varietystore chain, to build up cash and to reduce its indebtedness.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OUR TOWN The World and The New Yorker, an exhibition of original cover paintings, cartoon drawings and books originally prepared for the magazine, all celebrating the magazine's 50th anniversary, opens free to the public today at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, (TE 86690). The club, a private organization of bibliophiles, traditionally presents displays on books and the book arts. Over the years, The New Yorker has initiated more than 800 books. The art samplings and books in the exhibition were chosen from 2,600 issues of the magazine.

title: Bryan Ferry: Enfant Terrible of Rock
description: An Old movie was flickering in sepia tones on TVsomething to do with a Shirley Templeesque little girl in spangles carrying a hoop and looking grimly chipper. Sitting on the couch of his.Drake Hotel room and casting a casual eye in its direction was Bryan Ferry, elegant and unruffled even though he and his band, Roxy Music, had just that minute arrived from a series of six performances in Canada to begin a 19date United States tour the next night in Philadelphia (they will be at the Academy of Music on 14th Street here Friday night).

title: Tribute to Logan Set for March 9
description: Writers, composers and stage personalities will participate in A Gala Tribute to Joshua Logan on March 9 at the Imperial Theater for the benefit of Friends of the Theater and Music Collection of the Museum of the City of New York. Anna Sosenko is producing the show, to be staged by Donald Saddler.

title: 22 Hurt in Door Mishaps Since 1968, Says L.I.R.R.
Stage: Conga Mania
Convicted Boston Doctor Put on Probation for Year
description: BOSTON, Feb. 18Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin, convicted of manslaughter in the death of a male fetus after a legal abortion, was sentenced today to one year's probation.

title: Girl Shot Dead in College Cafeteria; Slaying Charged to Rejected Suitor
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 18A young man described as la rejected suitor allegedly shot and killed a 27yearold freshman coed at Marist College this evening after cornering her in a cafeteria office as she tried to telephone for help.

title: HIGH COURT KILLS NIXON'S BLOCKING OF WATER FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that President Nixon did not have the right to impound $9billion in water pollution funds approved by Congress because the legislation authorizing the program had not given him that authority.

title: People in Sports
description: Larry Csonka, Jim Kiick and Paul Warfield of the Miami Dolphins asserted yesterday that they would be playing in the World Football League next season. The authority for that belief is John Bassett Jr., the Toronto millionaire who signed the trio to a $3.5million contract to play in the W.F.L.

title: Lessons of Watergate
CARGILL ACQUIRES A PURINA FACILITY
description: Cargill, Inc., the large Minneapolisbased grain company, has purchased the turkeyprocessing operations and related facilities of the Ralston Purina Company of St. Louis,it was announced yesterday. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The purchase by Cargill, which was already involved in the poultry business to a small extent, involved two facilities, one at California, Mo., and the other at Springdale, Ark. The two operations employ about 1,000 persons.

title: Army Gains 3d Victory
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 18 (AP)Bobby Jones scored a seasonhigh 25 points as Army's basketball team posted an 84.62 victory over PittJohnsown tonight. It was Army's third triumph in 22 games.

title: 3 Seats Sold by Big Board
description: Three memberships were sold yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange for $90,000, $93,000 and $95,000, the exchange announced. The previous sale was for $85,000 on Feb. 5.

title: U.S. Imported No Gold at First of Month
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (Reuters)The United States imported no gold in the week ended Feb. 7, Thomas Wolfe, director of the Treasury's. Office of Domestic Gold and Silver Operations, said today.

title: Brookings to Recall Book With Material Without Attribution
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Brookings Institution, in a distressing and unprecedented incident, is recalling and destroying a book by a Georgetown University law professor who is a former United States tariff Commission chairman.

title: Notes on People
description: Two of the five top members of the United States mission to the United Nations will be leaving soon. William E. Schaufele Jr., the thirdranking delegate since 1973, will become inspector general of the Foreign Service,heading a force of 45 inspectors to oversee 132 American embassies, 9 missions, the liaison office in Peking, 45 consulates and 74 consulgeneral offices. A career diplomat, he joined the mission in 1971.

title: Lord Geddes, 67, Headed British Travel Association
description: Lord Geddes, who as chairman of the British Travel Association from 1964 to 1970, helped to promote tourist travel to Britain, died at sea on Feb. 2. He was 67 years old.

title: Curtail Recruiting and Help High Schools, McGuire Asks
description: Minutes after leaving his home in the Milwaukee suburb of Brookfield each morning, Al McGuire reaches Capital Drive.

title: TV Guide Changes Inaccurate Ad
description: In a directmail subscriptionrenewal pitch. Triangle Publications, in behalf of TV Guide, made the statement little more than a penny a day delivers copies right to your home each week. The National Advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus saw that at the annual subscription rate of 59.50 the cost would actually be a little more than 2.6 cents a day. At the request of the division Triangle has corrected the situation.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES FOR SEX EQUALITY
Plan for Sugar Refinery Is Supported by Alampi
description: BRIDGETON, Feb. 18A deal by a group of South Jersey farmers to buy an idle sugar refinery in Easton, Me., and grow sugar beets for processing there gained added support here today when the State Secretary of Agriculture, Phillip Alampi, said he was in favor of the project.

title: 36 Families Begin Picking Up the Pieces After East Orange Fire Destroys Homes
description: EAST ORANGE, Feb. 18 Yesterday afternoon, Carol Bullard and her 15monthold baby were watching television in their apartment at 321 Park Avenue near the Garden State Parkway when Mrs. Bullard becan to smell smoke.

title: Freed Korean Cleric Applauded At a Cathedral Service in Seoul
G.M. Recalls 220,000 Cars
description: DETROIT. Feb. 18 (UPI)The General Motors Corporation said today it was recalling about 220,000 intermediate sized 1975 model Chevrolets, Pontiacs, Oldsmobiles. Buicks and GMC Sprints because of a defect that could cause a rear wheel to fall off.

title: Recital
description: Joseph Villa, who last played here two seasons ago, pursued an interesting idea in his piano recital in Alice Tully Hall on Monday night. Pieces by Schuman, Beethoven, Schubert and Liszt himself were sandwiched between transcriptions by Liszt of other works by the first three composers. It provided a rare view of the interplay of Liszt's mind with the music of others, as well as a contrast between his imaginative but often fustian style and the solid quality of theirs.

title: Mary Lou Williams, at Piano, Leads Her Own Jazz Mass at St. Patrick's
Economic Anomalies
Abortion Error
description: The complex and sensitive issue of legal abortion in this countryalready the subject of bitter controversy has been made more agonizing than ever by the almost unbelievable decision of the Boston jury in the Edelin case.

title: Secretary of Army Approves Bird Kill At Kentucky Fort
description: FT. CAMPBELL, Ky., Feb. 18 (UPI)Secretary of the Army Howard Callaway gave his approval today for the destruction of millions of blackbirds roosting on this sprawling post on the KentuckyTennessee border.

title: Senate Unit Votes to Set Up ForeignAid Subcommittee
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today to establish a new subcommittee for foreignaid legislation.

title: Labor to Shun Role In Political Parties
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 18 In what appeared to be a major policy change, George Meany asserted today that the A.F.L.C.I.O. would no longer involve itself in political party affairs and would take no part in the selection of delegates to the Democratic National Convention next year.

title: A.T. Aide Tells House Panel of Wide Eavesdropping by the Bell System
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  The American Telephone and Telegraph Company eavesdropped on some 1.5 million to 1.8 million telephone conversations, which included an estimated 300,000 to 400,000 private conversations between customers, in its effort to stop toll fraud, a senior Bell System attorney testified today.

title: California Standard Is Leaving Namibia
description: The Standard Oil Company of California, the last of five American oil companies that have been urged by church groups to pull out of SouthWest Africa, which is also known as Namibia, has withdrawn from offshore oil exploration there.

title: McCord Declares That Mrs. Mitchell Was Forcibly Held
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI)James W. McCord Jr., a convicted Watergate conspirator, said today that Mrs. John N. Mitchell was basically kidnapped in 1972 to keep her ignorant of Watergate.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press

title: TAXCUT BILL GETS PANEL'S APPROVAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The House Ways and Means Committee gave its final approval today to a $21.3billion antirecession taxcut bill and in the process apparently set the stage for a fight next week over repeal of the oil depletion allowance.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Engagements
description: BILLICKDe LEIR

title: Ward Calls Blackness a Factor In Selection, but Asserts His Fitness
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19  I'm going to admit itI know that my blackness was a factor in the Governor's selecting me. Benjamin Ward told a Senate committee considering his nomination as Correction Commissioner today. But I don't think he would have put me in this job unless he thought I could do it.

title: 3 Mayors Call on Congress to Strengthen Job Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Three Mayors from the New York area told a House subcommittee today that the public  service employment program was just a drop in the bucket and badly in need of revision.

title: Textile Workers In Wallace, N.C., Reject Union Tie
description: WALLACE, N. C., Feb. 197The 12year drive by the Textile Workers Union of America to organize the J. P. Stevens Company's Southern textile mills stalled again today when employes here voted not to affiliate with the union. However, union officials indicated they would probably file unfair labor practice charges with the National Labor Relations Board to have the election voided.

title: St. John's Early Drive Subdues St. Joseph's
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP)  Beaver Smith and Kevin Cluess led a 173 spurt in the first half that propelled St. John's to 9273 victory tonight over St. Joseph's in the second game of a basketball doubleheader at the Palestra.

title: High Court Grants I.R.S. Wide Access to Bank Files
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Supreme Court said today that the Internal Revenue Service, in investigating suspected tax cheats, had the right to compel banks to make available records about large numbers of depositors.

title: 4 Supply Aircraft Are Hit In Besieged Cambodia Town
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 19 (UPI)Cambodian insurgent antiaircraft fire hit two American cargo planes and two helicopters on supply missions to the besieged Mekong River port of Neak Luong today, military sources said.

title: WRITERS GUILD EAST IN ACCORD WITH TV
description: The Writers Guild of America East and the three major television networks came to a tentative agreement yesterday on a wage reopening provision called for at the end of the second year of their fouryear contract, which ends March 1, 1977.

title: Bishop Who Died in a Hotel In Paris Cleared by Church
description: PARIS, Feb. 19 (Reuters)The Roman Catholic Church today absolved from moral guilt a bishop who died in a Paris hotel used by prostitutes.

title: Decade Environment Need Put at 16Billion by Bardin
description: NEWARK, Feb. 19New Jersey will need $16.6billion to protect and improve environment of the state over the next 10 years, David J. Bardin, the State Environmental Protection Commissioner, said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: There was a time (time out of mind) in the eternal progress of divadienst, at the suspensory pause in its career just prior to the advent of what was to be known as Mawrdolatry, when the cult of Morgana Neri flourished' But then (in a time clear out of its mind) came what Halcyon Q. Paranov, the paramount Gotham arbiter, was to call The Czgowchwz Moment. This is the moment James McCourt celebrates in his risen souffle of a first novel, Mawrdew Czgowchwz, his bottomless barrel of Meringue glacee It is the moment when Ralph, the first to hear Czgowchwz and believe, picked up on the predawn FM airwavesa transcription of James McCourt the Midsummer Night Prague Festival Gala and came ranting through the heat to the front door of a particular brownstone kibbutz on St. Marks Place, under the Dog Star, carrying a paperbased tape in both hands as if it were alive. The moment in time [when] a certain seven first heard the art and voice of Mawrdew Czgowchwz and learned to pronounce her name MARDU GORGEOUS, and heard of her flight from Prague in a singleengine prewar flying machine maneuvered by herself, her crash landing on the Champs Elysees at dawn on Bastille Day, and her triumphant first appearance at the Opera.

title: Yale Sextet Routed
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Pan Am Aide Says Some Jews Avoid Line Because of Iran Tie
description: Pan American World Airways has noted a small but measurable loss of Jewish passengers recently as a result of its tentative agreement with the Iranian, Government that will eventually give Iran 13 per cent of the stock in Pah Am, a spokesman for the airline said yesterday.

title: Carey, After 50 Days, Still a Conundrum in the Capital
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19A year ago, Hugh L. Carey had trouble rounding up reporters for a news conference on his candidacy, which then was something of a quiet curiosity on a slushy day.

title: RIGHTS AMENDMENT DEFEATED IN NEVADA
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Feb. 19 (AP)The Equal Rights Amendment: was defeated, 12 to 8, by the state Senate today, making Nevada the third state to reject the proposed amendment to the Constitution in as many days.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
House Establishes Intelligence Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The House set up a select committee today to investigate allegations of illegal or improper activities of Federal intelligence agencies in the United States and overseas.

title: SIDNEY BERRY, MADE EDUCATIONAL FILMS
description: Sidney N. Berry, a producer of educational films and audiovisual presentations, died Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 66 years old had homes here and in New Fairfield. Conn.

title: House Votes $347=Million To Aid Bankrupt Railways
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 After three hours of often bitter debate, the House voted, 270 to 137, today to help bail out the Penn Central and other bankrupt railroads with $347 million in Governmentguaranteed loans.

title: Ruling by Supreme Court Stirs Antitrust Question
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Supreme Court ruled today that the I.T.T. Continental Baking Company, having violated a 1962 antitrust consent decree, must pay a $1,000aday fine for continuing violation, rather than a single $5,000 penalty for the illegal acquisition itself.

title: Disease Affects the Brain and Spine
description: Meningococcal meningitis is a bacterial infection of the meninges, the membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord. It usually starts suddenly with symptoms of fever, intense headache, nausea and vomiting, stiff neck and sometimes a rash.

title: Excerpts From Questions to Bergman
TRUCK SHIPMENTS IN ALASKA CURBED
description: ANCHORAGE, Feb. 19The hauling of goods and materials to camps and towns along the transAlaska pipeline project came to a halt today as teamsters throughout the state staged a safety meeting to protest hazardous road conditions.

title: Basketball Star Keeps Cool On Recruiting
description: This is the time when college scouts are out in force attempting to persuade high school basketball players to attend certain colleges, withvarying types of scholarships offered. It can be a frightening and pressure  creating experience for some youngsters, who are under enough stress to continue the quality performances that attracted the scouts in the first place and to sustain their academic standings.

title: DOLLAR MOSTLY UP IN TRADING ABROAD
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 19 (UPI)The dollar recovered from a weak start today to close slightly higher on some European markets.

title: Pressure on Moscow Seen
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 19 (Reuters)  Israeli, Government sources said today that the arms condition stated by Egypt seemed to be a hint to the Soviet Union to provide weapons faster.

title: Ford, Regretting Vote on Import Tax, Criticizes Congress and Pledges Veto
Federated Cyprus
description: When the United Nations last debated the Cyprus issue, at the General Assembly in November, Turkey joined Greece in supporting a resolution advocating preservation of a single Cypriote nation, the return refugees to their homes and the removal of foreign troops. The unilateral proclamation by Turkish Cypriotes of a separate state in northern Cyprus is in clear violation of the spirit of this resolution. It should and undoubtedly will be condemned by the Security Council, which is scheduled to meet today.

title: ARSON THREATENED AT TRADE CENTER
description: The World Trade Center, which suffered heavy fire damage to several floors a week sago, reports that anonymous telephone callers have threatened to set more fires unless, Trade Center maintenances jworkers receive two weeks' back pay they won last month a new contract settlement.

title: Nixon, in First Trip Since His Surgery, Visits Annenberg
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 19 (UPI)  Former President Richard M. Nixon arrived at the desert estate of Walter Annenberg late today for a visit that was expected to last five days and to include a party.

title: Rep. Hansen Guilty
description: Representative George V. Hansen, Republican of Idaho, pleaded guilty yesterday to two misdemeanor charges of violating the 1971 Federal Election Campaign Act. Page 10.

title: 2 In French Chateau Fight Will Not Have to Stand Trial
description: TOULOUSE, France, Feb. 19 (Reuters)Baroness Anna de Portal and her daughter, Marie Agnes, who defended their dilapidated mansion for two years after it was sold by court order, today were declared not responsible for their acts. Their lawyers have asked the court to get an opinion from another group of psychiatrists.

title: Eloise Polak Francis, 56, L'Oreal Promotion Aide
description: Eloise Polak Francis. a promotion director for l'Oral Products, died on Monday evening at her home, 300 East 71st Street. She was 56 years old.

title: British Threaten Oil TakeOver If North Sea Interest Is Refused
description: LONDON, Feb. 19The BritishGovernment disclosed today that it had warned oil companies engaged in North Sea operations that it might feel', obliged to nationalize a controlling interest in their oilfields if they refused to sell such an interest to the Government.

title: Marquette Risks Streak In Garden
OddLot Transactions
description: Tuesday, February 18, 1975

title: Judge Metes Out a Written Punishment to Offenders
SENATE APPROVES, BY 6628, A DELAY IN RISE OF OIL FEE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Senate, in the face of a promised Presidential veto, voted today to suspend for 90 days President Ford's power to increase fees on imported oil.

title: U.N. DEBATE IS DUE ON CYPRUS TODAY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 19The Security Council today scheduled its opening debate on Cyprus for tomorrow and members began consulting on some new negotiating basis for talks between the Greek and Turkish Cypriotes.

title: F.T.C. Approves Divestiture
description: Special to The New York Times

title: U.A.W. WORKS OUT DEAL ON INSURANCE
description: DETROIT, Feb. 19(UPI)The United Automobile Workers and General Motors have reached an agreement calling for the automaker to provide health and life insurance coverage for blue collar workers even if they are laid off after the supplemental unemployment benefit fund has been depleted.

title: SENATE APPROVES, BY 6628, A DELAY IN RISE OF OIL FEE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Senate, in the face of a promised Presidential veto, voted today to suspend for 90 days President Ford's power to increase fees on imported oil.

title: Soviet Silent on Condition
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (Reuters)The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia, in a brief report of Foreign Minister Fahmy's speech, made no mention of the stated arms condition for a return to a Geneva conference.

title: Rep. Hansen Guilty
description: Representative George V. Hansen, Republican of Idaho, pleaded guilty yesterday to two misdemeanor charges of violating the 1971 Federal Election Campaign Act. Page 10.

title: BLUE CROSS GAINS A 16.8% INCREASE IN HOSPITAL RATE
Finley Wins Bando Arbitration Case
description: with a back injury, said Finley.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1975

title: PLEA ON BAN IS LOST BY PANTHER LAWYER
description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the disbarment of a Rochester lawyer who contends that he is being penalized for two crimes he did not commit.

title: Things That Bring Dirt and Disease
description: Social life in New York City is notoriously nocturnal. But there is also a form of night life in the city that seems strictly antisocial. Wherever one finds peopleand food and drinkit's certain to exist. As soon as the lights are low, the cockroaches, rats and mice come out and do their thing.

title: State of Economy Alarms Henry Ford and Woodcock
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) In parallel statements to Congress, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company and the president of the United Automobile Workers Union said today the country was heading for economic disaster and efforts so far by the Government to change course have been un

title: COMMINGLED EQUITY FUNDS
description: Total Rates of ReturnWith Income Reinvested (Years Ended 12/31)

title: The NewBoy Network
description: WASHINGTONAt a recent dinner party in the suburb of Chevy Chase, part of the old foreign policy establishment came together in a moving and courageous display of support for one of its embattled members, former Central Intelligence Agency Director Richard Helms.

title: Jets Set Back Giants, 42 In Tennis
description: Members of the Jets won three of four singles matches and split two doubles matches yesterday to beat the Giants, 42, in tennis. competition between players on New York's two National Football League teams. The matches were held at the Bronx Whitestone Indoc Tennis Club.

title: Rain Is No Barrier to Skiers in Jersey Wearing Protective Garb
description: McAFEE, N. J., Feb. 18A light drizzle that was little more than a mist found Peggy Kurlander, marketing director of the Great Gorge ski area, looking out of the resort's base lodge with an air of resignation. It's almost become routine, she said. Here we are in midFebruary and we've only had two weekends on which it didn't rain at least one day. It looks as if someone up above doesn't like us.

title: Senator Ammond Wins Support of Her Constituency
description: CHERRY HILL, Feb. 19State Senator Alene S. Ammond's constituents applauded today her court victory in obtaining a Federal injunction forbidding her 28 fellow Democratic Senators from excluding her from the Senate majority caucus and a ruling ordering a trial of her complaint on this issue.

title: U.S. TEAMS TRAIN FORCES IN 34 LANDS
Food Flim Flam?
description: Suddenly, after only three weeks in the sun, the Administration's promise of increased food aid for the world's hungriest people seems to be shriveling up, in plain view of everyone who had banked on the assurances from President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Luigi Dallapiccola Dies at 71; Composer and Musical Theorist
description: FLORENCE, Italy. Feb. 19Luigi Dallapiccola, one of Italy's foremost composers and musical theorists, died here today at the age of 71. He was taken to a hospital several days age suffering from a pulmonary condition. Death was attributed to a circulatory ailment.

title: HILDA HOLLAND
description: Hilda Holland, who had been associate editor and advertising manager of American Judaism, an official publication of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, died Tuesday in Roosevelt Hospital, following taxi accident Saturday. She was 74 years old and lived at 345 West 58th Street.

title: Kings Tie Penguins
CHRYSLER OMITS REGULAR DIVIDEND
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it was omitting its regular quarterly divideact of 35 cents a share, the first time the company has taken such an action since 1938.

title: Bridge.
description: An unusual solution to an old problem was devised last month by a group of Westchester players.
