The problem is how to avoid rescheduling a headtohead teamoffour match when one player falls ill at the last moment, The solution was to go ahead with the match, but arrange a telephone hookup from the sickbed to the playing scene.

title: Knicks Subdue Pistons
Kissinger Ends Tour, Heartened and Troubled
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Secretary of State Kissinger returned to Washington today, heartened by some progress in his latest efforts to achieve a new EgyptianIsraeli accord but troubled by a Syrian campaign to thwart such an interim agreement.

title: Ring Title to Aussie
description: MANCHESTER, England, Feb. 19 (UPI)  Steve Aczel of Australia, a late substitute, won the vacant Commonwealth lightheavyweight title in his 11th pro fight tonight by stopping Britain's Max Smith in the third round. The 20yearold Aczel put Smith down five times. Chris Finnegan was to have fought Smith, but pulled out after being injured.

title: Fuentes Critic Is Chosen To Head School District 1
description: An outspoken critic of Luis Fuentes, the suspended superinitendent of Community School District 1, has been named acting superintendent of the strife ridden Lower East Side district. the new acting head, who took over yesterday, is Leonard Lurie, who had been an assistant principal at Junior High School 22 in the heavily Puerto Rican school district. His selection was apparently made at private session of the local board and the informal vote could not be immediately determined. To make the action official, the board will have to also act at an public meeting.

title: People and Business
description: Atef GamelEldin, secretary general and counsel of the Houstonbased AmericanArab Chamber of Commerce, has disclosed that a proposal for formation of an ArabAmerican bank is being circulated among unspecified United States banks and various Arab countries. If formed, the bank would be a 5050 joint undertaking by United States banks and unspecified Arab interests.

title: Sterndent Suit Cites Kuwait Role in Bid
description: A Mount Vernon, N. Y., dental equipment manufacturer filed suit yesterday in Federal Court to block a takeover bid in which an Arab investment company and Jewish partners are involved.

title: Details of SovietEgyptian Arms Accord Are Disclosed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 19Sovet Union will supply Egypt with enough arms between now and June to make up for most of the losses sufered in the 1973 war with Israel, according to East European and Lebanese press sources here.

title: Article 2  No Title
CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Feb. 15 stated incorrectly that disability benefits to pregnant women under the New Jersey Workmen's Compensation Law were limited to single lumpsum payments. The maximum benefit is actually eight weeks of disability pay.

title: Pennsy Loss Wider; Firestone Net Off
Jersey City Firemen Resist Layoffs
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 19A spokesman for Local 1066 of ace International Association of Firefighters, representing the 559 rank and file members of this city's Fire Department, said today there would be no concessions from the union in its opposition to a plan by the Mayor to cut 65 of the newest members of the firefighting force from the payroll for economy reasons.

title: Reagan on the Road: Easy Smile and Hard Rhetoric
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 19When Ronald Reagan was forced to retreat from his oftproclaimed opposition to withholding California state income taxes, the Sacramento press corps gave him a trophy two shoes imbedded in concretetogether with a warning never to be quite so adamant on any future question.

title: Mrs. Ryan, Nazi Guard, Is Indicted in Germany
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Feb. 19 (AP)Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, the Nazi concentration camp guard who later was a Queens housewife, was indicted today with nine other Germans on charges connected with the killing of 250,000 inmates of a Nazi camp in Poland. The trial is scheduled to start this summer.

title: Electronic Surveillance: Scope of Wiretapping and Bugging an Issue of Rising Concern
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19From the advent of Watergate nearly three years ago, national attention has been drawn again and again to the question of electronic surveillance; the issue of exactly how much wiretapping and bugging really goes on in the United States. Recent disclosures that the Central Intelligence Agency engaged in domestic operations and that the Bell Telephone System monitored calls have served only to increase interest in the issue. Indeed, the problem has caused enough concern in Washington that a Federal commission has been appointed to investigate wiretapping and it is the subject directly or indirectly of studies by four Congressional committees.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange bounced back yesterday after having dropped on Tuesday. Prices closed mixed in the overthecounter market.

title: E.P.A. Offers Plan On Traffic Control For Boston Region
NEW GUN BATTLES RAGE IN ASMARA
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 19Shops and offices were closed and few people were on the streets in Asmara today after a night of fierce gun battles between Government troops and secessionist guerrillas, Ethiopian and foreign residents of the city reported by telephone.

title: Suit Charging G.O.P. Kickbacks By Nassau Employes Dismissed
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 19A class action suit alleging kickbacks to the Republican Party by county employes was dismissed in State Supreme Court here today.

title: Thyra Ferre Bjorn, 69, Author of Popular Novels
description: Thyra Ferr Bjorn, the author of nine popular novels with combined trade and hookclub sales of over 250,000 copies, died last Friday at the Medical Center of Massachusetts in Boston. She was 69 years old and lived in Longmeadow, Mass.

title: Police Call Subway Slaying a Preplanned RipOff
description: Three teenagers who are accused of stabbing to death 23 yearold graduate student on a crowded, rushhour subway train in Upper Manhattan on Tuesday had been riding back and forth on the train, looking for someone to rob, the police said yesterday.

title: Bitterness in Turkey Over U.S. Aid Cutoff Is Widespread
description: ANKARA, TurkeyAli Osman Kucukmolia, a foreman in a sugar plant fought with Turkish troops under United Nations command in the Korean war and he won an American medal for valor.

title: Battle of the Burger
description: The battle of the burger continues in New York, generating heat and litter. Community protest increases as the number of fastfood places grows. Protest is a fact of life which we accept, says one McDonald's spokesman. We must be doing something right, says another, referring to an apparently insatiable demand for Big Macs.

title: People in Sports
description: Roy White signed his 11th contract with the New York Yankees yesterday and got a slight raise to around $90,000, despite being so disatisfied with his status last season as a designated hitter and parttime left fielder that he had asked to be traded. The 31yearold White had played in 388 consecutive games before pulling a leg muscle last May while sliding into third base in Boston.

title: Ford, Regretting Vote on Import Tax, Criticizes Congress and Pledges Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19President Ford expressed regret tonight at the Senate vote delaying for 90 days his increased fees on imported crude oil but said he did not regard the Senate action as final.

title: Khalid and Linda, Together
Borg Struggles to Top Stewart of U. S.
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Feb. 19 (AP)  Bjorn Borg, Kim Warwick and Bob Hewitt advanced t othe quarterfinals today in the $60,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament.

title: Flames Halt Stars
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 19 (AP)Atlanta shelled the Minnesota North Stars goalie, Cesare Maniago, for two goals in each of the first two periods tonight and then held on for a 42 N.H.L. victory over Minnesota. The victory moved the Flames, fighting for a playoff berth in the Patrick Division, to within points of the idle third place New York Islanders.

title: Mishap on Ski Lift Termed Accident
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Feb. 19 (AP)A ski lift mishap that injured 10 persons at Mad River Glen was an accident in the purest sense, a state tramway inspector said today.

title: Finley Wins Arbitration With Bando
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 (UPI)  The Oakland A's owner, Charles O. Finley, won his salary arbitration battle with Sal Bando today. Bando may now also lose his job as team captain.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Feb. 15 stated incorrectly that disability benefits to pregnant women under the New Jersey Workmen's Compensation Law were limited to single lumpsum payments. The maximum benefit is actually eight weeks of disability pay.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Prices of soybeans and corn tumbled sharply again yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, continuing Tuesday's downtrend.

title: House Establishes Intelligence Inquiry
Helling Gets 10Pin Lead In Bowling
HOUSING STARTS CLIMB SLIGHTLY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Permits for new housing starts plunged to a record low in January, although actual starts rose slightly, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Attempted Escaper Indicted
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)  A Federal grand jury has indicted Frank Gorham Jr., one of two inmates who seized control of the United States District Court cellblock here last July and held eight persons hostage more than 60 hours before they escaped unharmed. The other inmate, Robert Nathan Jones, is serving a life sentence as a result of the incident.

title: Publisher, a Foe of Busing, Is Elected Resents Head
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19Theodore M. Black, a Long Island publisher and a foe of busing for integration, was elected Chancellor of the State Board of Regents today.

title: State Indicts Policeman In Slaying of Shore Youth
description: TRENTON, Feb. 19A Long Branch police officer who shot to death a 16yearold high school student on Dec. 8, was indicted here today by a state grand jury on charges of manslaughter.

title: PARENTS PROTEST S.I. SCHOOL CUTS
description: Parents, school officials and community  group leaders in Staten Island argued yesterday for restoring to the city's capital budget money previously allocated for new school buildings but rescinded by the Beame administration because of the municipal fiscal crisis.

title: MARION D. JEWELL
description: Marion D. Jewell, principal of Julia Richman High School from 1941 until her retirement in 1958, died Tuesday at a hospital in Scranton, Pa. She was 88 years old and lived in Newfoundland, Pa., and Syracuse.

title: Rate on City's Notes Drops to the Level Of 8 Months Ago
description: The city obtained yesterday the lowest interest rate on its notes in eight monthsan average of 7.0783 per centin a borrowing of $260million.

title: Music: Fleisher Soloist in Prokofiev
description: If anyone should ever wish to commission an essay on the uses of adversity, Leon Fleisher might be the man to write it. Mr. Fleisher's future seemed unlimited not long Ago, when he had come to be regarded as the finest American pianist of his (and probably any) time. He had to rebuild his artist's life, however, after losing the use of his right hand a few years hack. For reasons no doctor has ascertained, it simply refuses to function as the right hind of a great pianist must.

title: Lafayette Five's Hopes Dimmed by Injuries
description: Two players who have not participated in the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs may be as important in determining the eventual champion as all those who have. The players are Arthur Rosenfeld and Finny Fuller of Lafayette, which meets South Shore on Sunday in one of the weekend's quarterfinal games.

title: Richard J. DeHaan Dies; U. of Connecticut Official
description: Richard J. DeHaan, vice president for finance and administration at the University of Connecticut, was found dead; Tuesday in the garage of his home at 16 Willowbrook Road, Storrs, Conn. He was 45 yearsi old.

title: State Sees No Need To Remove Goldman From Shubert Fund
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that an 11month inquiry into possible misuse of Shubert Foundation finances by the foundation's president, Irving Goldman, had not produced enough evidence to justify action for his removal from the foundation post.

title: Harvard Six Clinches Title
description: Special to The New York Times

title: New Yorker
description: That great connoisseur of living, Fernand Point, is supposed to have said that a woman under 40 wasn't worth talking to. If publications can be judged the same way, perhaps a magazine under 50 isn't worth reading. The New Yorker, which celebrates its 50th birthday this week, was always worth readingexcept for an occasional touch of turgid profilase. In its style and its content, it is a connoisseur both of art and life.

title: TWO MEN INDICTED OVER NIXON TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The lawyer who prepared former President Richard M. Nixon's tax, returns,,and the appraiser; who valued the prePresidential papers claimed by Mr. Nixon as a tax deduction were indicted today by a Federal grand jury for conspiracy to commit fraud and other crimes in connection with Mr. Nixon's tax returns.

title: Article 1  No Title
Business Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 19 (AP)Tapline, the Americanowned pipeline that brings Saudi Arabian oil to the Mediterranean, is the latest casualty of the international oil surplus. The TransArabian Pipeline company announced today that it had stopped pumping Saudi crude oil to its terminal at Zahrani, 35 miles south of Beirut, on Feb. 9 because it had no contracts to ship from there for the next six months.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, Feb. 19, 1975

title: Jets Defeat Oilers
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Feb. 19 (AP)Joe Daley's solid goaltending helped the Winnipeg Jets beat the Edmonton Oilers, 41, tonight, stretching their W.H.A. winning streak to five games. Daley made 31 saves.

title: Gas Threat Off Canada
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Feb. 19 (UPI)Four rail cars loaded with 340 tons of liquid chlorine that could release a deadly gas sank in the ocean when a barge overturned north of here early today.

title: San Francisco Man Pleads Not Guilty in Sister's Death
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 (AP)Eben Gossage, the 20 yearold sole survivor of a prominent San Francisco family, has pleaded not guilty to charges that he bludgeoned and stabbed his younger sister to death.

title: Senate Panel Sets Recount In New Hampshire Contest
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 19 (AP) The Senate Rules Committee Voted today to recount about 3.500 ballots in its effort to determine the winner of the contested New Hampshire Senate race.

title: ITALIAN POLICE FIND ARTOBJECTS CACHE
description: MILAN, Italy, Feb. 19 (AP)The police said today that they had recovered a large number of ancient pots, statuettes, paintings and other works of art that were stolen or taken in illegal excavations.

title: Miss Bagaya, Removed By Amin, Goes to Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya Feb. 19 (Reuters)Elizabeth Bagaya, a former Uganda Foreign Minister, who was accused by President Idi Amin on charges of immoral behavior, has been allowed to leave Uganda and is living in seclusion in Kenya, her brother said today.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Carey, After 50 Days, Still a Conundrum in the Capitol
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19A year ago, Hugh L. Carey had trouble rounding up reporters for a news conference on his candidacy, which then was something of a quiet curiosity on a slushy day.

title: Moves by Saigon's Foes Said to Peril Roads to the Highlands
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Feb. 17South Vietnamese and Western officials believe that parts of at least four North Vietnamese divisions are carrying out a carefully planned series of moves that will cut the only roads into the vast Central Highlands and isolate its population.

title: Bonn Cites Schmidt Illness
description: BONN, Feb. 19 (Reuters)Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany is suffering from pleurisy in addition to pneumonia, a Government spokesman announced here today. Mr. Schmidt, 56 years old, fell ill on Sunday.

title: Credit Card Abuses Spread as Even the Affluent Plunge Into Debt
description: It's a good thing that Micawber lived before credit cards.

title: Souzay III, Recital Put Off
description: Gerard Souzay, the French baritone, is ill and the Ravel song recital he was to have given at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tomorrow night has been postponed to March 6. Tickets will be honored on March 6.

title: Fastidious Swiss Shun WhiteCoated Terriers
description: Unlike Japan, where the white dog is extremely popular, so much so that the Maltese is the No. 1 breed, in Switzerland the allwhite canine is in scarce supply.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Prospects for the continued operation of a cabinetmaking plant in the South Bronx and the saving of 200 jobs appeared doomed yesetrday when the board of directors of the major creditor voted to recognize bids that had been made for machinery and other property in the factory.

title: Rangers Play 22 Tie; Polls Hurt; Not Serious
Record 903 Entries Seek Pulitzer Journalism Prizes
description: A record number of 903 entries are competing for the 1975 Pulitzers in journalism, according to John Hohenberg, administrator of the prizes at Columbia University. The preyious record was the 729 nominations submitted in 1960.

title: Suspect in Piracy Of Films Is Seized
description: A 57yearold Manhattan man described as a major distributor of pirated motion pictures was arrested yesterday at his Broadway office, where a police raiding party seized illegal master copies of more than 500 commercial movies, including The Godfather, Planet of the Apes and Deep Throat.

title: $1Billion Steel Mill Planned by National
BERGMAN REFUSES TO GIVE ANSWERS TO SENATE PANEL
Sadat Postpones Trip
description: BEIRUT, Feb. 19 (Reuters)President Sadat's expected visit to Jordan this week has been postponed, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: BERGMAN REFUSES TO GIVE ANSWERS TO SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Bernard Bergman and an aide refused to answer questions today at a Senate hearing about their nursinghome operations, citing their Constitutional rights under the Fifth Amendment.

title: 2 IN HOUSE OPPOSE EXENVOY TO CHILE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Two Congressmen urged the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today to reject the nomination of Nathaniel Davis to a high State Department post, alleging that he had been involved in covert political operatiobs as Ambassador to Chile.

title: Wings Defeat Flyers
description: DETROIT, Feb. 19 (AP)Walt McKechnie, playing his first game for the Detroit Red Wings, scored on a power play at 11 minutes 15 seconds of the third period tonight to give the Wings a 43 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in a National Hockey League game.

title: Why the Knicks Want Eddie Donovan
description: At the time the New York Knicks needed another strong rebounder, as they still do. But the Buffalo Braves, instead of the Knicks, acquired Jim Washington, An experienced 6foot8inch forward, from the Atlanta Hawks several weeks ago for a ransom that the accountants who operate Madison Square Garden thought was reasonable$150,000 and a fifthround choice in the upcoming National Basketball Association draft. That's when the accountants seriously began to question the wisdom of Red Holzman's dual role as both general manager and coach. That's when the accountants seriously began to consider employing a general manager who wouldn't be burdened by the timeconsuming responsibility of also being a coach. And that's when the accountants seriously began to wonder if Eddie Donovan, the general manager who had obtained Jim Washington for the Buffalo Braves, would be interested in returning to the Knicks as general manager as long as Red Holzman agreed. If the DonoanHolzman regine resumes next season, Jim Washington, even in his Buffalo uniform, will be the Knicks player of the year.

title: Fed Asks Relaxing Of TakeOver Rules For Troubled Banks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Federal Reserve Board asked Congress today for authority to permit outofstate banks or bank holding companies to acquire large banks that are in danger of failure.

title: On Screen: The Dove
Tommy Tune Sings With Little Success Atop Village Gate
description: Tommy Tune, the 6foot 8 inch dancer and singer who gave the musical Seesaw lift it badly needed (and won a Tony Award as a result), has completed a threering circus at the Village Gate: Let My People Come downstairs, Charles Pierce at the Top of the Gate and now Mr. Tune in what is called Atop the Gate. Atop, thanks to some tight scheduling and rapid shifting of audiences, is essentially the same place as the Top of the Gate.

title: ExSuitor Couldn't Accept Slain Coed's New Life
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 19Anthony Acevedo shivered In the cold outside police head quarters this morning after the 2 A. M. arraignment of his 20 year old brother. Louis O. Acevedo 3d, for seconddegree murder.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: MARKET IS MIXED AS TRADING LAGS
description: The stock market, after its recent broad and sharp advance, paused to catch its breath yesterday and finished mixed in slower trading.

title: Kuhn and Rozelle Caution Against Legal Sports Bets
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The commissioners of baseball and football told a national commission on gambling today that betting on their games by the public was a reality, but that making such betting legal would be a disaster.

title: SUIT BY GOVERNMENT SCORED BY A.T.&T.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The American Telephone and Telegraph Company says a Government demand for documents in its antitrust suit could cost the Bell System $300million and 20,000 man years of effort.

title: Representative Hansen Pleads Guilty To Violation of Election Campaign Act
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) Representative George V. Hansen, Republican of Idaho, pleaded guilty today to two misdemeanor charges of violating the 1971 Federal Election Campaign Act by failing to file proper finance reports with the House Clerk.

title: Experiments on Humans
description: NEW HAVENThe controversy over the use of human beings in medical experimentation demonstrates the difficulty of reconciling two values basic to Western society: the desire to benefit from advances in medical knowledge, and the commitment to individual dignity and autonomy.

title: Beame Reiterates Need to Raise RealEstate Tax in Next Budget
description: Mayor Beame, reacting to criticism of the 74cent increase in realestate taxes he has proposed for the next fiscal year, said yesterday that, while he was very much aware of the problem created by increased real property taxes, the city has very few choices availablel to it in seeking new or expanded revenues.

title: Couple Plead Not Guilty In Fatal Neglect of Child
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Sports News Briefs
description: FALUN, Sweden, Feb. 19 (AP)Mike Devecka of Bend, Ore., will carry America's hopes in the 26th Swedish ski games starting tomorrow after Martha Rockwell, the top United States entrant, had to pull out with a sprained ankle. Martha Rockwell was in a better shape this year compared with 1974, when she captured the 10th spot in the women's 10kilometer crosscountry race in the world ski championships here, Coach Tom Upham said today.

title: Music: Webster's Ravel
description: The complete standard canon of Ravel's solo piano music makes for a rather long programtwo and a half hours, counting the intermissionand one we are likely to hear with some frequency in this centenary year. There are a pleasing unity and variety to the music, however, and the result can give great pleasure. At least it can when it is played as well as Beveridge Webster played it on Tuesday evening in a free recital at the Juil Hard Theater.

title: C.A.B.'s Use of Investigators Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Civil Aeronautics Board investigators have spent only 3 per cent of their time during the last four years looking into consumer complaints about airlines that cvercharged customers, bumped passengers or lost baggage, Senator Edward M. Kennedy charged today.

title: Governors Obtain Little Relief for Economic Woes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The nation's Governors got a tentative yes from Congressional Democrats and a tentative no from the Ford Administration today in their drive to waive the requirement that states match Federal funds as they spend $2billion in newly released Federal highway money.

title: MOSCOW HAS SHOW OF UNOFFICIAL ART
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (Reuters) An indoor show of nonorthodox art opened today in the Beekeeping Pavilion of Moscow's permanent Exhibition of Economic Achievements.

title: Court Finds Some U.S. oil Pricing Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19In a 2to1 decision, the Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals held today that the Government had, acted illegally in letting some domestic crude oil sell at uprestricted market prices since January, 1974.

title: Nets Win, 113  91; Paultz Is Hurt
Pentecostalism Rises Like a Phoenix From Slums
description: The Rev. Ricardo Tanon, Pentecostal minister, shook his fist in the direction of row of gutted apartment houses along Simpson Street in the South Bronx.

title: 3 Youths Terrorize and Rob Aged Couple in Home
description: An 83yearold Brooklyn man and his 78yearold wife were bound, terrorized and robbed yesterday by three teenaged boys who had started to burn bed on which the old man was lying in his East Flatbush flat.

title: $450,000 to Aid Black Internes In a Law Program in the South
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 19The Law Students Civil Rights Research Council announced here today a 5450.000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation to help finance a summer interneship program in Southern civil rights and public interest firms for black law students.

title: High Court Grants I.R.S. Wide Access to Bank Files
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Supreme Court said today that the Internal Revenue Service, in investigating suspected tax cheats, had the right to compel banks to make available records about large numbers of depositors.

title: Chess
description: To use a world champion's weapon takes more than a little doing, for while the moves of a favorite defense of a Bobby Fischer may seem to flow effortlessly out of the position, they are usually distilled out of a thorough understanding of the numerous relevant factors that govern the strategy and tactics.

title: Trainer's Hearing Put Off
description: The heading for John L. Cotter, a horse trainer who has been ordered to show cause why his license should not be revoked, was postponed yesterday from today until March 6. The New York State Racing and Wagering Board has charged Cotter with nine instances of rules violations, between August, 1969, and last January.

title: I.M.C. Plans to Buy Rest Of Commercial Solvents
description: The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation, the world's largest producer of fertilizer materials, reached an agreement in principle last night to acquire the remaining shares of the Commercial Solvents Corporation for $75.4million cash. I.M.C. acquired 1,425,753 shares, or 46.6 per cent, of Commercial Solvents outstanding common strock in two tender offers last March and August at $30 a share.

title: Kuhn and Rozelle Caution Against Legal Sports Bets
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The commissioners of baseball and football told a national commission on gambling today that betting on their games by the public was a reality, but that making such betting legal would be a disaster.

title: Italian Abortion Ruling Draws Vatican Warning
description: ROME, Feb. 19The Roman Catholic Church warned Italians today that a ruling by the nation's Constitutional Court easing the legal ban on abortion does not free human and Christian conscience from the duty to apply moral standards to the issue.

title: Rudel Survives 30 City Opera Years
description: Who speaks of victory? Survival is the issue. This quotation from Rilke adorns an office wall at the New York City Opera. It gives wry comfort to Julius Rudel, the company's director, who has survived for 30 years with the company and tonight will open the spring half of the City Opera's anniversary season by conducting Bellini's I Puritani.

title: Failures in 1974 For Businesses Put At a 3Year High
description: Business failures reached a threeyear high in 1974 in both numbers and the extent of dollar liabilities, according to Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., which issues monthly reports on the failure trend.

title: Advertising
description: Fans of the twopronged attack will be excited to learn that Allied Mills, Inc., is planning just such an attack on the $1.4billion dog food market.

title: Canada Announces An Increase of 11 In Spending Budget
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 19The Canadian Government announced today a spending plan of $28.2 billion for the 1976 fiscal year, an increase of $2.8billion, or 11 per cent, over the expenditures planned for the fiscal year ending March 31.

title: Bentsen Says Business Alone Can't Reverse U.S. Economy
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the mostrecent entrant in the Democratic presidential sweepstakes, told a luncheon audience of businessmen here yesterday that he did not think that business can do it by itself when it comes to turning around the United States economy.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: QUIET VICTOR Ian Hugo, who has been called a dedicated artist of the cinematic eye, is an experimental movie maker whose 12 short works spanning 25 years have won him an international reputation. Boldly imaginative and original, these beautifully wrought miniatures, ranging from 6 to 20 minutes in length, are hard to forget, with their mysterious shimmering images, colors and sounds. These striking avantgarde endeavors come from a skilled professional.

title: Senate RollCall Vote To Halt Oil Import Fee
Policeman Is Indicted by Jersey In Long Branch Youth's Slaying
description: TRENTON Feb. 19A Long Branch police officer who shot to death a 16yearold high school student on Dec. 8, was indicted here today by a state grand jury on charges of manslaughter.

title: State Drops LongStanding Demand For Tolls on City's East River Bridges
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19The state has dropped from the latest version of a New York City pollutioncontrol plan its longstanding demand for tolls on the East River bridges, Ogden R. Reid, the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, told the Legislature's fiscal committees today.

title: George Van Santvoord Is Dead; Hotchkiss Principal 29 Years
description: George Van Santvoord, who was headmaster of the Hotchkiss School from 1926 to 1955, died yesterday in Williamstown, Mass. He was 84 years old and lived in Bennington. Vt.

title: Fahmy States Condition
description: CAIRO, Feb. 19 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy told Parliament yesterday that Egypt would not return to the Geneva conference on the Middle East until her arms losses of the 1973 war had been replaced.

title: Spain's Premier Says Socialists Could Play a Role in Politics
description: MADRID, Feb. 19 (UPIPremier Carlos Arias Navarro says that political reform in Spain must go very far and very high. He sees no reason why Christian Democratic or Socialist groups cannot play a role in the nation's politics, he asserts.

title: Publisher, a Foe of Busing, Is Elected Regents Head
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19Theodore M. Black, a Long Island publisher and a foe of busing for integration, was elected Chancellor of the State Board of Regents today.

title: New Regents Chancellor
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19Theodore Michael Black did not wait for Pearl Harbor before enlisting in the infantry. He got back his entrance deposit from Yale Law School and joined up two months before the country had war thrust upon it. He went on to a highly decorated service in Europe. There was a war on and I decided that I was going to be in it, he said yesterday. This impulse to plunge into new activities has characterized Mr. Black's career since then, and has led to his amassing a list of civic, military and political affiliations that figuratively are as weighty as his own portly frame.

title: TV: Attack on Terror
description: Tonight and tomorrow, from 9 o'clock to 11 each evening, CBSTV continues The F.B.I. Story series with Attack on Terror, a largescale factual dramatization drawn from the 1964 murders of three young civilrights workers in Mississippi. Although the case is based on fact, and the script stays reasonably close to known details, the names of most participants, including the victims  Andrew Goodman, James E. Chaney and Michael Schwerner  have been changed to protect the privacy of those involved.

title: WBAI to Present a Series On Contemporary Writing
description: A radio series devoted to littleknown contemporary writing will begin on WBAI, the Pacifica network's New York station, 99.5 FM, on Monday at 12:05 P.M. The series, called Mag TimePacifica's Literary Magazine of the Air, will present poetry, plays, fiction and nonfiction from literary magazines in print and from other sources.

title: Nude Art in Halls of Justice Stirs a Storm in Bronx
description: Disclaiming any attempt at censorship, Owen McGivern, presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, First Department, has asked the Bronx County Museum of the Arts to dismantle a show of work by women artists that contains explicit male nudity and at least one fourletter word.

title: People in Sports
description: Roy White signed his 11th contract with the New York Yankees yesterday and got a slight raise to around $90,000, despite being so disatisfied with his status last season as a designated hitter and parttime left fielder that he had asked to be traded. The 31yearold White had played in 388 consecutive games before pulling a leg muscle last May while sliding into third base in Boston.

title: Ali Reveals Plan for 75 Foreman Bout
description: Muhammad Ali, the world heavyweight boxing champion, disclosed yesterday that negotiations were under way for a title defense against George Foreman later this year in an ancient setting that closedcircuit TV promoters identified as Cairo.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: The conspiracy, perjury and taxfraud conviction of Nelson G. Gross, former New Jersey Republican chairman, was upheld yesterday by the Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia.

title: Favored Hoso Wins Camellia at Hialeah
description: MIAMI, Feb. 19 (AP) Hoso, the oddson favorite, raced to a sixlength victory today in the $33,600 Camellia Stakes at Hialeah Park before a crowd of 15,525.

title: DR. CARL BREITNER
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 19 (AP) Dr. Carl Breitner, a psychiatrist, died Sunday lie was 73 years old.

title: East and West Germany Dissatisfied With the Slow Advance Toward Improved Relations
description: BONN, Feb. 19There is feeling of disappointment in West Germany and East Germany with the fiveyear policy of achieving better relations between them.

title: DIVORCE DISPUTE GROWS IN BRAZIL
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 19The divorce controversy sharpened today in Brazil, the world's largest Roman Catholic country, when a leading prelate conceded that divorce was inevitable.

title: Suspect in Piracy Of Films Is Seized
description: A 57yearold Manhattan man described as a major distributor of pirated motion pictures was arrested yesterday at his Broadway office, where a police raiding party seized illegal master copies of more than 500 commercial movies, including The Godfather, Planet of the Apes and Deep Throat.

title: Senators Move to Outlaw Abuses in Nursing Homes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19An 11point legislative program to end nursinghome abuses is being drafted by a Senate panel whose chairman predicted today that most reforms would be enacted.

title: School in Bronx Is Closed In Meningitis Death Scare
description: Frightened parents forced the closing of a Bronx public school and the mass testing of about 2,000 pupils and teachers by the Department of Health yesterday following the death from meningitis last Friday of a 6 yearold firstgrade pupil.

title: The Fear Of Truth
description: BOSTON, Feb. 19A group of Senators and Representatives is scheduled to fly off this weekend, at the State Department's suggestion, for a tenday visit to South Vietnam and Cambodia. They will be accompanied by high State and Defense officials, and on the scene they will get the usual official guidance.

title: Flap Problem Imperils DC10
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Feb. 19 (UPI)A Turkish Airlines DC10 carrying 169 passengers suffered wingflap damage while landing here last night; aviation authorities reported. The plane began to lose control at an altitude of 6,892 feet, an airline spokesman said. If the plane had been flying 300 feet lower, he added, a catastrophe could not have been avoided.

title: They Left the Hectic Life for Home in a Cliff
description: BEQUIA, West IndiesFishermen on this pastelhued little Grenadine isle were amazed when Tom and Gladys Johnston of Chicago moved into a giant rock hole overlooking the Caribbean Sea.

title: 5.94% and 6.09% Yields Set on Treasury Notes
Ouster of Black Principal Upheld by Federal Court
Notes on People
description: Several members of the jury that convicted Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin of manslaughter in the death of a legally aborted fetus expressed pleasure yesterday that the Boston City Hospital obstetrician had received a light sentence and one juror said she regretted her guility vote.

title: S.E.C. and Justice Men Differ on Securities Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Officials of the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission clashed here today on legislative safeguards they consider necessary to reform the securities industry.

title: Personal Finance: Consumer Division Acts Quickly on Banking Complaints
description: I have a savings account a bank but I didn't receive any interest last quarter. How come?

title: Warehouseman Is Held On CargoTheft Charge
description: Posing as truck drivers, undercover agents of the Waterfront Commission arrested a warehouseman yesterday at Port Elizabeth, N. J., after he allegedly accepted $100 in marked bills in payment for 15 cases containing 5,400 candy bars valued at $769.

title: TWO MEN INDICTED OVER NIXON TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The lawyer who prepared former President Richard M. Nixon's tax returns and the appraiser who valued the prePresidential papers claimed by Mr. Nixon as a tax deduction were indicted today by a Federal grand jury for conspiracy to commit fraud and other crimes in connection with Mr. Nixon's tax returns.

title: Byrne Presses for Registration by Mail
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Governor Bryne was asked today what he had learned during the first two days of the National Governors Conference winter meeting here.

title: Nevada Gaming Unit Favors Giving License to Shenker
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Feb. 19 (UPI)  The Nevada Gaming Control Board unanimously recommended today that a St. Louis criminal lawyer, Morris Shenker, be found suitable for a gambling license in the Dunes Hotpl on the Las Vegas Strip.

title: Timber Industry's Slump Hurting the South
description: WARRENTON, Ga.Trees have always been important to Southerners, but only in the last three decades have large numbers started to think of them as timbera renewable cash crop that is the basis of a major mechanized industry: one of the foundations of the New South.

title: Oil Tariff; Oil Price
description: Despite the heavy Senate vote yesterday to delay President Ford's proposed energy program, Mr. Ford and Congress seem to be sparring rather than trying to knock each other out.

title: Liggett Group Offers 5 TV Spots
description: The Liggett Group, two of whose major products are cigarettes and liquor, unveiled yesterday five of 12 planned public service television spots that it expects to have run without charge and yet have them end up with their corporate identification.

title: Market Place
description: The year 1974 was a cheerless one for the managers of the trust departments of the major New York City banks. Just how cheerless becomes apparent from the results posted in the socalled commingled equity funds for employe benefit accounts.

title: State Sees No Need To Remove Goldman From Shubert Fund
ALCOHOLICS FOUND IN CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: As many as 12 per cent of the 136,000 juniors and seniors in New York's public high schools may be alcoholics or show signs of potential alcoholism, according to a study of the attitudes and drinking habits of 10,000 high school students released yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: City Hall: Exploited MiddleManagers

title: New 7475 Highs Lows
House Votes $347Million To Aid Bankrupt Railways
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 After three hours of often bitter debate, the House voted, 270 to 137, today to help hail out the Penn Central and other bankrupt railroads with $347 million in grants and Governmentguaranteed loans.

title: Army Begins Bird Eradication, Spraying Flock at Kentucky Post
description: ET. CAMPBELL, Ky., Feb. 19 (AP)Flying over two pine groves, Army helicopters began tonight the destruction of an estimated five million starlings and grackles.

title: LEGISLATORS' TRIP TO ASIA IN DOUBT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The trip of members of Congress to Indochina, proposed by President Ford, has been indefinitely postponed or canceled.

title: To Check the Slump
description: The bill to cut personal and business taxes by $21.3 billion that has now cleared the House Ways and Means Committee is the essential first step in the campaign to halt the most serious slump the United States economy has experienced since the 193738 recession.

title: ExDeSoto Dealer Again Loses In Long Suit Against Chrysler
description: NEWARK, Feb. 20A Federal case that has amassed a file four feet thick over 13 years, closed another chapter here today.

title: Moscow Rapprochement
description: Back in 1971 a deep frost settled on AngloSoviet relations when the British Government summarily expelled more than 100 Soviet spies masquerading as diplomats and other legitimate residents of London. Prime Minister Harold Wilson's visit to Moscow and Leningrad a few days ago gave the Kremlin a chance, for reasons that bear scrutiny, to demonstrate that it has decided let bygones be bygones. So great was the Soviet cordiality to Mr. Wilsonas measured by the numbers schoolchildren assembled to welcome the British leader and the carefully controlled volume of applause accorded him when he visited the balletthat even British observers were by surprise.

title: Paterno: Revamp Football Program
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Feb. 20Joe Paterno has been up to his old tricks again, rocking the boat in which the intercollegiate athletic establishment is having stormy sailing these days. Calling for a series of drastic changes in major college football, Penn State's head football coach even went so far as to question a school's right to refer to its football players as amateurs.

title: Amstar Lifts Dividend By 7 Cents a Share
description: The Amstar Corporation, the nation's largest refiner and proces'sor of sugar, announced yesterday that its board had increased the regular quarterly dividend on the common stock to 60 cents a share from 52 cents a share. The dividend is payable April 2 to shareholders of record March 13.

title: Weekly Truck Tonnage Falls
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week as 26 per cent below the corresponding week last year, and 1.1 per cent below the immediate preceding week. The rail carloading report will not be available until tomorrow because of the Washington Birthday holiday which was celebrated last Monday.

title: The Boy Bookie of St. Paul's
description: Twentyone years after his retirement as a jockey, Earl Sande made a comeback, and the crowd at Belmont went wild when the 55yearold kept a tiring long shot named Miss Weesie going long enough to win a race called the Circlet Purse. The following week Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, owner of the magnificent Native Dancer, was guest of honor at the annual dinner of the Thoroughbred Club of America in Lexington, Ky. Acknowledging his introduction, Alfred said yes, it was true that he had been invoived in racing all his adult life, he had operated race tracks, bred horses, raced horses, trained horses and, he said to an audience whose members were all aware Sande's comeback, if I were 15 years older and 40 pounds lighter and weren't afraid horses I would be riding them, too.

title: Butz Is Conciliatory on Farm Program; Clashes With McGovern on Food Stamps
LAZARD SURVIVAL SEEN BY ROHATYN
description: Felix Rohatyn, a partner in Lazard Frees & Co., the international investment  banking firm excluded from several underwritings by pressure from Senate financial interests, told Senate subcommittee in Washington yesterday that we will survive this as we have survived other incidents in our 133year history.

title: Bill for Separate Office For the Retarded Gains
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20A bill creating a separate office for mental retardation, which Governor Carey promised to sign during the recent campaign, was passed today by the Senate, despite opposition to it from two key aides to the Governor.

title: Heads of Banks and Businesses On List of Symbionese Targets
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 22 (UPI)Newly disclosed lists of possible targets of the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army included presidents of banks, heads of corporations and other capitalist figures.

title: Surplus Capacity And Dollar Decline Worry Oil Trade
description: Uncertainty is continuing in the world oil trade because of surplus production capacity and the declining value of the United States dollar.

title: HOUSE PANEL ENDS GUN CURB HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20A House subcommittee ended today the first round of hearings on legislation to limit the use and availability of guns, and its chairman said he expected some form of gun control to be passed by Congress this year.

title: Testimony Against Legal Bets Called Weak by Head of Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The chairman of a national commission studying gambling said today that leaders of professional and amateur sports had failed to make a convincing case against legalizing gambling on team sports.

title: President Adheres to Plan On Energy and Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20Despite the wide margin of the Senate vote yesterday delaying for 90 days President Ford's increased fees on imported crude oil, a White House spokesman insisted today that there can be no compromiseon the goals of the President's energy and economic proposals.

title: For Purim, Hamantashen Galore
description: The hamantashen are in full flow in the city's Jewish bakeries, where customers are already stocking up on the threecornered baked delicacies traditionally consumed on the Purim holiday, which starts on Monday night.

title: Advertising
description: Some of the big boys are making big moves within the Interpublic Group of Companies and at the Leo Burnett Company, two of the world's major agency operations.

title: PARK'S UNITY BID OPPOSED IN KOREA
PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Two viewpoints on why today's parents seek out so much help: One is that we have become but quivering shadows of our own parents, insecure and helpless, needing instruction at every step. The other is that we are just now finding out how much there is to learn about the job of raising children.

title: JUDGE SAYS RIKERS VIOLATES RIGHTS
description: The judge whose decision a year ago led to the closing of the Tombs jail ruled yesterday that some practices at Rikers Island, to which inmates from the Tombs were transferred, violated the Constitution.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: Having been on rather intimate terms with axes and hatchets for the last 40 years even to the point of earning a living with themand other tools of the woodcutter's trade from time to time, I have some strong feelings about what types are best for the outdoorsman.

title: Soviet Tries a Russian on Spy Charges
880 Star To Debut In 1,000
description: Rick Wohlhuter intends to treat his first 1,000meter indoor race like any other halfmile, which is the first sign that a world record may be in jeopardy during the United States Olympic Invitation track meet tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: FALUN, Sweden, Feb. 20 (AP)Norway swept top honors of the men's 15kilometer crosscountry race and the Soviet Union smashed all opposition in the women's fivekilometer race today at the Swedish ski games. Oddvar Braa and Ivar Formo of Norway rallied to beat SvenAake Lundbaeck of Sweden, who controlled the 15kilometer race at the halfway mark. Braa trailed Lundbaeck at that point by 10 seconds but outclassed the Swede in the remainder of the race. Braa's winning time was 45 minutes 26 seconds. Formo was clocked in 45:42, with Arto Koivisto of Finland third in 46:02. Lundbaeck finished fourth 46:04. Tim Caldwell of Bend, Ore., was 30th in 47:44.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1975

title: Bullion Fraud Charged
description: Charging that they had bilked investors in silver and gold bullion of as much as halfamillion dollars, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz of New York State has obtained an injunction barring a corporation, two of its officers and an employe from engaging in the securities business in the state.

title: Recession Imperils CleanUp of the Rhine
description: BONN, Feb. 20Ambitious plans to clean up Europe's most important river, the 825mile Rhine, appear on the way to becoming a casualty of the economic recession. Though billions of dollars have been spent in recent years for purification plants on the Rhine and its tributaries in Switzerland, West Germany, France, Luxembourg and the Netherlands, experts say they have only managed to keep pollution from getting worse than it was in the late nineteensixties.

title: Dividend Action Deferred
description: The board of directors of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Inc.. has deferred action on its dividend. In 1974, the securities concern paid a dividend of cents a share on March 15 and 5 cents a share on Sept. 15.

title: NursingHorne Links Laid To Connecticut Politicians
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 20A number of top Connecticut politicians have financial interests in private nursing homes in the state and have attempted to use their influence to gain favorable treatment, a special investigating committee of the General Assembly was told today.

title: McKay. Admits Errors in Book on DC10
description: The David McKay Company admitted yesterday to a number of mistakes in The Rise and Fall of the DC10 by John Godson, a British aviation writer. The book, with an official publication date of next Friday, is billed on its jacket as the first complete and accurate account of the DC10 crash outside Paris a year ago that took 346 lives.

title: 7 Injured in Train Crash
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Feb. 20 (AP)Seven persons were injured today when a onecar Amtrak commuter train from Harrisburg to Philadelphia slammed into a truck and derailed 10 miles east of here. Injured were the truck driver and six passengers on the train. The police said that the acci dent occurred at an unguarded crossing in Leacock Township.

title: New Thai Government Delayed By Report of a Split in Coalition
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 20 (UPI)  Premierdesignate Seni Pramoj's efforts to form a government took a bizarre turn today when he suddenly canceled the presentation of his cabinet to King Phumiphol Aduldet, saying his coalition had split, only to discover it was a mistake.

title: Largest Reynolds Shareholder Will Sell $80Million in Stock
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., the nation's largest proaucer of cigarettes, announced yesterday that Malcolm P. McLean, a director and its largest preferred stockholder, would sell 1 million shares of Reynolds convertible preferred stock for conversion to common stock that would be resold to the public.

title: HUMOR COLORS SONGS BY GINNY REDINGTON
description: Ginny Redington, a young, blond singer and song writer who appears Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday evenings at, the Coriander, a small restaurant at 314 East 72d Street, is a startling performer.

title: Alcoa President Named To Chief Executive Post
description: W. H. Krome George, 56, was named chief executive officer of the Aluminum Company of America yesterday at a board meeting in Pittsburgh. Mr. George, who will continue as Alcoa's president, will take over his new post on March 1.

title: JUDGE SAYS ROBS VIOLATES RIGHTS
description: The judge whose decision a year ago led to the closing of the Tombs jail ruled yesterday that some practices at Rikers Island, to which inmates from the Tombs were transferred, violated the Constitution.

title: Suspect Held Here In Arms Smuggling Gun Cache Seized
De Waart Conducts Ives's Washington And Russian Works
description: Edo De Waart, the young music director of the Rotterdam Philharmonic and recently appointed principal guest conductor of the San Francisco Symphony, came to Avery Fisher Hall with the Boston Symphony Orchestra on Wednesday night to conduct a program that was partly American, mostly Russian. It consisted of Ives'sWashington's Birthday Shostakovich's Violin Concerto No. I in A minor and a Suite from Prokoviev's Romeo and Juliet. Leonid Kogan, the Soviet virtuoso, was the violin soloist.

title: Police End Fencing Operation; Net 41 Clients and Neat Profit
description: A sham trucking company that was set up by undercover burglary detectives last fall as a cover to purchase stolen property was closed down early this week after $480,000 in stolen credit cards, Government checks, cars, clothing and silverware had been recovered from thieves.

title: Flyers, Sabres Tie, 66
ANGUS M. HARRIS
description: Angus M. Harris, former commissioner and treasurer of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, died Wednesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 82 years old and lived in Saddle River, N. J.

title: IRAN LIFTS PARITY OF RIAL TO DOLLAR
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 20 (Reuters)  Iran set a high parity today for the rial against the dollar because of the decline in the United States currencv's foreienexchange value.

title: Montreal Committee Wins Renewed Support of I.O.C.
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland Feb. 20The organizers of the 1976 Montreal Olympics, using the right words and pictures, have regained the confidence of the International Olympic Committee. They'll be trying to keep the faith once a month for the next year. During that time, the I.O.C. will have no choice but to believe.

title: Trips of Kissinger Car Have Cost HalfMillion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (Reuters)The United States Government has spent more than $500,000 flying Secretary of State Kissinger's armored limousine to his various world diplomatic engagements.

title: Tin Cup Railroad
60 Nursing Home Report Said to Cite Present Group
description: Civil Court Judge Louis I. Kaplan testified yesterday that he presented to Mayor Robert F. Wagner in 1960 evidence of criminal fraud by the identical group that is involved in nursinghome investigations today.

title: TV: Funny Lily Tomlin
description: Lily, taking over the hour that begins at 10 on ABC tonight, is Lily Tomlin, a very funny woman. Armed with a battery of writers (most of them women), her own repertory company (Valli Bromfield, Archie Hahn, Lady Rowlands and Billy Zuckert) and the required guest stars (Richard Dreyfuss, Frank Blair, Dr. Demento), Miss Tomlin chats with the audience about her mother, does a few sketches and, after perching on a giant facsimile of an overstuffed sandwich, throws herself onto the floor while demonstrating a behavioral suggestion for world leaders.

title: C.I.A. Chief Says Charges Imperil Intelligence Work
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20William E. Colby, the Director of Central Intelligence, told Congress today that exaggerated charges of improper conduct by the agency had placed American intelligence in danger.

title: Business Briefs
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 20 (Reuters)Chile and the three other main copperproducing countriesPeru, Zambia and Zaireplan to cut back production by another 5 per cent from March 1, Chile's Mines Minister, Agustin Toro Davila, said today.

title: Clinic Held in Jersey City For Dismissed Employes
description: JERSEY CITY. Feb. 20Sixty  three  yearold August Gross sat in the Jersey City council chambers today and laboriously filled out a reemployment form along with dozens of other city employes.

title: Investors Greet Variety Of Corporate Offerings
description: Offerings of $75million of Mexican bonds: $100million of bank notes and two utility offerings were given what appeared to be a cordial reception when marketed yesterday inthe corporate sector of the credit market.

title: Foreign Aid Plan Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) The House Appropriations Committee approved today a resolution enabling the Federal Government to continue its $3.5billion foreign aid program through the end of March. The foreign aid extension was in cluded in a measure that also would continue spending for health, education and welfare programs through the end of June.

title: President Signs Bill Increasing Debt Limit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)President Ford signed today a bill temporarily increasing the national debt limit from $495billion to $531billion through June 30.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Liberal Democrats Are Mildly Critical of Carey
description: The New Democratic Coalition, the liberal wing of the Democratic party, said yesterday that Governor Carey was veering from the progressive and humane administration it had expected but that it was confident he would get back on track:

title: Consumer Ombudsman
description: Governor Carey's refusal to recommend continuation of the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy is a blow both to consumer interests and to whatever timorous inclinations there may be Albany toward political independence.

title: Bill for Separate Office For the Retarded Gains
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20A bill creating a separate office for mental retardation, which Governor Carey promised to sign during the recent campaign, was passed today by the Senate, despite opposition to it from two key aides to the Governor.

title: FilmMaking Experiencing a Revival On City Streets After a Year's Lull
description: Dressed in faded jeans and chewing bubble gum, Robert Redford stood on a ropedoff street corner in Times Square yesterday, ducking the approaches of fluttering girls and tying up traffic.

title: CITY IN DIFFICULTY ON NEXT PAYROLL
description: Legislation to amend the City Charter will be submitted before the City Council today and the State Legislature next Monday so the city can weather a oneday emergency in cash supply and meet its payroll next week.

title: Father of Hockey's Beliveat
description: VICTORIAVILLE, Quebec, Feb. 20 (UPI)Arthur Beliveau, father of the former Montreal Canadiens hockey star, Jean Beliveau, died today of a heart attack. He was 71 years old. Mr. Beliveau leaves, besides his son, his wife, Esmeralda, two daughters and four other sons.

title: INFORMATION ACT TESTED IN OREGON
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 20Charles O. Porter, former Oregon congressman, filed suit today in Federal District Court in what may be the first test in the nation of the recently amended Freedom of Information Act.

title: Hess Is Denied Permission To Meet Lawyer, Son Says
description: BERLIN, Feb. 20 (Reuters)Wolf Rdiger Hess, son of Hitler's former deputy, Rudolf Hess, said today that his 80 yearold father had been refused permission to meet with, his new lawyer in Spandau prison.

title: Vietcong and Hanoi Units Shell and Raid in South
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20 (AP)North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces carried out attacks in the Mekong Delta and near Saigon today, shelling population centers; blowing up bridges and striking at a regional headquarters of the international peacekeeping force, the Saigon command said.

title: EFFORT TO MODIFY FILIBUSTER RULE FOILED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20Senate reformers were foiled today in their attempt to modify the Senate's filibuster rule by the superior parliamentary skill of Senator James B. Allen, Democrat of Alabama.

title: People in Sports
description: Jimmy Connors, America's topranked tennis player and one of the sport's more controversial figures, has refused to sign with the Pittsburgh Triangles of World Team Tennis. Connors said that because of match commitments in Europe he believed it would be in his best interest to pass up the professional team tennis season. The Triangles said they had signed Evonne Goola gong, Peggy Michel and Ray ni Fox, an 18yearold newcomer to the circuit.

title: U.S. Report Finds Faults In Convention Center Plan
description: The planned New York City Convention Center on the Hudson River will have an adverse effect on airquality standards in the neighboring Clinton area and will produce a substantial financial drain on the city, accordng to a study prepared for the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: LABOR DEMANDS ACTION ON SLUMP
5 CHARGE BEATINGS BY SAIGON POLICE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20Four opposition deputies and a South Vietnamese photographer said that they were beaten by plainclothes policemen today as they attempted to march to, a Saigon courthouse to demand the release of 18 journalists arrested as Communist agents.

title: I.B.M. Suit Delay Asked Papers Held Illegibl
description: Lawyers for both the International Business Machines Corporation and the Justice Department said yesterday it would take at least six more weeks to prepare documents in the Government's antitrust action against the giant computer company.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NEAT MOORING The Showboat Lounge, just inside the main entrance of Joe's Pier 52 Restaurant, 144 West 52d Street, is a pleasantly informal stopover, especially after the theater, with its casual atmosphere and effortless music by the Hey Jackon Quartet. They go on nightly abput 9:.30 o'clock, except Sundays, ensconced in a high niche behind the lounge bar. Behind them. there's a large wallmounted swordfish pointed toward Mr. Jackson, who conducts and doubles as main vocalist at the drums. Instrumentally: and vocally, Charlie LaMont (saxophone), Don Friedman (piano). and Kevin St. John (bass) chime in.

title: WARREN JOLLYMORE
description: Warren R. Jollymore, who had been director of public relations for the Chevrolet Motor division of the General Motors Corporation since June 1, 1972, died yesterday in a hospital in Detroit, following a stroke. He was 53 years old.

title: A.M.A. Suing U.S. Over Peer Review
description: CHICAGO. Feb. 20  The American Medical Association filed suit here today to try to block implementation of regulations that would set up a system of medical neer review.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Staten Island man believed by law officials to be associated with organized crime, was indicted on charges of having murdered one man and critically wounded another in a shooting early Feb. 5 in a bar in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. According to District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn, Mario Paniccioli, 25 years old, of 314 Jefferson Avenue, entered the Club 24 Bar at 2377 86th Street with two other men. He is reported to have shot at John Consola, 27, and then shot and killed the bartender, 27yearold Eugene Glabick, when he sought to aid Mr. Consola.

title: Riders Cited At Bowie in Bet Inquiry
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 20Jockeys who rode in the last race at Bowie Race Course last Friday were subpoenaed today to appear before a Federal grand jury investigating some irregularities at the track.

title: Trevino's 66 Leads by Shot
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 (AP)  Lee Trevino, who hadn't planned on competing and didn't expect to play well, shot a solid fiveunderpar 66 today and established a firstround lead of one stroke in the $150,000 Glen CampbellLos Angeles open golf tournament.

title: Calm Air Marks Pleas At Hearings on Budget
description: William A, Alston, president, of the Queens branch of the United Block Associations and la resident of Hollis, Queens, yesterday asked the joint hearrings of the City Council Finance Committee and the Board of Estimate to add to the city's $1.95billion capital budget et money for planning a youth center in the area.

title: AQUITAINE SEEKS WESTRANS STOCK
description: The Aquitaine Company of Canada, Ltd., made a cash tender offer yesterday for the outstanding shares of Westrans Industries, Inc. The offer is being made through Aquitaine Pennsylvania, Inc., at $36 a share.

description: ROME, Feb. 20The Vatican said today that the views on a number of essential Roman Catholic doctrines professed by the Rev. Dr. Hans Kng, the independentminded Swiss theologian who teaches in West Germany, were in conflict with the church.

title: INFLATION WORSE, A REVISION SHOWS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The nation's inflation rate, shown by its broadest measure, was worse in the last quarter of 1974 than had previously been estimated, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Coombs, Reserve Officer, Plans Early Retirement
A Group Seeks to Buy Nixon Homes in Florida

title: 12 Rule Changes In Canadian League
description: TORONTO, Feb. 20 (AP) The Canadian football League ratified 12 rule changes today, including one that will result in blocking above the waist on punt returns and another that will allow a 2 point option on touchdown conversions this season.

description: TRENTON, Feb. 20An appeals court ruled today that a slate legislator could not have access to files of a special joint legislativeethics committee despite his assertion that its records might give him guidelines for avoiding violations of conflictofinterest statutes.

title: In Memoriam
description: KAHANEManfred S. Feb. 21, 1969. Mote man yesterday, less than tomorrow. Also remembering you on your birthday, Feb. 28. Loving wife, Elly and cevoted daughter. Vivian.

title: Initial Rail Grant Approved by House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The House voted today to appropriate $125million in Federal grants to continue the operation of bankrupt railroads, principally the Penn Central and the ErieLackawanna.

description: Rod Carew, the American League's 1974 batting champion, lost his salary arbitration case yesterday and says he's just a number, not a superstar.

description: The Staten Island home of Mr. and Mrs. James Walter was broken into by burglars last night while they were attending a wake for their son Paul, who was fatally stabbed on a subway train in Manhattan on Tuesday.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Les Mareyeurs, the French seafood restaurant that opened last week at 998 Madison Avenue, has been operating at tidalwave level since the first day. It makes a strong bid for fourstar rating but doesn't get there.

description: Civil Court Judge Louis I. Kaplan testified yesterday that he presented to Mayor Robert F. Wagner in 1960 evidence of criminal fraud by the identical group that is involved in nursinghome investigations today.

description: A bicentennial declaration that urged Americans to broaden their country's birthday celebration into an era of citizen activism and problemsolving was issued yesterday by 40 men and women of varying interests.

title: $5.2Million Total Cited
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 (AP) Bache & Co., the large brok, erage firm, has been accused b the Securities and Exchange Commission with aiding and abetting a scheme that allegedly bilked investors out of $5.2 million.

title: WRY OPENING ON NATURAL GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The Federal Power Commission began an investigation today to determine why certain offshore natural gas is not being produced and sent to market to alleviate the acute natural gas shortage.

title: Music: Piccinni's Didon
description: Any current interest in the composer Niccol Piccinni is historical. He is famous in the music encyclopedias for being a major rival of Gluck's in the late 18thcentury Parisian operatic scene, a rivalry stirred more by the two composers followers than by themselves. Gluck won out, and his operas still hold the stage today. Piccinni's works are almost totally ignored.

title: 3 Shooting Deaths Raise Toll in Uptown Area to 13
description: Death by violence came to three people on the Upper West Side Wednesday night. One victim was a woman, and another Was the older man she had been sheltering in her apartment for nearly 10 years. The third victim was a neighborhood fence, who had been arrested 24 times in the last 30 years. All three were shot to death.

title: MOST ISSUES RISE IT AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Liberal Democrats Are Mildly Critical of Carey
description: The New Democratic Coalition, the liberal wing of the Democratic party, said yesterday that Governor Carey was veering from the progressive and humane administration it had expected but that it was confident he would get back on track.

title: Visiting Chief to Meet Ford
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 20 (Reuters)President Ford will confer here tomorrow with Eric Williams, the Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago, the White House announced today. Mr. Williams is paying a private visit to the United States.

title: Omani Missiles to Guard Persian Gulf
description: MUSCAT, Oman, Feb. 14The Omani Government has decided to deploy Britishmade Rapier groundtoair missiles along the Strait of Hormuz, the gateway to the Persian Gulf, qualified Western informants reported here this week.
