title: NursingHome Links Laid To Connecticut Politicians
description: HARTFORD. Feb. 20A number of top Connecticut politicians have financial interests in private nursing homes in the state, and have attempted to use their influence to gain favorable treatment, a special investigating committee of the General Assembly was told tocLay.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
African Visits Chou
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 20 (Reiiters)Premier Chou Enlai was visited by Samora Machel, the president of the Mozambique Liberation Front, at a hospital in Peking tonight, the Chinese press agency Hsinhua reported. The Chinese leader was, first reported ill last May.

title: Guarantee for Israel?
description: The one new thing in the Middle Eastern diplomatic tangle is that Secretary of State Kissinger is back home talking more publicly, if still vaguely, about an American guarantee of Israel's political independence within secure and internationally recognized boundaries.

title: WAVE OF PROTESTS MOUNTING IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, Feb. 20Housewives and students took part in a mounting wave of protest in Madrid today and the police fired several warning shots to break up silent demonstrations in the center of the city.

title: Ford Wears His Helmet
description: Maybe President Ford played football with his helmet on, after all. And maybe the Democrats have been sandbagged in what looks like their triumph over Mr. Ford's energy program. At the least, he forced them to act; and since they acted as.they did, they now have to produce an energy program of their own.

title: Maresca Opens a 41Pin Lead
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 20A secondyear pro. Tony Maresca, widened his lead from 4 to 41 pins tonight as match play began in the $60,000 Long Island open bowline tournament.

title: Article 3  No Title
News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1975

title: Screen: Three Experiments of 1960's
description: It's always fascinating to re-encounter experimental works after some years have passedto see them outside the period that seemed to frame them. I first saw Kenneth Anger's "Scorpio Rising" in 1965, and it's pleasing to report that it holds up very well. The movie is playing today and tomorrow at the First Avenue Screening Room, and anyone who missed what was once called the underground should catch it."Scorpio," made in 1963, mocks the motorcycle cult and the voluptuous toughs who worship their machines. Blue-tinted shots of Marlon Brando in "The Wild One" and pin-ups of James Dean alternate with glimpses of Cecil B. De Mille's silent "King of Kings," and a Walpurgis party where genitals are plunged through a cardboard skeleton and mustard is squirted in a man's navel. The rock sound-track is hilarious: "Wind Up Doll," "She Wore Blue Velvet," "Baby, You're Torturing Me" and "I Will Follow Him" pound away throughout the proceedings, and there are flashes of some admirable abdomens. However, a few too many death's heads are included.Oddly enough, the references to the nineteen-fifties, which seemed dated and rather ponderous in 1965, don't make the film appear old-fashioned now. Admittedly, one then saw it in an unfortunate contextdraped in the mystique of the underground, when a number of inferior films employed some similar imagery, such as the juxtaposition of Christ and hipsters, or close-ups of all-purpose skulls. But after a decade's education in put-ons, one can savor the impudent freshness of "Scorpio" today.Jack Smith's "Flaming Creatures" (1963) has agedbut so has the print, hence it's hard to fully imagine what the impact would have been in 1966, when the film was judged "indecent, lewd, and obscene," and the theater that showed it was closed by the police. (Also, I suspect that this print may have been cut.) Now, this lighthearted pantomime of a group-grope seems almost as genteel as your in-laws' home movies. Since many of the participants are male transvestites, some in quasi-Victorian costume, it's occasionally startling to see a real breast. Though the turn-ons are elderly, they're still amusing, and the film has acquired a historical interest."Rite of Love and Death" (1968) produced, directed written and performed by the late Yukio Mishima, was based on his fine short story "Patriotism," which concerns a young lieutenant who committed suicide in 1936rather than fight against his friends and fellow officers who had failed in a military coup against the Government. Both the story and the film are intensely romantic about death, but the strength of the prose version springs from anticipation as the man and his wife prepare to kill themselves. However, the silent movie is mannered, creaky and unintentionally comica warped recording of "Tristan and Isolde" dispels the soberness that was intended.

title: U.S. Judge Refuses to Halt Inquiry on Big Dairy Coop
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 20 (UPI)A Federal judge has refused to stop a grand jury investigation of alleged destruction of documents by the nation's largest dairy cooperative.

title: PAUL CHANCELLOR
description: Paul Chancellor, a teacher at the Hill School in Pottstown, Pa., from 1925 to 1967 who developed its program in the humanities in which he held the chair, died Sunday in Philadelphia. He was 74 years old and lived in the Chestnut Hill section of that city.

title: Portugal Mans Land Reforms And Control of Key Industries
description: LISBON, Feb. 20 (AP)The Government announced a blueprint today for state control of key industries and the breakun of big agricultural land holdings.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A rapid transit line serving some 20,000 South Jersey and Philadelphia area commuters daily has been ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission to repeal a 34 month old fare increase, it was announced yesterday. The threemember commission ordered the Lindenwold Rapid, Transit Line, which is operated by the Delaware River Port Authority, to roll back the 5to15cent fare increases within 35 days. A spokesman said that the commission rejected the authority's including depreciation of the line's facilities in computing the rate increase, which went into fleet April 16, 1972. However, the spokesman said, the line will not have to make refunds to riders who have been Jaying the higher fare since then.

title: REGENTS SOFTEN OPPOSITION TO USE OF ETHNIC RATIOS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20The State Board of Regents today significantly softened its earlier opposition to the use of ethnic balance as a measure of integration by implicitly returning to the Commissioner of Education the power to move against districts with racially imbalanced schools.

title: Musical Spotlight Puts Ruth Seeger In Focus Sharply
description: Ruth Crawford Seeger has long held an honorable position in the history of modern American music, particularly for the extraordinarily evocative slow movement of her String Quartet: But as time lengthens between her accomplishment and the present and feminism stimulates our interest in women composers of the past, Mrs. Seeger has been heard with increasing frequency. It wasnot until Wednesday night, however, at Columbia's McMillin Theater, that anybody put together a retrospecive concert; of her workin this area, at least. The performance was under the auspices of the Performers Committee for TwentiethCentury Music.

title: REGENTS SOFTEN OPPOSITION TO USE OF ETHNIC RATIOS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20The State Board of Regents today significantly softened its earlier opposition to the use of ethnic balance as a measure of integration by implicitly returning to the Commissioner of Education the power to move against districts with racially imbalanced schools.

title: Stocks Are Buoyed By Economic News
description: Stock prices advanced yesterday in active trading as the list was buoyed by relatively favorable economic news.

title: Kallinger Is Indicted in Jersey Slaying
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 20Bergen County grand jury charged Joseph Kallinger today with the murder of Maria Faselling, a 21yearold practical nurse, in a robbery in Leonia on Jan. 8, during which seven persons were held hostage.

title: Israelis Debate a U.S. Pledge of Security
EQUITY FINANCING
description: Underwriters headed by Kidder, Peabody & Co., marketed yesterday a secondary offering of 1 million shares of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company common stock at $47.875 a share. All of the shares are being sold by William L. McKnight, trustee of the Maude L. McKnight Testamentary Trust and coexecutor of the estate of Maude L. McKnight. Upon completion of the sale Mr. McKnight will own beneficially 3,747,057 shares or 3.3 per cent of the company's outstanding stock.

title: SILVER AND GOLD SHOW PRICE RISE
description: Silver and gold futures moved up on the Commodity Exchange yesterday on continuing conjecture that the Arab oilproducing nations might insist on payment in constant dollars, or in Swiss francs or West German marks in view of the toll inflation has taken in the value of the dollar. Another factor in the buying of the metals yesterday was the firm Congressional rejection of the President's plan to tax oil imports, a development that could indicate a much larger Government deficit.

title: Boy Kidnapped in Colorado Freed for $5,000 Ransom
description: WESTMINSTER, Colo., Feb. 20 (UPI)A 6yearold boy who had been kidnapped from a Denver suburb and held captive for more than 15 hours was released unharmed today.

title: Mrs. Ammond's Senate Caucus Case Embarrasses Some State Feminists
description: TRENTON, Feb. 20Despite allegations of sex discrimination, the public confrontation between Senator Alene Ammond, the peppery Camden County Democrat, and her Democratic colleagues in the Senate, most of them men, has evoked consternation, embarrassment and dismay among prominent women in the state.

title: Aide to Delaware Governor Acquitted in State Job Case
description: DOVER, Del., Feb. 20 (AP)Wayne D. Ellingsworth, an administrative aide to Gov. Sherman W. Tribbitt, was acquitted of all charges of alleged abuse of state hiring laws today.

title: On Access to Ph. D.'s
description: Recent proposals by the New York State Education Department to curtail or eliminate inadequate Ph.D. programs in public and private universities may improve the quality of doctoral training, but it will also limit educational opportunities for many New Yorkers.

title: Sales of Gas Pushed By Big Oil Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)  The major oil companies started pushing gasoline sales last year because word leaked out that any future gasoline allocations would be based on sales during the last quarter of 1974, the president of a national gasoline station owners group said today.

title: MAN DIES, 26 HURT IN BELFAST ATTACKS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 20A 19yearold construction worker was shot dead today and 26 Roman Catholics were injured in the bombing of two bars tonight.

title: About Real Estate
description: STRATFORD, Conn.The condominium community of Oronoque Village, taking shape here on a hill above the Housatonic River, is not the only place to go to glimpse the evolution in progress in suburban housing in the East. But surely it is one of them.

title: RUSSIANS IN LIBYA INCREASE SHARPLY
description: PARIS, Feb. 20The number of Soviet military advisers and equipment experts in Libya has more than doubled in the last year, a reliable source said here today.

title: MRS. FORD SCORED ON EQUALITY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) Betty Ford's mail at the White House is running 3 to 1 against her outspoken support of passage of the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution, her press secretary, Sheila Weidenfeld, said today.

title: Beatrice Boswell Burton, Kin of Johnson Biographer
description: Beatrice Boswell Eliott Burton, greatgreatgranddaughter of James Boswell, the biographer of Samuel Johnson, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital at the age of 84. She lived at 150 East 72d Street.

description: Richard O'Connor, who wrote some 60 books, mostly biographies and popular history, died: Saturday, apparently of a heart! attack, at his home in Ellsworth, Me. He was 59 years old.

description: LIMA, Peru,  For centuries, Latin  American writers, artists and intellectuals have traditionally been the political gadflies of their countries, often enjoying a following and influence far greater than their colleagues in Europe and the United States.

description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 20  Secretary of State Kissinger has promised that the United States will play a positive role in support of a conference between oil producers and consumers on the price of oil and other raw materials, according to highly placed sources here.

title: The Pop Life
description: Those of us who are interested in both serious culture and popular culture like to try to explain to ourselves why it is possible to like both. Most of the explanations involve the notion that all music is part of the same experience, ranging from the largest audience and the broadest, most vital gestures to refined pleasures for the few. But that all soundrather abstract, so one is grateful when something comes along to help clarify the distinctions.
