description: BOSTON, Feb. 20The defense in the trial of Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin asked today that his conviction for manslaughter of a fetus in a legal abortion be set aside on the ground that it was against the weight of the evidence.

title: A.M.A. Suing U.S. Over Peer Review
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 20  The American Medical Association filed suit here today to try to block implementation of regulations that would set up a system of medical peer review.

title: Persistent DDT
description: Although concentrations of DDT have declined in the world's temperate zones over the past decade, its global spread is now as great as or greater than it ever was. Some 22 per cent of this dangerous pesticide now in use is still exported from the United States, where its domestic application is bannedbut not its manufacture.

title: Delaware Teachers End 3Day Walkout, But Demand Raise
description: DOVER, Del., Feb. 20 (UPI)Public school teachers today ended a strike that had closed most of Delaware's public schools for three days, butt union leaders threatened another walkout unless demands for more money and smaller classes were met.

title: Court Tells U.S. Agencies To Guard A.T.&T. Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) United States District Court Judge Joseph C. Waddy ordered the Justice Department and 43 other Federal agencies today to retain and secure from destruction any documents relating to the Government's antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Double Exacta Barred
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board denied yesterday the request of Roosevelt Raceway for permission to institute a double exacta. The request was to provide a oneticket bet on two consecutive races in which a bettor would pick in exact order the horses finishing first and second in both races. Roosevelt Raceway will begin its 1975 harness racing season on March 3.

title: AFRICANS DRAFTING A PROTEST ON DAVIS
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 20Foreign ministers of 43 African nations were preparing a resolution here today to express their opposition to the appointment of Nathaniel Davis as the United States Under Secretary of State for African affairs.

title: AllisChalmers Cutbacks to Idle 1,200
description: MILWAUKEE. Feb. 20 (UPI) The AllisChalmers Corporation said today it would close its Pittsburgh plant and cut back operations at its plant at Gadsden, Ala., because of losses and constant cash drain on the corporation.

title: BUSINESS LOANS RISE MODERATELY
description: Business loans at major New York City banks, after tumbling sharply from Jan. 1 through early February, rose moderately in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

title: President Adheres to Plan On Energy and Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20Despite the wide margin of the Senate vote yesterday delaying for 90 days President Ford's increased fees on imported crude oil, a White House spokesman insisted today that there can be no compromise on the goals of the President's energy and economic proposals.

title: 4th Period Reported
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that net income climbed 205.4 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1974 and 290 per cent for the year as a whole.

title: Market Place
description: Anthony G. Loreto, executive vice president of the Summit and Elizabeth Trust Company in Summit, N. J., has been buying the niftyfifty stocksjust as the major banks in New York City have been doingsince he joined the bank in 1968.

title: Back to Two Parties
description: WASHINGTONAlmost a year ago, I asked, tentatively for comment and discussion, whether it was not time for a realignment of our political parties into a liberal party and a conservative party.

title: Kallinger Indicted in Death Of Nurse in Leonia Home
description: HACKENSACK, Feb. 20 A Bergen County grand jury charged Joseph Kallinger today with the murder of Maria Fasthing, a 21yearold practical nurse, in a robbery in Leonia on Jan. 8. during which seven persons were held hostage.

title: NoFault Found to Aid HighRisk Drivers
Greek Cypriotes Appeal to U.N. on Turkish Pullout
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 20The Greek Cypriote Government of President Makarios called on the Security Council today to fix a deadline for the withdrawal of the 40,000 Turkish troops from the island.

title: Met Cuts French Show Due in June by 50 Paintings
description: Citing economy reasons, the Metropolitian Museum of Art has cut more than 50 paintings from a major show of French 18th and 19thcentury art. The exhibition has appeared in full at the Louvre and will travel in abbreviated form to the Detroit Institute of Arts on March 5 and to the Metropolitan in June.

title: Prosecutor Urges Lighter Sentences For SmallScale Dealers of Narcotics
description: Substantial changes in the state's drug laws, which were revised less than two years ago, were proposed yesterday by the city's special narcotics prosecutor.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: CBS Inc. has presented its collection of manuscripts of original music, commissioned from leading modern composers in the last 45 years, to the New York Public Library. William S. Paley, CBS chairman, presented the collection, which includes operas and symphonies as well as music in a more popular idiom, for use at the Library of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center, a branch of the Public Library.

title: PANEL VOTES TO VOID $120MILLION FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) The House Appropriations Committee voted today in favor of rescinding nearly $120million in Congressional appropriations. But it said President Ford must spend another $830 million he had asked to be rescinded.

title: Red Cross Names a Fund Chairman
description: Joseph A. Healey, an assistant vice president of the New York Telephone Company, has been appointed general chairman of this year's community appeal fund campaign of the American Red Cross in Greater New York.

title: Books of The Times
description: When Oki was tired of writing, or when a novel was going badly, he would lie down on the couch in the open corridor beside his study. In the afternoon he would often fall asleep there for an hour or two. Only in the past few years had he got into the habit of taking such naps. He used to go out for a walk instead, but after so many years in Kamakura he iiad become all too familiar with the nearby temples, and even with the hills. Then too, being an early riser, he always took a short walk in the morning. Once awake, he could not bear to loll about in bed; also, he preferred to be out of the way while the maid tidied up the house. Before dinner he took a fairly long walk.

title: Florida Man Found Guilty Under New Hijacking Code
description: PENSACOLA, Fla. Feb. 20 (UPI)A Tampa man was found guilty today of attempted hijacking in what was believed to have been the first conviction of its kind since Congress amended the air piracy statute to include planes on the ground.

title: NIXON, FORD VIEWED IN POLL AS OPPOSITES
description: A survey of 1,543 American households indicates that the public's view of President Ford is nearly opposite its opinion of former President Richard M. Nixon, the Harris Poll reported yesterday.

title: Coast Jury Indicts Party Host in Death Of a Rock Musician
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 (Reuters)A murder indictment has been returned here in the death of a rock musician of a drug overdose, sources on the county grand jury said today.

title: Priest Says His Bid To Aid Drunk Led To Larceny Arrest
description: A Roman Catholic priest told a Criminal Court judge yesterday that he had gone to the aid of a man he thought ill or drunk, had been mistaken for a pickpocket, and had been arrested on a charge of grand larceny spending a night in jail.

title: Mayor Daley in First Hard Fight Since 55
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 20For the first time since he took office in 1955, Richard J. Daley is facing vigorous opposition in a Democratic mayoral primary.

title: Sports Today
description: BOWLING

title: HalfMillion Birds Killed At Army Base in Kentucky
description: FORT CAMPELL, Ky., Feb. 20The 101st Airborne Division took advantage of a threequarter moon and 21degree weather last night to mount its first assault on five million blackbirds roosting on the scrawling base here.

title: Bridge:
description: For a serious tournament competitor, playing in New York is a mixed blessing. The field is tougher than anywhere else in North America, so his prospects of winning are correspondingly reduced. But the challenge is greater, and he can sharpen his game regularly against topclass competition.

title: State Freezes $23Million In City DayCare Payments
description: Charging the city with repeated failure to improve fiscal and safety standards in its daycare centers, the state's Department of Social Services has frozen $23.8million in Federal and state payments due the city's daycare program to meet ongoing expenses.

title: Rocky Mount, N.C.: One Example of Integration Without Violence
description: ROCKY MOUNT, N. C.When the black and white high schools in this tobaccoselling center merged in 1969, the Booker T. Washington Lions and the Rocky Mount Blackbirds disappeared. In their stead arose a mythological creature with a bird's head and a lion's body  the Rocky Mount Gryphons.

title: EXAGENT ON TRIAL ON DRUG CHARGES
description: Francis E. Waters went on trial in Federal District Court here yesterday on charges of selling heroin in 1968 shortly after he resigned as a narcotics agent in New York.

title: Jewels on Black Madonna Are Stolen in Venice Church
description: ROME, Feb, 20  Jewels adorning the ancient Black Madonna, a painting in the Madonna della Salute basilica in Venice that was revered by Pope Paul VI, when he visited three years ago, have been stolen, it was discovered today.

title: Irvine and Potvin Score With Writers
description: Ted Irvine of the Rangers, who scores few points, and Denis Potvin of the Islanders, who scores a lot, were honored yesterday for something that had nothing to do with points. Both players won Good Guy awards from the New York Chapter of the Professional Hockey Writers Association.

title: CAIRO WARNS ISRAEL ON AIRCRAFT PLANT
description: CAIRO, Feb. 20 (UPI)Egypt warned Israel today that plans to build a $10million aircraft plant in East Jerusalem was aggression that could blow up chances of peace in the Mideast.

title: Notes on People
description: The expected appointment of Kieran O'Doherty, a founder and vice chairman of the state's Conservative party, as a $38,000ayear commissioner of the Postal Rate Commission was announced yesterday by President Ford.

title: Three Shot to Death on Same Night Bring Uptown Area Toll in 75 to 13
description: Death by violence came to three people on the Upper West Side Wednesday night. One victim was a women, and another was the older man she had been sheltering in her apartment for nearly 10 years. The third victim was a neighborhood fence, who had been arrested 24 times in the last 30 years. All three were shot to death.

title: ABU DHABI DEMANDS RISE IN OIL OUTPUT
FilmMaking Experiencing a Revival On City Streets After a Year's Lull
description: Dressed in faded jeans and chewing bubble gum. Robert Redford stood on a ropedoff street corner in Times Square yesterday, ducking the approaches of fluttering girls and tying up traffic.

title: 2Mile Relay Record Set In L.I. Meet
I Puritani Opens City Opera's Spring Season
description: Colds, laryngitis, influenza and all their relatives are no respecters of persons. Last night they played havoc with the opening night of the New York City Opera's spring season. The opera was Bellini's I Puritani. On Wednesday. Enrico di Giuseppe, the leading tenor, seemed in vocal trouble. A call went out to Pierre royal in Canada to come down and stand by. When performance time came, he had to replace Mr. di Giuseppe.

title: 2 CAR MAKERS SET WORKER RECALLS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 20The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation will call back some laidoff workers next week, indicating auto output will increase slightly in the week ahead but will still run far behind 1974.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority has agreed to purchase 70 commuter rail cars for $51.1 million from the General Electric Company with an option for 30 more. The cars will be built at G.E.'s Erie, Pa., plant.

title: Meany and Labor's Role in 1976
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20George Meany's comments in Miami Beach the other day indicate that he and the A.F.L.C.I.O. are reverting to the days before 1968, when they took no major part in Presidential nominating politics. The difficulty with that, his political friends and foes agree, is that the political world of a decade ago no longer exists.

title: Taxes Turned Over
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 (UPI), The manager of a Los Angeles radio station turned over to a grand jury today the tape recording of the last message from Patricia Hearst.

title: Chiefs Hire Schnelker
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 20 (AP) Bob Schnelker, a veteran assistant coach in the National Football League, was named an offensive assistant today for the Kansas City Chiefs. Schnelker, who coached receivers for the Miami Dolphins last season, is the fifth assistant hired by Paul Wiggin, the new head coach of the Chiefs.

title: Ethiopia Questions 90 Soldiers On Reports of Eritrea Killings
description: ADDIS ABABA. Ethiopia, Feb. 20Some 90 Ethiopian army officers and men are being questioned here by officials of the military Government in connection with allegations that civilians were killed and private property was looted by Ethiopian soldiers during the fighting in and around Asmara.

title: FORD PROFIT FALLS 61% IN QUARTER
Corralling of Ordinary People Gives State Senators Some Tips on Ethics
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20Staff aides of a legislative ethics committee that has been ignored by the public went into the streets today to coax ordinary people before a hearing microphone, and returned with some tart, skeptical witnesses.

title: Mayor Daley in First Hard Fight Since 55
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 20For the first time since he took office in 1955, Richard J. Daley is facing vigorous opposition in Democratic mayoral primary.

title: Delay in School Votes Stays Nominations Too
description: TRENTON, Feb. 20 (AP)State Attorney General William F. Hyland ruled today that, because local school board elections are being postponed, the filing of nominating petitions for these elections and the advertising of the availability of absentee ballots also had to be delayed.

title: MEDICAID SYSTEM INSTATE ASSAILED
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20New York State's $3billionayear Medicaid program, the country's biggest, is the only one in the country that does not have a computerbased management system, a state study group said today.

title: Bonn Vote Favors Newsmen
description: BONN, Feb. 21 (AP)A law giving newsmen the unlimited right to refuse to divulge the source of their information won approval in the West German Parliament today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1975

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Article 1  No Title
Yugoslavia Closes Magazine Critical of Regime
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21The only legal Yugoslav publication that has regularly criticized the regime in the last 11 years has been forced by the ruling Communist party to close.

title: Berit Lindholm Sings Brunnhilde Role
description: sustain the necessary vocal quality and eloquence throughout his long secondact monologues, and he received too little help from Mr. Ehrling in the way of orchestral drama while plodding through these dry stretches.

title: Drug Ring Catering to Blacks Is Termed Broken in Brooklyn
Youth, Shot by Robber, Dies of His Wounds
description: PATERSON, Feb. 21 (UPI) A 15yearold boy who was shot in the head during a holdup Thursday night at a corner grocery store here, died today, authorities said.

title: CITY AGAIN BACKS WEST SIDE CENTER
description: City officials yesterday reaffirmed their intention to push ahead with construction of the $200million New York City Convention and Exposition Center on the Hudson River.

title: Penn Routs Cornell Five By 95 to 75
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Stenmark, Miss Wenzel Ski Victors
description: NAEBA, Japan, Feb. 21 (AP)The World Cup ski leaders, Annemarie Proell of Austria and Gustavo Thoeni of Italy, were both disqualified today after missing gates. Hanny Wenzel of Lichtenstein won the women's slalom and Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden the men's giant slalom.

title: Black Culture Seeks Strength at the Community Level
description: EUTAW, Ala.The audience was made up at young adults and students who looked about curiously as they filed slowly into the high school gymnasium to watch a play instead of a basketball game.

title: DOLLAR CONTINUES TO SLUMP ABROAD
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 21 (UPI)The dollar continued to decline on European currency markets today, closing, at a record low in Firankfurt but recovering from recordlow openings on other exchanges.

title: Funding Sterilization and Abortion for the Poor
description: A Department of Health, Education and Welfare proposal, now under study, to fund 90 per cent of the costs of sterilization for the poor but only to match state funds for abortion for the poor, is but the latest example of an ongoing disregard for individual freedom of choice.

title: New Pilot Warning System
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (UPI)United Air Lines has ordered a $3.8million airplane audio warning system to warn pilots when they have flown too close to the ground. A United spokesman said yesterday that the device would be installed in the cockpits of all United planes, including cargo aircraft.

title: Blacklisted Banks Take Part in French Rail Loan
description: PARIS, Feb. 21  The French stateowned railway system is using banks blacklisted by Arabs to help it borrow $40 million.

title: Senate Filibuster Stalls Rail Relief Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21Senate reformers prepared today for another assault next week on the Senate's filibuster rule.

title: SHOP TALK
Freight Train Is Derailed In Passing Amtrak Train
description: WOODBRIDGE, Va., Feb. 21 (UPI)A southbound freight train was derailed today while passing a New Yorkbound Amtrak train catrying 442 persons. At least 21 injuries were reported when seven passenger cars were knocked off the track.

title: Music: Kubelik Finale
description: Rafael Kubelik, completing his twoweek stint as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic, is leading the orchestra this week in Brahms's Symphony No. 2 and Frank Martin's Petite Symphonie Concertante for Harpsichord, Harp, Piano and Double String Orchestra, and the two works bring out the best in him.

title: STATE IS WEIGHING BIRTHPILL RULES
description: TRENTON, Feb. 21  The State Department of Health said here today that it was reconsidering its policy of requiring unmarried minors to have parental consent when obtaining contraceptive pills or devices.

title: PRICES RISE AGAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
Cairo Paper Calls Sinai Withdrawal Pact Certain
description: CAIRO, Feb. 21 (UPI)The weekly newspaper Akhbar alYom said today that an agreement on Israel's withdrawal from Sinai passes and the Abu Rudeis oilfield in return for American guarantees of Israel's security is certain unless an unforeseen surprise occurs.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HAPPY TIDE The Beachcomber is back and about time. The marvelous old 1938 comedy starring Charles Laughton and Elsa Lanchester is rarely shown anywhere these days. The picture was made in England, shortly before the Laughtons moved to Hollywood, after two previous joint appearances in The Private Life of Henry VIII and Rembrandt, with five more to come in Hollywood. But The Beachcomber remains their most effective teamwork. It's also one of the best filmings of W. Somerset Maugham, adapted from his short story Vessel of Wrath and having to do with the clash and ironic involvement of a South Seas wastrel and a missionary's sister. Directed by Erich Pommer, the picture was remade in 1955 in color, with fair success, starring Glynis Johns and Robert Newton (he played an island official in the first version).

title: More Banks Join in Cut Of Prime Rate to 8%
description: The nation's two largest banks  the Bank of America and the First National City Bank  lowered yesterday their prime interest rates on corporate loans to 8 per cent from 8 per cent, joining the Chemical Bank, which moved first to this level last Thursday.

title: Pistons Lose 7th Straight
Women Who've Turned School of Hard Knocks Into Credits for College
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.Women who have lived and learned are earning up to 30 credits toward degrees from the College of New Rochelle for writing their life stories.

title: Olympic Invitation Track Results
description: 1,600meter relay (handicap)First race: 1, Suffolk Community (50 meters) (Mike Cohen, Bob Orgoran, Rich Jarhmarkt, George Schroeder), 3:24.8; 2, Iona (20 meters) 3:25.1; C.C.N.Y. (20 meters), 3:26.8; 4, York College (50 meters); 5, Manhattan College (scratch), 3:28.2.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE DRAWS LABOR'S IRE
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 21 The Executive Council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. charged today that the Federal Reserve System under the chairmanship of Dr. Arthur F. Burns had brought recession to the American economy and unemployment to millions of workers.

title: ForeignTrained Students Cite Medical Blacklisting
description: Wearing hoods to protect their identities, four whitecoated medical students said at a news conference yesterday that they had been virtually blacklisted by state medical facilities because they had been trained in foreign medical schools.

title: Rise Seen in Pay to Illegal Aliens in State
description: NEWARK, Feb. 21Leonard F. Chapman Jr., the Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said today that there were about 300,000 illegal aliens in New Jersey.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press

title: People in Sports
description: Johnny Bench, the allstar catcher of the Cincinnati Reds, married a New York model, Vickie Chesser, last night at Christ Episcopal Church in Cincinnati.

title: Watergate Toll. Case Histories of 17 Men
description: Seventeen former aides to Richard M. Nixon or employes of his 1972 reelection campaign have been convicted or have pleaded guilty to charges in the Watergate breakin and its subsequent coverup.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Rangers' LineUp
description: AT TORONTO

title: Big One at Gulfstream
description: The $100,000 Gulfstream Park Handicap will be held on Saturday, March 22. It is one mile and a quarter for 3 yearolds and upward.

title: I.T.T. TO PURCHASE NEW STOCK OF AVIS
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation will buy about 1.4 million newly issued shares of the common stock of Avis, Inc., for about $17million, it was announced yesterday by Richard Joyce Smith, trustee of the 52 per cent interest in Avis, Inc., to be divested by I.T.T. under a court order.

title: West Coast Okies Recall Depression, Scoff at Recession
description: WEEDPATCH, Calif., Feb. 16  Okies, they called them then. No matter where they came from. And the name was an epithet, spat out with hatred, derision and sometimes even fear.

title: Canucks Defeat Islanders On Gould's 3 Goals, 41
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 21 All reporters were barred from the New York Islanders dressing room tonight by the general manager, Bill Torrey, after the team's 41 defeat.

title: Ford Reported Delaying Veto on Oil Tariff Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) In an effort to buy time for reversing opposition in Congress, President Ford has put off until next week the veto of a bill suspending his authority to increase the tariff on oil imports, White House sources said today.

title: James W. Husted, Lawyer And Civic Leader Here, 78
description: James W. Husted, for many years managing partner of the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts, died Thursday in a nursing home in Somers, N.Y. He was 78 years old and since his retirement in 1969 had lived in Bedford, N. Y. He had formerly lived at 7 Gracie Square.

title: Short Interest Sets Big Board Record
Seeks Asylum in U.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO Feb. 21 (AP)A Manila newspaperman who asserts that he was chief censor for President Marcos says that he is seeking asylum in the United States.

title: At New Yorker, Fete With a Diffidence
description: The New Yorker marked its 50th anniversary yesterday Diffidently.

title: A WOULDBE ROBBER IS SLAIN IN NEVADA
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 21 (AP)A wouldbe robber demanding $100,000 and holding a woman hostage at a savings and loan office was shot to death by police today after a sixhour standoff. The woman was freed unharmed.

title: Knicks' LineUp
description: AT GARDEN

title: Beame Assails State Freeze on DayCare Payments
4 HELD AS SUSPECTS IN BURGLARY SERIES
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Feb. 21An undercover investigation of a series of burglaries in Sullivan County resulted yesterday in the arrestof of three men and a woman and the recovery of $250,000 in stolen stork certificates.

title: CreditCard Ruling Bars Extra Charge
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit reversed today a Federal district court ruling that permitted national banks in Pennsylvania to charge compound interest on the delinquent accounts of creditcard holders of two local banks.

title: Stone's Shoulder Miseries Mar Mets Camp Opening
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 21Men in baseball suits suddenly appeared across the Florida landscape today as four of the 24 major league teams opened spring trainingincluding the New York Mets, who, opened their camp here with more grief for Yogi Berra's pitching staff.

title: A Conversation
description: St. Patrick's Cathedral and Temple Emanuel are fifteen blocks apart on Manhattan's East Side and worlds apart in ritual and theology. The spiritual leaders and the laity of these two religious centers have begun a conversation to explore what it is that they hold in common and what it is that divides them. The exchange of views that began earlier this month is scheduled to continue for at least a year. But it might well go on indefinitely.

title: $4Million in Art Stolen In German Burglaries
description: HANOVER, West Germany. Feb. 21 (Reuters)Works of art worth more than $4.6million have been stolen in burglaries here and Frankfurt.

title: New Thai Government Seated; U. S. Ambassador Is Reassigned
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 21  The reassignment of the American ambassador, a controversial figure because of his military and intelligence background, was announced here today as King Phumiphol Aduldet formally appointed a twoparty minority Government.

title: Barnett Assails CBSTV On Mississippi Movie
description: JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 21 (UPI)  Former Gov. Ross Barnett accused the CBS television network today of trying to create an atmosphere of ill will toward Mississippi with a movie about the slayings in 1964 of three civil rights workers.

title: CORRECTION
description: The prices of hamantashen at Gertel's Bake Shop, 53 Hester Street, were incorrectly given yesterday in an article in The New York Times. Gertel's charges 45 cents apiece for the large hamantashen and $3 a pound for the small.

title: Carnation Company Posts 27% Rise in 4thQuarter Profits on 23% Sales Gain; Other Companies Report
Metropolitan Briefs
description: William Cahn, former District Attorney of Nassau County, testified for five and a half hours before a Federal grand jury that is believed to be investigating charges that he doublebilled the county for expenses incurred while attending conventions of the National District Attorneys Association. Specifically, the grand jury is reported looking into allegations that Mr. Cahn, during his tenure as District Attorney, received $18,000 from the association and then billed the county for the same expenses. During his appearance, Mr. Cahn could be heard at times protesting loudly that he had done nothing wrong. Last month, the County Controller cleared Mr. Cahn of the allegations of double billing.

title: Books of The Times
description: By ANATOLE BROYARD When reading crime novels, I have always found it easier to suspend my disbelief in Istanbul than in New York, and when it comes to California, I'm not willing to suspend it at all. Escape fiction, for me, seems to mean escaping not just from reality, but from American reality. To read a fictional account of crime in this country now seems like nothing short of masochism.

title: 2 SUGAR REFINERS CUT PRICE 2 CENTS
description: Two of the nation's largest sugar refiners announced yesterday their third price cut in grocery sugar in seven weeks, but the reduction, 2 cents a pound, was the smallest of the three. The reductions were made for retailers and, depending on competitive conditions, may be passed along to consumers.

title: West Coast Okies Recall Depression, Scoff at Recession
description: WEEDPATCH, Calif., Feb. 16  Olties, they called them then. No matter where they came, from. And the name was an epithet, spat out with hatred, derision and sometimes even fear.

title: Bridge
description: Beginners learn a simple rule in handling honor sequences in defense: lead high, and follow low. Observing this guideline permits the other defender to draw useful inferences about the location of cards in the suit.

title: U S. ISSUES FUNDS TO SUBSIDIZE RENTS
General Motors to Cut Small Cars List Prices
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 21The General Motors Corporation, price leader of the auto industry, announced today that it would reduce prices of nine of its smaller cars by $104 to $313 by making optional some equipment that is now standard.

title: Federal Funds Released For Hospital Construction
description: TRENTON, Feb. 21 (UPI)Health Commissioner Joanne E. Finley said today that $34.8 million in impounded Federal funds were now available to New Jersey for the construction of hospitals and other health facilities.

title: PILOTS URGE CHANGES IN TRAFFIC CONTROL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 21 (UPI) Airline pilots and ground controllers called today for sweeping changes in the United States air tratfic control system, but clashed over whether controllers should be given more responsibility for aircraft.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Pavane pour une inIfante defunte, Ravel; Violin Concerto, Beethoven.

title: F.T.C. SEEKS DATA OF 34 COMPANIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission said today it had asked a court to force some of the nation's biggest companies to surrender detailed information about their profits and losses on individual product lines.

title: State Completes Program To Regulate Its Wetlands
U.S. WELFARE AID CUT $67.5MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21The Ford Administration, as part of its continuing effort to influence localities to purge their welfare rolls of ineligible recipients and reduce inaccurate payments, has cut the Federal contribution to states for family assistance by $67.5million this quarter.

title: Carey Denies He Promised Separate Unit for Retarded
description: ALBANY, Feb. 21Governor Carey denied today that he had ever made a campaign promise to create a separate state agency to care for the mentally retarded, He was immediately contradicted by State Senator William T. Conklin, who said he had heard the pledge at a dinner and could obtain affidavits from an audience of 700 parents who had given Mr. Carey a standing ovation on hearing the pledge.

title: 2 Cited Riders Skip Triple
Kissinger and Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21In the final days of the Nixon Administration and the early days of the Ford Administration, Congress viewed Secretary of State Kissinger as indispensable and unassailable. Now, a few months later, an increasing number of legislators want either Mr. Kissinger's power dispersed or his services dispensed with.

title: Average Size of Household Dips Below Three Persons
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) The average size of the nation's households has dipped below the threeperson level for the first time in history, as more people than ever before are living alone, the Census Bureau says.

title: WATER PROJECTS NOW GET PRIORITY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 21 (UPI)A new policy on fighting pollution is emerging from the State Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Major Factories Agree to U.S. Limit On Water Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI)  Factories responsible for nearly 80 per cent of the nation's industrial water pollution have agreed to bring their dumping down to the limits set by law, the Environmental Protection Agency announced today.

title: Moscow Revisited: Same Faces at the Top, but Living Is Changed
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21The Kremlin is still impenetrable. The economy is still confounded by its own plans. Social and political life remains under a heavy official thumb. St. Basil's is still too beautiful. The extremes and the excesses that tend to overwhelm are intact.

title: Back to ScatterSite
description: Live long enough in New York and everything reverses itself; ideas, attitudes and policies go up and down like a yoyo. The Lindsay administration started high on scattersite housingthe theory that public housing small doses could be absorbed by neighborhoods without the dislocating impact of largescale, lowincome developments.

title: Douglass 137 Leads Golf By 3 Shots
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 (UPI)While Lee Trevino, Jack Nicklaus and Johnny Miller had problems with the weather, Dale Douglass took a threeshot lead at the halfway point of the $150,000 Glen Campbell Los Angeles open golf tournament today with a twounderpar 69 in the wind.

title: Senator Church Decries Furor Over C.I.A. Inquiry
Notes on People
description: The director of the new Congressional Budget Office, who could, say many observers, become the most powerful staff director in Congress, will be Dr. Alice M. Rivlin, Congressional sources confirmed yesterday. Her fouryear appointment, at 540,000 a year, is expected to be announced Monday by Speaker of the House Carl Albert and Senator James O. Eastland, president pro tern of the Senate. The Congressional Budget Office was established in July to provide a staff of expertsprobably about 150to help Congress set its own policies and priorities for Federal expenditures and, when necessary, challenge the executive branch's Office of Management and Budget.

title: Basketball By Women At Garden
description: The largest crowd to see a women's collegiate basketball game in New York City is expected today when Queens College plays Immaculate (Pa.) College in the first game of a college doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: Medicaid Indictment
description: The owner of the Smithtown (L. I.) Nursing Home and a Westchester County accountant were indicted on charges of having swindled Medicaid out of more than $500,000. Page 13.

title: 72 From Shut Nursing Homes Badly Ill
description: Seventytwo persons recently removed from substandard nursing homes in the city required hospital care, according to officials of four city hospitals where the people were taken.

title: U.S. Judge Refuses to Move Trial in Educators Slaying
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 21 (UPI)A Federal District Court judge refused today to move the murder trial of two members of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army from here to Los Angeles.

title: COLOMBIA PLANNING FULL TIES WITH CUBA
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 21 (AP)Colcmbia will restore full diplomatic relations with Cuba, Foreign Minister Indalecio Lievano announced today.

title: Nyquist's Questions on Legality Led to Regents Retreat
description: Kenneth B. Clark, the only black member of the State Board of Regents, was standing in the hall outside the board's meeting room Thursday as his colleagues hammered out their latest revision of state school integration policy. He was visibly elated, and quoted Sir Walter Scott with sardonic glee: Oh, what a tangled web we weave, when first we practice to deceive.

title: ACCORD REPORTED ON ABU DHABI OIL
description: BEIRUT, Feb. 21Foreign oil companies operating in Abu Dhabi are reported to have reached a compromise with the Government under which they will end a production cutback imposed last month and the Government will cancel a premium for the lowsulphur content of the oil.

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS DEFENSE BUDGET BID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) President Ford called on Congress today to approve without cuts his 92.8billion defense budget and vowed that he would sign no declaration of dependence and inferiority.

title: Costs in Metropolitan Area Up Only 0.2% in January
description: Prices of consumer goods and services in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area, on a seasonally adjusted basis, rose slightly in January, 0.2 per cent, indicating some moderation in the pace of inflation here, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday.

title: Daylight Time Begins At 2 A.M. Tomorrow
description: Most of the nation will set clocks forward one hour at 2 A.M. tomorrow when daylight time will again go into effect, and will continue for eight months.

title: Laver Defeats Tanner to Reach Final
description: LaCOSTA, Calif., Feb. 21The scoreboard sad that Rod Laver won today from Roscoe Tanner to reach the final of the $60,000 Michelob Classic on the World Championship Tennis tour. But the script defied belief.

title: Restoring Balance
description: In ruling unanimously that former President Nixon had exceeded his legal authority when he impounded $9 billion in funds appropriated to fight water pollution, the Supreme Court took a moderate step toward restoring the constitutional balance of power between President and Congress. Such an agreement among the Court's liberal and conservative members is significant because it will remind future Chief Executives that they may nullify or ignore the will of Congress at their peril.

title: ETHIOPIAN FORCES IN FIERCE CLASHES WITH GUERRILLAS
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 21Fierce fighting erupted in at least four parts of Eritrea Province today as Ethiopian fighterbombers, armored vehicles, artillery and troops attacked villages and roads held by secessionist guerrillas.

title: Opera: Lavish Turandot
Dave Anderson
description: Aren't you superweary of superstars? Aren't you superflogged by the supernromotion of superstars?.

title: Rogers Plans Latin Visit
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 21 (Reuters)William D. Rogers, Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs, will visit Latin America from March 9 t17 to prepare for a trip by Secretary of State Kissinger. the State Department said today. Mr. Rogers plans to visit Brazil, Venezuela, Chile, Argentina, Uruguay and Peru.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1975

title: A Catholic Priest Is Acquitted Here Of Pocketpicking
description: A Criminal Court judge yesterday acquitted a Roman Catholic priest who had been arrested for stealing a wallet belonging to a man he tried to help.

title: Opera: Miss Nilsson Is Sieglinde in Met Walkure
Swim Mark to Miss Gray
description: PERTH, Australia, Feb. 21 (UPI)Fifteenyearold Sonya Gray set an Australian record today when she swam the 400meter freestyle in 4 minutes 17.9 seconds2.1 seconds shy of the world recordat the national swimming championships. Miss Gray's time was 1.2 seconds faster than the previous record set by Jenny Turrall of New South Wales.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: Medicaid Indictment

title: Business Briefs
description: ALBANY, Feb. 21 (AP)Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today that he had ordered an investigation into alleged pressures by Arab sources on major New York securities firms.

title: HAROLD E. NEAVE
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 21 (UPI)Harold E. Neave, former secretarytreasurer for ScrippsHoward Newspapers for 40 years, died yesterday at St. George Hospital here. He was 84 years old.

title: GRAIN PRICES OFF; SOYBEANS DOWN
description: Grains and soybeans dropped yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly in reaction to adoption by the European Economic Community of import levies on corn to reduce European demand for United States corn, used mainly to feed livestock.

title: Provocative Questionnaires End A Dating Business at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, Feb. 21 (UPI)The Student Creative Dating Service died a quick death here today after blushing university officials got wind of provocative questionnaires being sent through the campus mail, a spokesman said today.

title: WindSwept Oil
description: The nation's governors appear unwilling to recognize that oil and wind mix no better than oil and water. At their annual conference in Washington, the governors declaredwith only one dissenting votethat a conservation program of massive proportions must be the central focus of our nation's shortrange energy management program. But all sense of urgency was drained from that brave sentiment by the pathetic inadequacy of the machinery proposed for cutting fuel use.

title: Soviet Woos Gulf Oil in Drilling Deal
description: The Soviet Union has disclosed that it looks to the Gulf Oil Corporation as a potential partner in the exploration and development of oil deposits off the Soviet Far Eastern island of Sakhalin.

title: Impounded Funds Released For Hospital Construction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) The Government is releasing $292million in previously impounded hospital and nursinghome construction funds, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today.

title: BEREL WEINSTEIN
description: Beret Weinstein, an inventor and industrialist, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Fort Lee, N. J. He was 28 years old.

title: U.N. RIGHTS PANEL CENSURES ISRAEL
BARBARA R. RINKOFF
description: Barbara Rich Rinkoff, an author of books for children and young adults, died Tuesday of cancer at her home in Mount Kisco. N. Y. Her age was 52.

title: Wind Dissipator Devised for Skyscrapers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21High winds that move down the sides of certainskyscrapers may injure somebody on the walk near the entrance.

title: 2 Die in Connecticut Shooting and Fire
description: STONINGTON, Conn., Feb. 21A 30yearold man and his girlfriend were found dead of shotgun wounds this afternoon after police officers stormed a burning building on the outskirts of this New England village.

title: Colonels Lose, Drop to Second
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 21 (UPI)Warren Jabali's 3 point basket with 4 minutes remaining helped the San Diego Conquistadors to a 110108 victory over Kentucky tonight that knocked the Colonels out of their firstplace tie with the New York Nets in the Eastern Division of the American Basketball Association.

title: S.E.C. Disputes Charges on Bank Role; Needham Asks Changes in Reform Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21The Securities and Exchange Commission brought into the open today its longsmoldering disagreement with the office of the Controller of the Currency on how to handle banks in financial trouble.

title: Riverside Drive Building Owner Slain
description: Frank Horch, partowner and manager of the Masters Apartments at 310 Riverside Drive, whose father constructed the building and fashioned it into a cultural center for the Upper West Side, was shot to death there last night when he went into the basement to check the boiler room.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A Catholic Priest Is Acquitted Here Of Pickpocketing
description: A Criminal Court judge yesterday acquitted a Roman Catholic priest who had been arrested for stealing a wallet belonging to a man he tried to help.

title: Eden Recyded
description: A new heaven swept and garnished No Raggedy Ann people in it Hell, too, gone bourgeois Gas heat, floors of Persian muff Smog evanescent, obsolescent Cars Naderized f.o.b. Air and water depolluted Babies phylacterized, no dirt no more Worms in the woodwork Ecologized, reenergized Gully sludge photosynthesized Into aboriginal apples No backfire, no bellyache Planes and planets funtumbling Caught in seas of absorbent cotton Deluxe kidnappers parlayed Into finest public servants

title: French Justice Minister Releases 2 Portal Women
description: Paris, Feb. 21The French Minister of Justice today ordered the survivors of the Portal family, who armed themselves to avoid eviction from their manor in the South of France, released from psychiatric care.

title: A Russian, in Washington, Questions U.S. Reliability
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21A senior Soviet official said today that the collapse of the SovietAmerican trade agreement had raised questions in Moscow about the Ford Administration's ability to honor commitments in more complicated areas.

title: SURRENDER SEEN IN DRUG FATALITY
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21The police said today that they expected Kenneth Moss, the 31 yearold former New Yorker who became nationally known as the Wall Street whiz kid, to surrender voluntarily to face a murder charge in the drug overdose death of a rock musician.

title: Offstage, Royal Shakespeareans Play the Ambassador
description: On stage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in plays by Shakespeare and Gorky, or teaching Students at New York University (in a program financed by the National Endoirment for the Humanities), there is no mistaking the Royal Shakespeare Company. As actors and as parttime academicians, the cast is sharpeyed, quicktongued and the essence of articulateness.

title: Nixon Has No Comment About Jail Sentences
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 21 (UPI)Former President Richard M. Nixon made no immediate comment today on the jail sentences handed down to four Watergate conspirators, including three of his closest advisers.

title: TWO MASS RAPES LINKED IN BRONX
Coast Guard Cites 2 for Negligence In Tanker Crash
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 (UPI)A United States Coast Guard Marine Board of Investigation said today that it had found evidence of negligence andor misconduct on the part of the captain and pilot of an AMerican tanker involved in Jan. 31 crash that left 11 persons known dead and 15 missing.

title: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN JANUARY, BUT RATE SLOWED
Prisoners and Protest
description: A poet serving a life sentence because his words had displeased an authoritarian government was freed the other day. Therein lies the answer to the question of whether protest hurts or helps political prisoners rotting In jails in distant lands. The answer, once again, is that even dictatorships can be embarrassedsometimesinto granting freedom to dissenters.

title: General Motors to Cut Small Cars' List Prices
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 21The General Motors Corporation, price leader of the auto industry, announced today that it would reduce prices of nine of its smaller cars by $104 to $313 by making optional some equipment that is now standard.

title: and Ending Pollution
description: Constitutional questions aside, the release of additional billions of dollars in funds authorized by cleanwater legislation could not be more timely. The contemplated sewers and sewage treatment plantsmany of them long since contracted for  are desperately needed; the Court's decision will open up a very large number of jobs, and money to pay for the program is already authorized and available.

title: Edward Fairchild, 76, Dies; Music Director, Conductor
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 (AP)Edward (Cookie) Fairchild, musical director and conductor, whose career spanned 45 years on Broadway and in Hollywood, died yesterday at the Motion Picture. Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: 5 Die in Chattanooga Fire
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 21 (UPI)Five persons, including a grandmother, her daughter and her granddaughter, were killed early today when fire raced through a twostory frame apartment building in north Chattanooga. The police identified the victims as Jerry and Lucielle Cortney, both in their 40's; Mrs. Beaula Thompson, about 50, her daughter, Vickie, 18, and granddaughter, Johnnie, 3 months.

title: ABORTIONS CURBED AT HOSPITAL ON L.I.
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., Feb. 21  The superintendent of the Nassau County Medical Center said today that the physicians in its department of obstetrics and gynecology would no longer perform abortions on women who were more than 12 weeks pregnant unless the mother's life was in danger.

title: Stock Index Up 4.39 As Volume Climbs
description: The stock market closed higher yesterday in accelerated trading as investors continued to draw encouragement from sliding interest rates and a possible further easing in the nation's monetary policy.

title: Albert Aide Indicted In Influence Scheme
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21The Justice Department disclosed today that a secretary to House. Speaker Carl Albert and a Texas lawyer had been indicted by a Federal grand jury on, charges of fraudulently representing themselves as influence peddlers.

title: Report of Lower Oil Output Is Disputed by Venezuelans
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21The Venezuelan Embassy disputed today a report from Caracas that Venezuela would reduce oil production in 1975 to 2.4 million barrels a day from 2.6 million in 1974.

title: COURT SUSTAINS CRABIEL COUNTS
description: TRENTON, Feb. 21 Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel has lost a legal battle to have the State Superior Court dismiss an indictment charging him with rigging state highway bids.

title: Robert Strauss, Actor, 61, Dies; Known for Stalag Comic Role
A Russian, in Washington, Questions U.S. Reliability
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21A senior Soviet official said today that the collapse of the SovietAmerican trade agreement had raised questions in Moscow about the Ford Administration's ability to honor commitments in more complicated areas.

title: KAHANE GETS YEAR IN 74 CONVICTION
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday sentenced Meir Kahane, head of the militant Jewish Defense League, to one year in prison, declaring that the rabbi had twice willfully and intentionaly violated the terms of his probation.

title: Momoyama Art a Rare Show at Met
description: One of the greatest epochs in the history of Japanese artthe Momovama period, dating from 1566 to 1615is currently the subject of a dazzling and unusual exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It is the first such exhibition to be exported from Japan, and consists of more than 100 works of artimmense screen paintings, portraits, ceramics, gold lacquer and costumes and masks of the No theatermany of which are Japanese national treasures.

title: Text of Sirica's Statement
description: This Court has, for many days now, given careful and serious thought to what the proper sentence to impose in this case should be.

title: People and Business
QUAKES SUBSIDE IN COAST VALLEY
description: BRAWLEY, Calif., Feb. 21The residents of Brawley are finally beginning to relax. But it hasn't been easy.

title: In Memoriam
description: GETTINGFRPaul P. 19 years today. Dearest, most wonderful father. We miss you and lode you every day. Martin and Gloria

title: Stones Jumps 75 for Mark; Wohlhuter, Bayi Win at Garden
description: Over the objections of rival competitors, Dwight Stones got the conditions he wanted last night at Madison Square Garden and cleared 7 feet inches in the high jump for a world indoor record in the United States Olympic Invitation track meet.

title: South Africa Supports Davis For State Department Post
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  The nomination of Nathaniel Davis to be United States Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs was welcomed by South African authorities here tonight.

title: JAMES TOCCO UNEVEN IN A PIANO RECITAL
description: When James Tocco finally got himself into gear at his piano recital Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, he gave great satisfaction. Unfortunately for him and his audience, however, he didn't really get into gear until the last movement of the Chopin Sonata in B minor (Op. 58), which ended the evening. And from the point of view of the overall program, that was too little and too late.

title: Soviet Acts Against Priest
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21 (UPI)The Soviet security police today searched the apartment of the Rev. Dmitri Dudko, a Russian Orthodox priest who resigned from his Moscow parish last year after an official ban on his sermons, dissident sources said.

title: Music: Kubelik Finale
description: Rafael Kubelik, completing his twoweek stint as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic, is leading the orchestra this week in Brahms's Symphony No. 2 and Frank Martin's Petite Symphonie Concertante for Harpsichord, Harp, Piano and Double String Orchestra, and the two works bring out the best in him.

title: Scientists on Soviet Vessel To Seek Ocean Test Sites
description: With a team of American scientists as well as her own specialists aboard, the Soviet research ship Akademik Kurchatov made ready to sail from New York tonight to help select sites for the deepest holes yet drilled into the sea floor.

title: SLAIN MAN'S HOME VANDALIZED ON S.I.
description: The parents of 23yearold Paul D. Walter, who was stabbed to death on a subway train last Tuesday, were recovering from another blow. yesterdaythe vandalizing of their Staten Island home while they attended Paul's wake.

title: Congress Is Urged to Retain Authority
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21The New York Stock Exchange urged today that Congress retain for itself the further authority to reform the securities industry that would be granted to the Securities and Exchange Commission under proposed legislation.

title: ETHIOPIAN FORCES IN FIERCE CLASHES WITH GUERRILLAS
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 21Fierce fighting erupted in at least four parts of Eritrea Province today as Ethiopian fighterbombers, armored vehicles, artillery and troops attacked villages and roads held by secessionist guerrillas.

title: PHILIP W. KURZ
description: Philip W. Kurz, an Army officer in the New York Port of Embarkation in World Wars and II, died yesterday in Booth Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn. Mr. Kurz, who was discharged as a lieutenant colonel, was 81 years old and lived at 2301 Kings Highway, Brooklyn.

title: Miss Hamlin at 68 With Miss Alcott
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP)Amy Alcott and Shelley Hamlin shared the lead with fourunderpar 68's today in the $35,000 Orange Blossom Classic. Beth Stone and Sally Little were next at 69.

title: Slightly New Look At Bermuda Shop
description: There have been some changes at the landmark of classic sportswear, the Bermuda Shop at Madison Avenue and 55th Street. No, nothing so drastic as sequined blue jeans, but the stiff mannequins in the windows have been replaced by younger, less uptight ones, and inside, the merchandise is also becoming younger and sprightlier.

title: Cape Town Theater Shifts Policy on Integration Again
description: CAPE TOWN, Feb. 21 (AP)Officials of Cape Province bowed to heavy criticism and announced today that the Nico Malan Theater here would be open to all races seven days a week.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Feb. 21 (AP)For each of the last five years more than 50 cars have fought for spots in the starting field of the California 500. But only 39 are entered for this year's test at Ontario Motor Speedway on March Preliminary action starts tomorrow for the opening race the United States Auto Club's 1975 championship season for Indianapolistype cars. The effects of the economy on the sport are obvious with only six cars needed to be eliminated for the 33car field. The only name driver missing from the entries is Lloyd Ruby, but he was expected wind up with one of the unassigned cars entered. Heading the entries are last year's winner, Bobby Unser, and his brother Al.

title: Safranov Skate Victor
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 21 (AP)  Alexander Safranov, a world recordholder and sprint world champion, won the 1,000meter skating event today, in the International Union winter championships. His time was 1 minute 19.34 seconds. Joern Diedriksen of Norway and Klaus Wundersich of East Germany followed. Peter Muller of the United States finished 10th.

title: SUSPECT SEIZED IN EXTORTION PLOT
description: A 41yearold man who allegedly tried to extort $5,000 from an heiress who had advertised for the return of her missing 12yearold son was arrested in a midtown hotel yesterday afternoon. Detectives said they had seen the man retrieve a packet of money left by the woman. She was acting in response to telephoned instructions from the extortionist, they said.

title: Market Place
description: There is little evidence that armies of small investors have come back into the stock market. This is not surprising, for the current market environment is hazardous in the extreme.

title: Saigon Reports 6 Children Are Killed in 2 Incidents
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 21 (Reuters)  Five mortar ishells struck a primary school 45 miles southwest of Saigon today killing at least one child and injuring four others, according to first reports, a military spokesman said here.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Soviet Woos Gulf Oil
description: The Soviet Union has disclosed that it looks to the Gulf Oil Corporations as a potential partner in the exploration and development of oil deposits off the Soviet Far Eastern island of Sakhalin. P. 35.

title: Progress Is Besieging a ManySplendored Old City in Brazil
description: OURO PRETO, Brazil This former capital of the state of Minas Gerais with its Baroque churches, colonial mansions, monumental fountains and steep cobblestoned streets, is threatened by progress in the form of an aluminum plant and tourism.

title: Bentsen Renews Criticism Of Ford and Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 21 (AP) Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen Jr. said today that President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger could not have a foreign policy partnership with Congress if they continually charged critics with political partisanship.

title: Hans Stefan San tesson, 61, ScienceFictiun Editor, Dies
description: Hans Stefan Santesson, mystery and sciencefiction magazine and book editor, was found dead yesterday at his home in Edgewater, N.J. He had had heart ailment. He was 61 years old.

title: Jackson And Finley In Meeting
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 (UPI)  The Oakland A's owner, Charlie Finley, will find out on his 57th birthday tomorrow whether he has won his battle with his star right fielder, Reggie Jackson, over a salary increase for the 1975 baseball season.

title: 2 SLAIN AND 3 HURT IN OMAHA SHOOTING
Rikers Escape Attempt Reassessed as Stronger
description: The Correction Department, responding to an inquiry, conceded yesterday that an unsuccessful escape attempt by 11 alleged members of the Black Liberation Army from a maximum security celiblock on Bikers Island last Sunday night was a more serious incident than originally reported.

title: LAYOFFS AT FORD TO REACH 67,100
description: DETROIT, Feb. 21The Ford Motor Company said today it would have 67,100 workers laid off their jobs next week.

title: SPACE AIDES PONDER LAUNCHING FAILURE
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP)Space agency officials say they do not know why an Atlas Centaur rocket trying to launch an Intelstat 4 satellite into space headed for the ocean instead.

title: Marshall Held Fit for Court
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 21 (Reuters)Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall, who entered the hospital for treatment of pneumonia on Feb. 11, returned to his home today. A Court spokesman said that th 66yearold Justice had been advised by his physician that he could resume his Court duties whenever he felt up to it.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: ULSTER'S TOP JUSTICE HEADS CHARTER BODY
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland. Feb. 21The Chief Justice of Northern Ireland. Sir Robert Lowry, was named today chairman of the constitutional convention that is to decide on the province's future form of government.

title: Pop Music: Sweet Soul
description: People assume that one of a reviewer's greatest pleasures is coming upon relatively unheralded talent and being able to convey enthusiasm to a wider audience. People are right: It is a pleasure. And it's my pleasure to be able to write about a soul quartet called Sister Sledge and in particular about the group's lead singer, Kathie Sledge, who is 15 years old.

title: Canadian Strike Talks Off
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 22 (UPI)Talks broke off today in negotiations to end the fivedayold strike by Federal bluecollar workers that has disrupted airports and postal service throughout Canada.

title: Journalism Head Named
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 (UPI)  Edward Basset has been named director of the School of, Journalism at the University of Southern California. Mr. Bassett, 46 years old, was formerly dean of the William Allen Whitel School of Journalism at the University of Kansas.

title: American Express Plans Sale of Unit To Capital Research
description: The American Express Company and the Capital Research and Management Company said yesterday they had agreed in principle for Capital Research and Management to acquire a subsidiary of American Express, the American Express Investment Management Company, and its whollyowned subsidiary, American Express Asset Management.

title: ExCongressman Ford Steers the ForeignAid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21From his years in the House, President Ford knows that if foreignaid legislation is to make its way through a reluctant Congress, the man to deal with is Representative Otto Passman, the unpredictable chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on foreign aid.

title: 72 From Shut Nursing Homes Badly Ill
description: Seventytwo persons recently removed from substandard nursing homes in the city required hospital care, according to officials of four city hospitals where the people were taken.

title: Waldheim Bids Cypriotes Hold Talks on New Basis
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 21 Secretary General Waldheim today urged Greek Cypriote and Turkish Cypriote leaders to resume their suspended negotiations on a new agreed basis.

title: Train Hijacking Is Denied
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 21 (AP)A brakeman says a report that a Southern Railway freight train was hijacked near Temple, Ga., by a man with a shotgun 10 days ago is a hoax, according to a railroad spokesman.

title: SCHOOL BREAKFASTS GET LOCAL SUPPORT
description: Mote than 400 representatives of parents groups, community organizations and various school districts gathered here yesterday to start a drive to enroll more students in the Federally funded school breakfast program.

title: Anthony Takes 226Pin Lead Into Finals
description: GARDEN CITY, L. 1., Feb. 21With victories in his final seven games, Earl Anthony of Tacoma, Wash., cracked open a tight race tonight to become the topseeded finalist for tomorrow's windup of the $60,000 Long Island bowling tournament.

title: Vatican Condemns All Abortion In Reply to Italian Court Ruling
description: ROME, Feb. 21The Roman Catholic Church said today that abortion is morally unconscionable even if it is permitted by civil law.

title: Cabinet Shifts and New Council At the Top in Store for Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 21 President Park Chung Hee's new political structure, announced last week, will include a new supreme council, a reshuffled Cabinet and a revitalized National Assembly, an authoritative member of the ruling party said today.

title: Albert Aide Indicted In Influence Scheme
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21The Justice Department disclosed today that a secretary to House Speaker Carl Albert and a Texas lawyer had been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of fraudulently representing themselves as influence peddlers.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Loses in Bid For Quick Separation Trial
description: Martha Mitchell has been denied a quick trial of her separation suit against the former Attorney General, The Associated Press reported.

title: Art: Not So Much the Glasses as the Light
description: When the Duc de Guermantes in Proust's great novel sounds off about modern art he is particularly disdainful about the paintings of fruit and vegetables that Manet, for one, had lately brought to a point of perfection. It was outrageous, he thought, for a painter to ask $500 for a bunch of asparagus that could be gotten for $1.25 in the market.

title: U. S. UNIT OFFERS PLAN FOR AMTRAK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) The United States Railway Association is recommending that Amtrak blanket the nation's East and Midwest with fast passenger trains.

title: Mutual Fund Sales In January Soared To a Record Level
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (Reuters)Mutual fund sales reached a record $1.1billion in January, exceeding redemptions by $639million, the Investment Company Institute said today.

title: EDWARD H. WATSON, GEOLOGY PROFESSOR
description: Edward H. Watson, a geologist who studied the terrain of Brazil's interior to determine the feasibility of building the new city of Brasilia, died yesterday in his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 72 years old.

title: Dartmouth Tops Yale
description: Special to The New York Times

title: An Alliance That Never Was
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Tomorrow marks the twentieth anniversary of the first council meeting of SEATO, the alliance that never was. The pact itself was signed in Manila some five months earlier but the council of foreign ministers and all the apparatus set up as a poor man's image of NATO first foregathered in Bangkok on Feb. 23, 1955.

title: Soviet Writer Gets Suspended Sentence After He Apologizes
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21A Soviet writer who recanted his antiSoviet views was given a suspended sentence today at the end of his trial in Leningrad. according to Tass, the official press agency.

title: L.I. NursingHome Owner Called Medicaid Swindler
Judge Rejects Bid by 9 States To Stall Ford OilImport Tariff
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) A Federal judge upheld today President Ford's $3abarrel tariff on oil imports that nine (states had challenged on the ground that it would cause economic damage.

title: Said the Martian Macrobe, They Must Be From Earth But We Thought There Was No Life There!
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  There is an old story about the Biology One examination in which the students were asked: Suppose you could take to Mars any of the laboratory equipment used in this course. How would you determine if there were life on Mars? One famous response: Ask the inhabitants. Even a negative answer would be significant. The student got an A.

title: Beame Sets Up Panel On Sex Discrimination
description: Fulfilling a campaign promise, Mayor Beame announced the creation yesterday of a 30member Commission on the Status of Women, which he said would study and document instances of discrimination against women in both city government and private institutions.

title: Oil Producers Seen Moving Funds Into New Channels
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 21 (Reuters)  Oilproducing countries are switching a significant portion of their revenues into new channels, authoritative sources said today.

title: Pop Music: Sweet Soul.
description: People assume that one of a reviewer's greatest pleasures is coming upon relatively unheralded talent and being able to convey enthusiasm to a wider audience. People are right: It is a pleasure. And it's my pleasure to be able to write about a soul quartet called Sister Sledge and in particular about the group's lead singer, Kathie Sledge, who is 15 years old.

title: Newspaper Office Robbed
description: The Brooklyn office of The Amsterdam News at 1251 Bedford Avenue was held up yesterday by two men who robbed eight persons there and took an estimated total of $3,000 from the office safe.

title: Costs in Metropolitan Area Up Only 0.2% in January
description: Prices of consumer goods and services in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area, on a seasonally adjusted basis, rose slightly in January, 0.2 per cent, indicating some moderation in the pace of inflation here, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday.

title: Hsieh Ties for Golf Lead
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 21 (AP)  Hsieh YungYo of Taiwan, posted a oneoverpar 71 today to move into a firstplace tie with Ted Ball of Australia after two rounds of the Hong Kong open golf championship. Ball faltered today, carding a 72, which included six bogeys. Hsieh and Ball had tworound totals of 141three strokes ahead of their three closest rivals.

title: MITCHELL, HALDEMAN, EHRLICHMAN ARE SENTENCED TO 2 TO 8 YEARS, MARDIAN TO 10 MONTHS TO 3 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21John N. Mitchell, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, three of the most powerful men in the nation during the Nixon Administration, were sentenced today to serve two and a half to eight years in prison for their roles in the Watergate coverup.

title: A LABOR RIGHTIST SLAIN IN ARGENTINA
description: ROSARIO, Argentina, Feb. 21 (UPI)  Ten bomb explosions damaged branch offices of United States and other foreign concerns in this river port city today and a rightist labor leader was shot to death by three men.

title: 2 Wives Now Seek Kalahjy's Estate
description: PATERSON, Feb. 21The number of potential wives who are fighting in court here over the alleged $300,000 estate of a Paterson deputy police chief was reduced from three to two today, but the value of the inheritance remained in question.

title: Saudi Arabia Plans More Huge Plants
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 2IThe head of Saudi Arabia's oil and heavy industrial development corporation has disclosed that an agreement to build a $1billion petrochemical refinery is the first of a series of huge industrial projects under the new fiveyear economic plan.

title: House Intelligence Inquiry Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21There was no mistaking the wryness of the grin wrinkling the face of Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. as he extended his right hand and said, Congratulations, to Representative Lucien N. Nedzi. Ohhhh, I'm not so sure, replied Mr. Nedzi, as a gentle shake of his baldish head displaced wisps of white sideburns.

title: SILK CIRCLE FLOATS IN A NEWMAN DANCE
description: There was a familial warmth to Rosalind Newman's concert Thursday evening at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio. She obviously admires the master and has appropriated his gestural vocabulary for her own choreographic ends.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) The Pentagon announced today a twoday extension of special commercial charter airlift of military supplies from Thailand to Cambodia.

description: LONDON, Feb. 21 (AP)The police said today that 2,000 gold coins worth $385,000, being sent from South Africa to North America, were stolen from the London airport yesterday.

description: The lowkeyed dramas offered here in two auction galleries Thursday were a study in contrasts. The brisk sale of a schoolteacher's Chinese snuff bottles, all purchased for modest sums, brought from about 2 to 10 times what he had paid in 30 years of assembling the collectibles.

description: Friday, February 21, 1975

title: JEWISH CENTER FINDS DAMAGE BY VANDALS
description: Vandals ripped out plumbing, overturned file cabinets and scrawled antiSemitic statements on the walls of the Van Cortlandt Jewish Center in the Kingsbridge Heights section of the Bronx Thursday night.

title: CORRECTION
description: The prices of hamantashen at Gertel's Bake Shop, 53 Hester Street, were incorrectly given yesterday in an article in The New York Times. Gertel's charges 45 cents apiece for the large hamantashen and $3 a pound for the small.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Myers to Coach Toros
description: MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP) Gregory Myers, the coach at Florida International University, was named today head coach of the Miami Toros of the North American Soccer League. Myers replaces John Young, who resigned Wednesday.

title: 5,000 in Manila Join Protest March Against Rigime
description: MANILA, Feb. 21 (UPI) Five thousand Filipinos chanting revolutionary songs staged the first antiGovernment demonstration today since President Ferdinand E. Marcos imposed martiallaw rule two and a half years ago.

description: KERHONKSON, N.Y., Feb. 21 (AP)  Chuck Wepner sparred six rounds today with undefeated John Dennis of Attleboro, Mass., and brought to a total of 72 the rounds he has boxed thus far in preparation for his March 24 heavyweight title bout against Muhammad Ali in Cleveland.

title: Quebec Plans a Superport For Mideast Oil Supplies
description: QUEBEC, Feb. 21 (Reuters)The Quebec Government plans to build a deepwater superport port on the St. Lawrence River to receive Middle East oil shipments in the 1980s, Premier Robert Bourassa said today.

description: The City Commissioner of Correction, in a departure from his previous lowkey reactions to judicial decisions affecting municipal jails, yesterday sharply criticized the Federal judge who ruled that some practices at the men's jail on Rikers Island violated the Constitution.

title: Judge Sustains Indictment Of Crabiel in BidRigging
description: TRENTON, Feb. 21Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel has lost a legal battle to have the State Superior Court dismiss an indictment charging him with rigging state highway bids.

title: RIGHTS PANEL CENSURES ISRAEL
description: GENEVA, Feb. 21The United Nations Commission on Human Rights today adopted two resolutions of censure against Israel over her actions in the occupied Arab territories. Only the United States voted against both.

title: OftMugged Brooklyn Man, 86, Found Slain in His Apartment
description: An 86year old man who had been mugged several times in a Brooklyn neighborhood that his relatives feared to visit was found slain yesterday in his ransacked apartment, the police said.

title: J. R. Lippincott Weds Nancy Smith
description: Nancy Todd Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edgar Smith of Warwick, R.I., and Alexandria, N. H., was married yesterday noon to Jonathan Ramsay Lippincott, a management analyst with the New York City Human Resources Administration.

title: FOES OF ABORTION CHANGING FOCUS
description: A leader of the Right to Life Committee in New York State said yesterday that her movement in the state and the nation was concentrating this year on seeking an amendment to the Constitution barring all abortions except those requiredto prevent the death of the mother.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The $2 bill went out of print and into limbo almost nine years ago, the victim of a badluck image and a public attitude ranging from indifference to outright disdain. Now that absence has had a chance to do its traditional job, and with the added element of a growing national interest in finding significant ways to commemorate the Bicentennial, the $2 bill seems to be making new friends in many places. A steadily increasing support is reported for a rebirth of the deuce with a change in design  like the 17761976 quarter, halfdollar and dollar  emblematic of the American Revolution.

title: Castells in Spain
description: They're still building castles in Spain, but now they're called castells and made of flesh and bone. The spectacularand perilousconstruction of human towers is a popular diversion in Catalonia; it had its genesis some two centuries ago in the town of Valls, near Tarragona (where the accompanying photographs were taken).

title: Schools Open to RollerSkating for All
description: PARSIPPANY  A fourth R has been added to the conventional three in the ParsippanyTroy Hills school system. And that R, surprisingly enough, is for rollerskating.

title: Enough chutzpah to become a world figure
description: Amos Elon is a Viennaborn Israeli newspaperman whose books (in English) so precisely reflect intellectual. liberal Israeli opinion that they foreshadow changes in the political weather. The Israelis: Founders and Sons (1971) made it abundantly clear why the Russianborn founders of the state would soon have to yield power to the Sabras Last year's Between Enemies A Compassionate Dialogue Between an Israeli and an Arab (with Sana Hassan), revealed a desire for intellectual sympathy on the part of some Israelis and some Egyptians, a willingness to entertain ideological concessions, that may yet bear fruit among the politicians.

title: A Model of a Modern Singing Actor
New Jersey

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Success stories. Some books are born a winner. Consider that great white shark. Heritage: Literary descendant of Moby Dick. Begetter. Peter Benchley, son of Nathaniel, grandson of Robert. Prenatal care: Under the direct supervision of Dr. Tom Congdon and the full clinical staff of Doubleday. Godparents: Three book clubs and a movie company. Wellwishers: Every reviewer who appreciates a good read, an article in The Times Magazine detailing its case history, enough to make the public impatient for a chance to view the infant.

title: Morgan Horses Bought By British Sculptress
description: About 2 hours by car from London, at the foot of the Black Mountains near a small town in Wales, a noble equine experiment is getting under way. Nine days ago,an airliner left Kennedy Airportwith, among other cargo, three Morgan horses, the first of theirbreed to be imported by Britain.

title: Book Ends
description: Tolkien. That the J R.R Tolkien cult lives on is evidenced by the lively interest in an unpublished posthumous work by the chronicler of Middle Earth. Letters inquiring about the putative book arrive at Houghton Mifflin in Boston, Tolkien's publisher, in such volume that the company has had to get up a form letter to reply to them The company assures us that there is a book but when they will publish it is anybody's guess about all spokespersons there could say definitely was that they don't expect the completed manuscript before this time next year, if that soon. The reason for the delay is the laborious scholarship involved In preparing it for publication. This task Is being performed by Tolkien's son Christopher, a lecturer at Oxford. Tolkien. who died in 1973, left behind a corpus of work that has to be assembled and collated before it is a book. Evidently he worked on it over a period of years  probably during World War II, although the publisher wasn't certain Now Christopher Tolicien, who is described as having been very close to his father, must assemble the disparate parts of the MS. into a coherent whole, culling earlier versions in favor of later re visions Austin Olney, editorinchief at Houghton Mifflin, described the material as being analogous to a huge manuscript that somebody dropped on the floor with the pages unnumbered. Christopher Tolkien discussed the book with his father many times and seems to be approaching the chore with the dedication of a Dead Sea Scrolls scholar.

title: Opera in Vienna Has Abundant Money, But Many Dislike Repertory and Singing
