Return From Siberia Ends in Reunion Here
description: There was hugging and kissing and greetingsSveikas (welcome) and Labas (hello with everything good about it in heartfelt Lithuanian at Kennedy International Airport last night.

title: GOVERNOR SETS UP SCREENING PANELS TO SELECT JUDGES
description: Governor Carey yesterday established a new selection process that he said would improve the quality of appointments to the bench by careful screening of all nominees and by encouraging bar associations, civic groups and private individuals to submit names.

title: California Program Shifts Funds to Youngest Pupils
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.On the theory that it is better to diagnose and correct learning problems during a child's first few years of school than to provide costly remedial programs later, the state of California is pushing ahead with a massive effort to shift the preponderance of educational resources toward, the very young.

title: Miss Proell Clinches 5th Ski Cup Title
description: NAEBA, Japan, Feb. 23 (AP)Annemarie Proell of Austria won a women's giant slalom race today and clinched her fifth consecutive World Cup Alpine skiing championship.

title: Year After Racial Clash, Ossining Copes With Tension and Inferiority
description: OSSINING, N.Y.,  Like most of the more than 1,000 students at Ossining High School, Alan Copeland remembers the day a year ago when the cafeteria exploded in a chairthrowing racial brawl. His recollection of the aftermath is equally clear.

title: TWO END 26 YEARS OF HIDING IN CRETE
description: CANEA Crete, Feb. 23 (AP)  Two Communist guerrillas, until recently wanted on charges of murder and antistate activities came out of hiding today after living in mountain caves for 26 years. They said that their ideals had kept them alive.

title: Chase Mortgage Trust Is Sued by Shareholders
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, the nation's largest real estate investment trust, disclosed Friday that it had been served with a summons and complaint in a Federal court action brought by a class of shareholders who purchased the trust's stock between Sept. 1, 1973, and Aug. 28. 1974.

title: Byrne to Name Six Today To New Panel on Women
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23  In an apparent effort to mollify women's groups, Governor Byrne will submit six nominations tomorrow for the 11 member New Jersey Advisory Commission on the Status of women.

title: 2 Failing Blacks Charge Rutgers Law School Bias
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 23A controversy over whether the Rutgers University School of Law here discriminates against minority students admitted under a special admission program appears headed for the courts.

title: Advertising
description: Whether it comes from publicity or a contented reader, the best kind of book advertising is wordofmouth advertising, according to Richard X. O'Connor, ad director of Walden Books, a retailer chain.

title: 2 Killed in New Clash
description: LUANDA, Feb. 23 (Reuters)  Two people were killed, a black and a white, when troops of a rival liberation movement opened fire outside an office of the National Front for the Liberation of Angola, that group said today. It accused the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola of the shooting last night outside its offices in the town of Dalatanda, formerly Salazar, about 150 miles east of Luanda.

title: Aqueduct's Earliest Opening Today May Be an Omen of YearRound Racing
description: The thoroughbred horse racing season will open today at Aqueduct, the earliest beginning in the history of the state, beating by one day the introduction of the sport last year. The early openings seem a sign that yearround racing here is on the way.

title: JOSEPH F. LILLY
description: Joseph F. Lilly, who retired in 1971 as president of NortonLilly & Co., Inc., one of the oldest shipping concerns here, died Friday in Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Northport. L.I.

title: Athens Seeks Larger Role in U.S. Bases
description: ATHENS, Feb. 23  When negotiations resume on the future of United States military operations here, American diplomats expect Greece to demand significant changes in the size of those operations and the way they are managed.

title: In Memoriam
description: HAIGNEYBetty. February 24, 1969. With loving memories of our beloved Nonny. JOAN, SAM, SUSAN and LISA

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An offduty Newark policeman was shot and fatally wounded yesterday afternoon during a gun battle with three holdup men in a downtown Newark bar. Accordihg to the police, the victim, Richard Burns, 48 years old, a veteran of 18 yearson the force, was one of about 20 patrons in Murphy's Bar at 59 Edison Place, when three men walked in at about 5:15 P.M. and announced a holdup.

title: Bolshoi's Ivan Takes Moscow by Storm
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 23  The image of Russia's first madmandespot returned to Moscow last week, writhing, whirling murdering, loving, unifying the 16thcentury Czarist regimeall on the stage of the Bolshoi Theater in the new ballet, Ivan the Terrible.

title: JESSE SANDLER
description: Jesse Sandler, a writer of television documentaries, died Saturday, apparently of a stroke, in Los Angeles. He was 57 years old and lived in West Los Angeles.

title: DEAN ALAN RICHARDSON
description: YORK, England, Feb. 23 (AP) The Very Rev. Alan Richardson, Dean of York Cathedral, collapsed during the evening service today and died. He was 69 years old.

title: City Explores Issue of Offshore Oil
description: When it comes to drilling for offshore oil, the Beame administration appears to be very much in favor of protecting the environment  as long as it doesn't cost too much.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1975

title: Music: St. Paul Players
description: Dennis Russell Davies brought his St. Paul Chamber Orchestra into Town Hall yesterday afternoon, and the result was a most admirable concert. That it was presented as part of the Peoples Symphony Concerts, which offers topflight musical attractions at low prices, made it all the more admirable.

title: Bullets Wallop Blazers
New Orders Down For Machine Tools From the '74 Level
description: The economic slowdown appears to have hit the machine tool industry, according to statistics released over the weekend by the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

title: Victor E. Carbonara Dies at 79; Guided the Early Atlantic Pilots
description: Victor E. Carbonara, retired president of the Kollsman Instrument Corporation, and holder of patents in air navigation, died yesterday at his home, 49 Eklerfield Road, Manhasset, L.I, He was 79 years old.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Cheriepe, 351, Is Victor ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 23 (AP)Cheripe, off at 351, scored a stunnig wiretowire victory today in the $86,600 San Antonio Stakes at Santa Anita. The 5yearold chestnut owned by the Camjo Stable, scampered to the front from the start. A 101 shot, First Back, gave chase with the favored Ancient Title third. Cheripe. a son of Boldnesian, paid $72, $28.20 and $10 for $2 across the board.

title: Iowa Now Feeling Pinch of Recession
description: DES MOINES, Feb. 23For months Iowa has had the lowest unemployment rate in the nation, but now even this prosperous farming state has been caught in the deepening recession.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Feb. 23 (AP)  Dwight Stones, who set a world indoor high jump record Friday night. won his specialty with a meetrecord leap of 7 feet 4 inches last night at the Knights of Columbus track meet here. Stones jumped 75 at the Olympic Invitation meet at New York's Madison Square Garden Friday night. Francie Larrieu set her second meet record in two nights for the 1,500 meters, covering the distance in 4 minutes 14.6 seconds. She set a meet record Friday night in New York. Al Feuerbach put the shot 68 feet 6 inches, beating George Woods and Bishop Dolegewicz of Toronto. Henryk Szordykowski of Poland set a meet record in the mile, winning in 4:04.4. He rallied in the last 50 yards to beat Kenya's Joshua Kineo. Wojciech Buciarski of Poland established a meet record in the pole vault, leaping 176. Three other meet records were set in women's events. Eliz Bieta Katolik of Poland won the 800 meters in 2:05.2. Irena Szewinska of Poland took the 300 meters in 38.9 and Julie White of Brampton, Ontario, upset Debbie Brill of Vancouver in the women's high jump at 60, winning on fewer misses.

title: Turkish Cypriote Names 49 To Assembly in New State
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 23 (UPI)  Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriotleader today named the members of a new constituent assembly in the recently proclaimed autonomous state in northern Cyprus.

title: The Agency Top 10 by Billings
description: Agency executives anxious to know just where they stand in the big picture find out today as Advertising Age publishes its annual billing issue. The country's ad agencies, are ranked according to their total worldwide billings.

title: MILDRED BELLAH
description: Mildred M. Finn Bellah, executive editor of the McNaught Syndicate here for 35 years until her retirement in 1968, died Saturday at her home in Mount Vernon, N.Y. Her age was 73.

title: Return From Siberia Ends in Reunion Here
Wagners Quietly Prompt a Challenge Of Rossetti's Leadership in Manhattan
description: Fresh from his political revival in the Carey gubernatorial campaign, former Mayor Robert F. Wagner Sr., along with his son, the Manhattan City Councilmanatlarge, has beenquietly encouraging a challenge of the Manhattan Democratic chairman, Frank G. Rossetti, who is expected to seek another twoyear term as county leader after this year's primary.

title: Bridge:
description: Outsiders raced home and favorites lost at Aqueduct Saturday, but the impact on those present was not financial, simply emotional. Bridge made its debut at the famous race track with 32 teams, survivors of an original entry of 381, competing in the Grand National team championship. The eventual winner, after completion of district, zonal and national competition, becomes a candidate for international honors.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A recent column that issued from this typewriter was printed in an outoftown newspaper with the headline, Bee's Knees: This Is a Honey of a Cake. It elicited a response from Lorena Warnock of Wakefield, Quebec, who states, One of my friends has previously heard the expression bee's knees and we havebeen trying to track down precisely what it refers to. When I saw that headline, I thought Eureka, at last! but not once was it mentioned again.

title: World's Only Hindu King Is Crowned in Nepal Ritual
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Monday, Feb. 24The world's only Hindu king was crowned today in a sunlit courtyard that echoed with sacred Vedic chants and cannon salvos.

title: Special Prosecution
description: WASHINGTONThe magnitude of what happened in Judge Sirica's courtroom the other day can be appreciated only by taking one's mind back a year or two. In February, 1973, H. R. Haldeman and John Ehrlichman were still cocks of the White House walk. Even in February, 1974, not many could have imagined them standing at the bar of justice, with John Mitchell and Robert Mardian, to be sentenced for crime.

title: Ice Causes Crash in Texas
description: MCKINNEY, Tex., Feb. 23 (UPI)  Two Greyhound buses and three autos were wrecked and 33 people injured today on an overpass where six to eight inches of snow hid a coat of ice. None of the injuries were serious. Witnesses said the cars had stalled on U.S. 75 inside the McKinney limits and the buses had been unable to stop.

title: 3 Bodies in Indiana Cave
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 23 (UPI)The authorities pulled the bodies of three student explorers from Salamander Cave today, where they apparently became trapped and drowned in a flash flood yesterday. The authorities said that four other explorers who were trapped by roaring floodwaters in another cave two miles away had been found unharmed.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Feb. 24, 1975 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M. on Cyprus.

title: Jewish Congress Urges Restraints On Arab Investors
description: The American Jewish Congress said yesterday that it did not oppose the idea of Arab investment in United States companies provided that legislation was enacted to prevent possible discrimination against American Jews or economic boycotts against Israel resulting from Arab pressure.

title: Year After Racial Clash, Ossining Copes With Tension and Inferiority
Growing Congressional Staffs Are Running Short of Space
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 23  Swollen by the addition of thousands of extra staff aides in recent years, the Congressional bureaucracy is about to overflow Capitol Hill.

title: N.C.A.A. Tourney Begins to Fill 32 Berths
description: Indiana has joined Nevada, Las Vegas, in the 32team National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, and for San Diego State and Montana only formalities appear to stand in the way. They have assured themselves of at least ties for the Pacific Coast and Big Sky Conference titles, respectively. NevadaLas Vegas is the champion of the West Coast Athletic Conference.

title: Montagnards, Decimated by the War, Survive in Makeshift Refugee Towns
Article 6  No Title
Business Briefs
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 23 (AP)President Lee Iacocca of the Ford Motor Company has urged the United States to use all the resources at its command to break the Middle East oil cartel that has quintupled oil prices. Mr. Iacocca said all peaceful means of ending the cartel should be explored, because if the cartel continues, things are going to get tough.

title: World's Only Hindu Monarch Is Crowned in Ancient Nepal Ritual
description: incarnation of Vishnu, the god of preservation. He is the first formally educated Nepalese monarch and has surrounded himself with youthful Westerntrained advisers who seem determined to advance this impoverished, largely illiterate nation of 11 million.

title: Drifting Regents
description: The Board of Regents, with its broad policymaking powers over the state's vast public and private education enterprise, is endowed by law and tradition with extraordinary responsibilities for leadership. It is particularly in times of social and educational controversy that the Regents must earn public confidence by showing themselves able to withstand shortterm political pressures. And it is such a test of strength and independent judgment that the Regents have failed in the crucial matter of school integration.

title: 150 YEARS MARKED BY A CHURCH HERE
description: St. Stephen's United Methodist Church, on the northernmost tip of Manhattan, where the wealthy white patricians of Marble Hill worshiped in the eighteen  nineties, yesterday marked its 150th anniversary as a congregation.

title: 10 Months After 45th St. Explosion, Tenants Are Still Picking Up the Pieces
description: Ten months after a powerful explosion ripped through a 24story office building at 45th Street and Second Avenue, tenants and neighbors are stilt coping with lawsuits, unresolved insurance claims and red tape.

title: 10YEAR U. S. BAN ON PAKISTAN ARMS WILL HALT TODAY
Women Try to Leap Hollywood Barrier
description: LOS ANGELESThere are at least three common bonds that unite Nessa Hyams, Lee Grant, Ellen Burstyn, Nancy Walker, Lily Tomlin, Maya Angelou and Gail Parent:

title: Books of The Times
description: Long waves sweep slanting against the beach, hump muscled backs, raise trembling combs that trip over at the greenest summit. So reads the opening sentence of Uwe Johnson's fourth novel, Anniversaries: From the Life of Gesine Cresspahl, and immediately we are in difficulty with this unusual work (the first volume of atwovolume novel, which was first carved by Mr. Johnson out of his fourvolume German original, and then translated into English by Leila Vennewitz).  hump muscled backs, ? One hesitates for a microsecond to make sense of it: Is there a hyphen missing, or is there a bizarre ambiguity intended? Is it. bad translatin, or just alapse in copy editing? And so: can we trust what we are about to read, or must we continue to squint in puzzlement? We must continue to be puzzled, it seemsby the tone of Anniversaries, and by its intentions. It may be simple enough to grasp the basic situation in the novel's foregroundthat Gesine and Marie Cresspahl are respectively a young East German widow and her 10yearold daughter who live on Manhattan's Riverside Drive and that their taperecorded conversations with each other (dating in this volume from Aug. 21, 1967, through Feb. 24, 1968) are what comprise the novel's text.

title: Slight Cracks in HardLine Protestant Stand Appear in Ulster
Siege in Cambodia Town Traps 30,000 Refugees
description: NEAK LUONG, Cambodia, Feb. 23 This is a town where fear has become so normal that people hardly ever talk about it any more.

title: Personal Finance: Garnishment Limits
description: The increase in the Federal minimum wage last Jan. 1 to $2.10 an hour reduced the amount that can be deducted from some workers paychecks to satisfy a garnishment order. The rise in the minimum wage next Jan. 1 to $2.30 an hour will lower the garnishable amount still further for certain employes.

title: Corporate Profile
Burger Scores Congress on Judge Issue
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 23  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger accused Congress today of taking no action whatever to meet the imperative need for more Federal judges, and of then passing unnecessary speedy trial legislation that may throw the courts into a crisis unless funds to implement it are appropriated immediately.

title: Kogan Salutes 2 Famous Colleagues
description: Although there was no such indication in the program of Leonid Kogan's Carnegie Hall recital Saturday night, this listener is ready to bet that the Soviet violinist's unorthodox postintermission pairing of the Grieg C minor Sonata and several selections from Gershwin's Porgy and Bess was by way of homage to his great colleagues Fritz Kreisler and Jascha Heifetz.

title: Guns vs. People
description: At the conclusion of the latest hearings on legislation to control the proliferation and abuse of guns, Chairman Conyers of the House Judiciary subcommittee said: The public is literally screaming for something to be done. This judgment, based on a Detroit Congressman's sense of the public mood, is a significant rejoinder to the wellfinanced and highly organized gun lobby's claim that Americans continue jealously to guard the right to bear armsa distortion of the Second Amendment's intent to authorize the maintenance of a citizens militia.

title: Women's Skate Title To German
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, Feb. 23 (AP)Sheila Young of Detroit won the 500 and 1,000 meter events but watched Karin Kessow of East Germany take the 1975 women's world speedskating overall championship today.

title: Siege in Cambodia Town Traps 30,000 Refugees
description: NEAK LUONG, Cambodia, Feb. 23 This is a town where fear has become so normal that people hardly ever talk about it any more.

title: The Losers in PleaBargaining
description: Fear of violent crime is rarely far removed from the consciousness of urbanites. Therefore, when it is reported that eight of ten city homicide cases have been resolved by pleabargaining, with most sentences ranging from probation to a tenyear maximum, thoughts are stirred that the courts are releasing dangerous criminals to prey upon the populace.

title: The Theater: A Double Bill of Classics
description: In the absurd and shameful absence of a great classic theater in our town, we must need look for our classics where we can. Quite a few of them are turning up Off Off Broadway, where ingenuity perforce takes the place of opulent sufficiency, and dedication often the place of superior skills. Even if one believes that New York needs a theater of national proportions as much as, if not morethan, it needs the Metropoliton Opera House, one must nevertheless live with the attics and basements of harsh reality.

title: Italian Publication of Prague Liberal's Memoirs Stirs a Debate
description: ROME, Feb. 23The publication of what are reported to be the posthumous memoirs of Josef Srnrkovsky, one of the leaders of the brief Prague spring of liberalization in Czechoslovakia in 1968, are stirring debate among Communists here and are expected to have repercussions in Eastern Europe.

title: Busing Issue Is Reopened in Detroit
description: DETROIT. Feb. 23Last July 25 the United States Supreme Court struck down a schoolintegration plan that would have required the busing of black and white pupils between Detroit and its suburbs. It was widely assumed at the time that the integration story here was over, and that the concept of busing as a means to integrate metropolitan schools was dead.

title: TWO END 26 YEARS OF HIDING IN CRETE
description: CANER Crete, Feb. 23 (AP)  Two Communist guerrillas, until recently wanted on charges of murder and antistate activities came out of hiding today after living in mountain caves for 26 years. They said that their ideals had kept them alive.

title: Arriving Soviet Jews Celebrate Purim
Miss Alcott, Tour Rookie, Wins on 18thHole Birdie
CAST SHIFTINGS MAR RHEINGOLD AT MET
description: Since the Metropolitan Opera is presenting only three complete Ring cycles this season, it seems odd there has to be so much shuffling of casting.

title: Boston Museum's Far West Show Is a Hit
description: BOSTON, The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has a success on its hands. Enthusiasm runs very high (especially among those who have yet to reach the age of consent) for Frontier America: The Far West. A nationwide tour has been signed up for the show, with stops at Denver, San Diego, Kansas City and Milwaukee.

title: JAVITS SAYS ISRAEL SHOULD JOIN NATO
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, today proposed that Israel be incorporated into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to help bring peace to the Middle East.

title: Weddings
description: TOLKJABBOUR

title: Leo Shapiro, 62, Is Dead; Corporate, Realty Lawyer
description: Leo Shapiro, senior partner in the New York law firm of Kirschenbaum & Shapiro, died Saturday at his home, 3854 Laurel Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 62 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Red Smith
description: Ralph Garr has said that when he was trying to prove himself as a major league baseball player he kept encountering disencouragement. I've been lucky with the bat all my life, he once said, but the other parts of the game, running the bases and playing the outfield, I had to struggle. They drilled it into my head that I Couldn't field. I'd think, Why can't they give me credit? I reach balls other guys can't get close to. But I'd catch 50 and miss one and it'd be, I knew you couldn't catch it. It disencouraged me. Disencouragement ended over the weekend when an independent arbitrator named Eric Schmertz decided the $30,000 increase offered by the Atlanta Braves wasn't enough for the National League's batting champion and wrote a salary of $114,500 Into his 1975 contract, more than doubling his pay.

title: About New York
description: There is no one Broadway, and like the city itself it is made up of communities. Dorothy Kilgallen once called herself the Voice of Broadway, but this was really a conceit. Broadway is a babel of voices, many of them with accents, and the people on any one part of it do not necessarily have much to do with the people of any other part of it.

title: Identification Cards For Citizens Asked By Passport Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) Every United States citizen should eventually be required to carry a Government identity cardcomplete with fingerprintsto reduce fraud and other related crimes, Frances G. Knight, director of the State Department's Passport Office, said today.

title: Policewoman Helps Foil Brooklyn Bridge Leap
description: A 20yearold man who threatened to throw himself off the Brooklyn Bridge early yesterday after a fight with his mother was pulled to safety when a woman police officer got a headlock on him and held him so two of her male colleagues could seize him by the arms.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. URGES FEDERAL CONTROL OVER OIL IMPORTS
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23 Top leaders of the A.F.L.C.I.O. proposed today that the importation of oil be taken away from private industry and placed in the hands of Government.

title: New Books
description: An Arranged Marriage, by Inge Trachtenberg (Norton, $6.95). A novel dealing with the early days of Freudian psychology.

title: Gymnastics Paced By Miss Dunbar
ARABS REVIEWING TRADE BLACKLIST
description: CAIRO, Feb. 23Arab officials opened a 10day closeddoor meeting here today to consider changes in a blacklist of about 2,000 foreign companies banned from operating in Arab countries because they are considered to have important dealings with Israel.

title: ADM. SEVERT A. OLSEN
description: Rear Adm. Severt A. Olsen, Coast Guard, retired, died Saturday at his home, 72 Bayview Avenue, Princess Bay, Staten Island. He was 74 years old.

title: High Court Asked to Bar Professionals FeeFixing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Professional pricefixing by lawyers, stockbrokers and mutualfund operators is under legal challenge before the Supreme Court in a group of cases that could subject the pricefixers to antitrust prosecution for the first time.

title: Policewoman Helps Foil WouldBe Bridge Leap
description: A 20yearold man who threatened to throw himself off the Brooklyn Bridge early yesterday after a fight with his mother was pulled to safety when a woman pollee officer got a headlock on hint and held him so two of her male colleagues could seize him by the arms.

title: Lafayette, Bryant Fives Gain P.S.A.L. Semifinal
description: A few strong words at half time helped propel Lafayette into the Public Schools Athletic League basketball semifinals with an 8277 victory over South Shore yesterday at Queens College. In the second game of the doubleheader, Bryant retained its Queens championship by whipping Lane, 7763.

title: Connors Victor in Florida Final
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP)Topseeded Jimmy Connors stayed on good behavior today and capitalized on mistakes by Jurgen Fassbender to beat the West German star, 64, 62, in the final of the $30,000 Boca West International tennis tournament.

title: Ethiopia Presses Attack on Guerrillas But Is Reluctant to Give Hard Details
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 23Ethiopian jet fighterbombers and heavily armed troops pressed a daylong attack on guerrilla strongholds northwest of Asmara today for the second time in three days.

title: Article 3  No Title
Jersey Consumer Notes
description: The looming increase in Blue Cross and Blue Shield insurance rates is again making news, although the exact cost to the subscriber remains something of a mystery.

title: Unfair Attack
description: After the recent antiIsraeli demonstrations in the United Nations General Assembly and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, there can be no great surprise about the latest unfair attack on Israel by the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. But there is particular injustice in the Commission's two resolutions censuring Israel because the target is one of the most democratic countries of the world, while many of those who joined in the condemnation are dictatorial regimes whose devotion to human rights at home is minimal at best. It is enough to note that the Soviet Union's Valerian A. Zorin was one of the most energetic supposed defenders of human rights in this forum.

title: A BRONX MAN, 83, SLAIN BY MUGGERS
description: An 83yearold deaf man was robbed and beaten to death by four youths Saturday night in the firstfloor hallway of his apartment building in the Fordham section of the Bronx.

title: California Program Shifts Funds to Youngest Pupils
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.On the theory that it is better to diagnose and correct learning problems during a child's first few years of school than to provide costly remedial programs later, the state of California is pushing ahead with a massive effort to shift the preponderance of educational resources toward the very young.

title: GOVERNOR SETS UP SCREENING PANELS TO SELECT JUDGES
description: Governor Carey yesterday established a new selection process that he said would improve the quality of appointments to the bench by careful screening of all nominees and by encouraging bar associations, civic groups and private individuals to submit names.

title: Seals Gain A 22 Tie With Kings
For Many American Designers, The Scent Is Part of the Scene
description: The woman in her Halston dress, carrying her Gucci bag and lunching at Orsini's should be in a quandary about what perfume to wear.

title: U.S.SAUDI TALKS TO OPEN THIS WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Joint United StatesSaudi Arabian Economic Commission will hold its first meeting here this week amid official hopes that it will put a fresh glow on a special relationship that has lost some of its initial luster.

title: Petty Wins By 6 Laps; Pond Is 2d
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 23 (AP) Richard Petty took the lead for good early in the race and breezed to a sixlap victory today in the raindelayed Richmond 500 Grand National stock car race.

title: U.S. and Corporate Issues Will Test Market Rates
Government With a Soul
description: Unemployment, said Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1930, is a problem of the entire community. It is a major social tragedy for the individual who is denied the opportunity to work and earn, but it does not stop there, and if not soon corrected will have a longtime depressive effect.

title: DOLLAR'S DECLINE LEAVES U.S. CALM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The United States Government does not welcome the decline since last September of the international exchange rate of the dollar against many of the other leading currencies, but there appears to be no sense of alarm or deep concern about the situation.

title: Arthur Radasch, Chemist, Taught at Cooper Union
description: Arthur H. Radasch, who retired in 1963 from Cooper Union as professor of chemical engineering and head of that department, died Thursday at his home in South Yarmouth, Mass. He was 76 years old.

title: Free in Stabbing Case, Man Slays Complainant
description: Hours after crosscomplaints accusing two men of threatening to stab each other were dismissed in Brooklyn criminal court Saturday morning, one of the complainants stabbed the other to death in a knife fight, according to the police, who accused the surviving man and a friend of murder.

title: Music: Carter Premiere
description: It might seem peculiar that a composer of Elliot Carter's prominence, twice winner of the Pulitzer Prize, would have to wait 10 years for the New York premiere of his only concerto for a solo instrument. But the omission has now been taken care of, thanks to Samuel Lipman's performance of the Piano Concerto with the American Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

title: 3 KILLED IN CAROLINA IN BRIDGE COLLAPSE
description: SILOAM, N.C., Feb. 23 (UPI) A onelane wooden bridge over the Yadkin River collapsed tonight, throwing several cars into the water and killing at least three persons.

title: Hubris on the Hill
description: WASHINGTONOn three separate fronts last week, members of the United States Senate moved to abuse Senatorial power.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: More than 150 people committed to the preservation of a 20acre tract of natural wetlands near the south shore of Staten Island staged a rally yesterday and heard Borough President Robert T. Connor back their cause with a proclamation of Last Chance Pond Week.

title: REBECCA H. BRIDGE
description: Rebecca Hochmeyer Briage, who taught for 27 years at New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn and subsequently at the New School, died yesterday of carotid artery aneurisms at her home, 530 Grand Street. She was 68 years old and the wife of Dr. Frederick Bridge a physician.

title: Article 2  No Title
JAMES N. SMITH
description: James Nichols Smith, a retired insurance executive and director, of the Transcontinental Insurance Company, died Saturday at his home, 30 Beekman Place. He was 83 years old.

title: Cremation Halted As Questions Arise On Inventor's Death
King With a Sense of Mission
description: As the coronation of Birendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev in Katmandu alternates between 3,000yearold Vedic ritual and proud displays of uptodate implements of war, so the career or the 29yearold King of Nepal is a delicate balancing act between tradition and technology.

title: Births
description: MEYER

title: PENTAGON FEARS CAMBODIA'S FALL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that Cambodia would absolutely fall into Communist hands if Congress did not provide the $222million in military aid requested by the Administration.

title: Iowa Now Feeling Pinch of Recession
description: DES MOINES, Feb. 23For months Iowa has had the lowest unemployment rate in the nation, but now even this prosperous farming state has been caught in the deepening recession.

title: Jets to Seek Aide for Ward, Then a BackUp for Namath
description: DORADO, Puerto Rico, Feb. 23A top football man will be hired by the New York Jets to join the recently appointed general manager, Al Ward, and the new leadership will tackle the first order of business: finding a backup quarterback for the fragile Joe Namath.

title: 10YEAR U. S. BAN ON PAKISTAN ARMS WILL HALT TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The United States will announce tomorrow the lifting of its 10 year arms embargo against Pakistana move sure to provoke sharp protests in India.

title: ExOperative Says He Worked for F.B.I. to Disrupt Political Activities Up to '74
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  Despite assurances by the Justice Department that the Federal Bureau of Investigation's controversial Counterintelligence Program was halted in April, 1971, a former undercover operative says that the bureau continued as late as last June to employ programstyle, techniques against domestic political groups.

title: Israelis Report on Clash
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 23The Israeli military command said today that its forces had thwarted an Arab attempt to seize hostages in Galilee so they could be exchanged for guerrillas held in Israeli jails.

title: Allon Reaffirms Israeli Readiness For New Pullback
description: BERLIN, Feb. 23Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel restated his country's readiness today to contribute to an interim settlement in the Middle East by withdrawing from present lines on the Suez front.

title: The University Shop Falls Victim of the Undressedup Look
description: Coed dorms, explicit sex in the movies, longhaired cops? O.K. One learns to adjust. But two  button suits at Brooks Brothers? Isn't that carrying things too far?

title: Vietnamese Nationalism
description: Aid to South Vietnam is a moral imperative as long as two propositions are true: First, a world where totalitarian regimes such as Hanoi's fail in their violent and disruptive efforts to impose their will on others is a just world; second, a world where each people can sustain a society protective of its highest ethical and social traditions is a world that gives due recognition to mankind's diversity and equality.

title: MRS. HERBERT RAMSAY
description: Constance McCall Ramsay widow of Herbert H. Ramsay. a lawyer who was president of the United States Golf Association in 193031, died yesterday at her home, 165 East 66th Street.

title: Jockey Wins 4, Including First Three Races
description: The New York thoroughbred racing season opened in the rain yesterday at Aqueduct, and the nine race program could have been designated Angel Cordero Day. The Puerto Rican jockey thrilled the crowd of 23,949 by riding the first three winners on the card and finished with four victories in seven attempts.

title: Business Records
Banks Refuse Carey Plea To Back Development Unit
Greek Regime Says It Thwarted a Plot; 28 Officers Seized
description: ATHENS, Feb, 24  The Greek Government announced tonight that it had placed its troops on alert in the Athens region after thwarting conspiratorial, movements made by followers of the military Government that collapsed last July.

title: President of Syria, In Interview, States 2 Peace Conditions
description: President HafezalAssad of Syria has declared in an interview that his Government would agree to a peace treaty with Israel on two conditions.

title: THORNTON K. BROWN
description: Thornton K. Brown, a retired businessman, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 240 East 79th Street.

title: TRIAL OF GURNEY OPENS IN FLORIDA
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 24Former Senator Edward J. Gurney of Florida walked into United States District Court here today to open his trial on charges of bribery and conspiracy.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: By The Associated Press

title: Daniel J. Dowd Dies at 65; Athletic Commission Aide
description: Daniel J. Dowd, former Deputy Commissioner of the State Athletic Commission, died Saturday in Catskill, N.Y., where he moved last year after having lived here for many years. He was 65 years old.

title: Belgrade Stalinism
description: In the realm of freedom of ideas, at least, it is becoming increasingly difficult to distinguish between today's Belgrade Titoism and yesterday's Moscow Stalinism. Thus, the famed Yugoslav writer, Mihajlo Mihajlov, is scheduled to go on trial today for allegedly spreading hostile propaganda, a charge for which the maximum penalty is death. Last month eight outstanding Belgrade University professors were ousted from their positions by a decree that accused them of corrupting youths.

title: Basketball Ratings
description: By The Associated Press

title: American Cyanamid Lowers Price of Crystal 1.5 Cents
description: The American Cyanamid Company announced yesterday a reduction of 1.5 cents a pound for melamine crystal, which is used in making resins for decorative laminates, paper and paints. The new price is 34.5 cents a pound for bagged truckload quantities and 33.5 cents for hulk deliveries, basis Avondale, La.

title: Congress in Disneynam
description: The Administration is trying to get a group of Congressmen to go to Vietnam and discover that American policy there is sound.

title: LEVITZ FURNITURE OFFERING REBATES
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporation, of Miami, the country's largest chain of furniture warehouse showrooms, is offering customers cash rebates of approximately 10 per cent on all merchandise sold in its 55 stores.

title: U.S. WOULD DROP LOSING RAIL LINES
description: A longawaited Federal plan to revitalize six bankrupt railroads serving the Northeast and Midwest calls for the initial abandonment of 6,200 miles of moneylosing freight routes and the incorporation of 15,000 miles of remaining routes into a new system beginning next year.

title: Sports Unit and 14 Towns To Discuss Traffic Funds
Incomplete Justice
description: Two prominent Americans have their own particular reason for discomfort at the prison sentences imposed on three of former President Nixon's closest associates in the abuse of executive power: one is the unindicted member of their conspiracy, under whose leadership they acted; the other is the successor to the Presidency who personally arranged that his predecessor should go both untried and unpunished.

title: CARL BRADEN DIES; A RIGHTS ACTIVIST
description: Carl Braden, former executive director of the Southern Conference Education Fund, who since 1971 had led the Training Institute for Propaganda and Organizing in Louisville, Ky., died of a heart attack last Tuesday in Louisville. He was 60 years old.

title: Brubecks Shuffle Combinations For FastPace Jazz Samplings
description: The jazz family Brubeck is now so numerous and has so many formations that an evening with it allows for little more than a sampling of its various aspects.

title: Whitney Young's Papers Being Presented to Columbia
description: Margaret Young, widow of the civilrights leader Whitney M. Young Jr., will present a collection of more than 100,000 of his papers to Columbia University in a ceremony there today. The major part of the gift consists of Mr. Young's papers as executive director of the Urban League from 1961 until his death in 1971.

title: Kissinger and Clerides Discuss Cyprus Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  Glafkos Clerides, the Greek Cypriote leader, conferred today with Secretary of State Kissinger on ways of getting talks with Turkish representatives on the Cyprus issue started again.

title: XRay Reveals Escape Plot
description: DENVER, Feb. 24 (AP)Jailers took a convict, Tony S. Salazar, to a hospital for Xrays last night when he complained of back pains. The pictures showed nothing wrong with his back, but picked up a metallic object inside his mouth. It was a handcuff key. He was then booked for investigation of a criminal attempt to escape custody.

title: Waldheim Role Is Urged
description: Special to The New York Times

title: 3 STORES CHANGING PRICEFIXING PLEAS
description: Three Fifth Avenue stores charged with fixing prices of women's clothing received yesterday approval from a Federal judge on their request to change their plea from not guilty to nolo contendere.

title: Article 2  No Title
Article 4  No Title
Cleamons Out With Injury
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 24 (AP) Jim Cleamons, a starting guard, will be sidelined indefinitely with a severely sprained left shoulder, the Cleveland Cavaliers reported today. Cleamons was injured yesterday in the Cavaliers 111105 National Basketball Association victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: C. W. Post Wins No. 22
description: Special to The New York Times

title: New York Fed Shifting Officers
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has announced the promotion of two officials and the impending early retirement of a senior vice president, the second within a week.

title: JERSEY BELL SAYS IT TAPPED PHONES
description: NEWARK, Feb. 24The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company acknowledged today that it monitored 2.6 million telephone calls in the state between November, 1966, and March, 1970, and recorded 280,000 of those calls as part of its efforts to discover the extent of electronic toll fraud by telephone customers.

title: Soviet Dilemma: Ideology and the Desire for Trade With West
Justices Suspend Dean; Disbarment Is Weighed
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 24 (UPI)The Supreme Court suspended John W. Dean 3d today from practice before the Court.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the Arts and Leisure Guide in The New York Times on Sunday, the New Ideas lecture at the 92d St. Y.M.Y.W.H.A. was listed as taking place on Wednesday. It will be at 11 A.M. on Thursday.

title: Pipe Dream
description: On the assumption that water runs downhill, one would not think it beyond the ability of the Department of Highways to end the flooding of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive every time it rains. Drains installed at low points in the road and hooked to a few lengths of pipe should nicely convey excess water from the roadway into the East River. And the cost should not be excessive as most of the holes are already in place.

title: Man Wins Mixed Match at Love
Recital: The Menuhins
description: Even when he is having one of his more uneven nights, Yehudi Menuhin continues to be a musician deserving of the closest attention. The way he molds a phrase, the speaking quality of his tone and his ability to convey expressive and coloristic nuancesin all these ways and many more Mr. Menuhin reminds us that he is one of the grand masters of violin history.

title: Goodell Asks an Extension Of Month for Clemency Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Charles E. Goodell, chairman of the Presidential Clemency Board, said today he had recommended to President Ford that the clemency program, to expire Saturday, be extended another month to April 1.

title: House Veterans Readjust To Liberal Trend in South
Yugoslav Writer's Trial Scheduled to Begin Today
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 24 (AP)A dissident Yugoslav writer, Mihajlo Mihajlov, faces trial tomorrow on charges of hostile writing against the state. The charge carries a maximum penalty of death.

title: U. S. Aid Expected
description: ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 24 (UPI) The United States has indicated it will grant Ethiopia's request for an emergency supply of $25million worth of ammunition to continue the war against Eritrean rebels, Ethiopian Government sources said here today.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: PARIS, Feb. 24 (Reuters)A consortium of French banks led by Crdit Lyonnais has signed an agreement with the Cuban National Bank for a, $348million line of credit to finance Cuban imports of French capital goods, Credit Lyonnais said today.

title: General Killed in an Ambush
description: PHNOM PENH, Fed. 24 (Reuters)Insurgents killed a Cambodian Army general today in an ambush 24 miles east of Phnom Penh the military command reported. The command spokesman said Brig Gen. Hem Pao, commander of an army training center near Kompong Speu, died when insurgents opened fire on his jeep.

title: Nordiques Top Mariners
description: QUEBEC CITY, Feb. 24 (UPI)  One goal and two assists by Quebec's Rejean Houle led the Quebec Nordiques to a 53 victory over the San Diego Mariners before 11,289 fans tonight.

title: Greenspan Comments
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) Alan Greenspan, chairman of the council of Economic Advisers says that an economic blueprint advanced by Democrats could end the recession sooner than President Ford's plan wouldbut only at the risk of future inflation and recession.

title: Shredding Machines Feared
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 24 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that about 30,000 shredding machines designed to grind up sticks and leaves for compost heaps may have a defect that could cause the user's hand to be drawn into the machine. It announced that the manufacturer, The Kemp Shredder Company of Erie, Pa., was providing consumers with a free corrective kit that includes a protective plate and revised operating instructions.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1975

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: An opportunity for the public to examine issues and alternatives concerning the role of architecture in the city is being provided by the Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies, 8 West 40th Street, in a series of evening classes starting next Monday. Registration, Monday through Friday, from 1 P.M. to 3 P.M., is taking place through March 6 at the Institute, an independent research, design and education corporation. This second spring lecture, series is more extensive than last year's program and has support from the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: GOLDIN CAUTIONS ON CITY FUND AID
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin cautioned yesterday that the city should not rely on massive amounts of new revenue from the Federal and state governments to fill a budget gap for the coming fiscal year, which begins July 1.

title: GAF Negotiating to Buy WRVR And Make It a Classical Station
BYRNE NAMES 9 TO WOMEN'S UNIT
description: TRENTON, Feb. 24Governor Byrne today nominated nine women to the New Jersey Advisory Commission on the Status of Women, created last August to advise the state's upgraded Division on Women in areas of concern to female residents of the state.

title: After 18 Years, 3,057 StrikeOuts, Gibson Starts His Final Season
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24The St, Louis Cardinals, who missed a championship by 1 games last year, began their pursuit of another in the rain today. But for Bob Gibson, who holds more records than any pitcher still in the business of baseball, it was the beginning of the end, traumatic, but with no regrets.

title: Recession Impels Many to Work More Efficiently or Even Change Vocation
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.John Caldwell, a young businessman who has run a pictureframe shop for four years in this university town opened the door to a stotefront recently and turned on the lights.

title: American Express Dividend
description: The American Express Company raised its quarterly dividend rate yesterday to 20 cents from the 15 cents paid previously. The higher dividend is payable on April 1 to shareholders of record March 7.

title: Abram Considers Seeking Penalty in Medicaid Fraud
description: Morris B. Abram, the special state commissioner investigating nursing homes, said yesterday that he was considering requesting state legislation that would call for triple damages from operators who cheated Medicaid.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: 2 Orders for Concordes Planned by Iran's Airline
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 24 (Reuters)The Chairman of Iran's national airline said today Iran Air would sign firm orders for two BritishFrench Concorde airlines this spring for delivery within two years.

title: Signs Will Alert Riders On IRT Broadway Line
description: In response to demands from Columbia University and several Morningside Heights community groups, the Transit Authority will soon post signs on some Broadway IRT express subway platforms alerting passengers that only the No. 1 train, the Broadway local, makes stops on Broadway above 96th Street.

title: Common Market Jobless Increased 47% During Year
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 24 (UPI) Unemployment in the nine countries of the European Common Market rose an average of 47 per cent, between January, 1974, and January, 1975, statistics showed today.

title: Avis Trustee Firm On $11.63 a Share As Minimum Price
description: The courtappointed trustee for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's 52 per cent interest in Avis, Inc., said yesterday he was unwilling to sell the interest for less than $11.63 a share.

title: Market Summary
description: AMERICAN EXCHANGE Monday, February 24. 1975 (Volume 2,376,185 shares)

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Rookie policemen went into New York City station houses with their wives and children in a final, emotional appeal to veteran officers to work five tours of duty without pay to save the young men's jobs.

title: Crime on Reservations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The Senate was urged today to rcvise the procedures for law enforcement and criminal justice on Indian reservations.

title: Article 3  No Title
Two Freighters Collide In Delaware Bay Mouth
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb 24 (AP)Two ships collided tonight in Delaware Bay about three miles from Cape Henlopen, according to the United States Coast Guard. A spokesman said there were no initial reports of injuries and both vessels were in no immediate danger of sinking.

title: Esquire Is Suing W. R. Simmons
description: Now Esquire Magazine is suing W. R. Simmons & Associates Research. But unlike Time Inc., which is suing over the results of Simmons's syndicated audience research, Esquire filed a $1million damage suit in New York State Supreme Court Friday because, it says, it was excluded from the current study.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Mayor of East Orange, william S. Hart, said 75 to 100 city employes would be laid off to hold down the 1975 budget. We just cannot afford a budget increase of $5 million or $6million and, more importantly, we have to try to hold our tax rate under $8, Mr. Hart said.

title: Concert
description: It was a newsworthy night for Queens College on Sunday, and college music department people were glowing with pride. The occasion was a centenary Ravel concert, but not just any Ravel concert. For it was here that Arbie Orenstein (of the Queens College faculty) chose to present a number of the Ravel manuscripts he had unearthed in a Basque village.

title: Gillette Reports 21.1% Decline In Earnings for Fourth Quarter

description: More than 250 community activists and local elected officials went before the City Planning Commission yesterday to plead for Federal funds to be allocated under the block grant program for housing and community renewal being initiated this year.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24A State Department official announced today that the United States would begin a food airlift tomorrow to Phnom Penh, the besieged Cambodian capital.

title: Nepal's King, Just Crowned, Asks New Age and End of Poverty

description: The president of CBS Sports has been watching the National Basketball Association standings with as much interest as Red Holzman and Larry Costello.

title: GIRL KILLED HERE CALLED RUNAWAY
description: A girl found strangled Saturday night in a hotel described by detectives as a haunt of streetwalkers was identified yesterday by the police as 15yearold runaway from Cambridge, Mass.

title: Truth in Real Estate Bill Is Sent to Byrne by Senate
description: TRENTON, Feb. 24 (AP)The Senate gave final passage to. day by a vote of 350 bill that would make realestate advertising subject to the state law barring fraudulent advertising.

A.B.A. Eases Curbs On Prepaid Law Fee

title: Oratorio: Way of Jesus
description: Alan Hovhaness, one of our most prolific composers, has pioneered the use of improvised, freerhythm devices (he calls it controlled chaos), but he also is not afraid to write beautiful melodies, or to use lush, romantic harmonies. Many of his pieces are suffused with folklike elements, there is often a warm, flowing quality to his music, and more than a touch of mysticism.

title: 20 Armed Indians Seize a Building On Navajo Land
description: SHIPROCK, N.M., Feb. 24 (UPI)Twenty armed Indians, protesting poor health care and the layoff of Indian workers, seized an electronics plant on the Navajo reservation today and said they would stay there until their demands had been met

title: MORE JOBLESS AID SEEN RAISING RATE
description: Recent moves to liberalize the laws governing unemployment insurance are likely to swell the nation's unemployment rate this year by an extra 0.5 to 0.9 percentage point, according to a new study prepared for the Department of Labor.

title: Books of The Times
description: What repels me about Peter is his basic selfindulgence  When he married me, he married what he thought I took him to be, and in doing that, he married himself. His character has no outlets. This is Emily Stone talking about her husband, Peter. Here she is talking about herself: Sometimes I dream I am in Belsen, sorting through a pile of bodies rather like a postal clerk until I reach one uncannily familiar  a starved woman at the bottom of the pile  it is myself. I somehow feel I ought to have pity on her, but I won't. She'd only ask for food I hadn't got. Emily Stone is a disturbing study of two prevalent personality types: the bleeding heart and the computer mind. Peter is a bleeding heart, not in the usual political connotation but in an entirely egocentric sense. Caving in is the only kind of commitment he can manage. Irony and style are his sole restraints; beneath these, he is a swamp of sentimentality. A theatrical suffering is his way of mourning for the lost paradise of his childhood. No one will ever love him again as his mother did, his mother who, in the zoo, made him see so vividly the stretch of the panther's neck and the anachronism of elephants.

title: Market Place
description: Of the industry groups on the New York Stock Exchange last week, motion picture stocks did best. The DowJones industrial average rose 2.5 per cent but Barron's index of movie stocks jumped 8.5 per cent.

title: Additional Capital Funds Urged To Maintain State's Institutions
description: NEWARK,Feb. 24The New Jersey Department of Institutions and Agencies will need $133million in additional capital during the next five years to maintain, improve and deinstitutionalize its facilities around the state, Ann Klein, the Commissioner, said today.

Woodcock, said today that his office would not investigate the death of Beret Weinstein, a 28yearold inventor and industrialist who died in Fort Lee early Friday, pending results of an autopsy, Questions concerning Mr. Weinstein's death and the disposition of his body have been brought to the attention of Mr. Woodcock, who ordered that cremation be postponed.

title: Concert: Philadelphians

The standard Ormandy performance emphasized silky tone and smooth ensemble playing at all costs, so that whether the program said Mozart or Tchaikovsky the sound was remarkably similar.

description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 24 Chinatown and The Godfather, Part II today won the greatest number of Oscar nominations as the Acadmey of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences disclosed nominees of the 47th Academy Awards.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Treasury disclosed today tentative plans to borrow $7billion from midMarch to midApril and said it might have to borrow as much as $21billion beyond that by June 30.

Both the National Hockey League and the World Hockey Association have been signing just a few underaged players, and only in connection with their spring drafts.

description: The New York investment banking firm of Arnhold & S. Bleichroeder, Inc., 30 Broad Street, has purchased a seat on the New York Stock Exchange reportedly at $95,000. the exchange said yesterday.

description: CHICAGO, Feb. 24Three of the four Democratic candidates in tomorrow's mayoral primary spent their last day of campaigning doing what they have done for weeksattacking the performance of Mayor Richard J. Daley during his 20 years in office.

description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 24 The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations pledged today to continue to campaign for the ratification of the equal rights amendment.

Abu Dhabi has already sent airmen to the United States for training in manning the planes.

title: STATE HELPS EASE CITY HEAL PINCH
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24Governor Carey today signed into law emergency legislation, passed earlier today by both houses of the Legislature designed to help New York City meet payroll and operating expenses that become due by the end of the week.

title: Time Bullish on People Magazine
Crime on Reservations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The Senate was urged today to revise the procedures for law. enforcement and criminal justice on Indian reservations.

title: Notes on People
description: In June, 1971, Senator William Proxrhire issued a brief press statement to say that, by mutual consent, he and his wife, Ellen, will be living apart for a time but were not planning a divorce. Yesterday, in another news release unusual for Capitol Hill, the Wisconsin Democrat issued a onesentence statement that he and his wife had resumed their life together and that, since Feb. 17, the Senator, who is 59 years old, was living in the family home instead of a block away.

title: American Film Theater's 'Jacques Brel Is Alive ...'
description: "Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris," the American Film Theater's second presentation of the season, has less importance as a movie than it has as a public service for those people who somehow managed not to see the Off Broadway stage show during its nearly five-year run at the Village Gate.Maybe not. Maybe the people who did not see the original show chose not to. In that case they may now choose not to see this very fancified film version, which opened at selected theaters here yesterday and will be given two more performances today.The movie, directed by a young French-Canadian named Denis Heroux, tries very hard to recreate the sense of intimacy and spontaneity of the plotless show, which is actually 26 Brel songs performed by Elly Stone, Mort Shuman, Joe Masiell, a chorus and by Mr. Brel himself, who makes a fine and much too brief appearance in the film to sing one song.Mr. Heroux, with the obvious cooperation of Eric Blau and Mort Shuman, who conceived the original show and wrote the English translations of Mr. Brel's French lyrics, has transformed what was essentially a concert into an extravaganza of surreal images that keep messing things up. The images are vivid and disconnected to one another (good) but they inevitably wind up being visual translations of the lyrics (bad). It's a rather classy variation on the format employed by the old "Hit Parade" television show, though it's seldom as witty.I should admit that I've never been a Brel maniac. Some of his songs are most engaging, ("Timid Frieda," "The Taxi Cab," "Amsterdam" and "Carousel"), and some make one long for the lyrics of Rod McKuen as comic relief. Mr. Brel is something else as a performer, which is apparent here when he comes on after intermission to sing his own "Ne Me Quittes Pas."The song is not great, but the performance isdeadpan and pseudo-world-weary in the cabaret tradition of chansonniers, and Mr. Brel was one of the best until he decided officially to retire from performing to devote his full time to composing. Which was too bad.Other people take Mr. Brel's songs too seriously. Or, to put it another way, they lack that touch of redeeming ham that can sometimes make charming and even moving a truly rotten lyric about love or death or war or some other little flea in mankind's ear.Mr. Brel, you see, is inclined to write about rather large subjects, and the movie treats them so portentously it doesn't hesitate to give us a crucifixion scene. The song is "Sons of . . ." in which Miss Stone mocks Jesus for the world's ills, seriously, I think.Furthermore, the camera isn't always kind to the performers with the exception of Mr. Shuman, a burly, comic man with a fine voice and an aggressive way of singing that turns criticism into nitpicking. Miss Stone, a small, Giulietta Masina-type with a voice big enough to stop a clock at 300 yards, and Joe Masiell, who might be described as the romantic lead, are continually being caught in the act of hard-selling songs that ought to erupt with feeling.What's worseif not for me but for people who take the Brel lyrics to heartis that a lot of the lyrics are difficult to hear and understand. Sometimes it's the fault of the orchestrations, but more often it's the fault of all those images and the changes of scenery and costumes. They get in the way of possible listening pleasure.

title: Fighters Declared Fit
description: TOKYO, Feb. 24 (UPI)Guts Ishimatsu of Japan, the 25yearold World Boxing Council lightweight champion and Ken Buchanan, 29, of Scotland, the challenger, were pronounced fit today for their 15round title match Thursday night. A physician of the Nihon University hospital examined the fighters in a preliminary check for the Japan Boxing Commission.

title: Racism in Reporting
Article 1  No Title

description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 24The villages hugging the road junction north of the Eritrean capital of Asmara were quiet today, almost a year since the effective reign of Emperor Haile Selassie came to an end in riots, mutinies, strikes and the resignation of the Cabinet.

title: Opposition Leaders in Seoul Press Demands for Reform
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 24 (AP)Opponents of President Park Chung Hee defied Government warnings today and renewed their demands for political reform, including revision of the 1972 Consititution.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (Reuters)The Treasury issued today final regulations requiring United States corporations and their overseas subsidiaries to report their activities in nine major foreign currencies. The currencies are the Belgian franc, Canadian dollar, Dutch guilder, French franc, West German mark, Italian lira, Japanese yen, Swiss franc and British pound.

title: U.D.C. in Crisis
description: As the deadline draws near for the financially troubled Urban Development Corporationa heavy payment on its debts is due todayNew York State is faced with some dismal alternatives. This essential social program in which housing, jobs and new communities are at stake could be bailed out by the major banks in a tenuous, lifesaving cooperative arrangement with the state, but negotiations to that end have evidently collapsed.

title: 52% in Poll Say Jobless Rise Has Affected Their Families
description: The Harris survey reported yesterday that 52 per cent of the nation's families had been directly affected by the rising unemployment rate.

title: A CANCER INSTITUTE IS FORMED IN STATE
Owner of Nursing Homes Gives Up on Bilking Charges
description: HAUPPAUGE, LI., Feb. 25 (AP)A nursing home owner accused of turning in Medicaid claims for improvements on two homes and grooming of his pet poodle, surrendered to the Suffolk County district attorney today.

title: Ehrlichman Penance Irks Indian Legislator
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Feb. 24 (UPI)A Navajo Indian member of the New Mexico House of Representatives said today that he did not want John D. Ehrlichman coming here to do penance for his conviction in the Watergate scandals.

title: CONCERT IS SALUTE TO DOROTHY MOORE
description: A retrospective concert of music by Dorothy Rudd Moore was given at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night. The program covered 12 years, from a set of songs for soprano and oboe written when Mrs. Moore was a student at Howard University in 1962, to Dream and Variations for piano, composed last year, also on the program were Modes for String Quartet (1968), Three Pieces for Violin and Piano (1967), Songs From the Dark Tower (1970) and Dirge and Deliverance for cello and piano (1971).

title: MARIO GEMINIANI
description: Mario Geminiani, retired French Line passenger official, died Saturday at Orange Memorial Hospital, Orlando, Fla. He was 65 years old and lived at Yahala. Fla.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both 91 day and 180day maturities.

title: Volcano in Washington State Termed Violent
description: Specialists of the United States Geological Survey have concluded that Mount St. Helens, a relatively little known volcano 50 miles north of Portland, Ore., in Washington State, has been more active and more violent over the last few thousands years than any other volcano in the United States outside Alaska and Hawaii.

title: A,B.A. Eases Curbs On Prepaid Law Fee
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 24  The American Bar Association adopted new rules today that will help more middleclass Americans to obtain and pay for legal services, much as they can now get medical services, by paying regular fees ahead of time under plans similar to Blue Cross.

title: Newark Police Killed Two in 74 Clash, Then Blocked Inquiry, Grand Jury Finds
description: NEWARK, Feb. 24Two men who died during disturbances here last September were killed by Newark police officers, a grand jury charged today, The July also asserted that the policemen's identities had been covered up by a conspiracy of silence by the police.

title: OFFICERS ACCUSED IN NEWARK DEATHS

While knockout competition in New York City and Long Island reduced the field to 16 teams during the weekend, the adjacent District Three which includes New Jersey, Westchester and the Hudson Valley, reached a similar stage thanks to Swiss contests at five centers.

title: SEARS, ROEBUCK SEES DECLINE IN EARNINGS
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., the nation's largest retailer, said its earnings for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 would be materially less than those of the year earlier. Sears attributed the smaller net to reduced consumer buying and unfavorable underwriting experience of its Allstate Insurance Companies subsidiary.

Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is investigating employes of the board in an attempt to determine the source of a possible leak of confidential information to the magazine Consumer Reports.

title: Dollar Hits a Low In Trading Abroad; Gold Shows Gains
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 24 (UFI) The dollar fared poorly again on all exchanges today, hitting a new low in Amsterdam and closing in Paris at its lowest rate in 16 months.

title: Different Policy Cited
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 24Except for fewer than two dozen courtauthorized wiretaps, there was no monitoring of telephone calls in Connecticut last year, according to a spokesman for the Southern New England Telephone Company.

title: Steel Output Abroad
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 24, (Reuters) Steel production in major nonCommunist industrialized nations fell by 5.8 per cent last month, compared with the same period in 1974, the International Iron and Steel Institute announced today.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the House majority leader, disclosed today that the House Democrats panel on energy and the economy was recommending an increase of 16 cents a gallon in the Federal gasoline tax, spread over three years.

CORRECTIONS
description: In the Arts and Leisure Guide in The New York Times on Sunday, the New Ideas lecture at the 92d St. Y.M. Y.W.H.A. was listed as taking place on Wednesday. It will be at 11 A.M. on Thursday.

title: 2 Cases of Histoplasmosis
description: MILAN, Tenn., Feb. 24 (AP) Doctors have confirmed two cases of histoplasmosis detected in patients hospitalized for other ailments. The doctors blamed millions of birds roosting at the Milan Army Ammunition plant for spreading the disease.

title: Jersey Priest Slain Teacher Shot in Class
Miss Morozova Charms the U.S.
89 S.O.R.C.Yachts Set Sail for Nassau
description: MIAMI, Feb. 24A fleet of 89 yachts began the 178 mile voyage to Nassau here today in strong southerly winds and the 800 sailors involved will know they were in a race by the time they finish this 41yearold ocean racing classic sometime tomorrow.

title: The First Day of Summer
description: The temperature was 43 at 11:30 A.M. when the sky over Long Island quit fooling around with showers and turned loose a rainstorm of wild violence, cutting visibility close to zero, bringing traffic on the Belt Parkway, almost to a halt, driving the sea gulls to cover. Even thenthe gates of Aqueduct stood hospitably open and parishioners Were making their way inside for the sacred rites that annually signal the arrival of summer to New York horseplayers. In spite of the calendar and notwithstanding the sodden gloom overhead, winter passed, the sun shone and flowers bloomed yesterday at precisely 1:30 P.M. At that moment, Angel Cordero Jr. broke a colt named Joanne's Fling out of the starting gate in front of 10 Other 3yearolds and kept the animal in front for a $4.80 mutuel. Thus ended another winter of discontent, a winter that had dragged through 50 days since the thoroughbreds forsook the big town Jan. 4.

title: Patton Backing of Port Agency Assailed
description: Some members of Governor Carey's transportation study group yesterday criticized the timing, and in some cases the substance, of statements by the group's chairman, Ken Patton, that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was in model condition.

title: 20 Die in Bus Plunge
description: BOGATA, Colombia, Feb. 24 (Reuters)Twenty people were killed when a bus plunged, down a precipice in a mountainous area near Medellin in northeastern Colombia today, according to radio reports here.

title: Loan Rates to Consumers Showing Signs of Decline
description: The broad decline in interest rates, evident for many months to business lenders, finally appears to be reaching the consumer who has to borrow.

title: 73 PAN AM CRASH IS LAID TO LAXITY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The fatal crash of a Pan American World Airways cargo jet at Boston in November, 1973, was attributed today to inadequate regulations for the air shipment of hazardous materials and lax enforcement by the, company and the Federal Aviation Administration of existing regulations.

title: Senate Reformers Gain With Rockefeller's Help
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 With major assists from Vice President Rockefeller, Senate reformers appeared to gain the upper hand today in their battle to modify the Senate's filibuster rule.

title: KILLING AT ATTICA LAID TO OTHERS
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 24Defense lawyers for two former Attica inmates charged with the killing of a correction officer said today that their clients had seen indicted for a crime that others had committed. They argued that it was because their clients had been among the weakest and most vulnerable possible suspects.

title: ExGovernor of Oklahoma Goes on Trial in Extortion
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 24 (AP)The bribery and extortion trial of former Gov. David Hall of Oklahoma and a Texas man began in Federal Court today with the selection of a jury of seven men and five women.

title: OIL CONCERN SUED FOR ELECTION FUND
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24A stockholder filed a class action suit in Federal District Court here today against the Phillips Petroleum Company, eight of its top officers and three former chairmen in connection with the company's illegal corporate contribution of $100,000 to former President Nixon's reelection campaign in 1972.

title: U.S. Rushes Pennsy Funds For Its Emergency Needs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) The Administration rushed emergency funds today to keep the Penn Central Railroad operating for two more days while a bill providing $347million in grants and loans remained stalled in the Senate.

title: School Star Laments His Recruitment
description: When Billy Sims of Hook, Tex., signed a letter of intent with the University of Oklahoma last week, he ended one of the strongest recruiting struggles of the season in college football But Barry Switzer,Oklahoma's head coach, his staff members and other college coaches who tried to land Sims may have done more harm than good in the way they recruited the prize back in his Texas high school.

title: MIGRANTS A TOPIC AT ROME SESSION
description: ROME, Feb. 24The difficulties that many emigrants from Italy are encountering abroad led to the opening here today of a weeklong conference on migration.

title: Fight Over Hiring Of Minorities Hits Building of Campus
description: Work on $2.2million in excavation and foundations for the New York College campus in South Jamaica, Queens, has been threatened with delay and rising costs because of a bureaucratic impasse over city and state minorityhiring policies.

title: Greek Regime Says It Thwarted a Plot; 28 Officers Seized
description: ATHENS, Feb. 24  The Greek Government announced tonight that it had placed its troops on alert in the Athens region after thwarting conspiratorial movements made by followers of the military Government that collapsed last July.

title: 3Man Panel Set Up By the A.F.L.C.I.O. To Help Taxi Local
description: BAL HARBOUR Fla., Feb. 24  A special threeman committee of international union presidents was named here today to try to resolve the financial and operational problems of Local 3036 of the New York City Taxi Drivers Union.

title: Orders for Durable Goods Declined 2.8% in January
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (Reuters)New orders for durable goods fell in Januray for the fifth consecutive month, another indication that the business recession is still deepening.

description: In an attempt to rescue ailing small businesses operating with Government or Government  backed loans, the United States Small Business Administration is working out arrangements to permit some businesses to defer monthly payments on their loans for as long as six months.

description: Morning

title: U.S. Confirms Fear Of an Early Deficit On Social Security
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Rising inflation and unemployment are throwing the Social Security retirement system into deficit years earlier than expected, the Government said today, in its first official confirmation of economists predictions.

title: RESPONSIBLE PRESS LINKED TO FREEDOM
description: Freedom of the press and the responsibility of the press to inform the public fully and fairly are each essential to preservation of the other, in the view, of John B. Oakes, the editor of the editorial page or The New York Times.

India Assails U.S. on Its Decision to Lift Pakistan Arms Embargo
