title: Front Page 1  No Title
Sony Plans Saudi Venture
description: TOKYO, Feb. 24 (Reuters)The Sony Corporation said today it was seeking authorization from the Saudi Arabian Government of its project to set up a subsidiary in Saudi Arabia to manufacure and market laboratory systems. Sony said it planned to capitalize the subsidiary, Sony Saudi Arabia, Ltd. at $300,000.

title: French Bank Group Sets $348Million Loan to Cuba
JONES ACT DECISION AFFECTING GAS DUE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The Treasury Department expects to decide this week whether to waive the Jones Act and allow shipments of liquefied natural gas from Alaska to New England in foreign ships, a department official said today.

title: Loan Rates to Consumers Showing Signs of Decline
description: The broad decline interest rates, evident for many months to business lenders, finally appears to be reaching the consumer who has to borrow.

title: Rockefeller Panel Hears 2 Witnesses Still With the C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The Rockefeller commission tightened its secrecy procedures today as it took testimony from the former head of clandestine operations for the Central Intelligence Agency and from two officials still with the agency.

title: Fight Over Hiring Of Minorities Hits Building of Campus
Clair M. Roddewig, 72, Dead;. Led Chicago Board of Education
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (UPI) Clair M. Roddewig, former president of the Chicago & Eastern Illinois Railroad, the Association of Western Railways and the Chicago Board of Education, died yesterday at the home of a daughter in suburban Hinsdale. He was 72 years old. At his death he was a member of the Chicago Transit Authority Board.

title: Fordham Residents Get Police Whistles For BlockWatching
description: More than 1,400 new police whistles, donated by the Bronx Chamber of Commerce, were distributed to residents of Fordham and Bedford Park last night at a meeting called to organize civilian security patrols in the 40block neighborhood.

title: British Soccer
description: By Reuters

title: Base Closing Reported
description: ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 24 (AP) A United States Defense Department official here confirmed today a report that the United States was planning to close the Kagnew communications base outside Asmara in June. A spokesman for the United States Embassy denied the report.

title: Ford Calls It Tragic That Congress Hasn't Cut Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 President Ford assailed Congress today for not moving faster in passing a tax cut to stimulate the economy.

title: Harvester to Shut a Plant For Trucks, Idling 335
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (Reuters) The International Harvester Company will shut down its heavyduty truck manufacturing plant at San Leandro, Calif., on Feb. 28, the company said today.

title: Most Catholics in Ulster Believe That I.R.A.'s Terrorism Is Doing More Harm Than Good
Senate Reformers Gain With Rockefeller's Help
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 With major assists from Vice President Rockefeller, Senate reformers appeared to gain the upper hand today in their battle to modify the Senate's filibuster rule.

title: People in Sports
Policy on Floor Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said tonight that a floor price on imported oil was not United States policy, although it was proposed to an international conference earlier this month by aides to Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Wood,Field&Stream
description: Excessive netting of Atlantic salmon off the coast of Greenland is at last being brought under control, says Richard A. Buck of Hancock, N. H., chairman of Restoration of Atlantic Salmon in America (R.A.S.A.).

title: Hunter Wins League Title
description: Hunter College won its third Knickerbocker Confetence championship in five years last night with an 8883 victory over Brooklyn College at the winner's Manhattan court.

title: Leader in Kashmir Is Reinstated by India
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 24Sheik Mohammed Abdullah will be reinstated tomorrow as head of the Kashmir state government, 22 years after he was dismissed from the post.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Judge Charles M. Metzner heard more than an hour of argument and then reserved his decision in Federal District Court here on a motion for a preliminary injunction in a suit seeking to return Judge Bruce McM. Wright from Civil Court to Criminal Court. Judge Wright filed suit two weeks ago against the administrative judge who transferred him, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and others on the ground that his recent transfer was punitive because he had granted low bail to defendants. He also sued to block a scheduled judicial hearing on complaints against him.

title: U.S. Reports 125,000 Jobs Were Lost in the New York Metropolitan Region in One Year
description: The number of jobs in the New York metropolitan area declined by 125,000 from December, 1973, to last December, with the loss outside the city exceeding any recorded before in a December, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: THOMAS W. ASHWELL
description: Thomas W. Ashwell, honorary president of the International Advertising Association, which he founded in 1938, died Saturday at his home, 49 Park Street, New Canaan, Conn. He was 87 years old.

title: Rookie Officers and Families Plead for Jobs
QUICK WINTER AID URGED FOR NEEDY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Nineteen Democratic and Republican Senators have sent President Ford a letter urging him to move expeditiously to provide winterization for the homes of the poor.

title: HENRY FORD HEED IN TRAFFIC CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24  Henry Ford 2d, the head of the Ford Motor Company, was held in jail for about four hours on a charge of drunken driving late Saturday night after he and a woman companion were stopped by the police on a street in a suburb of Santa Barbara, the California Highway Patrol said today.

title: Brooklyn Inmates Denied Review Of Appeal for Trial or Release
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Supreme Court declined today to review a decision barring a group of prison inmates, whose trials had been delayed, from bringing a class action in the Federal courts to force the authorities to try them or release them.

title: BRITISH WILL FREE 80 MORE IN ULSTER
Parents of Young Offenders Meet and Ask, What Went Wrong?
description: WARWICK, N. Y.The voice was permeated with pain and bewilderment. She couldn't believe it, she said. But the reality was all around her. She was here, at the State Training School for Boys, visiting her son. David is 13 years old. He is being confined for up to 18 months, after being arrested and tried on a rape charge.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Grecwhko in New Delhi
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Friend of Casais
description: Mr. Tertis, who was born in the same day and year as his friend, the late Pablo Casals (Dec. 29, 1876), performed for the viola a service comparable to that of Casals for the cello.

title: Convictions Reversed in Ticket Fixing
description: An appeals court in Brooklyn yesterday throw out the 1973 convictions of Norman A. Levy, former president of the City Tax Commission, and John R. Fratianni, former deputy commissioner of purchase, on charges of having fixed 2,000 paraking tickets for friends and political cronies.

title: Alabama Takes Lead
description: ATHENS, Ga., Feb. 24 (AP) Eighthranked Alabama, led by Charles Cleveland and Charles Russell, regained the Southeastern Conference basketball lead tonight by beating Georgia, 7364.

title: Stocks on Amex and OTC List Decline as the Volume Slackens
description: Profit taking sent prices down on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market yesterday as volume fell sharply.

title: KILLING AT ATTICA LAID TO OTHERS
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 24Defense lawyers for two former Attica inmates charged with the killing of a correction officer said today that their clients had seen indicated for a crime that others had committed. They argued that it was because their clients had been among the weakest and most vulnerable possible suspects.

title: SUGAR FUTURES STAGE A RETREAT
description: With only four more trading days remaining, the spectacular March world sugar futures dropped sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The delivery, which hit a record 66 cents a pound last November 1974 and was as low as 7.4 cents a pound in October, 1973, closed yesterday at 31.15, down from 33.20 on Friday.

title: ARABS ADVOCATE MONETARY SHIFT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon Feb. 24 (AP)Governors of Arab central banks called today for World Monetary system that would discipline the financial policies of the major industrial countries and guarantee the stability of the exchange rate of Arab petrodollars.

title: STATE HELPS EASE CITY FISCAL PINCH
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24Governor Carey today signed into law emergency legislation, passed earlier today by both houses of the Legislature, designed to help New York City meet payroll and operating expenses that become due by the end of the week.

title: MORRIS MARGULIS
description: Morris Margulis, a supermarket executive, died Sunday in Miami. He was 77 years old and lived at 177 Wyoming Avenue, Maplewood, N. J.

title: State Charges Nursing Home In Brooklyn With 80 Violations
description: The State Department of Health moved against the Garden Nursing Home yesterday, charging the Brooklyn facility with endangering the health and safety of its patients.

title: Revue:Cotton ClubGala
description: In the nineteentwenties and thirties the Cotton Club in Harlem was the place to see great singers, dancers and musicians such as Cab Calloway, Duke Ellington and Lena Home. Now in Cotton ClubGala, playing occasional weekends at La Mama Annex, Ellen Stewart pays a joyful tribute to those opulent, glossy uptown Saturday nights.

title: BANGLADESH MADE A ONEPARTY STATE
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb. 24 (AP)Bangladesh's President, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, proclaimed Bangladesh a oneparty state today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Feb. 25, 1975 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3:30 P.M. on Cyprus.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1975

title: PRICES DECLINE IN BOND MARKET
Cambodian Disaster
description: Why doesn't Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger go on television and try to sell the Brooklyn Bridge? That would be easier and far more honest than trying to sell the shabby proposition that if Cambodia goes Communist, it will be both a disaster for the United States and the fault of the Democratic Congress.

title: Chess:
description: The 42d championship of the Soviet Union showed the younger generation vying on level terms with worldclass contenders. Mikhail Tat, a former world champion, had to share his first prize with Alexander Beljavsky, who has yet to obtain the grandmaster rank. Each won six games, lost two and drew seven in posting 9 points.

title: H.U.D. Nominee Pledges Compassion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) Carla A. Hills testified that she would be a tough but compassionate Secretary of Housing and Urban Development who would forebear rather than foreclose when the poor could not meet their mortgage payments.

title: Cambodia Rebels Intensify Shelling of Besieged Town
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 24Cambodian insurgent forces intensified their shelling of the isolated Mekong River town of Neak Luong today and other setbacks for the Government were reported elsewhere.

title: STIFF NEW TAXES AHEAD FOR ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 24The Israeli Government presented to Parliament today a $9.38billion budget, with 40 per cent earmarked for defense, and announced a series or new taxes to help pay for it.

title: FORD TO INCREASE CAR OUTPUT BY 50%
description: DETROIT, Feb. 24 (Reuters) The Ford Motor Company will increase car production by 50 per cent next month and will begin to recall some of its 35, 000 workers now on indefinite furlough, president Lee Iacocca said today.

title: U.S. WILL FLY RICE INTO PHNOM PENH IN 30DAY AIRLIFT
Will Medicine Be Strangled in Law?
description: In winning Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin's manslaughter conviction for performing an abortion, the forces opposed to the historic Supreme Court decision of two years ago may have won a battle but lost the war. Certainly the Edelin verdict has produced a national wave of anger that has turned that young physician into something of a hero.

title: Kentucky Upset, 6658; Indiana Downs Illinois
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP)Gene Shy and the Florida Gators defeated No. 4ranked Kentucky tonight, 6658, ustrig a tight defense in the first half and a slowdown offense in the final eight minutes.

title: Growing With Energy
description: A strong policy to conserve energy, implemented through higher prices, quotas, taxes or rationing, does not necessarily mean fewer jobs and deteriorating living standards. It is certainly true that major cutbacks in energy consumption may bring immediate hardship and unemployment. But it does not follow that energy industry spokesmen are on solid ground in reiterating their selfserving claims that a healthy economy requires ever more energy supplies to keep it growing.

title: F.T.C. Investigating Food Franchisers
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 24 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission started an investigation today aimed at determining whether illegal methods have been used to pad prices of the $10 billion worth of food sold through franchised restaurants.

title: Yanks, Ahead of Schedule, Start What They Hope Is Their Year
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24The Yankees are so eager to win the pennant that some of them jumped the starting gun today and began spring training a day early.

title: The Theater: A Disappointing Mother Courage
description: Bertolt Brecht's Mother Courage is a play of unusual dimensions. It is an epic drama, a chronicle play about the 30 Years War in the 17th century. Brecht saw the play as a political tract, showing that capitalism breeds capitalists, and that when the world is dominated by business and the pursuit of profits, then everyone becomes a collaborator in such a process, and everyone, particularly the poor, suffers.

title: Dutch Princess and Fiance Tell How Romance Grew
description: Princess Christina of the Netherlands and her fianc, Jorge Guillermo of New York, sat on a gray velvet sofa yesterday under the portrait of a stern 17thcentury Dutch baroness, held hands, smiled and with the utmost courtesy answered a flurry of questions from American and European reporters.

title: LIONEL TERTIS, 98, VIOLIST, IS DEAD
description: Special to The New York Times

title: CONVICTION UPSET IN TICKET FIXING
description: An appeals court in Brooklyn yesterday threw out the 1973 convictions of Norman A. Levy, formei president of the City Tax Commission, and John R. Fratianni, former deputy commissioner of purchase, on charges of having fixed 2,000 parking tickets for friends and political cronies.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Justices Hear Arguments On Offshore Rights Case
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 24 Twentytwo years after Congress supposedly settled the question in the Submerged Lands Act, 12 Atlantic coastal states and the Federal Government argued today before the Supreme Court over ownership of oil and gas resources on the continental shelf.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Fund Gets New Contract
description: A new contract covering 1,300 employes of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies was approved in a union rankandfile vote yesterday. The contract provides for increases from $19 a week over a twoyear period in the minimum wage brackets to $27 a week over two years in the maximum.

title: Ulster Outlook: Britain, Reluctant but Essential, Holds Key to Peace
description: BELFAST, Northern IrelandTheir general opinion is that it were better for England if this whole island were sunk into the sea: for they have a tradition that every 40 years there must be a rebellion in Ireland.

title: Retarded Reach Out for Friendship
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.No longer hidden away in back bedrooms or distant institutions, retarded adults are fighting for acceptance, and in line with current professional thinking, are being prepared to leave institutions for independent lives.

title: BOND PRICES DROP IN A HEAVY SLATE
Farmers Lag in Income
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI)Farmers dropped slightly behind nonfarm residents in average income in 1974, after a brief stand atop the economic ladder the previous year, an Agriculture Department report said today.

title: 3 NEW LANDMARKS BACKED AT HEARINGS
description: Designations of three proposed new city landmarksthe exterior of the main Bronx Post Office building on the Grand Concourse and the interiors of Federal Hall in lower Manhattan and the BartowPell Manmion in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronxwere supported at public hearings yesterday.

title: Ford to Play Today in Gleason Golf Classic
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla., Feb. 25 Big business, show business and sports go together like apple pie and ice cream, says the official program of the 1975 Jackie Gleason Inverray Classic golf tournament.

title: F.P.C. Sets First Inventory Of U.S. Natural Gas Supply
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Federal Power Commission ordered today for the first time a comprehensive inventory of the nation's natural gas reserves.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
Bulganin Dies in Moscow; KhrushchevEra Premier
description: Nikolai A. Bulganin, the former Soviet Premier, died Monday in Moscow after a long illness, according to dispatches from the Soviet capital. He was 79 years old.

title: Listing of U.D.C. Projects
Crimmins Case Ruling
description: The State Court of Appeals found there was overwhelming proof that Alice Crimmins killed her daughter nearly 10 years ago, but ruled there was not enough, evidence to charge her with the death of her son. Page 34.

title: CRAM SEEKING JURYLESS TRIAL
description: TRENTON, Feb. 25Having lost his legal battle to have a bidrigging indictment against him dismissed, former Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel was reported tonight to be seeking to stand trial without a jury.

title: Dunlop Asks Enactment Of a Tax Reduction Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) John T. Dunlop, nominated to replace Peter J. Brennan as Labor Secretary, said today quick enactment of a tax cut should be the top priority for dealing with rising unemployment.

title: NURSINGHOME PANEL LOSES ITS DIRECTOR
description: Dr. Amitai Etzioni resigned yesterday as staff director of the special state commission on nursing homes, only three weeks after his appointment.

title: Newsrack Curb Approved
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 (AP)A law approved by the Board of Supervisors would make it illegal for newsracks on public sidewalks to show certain parts of naked adult bodies. The law requires one more reading by the board and the signature of the Mayor before going into effect.

title: CREDIT IS OBTAINED BY KAUFMAN & BROAD
description: Kaufman & Broad, the West Coastbased multinational home builder, announced yesterday that it had obtained a new $111million domestic credit agreement from a group of 16 banks.

title: Rockefeller Set Up Urban Development Group on Rebound From Voter Rejection
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25It was precisely seven years ago that Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller was frustrated by voter rejection, on two occasions, of lowincome housing proposals.

title: Merger Discussions Are Started By Textile and Clothing Unions
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 25 Two long established unions in the textile and clothing field are discussing a merger as a means of strengthening their organizing and service activities.

title: Dr. Louis Parrish enjoys leftovers and frequently cooks more food than he needs, just to have some a second time.
description: cup soy sauce 1 teaspoon finely minced garlic 1 to 2 teaspoons grated or finely chopped ginger root 1 teaspoon peanut, vegetable or corn oil.

title: Carey Seeking New Agency to Save Insolvent U.D.C
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25Governor Carey today asked the Legislature to set up a new state agency designed to rescue the insolvent Urban Development Corporation by floating its own bonds and serving as a conduit for more than $250million in state subsidies.

title: A.M.C. CUTS PRICES OF SOME MODELS
DICTAPHONE CORP. IN A MERGER DEAL
description: The Sterndent Corporation, a Mount Vernon, N. Y., manufacturer and distributor of dental supplies, agreed yesterday to a merger with the Dictaphone Corporation of nearby Rye, N.Y.,Thus ended a proposed tender offer for Stemdent stock by the Mag u s Corporation and a developing controversy concerning Arab investments and fears of antiJewish discrimination. Martin Dubilier, chairman of Sterndent, said the Dictaphone merger had been arranged because a friend of ours met a friend of theirs at dinner.

title: State Hears 2 Drivers On Banning
description: Does a harness racing track have the right to punish drivers for lackluster efforts although no action was taken against them at the time by the state's stewards? Thatproblem was thrown yesterday Race into the lap of Bertram D. Sarafan, chairman of the State Racing and Wagering Board in what he termed an extraordinary case. It involved the recent suspension of Buddy Gilmour and David Dunckley by the Westchester raceway management.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association has overwhelmingly voted in favor of the agreement that its president, Richard J. Vizzini, worked out with Mayor Beame to prevent the layoffs of 180 firemen earlier this month, Mr. Vizzini said. With 90 per cent of the mailed ballots counted by the American Arbitration. Association, Mr. Vizzini said at City Hall, his 10,500 members were voting 3to1 in favor of the Jan. 31 agreement under which each fireman will work without pay one day this fiscal year and one day next, and will accept reduced compensatory time off for the donation of blood.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CLOSE QUARTERS More and more, informality and personal contact are becoming keynotes of musical lectures in New York. There is less and less of the old format of a musical authority droning away detachedly, often glacially, to listeners perched on remote chairs. Today performers themselves are often in there pitching for art.

title: People in Sports
description: Micki King, the 1972 Olympic gold medal diver and Air Force Academy diving coach, said yesterday she would accept a post as director of intercollegiate athletics for women at the University of California, Los Angeles. The U.C.L.A, post is a new one.

title: Ford Foundation Energy Study Accused of Favoring Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) A West Coast foundation today attacked a recent Ford Foundation study of America's future energy needs and policies, saying that the widely acclaimed study was filled with errors and biased in favor of tighter government control.

title: Contempt Investigation Opened Against Great Western Sugar
description: DENVER, Feb. 25 (AP)The United States attorney's office says it is conducting a courtordered investigation of the Great Western Sugar Company to examine allegations of criminal contempt.

title: District Attorneys Agree To IllegalGun Amnesty
description: Alarmed over the growing number of gunrelated crimes in New York, four of the city's five District Attorneys have agreed upon a new policy of granting amnesty to anyone who turns in illegally held firearms next month.

title: Harris Urges Tax Cut
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 25 (AP) Former Senator Fred Harris of Oklahoma said today that the nation was in a desperate downward spiral and called for a $30billion income tax reduction to shock the nation out of recession. Mr. Harris, who is running for the Democratic Presidential nomination, held a, news conference as he started the second day of a campaign swing through North Carolina. He spoke last night to a Democratic Women's group in Fayetteville.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CARSON CITY, Nev. Feb. 25 (UPI)Bill Ireland, director of athletics for the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, said today there was never pressure brought by the Boosters Club to reinstate Mike Thomas, star running back on the Rebel football team.

title: Yemen Becomes First Arab Nation To Doom Hijacker
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 25 Yemen today became the first Arab country to sentence a hijacker to death.

title: Policeman Indicted in Theft Of $1,500 From 2 Suspects
description: A 12year veteran of the Police Department was arrested yesterday on an indictment charging him with stealing $1,500 from two narcotics suspects and sharing the money with other members of a Bronx police team.

title: Money Growth a Puzzle
Linden Man Held in Slaying of Girl, 16
description: FREEHOLD, Feb. 25Robert Zarinsky, a 34yearold Linden produce wholesaler, is being held in lieu of $125,000 bail in Monmouth County Jail here on a charge of murdering a 16 yearold Atlantic Highlands girl in 1969.

title: House Votes Cuts Of Only, 222Million In Federal Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) In the first test of the new Congress on cutting Federal spending, the House voted today to reduce such outlays by $222.5millionfar short of the $929.4million recommended by President Ford.

title: Feminists Recoil At Film Designed To Relate to Them
description: Gael Greene loved the movie. Mrs. Ring Lardner Jr. considered it a putdown of humanity in general. Betty Friedan called it a ripoff of the women's movement, and then stomped out of the screening room.

title: Coop School Plan Marks Its 60th Year In Ceremonies Here
description: In 1925, when Edward Krug was a student at Newtown High School in Queens, he almost left school to support his family. But the Board of Education found him a job as a messenger at the Irving Trust Company and he managed to graduate.

title: Bus Overturns, 1 Hurt
description: JOLIET, Ill. Feb. 25 (AP)A chartered bus skidded on an icy curve on Interstate SO near an exit ramp and overturned today, seriously injuring one of the 19 passengers. Six others in the group en route from San Francisco to Boston were treated at Silver Gross Hospital and released.

title: Suicide Pact Preceded Deaths Of Dr. Van Dusen and His Wife
description: Dr. and Mrs. Henry P. Van Dusen, leaders in American theological life, swallowed overdoses of sleeping pills last month in the bedroom of their Princeton, N. J., home in an effort to carry out a suicide. pact.

title: Motive Is a Mystery in Shooting of Teacher and Priest
description: SALEM, Feb. 25  Authorities who questioned David N. Gary, the suspect in the shotgun slaying of a priest and the wounding of a secondgrade teacher in Penns Grove yesterday, said today they were still mystified about a motive.

title: Transit Authority Accuses Its Chief Of Police in Payoffs
description: The Transit Authority yesterday formally accused its police chief, Robert H. Rapp, of making false statements about payoffs from subway concessionaires to transit policemen, and of encouraging or condoning the falsification of subway crime figures.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Moscow Says It Is Processing 1,500 Emigration Applications
LOUIS P. SMITH
description: BOSTON, Feb. 25 (AP)Louis P. Smith, who had been president of the Combined Jewish Philanthropies, board chairman of the Boston City Hospttal and a director of Beth Israel Hospital here, died Sunday at Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: MARCEL KOVARSKY
description: Marcel Kovarsky, a retired social worker, died in Hollywood, Fla., on Monday at the age of 68.

title: Byrne Asks July 1 Deadline For SchoolAid Legislation
description: TRENTON, Feb. 25Governor Byrne asked the New Jersey State Supreme Court today to give the Legislature until July 1 to approve a new system of financing public schools in the state instead of the Oct. 1 deadline the court had set last month.

title: Bulganin Dies in Moscow; KhrushchevEra Premier
description: Nikolai A. Bulganin, the former Soviet Premier, died Monday in Moscow after a long illness, according to dispatches from the Soviet capital. He was 79 years old.

title: Koch Calls Medicaid Prosecution Lax
description: Representative Edward I. Koch said yesterday that a cursory look at programs for Medicare and Medicaid across the country had shown that despite extensive and costly abuses, there were only 40 convictions for fraud in 1973 and 16 in 1972.

title: Daley Routs 3 Foes In Chicago Primary
Coast Double Pays $1,092
description: ALBANY, Calif. Feb. 25 (UPI)The 27 combination of Crack n Pop and War Lord II resulted in a $1,092 daily double today at Golden Gate Fields. There were 70 $2 tickets and one $5 ticket sold on the winning pair. Crack n Pop paid $106.60 in the first race and War Lord II returned $35.40 in the second.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Greece Holds 6 Generals Among 37 Accused of Plot
description: ATHENS, Feb. 25Thirtyseven Greek officers, including six generals, were arrested during the last two days and charged with plotting against the Government, an official announcement said tonight.

title: 11 Cities Invite Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI)Eleven cities have told the Democratic party that they are interested in playing host to the nation's first taxpayersubsidized political convention in July or August, 1976. The cities, which are being asked to make formal presentations to the Democratic National Committee's site selection panel on April 23, are Chicago, Miami Beach, Los Angeles, New York, Atlanta, New Orleans, Houston, Washington, D.C., Kansas City, Mo., Cleveland and Norfolk, Va.

title: Arms Supplier
description: With the emergence of the United States as chief supplier of weapons and military training aid in the Persian Gulfnot to mention the dubious decision to lift the embargo on arms to Pakistaninsistent questions are being raised about American policy toward the entire area in general and toward the booming international arms trade in particular.

title: Miss Snow Sings A Varied Program At the Bottom Line
description: Phoebe Snow, a folkjazz singer from New Jersey who appeared for a single evening at the Bottom Line on Monday, has had a short but already most unusual career. Her rust album has not been overblessed with promotion, in Part because of a bitter struggle with her present record company. And yet largely on the enthusiasm of disk jockeys and word of mouth from listeners it has climbedafter half a year on the chartsinto the top 10.

title: Treasury Aide to Be Named Deputy Attorney General
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Jets Unveil Third Member of Hierarchy
description: This is the new combination, said the president of the Jets, Phil Iselin, yesterday as he showee off the threeman team that willguide the New Yorkers this season.

title: High Court Upholds Right Of Pupils to Seek Damages
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Supreme Court held today that school officials who discipline pupils unfairly cannot defend themselves against civil rights suits by claimingignorance of the pupils basic constitutional rights.

title: Gold, Silver Prices Are Down Sharply
description: Commodity futures prices generally moved lower yesterday, dragged down partly by much lower prices for gold and silver. The most immediate reason for the decline in the two metals was a statement by Jamshid Amouzegar, Iran's Interior Minister, that he favored continued use of the dollar as a means of payment to oilexporting countries. On the news the dollar rose sharply in terms of many other currencies.

title: Basketball Leagues Seek Ways to Cope With Judge's Strong Antitrust Position
description: Confronted with one of the strongest antitrust positions taken so far by any Federal judge in the current series of player challenges to the traditional reserve systems, the two major basketball leagues will be considering consequences in future actions in separate meetings during the next six days.

title: Preparations for School Board Voting Are Curtailed by a Reduction in Funds
description: A $1million reduction in funds earmarked for the May 6 community school board elections has forced a serious cutback in activities intended to promote voter participation and has dimmed some hopes for a better turnout than the disappointing one in the last election.

title: Sadat: I The Ides of March
description: CAIROAnwar elSadat expects big thing's to emerge from Henry. Kissinger's return trip to the Middle East next month. The Secretary of State's recent visit to this nervous area was only a factfinding tour but the scheduled March goaround is for negotiations. And, as the Egyptian President tells friends, he expects something serious to happen.

title: Music: Gramm's Artistry
description: After Donald Gramm had finished his opening group of three Handel arias in his Carnegie Hall recital on Monday evening, one would have settled for an evening of more of the same. At the end of the program, a set of five Ives songs inspired the regret that Ives works had not made up the whole recital. It was that way with everything the bassbaritone sang in between and for encores. His kind of artistry is rare these days.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1975

title: TOP GERMAN COURT REJECTS ABORTION
description: BONN, Feb. 25The West German Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe, in a highly controversial decision, today struck down as unconstitutional a law allowing abortions on request during the first three months of pregnancy.

title: DAYCARE PLEDGE IS MADE BY CITY
description: City officials said yesterday that they had promised to remove hazardous conditions from 37 day care centers here by March 5 or risk the permanent loss of millions of dollars frozen by the state.

title: Market's Fall, Worst in 3 Months, Is Also Attributed to Profit Taking
Patman to Hold Inquiry On Bank Interest Data
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, notified the Federal Reserve Board today that his subcommittee would investigate suppression of data about commecial banks interest charges on consumer loans.

title: Suicide Pact Preceded Deaths Of Dr. V an Dusen and His Wife
description: Dr. and Mrs. Henry P. Van Dusen, leaders in American theological life, swallowed overdoses of sleeping pills last month in the bedroom of their Princeton, N. J., home in an effort to carry out a suicide pact.

title: WILLIAM B. LEWIS, HEADED AD AGENCY
description: William B. Lewis, former president and board chairman of Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising, Inc., died Monday evening in Sarasota, Fla., where he had been living. He was 74 years old and lived also in East Hampton, L. I., and at 860 Fifth Avenue.

title: This Way or That? Standardized Signs Will Aid Travelers
description: In an effort to unscramble the oftenbewildering arrows, images and verbiage cluttering air, rail and bus terminals, some of the nation's leading designers have devised 34 standardized graphic signs to speed travelers on their way. The results, which go on view at an East Side gallery today, may prove just as puzzlingat least at first glancein the opinion of the designers.

title: Transit Authority Accuses Its Chief Of Police in Payoffs
LIST IS EXTENSIVE FOR ARAB BOYCOTT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The regulations for the economic boycott of Israel by Arab countries fill 100 doublespaced pages and cover such diverse matters as border smuggling, oil tankers and motion pictures.

title: Police Chief Demands a Fuller Inquiry In Slaying of 2 Newark Puerto Ricans
Syria Says Magazine Distorted Assad's View on Mideast Peace
A.B.A. Asks Tax Relief on Legal Fees
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 25  The American Bar Association called on Congress today to let people of moderate income deduct personal legal expenses from their income taxes the way they now deduct some of their medical expenses.

title: Two Large Refiners Reduce Their Price Of Industrial Sugar
description: The Amstar Corporation and the Sucrest Corporation, the two largest American sugar refiners, followed up their price reductions of last week on grocery sugar with a similar price cut in industrial sugar, effective yesterday.

title: F.C.C., Black Dissenting, Bars a Hispanic WNET
WarnerLambert Earnings Up 9% in 4th Quarter
CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Feb. 18 reported incorrectly that the State Court of Appeals had ruled that a group of tenants in the Parkchester apartment development lacked standing to sue. In fact, the court rejected the tenants lawsuit on the merits.

title: MRS. GEORGE MERRILL
DWIGHT HUTCHISON
description: Dorothy Dwight Power Hutchison, who wrote and painted under the name Dwight Hutchison, died Saturday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Boston Desegregation Cost
description: BOSTON, Feb. 25 (AP) Boston's school desegregation programs will cost the city some $42million this year and next, the state education secretary, Paul Parks, said today.

title: Mediator in School Strike
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Feb. 25 (AP)A state mediator, Elwood Tobias, said today that he would meet with negotiators of the Scranton Board of Education and the striking Scranton Federation of Teachers tomorrow night. More than 800 teachers went on strike yesterday, closing the city's 32 schools.

title: Louisville Wins, 7569, Clinches N.C.A.A. Spot
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 25 (AP)Thirdranked Louisville clinched a tie for the Missouri Valley Conference basketball title and gained a berth in the National Collegiate tournament by defeating West Texas State tonight, 7569.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Economic Policy Council painted a gloomy picture of the state's future for five mayors, saying it might take as much as six years for the state to recover fully from the recession. My reaction was thorough depression, said Jersey City Mayor Paul T. Jordan, whose city is facing its worst fiscal crisis and who has had to lay off more than 300 employes.

title: Elijah Muhammad Dead; Black Muslim Leader, 77
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 25  Elijah Muhammad, spiritual leader of the nation's Black Muslims, died here today of congestive heart failure.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Amid Signs of Racial Division, Atlanta's Black Mayor Begins Second Year Under Fire
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 25Little more than a year has passed since Maynard Jackson began his fouryear term as the first black mayor of Atlanta, now a predominantly black city.

title: Indians Obtain Powell
description: MIAMI, Feb. 25 (AP)John (Boog) Powell, the slugging first baseman of the Baltimore Orioles, was traded today to the Cleveland Indians, along with Don Hood, a pitcher, in exchange for Dave Duncan, a catcher, and Alvin McGrew, a minor league outfielder.

title: Key Procedures Are Outlined For School Election on May 6
description: The 1969 shool decentralization law created a network of community school districts in the city, now numbering 32, each headed by its own locally elected board. These boards hire their own district superintendents and have broad operating powers over all elementary, intermediate and junior high schools in their districts.

title: Appeals Court Upsets Curb On California Oil Drilling
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit set aside today a lower court ruling that had prevented four major oil companies from building a new oil drilling platform in the Santa Barbara Channel, site of a disastrous 1969 well blowout and oil spill.

title: YUNICH FEARS RISE IN FARE ON APRIL 1
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, testified today that the New York City transit fare would rise a nickel, to 40 cerits, on April 1 unless the state sub stantially increased its subsidy program. He said commuter rail fares would rise 30 per cent on the same day.

title: Hunter Leads Way as Yankees Open
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 25Shunning any type of special treatment that might befit the wealthiest Yankee, Jim (Catfish) Hunter was the first player to arrive at the ball park and the first player dressed on the Yankees first day of spring training today.

title: Ford Expects OilFee Veto to Be Upheld
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 25 President Ford said today that he expected the Senate to sustain his upcoming veto of legislation to delay for 90 days his imposition of a new tax on imported oil as a means of curtailing consumption.

title: Army, 6 Companies Accused of Yielding To Arabs on Jews
News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1975

title: SECRECY MARKS TRIAL IN SLAYING
description: PATERSON, Feb. 25The selection of a jury in the trial of one of three defendants accused of murdering a 79yearold Roman Catholic priest here last Oct. 29 ended its second day in secrecy today in Passaic County court.

title: Country Woman, OneTonner, Wins S.O.R.C. Sail to Nassau
Chinese Lantern Festival Day Marks the End of the New Year for 4673
AIR FARE INCREASES APPROVED BY C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today fuelrelated air fare increases ranging from 4 to 8 per cent for flights linking the United States with the Caribbean, Central America and South America.

title: F. T. C. REVERSES STAND ON XEROX
description: In an unusual move, the Federal Trade Commission reversed its position yesterday on an agreement it had reached with the Xerox Corporation to settle an antitrust complaint that it had brought against the copyingmachines maker two years ago.

title: Paris Opera, Once the Worst, Enjoys a Renaissance
description: PARISThis is the year that Paris is celebrating the 100th anniversary of the opening of the great opera house built by Charles Garnier. It took 14 years to put up, and what resulted was a sublime example of Second Empire bourgeois taste, neoBaroque, fake classicism, Byzantine splendor. The Paris Opra remains one of the most enchanting buildings in the world.

title: State Plans to Set Service Standards for Con Ed
description: The State's Public Service Commission said yesterday that it intended to set standards for customer service for the Consolidated Edison Company and had directed a management consultant concern to start working on them.

title: FILIBUSTER RULE STALLING SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Sucking cherryflavored instant glucose for energy from a toothpastelike tube, Senator James B. Allen. Democrat of Alabama, held the Senate floor for more than four hours today in his effort to prevent a change in the Senate's filibuster rule.

title: DEMOCRATS PRESS FOR A SHOWDOWN ON OIL DEPLETION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The House Democratic Caucus, defying most of its leaders, took the first step today toward forcing Congress to confront the issue of repeal of the controversial 22 per cent oil depletion allowance.

description: BEAN SPROUT AND SHRIMP SOUP

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: 3 National Conventions Set for State in '76
description: NEWARK, Feb. 25 (AP) Three national organizations will bring their annual conventions to New Jersey during the Bicentennial year of 1976, the New Jersey Bicentennial Commission announced today.

title: Notes on People
description: Margaret Thatcher, leader of the Conservative party of Britain, chose a Tory's Tory yesterday when she named Lord Thorneycroft as party chairman. He replaces William Whitelaw, now Mrs. Thatcher's deputy in the House.of Commons, as chairmana role that mainly involves keeping the party in trim.

title: Army Again Mounts An Attack on Birds At Kentucky Base
description: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., Feb. 25 (AP)The Army mobilized fire trucks and helicopters tonight in a second chemical assault on blackbirds roosting at this military base.

title: ExChampion Seeking the Perfect Court
description: With the Carpathian Count (Ion Tiriac) having had his way with the damsel in distress (Abbi Maynard) in the historic mixed singles at Ridgefield, Conn., one interested observer commented yesterday, At least they couldn't blame the court for her downfall.

title: FORD AND KISSINGER WARN CAMBODIA WILL FALL SOON IF CONGRESS DENIES FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the Cambodian Government would fall in a few weeks to Communistled insurgents unless Congress soon approved the Administration's request for $222million in supplemental aid.

title: Sugar Price Cut
description: The Amstar Corporation and the Sucrest Corporation, the two largest sugar refiners in the United States, followed their price reductions last week on grocery sugar with a similar price cut on industrial sugar, effective yesterday. Details on Page 59.

title: Elyse***Worth Journey For Visiting Master Chefs
description: PARIS, Feb. 25They were all dazzled by it: the starstudded lunch eaten today at the Elyse Palace by President Valry Giscard d'Estaing and 13 of the greatest chefs in Franceand in the world.

title: IMMUNITY BACKED IN INQUIRY ON C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence favors the use of carefully selected grants of immunity from criminal prosecution to encourage candid testimony from Government agents in the panel's investigation, a survey of the membership has disclosed.

title: Moynihan Calls on U.S. to Start Raising Hell in U.N.
description: Daniel P. Moynihan, former American Ambassador to India, said today that the United States should drop its defensive attitude toward the new United Nations majority of thirdworld countries.

title: Chelsea Residents Gain In Fight to Bar Garage
description: Community groups opposed to the construction of a United States Postal Service garage under new housing in Chelsea won a victory yesterday when a Federal judge here granted a preliminary injunction against the start of the project.

title: Carey Seeking New Agency to Save Insolvent U.D.C.
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25Governor Carey today asked the Legislature to set up a new state agency designed to rescue the insolvent Urban Development Corporation by floating its own bonds and serving as a conduit for more than $250 million in state subsidies.

title: Currency Bolstered by Central Banks
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 25 (UPI) The dollar rallied slightly at the close of trading today on European foreignexchange market's in apparent response to a decision by oilproducing countries to retain the United States currency in calculating the price of crude oil.

title: Mets Feel Catfish's Presence
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25Who owns New York, the Mets or the Yankees?

title: OPEC Weighs Firm Output for Guaranteed Income; Dollar Rallies After Oil Producers Decide to Keep It
description: VIENNA, Feb. 25A declaration by oilexporting countries of guaranteed levels of supply in exchange for guaranteed income from industrial consumers was debated here today at a ministerial meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Building Projects May Get State Minority Job Quotas
description: The state, in forming a new policy for getting more minority workers in the construction trades, is likely to set specific quotas for minority workers at individual projects, depending on current industrywide employment levels, according to Louis L. Levine, the State Labor Commissioner.

title: Britain Plans 45% Tax on Oil Revenue
description: LONDON, Feb. 25The British Government announced plans today for a basic tax rate of 45 per cent on oil revenues from the North Sea to be sure that the nation will benefit fully from its rich underwater Petroleum deposits.

title: Daley Routs 3 Foes In Chicago Primary
description: CHICAGO. Feb. 25Mayor Richard J. Daley, the last of the bigcity Democratic bosses, routed three opponents in the Democratic primary in his bid for an unprecedented sixth fouryear term as Mayor of the nation's second largest city.

title: Advertising
POIGNANT LYRICISM IN HAINES CANT AT A
description: The concert presented in Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night by the LeagueI.S.C.M. (International Society for Contemporary Music) was a sober, solid and earnest occasionbut then, this respected 53yearold society has rarely dabbled in the more flamboyant fringes of the avantgarde that have surfaced in the last 20 years.

title: Stocks Plunge 17.76
description: The stock market incurred its sharpest drop in more than three months yesterday because of negative economic news and profit taking. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 17.76 points at 719.18, its largest decline since Nov. 18. Page 53.

title: A Glossary of Terms Used in Bond Trading
description: Bond Anticipation NotesShortterm securities sold by an organization to obtain temporary financing.

title: High Court Leaves Standing Ruling Allowing Copying of Copyright Articles.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25A deadlocked Supreme Court failed to resolve today a major national controversy over the legality of wholesale reproduction and distribution of written material supposedly protected by copyright.

title: Built Religious Body
description: In his 41 years as its spiritual leader, Elijah Muhammad molded the Nation of Islam into a significant religious body.

title: GTE Sylvania Wins 18.9Million Award For Naval System
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (Reuters)The Navy selected GTE Sylvania today to develop and test a controversial new system called Sanguine to communicate with submerged submarines.

title: Her Job as a Broker Helps Her Food Budget
description: Last October, Barbara Saslaw Dixon decided not to buy salad oil for a while: Soybean oil futures were selling at the Chicago Board of Trade for the unusually high price of almost 50 cents a pound.

title: Children Starving In OnceLush Land
DEFAULT BY U. D. C. HITS BOND MARKET
description: Investors holding bonds and notes of the financially troubled Urban Development Corporation suffered a severe setback yesterday as the state housing agency notified its bankers that it could not meet $104.5million in payments due yesterday.

title: Nader Says C.A.B. Didn't Act On Political Gifts From Airline
Despair of Cambodia
description: For nearly five years, since the United States and South Vietnam sent their armies into Cambodia in pursuit of North Vietnamese forces finding sanctuary there, the people of that once peaceful land have known only grief. Illgoverned by their capital, illserved by their supposed friends outside, the Cambodians have lived a nightmare, pawns of a grand strategy not of their making.

title: Bridge:
description: Beginners have a habit of leading high from Qxx or Jxx in partner's suit. After a time they discover that it is better to lead low, since the honorlead frequently loses and hardly ever gains. In view of this, few experts even attempt to uncover the rare exceptions. Those who do however, get considerable satisfaction when they hit the right moment.

title: Ford Note To Albert
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Following is the text of a letter sent today by President Ford to Representative Carl Albert, Speaker of the House, on aid to Cambodia:

title: Rod Stewart and the Faces at the Garden
description: Rod Stewart, the ScottishEnglish rocker who appeared with his band, Faces, for a soldout Madison Square Garden concert Monday night, first emerged in the midnineteensixties as a member ofthe Jeff Beck group. He then switched over to Faces, and has alternated on disks between Faces albums and solo albums ever since.

title: The Week's Market Basket:
Motive Is a Mystery In the Shooting of 2 In School in Jersey
description: SALEM, N. J., Feb. 25Authorities who questioned David N. Gary, the suspect in the shotgun slaying of a priest and the wounding of a secondgrade teacher in Penns Grove yesterday, said today they were still mystified about a motive.

title: N.B.A. TV Game Changed
description: The National Basketball Association and CBS announced yesterday a change in their nationally televised game for March 2. Instead of televising the Los Angeles at Washington game as originally planned, the network will broadcast the SeattleBoston game at Hartford, beginning at 1 P.M.

title: Appeals Court Finds Overwhelming Proof Mrs. Crimmins Killed Her Daughter
description: ALBANY, FEB. 25The State Court of Appeals found today that there was overwhelming proof that Alice Crimmins killed her 4yearold daughter in 1965. The court statement was made as it overturned a lower court's reversal of Mrs. Crimmins's manslaughter conviction in the death of her daughter.

title: Soviet Defense Officials Continue Talks With Indians
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 25Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, the Soviet Defense Minister, met with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and Foreign Minister Y. B. Chavan today.

title: Richardson Gives Views On Kissinger's Tenure
description: Elliot L. Richardson, scheduled to take up his duties in London Monday as. the new American ambassador, privately told British correspondents that there was an even chance Secretary of State Kissinger would resign before the end of President Ford's term and that he would probably become his successor, The Chicago SunTimes reported yesterday.

title: Big Board Sends Members Proposal on Unfixed Rates
description: The New York Stock Exchange has began circulating to its members a detailed document of proposed rule changes that would amend the Big Board's constitution to conform with Securities and Exchange Commission orders that fixed brokerage rates be eliminated.

title: BEAME PRESSING A RESIDENCE BILL
description: ALBANY, Feb, 25Mayor Beame urged the Legislature today to adopt a bill requiring all employes hired by New York City after Sept. 1, 1975, to maintain a residence within the city as a condition of employment.

title: Rivlin to C.B.O.
description: C.B.O.for Congressional Budget Officeare initials that will have to become as familiar in the press and in the Federal bureaucracy as the initials O.M.B.for Office of Management and Budgetnow are, if the revitalization of Congress's power over the budget is to become a reality.

title: U. S. Policy on Africa
A Hong Kong Aide Guilty of Graft; Public Is Enraged
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 25This colony's most spectacular trial in recent years ended today when a former senior police official was found guilty of corruption and sentenced to four years in prison.

title: OMBUDSMAN BILL GAINS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25The Senate today overwhelmingly passed a bill authorizing the State Commissioner of Health to appoint an older person in each county of the state to serve as a nursinghome patientadvocate to investigate, complaints from residents and make reports to the Commissioner.

title: Early Indians Described As Rather Sophisticated
description: EVANSTON. Ill.  Contrary to popular conception, the Indians who lived in the Central Mississippi River Valley in 6500 B.C. were not primitive savages who struggled just to survive.

title: Dave Anderson
description: KERHONKSON, N.Y., Feb. 25In its brochure, The Granit Hotel and Country Club proclaims, The fact that we're perched on the slopes of the Shawangunks near Kerhonkson may not sound extraordinary at first, but it means a great deal to us. The fact that Chuck Wepner is training here may not sound extraordinary at first either, but it means a great deal to him. Until now he has always trained in Bufano's Gym above an old wooden store perched on Jersey City's cliffs, not far from Bayonne where he lived and where he ran in Hudson County Park the mornings before working his route as liquor salesman. But in preparing to challenge Muhammad Ali for the world heavyweight title in the Cleveland Coliseum on March 24, he is finally working full time a boxer. Other gladiators often train at Grossinger's or the Concord in a higherrent district of the Catskills, but there is something almost romantic in the thought that Chuck Wepner is sleeping here.

title: SexInhibiting Chemicals May Aid in Pest Control
Rare Rhinoceros Dies After Surgery in Iowa
description: AMES, Iowa, Feb. 25 (UPI)  Tiny, a 5,000pound, 14 yearold Indian rhinoceros, died of an intestinal obstruction last night, according to one of four Iowa State University vetinarians who performed emergency surgery on the animal.

title: Money Growth Quickens, Burns Says; Stocks Drop 17.76 on Economic News
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Federal Reserve Board has already set in motion actions that should lead to a quicker pace of expansion of the nation's money supply, Arthur F. Burns told Congress today.

title: The Shoe and the Other Foot
description: PARISA year ago during the energy crisis when Northerners were asking the United States Government to do something about the high price of heating oil, Southerners who live near our greatest oil and gas supplies were parading bumper stickers saying: Let the Northern bastards freeze.

title: Agreement Is Closer on 3d Water Tunnel
description: The city and contractors on the Third Water Tunnel project narrowed their money differences to $60million yesterday but failed to resolve the dispute that has kept 1,500 sandhogs and other workers idle since early last December. Meeting at City Hall, members of they Board of Estimate and representatives of the sixcompanyconsortium that holds the contract to build the 13.7mile underground conduit through the Bronx and upper Manhattan, and into Queens sought as basis for agreement that would permit resumption of digging.

title: Bonn Says OilImport Cost Rose in 74, but Volume fell
description: BONN, Feb. 25 (Reuters)West German crude oil imports fell by 7.2 per cent, to 102.5 million metric tons in 1974, but their value rose 153 per cent to $9.85billion, the Economics Ministry reported today.

title: HARAN'S CELLO MUSIC IN AUSTERE PROGRAM
description: Michael Haran brought an unusually austere program to Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening, bracketing the introspective D minor Sonata of Faur and Ten Variations by Haim Elisha with two long, unaccompanied works: the Bach Suite in D and Kodly's Sonata (Op. 8).

title: WINE TALK
description: Name one wine from each of the following French wine regions: Alsace, Anjou, Burgundy, Bordeaux.

title: LOUIS A. SCHULMAN
description: Louis A. Schulman, who operated L. A. Schulman, Inc., a women's specialty shop in White Plains, died Monday at his home, 12 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains. He was 87 years old.

title: About New York
description: The first few men got on the breadline before 6 A.M., and when it opened an hour later there were 200 of them, waiting to get a baloney sandwich and coffee in a cardboard cup. Brother Albert Aldrich stepped out from the kitchen then, and held up his hand. O.K., he said, ladies first.

title: High Court Upholds Right Of Pupils to Seek Damages
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Supreme Court held today that school officials who discipline pupils unfairly cannot defend themselves against civil rights suits by claimingignorance of the pupils basic constitutional rights.

title: Influenza Deaths Decline
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 25 (AP) The number of deaths related to influenza and pneumonia declined sharply across the nation during the week ending Feb. 15, the National Center for Disease Control reported yesterday. But the rate of flurelated deaths remained above the centr's epidemic threshold.

title: Islanders Set Back Blues, 30
NewcombeConnors Set for April 26
description: From opposite corners of the world, like two fighters moving in on a big payday, Jimmy Connors and John Newcombe will announce plans today for their tennis challenge match.

title: LID ON FOOD PRICES CALLED SUCCESS
description: Can government price control moderate the inflationary advance of food prices? President Ford and his economic advisers hold that it cannot, but the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico issued a report yesterday in San Juan, Washington and New York asserting that its expeprices.

description: The stock market incurred its sharpest drop in more than three months yesterday because of negative economic news and profit taking. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 17.76 points at 719.18, its largest decline since Nov. 18. Page 53.

title: CHURCH ENDS TALKS ON WRVR SALE TO GAF
description: The Riverside Church yesterday advised the GAF Corporation that it was ending discussions on the possible sale of its radio station WRVR to the manufacturing company. The action came after a report in The New York Times that the two parties were in negotiations.

title: Albert's Stenographer Charges An Attempt to Defame Speaker
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The attorney for a stenographer in Speaker Carl Albert's office charged today that an influencepeddling investigation that resulted in the stenographer's indictment was an attempt to defame the Speaker of the House.

title: 2 SENATORS LISTED FOR GURNEY TRIAL
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 25Two Senators and a former Senator are on a list of witnesses who may be called to testify in the bribery, perjury and conspiracy trial of former United States Senator Edward J. Gurney, now under way here.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The General Accounting Office reported today that cost overruns on 269 Federal construction projects had pushed up the total project costs by $57billion over original estimates.

title: 15 Daily Flights to Take Cambodia Rice and Kerosene
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 25The United States Embassy announced today that a 30day American airlift of rice and kerosene for the civilian population of Phnom Penh would begin Thursday from Saigon's Tan Son Nhut air base.

title: MARGUERITE S. GATES
description: NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 25  Marguerite S. Gates of South Nyack, who had served as director of St. Luke's School and the Silver Cross State Nursery in New York, died last night. She was 82 years old.

title: Market Place
description: Interest rates have declined sharply this year in the face of heavy financing activity and the prospect of much more over the next several months. Along with the decline in interest rates, investors hive become less insistent on higher yields for riskier bonds.

title: People and Business
description: Henri Simonet, vice president of the European Economic Community in charge of energy policy, strongly supported a world floor price for oil yesterday. In New York, after speaking to energy officials in Washington, Mr. Simonet said he thought that a floor price of $7 to $8 for a barrel of oil would be advisable, although he said that the Common Market had not made any major study of the question.

title: NAMING OF DAVIS ATTACKED AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Controversy over the nomination of Nathaniel Davis to be Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs continued today as Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr. called for withdrawal of the appointment.

title: Greatest of Great Houses
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica (UPI)Popular with tourists is the restored Rose Hall Great House in Montego Bay. The grandest of Jamaica's Great Houses, it was the home of Anne Palmer, the legendary, white witch who was said to have murdered four husbands and countless lovers.

title: TOP GERMAN COURT REJECTS ABORTION
description: BONN, Feb. 25The West German Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe, in a highly controversial decision, today struck down as unconstitutional a law allowing abortions on request during the first three months of pregnancy.

title: A Psychiatrist Who Finds Cooking the Greatest Therapy
description: A note recently from a favorite correspondentFeinschmeckerinformed us he'd just dined in the home of a Dr. Louis Parrish, a physician and friend who has taught many of his friends about herb cookery.

title: Dealer's Papers Sought In Indian Museum Case
description: A dealer in American Indian art has been ordered to show cause by Monday why he, should not be forced to give State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz records of his dealings with the Museum of the American Indian.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: The days of Charley Frost at American Express appear to be numbered. Charleythe fictional Charles F. Frost holds the company's bestknown credit card, one that has appeared in countless television commercials and print advertisements.

description: Tax Cut: Why It Must Be Quick and Big

title: YUGOSLAV CRITIC IS ON TRIAL AGAIN
description: NOVI SAD, Yugoslavia, Feb. 25Mihajlo Mihajlov, a dissident writer who is a leading critic of the Soviet and Yugoslav Governments, went on trial again here today, facing new charges of having spread hostile propaganda.

title: Bensonhurst Man Is Seized After a Police Siege
description: A 21yearold Brooklyn man, described as distraught over a fight with his girlfriend, threw a live hand grenade at two police officers and kept an assault force at bay with a flurry of rifle shots last night, according to the police, they said he finally succumbed to a detective's ruse and was seized in his Bensonhurst apartment.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The House Democratic Caucus, defying most of its leaders, took the first step today toward forcing Congress to confront the issue of repeal of the controversial 22 per cent oil depletion allowance.

title: Catherine F. La Farge Wed in Colorado
description: Catherine F. La Farge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. La Farge of Killingworth, Conn., was married yesterday afternion to John England, son of Mr. and Mrs. David England of Toronto.

title: The Wallace Spirit
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 25Gov. George Wallace sits at his desk here in the gleaming white capitol of Alabama these days and proclaims his fitness to run again for President of the United States in 1976.

title: George Parnassus Dead at 78; Boxing Promoter and Manager
Preventive Education
description: American education has devoted too much of its resources to massive remedial instruction, and not enough to the prevention of failure. Wasteful of manpower and funds, this policy is even more severely flawed in human terms. The frustrations suffered by children who cannot keep up with their peers are hard to erase, even with superficially effective remedial work.

title: Chimps Learning Signs Faster With Deaf
description: Two baby chimpanzees raised almost from birth in the homes of deaf people and others fluent in the gestural language of the deaf are learning sign language words at a pace approximating that of human infants in deaf homes.

title: Israeli Town Where 18 Died Stages Purim Parade Full of Joy and Color
description: QIRYAT SHEMONA, Israel, Feb. 25This stricken town on the Lebanese border today put aside mourning over the past and apprehension over the future to let itself go in the joy of the holiday that marks Queen Esther's deliverance of her fellow Jews destined for slaughter.

title: Attica Murder Trial Judge Bars Testimony on Police Prison Attack
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 25All testimony about the state police assault that ended the Attica prison rebellion of 1971 was ruled irrelevant and inadmissible this morning by the judge who is presiding here over the first major criminal case to stem from the uprising, in which 43 persons lost their lives.

title: FLORENCE CHAMBERS
description: Florence Chambers, a concert pianist who had taught at the JuiIliard Institute of Musical Art in the nineteentwenties, died last Wednesday at a nursing home in Blackfoot, Idaho, where she had directed a music therapy program at a Veterans Administration hospital. She was 84 years old and the widow of the Rev. Edmund Chambers, an educational missionary.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward (Mrs. Newman) will be honored for their movie achievements at the annual benefit gala of the Film Society of Lincoln Center on May, 5 in Avery Fisher Hall. The event is the fourth in the series inaugurated in 1972 with a tribute, to Charles Chaplin, which was followed by fetes for Fred Astaire and Alfred Hitchcock.

title: Article 1  No Title
Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)The Tieasury Department will have ready within two weeks revised policies on foreign investment in the United States, Assistant Treasury Secretary Gerald L. Parsky said today. He said the Treasury Department was considering whether there should be greater disclosure of foreign investment information, whether there should be advance clearance of investments in some industries and whether there should be limits placed on the amount of investments in some industries.

title: Built Religious Body
description: In his 41 years as its spiritual leader, Elijah Muhammad molded the Nation of Islam into al significant religious body.

title: Wine Labels: They Don't Tell All
description: Woman says: I hate making commercials But Madria Madria Sangria is made by my husband and his uncle in their special way with all the Spanish tradition that goes into Madria Madria I hope that everybody buys Madria Madria Sangria. That way I don't have to make more commercials.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A classaction suit to force the Nassau County Medical center to perform abortions on welfare recipients who want them up to the 24th week of pregnancy was filed yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn. Chraging that hospital policy banning abortions after the 12th week of pregnancy was dictated by hysteria and fear of criminal prosecution, the suit sought an injunction to force the hospital to comply with a twoandahalfyearold Federal Court ruling specifically directing that abortions be performed on indigent women up to the 24th week of pregnancy.

title: Ford Backs Reappraisal of Presidential Succession
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  President Ford endorsed a Congressional reappraisal of the 25th Amendment today at the same time that a Justice Department official told Congress that the White House opposed any substantive change in the amendment.

title: NEW GROUP BACKS HIRING GUIDELINES
description: A new national organization, the Committee for Affirmative Action in Universities, is being formed to support the Federal Government's guidelines for the academic hiring of women, blacks and other minorities.

title: Daley's Victory in the Primary More Than a Personal Triumph
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 26Mayor Richard J. Daley's overwhelming victory yesterday over three Democratic mayoral primary opponents was not only a personal triumph for the 72 yearold political boss, but also accomplished the following:

title: Compromise Sought In Filibuster Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The Senate Democratic leadership and a powerful member of its Southern bloc joined tonight in an effort to forge a compromise revision of the Senate's fillibuster rule.

title: $7BILLION URGED FOR REORGANIZING RAILWAY SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The Federal Government made public today its preliminary plan to reorganize the bankrupt Northeastern railroads by stripping away minor, unprofitable freight routes and investing more than $7billion in public and private funds in a vast longterm rehabilitation program.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: LIFE OF DUMP PUT IN HANDS OF P.U.C.
description: HACKENSACK, Feb. 26A three judge appellate panel ruled today that the Overpeck Creek landfill, which serves 26 Bergen County communities, should continue to operate for now and that primary jurisdiction over the question of its permanent operation rests with the Board of Public Utilities Commissioners.

title: Floppers Get A.A.U. Push
description: Based on a telephone poll of 23 members of the games committee yesterday, Dwight Stones will have his way again in the location of the high jump pit for tomorrow night's Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships at Madison Square Garden.

title: LEWIS P. HARRISON
description: Lewis P. Harrison, who retired in the nineteenfifties as president of Harrison Brothers. Inc., retail shoe dealers in Short Hills and Montclair, N. J., died yesterday at Point Pleasant (N.J.) Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Brielle, N. J.

title: Deductions On Players Are Upheld
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 26 (AP) Federal District Court Judge Frank Hooper upheld today the right of a team owner to claim the depreciation of a pro football player's contract as an income tax deduction.

title: Penney Reduces Men's Clothing Prices
description: The J. C. Penney Company, the country's secondlargest retail chain, after Sears, Roebuck & Co., announced yesterday that it was cutting prices as much as 25 per cent on a number of men's clothing items. Last month, Penney reduced prices on a wide variety of its home  sewing fabrics. Penney said that the cuts involved suits, jeans, casual and dress slacks. jackets and work clothing and attributed them to a softening of wholesale prices.

title: Ranger Surge Tops Blues, 51
Needham Head Praises Other Agencies Efforts
description: Frederick (Sandy) Sulcer, president of Needham, Harper & Steers, did a very strange thing the other night during a speech before the Business/Professional Advertising Association in Rochester. He mentioned what he considered as good campaigns from other agencies.

title: Bache Profit Drops 46.8% in Quarter; Revenue Is Steady
description: Bache & Co., Inc., reported yesterday secondquarter earnings of $1.1million, a decline of 46.8 per cent from yearearlier levels. Revenues for the quarter remained at $47.9million, and as a result Bache slid from its position as the nation's secondlargest securities house after Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

title: 1974 Cost Rise Here Most in 27 Years
description: The 10.7 per cent increase in consumer prices in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area during 1974 was the sharpest rise in 27 years, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

title: Bennett Cut in Ring
description: LONDON, Feb. 26 (UPI)Lonnie Bennett, a California lightheavyleight, suffered a cut near his left eye during sparring today in preparation for his world title challenge against Britain's John Conteh at London's Empire Pool on March 11. Bennett was cut while sparring with Billy Knight at the gym where the Los Angeles boxer is training for the world Boxing Council bout.

title: Fugitive British M.P. Is Denied Resident Standing by Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 26John Stonehouse, the British member of Parliament who entered Australia under a false name last year, was today denied permanent residence in Australia.

title: Hispanic Community in Newark Asks Further Slayings Inquiry
description: NEWARK, Feb. 26Members of the city's Spanishspeaking community today joined with city officials in calling for a continued investigation to determine the identities of city policemen responsible for the deaths of two men during two days of civil disturbances here last September.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: William J. Ronan agreed yesterday to testify at a New Jersey legislative inquiry into gifts totaling $550,000 given him by Vice President Rockefeller. Dr. Ronan, who is chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, will testify before the Joint Transportation Committee of the Legislature on March 10 in Jersey City, Assemblyman Michael Esposito, the committee's chairman and Democrat of Hudson, said.

title: Hospitals in State Face a Fiscal Crisis
description: TRENTON, Feb. 26New Jersey's general hospitals, beleaguered by skyrocketing costs, impoundment of last year's Blue Cross fund and cancellation of their malpractice insurance, appear to be facing a major fiscal crisis in the delivery of health care.

title: End of Investigation Unit Is Weighed
description: TRENTON, Feb. 26Several state officials said today that legislation that would abolish the State Commission of Investigation had been drafted in the Governor's office.

title: Widow of Police Aide Dies After Burglar Enters Home
description: The 77yearold widow of a former police official died yesterday morning, apparently of a heart attack after an attempted burglary of her Brooklyn apartment, the police reported.

title: $6.3MILLION CUT BY CITY U. ACTION
description: The Board of Higher Education volunteered the statement yesterday that it did not need $6.3million in its proposed $23.2million capital budget, a piece of news that so surprised Matthew J. Troy Jr., the City Council Finance Committee chairman, that he was speechless for a moment.

title: Film
President Is Using Leverage on Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 President Ford, who entered the battle with Congress over economic and energy policy as a decided underdog, seems to be scoring some important points with his repeated jabs at what he calls Congressional inaction.

title: Sanford Draws 250 WellWishers to His Presidential ComingOut Party Here
description: Making his first Presidential campaign foray into New York former Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina differed with many other Democrats yesterday and praised Secretary of State Kissinger for one of the most remarkable performances of any Secretary of State.

title: Webb Not Joking About Mets' Job
Snag on Dates Noted
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (Reuters)Secretary of State Kissinger would have had to pcistpone a meeting with Foreign Minister Chavan, even if Mr. Chavan had not done so, American officials said today. Mr. Kissinger is expected to be abroad on March 13 and 14, the scheduled dates for the meeting. He leaves March 5 for the Middle East and is not expected back for at least 10 days.

title: Women in Arizona House Help Defeat Equality Bill
Met, in Crisis, Asks Employes to Accept 10 Per Cent Pay Cut
description: The Metropolitan Opera, in what was called a survival situation, asked its employes yesterday to accept a 10 per cent pay cut, plus a shorter work year.

title: Early American On the Outside, But the Inside
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I. The tall brown house, just around the corner from Main Street, is about as Early and American as you can get out here.

title: CHASE SUPPORTING RESCUE OF U.D.C.
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank emerged yesterday as the strongest  and, possibly, the only  bank willing to support Governor Carey in his plan to save the Urban Development Corporation from extinction.

title: 40 Added Stocks Set in Few Months By Options Board
ROCKEFELLER POSES ENERGY SOLUTIONS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 26  Vice President Rockefeller, appearing in the capital of the depressed automobile industry, said tonight that the solution to the energy problem was not to downgrade the auto industry but to adapt it to new energy realities.

title: G.E. MOVES UP DATE FOR REBATES START
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it would begin its program of rebates on small appliances this Saturday instead of March 21 as originally planned. The closing date will remain May 18. G. E. will give rebates of $2, $3 or $5 to purchasers of any of 39 different small appliances. The program was originally announced on Feb. 3.
