description: VIENNA, Feb. 26 (Reuters) Major oil  exporting nations tonight ordered urgent studies to determine if the dollar should continue to be used to calculate oil revenues.

title: PROF. WILLIAM H. ROSS
description: Wiliam H. Ross, professor of physics at the University of Massachusetts, died Monday in Northampton, Mass. He was 65 years old and lived in Amherst, Mass.

title: Chess:
description: Dr. Max Euwe, world champion from 1935 to 1937, once said of the man from whom he won and to whom he later lost his title, Even if there are a thousand general reasons for rejecting a move, Alekhine is always ready to consider it. Such freshness of approach is undoubtedly admirable, but it demands discipline to avoid degeneration into eccentricity.

title: Cairo Is Proclaiming Optimism On a Sinai Pullback by Israelis
description: CAIRO, Feb. 26Egyptian officials say they are fully confident that Secretary of State Kissinger will be able to achieve an Israeli withdrawal from the strategic Mitla and Gidi mountain passes and the Abu Rudeis oilfields in the Sinai Peninsula when he returns tcv the Middle East next month.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The Federal Government made public today its preliminary plan to reorganize the bankrupt Northeastern railroads by stripping away minor, unprofit able freight routes and invest ing more than $7billion in public and private funds in a vast longterm rehabilitation program.

description: Governor Carey labeled the new Federal plan to restructure bankrupt Northeastern railroads yesterday utterly unacceptable.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

The upstate utility originally, asked for rises totaling $97.7million a year and later increased the total to $105.9million.

description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 26  The Common Market Governments are considering a counterproposal to Secretary of State Kissinger's plan for a floor under the price of oil, and they intend to present it to the United States and other members of the International Energy Agency next week.

description: The workmen, contractors, rental agents and prospective tenants of Roosevelt Island are holding their breaths.

description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 26Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that the United States decision to lift the embargo on arms supplies to Pakistan amounted to the reopening of old wounds on the Asian subcontinent.

description: The Norfolk and Western Railroad, one of the nation's major solvent railroads affected by the Government's new plan for reorganizing bankrupt railroads in the Northeast quadrant of the country, said yesterday that it doubted the viability of the plan without continuing Government financial support.

Howard Hunt Jr., convicted Watergate conspirator, and the four men from Miami who pleaded guilty in the Watergate breakin and burglary to withdraw their pleas.

description: WALTHAM, Mass., Feb. 26 (AP)  Two men robbed the North Waltham branch office of the NewtonWaltham Bank & Trust Co. today and fled with less than $5,000, the police said. 1The car believed used by the robbers was found at Windsor Village, a 701unit apartment complex.

title: Where Antelope Play
description: Conservationists are rightly aroused by the Interior Department's decision to give exclusive control of three of the country's major wildlife ranges to the Bureau of Land Management. Their concern is warranted enough for Congress to step in if President Ford does not reverse Secretary Morton's deplorable action.

title: Dr. Robert S. Porro, 40, Pathologist, Dies in Fire
description: Dr. Robert S. Porro, associate professor of pathology at the Cornell University Medical College and associate attending pathologist at New York Hospital, died Tuesday evening as a result of a fire in his apartment at 435 East 70th Street. He was 40 years old.

title: Paris Paintings Recovered
description: MONTE CARLO; Feb. 26 (Reuters)The police here have recovered paintings worth $2 million after a chase through the streets of Monte Carlo. The paintings, stolen from a leading Paris gallery two years ago, were found in the trunk of the car of a man arrested after the chase yesterday.

title: PRICES REBOUND ON AMEX AND OTC
On Political Similes
description: WASHINGTONThe art of the simile is as dead as a doornail. Here we are, making do with expressions like smart as a whip, blind as a bat, happy as a lark and sound as a dollar, which were coined centuries ago.

title: U.S. Currency Seen Eroding Oil Value
description: VIENNA, Feb. 26When an Iranian or Kuwaiti oil official went shopping in Vienna's fine stores a year ago, he exchanged his dollars for about 19 schillings and bought a good shirt for about $20.

title: Uganda Export of Copper Halted Till Investigation
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb, 26 (AP)President Idi Amin of Uganda has imposed a ban on copper exports until he finds out what is happening to the income from it, the Uganda radio reported today.

title: Catholic Officials In Philadelphia Cut Ties to Girl Scouts
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP) The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Philadelphia is severing relations July 1 with the Girl Scouts organization in a dispute over moral questions of abortion and birth control.

title: Pro Transactions BASEBALL
description: CALIFORNIA (A)Signed Ellie Rodriguez, catcher, and obby Valentine, infielderoutfielder.

title: RadiumSoaked Concrete Found in Toronto Building
description: TORONTO, Feb. 26Because a photographer here noticed last week that his film was becoming badly fogged, it has been discovered that a patch of radiumsoaked concrete, hidden under floor tile, presents a previously unknown hazard in an office building here.

title: Business Briefs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 (Reuters)BankAmerica Realty Investors said today that it was in technical default on a $50million term bank loan.

title: 3 Teenagers Are Indicted In Murder of John Walter
description: A Manhattan grand jury has indicted three teenagers in the murder of 23yearold John D. Walter on an IRT train last week.

title: PRICES STILL OFF IN WHEAT FUTURES
description: Wheat, corn and soybean futures prices continued their recent downdrift yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: BONNIE BRAMLETT AT THE BOTTOM LINE
description: Bonnie Bramlett, a singer whose career has been checkered of late, was not completely successful in her Bottom Line club debut on Tuesday. This was a pity, because the appearance was in the nature of a comeback.

title: Business Briefs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 (Reuters)BankAmerica Realty Investors said today that it was in technical default on a $50million term bank loan.

title: REBEKAH AUSLANDER
description: Rebekah Zeltzer Auslander, an Xray technician and a volunteer in the acupuncture clinic at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx, died Tuesday evening, apparently of heart attack, at the home of a sister, Ronya Margulies 91 Payson Avenue. She was 71 years old and lived at 3970 Hillman Avenue, the Bronx.

title: U.S. Confirms Role in Concern Boycotting Banks
description: A Department of Agriculture official said yesterday that the United States was an unwilling partner in the Intra Investment Company of Beirut, Lebanon, which has been boycotting banks that have given economic assistance to Israel.

title: Pie Hit Man Jailed
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 26 (AP)  A University of Minnesota student was pailed on charges of simple assault and breach of the peace after he allegedly tried to hit a woman in the face with a pie. Jeffrey D. Carpenter, 19 years old, of Minnetonka, was believed to be a hit man for Pie Kill, Ltd., whose members can be hired to hit specified persons in the face with pies or squirt them with a seltzer water. The group is patterned after others on the East and West coast. Both charges againset Mr. Carpenter are misdemanors, carrying maximum penalties of 90 days in jail and $300 fines..

title: 'Boss Nigger,' Black Western, Proves a Surprise
description: "Boss Nigger," the black Western that opened in neighborhood houses yesterday, is the kind of unpretentious, ramshackle movie that can be a pleasant surprise if you stumble upon it without warning. To anticipate it with pleasure is to put a hex on it, however. Such anticipation is a burden that movies of this sort immediately collapse under. You've got to discover them yourselves, which means that writing about them becomes a discreet form of public disservice."Boss Nigger" stars Fred Williamson, one of the more popular of the new crop of black actors. He also wrote the screenplay and co-produced the movie with Jack Arnold, who directed it. Unlike most leading actors, black or white, Mr. Williamson seems to possess a genuine sense of humor that hasn't yet been systematizedlike Burt Reynolds'sas part of a public personality. I have no idea whether Mr. Williamson is witty or not, though his movie is.In "Boss Nigger" he plays a bounty hunter who, with his black sidekick (D'Urville Martin), finds he has to take over the law office of a frightened frontier town in order to collect a debt. The West is that timeless West where it's always 1870, but the complications of the plot suggest the kind of West where Roy Rogers used to ride in the nineteen-forties; the villains are immediately identifiable, the heroes incredibly noble as well as bullet-resistant, and coincidence is a fundamental narrative device.The wit of the film is in Mr. Williamson's performance, which is an immensely self-assured parody of the Man With No Name played by Clint Eastwood in Sergio Leone's films. Though the screenplay gives the supposedly comic lines to Mr. Martin, it's Mr. Williamson who is responsible for most of the good humor, ambling through the movie, doing the old Eastwood act of squinting, shooting and being irresistible to women with less effort than it takes most other men to select a tie.Most black Westerns either ignore race or make it the fundamental point of the movie. "Boss Nigger" somehow manages to do both quite successfully. There's a lot made of the bigotry of the small Western town in which the black sheriff operates, but the effect of Mr. Williamson's Eastwoodesque performance has less to do with his color than with details observed and gently sent skyhigh.

title: Troops and Rebels Engage In Heavy Firing in Asmara
description: ADDIS ABABA, Thursday, Feb. 27 (AP)  Heavy rocket and machine  gun fire broke out for an hour last night between secessionist rebels and Government troops camped at the fairgrounds in Asmara, capital of Eritrea province.

title: U.S. Envoy in Phnom Penh Joins Appeal for More Cambodia Aid
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 26The United States Ambassador, John Gunther Dean, today joined the Administration's appeal for more aid for the troubled Cambodian Government.

title: With Book and Bottle, Hasidic Jews. Mark Purim on Israel's Fronts
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 26 Hasidic Jews in black hats, flowing beards and ritual prayer shawls whose fringes reached to their knees swarmed into frontline fortifications and military camps yesterday and today uncorking a thousand bottles of vodka.

title: Schlesinger and Kissinger See Scant Cambodia Hope
Allegheny Ludlum Sets Closing, Of a Plant in Western New York
description: DUNKIRK, N. Y. Feb. 26 (AP) The Allegheny Ludlum Steel; Corporation will suspend operations for two weeks next month in its plant in this city in western New York.

title: New Carpeting Standards Set In F. H. A. Guaranteed Housing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced today that it would begin enforcing minimum performance standards for carpeting in houses purchased with loans guaranteed by the Federal Housing Administration.

title: Jury Completed for Trial In Paterson Priest's Slaying
description: PATERSON, Feb. 26 (UPI) Jury selection was completed today in the trial of the first of three suspects charged in the beating death of a Paterson priest last October.

title: ALBANY APPROVES A BILL TO RESCUE INSOLVENT U.D.C.
Drivers Reinstated
description: Bertram D. Sarafan, chairman of the State Racing and Wagering Board, said yesterday that. the two drivers who had been suspended by Yonkers Raceway for lackluster efforts would be permitted to return to competition immediately. He explained his decision by saying, It is to the best interests of all parties that the two, Buddy Gilmour and David Dunckley, be reinstated.

title: Some Companies Puzzled By Inclusion on Blacklist
description: Initial reactions from American companies named on an Arab blacklist made public in Washington yesterday ranged from puzzlement through resignation to anger.

title: ARABS BLACKLIST DEPLORED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 26 President Ford spoke out today against Arab attempts to discriminate against financial institutions or individuals on religious or ethnic grounds.

title: Police to Alter Report Of GunRelated Crimes
description: Starting Monday, the Police Department will revise its daily reports on gunconnected crimes.

title: BEAME, IN ALBANY, PLEADS FOR HELP
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26  Mayor Beame told restive legislatorsalready grumpy at pressure today from Governor Carey and their leaders to come to the financial aid of the Urban Development Corporationthat they would have to help fill an $883 million gap in New York City's next budget.

title: Marcos Seeking a Big Vote Today
description: MANILA, Feb. 26Although he is the only candidate in the field, President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines is waging a highpowered campaign to win himself a big vote of confidence tomorrow in a referendum that his critics are denouncing as a farce.

title: $365 Stolen During Show At Carnegie Recital Hall
description: The box office of Carnegie Recital Hall was robbed last night by a man who suddenly reached through the ticket window and snatched a bag containing $365 in receipts, then fled.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Dollar Slumps to Another Record Low in Trading in Amsterdam
description: BRUSSELS. Feb. 26 (UPI) The dollar hit its sixth record low in as many trading days in Amsterdam today. On other European money markets, the United States currency also dropped, cancelling the preceding day's rallies and edging toward record lows reached earlier in the week.

title: ROGER M. SMITH, 59; TAUGHT AT JUILLIARD
description: Roger Montgomery Smith principal trombonist of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and a Julliard School faculty member for 28 years, died on Tuesday at the Central General Hospital in Plainview, L.I. He was 59 years old and lived in Hicksville, L. I.

title: Revitalized Rails?
description: The system plan put forward by the United States Railway Association for reorganizing the Penn Central and other bankrupt railroads in the Northeast and Middle West is an impressive document, a thoughtful start on the massive assignment given it by Congress.

title: ALBANY APPROVES A BILL TO RESCUE INSOLVENT U.D.C.
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26  Both houses of the Legislature passed and Governor Carey signed today a bill setting up a new estate agency that could salvage the insolvent Urban Development Corporation if investors now agree to buy the new agency's bonds.

title: Bridge:
description: Those who complain about the proliferation of conventions in tournament play can support their case by pointing to the latest book on the subject, which lists 220. Bridge Conventions Complete is a masterly 624page compilation by Amalya Kearse, one of the country's topranked woman players, and is published here by Hart at $7.95.

title: Chicago's Timid Vote
description: In renominating Mayor Richard J. Daley for an unprecedented sixth term, Chicago Democrats were blindly trying to play safe. The last four years have diminished Mr. Daley's reputation as an effective city administrator and a personally honest political boss. As the city's problems have worsened, several of Mr. Daley's closest political lieutenants have gone to prison for graft, while his own reputation has been damaged by the exposure his flagrant official favoritism toward members of his family.

title: RAYTHEON IN PACT FOR ITE IMPERIAL
Stottlemyre Making His Comeback Pitch
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26For the last decade he was the No. 1 man on the pitching staff of a team whose history has been punctuated with such noted pitchers as Red Ruffing, Lefty Gomez, Vic Raschi and Whitey Ford. Now, in his 12th season, Mel Stottlemyre isn't No. 1; he isn't even No. 2, 3, or 4. He may not even have a number.

title: Chinese Call for Gesture
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Kahane to Begin Serving Year Sentence March 18
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, the head of the Jewish Defense League, was ordered yesterday to surrender to a United States marshall March 18 to start serving a year in jail for violation of his probation.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 President Ford spoke out today against Arab attempts to discriminate against financial institutions or individuals on religious or ethnic grounds.

Tuesday's Fights
description: Miami Beach  James Scott, 176 pounds, Miami, outpointed Jesse Burnett, 176, San Diego, 10 rounds.

Jack Anderson, the Virginia general manager, made the announcement yesterday, but declined to say how much money was involved.

title: PRESIDENT PRODS CONGRESS TO ACT FAST ON TAX GUT
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 26 President Ford said today that at the rate Congress was moving on a tax cut for stimulating the sagging economy it might be June before the legislation reached his desk.

title: BRIDGE AUTHORITY FIGHTS RATE DROP
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 26  The chairman of the Delaware River Port Authority said today that the bistate agency would go all the way to the Supreme Court if necessary to overturn orders from two Federal agencies to roll back rapidtransit fares and bridge tolls between Philadelphia and its New Jersey suburbs,

title: Insensitivity
description: President Ford likes to play golf And South Florida in February is normally much warmer, sunnier, and generally pleasanter than Washington, D. C. Combine these factors and it is not surprising that Mr. Ford played golf yesterday near Miami in a fivesome that included Jackie Gleason and Bob Hope among others.

title: Middleman Charges Continue to Raise Family Grocery Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) Higher middleman charges for food continued to increase family grocery bills last month, although the rate of increase was substantially less than it was a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Nuggets Vanquish Nets By a 148to114 Margin
description: DENVER, Feb. 26  The Denver Nuggets, intent on finishing with the best wonlost record in the American Basketball Association, took another happy step toward the goal tonight by routing the New York Nets, 148114.

title: Oklahoman Calls F.B.I. Role Result of Gov. Hall Bribe Offer
description: OKLAHOMA. CITY, Feb. 26 (UPI)The Secretary of State of Oklahoma, John Rogers, testified today that a $25,000 bribe offer from former Gov. David Hall prompted him to do undercover work for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a briberyextortion case against Governor Hall.

title: Concert
description: Herman Berlinski, appearing in Carnegie Hall's International Organ Series on Tuesday night, used the second half of his program for the premiere of his Sinfonia No. 9, The Glass Bead Game: Magister Ludi. It is an hourlong setting of poems from Hermann Hesse's novel for organ, narrator, contralto, tenor and five percussion players.

title: Bill Asks Curb on Plutonium Use to Prevent Building of Homemade Bomb
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Citing plutonium as a potential source of homemade nuclear bombs, a Wisconsin Representative has introduced legislation that would prohibit the commercial use of the material pending a major new scientific assessment of its risk.

title: NursingHomes Scandal May Cost Touro $450,000
description: A $450,000 contribution to Touro College from a fund with along history of legal strife may be withheld because of a disclosure in recent nursinghome investigations.

title: Contract Award
description: The Donovan Construction Company, a subsidiary of Donovan Companies, Inc., St. Paul. received a $19.5million addition to its existing Army contract to manufacture 155mm projectiles.

title: CAREY VOTING FUNDS IN UPSTATE INQUIRY
description: The St. Lawrence County District Attorney, William Power, said yesterday that his office was looking into the circumstances surrounding a $2,000 political contribution allegedly from Governor Carey's campaign fund.

title: Air France Told to Buy French Craft
description: PARIS, Feb. 26The French Government, the principal stockholders in Air France, has warned the airline's directors to buy French planes, and not American airliners, to replace its aging fleet or they will lose their jobs.

title: Coaching Aide Promoted
description: NACOGDOCHES, Tex., Feb. 26 (AP)Richard Munzinger, defensive line coach at Stephen F. Austin State University the last four seasons, was named athletic director and head football coach today. The 39yearold Munzinger replaces John Levra, who resigned last week to become offensive coordinator at Kansas.

title: Advertising
description: A survey of advertising agencies would seem to indicate that the problem of late payment (accounts receivable) has increased only modestly since the beginning of the year.

title: Army Says Bird Trouble Is at Manageable Level
description: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., Feb. 26 (UPI)An Army spokesman said today that the blackbird population at the Fort Campbell most had been trimmed to a manageable number, and that was still undecided whether there would be another mass killing of the birds.

title: Albany Votes 15c Toll Cut For Southern State Pkwy.
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26  Both houses of the Legislature today unanimously passed a bill that would require the Jones Beach Parkway Authority to roll back the tolls on the Southern State Parkway from the present 25 cents to 10 cents.

title: McCrory Corporation Omits Its First Quarter Dividend
description: The McCrory Corporation, the diversified retail concern which is under the majority control of the RapidAmerican Corporation, said yesterday that its directors voted to omit the regular 30 cents dividend on the common stock for the first quarter due to end April 30. Last November, the company's board also omitted the fourth quarter dividend.

title: Goldman Calls Payoff Charges Untrue
description: Irving Goldman, the city's $1ayear Cultural Affairs Commissioner, said last night that it was untrue that his family's Jola Candy Company had been used to make payoffs to Transit Authority police officials.

title: Times Dividend Is Declared
description: The New York Times Company declared yesterday a regular quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share on its Class A and Class B common stock. The dividend is payable March 26 to shareholders of record March 14. The Times also declared a regular quarterly dividend of $1.375 a share on the 5 per cent cumulative prior preference stock, payable April 1 to shareholders of record March 14.

title: Stock Prices Show a Rise; Dow Gains 8.92 at 728.10
description: The stock market ended its twoday selloff in slower trading yesterday as prices were buoyed by indications that the Federal Reserve Board was again relaxing its monetary policy.

title: Names in the Rail Issue
description: Following are the names and terms used in connection with the Northeastern railroad problem:

title: Daylin in Bankruptcy Step
description: Daylin, Inc., a large West Coastbased retalier, announced, yesterday in Beverly Hills, Calif., that it had filed an arrangement for its unsecured creditors under the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: O'DWYER REJECTS MAYOR ON TUNNEL
description: City Council President Paul O'Dwyer yesterday refused a request by Mayor Beanie to reconsider his abrupt resignation as chairman of a Board of Estimate select committee seeking to resolve a dispute over rising costs of the city's Third Water Tunnel project

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Of Abortion, Manslaughter and the Case of Dr. Edelin

title: The Gallery Is Charitable Toward Ford's Golfing
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26 (UPI)President Ford won the applause and sympathy of a record golf gallery today shooting a 29overpar 100 while two of his partners downed and another, Jack Nicklaus, broke the course record by two strokes in a charity match on the Inverrary Country Club course.

title: Philip Morris Lifts Dividend
description: Philip Morris, Inc., announced yesterday that it was raising its dividend on common stock to 22 cents a share from 20 cents a share. The dividend is payable April 11 to shareholders of record March 17.

title: Cairo Is Proclaiming Optimism On a Sinai Pullback by Israelis
Rail Rescue Funds Cleared by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The Senate interrupted a filibuster today to pass two measures providing emergency aid to bankrupt railroads, mainly the Penn Central and the Erie Lackawanna.

title: Attorney General Set to Testify On Hoover's Files on Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Attorney General Edward H. Levi will tell a Congressional subcommittee tomorrow that J. Edgar Hoover, the late direcfor of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, maintained personal files containing derogatory information on members of Congress, a Justice Department spokesman said tonight.

title: RoundtheClock Job Whips Rain Problem
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., Feb. 25 Rain early this week pelted Mount Tom, which towers over the Connecticut River. Large pools of water had formed at the ski area's base by early afternoon. It certainly was an awful development, said Dave Moore, one of the resort's managers, today. It was like a monsoon. But now that the rain has stopped we'll be back in business tomorrow.

title: Cordero and Martin Ride High at Big A
description: Members of the CorderoMartin Marching and Chowder Society skipped out of AqueductontheSubway yesterday in a happy frame of mind, though only slightly richer. Dissidents in the crowd of 15,920 filed out mumbling about an antitrust suit against the frontrunning jockey and trainer of the new meeting.

title: SHARING OF DATA ON C.I.A. IS SOUGHT
TALKS WITH INDIANS ENDED BY FAIRCHILD
description: SHIPROCK, N. M., Feb. 26 (UPI)Fairchild Camera Company announced today that it would no longer negotiate with 45 Indians occupying the company's Navajo reservation plant and gave them until 6 P.M. Sunday to get out or consider the facility closed indefinitely.

title: Alleghany Ludlum Sets Closing Of a Plant in Western New York
description: DUNKIRK, N. Y., Feb. 26 (AP) The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation will suspend operations for two weeks next month in its plant in this city in western New York.

title: Unwitting Use of a Detective Foils Newark Kidnapping Plot
description: NEWARK, Feb. 26Four Essex County men who allegedly devised a $100,000 kidnapping plot saw the plan collapse almost as soon as it started this morning because they had unwittingly recruited an undercover detective to help carry it out.

title: Guggenheim Series Of Chamber Music Begins With Flair
description: The chamber music series at the Guggenheim Museum, begun with two summer concerts in 1973, was expanded to three in 1974, and this year has settled in for a FebruarytoMay cycle of four. It opened with high panache on Tuesday evening in the museum's auditorium.

title: Commons Votes Raise Of $1Million for Queen
description: LONDON, Feb. 26  The House of Commons today approved Prime Minister Wilson's proposal that Queen Elizabeth be given an extra $1million a year to meet rising costs of maintaining royal palaces, ceremonies and salaries. The vote was 427 to 90.

title: Youth Sets Himself on Fire
description: CLARKSVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 26 (AP)A lovespurned foreign student at Austin Peay State University doused himself with gasoline and set himself on fire early today in from of his girl friehd's dormitory window. Mehran Armin, who is 19 years old, of Tehran, Iran, was in critical condition in the intensive care unit at Vanderbilt Hospital in Nashville with severe burns over most of his body.

title: Article 1  No Title
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Liquidity Ratio Raised to 5%
description: Special to The New York Times

title: TITO DERIDES IDEA OF SOVIET THREAT
ARGENTINE REBELS KIDNAP A U.S. AIDE
description: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 26 (AP)About a dozen persons presumed to be leftist guerrillas kidnapped the United States honorary consul in the industrial city of Crdoba, snatching him from his com. bined home and office tonight.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Canada's Trade Surplus Off
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 26 (AP) Canada's trade surplus last year was $472million, the lowest since 1966 and only one quarter of the surplus in 1973, Statistics Canada has reported. It said the volume of export was down 7 per cent in 1974 while the volume of imports was up 3 per cent.

title: TV: In This House of Brede on CBS
description: In This House of Brede, a twohour GE Theater production beginning at 9 this evening on CBSTV, is based on the bestselling novel by Rumer Godden. And based on is an accurate description for the television script written by James Costigan.

title: Maye Shaw, 51, Secretary Of Bronx School Board 11
description: Maye Levine Shaw, secretary of Community School Board 11 in the Bronx, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. She was 51 years old and lived at 1102 Mace Avenue, the Bronx. Her husband, George, is a businessman.

title: ASSAD DEMANDS UNITY ON ISRAEL
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon., Feb. 26 President Hafez alAssad of Syria said today that there could be no peace in the Middle East unless Israel gave up all of the Golan Heights and all of Sinai and restored the rights of the Palestinians.

title: Onassis Is Improving
description: PARIS, Feb. 26 (Reuters) The codition of Aristotle Onassis, the Greek shipping magnate who underwent an operation Feb. 9 for removal of his gall bladder, is slowly but progressively improving, his doctors said tonight.

title: PRESIDENT PRODS CONGRESS TO ACT FAST ON TAX CUT
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 26 President Ford said today that at the rate Congress was moving on a tax cut for stimulating the sagging economy it might be June before the legislation reached his desk.

title: Son of Elijah Muhammad Succeeds to the Leadership
Coors Told Its Beer Is for Everybody
description: DENVER, Feb. 26 (AP) The Adolph Coors Company has no right to control distribution of its beer once it leaves dealers in the 11state region in which it is distributed, a Federal Court judge ruled yesterday.

title: ROLF J. THAL
description: Rolf J. Thal, executive vice president of the Berol Corporation, dided yesterday in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Danbury.

title: Soviet Trawlers Circle A Gas Rig Off England
description: LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 27 (Reuters)  A British warship was steaming toward a North Sea gas rig today after the rig reported by radio that it was surrounded by Soviet trawlers, the Ministry of Defense said.

title: Several Contractors Pull Men Off U.D.C. Projects
description: Several construction subcontractors working on projects of the financially troubled State Urban Development Corporation pulled their men off the jobs yesterday because of uncertainty about whether the concerns would be paid.

title: Mets Ticket Booth Opens on Saturday
description: The New York Mets Advance Ticket window at Shea Stadium will begin its seven dayaweek operation on Saturday. The booth, located near Gate D, will be open from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. on weekends and from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. during the week.

title: SAVINGS INFLOW ROSE IN JANUARY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) The nation's major home mortgage lenders received a nearrecord infusion of new money in January, but little of it went for home loans, the Government reported today.

title: HARBOR UNIT CITES DECLINE IN CRIME
description: The docks and piers of New York and New Jersey, once described as a jungle of crime and violence and practically a private preserve for criminals and racketeers, have become an area of relative serenity and security, according to the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

title: Taft's Surprise Quintet Aiming for 2d Straight Title
BRITONS GET PLAN FOR MARKET VOTE
description: LONDON, Feb. 26The Government published its proposals today for condudting a referendum on whether Britain should remain in the Common Market.

title: Lisbon Delays Election Drives For New Constituent Assembly
description: LISBON, Feb. 26 (Reuters) The official start of campaigning for April's elections for a constituent assembly has been postponed from next Monday until March 20, the Portuguese Council of State announced tonight.

title: Woman Released in Killibg
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 26(UPI) Joan Little, accused of stabbing to death a county jailer who she said attacked her in her cell, was released on bond today from the women's prison where she had been held since last September.

title: SCHOOLS BOYCOTTED IN MENINGITIS SCARE
description: Pupils at Public School 81 in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn were back in classes yesterday, and health teams were examining the youngsters to ease parents fears that an isolated case of noninfectiousb meningitis at the school would spread.

title: The Kissinger Doctrine
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26When the Soviet Union crushed Dubcek's Czechoslovakia in 1968, it claimed an inherent right of intervention to keep any sister socialist state from slipping out of the Soviet orbit. That was the Brezhnev Doctrine.

title: Stein for Phasing Out ProfitMaking Nursing Homes
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein announced plans yesterday to recommend to the Legislature that profitmaking nursing homes be phased out of New York's healthcare system.

title: The Albanian Solution, or Beating the Pink Slip
description: Any society can have full employment whenever it wants. Even during the worst of depressions. It requires no more than adding up the amount of money available for wages and salaries (about $800 billion) and distributing it among everyone who wants to work. This is what happens in Cuba, China and Albania. But we do things differently.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOUNDS OF YORE In heralding Circa 1900, a new musical program due tomorrow and Sunday, the. Eastern, Opera Theater of New York is stressing the advantages of the early 20thcentury background. It was a time bristling with optimism, when life was simpler, but no less interesting, with new machines like the horseless carriage and aeroplane. Last but not least, in salons, Americans were entertained by the foremost artists of the day, performing the music of an America coming of age.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you are confused by the wording used by some retailers and manufacturers in selling their wares, it isn't surprising. TWo vendors of identical products using the same terminology in their sales promotion and advertising may have sharply different meanings in mind. And some unscrupulous companies deliberately attempt to deceive.

title: COLOMBIA GUNFIGHT INVOLVES U.S. AIDES
A10 SHIFT CUE PERIL TO L.I. JOBS
description: Members of the New York Congressional delegation urged Defense Department yesterday to persuade Fairchild Industries, Inc., which makes the A10 fighterbomber plane for the Air. Force, not to go ahead with its plans to shift the final assembly and testing of the plane from Long Island to Maryland.

title: Revlon Net at Peak in Latest Quarter
2D DIABETES DRUG LINKED TO DEATHS
Official Again Denies C.I.A. Sought to Undermine Allende
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Harry W. Shlaudeman, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs, said today that the United States did not subvert the Chilean Government of Salvador Allende Gossens in 1973.

title: Met, in Crisis, Asks Employes to Accept 10 Per Cent Pay Cut
description: The Metropolitan Opera, in what was called a survival situation, asked its employes yesterday to accept a 10 per cent pay, cut, plus a shorter work year.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Up on the screen, as the videotape was slowed to 1/64th of a second, a 100meter sprinter in the 1972 Olympic Trials was veering inches to his left with every stride. See that, Dr. James A. Nicholas was saying. There's a lack of strength in his left leg that's causing him to veer like that. Eventually that leg broke down on him. In his long white coat, Dr. Nicholas was sitting in a darkened room witth stacks of cassettes and films at the Institute of Sports Medicine and Athletic Trauma on the eighth floor of Lenox Hill Hospita]. What we're doing here, he explained, is finding out why things happen that hurt people in sports. Not just pro sports or amateur sports. All sports for all people. Forget the medical terms. Finding out why things happen that hurt people is the essence of the research that Dr. Nicholas has been conducting for two years. He is a New York orthopedist known primarily for his four operations on the knees of Joe Namath, the New York Jets quarterback. But in his research, Dr. Nicholas is more.concerned with the knees? and elbows and hips and shoulders, of the millions who use sports as a leisuretime activity. He's not alone. There are similar institutes in Los Angeles, Cleveland, Atlanta, Seattle, Toronto and Madison, Wis., along with two others in New York at the Hospital for Special Surgery and St. Luke's Hospital. But in his role as the orthopedic surgeon of the Jets, Knicks and Rangers, he is perhaps the most prominent spokesman of the revolution in sports medicine that eventually will help millions.

title: Fire in Phone Building Disrupts Calls to Police
description: Telephone service was disrupted early this morning throughout lower Manhattan, south of 26th Street, following a threealarm fire in a New York Telephone Company equipment building at 206 Second Avenue, near 13th Street.

title: Schlesinger and Kissinger See Scant Cambodia Hope
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Secretary of Defense James. R. Schlesinger believes that Cambodia will fall Whether or not Congress approves emergency aid.

title: Key Senators Introduce a Bill To Resume Arms Aid to Turks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Senate Democratic and Republican leaders introduced a bill today to lift the military aid embargo against Turkey in an effort to prevent a worsening of TurkishAmerican relations and spur Cyprus negotiations.

title: OPTIMISM GROWS FOR U.S. ARSENAL
description: ROCKAWAY TOWNSHIP, Feb. 26Members of Congress and local officials were optimistic today that Picatinny Arsenal here would be chosen by the Secretary of the Army as the site of an armaments development center, increasing the arsenal's work force by nearly 1,000 during a fiveyear Period.

title: Transcript of President's News Conference on Domestic and Foreign Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Ford's news conference, held in Hollywood, Fla., yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC news:

title: Hatcher Seeks Reelection
description: GARY, Ind., Feb. 26 (UPI)Mayor Richard G. Hatcher said today that he would seek reelection to a third term. Mr. Hatcher, a Democrat, is the first black mayor of Gary, which has a populaton that is more than 50 per cent nonwhite.

title: Bennett Cut in Ring
description: LONDON, Feb. 26 (UPI)Lonnie Bennett, a California lightheavyweight, suffered a cut near his left eye during sparring today in preparation for his world title challenge against Britain's John Conteh at London's Empire Pool on March 11. Bennett was cut while sparring with Billy Knight at the gym where the Los Angeles boxer is training for the World Boxing Council bout.

title: Rubber Workers And Chemical Union Weigh Merger Plan
description: AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 26 (AP) The United Rubber Workers of America and the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union have agreed in principle to merge, subject to approval of their executive boards and members, Peter Bommarito, president of the rubber workers union, said today.

title: WILLIAM YALE
description: William Yale, author of The Near East: A Modern History, a volume in the University of Michigan Press's History of the Modern World series, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack in Derry, N.H. He was 87 years old and lived in Sandown, N.H.

title: A Museum Near Philadelphia seeks to Save Mennonite Heritage
description: SQUDERTON, Pa.  An abandoned little bank, a stack of castoff furniture and cartons of odds and ends may not look like the foundation for a cultural revival. But here in a small town 25 miles north of Philadelphia these things are being transformed into a heritage center for one of America's oldest and least conspicuous communities: the Mennonites of eastern Pennsylvania.

title: HARBOR UNIT CITES DECLINE IN CRIME
description: The docks and, plers of New York and New Jersey, once described as a jungle of crime and violence and practically a private preserve for criminals and racketeers, have become an area of relative serenity and security, according to the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

title: Witness Points Out Attica Defendant
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 26  The state's fourth witness in the first murder trial to stem from the Attica prison rebellion described today in grim detail the scene when inmates first attacked a correction officer who was killed during the uprising of September, 1971.

title: U.S. Names on Arab League's Blacklist
Panovs to Dance Benefit At Garden State Center
description: HOLMDEL, Feb, 26 (UPI)  The former Soviet ballet artists Galina and Valery Panov will perform at the Garden State Arts Center on July 2 in a benefit for the center's cultural fund, it was announced today.

title: Democrats in House and Senate Are Divided Over Energy Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI)  Wide differences in approach, philosophy and timing emerged today between Senate and House panels that are trying to put together a unified Democratic alternative to President Ford's energy plans.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Montserrat Caballe was slightly injured in an automobile accident in Barcelona recently and has had to cancel her appearances at the Metropolitan Opera next week in Manon Lescaut on Tuesday and Saturday, and in I Vespri Siciliani on Thursday. No replacements have been announced yet.

title: Rock Island to Request Help From Congress
description: Directors of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad, at a special meeting in Washington late yesterday, authorized the railroad's president and chief executive officer, John Ingram, to seek meetings today with Congressional leaders in an effort to obtain emergency legislation to help keep the financially troubled line operating.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York City Board of Higher Education volunteered that it had $6.3million in its capital budget it did not need. The announcement was made at hearings of the City Council Finance Committee headed by Matthew J. Troy Jr. The Queens Democrat noted that this was the first time in all the years that he had been attending capital budget hearings that someone came in and said, take it, we don't need The rescindments by City University of New York will eventually result in a reassignment of the money, particularly for projects favored by Councilmen.

title: Ford Yields to Senators, Drops Trade Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)President Ford said late today that he was bowing to objections from Senators Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, and Carl T. Curtis, Republican of Nebraska, and will not nominate Deputy Attorney General Laurence Silberman to be the nation's special trade representative.

title: World Judge Applauds the Movement of U.S. Dogs
description: The movement of your dogs is far superior to those of any place I've judged in the world, said Joe Cartledge, who was here for the recent Westminster show. The Englishman has done his share of judging. At last count, he said, I've had assignments in 24 countries. I work every weekend. In Britain I've judged best in show, all the groups and everybreed inthe terrier group.

title: A Museum Near Philadelphia Seeks to Save Mennonite Heritage
description: SOUDERTON, Pa.  An abandoned little bank, a stack of castoff furniture and cartons of odds and ends may not look like the foundation for a cultural revival. But here in a small town 25 miles north of Philadelphia these things are being transformed into a heritage center for one of America's oldest and least conspicuous communities: the Mennonites of eastern Pennsylvania.

title: Films
description: RUN WILD, RUN FREE (1969; 100 minutes) with John Mills, 12:30 and 3 P.M. Sunday, at Films for Children, Program, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. 8731300.

title: Compromise Sought In Filibuster Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The Senate Democratic leadership and a powerful member of its Southern bloc joined tonight in an effort to forge a compromise revision of the Senate's filibuster rule.

title: Byrne Plans Bill to Speed Environmental Unit Action
description: TRENTON, Feb. 26Governor Byrne said today that, in accordance with a campaign promise he made in 1973, he would seek a law to speed approval of construction projects by the Department of Evironmental Protection.

title: THERAPY IS URGED FOR LEARNING ILLS
description: Specialists in the learning disabilities yesterday emphasized the importance of detecting potential learning problems and beginning appropriate therapy even before the child begins school.

title: A Musical and Other Fun for Children
description: Since writers of children's television programs have demonstrated that a surefire way to hold a child's attention is through songs, live children's theater has followed suit with an increasing emphasis on musicals.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1975

title: 2 Freight Cars Derailed
description: BECKET, Mass., Feb. 26 (AP)  Two freight cars derailed on the Penn Central line from Boston to Albany, blocking freight traffic for several hours until repair crews cleared one track today. No one was injured.

title: Lebanese Killed in Riot
description: SAIDA, Lebanon, Feb. 26 (Reuters)A Lebanese Army corporal was killed and two other soldiers were wounded here today when dynamite was thrown at their jeep during a demonstration that erupted after a Lebanese company was granted exclusive fishing rights off this country's 130mile coastline.

title: Tournament Hopefuls on Garden Bill
description: Four colleges from the Metropolitan area, St. Peter's, Long Island University, Fordham and Manhattan  all hopeful of receiving postseason tournament bidswill present their basketball talents tonight in Madison Square Garden's penultimate doubleheader program.

title: Harry Chapin Brings Songs to Stage
Notes on People
description: A Santa Barbara, Calif., municipal judge put Henry Ford 2d on probation for two years yesterday when he pleaded no contest to a charge of drunken driving. He was fined $375 and given a suspended 35day jail sentence. Mr. Ford was jailed for nearly four hours after he was stopped Saturday night for driving on the wrong side of a suburban street and failed sobriety tests, according to the police. He was back in Detroit on Monday.

title: A Family That Thinks Together Wins Together
description: There are not many coaches who can come home and discuss the mistakes of the previous game with their quarterback, or review strategy for an upcoming contest over the breakfast table. For Dick O'Connell, basketball coach at Rutgers Prep in Somerset, it's an enduring luxury. His son, Rory, is the point guard, or quarterback, for Rutgers Prep, which is enjoying one of its finer seasons. The team has won 19 of its first 24 games.

title: For the Corporate Wives, Help in Adjusting to Moves
CONSTANCE NEALE
description: Constance Judwick Neale, assistant to the president of Silberman's department store in Stamford, Conn., died Tuesday evening in White Plains Hospital. She was 42 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: MILLS IN INSTITUTION TO CURE ALCOHOLISM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (Reuters)Representative Wilbur D, Mills, the former chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Ins entered a Florida institution in an attempt to cure. his alcoholism, a spokesman for his office said today.

title: Ecology Dispute Over South Carolina Plant Nears End
description: HILTON HEAD, S. C., Feb. 21One of the nation's thorniest environmental disputes has approached a climax here as Federal officials held a supposedly final hearing on a proposal to locate a major industrial facility on bucolic Port Royal Sound.

title: Composer of Hair in Premiere of A Mass in Our Time
description: His bony fingers spread on the keys of a Steinway, long legs apart, Galt MacDermot pounded a calypso beat with both heels of his shoes last night on the century old altar of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 73rd Street.

title: Celtics Crush Knicks
Auction Results Reported Of Drilling Rights Off Texas
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 (AP) The Interior Department has turned down high bids totaling $25.9million for drilling rights on 169,781 acres of Gulf of Mexico waterbottom off the Texas coast.

title: Mood in Cairo Pleases U.S.
description: Special to The New York Times

title: A Stoic, Dignified Uncle Tom Is Portrayed on Stage
VALERIE T. WHITNEY
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Feb. 26 (AP)Valerie Timken Whitney, a cultural leader whose TimkenSturgis Foundation gave millions to health research and other works, died Monday at her home here. She was 78 years old.

title: Highlights of the Plan
description: The highlights of the preliminary plan issued yesterday by the United States Railway Association for restructuring Northeastern rail service:

title: Erasing the C in Covert': In omplete Se urity
description: WASHINGTONAt the end of 1974, Congress enacted and President Ford signed into law restrictions on the Central Intelligence Agency's overseas operations that virtually put the C.I.A. out of the business of giving covert political assistance to friendly foreign governments or political groups. The White House did not make an issue of the legislative restrictions, nor did the C.I.A.

title: A Moral Obligation
description: In establishing a new state funding agency to bail out the overextended Urban Development Corporation, but without providing new state funds for either the U.D.C. or the new agency, Governor Carey and the Legislature have circumvented the basic issue raised by the U.D.C.'s threatened bankruptcy. That is the question of the state's readiness to back up with hard cash the moral obligation which was the basis of the public's acceptance of $1.1 billion in U.D.C. bonds, to say nothing $9 billion in similar bonding by other New York State agencies.

title: LiquorSale Curbs Denied
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26 (AP) Proposed regulations to prohibit the advertising of liquor prices and the sale of alcoholic beverages below wholesale cost have been rejected by the state Alcoholic Beverages Control Commission.

title: EXAGENT CLEAR IN A HEROIN CASE
description: Francis E. Waters, the principal Federal narcotics agent in the celebrated French Connection case, was acquitted here last night in Federal District Court of charges of selling heroin.

title: Books of The Times
description: How to Say No to a Rapistand Survive is today's revision of How to Win Friends and Influence People. The problem seems to be shifting from how to get a man to how to get away from him in one piece. As the battle of the sexes approaches a showdown, we may find our legal machinery too coarse for the delicate questions raised by a rape trial. We may need something as sensitive to psychological nuances as the medieval courts of love before we can render the kind of justice a violated woman deserves.

title: A Long Night of Testing
Market Place
description: Shareholders have long been perplexed by the fact that corporations often revise their earnings drastically in the fourth quarter. The most common reason for this is that the auditors make yearend adjustments and tend to look at financial matters more conservatively than management.

title: Kennedy Denounces C.A.B. Moratorium On New Route Competition for Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26In formal instructions from two recent chairmen of the Civil Aeronautics Board about a moratorium, never announced, on new route competition for airlines were denounced today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy as highly irregular and improper.

title: EXIMBANK FINDS U.S. EXPORT DROP
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The ExportImport Bank reported to Congress today that constraints on its lending authority and other factors were beginning to reduce United States companies' export business.

title: People and Business
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, said yesterday that potential control of American businesses by Arab and other foreign inteersts raised chilling prospects.

title: PRICES FOR BONDS CONTINUE TO DROP
ABC URGES DELAY FOR FALL SEASON
description: Frederick S. Pierce, president of ABC Television, yesterday proposed that the three networks delay the start of the fall television season to the end of September, because of programing complications resulting from recent developments in the industry.

title: STATE FINDS COST OF BERGMAN HOME WAS OVERCHARGED
description: The State Health Department ruled yesterday that Bernard Bergman had wrongly inflated the remodeling costs of his Park Crescent Nursing Home by at least $1,977,806.

title: SYRIA IS ACCUSED OF ASSISTING KURDS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 27  A proIraqi publication here has accused Syria of providing military aid and other assistance to the Kurdish insurgents in northern Iraq.

title: New State Warning on Busing Sought
description: William Jovanovich, a leading antibusing member of the state's Board of Regents, said yesterday that he would introduce a new resolution at next month's Regents meeting to require the Commissioner of Education to consider the possible harmful effects of busing in any future integration orders he issue.

title: World Biologists Tighten Rules On Genetic Engineering Work
description: PACIFIC GROVE, Calif., Feb 27An international confer ence of biologists decided today on tighter professional stand ards governing research in so called genetic engineering.

title: S.E.C. Planning New Rules On Variable Life Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it was beginning a new effort to write rules governing variable life insurance.

title: Hayward State Picks Coach
description: HAYWARD, Calif., Feb. 27 (AP)Tim Tierney, a defensive coordinator on the Hayward State College football coaching staff the last four years, was named head coach today.

title: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Station Wagons Shuttle Air Tanks to Firemen
description: A Fire Department shuttle service ferried more than 1,000 tanks of fresh compressed air yesterday from Roosevelt Island to the fire fighters battling flames and toxic smoke at the telephone switching center on East 13th Street.

title: Airlift Goes Smoothly
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb, 27The inaugural flights of an American airlift of rice to Phnom Penh went smoothly today, with three chartered cargo planes making a total of 10 runs from Saigon's Tan Son Nhut air base to the Cambodian capital without mishap.

title: Notes on People
description: He started in 1908 as a 15 yearold office boy, and yesterday, 67 years and 11 district attorneys later, Michael Weiss regretfully retired at 82 as supervisor of the clerical staff at the New York County district attorney's office. He was almost certainly the city's longest employed Civil service worker.

title: WILHELM STYER, GENERAL, 81, DIES
description: CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 27 (AP)Wilhelm D. Styer, a retired lieutenant general who commanded the United States Army in the Western Pacific in World War II, died yesterday at the age of 81.

title: Town Suspends Tax After Crop Comes In
description: AUGUSTA, Mo., Feb. 26 Melvin Fuhr, blond and stocky in a bright yellow shirt and white butcher's apron, leaned across the meat counter in his general store here and shook his head wonderingly. It ain't Augusta Where? any more, he mused. It's that little town that ain't got no taxes. Actually, it wasn't that big of a thing.

title: Rockefeller Doubts Role As Contender in 76 or'80
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Vice President Rockefeller, in a relaxed chat with reporters in his airplane early this morning, described himself as no longer a contending factor on the Republican Presidential scene.

title: Bulls Down Hawks for 8th in Row
FASHION TALK
description: Marc Bohan's seasonal arrival at Saks Fifth Avenue with the Christian Dior readytowear collection he designs is becoming a tradition. By Bohan time, it's already spring.

title: Ishimatsu Outpoints Buchanan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 27 (AP) Guts Ishimatsu of Japan retained his World Boxing Council lightweight title tonight with a unanimous decision over Ken Buchanan of Scotland.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Nepal Coronation Lured the World's Partygoers  Invited or Not
Mets Meet With Berra, Go to Work
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27Yogi Berra faced 42 men in the uniform of the New York Mets today, addressed his massed troops for the first time in five months, told them the curfew was midnight, that the goal was to win the Eastern title of the National League, and then announced with all the logic of Casey Stengel: I got nine outfielders.

title: February TradeOffs
description: Doubledigit inflation seems to be dead and, for now at least, gone in the United States. But doubledigit unemployment may be the price of that victory. This is a view with wide acceptance among economic analysts.

title: Moscow Arrests Author Who Tried To Emigrate to U.S.
F.C.C. TO APPROVE PHONERATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The Federal Communications Commission said today that it would approve a $365million annual rate increase for interstate service by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and indicated that it would consider another increase later.

title: Indians Refuse Work Offered by Ehrlichman
description: SAN JUAN PUEBLO, N.M., Feb. 27 (AP)The New Mexico Indian pueblos where John D. Ehrlichman said he wouId be working while appealing his Watergate coverup conviction don't want him.

title: Denver Official Named
description: DENVER, Feb. 27 (AP)John Henry, an aide to Mayor William McNichols of Denver, has been named vice president of the Denver Spurs of the Central Hockey League. The appointment is effective April 1.

title: HERSTATT CREDITORS AGREE WITH CHASE
description: A spokesman for the Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday it had reached a provisional agreement with certain creditors of the failed Bankhaus id Herstatt, covering Herstatt funds held in New York.

title: Pope Vetoes Jesuits Reforms And Curbs Order's Publications
description: ROME, Feb. 27Pope Paul VI has reasserted his control of the Society of Jesus, the Roman Catholic Church's strongest and most influential religious order, by vetoing proposed reforms and curbing publication of Jesuit documents.

title: AMEX PRICES UP IN SLOW TRADING
Restaurant Reviews
description: Getting right down to basics to begin with, let's say that Scoop, a twoyearold Northern Italian restaurant at 210 East 43d Street, between Second and Third Avenues, is heartily recommended for a visit. The food is good to excellent, the service is efficient and friendly, the general air of the place is bright, even festive, and the prices aren't all that high as prices go in good midtown New York restaurants with a la carte menus

title: Profit on Nursing Homes Tops 50% in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 27Almost half of Connecticut's proprietary nursing homes make profits of 50 per cent or more a year, according to figures submitted today to a special investigating committee of the General Assembly.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (Reuters)The composite index of leading indicators fell for the sixth consecutive month in January, dropping 1.3 per cent following an upward revised decline of 3.1 per cent in December, the Commerce Department said today.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO CUT TAXES $21.3B1LLION AND AMEND OIL DEPLETION ALLOWANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The House of Representatives passed today a $21.3billion antirecession tax cut bill that included the repeal of the controversial oil depletion allowance that has been part of the tax law for nearly 50 years.

title: OTB Hialeah Bets Face Threat
description: A crippled Offtrack Betting Corporation will attempt to get away from the starting gate today when It hopes to take bets on its separate pool of the Flamingo, which will be run tomorrow at Hialeah.

title: Faisal, in Price Rift, Will Shun Oil Talks
description: VIENNA, Feb. 27King Faisal of Saudi Arabia has advised Algeria that he will not attend a meeting of chiefs of state of oil exporting countries next month. The main reason is it was said here was a refusal of other countries to reduce oil prices.

title: Big Year Seen for Roadside Markets
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK, Feb. 27Experts meeting here today at the seventh annual New Jersey Roadside Market Conference predicted that 1975 would be a banner year for the operators of the state's $20millionayear roadside market business.

title: DOW STOCK INDEX GAINS 3.05 POINTS
description: The stock market made a moderate advance yesterday in diminished trading despite some unfavorable economic developments.

title: Elevator Bandit Gets 1020 Years As Judge Agreed
description: Arthur Williams, the elevator bandit in doorman's uniform, who had switched his plea to guilty in 84 robberies in East and West Side apartment houses, received yesterday the sentence of 10 to 20 years that State Supreme Court Justice James J. Leff had promised him. But the prosecution felt it was not enough.

title: PENTAGON STUDIES NORTHEAST ASIA
description: Northeastern Asia, where the Interests of four great powers converge in the area around the Sea of Japan, is receiving increased attention from the Defense Department.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: GEORGETOWN, S. C.It was late afternoon and a light rain was falling as we paddled out into a lake and cypress swamp in South Carolina's Santee Coastal Reserve.

title: Jerome S. Meyer, 80, Wrote On Science, Games, Math
description: Jerome S. Meyer, who wrote more than 50 books for adults and children on subjects that ranged from science to games and entertainment, died Wednesday at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived here.

title: Jersey Approves Subsidy To Keep Buses Operating
Helicopter Pilot Is Injured in Crash at East River Pad at 34th Street
description: A pilot was severely burned yesterday when the rented Bell47 helicopter he was operating crashed into a steel fence on its approach to the helipad at 34th Street and the East River.

title: State's Jobless Rate Soars; Highest Since Depression
U.D.G. Employes Brace For Word of Dismissals
description: It will be difficult to sleep tonight. Ralph Acquavella, a 40yearoki architect with the Urban Development Corporation, said yesterday as he discussed the sharp staff reduction planned for the financially stricken state agency.

title: Jaworski Praises Americans Action In Watergate Case
China Cancels 2d Large Order Of U.S. Wheat for 75 Delivery
RailReorganization Plan Gets Favorable Response
description: The Federal Government's sweeping plan to reorganize the bankrupt Northeast railroads, made public Wednesday in Washington, drew favorable responses yesterday from two key transporatation officials and a flood of questions on how various communities would be affected.

title: WrongWay Richardson
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Elliot Richardson of Massachusetts is now on his way to London. by way of the Bahamas, to be the American Ambassador to the Court of St. James. In many ways, he is the most interesting figure on the American political scene today, maybe better qualified to be President in the last years of the seventies than most candidates now in the race, but obviously not even in the running.

title: Soviet Trawlers Frighten North Sea GasRig Crew
description: LONDON, Feb. 27 (Reuters)  Soviet trawlers that surrounded a North Sea gas rig caused a scare today, but when a British warship arrived the trawlers had disappeared.

title: Emergency Rail Aid Given House Approval
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI)The House gave final Congressional approval today to a measure providing $125million in emergency aid to bankrupt Northeast railroads.

title: Manhattan Beats Fordham, 8175
Kidnappers Seize Berlin Candidate
description: BERLIN, Feb. 27The Christian Democratic candidate for Mayor of West Berlin was kidnapped by at least three persons today, just three days before the election, as he was being driven to his office.

title: ANNE REID OBER
description: Anne Reid Ober, widow of Harold Ober, who founded the New York literary agency that bears his name, died Wednesday at the Sleepy Hollow Co'nvalescent Home in Falls Church, Va. Her age was 85.

title: Schlesinger Terms Cambodia Situation Grim, Not Hopeless
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the situation in Cambodia was grim, but not irretrievable if the United States were to provide additional military aid.

title: BAN ON EXCITIZENS ASSAILED BY A.C.L.U.
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 27  The American Civil Liberties Union charged today that thousands of United States draft resisters who had become nationals of other countries were being denied reentry to this country under a littleused section of the immigration laws.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO CUT TAXES $21.3B1LLION AND ALSO END OIL DEPLETION ALLOWANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The House of Representatives passed today a $21.3billion antirecession tax cut bill that included the repeal of the controversial oil depletion allowance that has been part of the tax law for nearly 50 years.

title: 10,000 Construction Workers Block Traffic Near City Hall in Job Protest
description: About 10,000 construction workers protesting the loss of lobs, surrounded City Hall for five hours yesterday, stopped traffic on the Brooklyn Bridge for three hours during the morning rush and intermittently clashed with the 600 policemen called out to keep them in check.

title: TV: Watching Watchers of Bread & Butterflies
description: Sometimes in the business of trying to comprehend television it can be of considerable value to watch the audience that is watching the program in question. That rare opportunity was provided yesterday morning by a number of individuals and groups involved in the presentation of Bread & Butterflies, a new series of 15 educational quarterhours being carried, at various times on various days, by Channels 13, 25 and 21 in the metropolitan area.

title: AIRLINE PROPOSES NOFRILL SERVICE
description: National Airlines sought Government approval yesterday to introduce a new no frills passenger service with a cutrate fare in separate cabin with a 25cent charge for coffee, tea or milk, and bringyourown meal service. On some routes, the tares would be lower than those on buses and trains.

title: Holmes Memorabiliathe Flotsam of an Olympianon Display at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, MassThe display cases celebrating Mr. Justice Holmes are moored like fragile vessels in the ambient sea of the Harvard law school library.

title: U.S.Consul's Kidnappers Set Demands in Argentina
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, Feb. 27 (AP)Leftist guerrillas who last night kidnapped the United States honorary consul here, John Patrick Egan, said today that they would kill him if the authorities did not announce the whereabouts of four captured guerrillas by tomorrow evening, according to a message delivered to newsmen.

title: Backers of Legal Directory Sue A.B.A.
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 27  Two consumer groups filed suit in Federal District Court in Richmond today to force the American Bar Association to let them publish a community directory of lawyers that would list their specialties and their average fees.

title: Diverse Group Advocates Economic Planning for U.S.
description: Aroused by public policies that have generated heightened inflation and a deepening recession, a group of 11 leading businessmen, academicians and labor leaders today called for a national commitment to economic planning in the United States.

title: Ozone Depletion Seen as a War Tool
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27Not only the fluorocarbons used as propellants on spray cans, but a variety of other manmade substances as well may be endangering the protective layer of atmospheric ozone, a Federal panel was told today.

title: F.C.C. TO APPROVE PHONERATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The Federal Communications Commission said today that it would approve a $365million annual rate increase for interstate service by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and indicated that it would consider another increase later.

title: Street Gang Chiefs Said to Be Recruiting Juvenile Assassins
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP)A growing trend in which street gang leaders recruit juveniles as hit men is spawning a new type of gang warfare, the police and prosecutors here say.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP)The University of Tampa's board of directors voted 169 today to drop football immediately, cancelling the 1975 season. The finance committee voted two weeks ago to kill the sport after the 1975 season because of heavy debts and the threat from the National Football League team beginning in Tampa in 1976. But the full board decided in a lengthy meeting to stop the program immediately.

title: Black Muslim
description: Anyone looking for a modern example of a religion of the oppressed need look no further in this country than the Nation of Islam, the Black Muslims. As Prof. C. Eric Lincoln, historian of the Black Muslims, has noted, they represent that segMent of the black subculture who, being most deprived of traditional incentives, have finally turned to search for alternatives outside the commonly accepted value. structure. Much in this alternative religious systemespecially the racism and authoritarianism of Black Muslim doctrineis abhorrent to the overwhelming majority of Americans of all colors and races; yet the positive aspect of the Black Muslim movement, the success it has had in rehabilitating and inspiring thousands of once defeated and despairing men and women, suggests a need for deeper popular understanding.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Lower in January
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The United States foreigntrade deficit declined in January as a further rise in exports helped to offset yet another increase in the cost of imported oil

title: Elder Statesman Delaney Keeps the Party AliveO
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27It is 8:30 on a Friday evening at the Charcoal Grill in Long Island City, and Bob Caniano, the bartender, breaks into an impromptu soft shoe. Congressman Jim Delaney looks up from his bluefish platter, hoists a martini and sings in a voice rich with enthusiasm, to the tune of Cockles and Mussels.

title: 22 Million Vote on Mandate for Marcos
description: MANILA. Feb. 27At least 2 million Filipinos voted today in a referendum called by President Ferdinand E. Marcos to seek a new mandate for his martiallaw powers.

title: MOSCOW CRITICIZES CHINA IN U.N. DEBATE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 27The Soviet Union accused China today of exacerbating the crisis in Cyprus and the Middle East in the wild hope that the Soviet Union and the United States would be drawn into nuclear warfare and destroy each other.

title: Hunter, Lehman Triumph
description: Topseeded and defending champion Lehman College advanced to the semifinals of the 11th annual City University of New York basketball tournament at Brooklyn College yesterday with an 8564 victory over Baruch College. Hunter, City and Queens Colleges also gained semifinal berths.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES REGISTER DECLINE
description: The general price decline of grains and soybeans continued yesterday for the fifth day on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Schlesinger Terms Cambodia Situation Grim, Not Hopeless
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the situation in Cambodia was grim, but not irretrievable if the United States were to provide additional military aid.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1975

title: ROY SPECTOR
description: Roy Spector, vice president of the Equity Advertising Agency, Inc., died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived here.

title: Scott Easy Victor In Court Tennis
description: Gene Scott, the defending champion, advanced to the quarterfinal round of the United States amateur court tennis championship yesterday, defeating Roger Tuckerman, 63, 62, 61, at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club. Both are from New York.

title: 3 Prisoners Escape From Court Here
description: Three prisoners escaped from the Civil Court Building in lower Manhattan around noon yesterday after overpowering their escorting guard on a freight elevator, unlocking their handcuffs, and fleeing through the building to the streets.

title: FIRE SILENCES 170,000 TELEPHONES, DISRUPTING LIFE IN 300BLOCK AREA OF MANHATTAN BELOW 23D STREET
description: Service on 170,000 telephones was cut off yesterday, creating turmoil in a large area of Manhattan south of 23d Street as a fire blazed out of control for more than 15 hours at a New York Telephone Company switching center.

title: Commissioner's Lament
description: There is no valid reason for Corrections Commissioner Benjamin Malcolm's cry of anguish at Federal District Judge Morris Lasker's order that the Rikers Island jail must conform to the Constitution. The ruling that those prisoners transferred to Rikers Island from the Tombs were still entitled to the rights they had before the Tombs was closed makes sense. And so do the rightssuch as the right to have substantially more recreation time than the very limited amount the prisoners were being granted, more time out of their cells and the right to have contact with their visitors.

title: Arab Blacklist
description: The pressures being exerted by Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other Arab states on American firms to try to make them exclude socalled Jewish houses from financial syndicates and the threats to blacklist those who do not cut off their commercial relations with Israel are in sharp conflict with United States tradition and United States law.

title: ADM. F. E. HAEBERLE, LED NAVY YARD HERE
description: CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 27 (AP)Rear Adm. Frederick E. Haeberle U.S.N., retired, head of the design and construction branches of the Bureau of Ships in World War II, died Monday at the age of 81.

title: AMERICAN SMELTING CUTS BISMUTH PRICE
description: A decrease of $1.50 a pound in its price of bismuth, effective immediately, has been announced by American Smelting and Refining Company, al eading producer of nonferrous metals.

title: Dean Gets $11,000 For Three Speeches At Colleges Here
description: After three somewhat contentious but remunerative speaking engagements in and around New York City, John W Dean 3d, a Watergate conspirator, checked out of the Warwick Hotel yesterday and headed for Kutztown, Pa.

title: Musicians Union Suspends Met Talks
description: Max Arons, president of the American Federation of Musicians Local 802, said yesterday that the. Metropolitan Opera orchestra had suspended collective bargaining with the Met.

title: Gurney Trial Lists Official Of H.U.D. as Coconspirator
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 27 (UPI) Court reocrds confirmed today that E. Lamar Seals Jr., regional director of Housing and Urban Development in Atlanta, and two other men had been named unindicted coconspirators in the briberyconspiracy trial of former Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Floridua, and four codefendants.

title: LABOR HEADS HERE ASK DUAL JOB PUSH
description: New York labor leaders, appalled by the high unemployment in the city and the state, called yesterday for both local and national steps to set up more jobs and to aid the victims of the deepening recession.

title: U.S. JETS. IN THE AIR IN KOREAN INCIDENT
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 27 (AP)  Four United States warplanes took to the air last night during a tense situation involving North and South Korean fighters and a sea chase south of the demarcation line, United States officials said today.

title: Bank Sets Venezuela Fund
description: Special to The New York Times

title: State Jobless Rate Soars To Peak Since Depression
description: The unemployment rate soared to 9.3 per cent in the state in January, the highest level since the Depression, and to 10.6 per cent in the city, higher than in any other big city in the country except Detroit, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Why the U.D.C. Must Not Die

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger told a House Appropriations subcommittee yesterday that the situation in Cambodia was grim, but not irretrievable if the United States were to provide additional military aid. He said he did not believe, as reported in yesterday's editions of The New York Times, that the Cambodian Government would fall, whether or not the United States provided the emergency military aid requested by the Ford Administration. [Page 1, Column 2.]

title: Cambodia:
description: OXFORD, EnglandNearly five disastrous years ago, as he invaded Cambodia, Richard M. Nixon exulted that time is no longer on the side of the Communists.

title: About New York
description: William Dedych tried to sleep through it, and so did Joseph Skorupa. Mr. and Mrs. Andino Acevevo went up on the roof, looked around, and then went back to bed again. Mrs. Merle Becker went from house to house, knocking on doors, and worrying about the old people. She would get them out of their apartments and out on the street, she said, but then they would go home again. The people on East 13th Street tried not to let a fire get in their way.

title: Another Robbery, Last September, Laid to Kallinger Boy in Harrisburg
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 27Richard Guida, deputy district attorney of Dauphin County, said today that the 13yearold son of Joseph Kallinger had been charged with forcibly entering the home of Dr. and Mrs. Herman Rifkin in suburban Harrisburg and removing $6,195 worth of jewelry, cameras and coins last Sept. 2.

title: BLACKS IN CONGRESS STRESS JOBS NEED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)  Strict gun control, fuel subsidies for needy families and close scrutiny of Central Intelligence Agency and Federal Bureau of Investigation surveillance activities are among the goals of the Congressional Black Caucus announced today.

title: Rockefeller Doubts Role As Contender in 76 or 80
