description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Vice President Rockefeller, in a relaxed chat with reporters in his airplane early this morning, described himself as no longer a contending factor on the Republican Presidential scene.

title: CAREY RESTORES ACADEMY FUNDS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27For the second time since he announced his austerity drive, Governor Carey retreated from a proposed budget cut today, restoring state aid for an academy that trains volunteer firemen.

title: People in Sports
description: Tom Nissalke, dismissed as head coach of the San Antonio Spurs on Dec. 13. after openly exchanging criticisms with the management, has won an undisclosed settlement from the American Basketball Association club. Hired as head coach at Utah on Feb. 11, Nissalke will be looking for another victory over his former team tonight when the Stars visit San Antonio for their first game against the Spurs since he took over. However, both parties have indicated happiness with the settlement.

title: City's 5 District Attorneys Vow Fight on Illegal Guns
description: The city's five District Attorneys yesterday pledged a concerted drive against sellers of illegal guns, promised to seek severe jail sentences for those convicted on gun charges and called on the Legislature and judicial system to aid in an attack on the illegal possession and use of firearms in the city.

title: Kidnappers Seize Berlin Candidate
description: BERLIN, Feb. 27The Christian Democratic candidate for Mayor of West Berlin was kidnapped by at least three persons today, just three days before the election, as he was being driven to his office.

title: LOUIS ATKIN
description: Louis Atkin, a jewelry manufacturer here, president of Lou Atkin Casting, Inc., died Wednesday of cancer at his home on Steven Road in Bald win, L. I. He was 71 years old.

title: Elder Statesman Delaney Keeps the Party AliveO
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27It is 8:30 on a Friday evening at the Charcoal Grill in Long Island City, and Bob Caniano, the bartender, breaks into an impromptu soft shoe. Congressman Jim Delaney looks up from his bluefish platter, hoists a martini and sings in a voice rich with enthusiasm, to the tune of Cockles and Mussels.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Books of The Times
description: The Last Testament of Lucky Luciano is the nursinghome scandal of booksan enterprise with a surface look of respectability (a reputable author and a respectable publisher), with all sorts of dirt in its interior (it's a history of American racketeers), and with hints of skulduggery swirling in the background

title: John Brooks Elected Head of Authors Guild
description: John Brooks, author of The GoGo Years and other books on business, was elected yesterday as president of the Authors Guild, a national organization of some 4,000 writers. The election took place at the guild's annual meeting, in the St. Moritz Hotel.

title: LABOR HEADS HERE ASK DUAL JOB PUSH
description: New York labor leaders, appalled by the high unemployment in the city and the state, called yesterday for both local and national steps to set up more jobs and to aid the victims of the deepening recession.

title: Mobile Phone Stations Help Businesses Adapt
description: For residents and businesses in the 300 blocks or more left without telephones by yesterday's fire, there was a scramble through the day for alternative means of communication.

title: U.S. Widens Inquiry in Arab Boycott
description: WASHLNGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) Assistant Treasury Secretary Gerald Parsky said today that United States companies that cooperated with the Arab boycott against Israel might be subject to legal action if their compliance was based on religious or ethnic discrimination.

title: Brewery Worker Winner Of $250,000 in the Lottery
description: WAYNE, Feb. 27 (AP)A 49yearold brewery worker from South Plainfield won the top prize of $250,000 today in the weekly Jersey Jackpot drawing.

title: DEALERS HALTING U.D.C. BOND SALES
description: Leading municipalbond dealers on Wall Street have quietly suspended trading in bonds of the Urban Development Corporation, industry officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Cancer Institute Chief Cautions On the Use of Birth Control Pill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  The socalled morning after birth control pill called DES should be banned if unnecessary use of it cannot be curbed, the director of the National Cancer Institute testified today.

title: ATTICA WITNESS HAS SOME DOUBTS
description: A report prepared by two state investigators in 1971 says that Correction Officer Donald Melven, now a key prosecution witness in the first murder trial to stem from the Attica prison rebellion, once retracted his identification of a defendant in the case.

title: RAY DENIED PLEA FOR A NEW TRIAL
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 27A Federal judge today criticized James Earl Ray's attorneys and state officials involved in his case but ruled that the confessed assassin had clearly and deliberately elected to plead guilty to murder and was not entitled to withdraw that plea and have a new trial.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A surcharge granted the South Jersey Gas Company late last year to allow for additional gas purchases has been rescinded by the Public Utilities Commission, effective today. The surcharge had been expected to last through May and raise the average residential customer's monthly electric bill by $11. But the P.U.C. decision means the surcharge was in effect for February only.

title: President Names Dent Top Trade Negotiator
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 President Ford named Secretary of Commerce Frederick B. Dent today to the post of the President's Special Representative for Trade Negotiations.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NO STRINGS Sally's, in the Sheraton Hotel on Seventh Avenue at 55th Street, Is a bistro where you can sit and sip or stand at the brightly lighted bar, take your time and hear music by a young sextet called the New Wave. It won't cost an arm or a leg. Basic drinks are $1.75 to $1.95. There's no minimum or cover charge, and the place has a turnofthecentury dcor.

title: Jersey Provides $26Million To Keep 14 Bus Lines Running
description: TRENTON, Feb. 27  The State Senate and the Assembly overwhelmingly approved today a measure designed to provide emergency subsidies to prevent the suspension of services Saturday by as many as 14 New Jersey bus companies.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 50%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $876million, up 5 per cent from last year's $832 million. Total retail store sales were about $10.48billion, up 5 per cent from last year's $9.97billion.

title: Chrysler Will Open All Units; G. M. Plans Additional Layoffs
description: DETROIT, Feb. 27  The Chrysler Corporation will have all its United States assembly plants open next week for the first time in four months, but the General Motors Corporation announced today its layoff total would climb by another 26,345 workers.

title: About Real Estate
description: The 32yearold president of Diego International, Inc., his wavy black hair flowing to his shoulders, looks out on Madison Square Park from a small fifthfloor office, only a block away from plastic dolls.

title: Democrats Support Plan To End Investigation Unit
description: TRENTON, Feb. 27Governor Byrne's apparent determination to abolish the State CommiSsion of Investigation was supported today by the leadership of the overwhelming Democratic majorities in the Legislature and condemned by the Republican minorities.

title: Pilots in Cambodia Airlift Ordered to Remain Silent
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 27The United States Embassy and Cambodian Government opened the military air port here to newsmen today to allow them to observe the formal beginning of the expanded supply airlift to this isolated city, but the Americans flying the cargo pianes in and the United States Air Force men who come in from Thailand to direct the landings refused to discuss their mission. They said they were under orders to stay silent.

title: Bronx Hurler Making Pitch for Yankees
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 27Gene McElwain and Jim (Catfish) Hunter have three things in commonthey're both pitchers, they have mustaches and they're in their first Yankee spring training camp. After that, the similarity fades.

title: Flyers Defeat Canucks
DOLLAR PLUNGES IN VALUE ABROAD
description: PARIS, Feb. 27The dollar fell today to a new low against the Swiss franc and to the lowest levels since 1973 against the West German mark and the French franc, despite support buying by authorities in West Germany, Switzerland, France and the United States.

title: Mobile Phone Stations Help Businesses Adapt
description: For residents and businesses in the 300 blocks or more left without telephones by yesterday's fire, there was a scramble through the day for alternative means of communication.

title: BOSTON SCHOOL UNIT ACCUSED OF GRAFT
description: BOSTON, Feb. 27 (AP)The Boston School Committee is politically dominated system of patronage and nobid contracts that is lowering the quality of education and should be abolished, according to a report released today by the Boston Finance Commission.

title: Music: Rare Guarneri
description: If the Guarneri Quartet was celebrating Wednesday night an anniversary that is, by tradition, tinny, its performances were pure gold. The occasion was the second in its series of five programs at Alice Tully Hall observing its 10 years of existence. It was the concert that came nearest to the date, Feb. 28, when the quartet made its New York debut in 1965 at the New School: It became something special, since the Guarneri Quartet must be as good as any quartet playing today.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: It was crazy enough that Matt, the 16yearold son of a police officer, would break into that fried chicken store at all. But the way he did it was especially hard to believe.

title: People and Business
description: Albert Rees, the director of the Administration's Council on Wage and Price Stability, said yesterday that the present economic slackness will n.ersist for some time in the treat majority of industries despite an expected recovery in the latter half of the year.

title: STATE FINDS COST OF BERGMAN HOME WAS OVERCHARGED
description: The State Health Department ruled yesterday that Bernard Bergman had wrongly inflated the remodeling costs of his Park Crescent Nursing Home by at least $1,977,806.

title: Pepsico, Inc., Raises Profit for Quarter and Year
Turtle Growing Fat on Fish
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (UPI)One of the leatherback turtles being raised at the Miami Seaquarium, in cooperation with the State Natural Resources Department, gained nine pounds in one month, an increase of 150 per centon a diet of jellyfish.

title: Republic New York Plans to Buy A merswiss, Franklin Subsidiary
description: The Republic New York Corporation, the holding company for the Republic National Bank of New York and the Kings Lafayette Bank of Brooklyn, announced yesterday an agreement in principle to acquire the American Swiss Credit Company, Ltd., for cash and notes approximating $33.5million.

title: The Screen
Metropolitan Briefs
description: Richard Guida, deputy district attorney of Dauphin County, Pa., said that Michael Kallinger the 13yearold son of Joseph Kallinger, had been charged with forcibly entering the home of Dr. and Mrs. Herman Rifkin in suburban Harrisburg and removing $6,195 worth of jewelry, cameras and coins last Sept. 2.

title: How to Kayo The Energy Crisis In the Back Yard
description: WASHINGTONAlcohol (ethyl or methyl) is an efficient clean fuel. It can be produced from any plant or plant residuecorn stubble and grain for example. It can be produced from paper or trash or it can be easily synthesized. It can be burned in an automobile engine with very little change to the car engine.

title: Carey Aides Continue to Press Banks To Help Revive Development Agency
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27Declaring that he stood ready to consider any offer from the banking community, Governor Carey today had his chief aides working to get the banks to change their position and cooperate with his plan for reviving the Urban Development Corporation.

title: Yifter Adds Glitter, Enigma to A. A.U. Field
description: Filbert Bayi will run the final mile on his American tour tonight at Madison Square Garden before shipping his 25 new record albums, a jazzy Westernstyle outfit and assorted trophies; watches and subfourminute headlines back to Tanzania.

title: PLAN DESCRIBED TO MURDER JURY
description: PATERSON, Feb. 27The alleged confession of a man accused of murdering a 79yearold Roman Catholic priest last Oct. 29 will be introduced at his trial, a jury in Passaic County Court was told today.

title: Bridge:
description: The first major tournament of the year in the metropolitan area, the Greater New York Sectional, begins today at the New York Hilton Hotel. The schedule is as follows:

title: Before Chemical Took Over Security: Expansion, Ineptitude and Loan Losses
Adult Liability
description: Entirely consistent with its holding last month that children, too, are entitled to the benefits of fair justice, the Supreme Court has now ruled that school board members are not immune from liability for damages when students constitutional rights are violated by school authorities. Once again the Court, by a narrow majority of 5 to 4, has advanced the principle that children, too, live under the shelter of due process that routinely protects adults.

title: The Pop Life
description: Any popmusic enthusiast who hadn't heard the Average White Band's Atlantic album or the single Pick Up the Pieceswhich would be unlikely, since both are or have very recently been No. 1 on the sales chartswould be amazed at how black the band sounds. But if he then went to Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night for the six musicians forthcoming concert, he would see that they were just as white as their name suggests.

title: Article 2  No Title
Santa Anita 42, Play on Confined Japanese
Cambodian Climax
description: Cynical exercise of realpolitik, in blatant disregard of human suffering, is conveyed In the Ford Administration's stance toward what are now generally regarded as the final weeks of President Lon Noles illstarred rule over Cambodia.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Barely four weeks before the deadline for adopting a new state budget, the Republicans are adamant against enacting any of Governor Carey's $806million proposed tax increase and say they plan to make deep cuts in the Governor's spending proposals.

title: Cordero Rides Five Winners
description: Angel Cordero rode five more winners at Aqueduct yesterday, and if he were a baseball player instead of a horserider his batting average would be pushing the 500 mark.

title: Compromise on Filibuster Rule Seems Likely in Senate Today
Paris Bank Robbers Flee With Ransom, Free Women
description: PARIS, Friday, Feb. 28 (Reuters)Three women hostages were freed early today after being held for more than 12 hours by bank robbers.

title: Daylin, Big West Coast Retailer, Files a Petition for Bankruptcy
description: In the secondlargest retailing bankruptcy in less than a year, Daylin, Inc., a major West Coastbased retailer, filed yesterday a voluntary petition under the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Wednesday's Fight
description: By The Associated Press

title: The Wreck of Old 144
description: The Government has just proposed a sweeping reorganization of the Northeast railroads, mostly to retain and expand freight service but also to provide docent passenger service in the vast parallelogram with its corners at St. Louis, Chicago, Washington and Boston. Sadly illustrating the need is the demise at the end of February of the once great Bay State, old Number 144, that used to travel the preferred route from New York up through Hartford, Springfield and Worcester to Boston.

title: Faculty Senate at City College Refuses to Censure a Professor
description: The faculty senate of City College yesterday rejected a resolution calling for charges of unbecoming conduct to be brought against a history professor accused of making continuing unsubstantiated attacks on his colleagues.

title: Church Says Colby Is Lifting Secrecy for C.I.A. Inquiry
World Biologists Tighten Rules On Genetic Engineering Work
description: PACIFIC GROVE, Calif., Feb. 27An international conference of biologists decided today on tighter professional standards governing research in socalled genetic engineering.

title: 74 Verdict Against A.&P. Is Upheld by Federal Judge
description: A Federal judge in San Francisco yesterday upheld a $32.7 million trebledamage antitrust verdict awarded last year by a Federal grand jury to six cattlemen against the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company on charges that A. & P. had conspired to fix beef prices.

title: Democrats Fashion An Energy Package
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  Driving hard to unify their ranks for a showdown with President Ford over energy policy, Congressional Democrats fashioned today a package of measures that would have little effect on oil imports this year.

title: Radio
description: 6.7 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Flute Concerto, Hoff. meister; Symphony No. 8, Bee. thoven.

title: E.C.A.C. Meets With Syracuse
description: Robert M. (Scotty) Whitelaw, commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference, was at Syracuse University yesterday attempting to talk the Orange out of joining six other E.C.A.C. colleges and Penn State to form the Notes new Eastern Independent Basketball League. Representatives of Penn State, Rutgers, Syracuse, Pittsburgh, Villanova, George Washington West Virginia and Duquesne will meet in Harrisburg, Pa., on Sunday to formalize the organization.

title: Holmes Memorabiliathe Flotsam of an Olympianon Display at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The display cases celebrating Mr. Justice Holmes are moored like fragile vessels in the ambient sea of the Harvard Law School library.

title: Sadat Refuses to Hold Talks With a Palestinian Delegation
description: CAIRO; Feb. 27 (Reuters) President Anwar elSadat today refused to invite a delegation from the Palestine Liberation Organization to visit Egypt for talks on EgyptianPalestinian relations.

title: FIRE SILENCES 170,000 TELEPHONES, DISRUPTING LIFE IN 300BLOCK AREA OF MANHATTAN BELOW 23D STREET
SAKS, BERGDORF AND BONWIT FINED
description: A Federal judge yesterday imposed the maximum antitrust fine of $50,000 each on Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman and Genesco, Inc., which operates the Bonwit Teller stores, after the concerns had pleaded no contest to charges of pricefixing on women's clothing.

title: Rock Island Board Sets Policy Parley To Bar Shutdown
description: Directors of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad will hold an emergency !meeting in Chicago this weekend to determine if the carrier can avoid shutting down next (month because of a severe liquidity problem and the Government's refusal earlier this week to provide a $30million loan.

title: P.L.O. Calls Off Visit
Phone Company Says Replacing of Center Could Take Year
Federal Reserve Reports a Decline In Money Supply
Praise and Questions
description: The Federal Government's sweeping plan to reorganize the bankrupt Northeast railroads drew favorable responses yesterday from two key transportation officials and a flood if questions on how various communities would be affected. Details on Page 45.

title: ROSALIE F. McGLEW
description: Rosalie F. McGlew, a retired vice president of Salomon Brothers, Wall Street investment banking house, died Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Brooklyn. She was 67 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: CORRECTION
description: There were typographical errors in a table of short. interest positions in the issue of Feb.22. The correct figures for the Anaconda Company were 3,083 for Feb. 14 and 700 for Jan. 15.

title: Brazil Air Crash Kills 15
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 27 (AP)A twinengine plane of VASP, a domestic airline, crashed and exploded in a wooded area of Sao Paulo shortly after takeoff today, killing 15 persons aboard, the police reported.

title: Landing System And Winds Cited In a Boston Crash
description: A rapid change in winds encountered in the final glide toward the runway and a belowstandard landing system at the airporta situation that still existswere cited yesterday by the official inquiry as likely causes of the 1973 crash of a Spanish jumbo jet in Boston.

title: Market Place
Francis Cameron Is Dead at 72; Headed St. Joe Minerals Corp.
description: Francis Cameron, retired chairman and president of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Lakeville, Conn. He was 72 years old.

title: Productivity Challenge
description: Despite the mounting desperation of the city's budget squeeze, any sense of urgency seems to have escaped the new Citywide Productivity Council. Formed last October by the Beame administration and the municipal Civil Service unions as a major device for raising productivity among New York's 350,000 public workers, the council'did not get around to holding its first formal meeting until a fortnight agoand nothing tangible has yet come of its activities.

title: Crabiel in a Move to Get Separate Trial on Issues
description: NEWARK, Feb. 27  Attorneys for J. Edward Crabiel, the New Jersey Secretary of State, moved today to have bidrigging charges against him tried without a jury and to hold an unusual separate trial on the overt acts alleged in the indictment before a full trial is held.

title: House Panel Approves New Curbs on Strip Mining
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Democratic majority on the House Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs gave nearly 3to1 approval today to a new stripmine regulatory measure that is slightly tougher than one vetoed by President Ford as too restrictive two months ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: There were typographical errors in a table of shortinterest positions in the issue of Feb. 22. The correct figures for the Anaconda Company were 3,083 for Feb. 14 and 700 for Jan. 15.

title: City Sues Karate Schools for Consumer Restitution
description: The City Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday that it had instituted a suit for more than $300,000 against Jerome Mackey judo and karate schools and its franchises and collection agency for consumer restitution and for fines for violation of city and state laws.

title: Schlumberger Splits Stock
description: Schlurnberger, Ltd., declared yesterday a 3for2 commonstock split, payable April 16 to shareholders of record March 21. The company, an oilfields services, electronics and meter concern, also declared a regular quarterly dividend of 22 cents a share, corresponding to 15 cents a share after the split.

title: Congressman Is Told of Beatings in Saigon Jail
description: SAIGON, Feb. 27Representtative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. said today that a young woman accused of being a Communist agent who had infiltrated the press had told him in a Saigon prison that she and other prisoners had been beaten very much.

title: G.O.P. Plans Sharp Cuts In the Governor's Budget
Yugoslav WriterSays at Trial He Expects Conviction Today
description: NOVI SAD. Yugoslavia. Feb. 27  The dissident Yugoslav writer Mihailo Mihailov said today in his final defense statement at his trial here that he expected to be convicted of a charge of having spread hostile propaganda.

title: Levi Details Wide Scope Of Hoover's Secret Files
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27J. Edgar Hoover, as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, kept secret files of derogatory information on Presidents, members of Congress, Federal officials and those who simply tried to oppose him, Attorney General Edward H. Levi testified today.

title: Tharp Dance Hit Gets Even Better
Prices Close Mixed in Credit Markets
description: Prices closed mixed yesterday in the credit markets. New offerings continued to occupy participants in the corporate and taxexempt sectors, where business was being done at what appeared to be some newly established interestrate levels. In the tax  exempt market, for example, the closely followed weekly Bond Buyer index of the yields or rates of 20 longterm municipal obligations yesterday reached the level of 6.55. A week ago the index stood at 6.40, indicating a rise during the week of 15 basis points. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.

title: A New Hearing Ordered In Police Killing of Boy
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday that he would convene a hearing to consider new evidence in the case of Officer Thomas J. Shea, who was dismissed last August for improper use of his weapon in the fatal shooting of a 10 yearold boy.

title: Advertising
description: You say you have a marketing problem that your agency doesn't seem to be able to solve, but that you don't want to look for another agency.

title: Stanton, With 64, Leads by 3 Strokes
Senate Expected to Back Arms for Turks
description: WASHLNGTON, Feb. 27The Ford Amminstration, after behindthescenes soundings, believes it has enough support in the Senate to overturn the mili taryaid embargo against Turkey, but is uncertain about the situation in the House.

title: Mrs. Hills Nomination Wins Approval of Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) The Senate Banking Committee approved today the nomina tion of Carla Anderson Hills as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

title: 5Day Battle Reported for a Key Eritrean Town
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 27Some of the heaviest fighting in Ethiopia's 27dayold civil war has reportedly raged for five days over control of the Eritrean town of Keren near the border with the Sudan.

title: Frank Robinson's Day in History
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 27History isn't always accompanied by a blare of trumpets. Sometimes it happens quietly and unobtrusively, as it did today when Frank Robinson supervised his first workout as major league baseball's first black manager. He would address 27 players, mostly pitchers and catchers, at 9:30 this morning, but now, half an hour earlier, he was sitting in his whitewalled office off the locker room at Hi Corbett Field where the Cleveland Indians train. He was wearing his grayish blue doubleknit uniform with red, white and blue trim. On his desk was a pocket watch he would use to time the segments of the workout. At breakfast with his coaches in the Sheraton Pueblo Inn, he had gone over the workout schedule.

title: Levi Details Wide Scope Of Hoover's Secret Files
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27J. Edgar Hoover, as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, kept secret files derogatory information on Presidents, members of Congress. Federal officials and those who simply tried to oppose him, Attorney General Edward H. Levi testified today.

title: Concert: La Favorita
description: It was billed as a concert performance of Donizetti's La Favorita, but the Opera Orchestra of New York event at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night might also have been heralded as a singing competition.

title: Boycott Called Legitimate
description: CAIRO, Feb. 27The director of the Arab League's boycott office, Mohammed Mahgoub, today defended the organization's sanctions against companies that deal with Israel as a legitimate means of legitimate selfdefense.

title: Help for the Elderly Who Can't Get Out
